reviews.review: Great Neighborhood. This is a quieter part of Paris, full of great boutiques, art galleries & museums. Nice restaurants & bistros

Another must! Excellent discovery!. As I mentioned in another review, this is not the first time I went to Paris BUT it is the first time I walked around Marais. Its been absolutely a fantastic and super positive surprise. I would definitely go back! There are plenty of restaurants and cafes..plenty of arty shops, local people walking around... lovely Parisian atmosphere! I consider this place a must.
Best area on Sundays. Sundays when everything is closed in Paris, the Marais is lively with many shops open. Our favourite stop: felafel Rue des Rosiers.

The Place to go on Sunday. Many restaurants, shops and attraction are closed on Sunday, so the Marais, as the Jewish quarter, is the place to go then. The Jewish Museum is fascinating, and the many antique shops and cafes make wandering around great fun.

Promenade . It's laid back neighbourhood with a lot of small shops, bars and restaurants. Every day is interesting in Le Marais. Like most of the city, I find that most of the deals in local shops are not good deals €€€€ wise. However, you might be able to find something exclusive and/or unique for your money. Perfect day for visiting: Any weekend with good weather.

My favorite area. I love the marais - just came back from a walk around the old part of the city. I love the streets, shops, eateries and the human buzz. Picasso Museum is there and many other historical monuments.

Be sure and have a great guide.. The history of this area is incredible. There are lots of museums and cafes and the people were hospitable. We even had an opera performer singing on the corner while we ate at the cafe.

A leisurely stroll through historic Paris - Le Marais. There are so many interesting things to see and do here. Start the afternoon with a falafel sandwich and Just spend time wandering through interesting streets and beautiful architecture. Stop in at the Picasso Museum and end at the Place du Vosges

Great neighborhood for travelers. I stayed in Le Marais for six weeks over the summer during a summer research trip. This is an area of town with diverse attractions for all kinds of travelers and toursists. Here, you will find: great LGBTQ nightlife for all genders; loads of interesting boutiques full of different styles, across a whole gamut of prices from clothing-by-the-kilo vintage to department store name brands to famous luxury and designer brand; varied and good quality dining; museums for the whole family to enjoy, such as the Musée Picasso and Victor Hugo's house; a vibrant open-air market, Marché des Enfants Rouges; historic buildings; and numerous cafes. If you stay here, you are also only about 20-30 minutes on foot and even less time via metro from many other destinations in central Paris, including the Louvre and the Centre Pompidou, as well as Châtelet and Les Halles, where there is a lot more shopping and dining to be found.

Old part of Paris. This is a beautiful part of Paris and not to be missed. Walk the small streets visit Place des Voges, visit the different museums and do not miss the renewed Picasso museum. Stop at coffee houses and enjoy the special atmosphere. Take a walking tour and learn the secrets of this old part of Paris. Yona. S.
Superb. Took walk around Marais on our way from Notre Dame towards Republique. Nice boutiques and restaurants everywhere.
Lovely neighborhood. We enjoyed our walk through this lovely neighborhood. It is very busy and there are a lot of retail stores.

My Favorite Area to Walk Around. Great area of Paris to walk around! Very interesting and historic. Visit the Picasso Museum and eat at L'as du Falafel. Visit small judaica shops and Jewish bakeries. Good shopping and small parks. Loved it!
Paris with Kim!!. Fantastic area to stay and shop and eat and play!! This is the area we always stay. So many restaurants and tiny bars to get lost in!!

Wonderful Vacation. My wife, daughter and I stayed in an apartment in Le Marais for 4 days in September 2016. The Marais is a fantastic area for shopping, eating and people watching. There are so many things to do and see and the area is conveniently located to the Metro.

Good vibes. Le Marais is not the chic-est area of Paris, but it is safe, and we love its vibes. It has a large number of restaurants and bars, and an ethnically diverse community. The transport connections by metro, and bus are good, and it is a 20-minute level-ground walk to the River Seine.

Good area to stay when in Paris. I've stayed in apartments in the Marais on three separate visits to Paris. It is very central to many of the main sights of the city, has lots of good shops and facilities, as well as excellent access to many metro stations.

Mix of cool hipsters and bears . Loved this area, busy but not too busy lots of Japanese restaurants and mix of Italian and French. Loved the vibe around the North of the Marais. Off Rue Sebastopol is a good area.

The best neighbourhood in Paris!. We love everything about Le Marais! The shopping, the food, the atmosphere! Would not stay anywhere else when visiting Paris! Everything else in the city is easily accessible via public transport or walking.

My favourite spot in Paris. Back again in Paris, this time spending a month and staying in the Marais. Love wanderingaround the streets of this area. Great shops, better restaurants, architecture, local culture, be it Jewish or GL, always something happening. The area is flat so very easy walking, although the pavements are very narrow. Museum Carnavalet is worth a visit with it's interesting gardens and don't forget Les Voges .

Delightful area. Lots of shops, restaurants and cafes, charming courtyards, the Cloitre des Billettes, the Jewish museum, what's not to like? The Marais attracts tourists, but lots of locals are also out on the street. Spend some time here: you'll enjoy it.

Visit every time in Paris - love it that much!. What is not to like in the Maria's?
Restaurants are friendly, even w/out reservation...almost unheard of in Paris!
Great art galleries, shopping with more reasonable pricing, which is refreshing!

A bustling neighborhood with many restaurants and shops. Le Marais is a bustling neighborhood. The area is filled with tourist, but locals visit as well. There are many restaurants in the area. We tend to avoid this neighborhood because so many of the restaurants cater to tourist. Parts of the neighborhood are very beautiful, though.

Great area. We stay in an apartment in Le Marais. Plan on going to the Bastille Market. If you go on a Sunday the streets are crowded and the bistros are full but that is the fun of being in Le Marais.

Excellent area for a leisurely walk. The Marais district has some lovely streets,quirky shops, isnt always crowded, some hidden gardens and the Place de Vosges is very pretty square. A pleasant interlude in Paris.

This is perfect for Sunday. When everything else is closed in Paris make this your destination. All the shops are open as well as the restaurants. Plan it for s great day of walking and discovery. You won't be disappointed and do start in Place des Vosges
Food & Shopping Mecca. Lots of beautiful buildings and small streets lined with delicious shops and cafes. Take a Paris by Mouth tour through the Marais-- book before you go.
Beautiful Area. So close to so many sights, so many laneways with quirky shops and markets, another great area to people watch from sidewalk cafes and restaurants.

Felt like the West Village in NYC. Great area of Paris! Amazing shopping with tons of very local stores at all sorts of price points. Same with the restaurants. If you want to shop or eat something and have a true Parisian experience, than spend some time in Le Marais- we really enjoyed our visit!
Great Gem. ❤️❤️❤️ Such a good neighborhhod with hidden gems and fun things to do. There is the Jewish neighborhood, also a bunch of great restaurants, ❤️❤️❤️

Best arrondissement in Paris!. Out of all the arrondissements we visited, this is by far my favorite. Although the Marais has become very chic over the last 20 years, it still maintains its authentic Parisian charm. The food in the Marais is some of the best in Paris. There is nothing more lovely than picnicking on the lawn of the Place de Vosges, during the day or even in the evening. The neighborhood feels very safe and you often see school children walking to school or playing in the park.

Everything you need. Some very good restaurants, trendy shops and galleries, design studios, local artists, bars. Don't miss Favourite opposite Saint Paul's for cocktails, breakfast, lunch, dinner. Affordable good tucker and even better service.

Great Walking Area. After visiting Notre Dame, we crossed the river and visited Le Marais. First stop was the Holocaust Memorial which details the history of European Jewry through and past World War II. Most of the exhibits have English translations, however, some of the holocaust survivor video testimonies are not translated. We then walked through the neighborhood and enjoyed the mix of people from orthodox Jews to hipsters who make this a lively yet historic area.
Charming old quarter. In a city filled with charm, Le Marais is a bit unique. Orthodox Jews, gays, shoppers, tourists and diners mix well (not necessarily a natural blend). My favorite neighborhood.

Nice area but not that much more. Try the falafel!. It's nice to stroll around here for a couple of hours, having a coffee or a glass of whine while looking at people. If you are into new designers there are a lot of shops, but the prices are rather high. There are a few falafel places that are rather famous, if you are prepared to queue for a falafel for about 20 mins you can get a nice meal for 7€ to bring to a nearby park to eat.

The way Paris should be: a big neighborhood.. The Marais is every guidebook’s favorite Paris neighborhood. It’s a quarter of narrow streets that lacks the authenticity of the rest  of greater Paris. When Paris was only a small town located on an island, the  area currently known as Le Marais was a marsh. Only in the 10th century did it get drained. We spent half a day exploring the area. The Place des Voyages is in the heart of the area. It’s a superb square. Included in theLMarais is the Paris Jewish sector. Good walking area.

One of the best areas to spend an afternoon walk.. The Marais is one of my favorite areas for walking when the weather is nice. Animated and filled with places to sit and relax, whether by a fountain or at a café. Just a shame they stuck the Pompidou Center nearby. After 39 years it is still a monstrosity.

Every street reveals something different.. Interesting place to stay. The small lane ways constantly revel something different. Many new concepts in clothing. Excellent range of men's wear shops. Many craftsmen making very individual pieces.

the true pulsating heart of Paris. A perfect location for a romantic escape. Bohemian atmosphere, tens of art galleries, finest shops and boutiques and good dining. The old jewish area is just lovely. Just to walk until you get lost.

Just not my cup of tea. We have strolled through The Marais several times and other than Place de Vosges and The Carnavalet Museum I just don't see the draw. Maybe for college age types it works...lots of junky looking eateries and shops. Yes, it's hip & trendy, I guess I'm not.

Oh - the history.... What a fantastic place to stay and explore Paris. The little side streets have wonderful shops and the cafes are plentiful and a great place to sit and watch the day go by!
There is history all around and our apartment had all the latest mod cons even though the bulging was at least a couple of hundred years old.
A Great Area to Stroll. When I as there it was not too crowded. Loved the cool tree-lined streets, the area around the Bastille and Rue de Rosiers. Easy to get to and from.

Historic and quirky. This is a lovely historic area to wander in. Nothing opens until 11:00, but shops stay open later. The City of Paris Carnavalet free museum is here and it's interesting. Worth a visit. Cute shops that are unique reside alongside global giants like Uniqlo. But it's not obtrusive . You can wander into the Marais from the Seine at the Hotel de Ville. This area is all about wandering, so succumb to that.

good shopping area. My sister and I liked this area for upscale, unique shops. There are plenty of cafes and restaurants to reresh in between all the shopping. Parisians feel this is a premier shopping area for boutique stores.

One of best neighborhoods to walk around in. . This area is great for walking around and has probably the best feel for an active living area. Lots of great restaurants and shops. Place des Vosges is a beautiful square park and is on fat feast of area and is good place to start your visit and then walk back towards Louvre area.
Love this neighbourhood!. Walking in this neighbourhood is my favourite thing-to-do in Paris! One of the oldest neighbourhood with lovely art and coffee shops and museums!
Chić & trendy!. Marais is the place to be and be seen in Paris. Very centrally located, clean, excellent cafes, luxury and vintage shopps, Le Marais is the Mecca for luxury travellers.
Fun. Great walking neighbourhood. Good shops, relaxed. But keep your money/wallet/ bags closed and close. It's close enough to Notre Dame to have lots of pick pockets.

Wow what a cute, lively...not noisy, stunning family suburb. My husband and I had the pleasure of staying in a little french apartment on the 4th floor, off Rue Du Temple but found it Awesome as it was very close to the Metro/ Bus & subway. We did take an Uber taxi from the airport as we did not know where to go at first but then we used the metro & subway for traveling almost every day & found it very easy. Lots of walking but a true treat in the summer. Discovered museums and quaint shops in the area as we went on tourist jaunts & the people are quite friendly - we don't know a word of french, so it was refreshing to see the locals try to help in broken english,..we are from Cape Town but have traveled and lived in Ireland, on the Isle of Wight UK & in Geneve Switzerland. So happy to have spent time in Paris to add to our memories. Will definitely return when our boys are older to stand the walking ;)

I like to come here for falafel and cake . A little bit like an upmarket and slightly quieter version of the Latin quarter, the Marais has synagogues, churches, houses and art to blow your mind. More importantly the street food is really delicious
Very nice area. nice area with many places to visit. There are lots of nice shops and many restaurants. The area has a few metro stops.

Local culture at its best.... If you want local culture and a little bit of grit, Marais is the neighborhood for you. There aren't many hotels, but you may be able to book through a small apartment. Just remember that apartments in Paris typically do not have central air and are small by American standards.

Close to tourist attractions but unique small maze of streets. Stayed here when found reasonably priced typically French hotel. Lovely to wonder lots of people watching and so much eating n drinking choice

Quaint and Charming. Le Marais is not as touristy as most other famous areas. The more intimate side of Paris is revealed. Families with children out and about amidst amazing art galleries and superb restaurants. It's a very special place!

Amazing suburb . Loads of food, loads of culture, if you are able to stay in or nearby this area, do it! Otherwise, make sure you come and explore the streets at least once. Rue de Rosier would be the best place to start

Paris at its most charming. We spent a good four hours strolling through the Marais district on a fine Sunday morning. Look out for the scenic inside squares and small alleyways and the lovely communal gardens - and this is where you also find so many charming restaurants and boutiques round ever corner. Our impression was that you get much closer to a "true" impression of Paris life there than at the major sights with thousands of visitors elbowing their way past each other.

Wonderful for a wander. Just a short walk from the Centre Pompidou, Le Marais is like a step back in time, with wonderful boutique, chic bars and cute cafes. Allow time just to wander & go hungry so that you can enjoy the cafes.
The place to visit for original shops in Paris. This area near to Place des Voghes is a must for one off stores, interesting places to pop in and lovely cafe's to enjoy.
A delightful but often overlooked quarter. We spent the better part of a day wandering the streets of the Marais, enjoying especially the Picasso museum. More down to earth than most areas of Paris.
Lively Spot. A great area for strolling, eating and drinking. Narrow streets, lively cafes and restaurants, bakeries, museums and parks. Great street life.
Just walk and enjoy. As the title says. Take time to walk along the many streets and enjoy all the little shops, small bars and restaurants.
fun area, good views. Pretty far away from the city center but you can take the hoho bus and the walk is not too bad. Many restaurants and things to see, well worth the visit.
Iconic Pais. Perfect spot for shopping, museums (musee de Picasso is a must see) people watching and getting lost wandering though the ancient streets

Awesome to shop and stroll!!. Love the museums, boutiques and cafes that line the narrow streets in the Marais! Sundays are great because so much of Paris is closed, yet the Marais is largely open. This area is a must do if you want a real taste of Paris, and want to get some shopping done too in a more "village" like area than the large avenues....
Busy place. Fun place to spend on a Sunday because the great boutiques are open too. Shops aren't open everywhere else.

J'aime Flane le Marais. The mediaeval marais is one of my favourite places in Paris. It is where I try and rent an apartment. It has everything. Amazing streetscapes, wonderful buildings and views at every turn. Parisians live here so you can buy groceries or eat at a cafe like a local. It is full of museums so you can spend days just within this arrondissement.It has excellent transport links and you can get anywhere fast.Then it is close to the Seine, where one is overcome to take their partner in their arms and kiss them romantically.

My favorite Arrodissement. Lots to see and do in the 3e. Pretty expensive area, to live, eat, drink, etc. since it's still a touristy area, but lots of hidden gems to be discovered and the vibe on the streets is chill compared to many other areas in Paris. Im American, from Los Angeles, I've lived in Paris for a few years, and I would have to say it is a safe, cool, and definitely must see place in Paris. Really so much to say as far as what to see and do, but the whole arrondissement is totally walkable so I'll leave it for you to discover!*Gay Tip: Le Marais is what West Hollywood is to Los Angeles. Nightlife is awesome, and the locals know they live in the gay friendly arrondissement of Paris, so this is the place to be and all that jazz *
Great area. Beautiful area to wander and relax while in Paris, lots of boutique shops and bars to save your feet, it's choices are endless

Superbe!. This is THE place to stay/visit when in Paris. So much to see and enjoy - the old historic narrow lanes, squares, food shops, galleries and designer shops. Le Marais has it all. Everything buzzes on a Sunday when some of the streets become vehicle-free and musicians and entertainers abound. We always felt safe here, given the recent terrorist attacks.
nice stroll. I was staying in a flat in le Marais, I cycled around and I found lovely shops, cafe' ... it is a very trendy area!

Neat part of town. Much of Paris is closed on Sunday, so since the Marais was traditionally the Jewish quarter it is mostly open on Sunday. This is when we went. Very vibrant part of town. Not touristy, just a neat Paris neighborhood. A very desirable part of town.
Check it out on a Sunday. Great place to get some amazing fallafel (try L'As du Fallafel)l and snag a seat at a cafe and people watch on a Sunday.

A Great place to wander.. Le Marais is the heart of Medieval Paris, it is worth visiting just to wander andsee the ancient architecture. While wandering you can visit a free museum Musee Carnavalet (Rue de Sévigné). A stones throw away on rue de Rosiers you will find the best falafels in Paris, (L'As du Falafel) get there early it is always busy. I recommend you grab it and go eat it in a park. After you can get a dessert on Rue Pavée at L'éclaire du Génie. Then head up to Rue du Franc Bourgeois for some boutique shopping. Then over to either Place des Voges (east) or to Centre Georges Pompidou (west). You could spend an afternoon wandering and being 'Parisien'!

Fashion and hip distric. Marais was a former working class area which grew into a hip neighborhood with plenty of cafes, restaurants and parks. Here you can find some of the best Parisian art galleries as well as designer shops. In between shopping and relaxing, be sure to stop in Rue des Rosiers to try best falafel in the city

Best neighborhood for everything.. Stayed in Le Marais and couldn't have been happier with our choice. Great neighborhood combining old cobblestone streets with modern thoroughfares and shopping. Plenty of good restaurants and stores. Close to Notre Dame. Bastille Market is on Thursday and Sunday mornings. Never a shortage of anything you would need or want as a tourist.

Great place to stay. Stayed here with my daughter on a sightseeing trip. The area always felt safe with plenty going on. Plenty metro stops and sightseeing bus tour stops. Would stay in this area again on return to paris.

Gentrified. There is still layers of history and historic streets and sites, however, to be quite honest, I used to like this area way more back in the 1990s and even still in 2001, when it was not as badly gentrified as it is now. Too many shops and cafés, too crowded... I quess it can't be helped.

Birthday celebration . This is a lovely area to stay in. Lots of nice restaurants, bars and a variety of boutique shops and named brand shops. It is a friendly and fairly safe area and everything is walkable. I highly recommend this part of Paris, it is one of my favourites.

Shop til you drop!. Dropped a few coins on jewelry but also enjoyed visiting many galleries in Place de Vosges. Also stopped at 2 cafes -- one to eat and another just for a beer. Visit la place de Vosges but also just get lost in the streets/shops in the area.
Fun Neighborhood . We stayed here during our Paris trip and loved the vibe. There are bars, coffee shops, bakeries and interesting streets all over. You will live it.
Le Marais. A neighborhood steeped in history..and unrebuilt by Hausmann, It is a mixture of old churches..narrrow streets..funky clothing retailers and shadows of the former Jewish community.
Great area!. The area has it all! Chinatown is on the side, many, many bars, restos and boutique stores. Cafes, and happy people everywhere.
Next time im staying here. Ive stayed in the 1st and 2nd arr. But la Marais is by far the coolest neighborhood in Paris. Very design and artsy.

Great place for a Parisian vibe. Lots of boulangeries and patisseries, great cafes, lively bars, and plenty of boutique shopping. You won't find souvenir shops here. I booked a hotel in this location and loved it. If you speak a little french, and you don't need to rely 100% on your credit card (a few places don't take them), this is definitely a great location. It's an easy walk to the Metro or to the 69 bus (great for sightseeing and getting to the Louvre and the Eiffel Tower). If you can't be bothered with the French language or messing with euros, then the more touristy Latin Quarter is probably a more comfortable option. Me, I'd stay here again in a heartbeat.
Crowded streets. . Very narrow crowded streets. A lot of attractions here but also a lot of undesirable behaviour. Didn't really feel safe here.

Parisian Paradise on Saturday . Such a wonderful wonderful neighborhood. Stayed in between the Oberkampf and Republique stations which is a skip from the true edge of Le Marais and it's a wonderful spot for a hotel (quite, great transportation, and accessible to food easily). Le Marais has brilliant galleries, museums, food (omg the food and gelato and salted crepes (chez imogene)). I suggest the main rue du Rivoli for the known stores and weave ridiculously up to rue du temple and from St. Paul's metro station to the Hotel Du Ville for vintage stores, high end boutiques, cuties thoughtfully priced boutiques and pop up art galleries. This country truly embraces there artist.

Great walking, food, Parian culture. We staying here on our first trip to Paris and are very glad we did. It's extremely convenient to major sights and has much to offer in it's on right. We got a map of the area from a shop and did a walking tour of the sites. And, there are my great places to eat.
Our favorite.. We have stayed in the Marias several times. It is safe and wonderful. We stayed close to the St. Paul metro this time. The restaurants in the area are great.
Great place to walk!. Great place to walk around! Interesting shops with unique items as well as high end stores like Chanel. Many bakeries and cafes too! Also open on Sunday.

One of the most unique neighborhoods in Paris.. We has such a great time in Le Marais! There is so much to see and do. This chic neighborhood offers great shopping, the best falafel I've ever had, and museums (the Picasso Museum was our favorite!).

What a cool neighborhood . Walking in this area was a highlight of our trip in Paris. The streets, stores and hidden gardens are beautiful, hip and full of incredible history. Our guide Justine walked us around here and my wife and I wound up staying the nite strolling the streets on a romantic Parisian date. This is the cool hip neighborhood like the village or soho in NYC

Great shops and restaurants. Although le Marais is enjoying great popularity these days it is still a worthwhile visit. The shops and restaurants are a bit pricey these days, but there are still bargains to be had if you look for them. Fun to walk the streets and check out all the trends both in the stores and on the street.
Beautiful laneways of Marais. Wander the laneways & make sure you sit and contemplate Paris at Place des Vosges. Eat at local Cafes & stick to the lanes rather than main streets. Full of character

Food and shopping in a intimate paris neighbourhood. Rue rambuteau(east of the centre Pompidou) is a really long street covered with bakeries, butchers, vegetable shop and restaurants. Perfect street for any food lover as you can try loads of patisseries as they are in close proximity. Around the corner you'll find all sorts of boutiques and chain stores but on old narrow streets, quite opposite of the commercial giant stores in the champs Elysee. You eat your pastries in place des vosages.
Le Marais. I lived in Le Marais for 2 years. I love this area.Bars, shops, 2nd hand stores, you can find it all in Le MaraisGreat area. I love it.
Another oh so Parisian place to wander. Lovely streets to wander down again, look in the shops, have something to eat in one of the many lovely little cafes, which aren't cheap by the way!!
Worth a visit. Food is good, cafes are great...just wander and take it all in. If having dinner there, make reservations!
Great area. Le Marais is for me the best Paris area. Small streets, excellent shopping and great bars and restaurants.

Desrves the #1 place. This district definetely deserves to be in the first place in the Paris attraction list. This is place where you can see the locals. There is a small park in the middle of it and people just lay on the grass and enjoy the day when it is good weather. There are lots of art galeries which you can take look at eventhough you're not an expert of art like me. The galeries were really good. There are really good boutique shopping places on the narrow streets. Get off at Saint Paul stop on Metro 1.

A gorgeous part of Paris. We chose to stay in Le Marais for our first trip to Paris and I'm so glad we did! The area is just beautiful. Close to all the tourist sites, full of wonderful cafes, shops and restaurants, it is a great place to stay. Loved it!
Lively neighborhood. The area is filled with nice bistros and brasseries, as well as, great small boutique for unique shopping.

Great for a sunny day. Enjoyed an afternoon and early evening strolling the area with my daughter and infant grandson. It was hot, so we had drinks at several small restaurants, stopped at a park to rest for a short while, and did some shopping. Lovely old buildings, small parks, boutiques of all kinds.
Great bustling neighborhood. Worth walking around the Marias one of the afternoons you're in Paris. A ton of restaurants, shops, malls, and museums. Lots to do.

5 day visit . I found this section of town to be very artistic. Lots of shops, lots of restaurants, but a bit crowded. Good access with buses and metro everywhere. Down side is crowded sidewalk seats and generally it is quite expensive.

Lovely part of Paris . We stayed in a studio apartment in Le Marais which was the perfect place to go out and explore from. With the metro you can get to all the main attractions easily and can walk to ones like Notre-Dame in a few minutes

Beautiful area. A beautiful area of Paris with shops & cafes, lovely to stroll about even if U do not buy anything, good for Souvenir hunting.
Well worth a visit.

Get the feeling of the city of fashion. The best of Paris, wonderful stores and cafes, restaurants as well. If nothing, great for window shopping, the designs are beautiful. The buildings around are well thought out in a cosy neighbourhood.

A favourite part of Paris. When we find Paris busy and tire of crowds we always head to the Marais. It is filled by splendid galleries and museums, special historic houses, enchanting streets and plenty of shops and cafes.
Wonderful shopping. My favorite aspect of this quarter is the shopping, and I go back during every visit to Paris now. Don't miss jewelry stores such as Cécile Jeanne!

Do NOT avoid this area... it is WONDERFUL. We have had an apartment there for the past several years until we sold it recently, but miss it already. This part of Paris stays opens late. Les Philosophes is THE place to go for a mostly organic, fresh cooked late-night meal, and right across the way, we encourage you to have drinks with the lovely, smart and charming Cendrillon (translated: Cinderella... yes, you read that correctly) at Hortense Bar Litteraire, where you can read Proust while imbibing one of her own cocktails.

A great, central place to stay in Paris. Rented an apartment from 'At Home hotel - Apartments Paris Center' - ours was on Rue Temple just steps away from the Temple Metro station. Nothing is too far from this area - we did take a subway to Montmartre but otherwise this is very much the heart of Paris.Cafes abound as do pastry shops and you're really less than 15 minutes walk from the Seine (Hôtel de Ville) - I can't imagine staying in another part unless it were to be the Latin quarter (which would not be as central, but equally enjoyable for eating options).

Fantastic Area of Paris. We actually stayed in this area and loved every minute. It has so much character and everything is at your fingertips. There is an array of eating places from cafes, restaurants, boulangeries, boucheries to take aways like falafels, chocolatiers and other interesting cuisines. The shopping is superb too with wonderful boutiques, jewellery shops, kitchen stores etc. etc. The area is steeped in history and some amazing buildings and museums. We were around the corner from Musee Carnavalet and Musee Picasso to name a couple. The controversial Centre Pompidou is also located nearby. The Marais has a throbbing beat to its pulse which seems to come alive from around lunchtime on. It is a great location to just amble through the little cobbled streets and take in the ambience of it all.
Relax and have a falafel . I realy love the Marais at night. Strol around the neighborhood have a falafel at l'as du fallafel, eat great pastry and buy some second hand clothing. Just enjoy!

Still authentic, in spite of tourists and gentrification. Le Marais has been a very popular neighborhood for tourists for quite a while, and after many transformations in the last 20-30 years, it is increasingly gentrifying. And yet, it is still a charming "quartier", full of quaint shops, cafés and restaurants, the "re-born" Rue des Rosiers with various excellent falafel shops, charming little streets, almost no car traffic, and a polyglot mélange of Jewish tradition and the queer scene. A very relaxing area of an otherwise buzzing city. And very much off the big bus tour group paths of the French capital. Recommended for individualists and leisure lovers.

Probably the best location to stay in Paris. The Marais district has it all and is the best place to stay when visiting Paris. All the attractions are within walking distance and buses run along rue de Rivoli to the Eiffel Tower (€2) There are plenty of little streets to wander among and in the evening lots of really good restaurants where you can eat relatively cheaply. Don't order water with your meal or you'll get a bottle of the most expensive water the rest carries. Instead order "un carafe d'eau",which is just tap water but excellent. Also there are hundreds of public water fountains in Paris some even dispense ice cold sparkling water.

My favourite part of Paris.. Although this part of paris is infamous for being the ¨gay¨ part, there is so much more to it. The best shopping and restaurants in Paris are found here. There are also several museums my favorite being the Centre Pompidou. It also has some great street art and the best shops in paris. If you have time make sure you have a glass of wine in the BHV terrace with a beautiful Parisian view.

Paris like no place else!!!. If you like mazes and you love beauty and architecture you should come walkand not just visit Le Marais. Regardless of what anyone thinks, this is Paris at its best. You walk and your eyes and senses would enjoy what you see. You enjoy the house gardens and the beauty of the flowers dangling from the windows. Come and enjoy a hidden area in Paris. You will love it

Charming. If you're looking for independent and stylish shopping, good restaurants, bars, and cafes, and just in the mood for people watching, then this is the perfect area to visit. As someone mentioned in a review, it's also fully functioning on a Sunday which is fairly rare in most of France.

great place to stay. My friend and I really lucked out when we chose to stay in this part of town. It is charming and historical. It is, in fact, the old Jewish section of town, and it features a lovely square surrounded by restaurants, lots of boutiques and quaint shops, easy walking, easy access to the subway, close to so many of the major attractions. Mostly, staying at a small hotel in the area, L'hotel Jeanne D'Arc, we crossed the street to eat dinner at least four times, and we walked to other fabulous small restaurants. Apparently, this is a "happening" part of town right now.

Very nice for a walk!. The best of Le Marais is that its open on Sundays while every other part of Paris is closed. You can still have lunch in very nice restaurantes and the shops are open.Very trendy and chic.Love it.

Friendly, interesting and full of surprises. We stayed in this area and really enjoyed it- there were lots of delicious places to eat and drink, boulangeries, macaroon shops, cute little stationers, historical buildings, museums and courtyards and suchlike at every turn. Busy, bright and interesting area.

Historical Section of Paris. Led by a guide, we walked through Le Marais and enjoyed learning about the various buildings. We were impressed by a memorial to the Jews who died during World War II and saw a school that had been for Jewish students.

Beautiful old Paris. You can walk around it forever, I myself would never leave. Food, bars, ice cream, shops are everywhere. Gay quarter and you can feel the vibe.
Mije hostels are a great affordable place to stay in the heart of Le Marais, just saying 😊

Wonderful fun neighborhood to visit, shop and eat.. We loved the Hotel Caron de Beaumarchais and the great restaurants and shops within easy walking distance. The hotel is small, charming with very friendly staff. We ate crepes and other great food. The many shops are unique.

Too cute!. The delightful old quarter of the city, which was, and very much still is, the Jewish quarter, and yet it also has an interesting lgbt history! I've been here six months and still can't find my way around this maze, but that's okay, because why would you want to leave!?

So Happy We Stayed In This Neighborhood!. This was our first stay in the Marais neighborhood and we were really happy with our choice. There were so many good restaurants from which to choose. Shops, bakeries, grocery stores.....everything you needed to experience the city as a local were close at hand. We stayed in an apartment rented through "Our Home In Paris", and it was just beautiful. Would really recommend both the area and the rental. The beautiful Places des Vosges is only 2 blocks away.

My favorite part of Paris!. The Marais is historic, quiet, safe and a good location to explore the city. Stayed at an apartment in a 14th century building and walked to most of the areas we explored in the city. The Marais is full of casual laid back cafes and interesting shops. I think the Marais has a secret sort of enchanting vibe,
Full of character. Cool shops and nice cafes. Expensive but very nice area for browsing and eating. My teenage son went to his favorite store- Supreme. Not all stores open but lots of cafes.
Nice. Leave the crowd and walk thru this wonderful neigborhood when you'll see the hipster side of paris, you can eat, shop and take coffee.
lovely area. lovely little artsy neighbourhood, easily accessible to everywhere and filled with locals as well as tourists for that authentic vibe

A good neighborhood for strolling, shopping, and people watching. This was one of my favorite Paris neighborhoods to stroll around -- I'm struggling with the changes since my last visit in 2001. Three of my favorite shops are gone -- Jo Goldenberg's, a perfumery, and a Little Prince shop. The area is still filled with interesting places to shop and small eateries. Stop in to St. Paul's and leave a small donation. The Place des Vosges is a beautiful park; its Victor Hugo museum is worth a visit.It's served by a central metro line and a map specific to the area can be picked up at the tourist office. The streets can easily turn you around.
One of the best areas of Paris. Le Marais is one of the best areas to shop and walk around. Rue des Rosiers is great for shops, falafel stands, and people watching. Be sure to visit Place des Vosges.

Place des Voges - Pity its become so touristy but still worth the effort. Its changed dramatically over the years to being very much a tourist trap, Expensive food and not the genuine and important experience I always remembered from years ago .Best Felafel at Las du Felafel - very reasonableSome of the bars expensive and tourist trapsWorth a visit but not the "real ting" any longer.

Worth a stroll around. and joining the `bun fight' for a table at l'As de Fallafel. What was the old jewish Quarter has now bwcome a trendy fashionista, gay area, but it is worth a stroll round, especially in fine weater with a paue to relax in then Place des Vosges. Walk along rue Rosier ( the `fairly' main street & you will note a lively noisy crowd midway along. They are jostli9ng to eat at l'As de Fallafel, a middle eastern fallafel/ schwarma joint with enormous character. It is actually kosher/supervised, so is closed on saturdays & Jewish Holydays, but produces reasonably priced, enormous portions of filling lunches. Great experience to add to one's itinerary
Beautiful Neighborhood . We stayed a week here in his neighborhood. It's a very nice and quaint neighborhood with a lot of shops and eateries. Palace de Voges is here which is very beautiful to see.
A very nice part of Paris. If you visit Paris you must see the arrondisement 3 and 4 Le Marais. The jewis quarter and a lot to see. Picasso museum etc et.

Don't forget this lovely little neighborhood...Go Hungry!. Busy little streets and lovely places to eat. I highly recommend going hungry and walking around so you can eat again. There is a great little Jewish 'bakery' Murciano...unassuming but some of the best pastries. Do not miss.

Gay district. Not overtly gay, but if you're looking for gay or gay friendly bars clubs restaurants then this is the place to be Situated north of rue rivoli sandwiched between Bastille and Pompidou centre
Very clean a d welcoming neighborhood.. People are really welcoming and friendly. The neighborhood is really clean and well maitained. Feel secure and would go again with my little baby girl.
Wonderful place. One of the best places in Paris with small and cute restaurants, beautiful by lanes. Nice to walk around and experience the local atmosphere.

Real Paris. A very nice and romantic place, one of the place not touch by the restructuration of Hausmann. lot of trendy shops, Picasso's museum ( hotel sallé) , LGBO place but not only. very nice and authentic houses, take time to visit " la place des vosges"

A Sunday Must!. This area is so great, with so many shops and the best falafel place there, too! This was my go-to place on a Sunday, since everything was open and it was so lively. Take the time to visit, shop, and get lost in the beautiful streets!
My favourite place in Paris. Truly my favourite place in Paris. Perfect to stroll around, pop into cute ice cream shops and "hipster" coffee shops.. Lots of trendy retail shops too!

Strolling . Nice place to stroll around , lots of shops, restaurants. I love the small streets and hidden sights. Easy to reach and a great place to start from. Walking is still the best way to discover a city and its districts.
Being August - far less crowded which is a bonus for me.

Beautiful Paris. lovely surrounding, the lovely part of Paris I think.From Place de Vosges with that le carre houses&park to Pompidou Centre you”ll find medieval houses and palaces,fine IXI and XX century buildings, museums, shops, coffee”s and restaurants.You will find everything here: Hammam, Yddish and oriental food, jewelery, really french food, art gallery.....and more. Le Marais is romantic and so french.

The best neighbourhood in Paris. This is the neighbourhood to stay in Paris. Lot's of ambiance, character, restauants, bars, shops. Very lively, but you always feel comfortable. It's in the center of town and great to explore the city by bus or by metro. Attractions not to miss there are the Centre Pompidou, the Musée Picasso and the Musée de la Chasse. Or simply stroll down the busy streets and enjoy.

The best Paris neighborhood.. We love the Marais. As Jews, we appreciate its history (yet, unfortunately, incompletely.) The people there make you feel comfortable, at home, while offering an incredible assortment of shops with designer apparel and jewelry. But it's the architecture we go for. Really old, lovely streets, fantastic food. Just walk and get lost. See the Picasso Museum of course. Inexpensive audio tour.
Beautiful Neighborhood . We were only in Paris 3 days and could have spent all 3 here without ever venturing elsewhere. Great restaurants, bars, shops, historic sites, access to other areas.

Great for food and shopping. . If you are looking for beautiful Paris designed and made clothes that are comparable to J Crew prices...go to the Marais. Tons of great shops! Food is great and varied as well.

Beautiful Neighborhood. One of Paris's oldest neighborhoods, Le Marais is my favorite part of Paris to stay. You can't help but feel as if you are an honorary Parisian while staying in Le Marais. The cafes, the shops and boutiques (most local, but some international names), and the small hotels all make me feel as if I'm experiencing Paris more authentically than if I were to stay closer to the tourist attractions. Spending the day walking around, stopping at a cafe for a snack and a coffee, visiting the Picasso Museum and returning to your boutique hotel in an 18th century building make this beautiful arrondissement a favorite when staying in Paris.

Le Marais. One of my favorite neighborhoods (arrondissments) in Paris; exotic foods, fascinating history, a Jewish quartier of the city. Love the food, small hotels and great restaurants. Le Marais, Rive Droite of the city, is within a walking distance of Louvre, Commedie Francaise, Musee Victor Hugo and much more. If you like to shop, le Marais is just a moment away Rue Rivoli and its large stores and shopping centers. Mostly staying within le Marais is to experience history, intimacy and much more.
Best neighbourhood to stay. Dynamic, charming, full of hidden places, nice cafes. Le Marais is the best neighbourhood to stay if you like to discover new places.
not not miss in paris. good for eating , for shopping for museum it is hip but deserve so and a nice walk from for instance notre damme

Great place to stroll on a Sunday. This is one of the livelier street scenes in Paris, especially on a Sunday. Crowds of tourists line up for one falafel shop after another. Baked goods, luxury stores, cafés all bustling with people enjoying life.

Disappointing!. When my husband and I were here 5 years ago, the neighborhood was completely different. Historically it's the Jewish quarter but it has changed and now seems to just be an area with high end boutiques. So if that's your thing, then you'll love it. If you're looking for the charm, we'll that just isn't there anymore.

Beautiful old walking area, old Jewish quarter, hipster-filled. This is a great spot to walk around, visit hipster fashion shops and eat at delicious quaint cafes. L'As du Falafel is probably the best falafel stand outside of the Middle East - and kosher, too!

The best arrondissment in Paris. I contemplated as to whether to write this review for fear of making this area even more popular.If you are an obsessive shopper of high end labels, then skip this review and go to St Germain de Prés or the Rue Faubourg St Honoré. It is in these areas that you will find the fashion houses that will provide you with the brands that will endower you with the uniform that will let you subltey indicate you are a person of great wealth an someone who does not look for VFM.If you are a thinking person and have read past the above paragraph then you are in for a treat.The beautiful Marais, built on a swamp, that's what the Marais means, this area exemplifies medieval Paris. The architecture is beautiful, the area is filled with cobbled streets, remnants of its former aristocracy, its strong Jewish culture and its current occupancy of fantastic restaurants, ancient museums and modern ones ( the Pompidou) it has one of the best tea houses in the world, Mariage Fréres ( try the Marco Polo tea - deeeelicios) it has some wonderful little galleries. There are food markets and a few concept store, most f all it has soul.It is closed on Saturday because of Shabat but is open on Sundays when a lots of Paris is stilled closed.It is a great place to stay - there are many short stay apartments available. I have stayed in this area several times.

Great neighborhood for LGBTQ and open travelers. The Marais is unique in its history and origin starting from a swamp, to Jewish neighborhood to a trendy gay area. A wide variety of food, as well as less-visited monuments and museums.

Must do!!. A great area of Paris for shopping and wandering with lots of wonderful shops and cafes! Great area to she at night as there are a lot of outdoor performers to enjoy!! Highly recommend this area of Paris!

Nice walk and Picasso museum. This is a nice area, maybe it has gotten more ' touristic' than it used to be but it is still nice, you can find restaurants and cafes that are inexpensive compared to other parts of the city and the area is kind of cozy, you can walk for a while and just enjoy the streets and the views and you can also visit the Picasso museum while in here.

Lovely buildings, chilled atmosphere. Full of lovely buildings, character and atmosphere. Lots of cheaper cafes and shops too. We stayed in an apartment here and found it friendly. We walked the length of Paris, to the Arc de Triomphe from here nearly entirely on one road :)

The real Medieval Paris, and no, it's not only for gay peopple. This wonderfull area is the only left ( and impressively well preserved ) neighbourhood from medieval Paris, boasts a vast number of houses / buildings almost 1000 years old. And is big, goes from the 3rd till the 4th arrondisement, includes attractions like Pompidou Art Center, Victor Hugo museum house, Etienne Marcel monument, etc. Rue de Renard, rue du temple, rue Saint Martin are quite interesting to stroll. And for GLTB ones, rue des ours honors its name with many Bears only bars.

Wonderful. First time in Paris we ventured into le Marais, and I loved it. I spent a could days just wandering the streets and alleys, enjoying lunch at small cafes and some of the best pastries from shops just around the corner from adorable alleys. Some great shopping (in themed sections it seemed - found a street with 4 calligraphy shops in a row). Did pass a few bigger name stores on the main streets, but that didn't take away from our enjoyment of the entire neighbourhood. A great place to get away from typical tourists Paris, and interact with more locals. Loved it.

The most interesting district of Paris. Despite the constant rain when I was there, I absolutely loved the Marais, and it's the part of the city that I think back on most fondly and often. There are of course wonderful historic and cultural sites like the Place des Vosges and the Musee Carnavalet among many others, but I found it rewarding just to wander aimlessly through the streets. Next time I go to Paris, I'll stay in this area!
Great place to spend the evening. The only in place in central Paris where Parisians are more relaxed and even (some of the careless ones) friendly! Very good cafes and restaurants, too.

Best quarter in Paris to walk around. The Marais has always been a very pleasant quarter to just stroll through: specialty shops, nice restaurants and some high quality museums. The Musee Picasso has reopened and is definitely worth a visit.

My favourite area in Paris. This is my favourite area in Paris. You can spend hours by just strolling the streets. This area has some quite good, inexpensive restaurants that have a bit more adventurous menus than restaurants in some other typical tourist areas. There are also some good museums, such as Musee de Picasso and Museum of Paris. There are still many Jewish restaurants and coffee shops in Rue de la Rosiere. Marais is also an area where many of the most popular gay bars in Paris are located.

A guided tour and some Picasso. We started our Sunday Morning with a guided tour through the Marais. What a fascinating place. Lunch of course at a Mediterranean restaurant. If Paris is concerned about terror attacks it was not evident in this historical Jewish quarter. This was just a few days after the Nice attack. Glad I went and would do it again. Don't forget the Picasso Museum.

Got very touristy!. So, I was there five years ago and it was quite quaint and full of history on all its small, narrow streets. Now, just a few years later, it is a tourist mecca with many regional and chain stores... but with very few local shops now. I personally think it's lost its old-world charm... But, I may be alone in that thinking as the place was packed and everyone seemed to love the area. So, I guess I'm just old and I am one of those that just "misses the way it used to be." On the positive side, it is clean and modern... in an old fashion style. A great "hang."

Don't waste your time. With everything there is to do in Paris, this area should be skipped. Maximize your time by spending it elsewhere. Boring and more of the same architecture and activities you find all over Paris. Other areas are much more fun.
Just go!. Nice area of Paris never visited before. Lots of shops and cosy little streets. Nice cafés as well. Not really a touristic place just a little walk from river Seine

Historical, Walkable and Beautiful. This is one of Paris' most engaging neighborhoods, filled with shops, cafes and all sorts of interesting people. It has been a Jewish neighborhood for many years and consequently, during the Nazi occupation from 1940-1945, witnessed much of the suffering and deportation of tens of thousands of Parisian Jews to death camps. We were told that 11,000 of the Jewish deportees from Paris were children. There are plaques on many of the buildings that commemorate some aspect of that terrible time.The history of the Marais parallels the history of Paris; it was once the site of Royal residences, it has long been the center for art salons and crowded cafes, it suffered for awhile during the post WWII period but has reemerged once again a bustling, happy neighborhood that draws visitors from all over the world.

Small area to window shop and eat Jewish food! . This is a part of Paris where many Jews lived and still do. Many high end boutiques crowd the streets around the area and many small places to eat nearby. Really neat place to window shop as many of the clothes can be over 100-300 euros a piece. Some shops have cheaper items but you could easily spend over 200 euros in a woman's shirt and over 200 euros on some men's dress shoes. If that's your style you'll love these small shops. If not, walk around it for the history, and plaques on certain buildings telling short stories of what went on in the mid 1940's. And get falafel at one of many shops on the main streets. Definitely worth a stop to look around and enjoy a small piece of history. A few blocks away is also victor Hugo's house. Enjoy!

Lovely part of Paris!. We LOVE this part of paris and all want to move here. This is what you belive Paris will be like from TV and Movies. Its so charming with small bistros and shops everywhere. We stayed in the area and can truly recommend this when travelling as a family.
One of my favourite places in Paris. Great to amble along the streets and fantastic for affordable shopping. All main shops there but lots of unique ones and some great independent bars and bistros

Neighborhood walking. This is one you can walk around all day and still find a new and interesting place. Like to look for treasures--antiques, consigned couture clothing? This is the area. Just take the metro to Hotel de Ville and cross the rue de Rivoli. You're in! They're everywhere. Just have a felafel for lunch in a little neighborhood park, and continue sightseeing and shopping.

Beautiful. I really intended for us to stay here. Our now week of Paris being based in Le Marais was a good way to experience local living. It is quite with a bustling cafe atmosphere as in multiple places...lots! We walked up to Rue Rossiers and I can't remember the streets we took leading up to the there but is was a great walk from Rue Bretagne. All the description online is pretty accurate. The key attractions are really close although we did;t get to cover them. A couple of good pastry shops were right on our block...the Poilane and Poplin. A lot of historical places and not saturated with tourists.

Le Marais - a trendy, vibrant quartier. I've been visiting Paris for years, and Le Marais is still my favorite quarter in Paris.It is vibrant, alive, buzzy and busy, trendy and artistic.Plenty of friendly bistrots and bars, shops selling design and kitsch.

Great walk!!!. I followed the Marais walking tour from the Frommer's Guide and it was lovely. You will see ramparts from Philippe Auguste's city wall, taste delicious falafel in the Jewish quarter, and see some of the grandest homes built in Paris. I very much enjoy walking. My travels began in the village of St-Paul and ended at Victor Hugo's apartment on place de Vosages, and took me several hours as I'm a history teacher and I stop a lot to read things or learn more and visit locations like the National Archives. I highly recommend a visit to this magnificent area of Paris, make sure to wear comfortable shoes!
The Best. We rented an apartment from Cobblestone Paris Rentals. It was perfect. We traveled around the different neighborhoods and decided that Le Marais is with out a doubt the most fun.
love the vibe. this section of town stole our hearts with its friendly residents who were more than willing to help. drinks every night here and some into the wee hours.

Plenty of funky restaurants and shops. We stayed here for 5 days and loved visiting the different restaurants and shops. We sought out, off the beat places where only "locals" were eating - which was great.

the perfect neighborhood to stay while in Paris. plenty of cafes, patisseries, shopping and sights. lots of small tucked away museums. Everything is walk-able. Has a NYC Greenwich feel, except in a French style. The architecture is beautiful. Every 5 feet I stopped to take another picture, Took several pictures of the doors, all of which are tall and very detailed. Stayed in an apartment here, can't wait to come back again.

Parisian Charm Personified!. What a great neighborhood to spend a morning or afternoon browsing! Le Marais is laden with shops lining from quaint to retro to antique which all contain art work, clothing, jewelry and more. Many cafes and restaurants line the streets and my daughter and I found ourselves sitting at a café for a lengthy period time sipping drinks and taking in the entire 'vibe' of this great Parisian neighborhood. It's definitely worth a visit during your stay in Paris!
a beautiful quartier. it is an area for amusement, shopping, eating, and do nothing. if is sunny have lunch there- grab a sandwich, seat at a restaurant, visit the vitor hugo museum
Exciting and romantic. A couple of afternoons and evening were spent in Le Marais. It's fun with nice shops and bistros fun nightlife

Not sure what the fuss is all about. It's supposed to be a hip neighborhood of Paris. What a disappointment. The prices were very steep and the clothes were not that special. There are no cute streets there either. Not sure what the hype is about. Hubby did find a nice shoe store and bought two pairs of shoes so not a complete waste.
One of the best neighborhoods in Paris. Le Marais is a must see neighborhood. It has alot of great shops . Close to notredame. There is a very department store mall there called BVS.
Walk around. Walk around and go shopping. Forget Champs Elysee. Here you will meet the locals in a more human scale. Prepare to walk a lot.

Take a walk through this interesting neighborhood. This area has a lively ethnic culture and some notable Jewish attractions including places to shop and eat. It is a great neighborhood just to amble through, browse the shop windows and grab a bit to eat.

A glimpse of Paris pre 1860. We went to le Marais to see some of Paris as it was before the big changes under Napoleon III. Hidden gardens were great but so little else is left and the street is still wide. You get a better idea of it from Avignon or old Lyon, I think.

Don't miss the Marais!. Even though I stayed in the Latin Quarter, I walked to the Marais nearly every day. Even when full of tourists, it feels like a true Paris neighborhood. There are cafes, restaurants on each block, and the shopping is great. There is a huge mall, but I would avoid it, as the neighborhood stores and those on the street offer wonderful deals and unique merchandise. I also got my haircut there and had a delicious glass of wine in one of the outdoor cafes, and one of the cheapest too! Don't miss the Marais! A fun and bustling shopping mecca.

Although majestic hôtels, there is an intimacy that makes you adapt your pace. Le Marais helps you adjust your pace and regain a certain calm. It is a meeting with times gone by and it invites you to a tourism, which makes you see, really see and not only though the lens of the camera.

Fun day shopping and wondering . The strong police and army presence tells you how popular this area is. Locals and tourists enjoying the cafes and bars, shops and parks. Not far from the river. Great chocolate and ice cream shops, independent jewelry stores, clothing stores, as well as the typical chain stores (sadly). Ask a cafe for a map of the area and walk. Get lost and explore.

our favourite arrondisement. Things we love about Le Marais:> The smaller museums, like Victor Hugo House, Musee Carnavalet, Musee Picasso> Much of it is open on Sunday, when many other parts of Paris are not> Smaller, interesting shops: keep an eye out for Le Labo (fragrance), Papier Tigre (stationery), Bon Ton (children's store, including a black & white photobooth), Mona Market (interiors)> Merci. Say no more!> A glut of terrific coffee: Fragments, Foundation, The Broken Arm, Louistic, Ob-La-Di, Boot Cafe> Great cafes: Bob's Kitchen, Fragments, Season> Top-shelf bakeries, like Poilane> Fabulous restaurants, like Le404 (Morroccan), Breizh cafe (galettes and crepes) > Providores like Maison Plisson>

Wonderful neighborhood with everything. Such a wonderful neighborhood, full of history, culture and the new up and coming scene. I was told this is the hip part of Paris and I can see although a lot of tourist are coming around, but some private gardens and alleys still savor its flavor. Wonderful bakeries, small vintage shops, adorable neighborhood. We took a three hour walk and it was a very nice stroll and picked up somethings from the shops too!

Fascinating pic op!. Our senior group was on a panoramic tour and we had an opportunity to get a fascinating picture here. Did not make a stop except to see the statue. Amazing. Just one more marvelous thing to see in Paris with so many many more to see.
historical . le marais is total historical areawe saw very old buildings here we saw old architecture here I never see this type of difficult architecture any where
An area to stroll and buy. We whiled away several hours in this area. Full of intriguing independent shops, great stops for lunch and for coffee. A place to wander and see where you end up.

Our favorite Parisian neighborhood. Let's be honest - all of Paris, Haussmann re-designing or no, is atmospheric and full of romance. But the Marais, even as it becomes more upscale as it gentrifies, retains an old-fashioned Bohemian quality. Wandering the streets, stopping at a cafe, drinking it all in, that's where it's at. If you want sights, try Carnavalet or Place des Vosges.

Be welcome to Paris 17th till 19th centuries !. Hard to believe you have so much to discover in Paris ! Alone in the Marais, you should see the 'Place des Vosges' buily by Henri IV and one of the 8 museums to be found there, as well as fabulous fountains and old 17th century buildings and fabulous roofs and carpentry works with high ceilings... Be sure you have at least half a day to visit this part of Paris.

Great location. We stayed in a flat in Le Marais on vacation recently. I've been to Paris many times and never spent much time in this area. It's a great location for a base of operations. Away from the noise and the crowds, a neighborhood full of locals.

Loved it. I love this hip little area. We stayed in an old art gallery that had been converted to an apartment. There are tons of restaurants around and Centre Pompidou is right there. Lots of little clothing stores.

Historical and shops too!. Le Marais is a lovely area, with the Jewish quarter and some good little individual shops. There is a good Falafel restaurant, L'As de Falafel in the Rue de Rosiers, and be prepared to queue. Great place to walk around and enjoy the atmosphere.

The 'Heart' of Paris. If you have the chance to stay in the Marais district do so! Hotel, pension or apartment, this area is close to so many of the attractions of Paris, you seldom need to do anything but walk (like the Parisiennes do). We have seen the Ile de Cite, with Notre Dame and the Place de Justice, the Left Bank, the Louvre, La Place de Bastille are all within reach and even places like the Luxembourg Gardens and the Tuilleries can be walked to by those with a reasonable level of fitness. A few places (notably Montmatre, the Eiffel Tower and L'Arc de Triomphe) are further afield and require the assistance of the excellent public transport or one of the two 'hop on / hop off' bus services.As for eating - there is an abundance of eating places - boulangeries, cafes, brasseries and restaurants. Most are friendly, relaxed places with a good range of food. Choosing 'la plat de jour' daily specials ensures a good meal for reasonable prices.There are also good services (banks, post office, metro stations and many buses along the Rue de Rivoli).Overall, the Marais gives you access, convenience and a taste for a little of the Paris life style.

So many good restaurant. 옛날 신사동 가로수길처럼 고즈넉하고 전통있는 가게가 많아요 한번 지나가서는 모를수도 있지만 바스티유역에 숙소를 잡아보니 예전엔 몰랐던 매력이 있습니다Marais is old, but it has many hip place. if you visit here couple of hour, maybe you cant feel what marais is. I found many charms when i stay hotel in bastille.

The best part of Paris!. After a 9 night visit, our entire family agrees that Le Marais is our favorite neighborhood in Paris. Very charming, fashionable shopping, lovely streets and parks, enchanting corner cafes, and close proximity to Berthillon, which my teens visited often.

When you've gotta sit, you've gotta sit!. And this is a lovely spot to rest up in. Take a day off the buildings and the cement and architecture, wander round the green and the statues and just keep Cool. Take your 'The Secret Paris' book and lie on the grass and absorb that. take a wee picnic from the buffet in the hotel and just chill out. SUPER

Just stayed in the Marais - wonderful. Just stayed for a week - bustling, without too many tourists. Great area for walking, cafes, and the like. Interesting museums in the Marais or nearby. Definitely will stay in the area next time.
c'était bien long time ago. years ago.it used to be a nice area now it's on is way to become some kind of ultra chic place .. gucci shop & co.. what a shame !

Cafés - restaurants and boutiques. If you want to enjoy real Paris shopping and do not want the hassle of the crowdy and long Champ Elysee with the pricy shops - you have to go to this area of Paris.
Small boutiques, variety and cafés for a coffee or lunch break.
Le vrais Paris.

Absolute best part of Paris. I've been to Paris maybe 5 or 6 times and this is the first time I rented an apartment and choose to do so in the Marais. It was the best decision I could have ever made. I was traveling with my 80 year old father and 11 year old niece and to be honest it was hard to get them out of the Marais except for going to dinner restaurants around Paris. It is vibrant, fun, local! Full of small cafes and marches of every sort. An absolute joy for your culinary senses. There are also loads of little shops for everything from vintage clothes to the latest fashions for both men and women. Be warned. It is expensive. It is also in walking distance to many great Paris attractions and easy to catch the metro or a taxi. But what surprised me most is that despite how exciting and lively the area is, it can also be quiet and extremely charming, especially when going for your morning cafe and breakfast. Visiting or staying in the Marais is an absolute must!!!
Explore around. Do visit to explore around and dine in the area. A bit upscale for shopping but very picturesque and full with restaurants and cafes.

Great location to see Paris. We rented an apartment. We we able to easily walk or take metro to any place in Paris. Neighborhood was very safe. It also had plenty of restaurants, shops, etc. Much quieter than the left bank but not as boring as the business area of the right bank. Easy market shopping if you dine in also.
Boring. Took a walking tour lasting a whole day. Nothing very notable to see. Good place to observe Parisian average person daily life.

we visited each day for 4 days. A lovely community of boutiques and cafes and restaurants and historical sights. Put on your walking shoes and stroll the streets. Eat at Chez Hannah. Do this in the late afternoon and have a late dinner.

Great place to stay. Le Marais district is a wonderful base for visitors to Paris. It has a great selection of hotels, apartments, restaurants and shopping and all the main tourist attraction are within close proximity. The bonus is the people and atmosphere. We will certainly return.

Fun neighborhood for strolling!. Just a fun area for shopping, strolling, people watching...a favorite! Quaint - flower shops, ice cream, art galleries, clothing boutiques, street cafes and bistros, A lovely way to spend a day!

Lovely part of Paris. Allow yourself at least a day to explore this wonderful part of Paris. It is picturesque and full of life. There are so many little shops to wander through and delicious food. The buildings are lovely and give you a lot of photo opportunities. The day spent here was definitely in the top three areas we visited in Paris, and if I get to go back to Paris, I will want to spend more time here.

Still the place in Paris. Le Marais has everything and every time I return there is something new. It is a growing and living part of Paris with a rich history, intimacy, wonderful shops, historic sites and places to browse, cute hotels, bars to have a drink, people watch and take in what is the essence of Paris. It is a place to wander aimlessly or with purpose and it is totally full of charm and options!
not touristy. wonderful area. Has great shopping and restaurants. Loved all the shops and people very friendly. Walked everywhere.
Check out this part of Paris. I loved biking this part of the city and seeing the street art. There are tons of fun shops, cafes, and things to do. Great vintage and fun!
Fabulous and So Much to do. Love this area of Paris. Tons and tons to do, great restaurants and shopping and huge people watching!

Great for a Sunday stroll when lots of other shops are closed. Our rental place was in Le Marais and we enjoyed being able to explore the area on Sunday when other shops were closed.
Lots of shops, cafes and places to explore on a Sunday.

So Ho of Paris. We stayed for a week in the marais this time and was surprised by how fun and hip it was. I had remembered it as more stuffy and dead but they have many great little restaurnats and wine bars that are open late and very welcoming
Fun walk. Was looking forward to exploring Le Marais. Interesting area but many shops closed due to Jewish holiday. Best to check

I LOVE this area!. We were recommended to visit from everyone from the taxi driver who took us from the airport, shopkeepers and pretty much everyone we spoke to. After visiting I can understand why. A maze of lane ways and streets filled with shops, boutiques, restaurants and cafes, museums, history, shopping... It's awesome! Do not miss it!

Best shopping and quiet stay. Lovely neighborhood to stay in. Great food and shopping. Easy walking distance to many metro stations and attractions such as the Louvre, Hotel de Ville, Notre Dame, etc. With some googling, easy to find vegan or gluten free restaurants or good coffee. Side streets are good for quiet accommodation. Beautiful architecture. Hip but simple. I always stay in this area while in Paris.

Vibrant area of Paris with village feel. Spent long weekend in apartment with our adult children overlooking Saint -Paul cathedral . Extremely busy area with numerous eateries to suit all tastes. Very easy walking distance to Notre Dame .

Gorgeous area in the heart of Paris. I lived in Paris for 6 months and this is my favourite area of the city. Such a lovely atmosphere, live music sometimes, quaint cobbled streets, cool shops and fantastic food. Typically Parisian.
nice place to explore. one of the nice places in paris to stroll or explore .. where a numbers of museums located .. as well as a big numbers of art gallery
Earthy Section of Paris. Lots to do and see and stroll around for in this historic area. Kosher restaurants? Yes. Lots of Jewish history here. And more.

Beautiful neighborhood with many cafes and bakeries and . We stayed at a Paris for Rent apartment in the Marais neighborhood of Paris. We absolutely loved it! Lots of narrow streets and boulangeries and restaurants. Bubbling with people and activities. Charming. My boys really enjoyed the many sweet shops and gelato ice cream places. We also ate at the famous L'as Falafel shop which I thoroughly recommend. A walk through the Place des Vosges was leisurely and historical.
Love the Marais district!. What a fabulous district to explore with all the restaurants, beautiful old buildings and any number of shops. A great experience!

Couldn't stop smiling. I visited on a Sunday with my husband and we had the happiest six hours wondering the charming streets, enjoying the art and music and doing a spot of shopping. Never a dull moment, If people watching is something you enjoy, you won't be disappointed as so many local characters to keep you entertained while you enjoy the excellent food and drink from one of the many beautiful street cafes.

Beautiful corner of Paris. This was my first visit to Paris and we were only there for one day and one night. Our Son who has visited several times joined us as our guide. It was a fast and furious day which began at the Eiffel Tower and ended in Le Marais. Our son knew what he was doing - having walked and queued at all the famous tourist spots in Paris during the day we were booked to travel to London on the Eurostar at 9pm - our son planned the day so that we would finish wandering the gorgeous Marais district and finishing with a meal there. It was such a treat - a feeling of elegance, quintessential Paris and calm after a very hectic day. We sat for an hour at a delightful bar "acting like a couple of Parisiennes", resting and just taking in the incredible life of this great city in one of its most beautiful arrondissements ! We found dinner at a Entrecout - Excellent steak, frits and salad with the most speedy and efficient service. we also managed some shopping in Le BHV Marais and purchased chocolates to take home from Alain Ducasse. All of this with enough time to comfortably board the Eurostar for a 9pm departure. A visit to Le Marais would definately be on my must do list for a visit to Paris.

West Village of Paris. What a cute neighborhood. I am so glad I chose to book my hotel in the Marais. It is centrally located and it is only a 20 minute walk to the Seine. There is a cafe/boulangerie/patisserie on every corner. Also, the bike share program here is extensive. There is a station every few blocks, so you'll never be without a dock for your rented bike. I stayed at Hotel Marais Home, a super cute, clean hotel with a Turkish hammam

place vosges is one of the finest in Paris. The Marais is an area of antique stores ( and a gay area)....the heart is Place Vosges( so called because the Vosges was the first part of France to pay its taxes after the revolution. Lovely harmonious red and yellow brick architecture, with arcades covering some excellent restaurants, and the house of Victor Hugo. Pavilion de la Reine hotel is one of the better ones in Paris, four stars.

Lovely.. Le Marais was such a lovely and romantic place. Went there to spend my sunday afternoon after visiting the bastille market. Yet I didn't expect to listen to such lovely music played on the streets!! Loved the overall relaxing atmosphere, and the arts performed on the streets made it even lovelier ;)

Le Marais is great to do a self guided walking tour. I downloaded a Frommers self guided walking tour and started from the Bastille Monument. A very lovely area to weave in and out of and find the Jewish area and stunning old buildings and see Parisennes in everyday life.
Hipster France. If you are looking for the Hipster France style, you should go to Marais. This neighbourhood is amazing! You can find a lot of Thrift Shops!

Lovely area of Paris. This was my first visit to Paris and it was a family gathering, we in a 3* hotel in the area, some of my family were staying elsewhere and my sister had rented a small apartment, all were in the Le Marks area. Each night we had booked dinner in a different cafe restaurant there were so many to choose from. The area is what I should think is typically Parisian, tall buildings,narrow street a cafe on every corner. You find better value if you wander a little way off the main drag but I suppose that applies to most cities. The metro is so good you can explore where you like in the city with ease. We did a lot of walking around the area in 3 days there is so much to see. I would come back to the area in a heartbeat

Walking around. Place des Vosges to museum de la chase "hunting museum", to so many small streets with amazing possibilities to discover some interesting museum, old house or courtyard, store, or just sit and watch people. This is a dynamic and vibrant neighborhood in Paris, another favorite when we visit this fabulous town
Interesting area. Interesting neighborhood. We found a number of shops that sold men's shirts at outlet prices. Has some hidden gardens and pretty areas.

Very interesting neighborhood. It is a great pleasure to wander around this neighborhood with the interesting street art and lots of fine and quirky shops. There are unexpected plazas to come across as well as interesting retail opportunities, from chain stores to Mom and Pop shops. Use Trip Advisor to help you find good food to eat. And don't forget to see the Centre Pompidou (Beaubourg) and its interesting sunken plaza. Do not fail to head south of the plaza to enjoy the whimsical sculptures in a large fountain. Very amusing.

Surpringly nice neighbourhood. This was a surprisingly nice area to stay and walk around in. Quite a few sucky touristy places, but also so many nice ones to visit. You could also easily get away to non-touristy stuff by walking 1 km or so. So, in short, be a bit cynical and you can find very nice things.
In the 1980's, I worked for a designer in this neighborhood.. Back then, it was very charming. Now it is still charming, but much more upscale, with loads of designer shops and beautiful cafes.
Lovely walk. Definitely recommend a walk through this historic neighborhood. Especially enjoyed the Musee Carnavalet and the many quaint shops and bakeries.

There are so many palaces and unique shops, restaurants, antique markets and food markets.. I visited here almost every other day for a month during my stay in Paris. I was taking classes atLa Cruisine Paris which if you have time do sign up it as it was fun and delicious.

This is my Paris. This is my favourite neighbourhood in Paris; even though I have not experienced them all, I know Le Marais will always be my favourite. Shops, streets, old buildings, parks, friendly people, restaurants, markets - Le Marais has it all.
