Lovely neighborhood with character . On Sundays they close the streets down for cars, have a walk trough it and enjoy shops, cafes and nice people. Lot to experience.

Maybe the best walking area of Paris - a walking city. The Marais has a bit of everything. History, charm, museums, food, shopping, small narrow streets, lots of activity and the Place de Vosges for bench sitting and relaxation (except, as I just learned, on a hot summer day it is like the sheep meadow in Central Park in NYC where it becomes a sunbathing haven)

Exciting, relaxed and vibrant. Le marais is filled with not only cute and interesting shops, but amazing local food and a wonderful atmosphere. Relaxed, interesting and arty, and a refreshing change from the stuffiness of the centre of Paris. If I were to come to Paris again, I would definitely try to stay in this area rather than the city.
Great shopping. Le Marais has recently become one of the hippest shopping areas in Paris and I really enjoyed all of the unique stores we visited.

The true nature of Paris. As a Parisian for about 3 years now, I spend quite a lot of my spare time in the narrow streets of Marais. This place has an atmosphere filled with all the different communities in a peaceful place. As a majority of Jewish community living there, fridays are quiet but sundays are the best! If you already saw the tourist attractions of Paris, such as Eiffel, La Fayette, Champs Elysées, you have(!!) to spend your time in the hidden places of Marais. There are a lot of cafés where you can have a cup of coffee and a great dessert, or a loud brunch, or just a fine lunch with your family. You can also shop from the small boutiques and branches of big clothing companies whom are spreaded on the streets of Marais. Especially Rue des Rosiers and Rue des Archives ( also you can go to Rue de Rivoli, one of the most important streets for shopping). Also, you can find the Museum of Picasso, The National Archives and some much smaller art galleries. If you want to party, there are a lot of bars, night clubs. You can see easily that Marais is a huge part of LGBTQ community, which makes the quartier even fun and cool. There are still so much to stay, but even more to experience!
Hidden gem!. 15 minute walk from Notre-Dame-de-Paris.Loaded with (less expensive) cafés, bars and nightlife.Nice shopping too. Don't miss Peru's very own Miséricordia in front of Hotel l'Antoine.
Great Sunday morning activity. Just wander the streets before the crowds come. The Place Voges is beautiful. The little shops are interesting and the architecture is amazing.

espetacular. diversity is the name of this arrondisement. we have people from different nationalities and different sexual options. different types of food. we visited carnavalet museum, place of bastille and place saint paul. is was wonderful
The best area in paris. Lot of shops, restaurant and bars. The buildings are really old and nice. That s the real Paris for us. Easy to go. And not far to notre dame de Paris ;))

Absolutely worth the trip. Since going to this neighborhood 8 years ago and then recently it's changed a bit. It's much more commercial now with more chain stores (but since they include what would be high end in the States it's not really a big deal). It's very crowded now but the shopping, food and atmosphere are all great and absolutely worth the trip.
Beautiful neighborhood. This was a wonderful and vibrant neighborhood. Great shopping! There were many specialty stores and small cafes to stop at for some refreshment.

Still a pleasure to be around. Marais is one of my favorite places in Paris.
Yet i seemed to feel that there were more interesting shops until a couple of years ago.
It was still a pleasure to shop from les mariages
The shop is an object of desire for me with the mesmerizing tea smells from all around the world

Sunday stroll . Always fun to watch the people waiting forever to have the honor of eating a huge "sandwich" standing! The July store sales were particularly good there but the crowds to try on clothes made the process seem less worth the savings .

Typically French! Quirky and beautiful! . A great little place. Full of locals, cafes, bars and restaurants. Quirky little streets and shops. Well worth a visit. Our hotel was here and couldn't have picked a nicer place :)
Buzzing with energy, Le Marais is a great location. With beautiful cobbled streets, great bistros and lots of boutiques to explore - this is great Paris destination.
Charming. The area is very cute. Plan on eating there as the coffee places have outdoor seating and it's relaxing just to see people around. There a lot of cute boutiques also that are worth visiting
great neighborhood!. Quirky and fun neighborhood to walk around in, plenty of shops and restaurants, parks- a great part of a great city.

Le Marais - The place to be. Whenever i am in Paris, even when only for a day, I make sure to stop by in the Marais. It's buzzling with life and history. Find out about the Jewish heritage of the town, enjoy coffee in the various beautiful cafés and delicious Falafel at Chez Marianne. The Marais is alive and friendly. The gay scene is also very present there, you will find a lot of nice bars, restaurants and shops, that welcome all people.Be advised: The Marais is rather expensive.Don't miss Place de Voges, to me one of the most beautiful places/squares of the world.
Great restaurants- get here early to avoid the crowds. We loved this area and especially early in the morning- 9AM or so before all the crowds came. Some great restaurants and treats.

Wonderful area of Paris!. We stayed just adjacent to the national archives and it was wonderful. The first day I walked out I stopped at a bakery, an Italian Deli, a farmers market, and a florist....and later a chocolate store, cafe, restaurant, cheese store, etc. I could easily spend a day and not go past 100 meters!

Great for shopping! . We found in the Marais a great shop of a new shoebrand, ethical, who gives a free pair after each sell.
Great collection! The name is Twins For Peace
Love!. Our apartment is in this bustling neighborhood. Many good shops and bistros and close to the market on Bastille. Busy streets and colorful characters and the falafel smell is incredible!

Stroll and stroll and stroll. This is the perfect neighborhood to stroll the small streets and passageways of boutiques, restaurants and cafes. The goal here is to simply get yourself lost walking around this district. Find yourself a cafe. Order a coffee, something to eat and sit outside. Soak up the atmosphere; people watch and the Parisian way of life. If you're of the LGBTQ community, this is heaven!

Le Marais - a guided tour is recommended. A place worth touring. A lot of hidden places, so a guided tour is recommended (we took the free discover Paris tour which was excellent). Many restaurants (including Kosher ones) and little fashion shops. Allow 2-3 hours for tour.

Discovery tour of Le Marais. Le Marais is an area of Paris well worth visiting and we did it with the free guided tour offered by Discovery tours (tip supported tour). You appreciate an area so much more with a guide. We learned of its varied history, contemporary story and peeked into places we were not likely to find on our own.

Excellent place to base your stay in Paris. We've rented apartments in the Marais twice in the last three years and it is an ideal place to base your visit to Paris. Lots of fun shopping, safe streets for walking (even late at night with just a mom and teenage daughter), close Metro stops and easy walking to Notre Dame and the Latin Quarter. Good cafes as well. Make sure to spend an hour dozing in the lovely Places des Voges, listen to the fountains and relax among the Parisian people who visit and picnic all around you.

Interesting buildings and shops. Very old section of the city. Lots of historical buildings with interesting architectural styles. Many shops and street merchants. Nice place to walk around and sightsee - buildings, shops, restaurants, architecture, people.

Love the area. Just a really good area to walk around. Great small boutiques, not many chain stores. Few good restaurants. Avoid rue du temple as just cheap jewellery stores that only sell wholesale but do go to rue de vieille Du temple.

Cool vibrant district. We are staying here at an AirB&B and this is just the perfect location to be. You go out on the street and life is bursting. There are quaint little cafes and restaurants everywhere, a lot of cute stores for shopping (girls watch out). Metro connections are good, just be prepared to walk a loooot underground - there is a whole world down there!

The cultural section of Paris. This section of Paris, is a must visit. There's the Jewish district, boystown, multiple selections of ethnic cuisines, you can visit Victor Hugo's home, great place to shop for clothes and of course, my favorite authentic french offerings, Chez Paul.

Charming streets. Charming stroll through narrow cobblestone streets. But I felt I wasted my time trying to shop here. Couldn't find anything that was appealing to buy, especially when 1/2 the shops were still closed at 10:30.

Very interesting area,.. We really like this area. There are art galleries beyond ones ability to count. The dining choices run from Fine French to Sushi to local Bistro fare. Shopping is varied wide and far from Vintage to Couture. Several historic areas to visit, plus the newly reopened Picasso Musee.

Great Jewish district. Le Marais is an old Jewish district in Paris. Great for quick lunch (delicious falafel in the rue des Roisiers) and long historic walk. Highly recommended for everyone, who loves modern and old world mixed together.
Always something new to see; to drink; to buy. Its one of the oldest areas of paris; and its filled with beautiful twisty turny roads filled with boutique shops; art galleries; small cafes and bars

If you like beautiful, charming and historic neighborhoods this is not for you.... We stayed in an apartment on Rue-St. Paul down by the Seinne, and soaked up every square inch of the charm in this neighborhood, and that's a lot. Unless you're into the party scene and need more excitement, I can't think of a better neighborhood to visit. Great restaurants (try the falafel, even if you don't like it), and use it as a home base to get where you need to (St. Paul station is very close and accessible).

a place to find a lotof things and spend nice moments. just take time to wander, to taste cakes in one of several patisserie, discover the special content and stuff in small shops, breathe this special air.

Bohemian Paris. This area is the hart of Paris! All of us we come here ones a month just to have a drink, to have a diner, to have a brunch, to have a gallery visit, to have a walk.... To have a hart beat!!!Le marais is Paris!

So much fun, best part of Paris!. One of the most amazing places in Paris! There is so much to do here and so much to see. Tons of restaurants, shopping, street vendors, crêpe stands, etc. for a solo outing or with friends or family. Perfect for a sunny day!

Loved this area!. It's probably not the MOST exciting part of Paris but on my 15 day vacation, I went back 4 times. I love this place and all of the sites! Great History! It's hopping all of the time but filled with a different kind of a vibe. Really nice stores, casual, friendly, great food. I really loved walking around this entire area!

Le Marais, my favorite place to stay!. I love the Marais district. I've stayed in several but this is still my favorite. It's close to the river, centrally located, best of old school Paris, Saint Louis island, Notre Dame, gardens, second-hand and artsy shopping, great food, great Metro connections, intimate but clean hotels. It's also far enough away from the busy train stations and heavy tourism.

Wonderful Neighbourhood!. We rented an apartment here for a few days and it is a great place to stay. Lots of shopping, cafes and bars - you will never be bored. Nice and central. Highly recommend this area to stay/eat/play

Lots of surprises in a former swamp. This is a district filled with all sorts of hidden gardens in classical formats, it is the old and new again Jewish quarter with plaques to mark some individuals who died after deportation to camps, lots of unique small shops, bistros including that of the king of falafel and squares with classic apartments featuring the Parisian creation the dormer. Each small street has fascinating things to discover including the largest portion of the remaining wall of the Bastille and a church, St Paul and St Louis that is more impressive than Notre Dame. It features a multitude of chandeliers and Jesus in the Olive grove by Delacroix.

Great way to spend Sunday. When almost every shops are closed on Sunday in Paris, ale Marais is the perfect hangout. A 20-30 minutes walk from Bastille metro station, I was lucky to see the open market with fresh fruit, vegetable, cheese and crepe as I come out of the station. On the way to Le Marais, you can also visit the Victor Hugo museum. Le Marais is lively on Sunday with street performers and lots of lovely boutiques.
The Marsh that was. This was the first time I hung out in this part of Paris. Cafes, restaurants and grocery stores. An antique fair was going on. Pretty cool

Great Sunday shopping. Considering most shops are closed on Sunday in Paris, The Marais is a great area to spend your Sunday. I got off at the Bastille metro station and was lucky to see the open air market with fresh fruit, vegetable, cheese and crepe! From there is a 15-20 minutes walk to the shopping street of The Marais.

Bistros and boutiqe shopping everywhere.. Here you will find the best of Paris. Hip boutiqes, bistros and 2nd hand shopping. Lonely Planet's got some good tips to get you started. This is the hipster, hobo, gay and lively part of town with lots of nightlife. Good for couples too. Walk or bicycle is the best ways to move around here.

A wonderful neighborhood in the center of Paris. We spent a week in Le Marais during Christmas week in 2015. We had a great time. We loved every minute. Fantastic bakeries, cafes, restaurants and upscale shopping. We used public transportation as well as taxies to get around. We could walk to Notre Dame Cathedral and take the Metro to all the places of interest everywhere in Paris. A special "Merci" to the people of Paris, they made our trip most memorable.
great museum and many shops. Don't miss the Picasso Museum, and it is fun walking among the many shops. One of my favorite sections of Paris.

Great place to walk around and shop. Took my 12 year old daughter here with two other moms and daughters. What a great day! We shopped at all the great boutiques (found some inexpensive sneaker stores!), had the BEST falafel and stopped in for lunch and hot chocolate at a local brasserie. There was a wonderful art exhibit that day and we go to see a lot of local modern art. We loved the judaica stores too!
Great Area. Le Marais is well worth a visit and you can walk from St. Germaine area. Lots of cool boutiques and galleries.

Very "Bohemian" place.. Lovely change of atmosphere in this area. Great eateries, especially the fromageries and the stunning display of the fruit stalls. Very good value for accommodation and eating here.
Cool Vibe. We took a tour of this neighborhood and found it to be a very laid back area. This is a great neighborhood to explore on a free afternoon.
Amazing. I always walk by le marais to buy amazing french designer cloth and to have a quick bite or a coffee

Le Marais: Gourmet Food Walk. Was taken on a foodie tour by Randa in this district and went to places you would not normally know about and also tasting some wonderful baking. Randa was a wonderful guide

Live like a Parisian. We stayed for a week in an apartment in this charming neighbourhood, and felt we were living a Parisian lifestyle! So convenient to Metro, bus, local shops, bars and cafes and short walking distances to the Seine, Notre Dame, Louvre, Centre Pompidou, Left Bank etc. It's the old Jewish Quarter, so it's full of history, with many of the lesser known museums close by. Wonderful area to walk around and explore.

Love the Marais and its small streets, cafes and shops. Wandered around after the walking tour of the Marais. The tour was pretty good and took me to many little places I would not have discovered on my own, but I loved walking the streets and wished my wife was with me, but she did benefit from a gift. Will return next year and explore more.

wonderful old part of paris. probably if interested in history best with a guided tour. otherwise stroll and stroll , lots to see , lovely shops cafes restaurants, and take the whole day , won't be enough!
Great area for restaurants. Stayed in this area for 3 nights - you can't go wrong plenty of places to eat, sit, shop or go on to. Always my choice of places to stay in Paris

Our favorite quartiere of Paris--until the next visit. We stayed a month in an apartment in the Marais, and thus got to know its less-touristic nooks and hiding spots as well as to connect with some of its long-time residents. It was a long-time dream of ours, and we hope to do it again. Next time we'll try another district, which may then become our new favorite! How can you miss with Paris?
Marais on a sunny day. We wandered all around the Marais one Saturday with our trusty Michelin Green Guide. A very lovely neighborhood with shops, restaurants, museums, gardens.

Stroll the shopping streets, picnic in Place des Vosges. Get lost on the side streets of the Marais, never far from big boulevards and Metro stops, but a world of its own. Each shop front entices, some are even affordable. Enjoy the galleries lining the Places des Vosges, but for lunch grab a baguette Parisien or similar in a nearby Patisserie and eat on the benches of this beautiful square alongside the locals.

Memorable Paris Experience. We visited Paris in June 2016 and stayed in Le Marais area, The area is known for preserving it's historical appearance, old houses, small streets, historical hotels, beautiful small gardens.. This is where the Paris Jewish community settled long time ago. Place for Victor Hugo's mansion, Picasso museum, countless historical sites. The area attracts a lot of tourists especially on Sundays as many stores remain open for shopping. We rented small studio from Marie's Paris Apartments at perfect location- next to the Pompadour Center and 5 min walk from Notre.. It was a memorable experience.

Plenty of History. This area has a lot of Parisian history and is a beautiful place to explore and shop. The buildings managed to escape too much damage over the years and wars and a walk in this area is really worthwhile.
Great area to shop in. This is a wonderful neighborhood to explore by walking around. Lots of shops and restaurants, as well as a couple of museums and parks. Well worth visiting.

Lots to do close to Notre dame. There's everything that you possibly need in this neighborhood, all kinds if restaurants, bars, night life, shopping at BHV bazaar hotel the ville. Very trendy quarter that cater to all people but more prominently gays. Very safe at all hours of day or night
Good place to visit. I would have given this place a better review if I didn't feel it was a little inauthentic compared to other less touristic places in Paris

Nice place to walk and shop around: shops are open on Sunday. Very animated and nice place to walk without being annoyed by cars. I am not sure if the streets are closed to car everyday, but on Saturday there was no cars.The Shops are typical Paris shops with same prices as elsewhere in Paris, but the animation is nice and there is special ambiance not found elsewhere.The best place to have a walk on a Saturday or Sunday. I guess it should be even better on a Sunday evening.

Lots to see. The magestic Townhall, the Picasso museum and the famous Place des Vosges are a few of the many sightseings at this very old part of the city. Its air of royalty is still there, mostly at the old "Hotels" which are numerous and many of them are now museums worth visiting. Some of them have amazing gates and one can see the barok ornaments almost everywhere!

Favorite Arrondissement to Roam, Shop and Dine. Long removed from its history as a swamp, visit some of the unique museums and sites in Le Marais, shop the unique boutiques and one-of shops, and then enjoy a curb-side lunch or dinner at reasonable prices as life bubbles around you. Great people watching, and perfect for a rainy day.

The best part of Paris. We enjoyes all Paris, and although we stayed in Latin quarter, Le Marais was The part of town for us. Great restaurants, beautiful streets, romantic part of town, but also great for young people... wow!

Wonderful neighborhood. Our party of seven, ranging from age 13-73 stayed in Le Marais in a private apartment. We would highly recommend this neighborhood to anyone. Our location was very close to Metro and Bus lines. However, it is so close to the islands, St Germain, Latin Quarter, and the Louvre that we walked almost everywhere. The restaurants in the area were awesome. The shopping was great. Almost didn't have to leave our area it was so wonderful! Great bars and night life without feeling unsafe.

Our favorite part of Paris. This neighborhood is so colorful! There are beautiful parks, fun shopping, the Picasso Museum, an assortment of unusual people... and don't miss the famous fallafel joint. Little streets and adventure abound. SO special!

Walk in the Paris that von Haussmann didn't dynamite. This is our 3rd visit to Paris, and this time we stayed in Le Marais, near the Pompidou. Perfect neighborhood on Rue Rambuteau with everything one would need for breakfast, lunch and dinner...also a bank, pharmacy and chocolate. Walking distance to the Cluny (Left Bank), the Picasso museum (Right Bank), Les Rosiers (quaint narrow rue for walking and seeing what Paris used to look like before the 19th century), Place des Vosges, Hotel de Ville, etc etc.Rent an apartment if you can and stay for at least a week. Yes, Paris is an expensive city to live in, but less expensive than, say, San Francisco, CA. You can easily get by for lunch with a gorgeous sandwich from Huré, a bakery on Rue Rambuteau. Or if you'd like an inexpensive meal, try one of the bars or cafes. If you've got the bucks, there are more restaurants of high quality than you have time to enjoy in a week. In Le Marais, if you are a walker, you will be delighted to find that you can get to numerous highlights of Paris (on the Right Bank) quickly. There is always the Metro (unless the French transportation workers are striking which is something that does happen--the right to strike is written in the French constitution). In a single morning stroll, we managed to see two world-famous cathedrals (not Notre Dame Paris but others), the Victor Hugo Museum, Les Vosges, and Hotel de Ville and the delightful carousel. Be sure to look for Florence Kahn's deli and other authentic sites.

Cité Internationale des Arts. In 2009 I got a residence at Cité des Arts, Marais and I fell in love with the neighborhood. I just love this area! It's a lot of fun, several restaurants of different styles of food and ambience, some quite exotic, not to mention delicious boulangeries with fresh bread and omelettes (it was my number one program on Sunday). The area is full of art galleries, an interesting photo museum, and the more you walk the nicer little shops you find, making it a very charming and seducing walk from Marais to Centre Georges Pompidou. The Île de Saint-Louis, located just across the bridge from Cité des Arts over the Seine River, with its typical bookinistes, book sellers, offers a number if caffes and restaurants, wine and jewelry as awell as antique shops. Your eyes won't get enough of it, till you reach Notre Dame. I loveso much the place that I had to write a bit about it but the real fun is to discover by yourself the little corners and delucacies of romantic Paris town, specially at the Marais 4ème! Have fun!

Great experience!. Even though we were already staying in the Marais, we thought it would be informative to take the walking tour. We definitely were not disappointed. Our guide, Lucian, was a wealth of information about both the history of the district as well as current developments. Walking some of the back streets was where you really got a feel for the way people lived. Terrific tour!

Crowded but interesting. Lots of interesting shops and markets in the neighborhood. We were staying in the area, so we had time to explore the little side streets. The Marais was one of the more crowded areas we explored by foot.

Historic area to visit. I had previously been on a free guided tour of this area and wished to see more. Just stroll around the narrow streets looking for plaques with insights to the history of this area. Little streets open up to old gardens where you can stop and relax or enjoy the history by simply looking at the surrounding buildings, Do yourself a favour and read up on its coloured history or simply search the web for free walking tours of the Marais where a tip of your choosing is given at the end. Well worth a visit. Travel by wheelchair would be hard due to size of footpaths. ( If you find this review helpful please tick the box tks )

Stay Here if you Can!. Planning my first trip to Paris, I was overwhelmed by deciding what neighborhood to stay in. We ended up booking an Air BNB in Le Marais, and what a perfect decision. This area has everything: shops, restaurants, history. The best part is that it is within walking distance of some very cool spots in Paris, such as Notre Dame and the Louvre. I would highly recommend staying in this neighborhood. If you can't stay here, at least come and visit! Pick up a candle at Cire Trudon, the oldest candle maker in the world!

Quirky shops off the beaten track. Walked around looking for bicycle shops, found plenty of amazing and quirky shops. Boots and retro clothing too.As with the rest of this amazing city there is no shortage of cafes and restaurants either.Traffic is unrelenting so be careful crossing the roads with each red light being a moped Grand Prix!Look off the beaten track as there as some amazing shops and buildings.

Very cool. Filled with cafes, bars, restaurants and strangely enough, lots of vintage clothing stores. It's bustling and charming. I booked for 2 nights in thus area but stayed for 5. Everything is at your doorstep...grocery stores, metro, patisseries....I definitely recommend a visit.

Found this place the forth time in Paris. My favorite area to spend wandering, hanging out at coffee shops, and in general soaking up the nice atmosphere. It is perfect for people watching albeit the majority seem to be tourists. Get to the cafes farther back from Rivoli road (the main road) and you will find some local places with lower prices.

Perfect location . Having never been to Paris before I didn't know where to book accommodation. I found this by reviews and we have loved it here.
Walking distance to Hop on Hop off stops, Notre dame, the Seine, metro stations and so much more.
Amazing boutiques and galleries (not in my budget unfortunately) and great eateries within minutes.
Loved it here.
Best shopping. This is such a wonderful area for shopping, the sublime Picasso Museum and French character. The shops are not chains or couture, but rather feel more individual, bohemian, local.

I miss the "old Marais.". Ugh, it reminds me of Soho, NY now. It's full of the same type of boutiques. Crowded, touristy and lacking any real authentic character, like it had before. When I see an H&M or American Outfitters, I usually run. Do a fly by, but don't spend too much time there. So many other fab places!

Older Jewish neighborhood with fabulous delis and boutiques along with upscale restaurants. Marais is a more and more popular place to stay,with AirBnB's abounding. Great eats and shops.Found great scarves for little money and had gelato on a cone the employees make in the shape of a flower

Rue charlot in Marais is an apartment to stay in. The Marais area is a great area to visit. Walkable and many small pubs - diners; featuring local food. A great place to stay and walkable to all other features- or public transit

Perfect Neighborhood to Explore. I love the Marais - it is the perfect neighborhood of narrow, attractive streets, small neighborhood specialty markets, great coffee places and a colorful array of locals and tourists for people-watching.My wife and i always find that taking time off from a continuous stream of well-known tourist attractions, and just wandering through the stunning neighborhoods of Paris, is the best part of our trip. Don't miss it!

Favorite neighborhood in Paris. I have walked many of the arondissments in Paris many times. The Marais is my favorite by farTONS of boutique little fashion shops with nice clothes - in all range of prices. Lots of hidden restaurants, bars etc.Plenty of hotels and, most importantly, air bnb options here.Close to the Louvre, picasso museum, and plenty of other things!

the Marais is Paris for real. wow what a change I find myself in with the Marais.Last year I didn’t like it at all dirty full of dog…. people unfriendly suspicious people.Well, what a change firstly les Halle are newly renovated with a new dome just the garden to be done.Most streets are now walking streets and so clean. The shops are clean and renovated.Friendly is defiantly the case everywhere I went to from restaurants to coffee shopsClothe shops Etc. A total renewed old part.I find some manu new places making the Marais so exciting
Very crowded. Lots of stores which are open on Sunday which is nice since all stores in Paris are closed on Sunday. It is very crowded and not much to see.

Good Place for tourists to stay. This area is huge and a great place to stay with cheaper accomodations compared to accomodations in areas like st. germain and champs ellysees. But it could be a little trick as the most happening areas in st. germain is difficult to find if you dont research and book you hetels properly. But there are great pubs and cafes all around this area.

Stroll around le Marais . Visited le Marais for a few hours this afternoon, lovely relaxing walk around some independent shops and restaurants. The area was recommended by our tour guide from 2cvparistour.com and it was an excellent recommendation

Beautiful and quite ... amazing !. Le Marais is located on the 3e arrondissement a few minutes walking from Notre Damme. The stores are opened all week and Sunday is a very strong day for local business, hence to go shopping as well. There are streets closed due to this fact I found here a peaceful place and an imperative place to visit and go for a walk.Streets are narrow and full of people from everywhere taking advantage of the beautiful gardens such as Place des Voges, garden of an hotel at Rue du Temple Vieille and Carré du Tempe.
Intersting & very good food. We really enjoyed exploring this area. Great shopping too. And the food here is delicious. Great vibes in this quarter. Not to be missed
Paris chic. Art , music , fashion , eat , drink , history , modern , Paris, , gay , Jewish history , what else you need for a weekend ? :)
great place to visit.. Brilliant boutiques, galleries and restaurants. Well worth a visit. Take time to have a bite to eat and a glass of wine or a walk in the park. This is a hidden gem in Paris
Delightful walking and shopping. We spent out last day in the Le Marais district and it was an excellent choice. Lots of shops and restaurants to choose from and many pedestrian only streets.

Great place for a vibrant day in Paris . I would recommend this area as there are little boutiques with exceptional unique things, coffee shops, restaurants and Pompidou and Picasso museum are there as well.

Best of Paris. First of all, we are not big museum fans (some how I get super tired very quickly in museums). And how many different angles of Eiffel can you really appreciate? Champ E. Blvd had more American chain stores (GAP) than your neighborhood mall. Le Marais has the quintessential Paris feel. With every turn of the corner, every boutique shop, brasserie, boulangerie, restaurant, falafel house, you feel as though you are in a movie set in urban Paris. Rent an apartment and stay here in this district.

Interesting Walk through This Neighborhood. On my walk from St Honore to the Picasso Museum, I enjoyed the crowds along the way. There was a street singer with several musicians, a neighborhood market (on this particular weekend), lots of people and shops. I stopped at the market to taste the dates and look at the various booths, and later in the Jewish section, I looked in a shop with all things Jewish, nothing I wanted but very interesting.

Very nice!. I was in Paris for 5 days on an adult class trip so we went all over inner city Paris going to sights and museums, and I gotta say Marais was by far my favourite place. It's a calm and cozy neighbor with a lot of nice little interesting stores and back alleys. It was one of few places I didnt feel like I had to watch out for pickpockets. Just a relaxing part of the town.

Wonderful hip area!. Great hip and diverse place to find an Airbnb and just stroll and bump into wonderful restaurants, cafes, shops, bars etc. Lots of hidden places within Le Marais to discover. I highly recommend it.

Shopping experience. Though the other reviews say how trendy this area is, it does have a lot of small shops, though it also has a dirty side as well, it is separated into a class division, the high end and the low end, we walked around for quite a few hours and experienced all of it, though the little alleyways in the low end did not feel safe at all, once again great for fashion, food, souvenirs, we loved BHV department store and went back quite a few times, many male fashion stores here selling really good clothes at good prices, great little restaurants and bistros, sort of like Prahran and South Yarra in Australia.

Lovely district. The Marais is a lovely area of Paris, perfect for walking around on a quiet afternoon. The whole are is quite romantic, full of places to sit down for a drink or a quick bite to eat, and is also filled with locals who actually live here. Excellent for some people watching!

Unique charm here. So, I lived in Paris for about a year a long time ago, but I rarely ventured into the Marais. I made Le Marais the focus of a recent trip to Paris. What can one say about the unique charm of this neighborhood, which combines the old Paris of little cafes and brasseries, with art and haut-couture, not to mention a beautiful and diverse Jewish quarter. I recommend starting at the Place de la Bastille and walking down rue St. Antoine, turning right into the Place des Vosges...beautiful. A good thing to note here is that the shops and cafes are under an arcade, so this is a good option for a drizzly day meal or drink. Exit the Place des Vosges from the northwest corner and go down to the Musee Carnavalet, then turn left and just wander around, making your way down to the Seine.
Wanderings in Paris. What a great neighborhood. Wander the streets, get lost (we did) and enjoy the shops, people and sights.

Paris highlights . Best place to stay surrounded by bars and places to eat , great open market with all types of food , sites to see Picasso museum , get lost in the laneways and find most amazing places

Shopping chilling on Sunday. One of my fav area in Paris, love that it's open on Sunday. Have all kind of shop n cafe. Come here every time when i visit Paris. Love it's vibe. The museums and gallery in here are nice to visit too.
hippest part of paris as far as im concerned. flea markets, hip little boutiques and great resaurants and cafes. whats not to like?? I recommend a day here!
Great area for exploring. This is a lovely area of Paris for walking. Lots of little streets with tallish old buildings. Great stores and restaurants. Highly recommended.

A must see. There is plenty here to interest visitors. The Marais is in central Paris and it is a great and very convenient place to stay, with a good choice of hotels and short-term rental apartments. There are about 10 museums within the area, a huge selection of cafes and restaurants and some excellent shopping opportunities as well. The main department store is BHV and there are plenty of fashion boutiques along the rue des Francs-Bourgeois and its enjoining streets. The Marais also has excellent food shopping, including some very good chocolate shops and patisseries.

I would love to live here. What a sensational district. Shops, food, bakeries, fashion, galleries and restaurants that are much better than your average Paris tourist joint with a tout out front. My daughter is fortunate enough to be living in the heart of Le Marais for 6 months and having spent the last week in Paris close by on the edge of Le Marais I would have no hesitation in ensuring I was located in the heart of Le Marais for my next visit.

2nd stay in Le Marais. This trip I stayed in an apartment on rue Saint-Paul. I felt it was very well located, close to the Saint-Paul Metro (line 1) which seemed to take me almost everywhere I needed to go. Also close to the Sully Morland Metro stop (line 7). Good bus routes; 69 and 86 were the ones I used most often. As others have said, the Marais is very crowded on a Sunday. There is a lot to do and see. I found good restaurants, a multitude of boulangeries, fruit stands and places to grab a quick bite to bring back to the apartment. All I could need was right outside my door. I felt very safe at all times of the day and night. The only thing drawback was that my rental apartment was noisier than I'm used to (I live in the woods, it's pretty quiet). My apartment windows faced an interior courtyard, so there was no street noise. But with my windows open, I could hear the conversations of my neighbors who also had their windows open. The interior courtyard acted as an amplifier. I could hear dishes being taken out of cupboards, cutlery clinking, etc. My neighbors were pretty considerate, no late partying, etc. Just normal daily living noises that I'm not used to hearing. I suppose if I lived in a city full-time , I wouldn't have noticed the noise at all. This is probably pretty common to anywhere in a city where the windows open to an interior courtyard. Not a knock or criticism on the Marais at all! Just a comment that if you think you'll be in a quieter apartment if your windows open to a courtyard rather than the street, it might not be as quiet as you think. With the windows closed, I heard little noise. But if you like fresh air, you'll hear your neighbors. On my next visit to Paris, I'd return to Le Marais. It feels like home.
Great area to visit. . Would definitely recommend coming here. Lots of cute little streets full of great architecture and amazing shopping. Area is eclectic and will make you fall in love with Paris.

Paris way of life!. If you want to see how Parisian lives a lively life stay and explore this area. It is amazing! It is full of galleries, shopping stores, boulengeries, cafes, restaurants, museums, churches, patisseries, and nightlife party. It is safe to walk day and night. I love this place!
The most amazing place in Paris. This is where I stayed. Right in the heart of the city; rather crowded and loud but I loved it! It has so many charms! A must see!

Sunday in the Marais. I am not sure there is anything better to do on a Sunday in Paris than wander through the Marais. There is so much to see and do from fabulous cafes and shops to beautiful hidden gardens and courtyards. It was a perfect way to spend a Sunday and there were so many interesting things to see and do that hours went by in total enjoyment of this gorgeous area. It was very vibrant and lively despite overcast skies. Although it was busy it felt like there was plenty of room for everyone to just wander and to relax and enjoy . the gardens and museums are just divine and I now have a new favourite place in Paris.

Perfect place to stay for a first visit to Paris. I loved staying in le Marais my first time in Paris. I was walking distance to the Notre Dame Catherdral, plus many great shops and restaurants. Easy access to the whole city on foot or by metro (Chatelet/Les Halles station will connect you with the entire network, including easy access to the CDG airport). Highly recommended.

Charming - A plus - Eat and loose weight!. We rented an apartment for 2 weeks on Rue d'Orchampt. Very close to Place de Tetre and Sacre Coeur. Love the area. Very hilly so if you walk everywhere which we did you can eat the wonderful pastries and breads without worrying too much about gaining weight. The locals are in great shape! Montmartre is so beautiful with amazing atmosphere. I could not stop taking photos. If you use the subway (Abbess Metro) is very close and easy to use you may see musicians every evening performing - we did.

Very pretty shopping area . A walk through Le Marais can transport you to another time. The cobbled, winding streets are unlike the rest of the city and its very quaint. There are lots of great shops, both well known and independent and you could easily spend a full day here. There are also plenty of good cafes and restaurants as well a great kosher delis and patisseries.

Amazing neighborhood that brings out the Parisian spirit . We chose to stay in Marais because friends recommended this area for Paris newbies like us. So charming with plenty of restaurants, shops, cafes and bars in the middle of charming Paris.
Love this neighboorhood. We love this neighborhood for its cafes, restaurants and shopping. Such a walkable area, everyone should make this part of their Paris experience.

Experiencing the vibrant heart of Paris!. The Marais happens to be the historical heart of Paris. And though it does hold a truly authentic mood, it is also one of the most hype site of the parisian life (day / night). Certainly one of the best 'arrondissement' to experience the parisian way of life.Some must see spots :Shops : Merci, l'éclaireur, etc. ...Shops / Restaurant : la maison Plisson, Nanashi, Mariage frères, Sentou Galerie,

Don't bother to arrive before 10am. Le Marais is a very interesting quarter, with some of the oldest buildings in Paris. Lots of Jewish food stores (buy poppy seed strudel!) and small designer shops (as well as a few multinationals like Uniqlo). Many of the oldest hotel buildings are signposted with their history (some go back to 15th century) and Place des Voges is a must see. But nothing really opens before 10-11am.

Lively interesting area. Visited this area for a look-around and some lunch. Would consider staying in this area next trip. Many eateries and nice shops and seemed very lively. Not enough time to really explore the area but would suggest a visit especially for the younger trendier group.

great place to shop for clothes, eat great food and hang out in cafes. I love spending time in this district....one can find all kinds of food and restaurants from simple to elegant...I love Mariage Freres Tea Salon...desserts are great. Chez Helene for candy is beautiful. In this small area one can really get a great feel of this wonderful city. Musee Carnevalet is so unique. Great place to wonder about.

Everything people say about the neighborhood is true!. Vibrant, less touristy neighborhood with interesting streets, shops, boutiques, cafes! Upon arrival in Paris, we immediately went out to explore the neighborhood! We were delightfully thrown into an authentic Parisien Sunday afternoon with many families, young people, seniors, couples and singles, all just strolling the streets browsing in the shops, sitting at the cafes enjoying each others company with their wine, beer or coffee, etc! Everyone seemed so happy and friendly! We stayed near the Picasso museum and I never once felt unsafe. It was a first day in Paris experience I'll never forget! It put me in the "Parisien" mood immediately!
Impreesive night life. Plenty of shops, restaurants and bars it is now as busiest as the quartier latin, but not so widely spread. Very gay venue in all aspects.
My fave nabe. Full of trends and old-time establishments, this bustling yet manageable neighborhood has everything you need. Great location and place to wander from

Very historical. This was the Jewish Quarter and is now the home of a large Asian population as well as the LGBTQ district. There are many thriving and colorful markets so make sure that you visit the side streets.

The coolest and hippest. This area has the most eclectic brand shops (think Cos, all saints, Fred Perry). Very cool, much cleaner and neater than the rest is Paris, also a great Jewish area on rue des rosiers. Check it out!!!

A great spot to spend an afternoon or morning strolling around looking at shops and having some lunch. There is possibly no better place in Paris to while away a few hours. Eat early to ensure you get a good spot to watch the world go by and order a Rose wine on a hot day
Fantastic area. Stayed in the rue de Temple. Couldn't have been happier. Quiet and lots of places to buy food. It was close to Notre Dame and the Centre Pompidou.

Vibrant place to stay. We have spent the last week in the Marais and have loved it. The streets are lively at night with the many people who live here and the various peep show marquees add a quirky touch.

best location. Great place, cafes,restaurants, shops and bars no need for bus, metro or taxis, just walk around, all flat and easy. Friendly place and safe at night. Place de Voges......cafes and galleries galore. Picasso museum closed Monday. Walking distance for Pompidou and D'orsay.
Charming. Gay gay gay! It is the gay spot in Paris! So it is loud and party time! Great bars and restaurants to choose. Amazing peoples to chat away with, fun and colorful lives....

Le Marais!. One if my favorite places in the world; part-owner of apartment since 2010: Les Philosophes, Lizard Lounge, La Belle Hortense, L'Improbable, Breakfast in America, Museum Carnavalet, Picasso Museum, BHV, Sunday Street Scene, bikes, shopping, walking - Tres Bon!

Delicious treats at Manon.. We return to this Patisserie very time we visit Paris and Place des Vosges and it was just as much a treat again. Coffee with a Citron Meringue tart for one and Frambroise tart for the other.
Both were delicious and a s good as ever.
The Marais is fascinating and BHV is certainly a store to visit.
Great area. The Marais is one of those cool neighborhoods that feels like an authentic experience a little off the tourist path.

Nice neighborhood you can visit. visit the street called Rue des Francs Bourgeois and combine that walk with a visit to Pompidou (Le Voltigeur ice-cream and crepe shop). Take a break at the end of that street at Place des Vosges
bohemian - cool !. This quarter is still on the up with many small shops , lots of landmark sites and nice little cafes and restaurants - most shops open on Sunday !

Historic, eclectic and beautiful. The title words from 'City walks in Paris - 50 adventures on foot'. Very apt. Wonderful place to stay while visiting Paris. Great to stroll around, many very good restaurants, bars and trendy shops. Bakeries excel! Everything close by where we stayed on Rue St-Gilles. Fantastic Thursday and Sunday market just off Beaumarchais. Would stay in this area again.
Lively Urban Stroll. We usually stay in or near the Marais. The architecture, street life, smells, and storefronts are intoxicatingly stimulating and quintessentially Parisian.

One of the best, trendiest neighborhoods in Paris. It is expensive here, but it sure is beautiful. Great shops, good food and a central location. It is a bit over the top, but nonetheless a great neighborhood to walk around in.

Entertaining and Fabulous. When you're finished seeing the requisite sights for a true Parisian experience discover the Marais. Watch the people, window shop, say "Bonjour, Madame or Monsieur" upon entering a shop or enjoy the Pompidou. It's really fun to stay at one of the small chic boutique hotels. We always stay at the Hotel Caron de Beaumarchais on Rue de Vieille Temple watching everyone go by from the upper windows. The street is blocked to vehicles on weekends. Cafés serving coffee or tasty local dishes and smallish shops are everywhere. The Seine is but 3 blocks away. Paris is a jewel with some parts polished and others in the rough. Have fun! The French are friendly and interesting to all who smile and greet them. Best to leave your sweats, distressed jeans and baseball caps home.M. Keller

Parisian Gem of a Neighborhood!. I love staying in the Marais! It's away from the big hotels, tourist bustle and crush of Paris but right on the edge of it to make tourist spots easily accessible. The shopping is wonderful especially for clothes, perfumes, patisseries and a great array of restaurants. And stop and pause to take in the courtyards and gardens on your walks.

Hip neighborhood. We chose to stay in the Marais because it's a cool neighborhood, rather than near the tourist attractions. The Picasso museum is here, along with wonderful shops and cafes in a residential part of the city. The old mansions, converted to apartment buildings, are 6-8 stories. No high rises. Wandering the narrow streets was charming and romantic. It all felt very hip, fun, and safe.

Wonderful Atmosphere Food and Cafes. Put your comfy shoes on and meander there isn't a dull corner, there are a myriad of incredible eateries and cafes bars and the shopping is varied and is mainly boutique. Loved this area very friendly and cool at the same time. Walking distance to the Seine and many other attractions.

Had the best falafel here!. It's a lovely place to stroll and shop without feeling paranoid but it would also instantly make you feel hungry with so many taking away their so good smelling wraps of falafel that I just had to line up for one as well and it was so worth the visit to Le Marais!

Great walking area. This old section of the city is interesting for architecture, history, and food. The narrow streets are filled with interesting small shops and big name stores. The book stores are noteworthy for browsing.

Lovely neighbourhood to stay in. This was my second time in paris and i wanted to be in a good suburb, in terms of proximity to central paris and also safety.I'm very happy with what i saw and had access to in Le Marais, i walked everywhere, all the way to the Eiffel tower, however there are lots of public transport options around too if you are not a keen walker like me :)I would definitely stay here again

Favorite arrondissement in Paris. Entwined in many small streets, The Marais is one of the most charming Quartier in Paris. So many great small restaurants, art galleries, food markets, museums. Whenever I visit Paris, I always rent a small apt. In the Marais through different rental companies on the web. It turns out to be cheaper and way more spacious than a dinky three star hotel. They usually require a minimum of a three night stay. My favorite square is Place des Vosges. You will stumble on so many great small restaurants. Never had a bad meal. You are in walking distance to the Pompidou center and the charming Picasso museum along with several other great small museums like the Carnavalet. So many cafes to spend hours people watching. The Marais has a great assortment of eclectic people. I prefer this area over the left bank which is very touristic and not as authentic.

Great Neighborhood for walking . Great area to walk and look into the unique shops that it has to offer. The area also has small cafes and different ethnic restaurants. A great area to spend a few hours exploring.

Great walking tour.. My wife and I love to walk the neighbourhoods of world cities we visit. The Marais in Paris is one of our favourites! We have visited it on two occasions and always find something new of interest. Lots of designers' stores, cafés etc.

Gorgeous . Oodles of eateries, shops and beautiful architecture. Underground station works made it a little bit hard to get around but worth getting lost...make sure you have a good map!Find a jazz club...Sunup sinset club was brilliant...
FOOD TOUR!. We took a tour of the Marais with Paris By Mouth. If you want to get to know the neighborhood and the divine food it has to offer, I highly recommend it as the best way to do so.
a wonderful walk. The old Jewish quarter is filled with small shops, lovely bistros and very close to the Picasso Museum--walk through until you reach Place des Vosges
Great Area. We are walkers and the Marais area is just has a pinach to it.We walked through great shopping area and saw a good mix of retail stores and residentials.

So many cafes and bars!. This area is packed full of bars and cafes. You could your way around the world here, and go for a pub crawl just in one road. Amazing district that is really up and coming. Must be crazy at night for those who are young!

The most charming quartier of Paris. Well worth the hours of exploring this historical quartier of Paris. Just walking from one street to another, so much to discover. The colombages, unique architecture, cobblestones, churches, squares etc etc. Great small tapas bars, happy hours in a small sidewalk cafe, tea houses and small cosy restaurants for all appetites. Also to mention all the small specialty shops. A absolute must when in Paris.

very vital and energetic area. This is a great area of the city to visit and hang out in...or live in for 3 months like I am right now. Lots of diversity in the 3rd for sure. Great little shops, cafes, bistros and just walk around the area. Everything you could want.

Lots of beautifully restored old residential buildings. Very pleasant to walk around this neighborhood and to appreciate such a variety of charming old structures, especially Pl de la Vosages. There are lots of nice pastry, grocery shops as well as cafes & restaurants. Wish I had planned more time to spend in this neighborhood.

A lovely surprise. We enjoyed a Free Discovery walking tour of this less well known area. I'd recommend a visit, and to use the Free Discovery guides. Palace de Vosges was excellent as were some of the hidden areas of older grand houses.

Heart and Soul of Paris. Le Marias is just chock full of restaurants, galleries, wine bars and shops. All within walking distance or a short cab ride to nearby Opera or Chatelet districts. Hotels abound, as do museums and markets. My first choice (if I have one) when staying in Paris.

Very Cool place to visit.. We stayed 3 days in Le Marais before starting a tour. We loved being local and walking distance to many classic Paris sights,great cafes and great nightlife. Wonderful shopping, a few lovely museums, great food and accessible by Metro. Despite all that it was quiet at night and we slept very well each night.
Love the setting. Some very unique art galleries located here. A quiet park in the middle and the Sully Hotel is a gem.

I'd stay here again. We chose to stay in an apartment as we were a family of five, and I would recommend staying in the area. It was an easy 10 minute walk to the Seine river, the Louvre, Palais Royal. Just two minutes up the road there is a great pedestrianized street full of cafe's, bakery's and a small supermarkets. There are local markets near by on the weekend. Transport is easy with a number of Metro stations nearby and also the RER station which can take you out to the airport.  A bustling location making you feel like a local!

A beautiful park. It was soo hot the day we visited. There were tons of shade trees. We walked around and also sat in the shade under a big tree. Lots of French families wer sunning on the grass playing with their children. amorino a fabulous gelato place was a block or so from park. They make the most beautiful tulip designs on ice cream cones! carol6440
The best!. This is my favourite district in Paris. I like it so much. It's the old city of Paris, so charming and unique.

Great neighborhood. We stayed in an apartment in Le Marais during our first trip to Paris. It was the perfect home base for walking everywhere. There are many, many cafes and restaurants at a variety of price points plus markets, bakeries and the G20 supermarkets. Lots of young people, not many tourists, and many historical sites and museums. Highly recommend this arrondissement as your home in Paris. You'll feel like a local.

My favorite neighborhood. It's hard to choose a favorite place In Paris but, even so, I dare to confess that Le Marais is mine. Little streets filled with artists, jazz, museums, nice boutiques and lovely food: Le Marais does have it all!

Great happening beautiful area. I love strolling around this area that is so parisian. Old streets, beautiful boutiques, great terrasses, wonderful little restaurants, we found the people very friendly too. Enough museum, squares and subway station nearby to go anywhere else in paris. I love le marais I love paris
Typical Paris. One of the most typical neighborhoods of Paris. Walking in the typical streets with beautifull shops. We have been in a good Jewish restaurant.

Heart of the city. Everyone thinks of the Eiffel Tower or the Arc de Triomphe as Paris but to really feel the pulse of the place, go to Le Marais and experience a real Parisian suburb. Stylish shopping streets of chic boutiques, winding little back streets lined with beautiful apartment blocks, hidden and not so hidden, churches and wall to wall cafes and bars full of Parisians living their daily lives. Great place.

A wonderful corner of Paris. Le Marais is a really interesting neighborhood. There are narrow streets lined with shops, cafés and restaurants of all kinds, beautiful mansions, museums (inlcuding the Picasso Museum), parks and squares.A stroll through the streets of Le Marais is highly recommended.
Great vibe!. A wonderful area to wander in, particularly in the smaller streets. Everything from big stores to lovely little boutiques and great cafes for people-watching.

Le Marais is like Beyoglu of Istanbul.. Le Marais reminded me the vibe of Beyoglu / Karakoy of Istanbul and I adored it. Just feel free to get lost in the narrow streets and find your own way. On your way to find it, you will find some cool vinyl stores, Gay bars and lovely café's. And definitely spend some time (and money if you like). If it is your first time I'd suggest you to see all the touristic points and then experience areas like this (or Bastille for example).
Great Neighborhood. A wonderful place to explore. Great food and shops. Wonderful historical locations around every corner. Don't miss the Picasso Museum.
A nice. This neighbourhood is quite representative of Paris and its enticing architecture. I do however prefer other parts of Paris a little more.

Best part of Paris. We have been to Paris several times and this is the first time we have stayed in the Marais, such a nice area. Full of small bars and interesting restaurants and small quirky shops. Easy to get lost in the winding streets but who cares.
Just a great area to walk through. As the title says, great area to visit. Shops to see good range of restaurants to visit. Recommend visiting and taking in the atmosphere

Nice Neighborhood . We stayed in this neighborhood for two weeks in a small comfortable hotel which was not frequented by many Americans. Lots of restaurants within easy walking distance as were many attractions. A fun place.
Wonderful walk. Wonderful place for walking, for a lunch in many of local restaurants or just a coffee, this place has a rellly unique atmosphere.
Do a Marais tour. We love the Marais in fact so much we stayed there in our last trip to Paris. Don't forget to try the Falafel's at L'As du Fallafel in Rue de Rosiers - awesome!!

The Place to Be on Sunday. Enjoyed a beautiful warm day wandering the narrow streets with lots of Parisians. Plenty of places to eat and get ice cream or gelato. Most of the stores are open unlike the rest of Paris.

One of the most vivid and beautiful districts of Paris. The choises here are unlimited. You need at least one whole day to enjoy it. It's a must, for food and drinks, also for art lovers, since there is a number of good art galleries around.

Merveilleux Marais. We were told that this was a hip and expensive part of Paris. We found the medieval street lines, the architecture, the shops and market as well as the transport links all worked to make this a great place to stay. There were so many walking, shopping, sightseeing options when' we didn't want a big sightseeing day as tourists. We just soaked up,the vibe and enjoyed the everyday life here. There was a good community feel.
Lively arrondissement. One of the liveliest parts of Paris, I love to go there to do shopping and eat a bite. It is always a bit crowded, but it feels so Parisian all the time. Recommended!

Fascinating . What a lovely area of Paris. Just walk and walk and walk and you'll see wondeful cobblestone streets, markets and hidden away antique shops. A very pretty and interesting part of Paris. Totally worth going to see.
Meandering. Get lost in the back streets of the Marais mingle with the locals enjoy quirky shops and the wonderful Picasso gallery.

Oh, how I love this area!. We stayed here once or twice in the past but not this time. I love the Marais. It's unique and filled with treasures, wonderful shops and great places to eat. I love Place des Vosges and the surrounding streets. It's great at night and on Sunday's when other areas are more closed down. Try Crepe Suzette or the Breizh Cafe for especially good crepes. Fragonard is a lovely shop, as well.
walk walk walk. A great place to a leisurely walk with your lover. I love very much less crowded environments like this.

Le Marais the ideal place to stroll and have a coffee. Old buildings, place des Vosges, great shopping in the little streets... The whole neighborhood is a great cultural mix with an incredible variety of athmospheres.

Excellent walk.. We had a long walk through Le Marais, it was lovely. If you are a shopaholic then Le Marais is the place for you. We didn't do too much shopping as there is so much to see in Paris. We did enjoy this area though.

Most fascinating arrondissement of Paris. I love the Marais! You can find little cobbled streets with fantastic boutiques, galleries, incredible old mansions, the newly renovated Picasso museum, incredible restaurants, amazing small restaurants, covered markets, nightlife - you name it. To me its one of the most fascinating and authentic parts of Paris and whenever I visit Paris I spend hours exploring this district.

walk around. this section of the city is for slow strolling, sitting outside bistros with wine & cheese ( remember the Parisian millennials are chain smokers) & generally enjoying the sights of people etc

Take a stroll thru and about the Marais.. Make sure to get a neighborhood map and start on a selected path but quickly just ramble the narrow streets stopping at sights/shops that catch your eye. A calm beauty but a lived in setting where the people simply enjoy their lives and carrying out their acts of daily living. A must stop is the Breizh Café for their amazing crepes. Skip the lunch crepe and go with the dessert offering. All potions are huge and delicious.

chic quartier. we enjoyed our walks in Le Marais, we found the area very pleasant,it's not as crowded as other sights in Paris, a lot of boutiques, many jewellery stores, some of them not expensive :) my wife bought a pair of nice earrings with 30 euro,cobblestone streets ,similar to Rione Monti in Rome
Pleasant Place to Stroll and Dream. Wonderful old buildings and lots of up market shops. Not a great deal of traffic, so a relaxed feel. Take the time to soak up the ambience of Paris.
An artisanal area. Great shopping in the small streets lots of small boutiques as well as better known names. Huge number of cafes and bars.
Nice place to stay. Very trendy location, and centrally located. Even if you don't stay here, it's worth wandering the streets.
Many shops closed on Monday. Excellent shopping and great dining. Do not miss Picasso museum. Expect big crowds on Sundays as the rest of Paris shops closed.
Good for a stroll. I like to come Le Marais for a stroll even when I didn't do any purchase. You could see many locals and tourists at the same time and many beautiful buildings.

Le Marais is the ideal location!. We visited Paris for eight days last fall, staying in a great little apartment on Rue des Blancs Manteaux. The street itself was perfect, being a quiet spot to unwind after busy days checking out the city. The Marais has wonderful character and some interesting spots to check out, such as the Carnavalet (history of Paris), and the Musee National Picasso, and the Centre Pompidou (modern art) just steps away. Walk to Place des Vosges and check out Victor Hugo's former home, or just enjoy people watching. The Place de la Bastille is close by (although not there's not much to see there any more) and there are tons of little shops and restaurants everywhere. When you get hungry, you must try the falafel at L'As du Falafel (worth the line-up, which is always there) or sit down and try the boeuf bourguignon at Les Philosophes. These streets are quite old and atmospheric! Go for a romantic stroll on the Seine after dinner.You are always only a few minutes from a metro station (St. Paul's, Hotel de Ville, Les Chatelets, etc,) to take you in any direction, whether it's Montmartre, the Eiffel Tower or the Champs Elysees. Other spots such as Notre Dame or the Louvre are an easy walk away. Bertie's Cupcakes, on Rue Chanoinesse around the corner from Notre Dame is a must-see if you have a hankering for a sweet. You're also walking distance (albeit a little longer) from great spots like Saint Sulpice, Luxembourg Palace, the Sorbonne, Cafe de Flore and Les Deux Magots.I can't think of a better neighbourhood to stay in than the Marais if you want to be surrounded by history, art and the beauty of Paris. Enjoy!

Nice area in Paris . Marais is a nice and lovely area in Paris. A lot of boutiques, shops and restaurants in a great mix. We stayed for fore nights in a hotel in the area. We walked a lot and we could walk to several sights and tourist attractions. The area felt safe. My spouse have lived in Paris for a few years and she thinks this is one of the best areas to stay in when visiting Paris.

A slice of heaven in bustling Paris. I was determined to spend time in Le Marais and enjoyed very moment. So much to see and enjoy. The art galleries had some stunning displays and there were many interesting little shops. Shame in a way to see the intrusion of 'chain' stores - would love it to stay more independent and artistic (in all forms of the word). A must when visiting Paris
Cathy . Love this section of paris...would like to see list of shops with the locations provided for visiters.

Great atmosphere, good food and friendly staff!. We had a very nice diner in a warm & friendy place! Good and honest food combineren with helpfull and frendly staff made our stay here very pleasant. We would come here again when we are in Paris!
A nice neighborhood. Stayed here for five days. Great area for food shops, restaurants, and people watching. People are friendly in the shops once you frequent them more than once.

Great place to eat, shop and people watch. We spent a week in the Le Marais area and walked nearly every inch of it. This is a great area and chock full of things to do including eating the best Jewish veal pastrami sandwich I have ever eaten (Shwartzes). Most of the clothing shops are for small statured people and my tall girlfriend found virtually nothing to wear. Even so, it's a great place, and I recommend staying there.
Nice area. I would recommend it if you do not really know where to go. It offers easy access to most of the sight-seeing and is a lively place.
B-E-A-U-T-I-F-L. I was new to the neighborhood, found it nice, close to everything, has everything you need felt like a real parisian when living there

Excellent part of Paris. We stayed in Le Marais and I loved this neighborhood. It was perfect for what we are looking for. Good food, art and shopping. I would recommend staying in this district if visiting Paris.
Great area. We stayed in an apartment here for a week. You can walk many, many shops and restaurants. Centre de Pompideau is walking distance and very interesting.

Quaint but becoming too touristy. We like the Marais and it is a great accessible district of Paris to wander around for a few hours. There are lots of interesting small shops, cafes and restaurants, and plenty of cool scruffy architecture. There are different parts, such as the exclusive Place des Vosges or the more run-down (chabby chic) Jewish quarter. But it is becoming more and more gentrified and touristy, and has less of a genuine feel than in the past, so its nice to visit the quieter northern parts as it approaches Republique

Great neighborhood. Was there very briefly but felt like the safest place in Paris. So clean, quaint, peaceful and pretty. Wonderful cafes all around, affordable too. Great place to find Kosher, if you are. Would love to rent an apartment there for a couple of weeks. It's still central to Paris, yet has this cozy homey feel.

Fantastic for Walks and Shopping. Le Marais is a great and super busy district in Paris. I love to walk here, shop, stop for tea and just people watch. While people in Paris are super stylish, style goes to the next level here in the Marais, thanks to the denizens of this neighborhood! Love the Marais.

The perfect neighbourhood. It's is a amazing neighbourhood quite near to the center of Paris, if I can say, I would love to live there. The are to many things to see, like, Place des Voges, or if you want to eat something, there are to many diferent tipical foods, like Empanadas...well worth the visit and there's no need to expend money!
this is the oldest place in paris. well it was, now a place for existentialist, writers, gay people and also rue mouffetard where is one of the best market of paris

Nice but getting pricey. It is one of the nicest neighborhoods in Paris. It feels like there's always something happening in this place. Best falafel in Paris (As du Falafel) usually has a line. It's soothing to walk around, enter the public gardens, the museums. Be wary, the shops are on the upper scale. Still a nice place to spend your evening.

a great area to just wander through on weekends. from the old Jewish area to the Picasso museum to funky boutiques and restaurants amidst also the encroachment of large chain stores too...the heart of it remains mostly closed to traffic on the weekends so lovely to stroll through.
Eat falafel.... This neighborhood is a pretty place. You can find middle east foods here. I recommend you to eat falafel. Eat and walk between roads.

Good place to find trendy presents and clothes. This area is not so crowded by tourists yet. There are many clothing stores as well as Jewelry stores that you can't find in big department store. Hence if you are looking for presents that are not high fashion yet chic, this is the place. Main shopping area is along Rue des Francs Bourgeois leading to Place des Vosges. Place des Vosges is a nice park to sit and rest your tired feet.

A Feast for your Eyes. Le Marais district is one of the most charming in Paris, very busy & bustling with locals and tourists at weekends it's crammed full of both wide and narrow streets filled with trendy shops and all kinds of eateries from small middle Eastern Falafal places to bistros of all kinds. It's part Jewish quarter, part gay quarter and totally absorbing, central feature is the Place des Vosges park which in early spring is simply stunning. Surrounded by covered walkways filled with art galleries and restaurants it's a place you can never tire of.

One of the trendiest neighbourhoods in Paris. Even my guide wondered how his group came to explore Le Marais, a district steep in aristocrat legacy and home to those who needed shelter. Le Marais, on the Right Bank starting near Hôtel de Ville is a vibrant district of shops, gastronomy and art galleries. It’s quite a trendy district, with many outwardly attractions but also holds many hidden corners and secrets, which is why a walking tour with a local guide was worth it. For instance, I would not have ventured into Square Saint-Gilles du Grand Veneur which is peaceful enclave surrounded by residential apartments. There are many many secrets like this in Le Marais. Hence the allure.For Le Marais, I decided to join a walking tour organised by Discovery Walks Paris. One of the thing that attracted me to them was the idea that their guides are Parisians who have lived there, grew up there and therefore better suited to share the more intimate secrets about the city. For Le Marais, that local knowledge is crucial.Place des Vosges was once meant to be the royal residence and here lived the aristocrats and noblemen at the time. This is one of the prettiest squares I’ve seen in Paris and felt incredibly local. The arcades along Place des Vosges is lined with many discoveries. Even the cafes look so incredibly tempting to me. I like how they look up into the garden square, as the garden is actually one of the prettiest in my opinion in Paris.I was surprised to note that the Marais district did not underwent the big renovations of the Haussmann era. Which means I would be able to appreciate Paris before its current signature look. In one corner of Place des Vosges is a backdoor entrance to the gardens of Hôtel de Sully. It’s not exactly a hotel, but was once the private mansion of Sully, the right hand to the King. He had bought this place to be close to his patron, King Henri IV.When my guide mention that Marais is a trendy district, he wasn’t kidding. As we sat here at Place Sainte-Catherine for a 5 mins break, the number of swanky Parisians, no doubt heading out to the cafes and bistros that lined this square. It’s off the busier shopping streets which makes it a great hideaway from the traffic and shoppers.Hidden under the radar in between Rue de Francs Bourgeois and Rue des Rosiers is a pretty little park, the Rosiers-Joseph Migneret Garden. What was interesting about this garden is that parts of the medieval wall of 12th-century Paris still exists and integrate with its newer buildings.Rue des Rosiers is filled with chic boutiques notable for the trendiest fashion from interesting independent labels. It’s in the heart of the Jewish quarter, "the Pletzl” and the fashion boutiques extend to several adjoining streets. You can really see gentrification at work here. This used to be the heart of the Jewish community. My guide pointed to the example of a famous Jewish bakery in one of the corners which is now a clothing boutique. The original signboards and ornaments remain, perhaps to borrow some authenticity, preserving some semblance of legacy and history in the process.

A slice of true Paris. Le Marais is a big area, spanning the 3rd and 4th Arr. but well worth a day's stroll. Plenty of good value places for lunch, and the BHV itself is with several hours browsing. (I spent 2 hours in the hardware section this afternoon!)It is busy, noisy and not the place for people who want things perfect or who struggle with seriously out there diversity
Marais. Love the Marais!Great shopping, beautiful park Place Des Vosges, historical Jewish section, great restaurants, cafes, etc

Trendy neighbourhood. During our long walks of this amazing city we visited many sites and neighbourhoods, we especially liked the swanky Marais. Located partly within the 3rd and 4th arrondissements on the right bank of the seine. Chock full of vintage and alternative clothing stores, we had a ball just cruising the streets taking it all in.

The best of Paris. I lived here for 45 years ago and the list to say the Mare continues to change year-by-year. Unfortunately it is more crowded with tourists than it ever was and their time is it negotiating the sidewalks is very difficult. But it hasn't lost its charm every year there are more hotels that have been renovated and give a beautiful picture of Paris in the 17th and 18th century. The cafés and restaurants are a lot more upscale and expensive than they used to be but there still charming. The Archives Nationales, the Musee Carnavalet, and the Place des Vosges are not to be missed.
Great neighborhood!. It's great to walk the streets, see the little and cute stores, try restaurants, see people... It is a really great plan for a Saturday afternoon.

A Lovely Part of Paris~. I stayed in this part of Paris for 4 days at the end of a two week trip to Paris & Rome and was not disappointed. This area has a lovely feel to it, plenty of shopping and restaurants. It is not full of tourists which is nice. The restaurants are plentiful and nice, the area is very clean & I found the locals friendly. There are great coffee shops as well and it's a romantic area to stroll in too! Give yourself sometime to see the area if you can!

Pleasant stores great for walking. Nice neighborhood full of shops and bakeries, Great for a pleasant walk and very pretty area full of charm.You get a great feel of downtown Paris in this area of the city.I recommend it.

A Joyous Sunday. On a recent visit to Paris , my wife and I followed travel advice and went to the Marais on a Sunday. We took the train to the Chatelet Les Halles and after a stroll through a nearby street market , we headed toward the Pompidou Center and the Marais beyond. It was a sunny and about 16 degrees C and the narrow twisting streets were filled with a mixture of tourists and Parisians. Many of the streets took on the appearance of a pedestrian mall and people moved aside with the occasional passing of a taxi or other vehicle. Some people were shopping while many were eating food as they walked with falafel sandwiches and gelato seeming to be the most popular choices among many possibilities. There didn't seem to be as many sidewalk cafes as in other areas of Paris but the major focus of the people seemed to be the unhurried strolling along the streets with stops to listen to very talented street musicians or at a museum or to window shop. Everyone seemed to be grateful to be in Paris in such a beautiful area on such a great day. We had no special agenda and for 5 hours, just followed our instincts [ with an eye to our map] and eventually found our way back to the train station and then home.

historic. walked through here to eat at Breizh cafe. It seems like a nice spot although I enjoyed it was a little far from the more tourist- oriented parts of Paris. I think if it's your first trip you might want to stay more central.

A good residential area. Just at the end of nine days in the Marais area. We chose this area for its Psrisian feel and were not disappointed. It has been easy to get around all of Paris from here and it feels safe. There is a laid back feel to the area and most people are friendly. If you want to eat locally it is easy, and not too far if you want to branch out. I haven't been to Paris for over 30 years and the attitude to tourists has changed enormously, for the better.
