Do not hesitate to ask for special places. Go to "Les Enfants Perdus" it's just near la Rue de Bretagne. It's a street market, restaurants, bars... it's tiny but worth to go.

Shop til you drop (then eat!). We will absolutely be returning to this chic, fun neighborhood. Galleries, shops for all price-ranges, and nearly endless-options for eating and drinking. A not-to-miss neighborhood to explore!

Lovedvthe area. We stayed 3 nights in Le Marais. Really enjoyed all the little restaurants, cafés, bars, and shops. There must be every kind of food readily available in this area. Also, a huge variety of art, jewelry, and clothing shops. Our hotel, The Alhambra, was on a quiet side street with very little noise. We were also quite close to the Republique. Would stay in this area again.
Art & shopping area. Very artistic area: nice boutiques and galleries. Perfect for weekend shopping and to have a couple of afternoon drinks.

Les Halles, the soul of the Marais. Although it is still under reconstruction the Halles remain the soul of the Marais. You have to visit this sector of Paris because that is where you really start to discover the daily life. It is quite a lovely area with Beaubourg close by and la Bastille not too far away. Have a nice walk.

My favorite area of Paris, no question.. Without question, Le Marais is my favorite area of Paris. The architecture, the cafes, the stores... just the overall feel of the place is second to none. I've been there during the day as well as at night, and it's perhaps even more stunning when everything is lit up.

Artistic. This section of Paris is one of its most artistic in nature. It hosts the Hotel de Ville which is, in my opinion, the best city hall one can see especially at night. The houses are subtly decorated. Allow a good amount of time to grasp the beauty of the area.
Le Marais is a Must. Exploring the Marais and its sites is a must for visitors to Paris. There are recommended routes and most will require a full day to appreciate it in its fullness.
City centre budget hotel, clean and very friendly. Great location, near to Notre Dame and hop on and hop off Batobus which is the boat on river Seine which drops you at local attractions.
Most visit!. In sunday sunday u can find here open shop, nice gallery and alot of people speek the old and beuty langage Hebrew!

Always action. Museums, department stores, large venues were all closed do to the terrorist attack so we headed to Le Marais. Stores are always open, restaurants are open and there is always action in the street. We walked around the Place de Vosges and all through Le Marais and would up buying gifts across from the Louivre.

Beautiful!. So much to see, architecture was gorgeous! Went to the beautiful Notre Dame then ubur-ed it to Le Marais, that's were I need to return. Haven't seen all of it yet. Staying in this area next time, the 8th arrondismont is nice but Le Marais somehow feels better.

Le Marais / Paris. It's a historic area in the heart of Paris; The Town Hall of Paris, on the Place "Hotel de Ville, very nice construction Renaissance style, (1880) with coupoles and pyramides;In the Marais square is also the museum of Picasso in the hotel Salé; also the museum of Carnavalet is in the Marais, represent the life in Paris under Louis XIII etc.You will find the very known rectangular "Place des Voges" 108 m rectangle, in the middle of the place in the center of trees, une statue in marble of Louis XIII on horse.Nice residences, élegant houses to live and elgant chops, art gallerys.
My favorite place (exit Hotel de Ville). Most of my favorite restaurants are here. The place also offers some galleries, a Jewish quarter, crepes and a great open LGBT atmosphere . Nice to do.

Wander around.. When I was passing through Paris this time my hotel was in the 3rd arrondissement and I ventured upon this attraction, a very pleasant experience, try it yourself, just wander around have a relaxing stroll

A Great Place to get Lost for a Day. Can recommend you put on your walking shoes and spend a day here. Start with a coffee and people watching followed by some retail therapy. From fashion to boutique jewellers and art galleries this is a delightful area. Be sure to finish the day with some people watching by having a drink on a street Café during happy hour.

An area worth walking. this area is filled with great history, shoppes and bistros. Take time to walk the area and tap into the history that is filled with great French culture and History. The bistros and food venders are very ethic and delicious.

Cool independent shops and great atmosphere. We love to find interesting and unusual stuff to wear and for the house and this is the perfect area to fin it !!Also great cafe's and bars and great people-watching !!
Beautiful neighbourhood! !. I could walk there for years :) even when the weather is bad it's just beautiful. Look for an art gallery tour! We did Arternative and they were wonderful.
Nice and relaxing area. A bit bohemian with a lot of cafe and restaurants. Small shops and parks all around. Great for a day of hanging around.

Spectacular!. In addition to be the place where my grandmother and her family lived at the turn of the century, the Quarter holds beautiful charm and history. From the quaint shops, restaurants, and buildings, to the market and Parisian way of life, you will be amazed and delighted...It is more than the old Jewish Quarter. In fact, it is now one of the 'chic' places to live.Not sure how I feel about the expensive boutiques mixing in with the old charm, however.Because the area is so old, many buildings need to be renovated and sometimes the modern additions take away from the area. There is so much history there -- from the Place des Vosages to the Hotel de Ville. The museum (which I will review later) details the significance of the area throughout the years... But, it is the more recent history of the lives lost during WWII and lately, that hit you. The monuments of the poor souls are an emotional wake-up call. (Particularly, with armed guards walking near the Temple and streets.) It is a sad statement that some things never change...

lovely area. we spend day exploring the area. used the metro.this was not my first time to Paris so I did not want to do the tourist things. loved to explore the small shops, looked for quality linen and cloths. wear comfortable shoes!!

Birchy . Nice part of Paris ... Pleasant walk around an old part of France that has kept its charm . Lots of nice little shops and places to buy food ..... Falafel centre of France !!
If you are in Paris or are going take a look here :)
Quaint streets, a great place to walk through. For those of you who wish to do a little window shopping, or shopping, this area of Paris has unique little shops. Not to be missed.

The old Jewish quarter. You need to look carefully (or have a guide) to understand that this was traditionally the Jewish quarter of the city. We recommend looking for one of the entiies that gives walking tours of the area focusing on its Jewish history. Well worth the 45 Euros.

Funky and Charming.... After attempting the larger thoroughfares of shopping, this was a welcome change. It was quiet in comparison and full of lovely little boutiques and cafes. Sweet streets and things to see make this area of Paris an absolute must!

very trendy, nice part of Paris full off boutiques and great shops and restaurants and bars. very nice and trendy part of Paris.great for shopping in little boutiques and shops.excellent restaurants and bars.lovely to walk around nice little streets and place des voges and the Picasso museum.

Best place for shopping in Paris. The best place to do your shopping in Paris !!!
Every shop has unique pieces, made by designers, you will find clothes that you might not find anywhere else !!
So save your shopping money for when you'll get there because you might regret it if you didn't !!!
Beast place for a stroll. The Marais is a neat place to visit for a stroll. There are plenty of interesting shops, cafes and restaurants to visit. The little parks are inviting as well.
Wonderful neighborhood atmosphere. Wonderful neighborhood atmosphere. Close enough to walk to Notre Dame and Seine Rivet. Lots of quaint sidewalk caFeds at reasonable cafes.

Lively neighbourhood. A very central and lively neighbourhood in the heart of Paris.
Houses are v old, restaurants are decent and the Sunday shopping is good after getting some brunch with family and friends.
Only negative point: not easily accessible with trolleys /kids/elderly as the pavements are too narrow

A must visit neighbourhood in Paris. When you plan your next trip to Paris, you must allow yourself to walk through the narrow streets of Le Marais. It is filled with plenty of trendy apparel shops and you get the best fallafel in the whole capital, just make sure to go with enough time to stay in line for upto 30 minutes, every single day, that´s how good this restaurant is.
Quaint French neigborhood. Who can find fault with this authentic French section of Paris. On Sundays there is sidewalk music and dancing. Great historical area that is a must visit

Wonderful. We spent a day in Le Marais . Went to the museum for Paris history and to the Picasso museum. It was a rainy day so it was a day for indoor activities. We visited the Caravalet as well. We followed our guide book to the Chez Janou for one of our best lunches. The staff were great and made for a fun time. Excellent food. Our waiter bought us free shots of a melon aperitif and then left the bottle for us to help ourselves. I ordered the chocolate mousse and they brought me a plate and a soup tureen full to the brim for me to serve myself!!!! We didn't follow the usual tipping rules !!!

Best walking, eating & shopping in Paris. Shopping heaven in boutiques with designer clothes, shoes, handbags and jewelry. Tiny restaurants line the streets with very few cars and lots of bicycle riders.

Disappointed. According to the travel guide I consulted Le Marais area of Paris is open on a Sunday. We were leaving Paris in mid afternoon and so had left this till Sunday morning. The whole area looks depressed and rather downbeat. Very few shops were open although there were several cafes. We had read that this area houses chic boutiques and we spent a couple of hours or more wandering the streets. Sadly, the Marais district did not impress at all.

The best neighborhood in Paris. We stayed here and it was the best choice. It is a hipster area. People are cool, many bars and restaurants in a walking distance. If you want to go shopping it is the perfect area with all the most important brands around the corner without the crowd of tourists in the Galerie Laffayette.

I would call this the Newtown (Sydney) of Paris. Nestled on the Right Bank and dominated by the Republique statue (surrounded by protesting students on one day during our stay), this is area is known as the 'real' Paris. In this city, you are either Right or Left Bank, rarely both. Le Marais is hip, funky, young, Gay friendly, bohemian, gritty and pretty. Be sure to do a walking tour with Justine from Just In Paris. She will show and tell you everything about this neighbourhood. The Rouge Enfants markets and Place des Vosges are a must see.

See Paris as the Locals do!. We were lucky enough to book a local's flat in the heart of Le Marais. We couldn't have chosen a better location! Not only is it situated very central to many of Paris' main attractions, but it is a unique attraction itself! The neighborhood is clean, full of exceptional shopping, cafes and historic buildings. When we return, I plan to stay in this area again! I highly recommend it.

Get lost in the cobbled alley ways!. A great area full of vibrance yet sometimes overlooked by the main flow of tourists. If you extend your curiosity by taking a walk through the numerous alley ways and small cobbled streets you'll come across picturesque and quiet parks hidden between houses, traditional cafes and chocolate shops and much more. Don't just walk down the main streets - there's much more to 'investigate' & to feed your curiosity down the small back streets here in the Marais area.

lovely neigbourhood-quiete a chic feel to it.. loved walking around for the shops. the museum Carnavalet is a MUST SEE. it's free and shows beautiful paintings from the art nouveau period and lots of stuff from Alphonse Mucha ! Superb ! The area has very nice shops. Visit the teashop DAMMANN, it's unbelievable and not expensive in a posh surrounding ;-)
Wonderful village St Paul.. One of the must see and feel areas of Paris. Very cosy. Lots of small shops, historical buildings. Place Vendome is Marvellous.

Lovely place to stay for the real old Paris. Not necessarily a tourist destination, Le Marais has evolved into a wealthier quarter over the past 20 to 30 years. Lots of historic buildings and gardens remain, right at the centre of Paris. Great food all around. You need to get a cab to the Eiffel Tower (costs about 12 Euro) but the Seine and Notre Dame are in easy walking distance. If you are a bit of a bohemian you will love this part of Paris. Plenty of 'rainbow people' around too.

Great district to stay; very much a neighbourhood. Busy, full of shopping and food/wine. Close to several hubs for other parts of Paris but you could spend days just in Le Marais. Museums of note, galleries, wonderful architecture, historical precincts.

Easily the best part of Paris to stay.. This was my first visit to Paris and I a stayed in Le Marais and I was thrilled. Fantastic feel to the area and very safe with awesome shopping and restaurants.

Edgy must visit area. If you like 7 dials or Soho in London you will like the Marais. Lots of small streets with all sorts of treasures whether it be shops, bars or restaurants. A really good north african area in the middle with the best Falafel but prepare to queue.
Cozy streets. Loved it so much, streets are cozy and there are very nice boutiques. But for lunch its very very expensive!

Marvelous Marais district. There is so much to see in the Marais District as it is so varied. There are some fantastic blogs to read more about what to see and where to eat.Le Marais is a very trendy place in Paris, you have to go to the rue des Francs Bourgeois. In this street, you can see a lot of hipsters and fashion lovers walking in the streets, looking for the best clothes in the shops. This street is where you can find the very typical Parisian style. Place des Vosges: it’s also the oldest square in Paris. This garden is one of the only gardens in Paris where you can sit on the grass. It’s a very typical French garden, everything is tidy and the buildings all around are harmonious. This is the place where all the locals come to relax and sunbathe when it’s sunny. Don't miss the Jewish Quarter and eat the best felafel in Paris at L'as du falafel.
A slice of a different Parisian history. We love walking around this eclectic district. History and museums around every corner. Place de Vosges must be the most beautiful square in Europe.
Not what I expected. Seems to be becoming more popular, with many designer shops and quite expensive cafes. Still a pleasant area but no longer an undiscovered part of Paris.

Wonderful. Having not been destroyed by Haussmann this is an area of rabbit warren type streets. It is an interesting mix of people and intriguing buildings. It is also a great area to stay in as it is quiet and yet close to everything

A fun place to walk and explore. Lots of interesting shops and places to eat and people watch. I've been to Paris more than I can count and this area is great with all of its history, some very sad, and great people.

In the heart of Paris. I stayed in La Marais arrondissement this trip to Paris, and it is within walking distance of everything. I also did the Paris by Mouth tour of Le Marais and got to know the streets a bit better (although I still got lost...... but who worries about getting lost in Paris). The Museum of Nature is here, as are lots of little boutique shops. Also the No 1 croissant maker is in the La Marais district. What better excuse to go there?
A Great Place to Drop a Ton of Euros. Finest shopping district in town. Just off the main drag is a row of shops with artisan offerings that can only be found in Paris.

loved staying here. I stayed at the Jeanne d"Arc hotel in the Marais for three days at the end of September. The staff there is so kind, and I felt very much at home. My room was comfortable, and small, as is the case with most Paris rooms. The Marais has so much happening-we went to the Carnavalet, the Jewish Holocaust Museum, the deli, and Eclair du Genie, to mention just a few things.

Charming and romantic. Le Marais is a must see section of Paris with narrow cobblestone streets and chic boutiques for browsing. It is the jewish section of the city. My husband and I agree that this is the prettiest neighborhood in Paris and the place we would most like to live in Paris. Don't miss Rue Des Rosiers and the best falafel at L'as Du Fallafel.

A trendy and cozy area. The area is experiencing a vibrant development also thanks to the world known fashion brands estabilishing here their branches. Smart people; funky people business people are enjoying the Parisian life at every hour

The North of Thailand. I was disappointed with the hotel, comparing to the other 5 stars hotels, the one is on the bottom lists. It is expensive if you compare the price that you paid VS services. My impression was in my room there has no slippers, not enough shampoo, and shower gel. The sad part is the hotel does not provide any toothbrush and toothpaste. I have stayed 5 stars hotels, this is my first time experience this.

Classic Paris!. Le Marais is Paris as you've always imagined .... winding streets, lots of shops and cafes. We stayed at a hotel in Le Marais which proved to be so right on so many levels. Finding a nice place to eat for breakfast, lunch or dinner was never a problem. Do as the Parisians and get an outdoor table with the chairs facing the sidewalk and passing pedestrians. This is what it means "to see and be seen."

Love this Neighborhood. Are you looking for the quintessential Parisian experience? We found it here, as we wandered the less visited side streets. The people watching from cafe sidewalk was superb, but we were off the main drags.
Interesting place to have a wander around!. We only visited during the day however I'm told this area really comes alive at night. Lots of little Boutique shops that are one offs.

the original Paris,. Le Marais is the original historic district in Paris. Long the aristocratic district of Paris, it hosts many outstanding buildings of historic and architectural importance. It spreads across parts of the 3rd and 4th arrondissements in Paris. Originally hosting les Hales de Paris now outside Paris.You find the Beaubourg museum, musee national Piccasso, musee Camavalet, you will find small and fantastic fashion designers,restaurant bars club. Also known to be the gay ling of Paris.In short to describe this fantastic part of ParisLe Marais' classic Parisian streets and cafes strike a delicate balance between well-traveled tourist hotspots and local-favorite hangouts.

nice walk. there are many nice bars and restaurants. it is place where locals meet tourists. Morever you could visit the shoa monument/museum. one could also go shopping in the area as there are many trendy/new style boutiques around.

An interesting district to visit among others in Paris for its shopping and historical offerings. We spent a morning accompanying a tour guide of this popular district in Paris with lovely shops and its vibrant neighborhood
From a Jewish Getto to a trendy section of Paris. We went to the Picasso Museum and on to great falaffel. trendy stores and restaurants, windy quaint streets makes this section a must see.
Wow. We stumbled on this area by chance but did not want to leave. Shop after shop of fantastic French couture. Window shopping was all I could afford to do though sadly!
Fascinating area. This is a very interesting area, rich in history, with some wonderful mansions and excellent museums. Good shopping and superb food.

Don't miss this funky Paris neighbourhood. Le Marais is one of the most enjoyable neighbourhoods of Paris with little shops and restaurants, terrasses, bakeries.... It feels like a little village inside of Paris

Fun and interesting area of Paris!. The Marais, is the old Jewish area of Paris. It is chalked full of Jewish bakeries, loaded with tasty treats. The streets abound with interesting, and non interesting stores, and restaurants. It's a very lively area, and the streets are closed to cars on the weekends. GO!! You will not regret it....

Walk and take the time to look. I had not spent time in the Marais area for many years, concentrating more on the Rive Gauche and area around the Champs Elyses. I am happy I took the time to spend at least half a day walking around the Marais, it's many streets and taking the time to have a coffee or a drink on various terrasses or sports along the way. In my late 50s I seem to be wise and don't need to see everything. I am more in the mood of appreciating things while remaining as curious and interstellar as I have always been. Le Marais is a living neibourhood where actual people live and business's are carried on daily. I love witnessing the xchanges between salespersons and clients, waiters with varying style serving different clienteles and more ethnic surroundings. This is the reall world and not a show given for tourists. I love my last visit and intend on spending more time nxt time in Paris. I probably would even be looking for a hotel in the area next time.

The place to stay!. I was in paris once. I stayed in Le Maris, and everything was right there. you could walk to just about anything you wanted to see. the restaurants were all there. shopping right there.safe and alive all night.

Nice Neighborhood. One of the safer neighborhoods in Paris. Go early on a Sunday to visit the Flea Market there. The only drawback was seeing the armed military in one section. They were there because of some recent violence against the Jewish community who live there.
Interesting area and interesting shops. Variety of places and shops to wander around and all open on a Sunday too. Good spot if rainy as plenty of cover.

Only place to stay. We rented an apartment for two weeks and there really is no where better to stay in Paris the trouble is everyone else wants to visit so it gets very crowed Le Marais has something for everyone and mostly within walking distance quaint supermarkets where food and drinks are very inexpensive if planning a visit to Paris you cant go wrong staying in this area

Must visit, preferably on a Sunday. This is a lovely are, lots of eating places, attractions and nice crowd local as well as tourists. Make sure you go to the Jewish district and enjoy some delicious pastries and cakes. Perfect atmosphere.

Fun to explore. I have been to Paris numerous times but somehow never visited the Marais area until Oct. 2015. A very pleasant and interesting quarter with kosher food. Note the carved inscriptions on the buildings telling of people who lived in that building and were deported during WWII.

Great Location, loved it!. We stayed in Le Marais. What a great location for walking, eating, exploring and the Metro is close by for all parts further afield. Notre Dame, Seine, Louvre...all within walking distance. We did a free guided walking tour of the area and it was a great addition, giving us bits of information on what to do and where to go. A lot of hidden gems here!
Stroll along the old streets. I think the highlight of my stroll along these old streets was the collection of unique small restaurants selling everything from desserts to pizzas...

no comment necessary. shopping paradise with space for culture freaks. eating a falafall bread after standing outside in a big row gives a sparkling sensation even when your are seating on the street.

Historic, romantic Le Marais. Two wonderful locals gave me a full day tour of their beloved Le Marais. I'd highly recommend hiring a guide because the details are fascinating. Here is the Jewish section, the apartment where Victor Hugo wrote Les Mis, a Roman wall, a private garden with wild modern sculptures, museums (Picasso, Carnavalet for the history of Paris, and many more). I loved the small shops with friendly, English speaking clerks eager to explain the high quality treasures they sell, from scarves to pastries to books. Tiny cafes fill every block for a champagne break and restaurants of all types abound. A visitor could spend days here and never stop learning and experiencing the real treasures of Paris along narrow, winding streets of the oldest part of the city.
Love the vibes. So many unique, cute, restaurants and store available there. From bio stores & restaurant to unique fashion stores. It is also nice for sunday stroll because some/ most stores open

Marvellous Marias. Marais is special not just for the shopping, the museums, the restaurants and the location, but also the people. It is a city within a city and, in many ways, one of the main arteries...if not the pulsing heart...of Paris. Rife with boutique hotels such as the Jules and Jim, trendy restaurants such as Le Dôme and le Derrière and the beautiful Place des Vosges, it has become my preferred place to stay when visiting the city of love.....

Absolutely fabulous. A time well spent in the Marais. Best day I have had for a long time. I was able to combine history, food, shopping, browsing ... and the sights are absolutely lovely. My favourite area to spend a day in Paris.
Cosy. Really nice part of Paris. Stores are open on Sunday. Lot's of people but that creates the atmosphere :-)

Delightful stroll. We used Rick Steve's Paris book and the "Marais Walk" that he outlines in the book as our basis. We included a stop at Victor Hugo's house and the Carnavalet Museum...both are free attractions, and had lunch at a sidewalk cafe. Rick Steve's also has a "Carnavalet Museum" tour in his Paris book which highlights some of the displays. A very pleasant way to spend a beautiful fall day in Paris.

A ROMANTIC FAIRYTALE!. Beautiful roads, historical buildings and magic atmosphere! in my opinion, these are the top and most important informations for a visitor who interests to visit something alternative in the heart of Paris. put Marais in your schedule for sure! it's worth a visit.

Beautiful but Touristy. Le Marais is a beautiful, centrally located district/neighborhood in the heart of mainly the 3rd Arrondissement (part of Le Marais bleeds into the 4th). One would have to deliberately avoid it in order to miss it. The Picasso Museum is there. The Jewish Art Museum is there. The Shoah Memorial Museum is there. And lots of famous upscale and casual restaurants (like falafel places) are there. It's beautiful. It's clean. It used to be the heart of Jewish life in Paris, and that history still remains even though most of the Jews have since moved.The reason I rate it only 3 stars is because it is crowded and touristy. I almost stayed in Le Marais, and I'm so glad I didn't. My experience of Paris would have been vastly different, with expensive boutique shopping on every street and the bustling of tourist life on every corner. Le Marais is not where the Parisians are; it's not where they live or where they hang out -- any more than Champs de Elysses is -- any more than Times Square is for New Yorkers. One will pass through. One will even go to Le Marais itself. It's lovely, but it gets old. Sure, there are great bakeries there, but there are great bakeries all over Paris (one of my favorites was in the 20th Arrondissement, which is very Parisian). I went to a few of the falafel places; I went to the Shoah Memorial, the Musee Picasso, and the Jewish Art Museum. I also went to some higher end restaurants. It's near-impossible not to pass through. I loved it, but all the same, I was happy to leave it once I was done with why I had come.

Favorite neighborhood in Paris. This is a neighborhood full of stores, restaurants, and nice cobblestone streets. I love staying here, or in the nearby Bastille area. They're somewhat less touristy, but still just a 15minute Metro ride away from any spot you'd like to go to.
Nice environment. This is a really nice area of Paris where you can wonder around, look at the may small and Original shops, have a drink in one of the many café's. A must-see!
Thats where I lived.. Everything was within walkable distance. The musee de Pompadour was as always a big hit. The restaurants around were very good. And I feasted on the escargots whenever possible.

Beautiful but overcrowded. Paradise lost. Just about any travel guide/agency will tell you about what to see, what to buy,..and there still is much of both, except that the soul of the area is lost. Crowds of visitors with little time but fair amounts of money available to most of them turned visiting the area, not to mention living there, a disappointing experience.Some of the beautiful "Hotels du Marais" are still worth the trip but better get there early in the morning, far "away from the madding crowds". Note: I know a little bit about what I'm talking about. I lived ther for over twenty years.

A beautiful part of Paris, full of historic buildings. We stayed at a hotel in Le Marais for four nights. Le Marais made a great base for our trip to Paris, we loved wandering the streets of historic buildings and shopping at local bakeries.

Perfect location to stay in Paris. We rented an apartment in this district through Air BnB and could not have been more pleased. Easy, pleasant walk back from the Louvre, Tuileries and Notre Dame or simple metro stop (St. Paul). Great shops and restaurants as well as fun outdoor markets. We bought wine, cheese and olives from a market with the nicest vendors who very kindly and patiently encouraged my rusty French. When we return to Paris, we will stay in this area again.
Lovely area!. The Marais area is a wonderful place to spend time in just walking and exploring historic buildings, the museums and the many shops!

Put on your walking shoes. A good 40 minute walk from the Lourve, there is nothing much here except some statues and cafés. Personally I think it's a waste of time. A bit of the Bohemian feel Montremarte used to have-second hand shops etc. but they're all over Paris

Vibrant, welcome change of pace. We spent a wonderful afternoon walking through Le Marais on our way to the Notre Dame. It was a delightful change from the hustle and bustle of the more opulent L'Opera area. Looking forward to exploring this area in more detail in the future.
Great place to go see on a Sunday. Went on a Sunday and it was so nice that all the shops were. Streets were very crowded,but it just added to the ambiance. Nice neighborhood

Beautiful area. We stayed in Le Marais for four nights in a very tiny apartment we found via Airbnb. Whilst I had some reservations about our accommodation, I couldn't fault its location as this is a wonderful area in which to stay. There are glorious old buildings to gaze at and a myriad of wonderful eating places, including the most magnificent bakery I've ever been to! I hope to return to Paris one day and if I do, I'll certainly stay in this beautiful area!

A GREAT AREA TO BE BASED WHILST IN PARIS. On a prior trip we stayed south of the Eiffel Tower which was more of a residential area, and it seemed a little remote, (as tourists) we couldnt go for a walk at night because there was not much around other than housing.This time I got a bit more info. It was a great area to be based. we stayed 5 minutes from Notre Dame. Lots of bars, shopping and could just wander around at night if we pleased. There are a lot of apartments available, and we ended up staying in Rue Quincampoix in a ground floor apartment ( called the Edmund Michelet) rented through "The French Experience" based in Sydney Australia. We had no problems at all. Subway close by, walking distance to Notre Dame, Saint Chapelles Church, The Lourve, we even walked down to the arc and then got the subway back. There was s supermarket for us, practically at our doorstep which I had researched prior, (this is handy to know if your hiring an apartment, saves running around trying to find it once there)We went to the new shopping centre called Las halles. Most of this is underground. We got lost. At closing time we just followed the crowd, we were so pleased when we felt a cold breeze coming in our direction. Thought we were going to be trapped in a shopping centre all night!!!! My husband would have loved that!
Nice interesting area. Good interesting part of Paris, with lots of individual attractions including the Pompidou Centre, Picasso Museum and more.Wander round the little streets on a dry day!
October Visit. Our hotel on edge of MaraisGreat place to be as not too many tourists and lots of lovely bars and restaurantsNever seen so many art galleries!

The Old City. This area is the old part of Paris with lovely architecture, good shopping, lots of places to eat. Very walkable with a neighborhood feel. Cafes have character and charm. This is the area to stay in.

Best shopping in Paris. This was an awesome neighbourhood to explore. It has better shopping than St. Germain de Pres if you want more authentic Parisian boutiques and less chain stores. Also the it's one of the only places with most of stores open on a Sunday.
My favourite place in Paris. I love walking in Le marais for its overall experience, for a coffee break and definitely shopping. A very cool place.

Great place to people watch and shop. Charming streets and shops. Great place to walk around and have pastries and coffee at a restaurant. Many great places to eat and shop. High end fashion mixed with local shops.

Quaint, hip neighborhood with everything. This ancient neighborhood, within walking distance of central Paris, is full of meandering streets, charming bistros, chic shops, lovely museums and verdant parks. Historically, a Jewish neighborhood, this charming area has much to offer those who're willing to wander through it's narrow passageways. The Picasso Museum and the Carnavalet Museum are two of the fascinating museums to explore. Spend the good part of a day here and leave in love.

Took a walking tour with Discover Walks. Worth the time. We have been to Paris 4 times and make it a point that we do a walking tour or two. Our guide Thomas made the area come alive. Took us to Place des Vosges, talked about the Jewish center, etc. We did the tour Oct. 9th. Worth our time. Tour was about 90 minutes.

Marais is a beautiful area, well worth a visit.. We did a walking tour of the Marais and it was excellent. There is so much history and it is a very beautiful area. There are great cafes and its close to the river and Notre Dame so it can be visited in conjunction with other places.
Great district. This was my favourite district in Paris. I wish I had of stayed here. It felt safe, lots of places to eat and drink, nice little shops

Beautiful, Iconic Paris Neighborhood. We rented a beautiful apartment in this lovely neighborhood & found it to be an ideal home base to explore Paris. There are many great cafes, markets, shops & bakeries in every direction. Hailing a cab was a breeze & the metro stops are within a few blocks of each other. We had "our" cafe across the street which was opened late & has friendly neighbors who recognized us every day. Cannot recommend visiting Marais enough!

Great to Visit: Art and Food and Architecture. This is an old quarter of Paris, now a Mecca for shoppers and tourists. Once a center of Jewish life in Paris, the Marais many (most?) of its Jewish inhabitants to rounds ups and "transportation", with the willing complicity of the Vichy French government. Today, the Marais abounds with shops and restaurants and a busy street scene. The Centre Pompidou is here for those interested in modern art. Restaurants and small food shops are mixed with galleries and clothing stores. For those who love falafel, try the rue du Rosiers for good eats.
Love it!. Really nice neighborhood. Nice shops. We really enjoyed walking get around. It's full of coffee shops and restaurants.

Wonderful little corner of Paris. The Marais is a great place to stroll around away from the crowds and to enjoy the beautiful neighborhood. Don't miss the Picasso Museum and the Breizh Cafe for the best crepes in Paris.
Vibrant area. This is a busy and vibrant area with many restaurants and clubs. Great for people looking for interesting nightlife

Love this area. Since my first trip to Paris I always make a point of wandering the streets of Le Marais. This time we did see the Stravinsky Fountains and the Place Des Vosges which we missed last time.
Lovely area full of charm. Great area to walk about with many small shops for browsing . When walking to the Picasso museum you can walk through this area.

An excellent area to stay when in Paris. This to me is the "heart" of Paris. Excellent hotels and restaurants. Able to easily get to many of the famous Parisian sites on foot. Many nearby Metro stations to take you further afield. I love this area and will return when visiting Paris for its diverse wide boulevards and narrow alleys.
Great are to walk around. Able to walk around and see how people lived in years gone by. Picasso Museum and new stores make it a must see part of Paris.

Great district. This area is packed with a diverse range of shops, bars, museums and the odd garden and is a cracking place to stay in. At night it comes alive with numerous cafe bars and restaurants to visit. Try to visit on a Sunday as many if the roads are closed to traffic so you can wander at will.

Expensive and over-rated. Saw that this was one of the top areas to visit for shops of character, bars, cafes etc. We found it a bit disappointing. Some of the independent shops had very high prices. The cafes only seemed to be catering for "brunch" customers and we finally found a quiet bar/cafe only to be charged 8.40 euros for a cappucino and an Americano.

Very nice part of the city . Marais has lots of charm, a great variety of restaurants, and good shops. I often stay here when I am in Paris, and it's definitely one of my favourite parts of the city. Not to be missed.
Great area. Cool little trendy area, lots of nice shops and restaurants and art galleries. I make a B-line for this area whenever I'm in Paris.

Charming . I am a fan of this neighbourhood. You can spend an entire day here - shopping, window shopping, relaxing, strolling, eating, drinking. Also, this is full of Parisians, so absolutely perfect if you want to be surrounded by locals. Have a falafel at L'As du Falafel of you are in this area.

Lazy, easy, trendy, cool and very very chilled. A lovely long weekend and nothing better than basing yourself in or around Le Marais. We jumped on the Eurostar from London at midday Friday and 2hrs 17mins later at Gare de Nord in Gay Paris. It's such a beautiful city oozing with class and sophistication, but at the same time is boasts arts, fashion and bohemian alternatives! We stayed near Bastille which is just in Le Marais with the wonderful streets on our doorstep and it's our favourite place to be in Paris to wonder, explore shop and eat! Go and enjoy......

Cute little neighborhood to walk through, shop and stop and eat. We loved the day we spent strolling through Le Marais. We were lucky cause it was on a day where there was an outdoor antique market in the streets which was very fun. Go to the Royal Turenne for lunch and be sure to people watch the very chic hipsters in the area and shop the cute boutiques (I got an amazing cashmere sweater at a boutique that was just the *perfect* little parisian find I was looking for) - we had an amazing time in Le Marais!

Very nice area for a stay and get around Paris. We were staying in the place in Le Marais and found it very convenient to get around and explore other places. There is a lot of cafes, restaurants, places to find a great food or anything else you need.

Urban Heaven. I can think of nothing better to do in Paris than to get lost wandering the streets of Le Marais, Going with no particular purpose and finding the perfect little dining spot or an antique treasure or magnificent architecture or most likely all three makes for a memorable day in Paris. Give yourself time to do it leisurely!

Over crowded and much of a muchness. The Marais used to be a fantastic place to visit and wander around full of little original shops and full of neighbourhood life. It had a thriving Jewish quarter which has almost disappeared. Everything seems to have been swallowed up by chain stores or expensive designer shops and the crowds of people swarming along the narrow streets is terrible to make your way aroundI know things don't stay the same and that progress is unavoidable but it is a shame

A beautiful area in Paris.... The Marais district is a wonderful old area in Paris. Lots of local artisans, interesting cafes, street food and wonderful architecture. Sadly we visited late in the day when much was closed but there was still a lovely atmosphere.
Fave area. I like that area! Gay friendly, culture. A lot of artists, writers, painters. I would defiantly go back! A lotSmall bars

Best area. I totally regret not spending more time in Le Marais in the little time I had in Paris. Everyone talks about Montmarte so I felt I had to see it too. Wish I just stayed in Marais. Great cafes, shopping and overall atmosphere.

Perfect Spot for Sunday in Paris. Paris is very quite on Sundays, most shops are closed and museums are packed.... so this is an alternative to visit have brunch and browse the different galleries and little shops.

Great for shopping . Marais is one of the best places in Paris if you are a tourist who likes shopping. At this area you can find many local restaurants, small cafes, pubs, vintage&design shops as well as small art galleries. And of course the BHV stores (one of the biggest department stores in Paris) If you like shopping and discovering new things Marais is definitely for you.
Great neighborhood. Wow, neat place to explores, great restaurants, lots of neat art galleries. Great place to spend half a day
My fav arrondisement. Best bars, pubs... I love the atmosphere around Le Marais. Raidd Bar is a very nice experience to have there.

Make sure to include Le Marais in your Paris plans. One of the oldest areas of Paris, with funky unusual shops and lots of places to eat, tiny winding streets with something to discover around every corner. Also, the old Jewish quarter, home to Librarie Chir Hadach, falafel shops - just allow an afternoon and wander, you will find something great.

Best Shopping in Paris. This area is a must visit for people looking to escape "tourist" Paris. The streets are full of cool shops and restaurants/cafes. Love shopping in the Marais and always bring home something fabulous. This year it was shoes and a necklace. Try any falafel joint for a quick bite and check out the Musee Picasso and the Musee Carnavalet while there.

Wonderful Neighborhood. WE spent a day walking the Marais neighborhood and could have spent 2-3 full days there. The Jewish Museum is very well done. The HOLOCAUST MUSEUM is under appreciated, Picasso Museum should not be missed. You are also close to the CENTER POMPEDAU.....don't miss it (modern art museum)

Another amazing spot in Paris. And durely one of the things you must do and go to in Paris.The place is amazing and you will find many shops and resturants and galleries that fits your needs and satisfy your desires
Great neighborhood. Great place to stay and shop, very vibrant hip part of Paris. Food streets, restaurants, night life and more. Take a walking tour and see it first hand.
Great district to visit. The district is full of shops, restaurants, small synagogues and a very good Jewish Museum. The variety and range of restaurants was impressive!

Great place to stay. We stayed here on our last trip and loved it. Easily accessible by public transport and just outside of all the tourist traffic. We rented an apartment and loved it. There is a fabulous farmers market there selling fresh fish and vegetables as well as local meats and cheeses. You really get a taste of living in Paris
Le Marais. One of the most beautiful district in Paris. Very quiet place full of soft colours and magic. Highly recommended to visit!

Sunday with the crowds was fun. We just loved walking through this area. There are lots of shops to visit which are interesting. There are gardens, museums and amazing food places. On Sunday it was filled with all kinds of people not just tourists. It was fun and we definitely will go back
Great location. Wonderful part of Paris which still has its courtyard apartments, cobblestones and untamed street grid. It is full of museums, landmarks, shops, bistros and restaurants.
Plaza. The plaza is nice but it is a good walk to get there. Unless you are there for a week or take a cab, might spend your time better elsewhere.

Le Marais is stunning. Loved wandering around Le Marais with Justine from Just'in Paris and learning so much about this area's history! Could spend days taking in all that it has to offer in both French history and beautiful food and wine in the gorgeous stores!

this neighborhood has it all. This neighborhood has everything! streets full of any kind of stores, all of them nice. During the day is full of life, working people, fresh vegetables markets, small cafes, boulangerie and so much more. Subway is around the corner, near to the train station and of course The Pompidou Center!

A Great Area of Paris to Explore. A great area of Paris to explore or stay in. We had the pleasure of both. Our hotel was in the Le Marais for five nights so we were able to explore this diverse area in depth. I highly recommend it for restaurants and just walking around to see the people and sights. Also, it is the gay area so this is another bonus not to be missed.

The perfect area to stay while in Paris. My first visit to Paris was when I was 14 years old, some 54 years ago. I am an annual visitor and I stay in the Marais each time. To my way of thinking, it is the perfect fit for a first time or long time visitor. It is very central for a tourist as it is only a block or two from the Seine River, and its wonderful quai-side walks, Ile St. Louis and Ile de la Cité, with its treasures of Notre Dame, La Chapelle, and the Conciergerie. The Louvre, the Centre Pompidou, the Picasso Museum, and Place des Vosges are all within walking distance. For those who prefer the metro, the main line (#1) runs through the area and can whisk you off to Place de la Concorde, The Petit and Grand Palais art museums, the Champs Elysées, and the Arc de Triomphe without needing to take a correspondence (a transfer). The Marais is stocked with small streets full of centuries old buildings and good restaurants that won`t strip your budget. It is a real area, where people actually live, not just offices, tourist attractions, and pricey hotels. It has an atmosphere which I very much like and I would never consider staying anywhere else during my Paris visits. While in Paris find a reasonably priced Marais hotel on the internet, relax, and enjoy your stay - to my way of thinking the Marais has everything you will need to make your stay enjoyable and memorable. Personally, I usually stay in one of numerous smaller hotels in the area where Rue de Rivoli and Rue St. Antoine meet, near the métro station St. Paul.

Fashion and cafes. You'll find trendy cafes and fantastic little fashion boutiques here. Streets are lined with galleries which have openings that fill the street next to it. Super cool retaurants! Picasso museum just reopened

Quaint shops. This is an upscale neighborhood that still has some down-to-earth charm. We happened to wander around on a day when they held the neighborhood flea market - a nice mix of free food samples, bric-a-brac, and cheap surplus items.

Gorgeous spot. This is a fabulously wonderful area. If you can stay in this area I'd do so, we wanted to but just couldn't organise to do so. It is full of life, beautiful old buildings, music, scrumptious ice creams, cafes, etc. just lovely
Sympa !!!. The area is a tipical parisien arrondissement. Nice music and roundbys. Really recommended for a walk.

Magnificent!. Such a beautiful, hip, trendy area to stay in. Whether you are gay or straight, Le Marais, is a FUN & COOL area to stay in or just to visit. Tons of shops, bars, restaurants, etc. Sit at an outdoor cafe to just enjoy the sights or people watch. My favorite place in Paris!

So much to see and do. There are so many things to see in this old area of Paris. Just walking around the streets, visiting markets, seeing the beautiful parks, or going to the museums and churches, there is certainly plenty to do in this area. We did a walking tour of the food places in the area, which was great.
Beautiful!. This is a happening place with lots of open restaurants and shops around. The streets are nice and very happening to walk around!
Sunday afternoon in Marais. We had a wonderful Sunday afternoon shopping in the Marais district. We found a great little shop for ladies that was très chic.

A most pleasant historical district. A most pleasant historical districtThe neighborhood was purifies by different religious orders , including that of the Temple (see street names ) , it was still swamps in the twelfth century... Today it is one of the most beautiful areas with hotels individuals ( some have become museums ) the old National Library, the Place des Vosges ... really a neighborhood where you can stroll on foot, by ignoring (as far as possible) all this invading trade...

Beyond the barricades. Le Marais is 'as advertised' ... arty, trendy and a 'real world' Paris experience unlike the more touristy quarters. Go for the boutique shopping, great cafes and restaurants and old cobbled streets, but take note of the sad and poignant history that echoes through those streets and read the dedications to the hundreds of Jewish residents who never returned to their homes in le Marais.

Home Away from Home. My husband and I recently spent a week at Les Jardins du Marais Hotel in the Marais area of Paris. It was a nice hotel, close to the Metro, and surrounded by wonderful restaurants. The area was an interesting one to explore on foot. Yes, there were tourists, of course, but there was a great neighborhood feel about the area. It is a lovely area to experience a less hectic, friendly Paris.

Beatuful and interesting neighbourhood. As an old distict of Paris Marais offers much to discover. The best is just walk aimlessly and you'll find interesting streets, nice squares and number of great restaurants in every step. I so muhc enjopyed the vibe of that area.

The Old Paris. Magnificent area of beautiful old Paris and cafes, restaurants and collage of shopping. When we were there it was the Jewish Festival so the Sunday was packed and the Falafels were selling like hotcakes. Definately worth a visit or better stay in the area.

trendy place. if you want to go shopping on a sunday, this is the place it has lots of name brand clothes and fashion stores.. but it is quite expensive though. the neighborhood is very charming and the jewish establishments are very cool

The best. This neighborhood is the cutest and the best of Paris with plenty of stores, restaurants and cute cafés. I have also stayed near the Eiffel Tower and I must say that the Marais are a lot better!It's location is perfect, just a walk to the seine and the beautiful islands. If I go back to Paris I would definitely stay in Marais.
Cosy little part of town. Several small shops and restaurant (try to find the ones that serves falafel). You get the feeling of a small town within the actual city.

Come while the old charm remains. Wonderful old part of Paris. Has the first residence of Henry the IV with a suberb harmonious garden. Also one or two streets left of the Jewish section. Area is going through urban renewal with inclusion of small gardens, shops where you can get bargains for clothing.

My ffavorite part of Paris. This is without any doubt my favorite part of Paris. I have been to Paris loads of times over the years, but I always return to Le Marais. Although gentrified, the narrow streets, small boutiques, specialized shops (like the fantastic tea shop Mariage Frerés) restaurants, holes in the wall where you can buy the best falafel. It's just a really charming part of Paris. Warning, avoid Saturdays and Sundays - to crowded!

One area you should visit in paris. Love walking Le Marais when I am in Paris. Especially love to go to the Place des Vosges - probably the most beautiful architecture and best 'square' in Paris. This area is famous for the Jewish community who live there and wonderful history of Paris. great little cafes. Vibrant community and tourists alike .

Lovely mix of things to see and do, but "real". We stayed and ate ONLY in this arrondissement -- venturing out selectively for events -- and loved it. There is a glitzy end, but once you push into the area deeper, it is delightful mix of bistros, boutique, antique stores, markets, varied museums, cheese stalls, food halls, grand hotels (palaces) and plenty to see and do for days. We loved spending time there and will go back for more

Le Marais is the best place to stay. My wife and I rented an apartment in Le Marais for our weeklong stay in Paris. The apartment was a block from the Centre Pompidou and was a 15 minute walk to Notre Dame Cathedral. There were two great bakeries on our street and numerous restaurants. We walked down to the Place des Vosges and lingered in the park there and browsed at a nice neighborhood flea market. On Sunday, the streets were closed to traffic and it seemed like half of Paris was there strolling around. The street performers that I remember most was a quartet playing Dixieland jazz. Le Marais was a great location to stay on our first trip to Paris.

Great place to go on Sunday. If you want the Paris shops and restaurants on a Sunday, Le Marais is the place to go. Everything is open since this is the Jewish section of town. Lots of restaurants offering falafel and pastries. All the shops were open and streets were packed.

Pleasant Right Bank Quartier .... A really nice quartier on the Right bank where you get the feel of being a Parisian, and how Parisian live. Walking distance to the Seine, Pompidou Cente & Musee Carnavelet, plus wonderful markets, shops & restaurants. Worth walking through. Enjoy...

The real Paris.... Where the locals hang out.. Love this area! So much to see, and the wonderful tiny little gems of shops! You could easily spend a whole afternoon walking around... The atmosphere is changing... Do a tour to learn all the history and how it is now becoming gentrified. Would probably consider renting an apartment in this area next time.

Ana area tIhat is a tribute to tthe Jews in Paris. It is an interesting area the is becoming upscale. The need for armed security guards around The Jewish schools and synagogues is both shocking and reassuring.

Take it all in. Beautiful part of the city and worth the time to wander through. Stop for lunch but unfortunately there is no good coffee on offer (pretty much the whole city has terrible coffee). Don't be in a rush!

Spend 7 days in Paris two weeks ago, and I fell in love with it!. I enjoyed Paris to the maximum! I visited the Louvre Museem, Orzay Museem, Picasso, the Veirsalles Palace, the Picasso Musee, the Eifeel tower, the Sacred Heart of the Baisica, and Morntmatre. I also enjoy LeMarai, the Notredame, Champs DeElysees, the Art of Triumph, The Opera House, the great outdoor cafees, the outdoor living in general!!! I feel so depressed post my trip to Paris and having to come back to iivein Miami, which is a boring city, and it is frustrating to me I feel very depresed to have to live in Miami, which I detest, but my family lives here. Any advice? I love Paris so much!!!!!!!!
Allocate some time for le Marais. This is a great part of the city. I did not have enough time to explore (after a mistake on the metro), but loved the area. There were great shops and bakeries.

Snobby cafes. Be careful of snobby cafes who say yes you can come in to order just a drink then ask you to leave if you don't order a meal, so rude. Apart from Chez Hannah falafel wrap not much good I can say about this district.

Style and sunstance (and sustinence). Love the Marais. OK it is the guy centre of Paris but get over it. Cafe culture, wonderful shopping. Do a bike tour starting at the Notre Dame and it will give you an excellent insight to the city particularly this area.

Rent apartment here!. I rented small flat in the center of La Marais, close to De Ville Hotel and felt I could not choose better location for historical center. I walked to Notre Dam, to Siene boat cruise, walked Cite and many bridges, bought fruits and cheeses in a little street markets, had coffee and croissant sitting and watching street and people. I admired architecture and well-dressed Parisiens, and I wished I had more time to spend here. Stay in Marais!

A special visit.. Wonderful area, many Jewish sites and shops. The only problem is some Ultra Orthodox begging on the streets. Went again to have lunch and take some goodies to the apartment. It seems the restaurant has changed hands, food a little different, and prices higher.
Took home almost 59euros worth.............everything was good, but not like my Moms.

Magical Marais - stay in this district. The nicest, romantic, rekaxed area of Paris to stay in. If you go, stay here. An excellent base. Village feel, lovely little cafés and winding streets, hidden gardens and bars. Our favourite location to chill and eat in Paris with easy access to all the main sights

Do not miss when in Paris. I just love le Marais. Not only the shopping and food is different than anywhere else in Paris. Enjoy the architecture you see in the buildings and narrow streets with cobble stones. Best spots for fun shopping: Merci, check out the small streets, you can find one off stores too.

Paris of Old - Quaint and interesting walk. Le Marais or Marais is on the right bank not too far from the river. It is a wonderful area, great and unique shops, interesting museums (some free), very old buildings, good restaurants and simply a wonderful walk through Paris. The best way to do it for free is to google Framers walking tours of Paris #3 - make sure you get the map which is on the web site. It does not matter where you start - we liked the Hotel deVille (Hotel is the name of a mansion not a Hotel as we know it), once you get started following the written directions is very easy. Hint - several times they give specific street numbers, frequently these are the very old numbers but in all cases very close to the new number and on the same side of the street. You will see some wonderful churches, oldest wooden houses in Paris, Musee Picasso (ok not great), Musee Carnavalet (free) and Victor Hugo House (free) and squares and gardens in front of the mansions. . Make sure you walk completely around the place des vosges as it is very interesting and where the Hugo house is located. A few spectacular art shops - not to worry too expensive to buy but great to look at. we spent the whole day here.

A Beautiful Paris Neighborhood with Historical Buildings and Nice Streets and Restaurants. Even if you are staying in Paris for 2-3 days, don't miss walking in the beautiful Le Marais neighborhood for a few hours in an afternoon and maybe for a nice dinner in one of its fabulous cozy restaurants. There are lots of amazing buildings, structures, little gardens with fountains, and above all wonderful narrow streets with all sorts of shops, great fast food places, and restaurants. You will not get tired of walking in this neighborhood for hours and taking some of your best Paris pictures. Relax for 10-15 minutes in the beautiful Place Des Vosges peaceful park and be amazed by its beautiful surrounding building. If you have your sandwiches with you, you can have a nice picnic over there. After you go through a beautiful and old arch, you get to Hotel De Sully, which is another marvelous structure in Le Marais. Next get on the narrow streets and enjoy a nice walk and some window shopping, if you like. Carnavalet Museum is another place to see, but it was closed and we could not get in. As you walk on one the streets in the 4th district, stop by the Amorino ice cream parlor and enjoy one of the best ice cream cones in Paris. Finally, make sure you see the Hotel De Ville when you are in Le Marais and again be amazed by this absolutely breath taking structure and its beautiful fountains. This building is simply a must see in Paris. Now, complete your walk with a nice dinner in one of the cozy restaurants in this gorgeous neighborhood. Have fun!

Just stay there.. Best area in Paris to stay for local interesting events, food diversity, quiet breakfasts if you are early enough, marketplace bargains, fashion for all tastes , near to metro stations, people watching from the cafes and in the parks along with easy access to so many tourist attractions .

Great Place to walk around and take in the beautiful shops!. A great place to walk around. The shops are lovely. Great to do on a Sunday as most places and shops are closed in Paris, most of the Marais shops are open!
Paris Walks Tours. We did a walking tour with Paris Walks and really enjoyed it. The guides are English speaking and are full of interesting facts and anecdotes. Highly recommend.

what else to do on Sunday!. One of the rare area in Paris where most of the shops are opened on Sunday and where people go for brunch. Lively and nice. I like particularly the Swiss house where they often have exhibits, seating at a terrace and sipping a Perrier citron.

History, Culture and Change. Le Marais is the traditional centre of Jewish Life in Paris. Visiting it one is exposed to many parts of this history. Yet at the same time you can see the changes that happen in any major city. The gentrification of some of the areas. But still the wonderful Kosher bakeries , often with queues. Fascinationg

Excellent Area for Food. We walked through this area - narrow cobble stoned streets filled with excellent patisserie and food places. Walk in
Rue des Francs Bourgeois - there are great patisserie - amust

nice area to hang out. Just walking and hanging out the area would be nice to feel being in Paris with nice buildings that doesnt even appear in the map. You can even just encounter a festival and concert and have fun freely there like I did in September (I dont even know what was the festival but enjoyed the music and the food there:)

Paris 2015 visit. Le Marais district is full of diversity and wonderful restaurants and bars and small hotels. We stayed on rue St. Merri in a lovely apartment we rented through HomeAway.com. It is tres-gay in this area which suited us just fine!
relaxing area to wander. A beautiful area to wander, view many historic and beautiful buildings. Many great photo opportunities.

The place to stay in paris. We stayed here during our visit and enjoyed the great neighbourhood atmosphere, plenty of places to eat and drink, intriguing streets and alleys dripping with history, easy access to metro, and walkng distance to so many visitor destinations

Experience the Real Paris-Walk Through Le Marais. Such a great place for walking and discovering Old Paris. You will find cute little shops, vintage shops, wonderful bakeries, cafes and museums. Do not miss the renovated Picasso Museum or the Pompidou. You will find unique art work and shops featuring new designers. Pop into some of the lovely cafes close to the Picasso Museum.

The best of what you dream about Paris. A gorgeous neighborhood filled with restaurants, shops and intimate streets. Walk, dine, shop for all manner of goodies, and take in the galleries. One of our best days in Paris was spent in the Marais.

great place to stroll. I really liked exploring the neighborhood of Paris. Each turn at a corner brings a new delight...from shop...to architecture. You can really get a feel for what life was back when this part of town was constructed. Great shops, small boutiques and restaurants....plus you'll discover small gems of your own as you wander the streets.This was, in my opinion, one of the best places to stroll in the city

Enjoyable walk through a perhaps overlooked arrondissement. We had a nice walk through Le Marais, an historic and formerly aristocratic district in Paris. Beautiful architecture, fantastic art galleries, and charming streets.
Heartwarming neighborhood. The Marais is full of cafes and pubs and is probably one of the best neighborhoods to stay in Paris.
Great history in a lovely neighborhood. Our Airbnb apartment was in this historic neighborhood, which we found safe, friendly, with nice cafes and shops. East access to Metro.
Old Paris. Really great shops....Need to go to the "real Marais" not the touristy falafel spot. There are great shops near Rue Charlot (I can't think if the cross street).

The old Paris in the modern days. One of the best quartiers in Paris. You'll experience the vibe of the old Paris along with the fresh and vibrant moods of the new generation. It is one of the most vibrant quartiers in Paris gathering many pop-up shops, art galleries, great bars and restaurants as well as record shops. The Marais is well known to be one of the Gay quartiers of Paris and you'll find many Gay friendly bars and shops around the place. Go wander in the streets by stopping at the Metro Hotel de Ville (Line 1) and walking through the streets till Saint Paul du Marais and until Bastille. The architecture will surprise you, the bistrots will serve you great beverages and the people will smile back.Have fun!

Jewish quarter. An interesting place for a walk-through. Lots of tiny lanes and small gardens/parks tucked away where you least expect to see them. Food experiences galore and on Sunday's musicians in the streets. A totally different side to Paris.

Interesting walking area. Lots of nice cafes in this neighborhood, take a stroll around Place de vosges, pop into a couple of museums or shops, interesting historical sites including the Holocaust memorial and a monument at the site of the Bastille.

Le marais - THE place to stay!. We stayed in Le Marais. A great choice! Wonderful cafes, restaurants, shops, gardens, museums and people watching. Close to the Metro, with good bus service. Shopping was great too for our grocery needs for our apartment as well as for finding special gifts for friends back home.
You can't come to Paris without passing through the Marais. Charming neighborhood filled with beautiful small street, cafes, restaurants, history, shops, etc....

My apartment!. I rented an apartment in the Marais for the second time - the first being in 2004. It is a lively vibrant area with shops - cafes - museums - anything you need or want to enjoy being there. They say true French people stay on the right bank - tourists on the left!

Cascading fountains...delicious delicatessens and pastries.. The Marais is a magical maze of tiny streets. Visit Rue des Rosiers for the wonderful yellow coloured shop selling sumptuous cheese pasties and vegetable pies. Spend a morning walking it. Visit the Place des Vosges for beautiful water features and greenery.
must do. Wander round the neighbourhood for a view of older Paris not effected by modern buildings, location of the Picasso museum if you can stay longer

Great shopping, walks, and museum. I really enjoyed this area, it felt less touristy then some of the other areas of paris. I went here during the week, rather than the busy weekends. I found lots of great shops, whether you are looking for affordable boutique, or thrift, or high end with a designer flair. This area made me feel most like a Parisian while I was in Paris.
Don't miss. Just the kind of place to get lost in. Rue des Rosiers is a mst for falafel and take home some bagels.

Charming old and untouched part of Paris.. A great neighbourhood, not touched by much of the changes in Paris' centre during the 19th century, this area is charming and Paris as it used to be, essentially a 'tie stood still' village in Paris, lovely for a walk and it is where the Picasso museum is located.
Relax and enjoy Paris. Great shopping, wandering, restaurants, Museums of Paris, street entertainment. Wonderful Sat market at Place Baudoyer.

My first trip to Paris and we stayed in the Marais: wonderful. It was a couple of years ago we stopped in the marais but remembered that it was much nicer than the next visit. Of course it was all new to us and therefore exciting but we were close to the River Seine and Notre Dame within walking distance and on the way discovered other interesting sites. Despite comments from other travellers, we found the locals very friendly and found lovely little cafes with wonderful new food delights. The rail transport was convenient. One of the local streets were closed so the residents could have a street party so the city folk could get to know their neighbours. Great idea.(Couldn't show proper date but had to put something in) Can't imagine that the atmosphere would have changed all that much.

A Must See. A vibrant neighbourhood filled with small, interesting shops, restaurants and cafes. Narrow, winding streets are wonderful for strolling and enjoying the sights. It was raining quite heavily on the day we visited, and it was still very enjoyable. I don't think I will ever be able to go back to Paris, without visiting The Maris.

Special place in Paris. Fantastic neighborhood with many things to see. Elegant mansions, wonderful apartment buildings. My only regret is that so many of the special Jewish small businesses have gone away, to be replaced by not-so-interesting boutiques. It's really lost its historic flavor. Still, it has retained its village-like atmosphere, which is incredible.
Marais always fun. always fun to stroll this quaint area even though it gets busy on weekends with shoppers in little stores stop in Picasso too

Wonderful Neighborhood!. We had an apartment (through VRBO) here which was amazing! What a great location in the heart of the Jewish section and Rainbow Flags were in abundance. The true center of Paris! Remember, lots of small businesses close in July & August & it is completely up to the individual owner.
Most interesting part of Paris. Exciting and wonderful, this colorful part of Paris is a don't-miss. We love exploring it; you never see it all.
Don't miss the Mariais. We took a walking tour and although it rained the whole time, the Marais is so interesting just to look at and learning it's history. Walk through the streets and enjoy!

Great place to stay!. My husband and I stayed in this neighborhood on our recent trip to Paris. It was centrally located and easy to get around by walking or train. There were cute cafe's to eat at and people watch. Recommended to stay in this area if you want to stay in a neighborhood but still close to everything!

Best location for couples in Paris. If you are a couple stay in the Marais. Central, romantic and wonderful. On Sunday the place is the most vibrant area of the city. Before we had kids we just couldnt resist a weekend in the Marais. Also a great great great shopping district...
Buzzing with people on sunday. This area has so much to offer. The Jewish section was very lively and we stood in line for our falafel. The free city museum , Carnavalet is also here.

Be a wanderer!. We spent a sunny warm afternoon wandering and shopping on the Ile St. Louis, because we had read it was the thing to do. The next day we wandered through Le Marais, on a rainy day, slightly chilly, and we enjoyed it just as much. Maybe more. More shops. More distinctive shops. More streets that meandered this way and that. More small sections with their unique offerings. We filled a major portion of one day there.

Nice but over rated . Lots of great reviews but was below expectation. palace de voyages is a nice park but no activities for the children. If in Paris for more than a few days worth exploring but otherwise not on par with Montemarte, St Germain des pres or Latin quarter.
Trendy and hip. The gay area in Paris.. Awesome area that we just visited last time here and now lived in. Perfect for shopping, nightlife and many attractions in the area.
Original and groovy. Stayed in quaint apartment with no room to move, but so handy to everything Paris has. Walking is the way to go and the Marais makes this do-able .Love this city
A walking delight. One of the best districts to walk around it, leave behind the mayhem of the Left Bank and visit Le Maraisl

Apartment Rental in Le Marais. We rented an apartment through Vacation in Paris. I love this area. The location of our apartment was in the gay area of Paris. Since we were 4 traveling females, we felt perfectly safe in this area. There are many stores and restaurants in this area. The train locations were close. Our apartment was conveniently located. Traveled July 2014.

This is Old Paris! And Yet New Paris!. The Marais is one of the oldest sections of Paris. It was built literally out of a swamp. During Louis the IVX's time, the Marais was the home of his nanny to his may bastered children. She ultimately became known as Marie de Maintenon. She ultimately married Louis in a morganistic marriage. She never gave Louis any children but she was highly respected for her love of his bastered children and her care of those children. Today the Marais is valued for the valued antiques and history that is available to view there....
Worth a visit but no longer old Paris. Now basically a shopping center with very upscale shops and some still interesting galleries and restaurants plus the Picasso museum. The Marais of old is gone.

Stay Here .. We stayed here for 4 days in a rented apartment. Best decision we could have made. Great neighborhood to walk around , see the sights, shopping , museums, 1 mile from Notre Dame and near metro. Safe area to walk around at night with many restaurants including the famous Fallafel café . Great vibe .
Where else would you stay in Paris. The Marais is so much fun. Great restaurants, so many interesting people, excellent bars and bistros.. And the shops can be very different and individual.
Love this area. This area of Paris is always alive with activity. Good restaurants, lots of public art, and fun things to see.

Best Day to visit is Sunday. This part of Paris is a must see. As you walk through the Marais the excitement builds. You will find a neighborhood where Parisians work and play. The Jewish quarter is a must see. Great food and bakeries. Save your appetite for a falafel, but be prepared to stand in line. Well worth it!!!

trendy spot. It boasts great restaurants and many that are not even costly. The area has character, it is artistic, bohemian and creative. Plenty of coffee shops, tons of photo opportunities, many apart gallery and just a great place to discover.
Fun Paris neighborhood.. Fun lively neighborhood with a mix of cultures. Great for dining, cafe people watching and shopping. Easy to walk though metro is an option too.

Cultural and Historical Experience in One. I love the Marais district, or arrondissment (in French). It is the 4th Arrondissment and is easily accessible by Paris's extremely efficient metro system (you can get off at St Paul, Châtelet, Hotel de Ville or Louvre-Rivolli along the yellow line -line 1 to easily access it). The Marais is the Jewish district and it is filled with scrumptious bakeries with many Jewish delights as well as normal baked goods like croissants, pain au chocolate etc. I definitely recommend a walk along Rue de Rivoli (the main street) however there are many cute streets just off it around the St Paul area. Great authentic Parisian cafes. Visit the area at night or by day, and make sure you visit it whether you're here for a day or a week. I stayed via Air BnB in the Marais and I just love it. If you get an accommodation with kitchen space and have the implements to cook, I recommend that, it saved a lot of money!

Vibrant Neighborhood. My favorite Arrondissement. Great neighborhood with lots of fabulous cafes and restaurants. Not to mention the excellent shopping. Must visit Place des Voges for a walk through the square and under the arcades. Also be sure to grab a snack at L'As du Fallafel. Skip the line and pay a little extra inside for faster service.
Le Marais. Another fun area to spend walking and enjoying as there is much to see! Please take the time to do so when you visit Paris!

Excellent bars/ restaurants/ shopping. You can easily spend a day or two wondering around this area visiting the many, many cafes, restaurants and bars between shopping. It is a reasonably large area with lots of little back streets and interesting buildings as well as being very easily accessible from Bastille. Worth giving over at least a day to.
Lovely Quarter. See Victor Hugo's apartments, overlooking the Square. Picasso Museum near-by. Lots of boutiques, cafes, Holocaust Museum, history comes alive.
Fabulous arrondissement. Great area to stay. So much to see and do. Place de voges, Victor Hugo Museum. Musee Carnvalet and so much more.

History, art, cafe's and shopping altogether.. Visiting Musee de Picasso, Maison de Victor Hugo and Hotel de Sully, walking inside a beautiful yard and the park of Place des Vosges, having a lunch at a cafe at Place du Marché-Sainte-Catherine, walking around the streets full of varieties of shops, Le Marais was truly a pleasant experience. I wish I had planned the whole day here.

Best tour with Jennifer of Paris By Mouth!!. Jennifer is great and enthusiastic. She knows the city, her wine and cheese!! take this three hour walking tour in the Marais and you will not be disappointed!

Le Marais. This is a great place to say
Its on the metro. Its less touristy than most of the other area. The restaraunts are good value (not overpriced). Walking distance to most sites. Its also got some really good local attractions. Its got a lot of small galleries - hidden bars etc etc

Truly the living heart of Paris. This area of 4th is humming with little cafes, people chatting, art studios and the essence of being Parisienne.
My fave spot to just wander and enjoy. Very affordable and very good food.

Great area to discover. This is a wonderful area of Paris with many small cafes, shops, intercepted by lovely small gardens. It has a very hip feel to it, yet has so much history if you read the plaques on buildings etc.

Trendy. A must-visit!
The neighbourhood is known for being the gay community's favourite spot. It's great to walk around and discover artistic and trendy designs. Came across an ice cream store which opened recently: "Une Glace a Paris". Exquisite flavors! Just one of the very many gems one can stumble upon.

One of my favourite places in Paris. The Marais district is one of the most historic, beautiful, bustling, exciting districts in Paris. My favourite haunts there,,,,,,,,,are The Auld Alliance pub , Place des Vosges... St Paul village, Carnivalet ( Museum of paris ) Picasso Museum, Place de la Bastille, and Hotel de Ville.
