Easily accessed by metro St. Paul ans Bastille ,or buses 29, 69, 96, & 75. Lots of choice of restauraunts and cafes to suit all tastes and price range.
A Culinary Crawl. I did a culinary tour, a neighborhood foodies crawl, which was great fun and gave me a glimpse of some of the best places in this fascinating area of Paris.
Sunday Stroll. The place to go for shopping on a Sunday. Fantastic atmosphere with live music on the streets as you stroll. Boutiques and restaurants, beautiful architecture abound.

So hipster chic!. Theres a range of great food here. Little vintage cafes, gelato bars, also big meals.Best falafel in Paris! Just find the most crowded falafel.Spend time around here by feet, take your time to explore the small alleys. Its such a chic place with small local shops.

A walk in the Marais. Stayed in this lovely area for a week. A great walk available starting a the Rue Anotine and finishing at the Pompideau Centre. Takes in a very historical part of Paris including the Jewish area. Penty of good eating in this area, is a 10 minute walk to Notre Dame. Well served by Metro (St Paul)and the hop on - hop off tourist buses. 5 minutes walk to the Bastille and market.

Good stroll. The SoHo, Village of NYC..... Super trendy, we have seen the develop of this part of town thru the years; worth to stroll around and get lost among all bistros, cafés, little shops with detailed personalized attention.

Take a walking tour. Eat the falafel (L'As du Fallafel is really good and hype is deserved) and explore the shops -- and take a walking tour. I loved the Marais before taking a walking tour and loved it more afterwards because I learned how to access many splendid public gardens. Get off the streets and into these gardens. They are terrific. I took the Paris Walks Marais tour (as well as several others in 2014 and 15) and they are uniformly good.

Great neighborhood to stay in while visiting Paris. We stayed in Le Marais during our recent visit to Paris. The neighborhood is bustling with cafes, restaurants and shops. It's also extremely convenient to hop on the metro (Line 1, Saint Paul stop) and visit all of the popular attractions. Then come "home" at the end of your day and find a nice restaurant for dinner. Neighborhood museums include the Picasso Museum and The Victor Hugo House.

Stay in the district or spend time in it. This is the place we always stay. Night time in the Marais is full of bustling people, young, gay, straight, locals, tourists. Great place to watch the world go by.

Vibrant neighborhood..well worth spending a day in.. Love this area of Paris. So vibrant and beautiful. Lots of shopping and restaurants. Definitely stop to have some falafel on Rue des Rosiers. Walk from the Bastille to the Place des Vosges and check out the Hotel Sully. Victor Hugo's home is a free musuem. Le Marais is also home to the Pompidou Center. It houses modern art and has a spectacular view of Paris.

I would stay in this area again if I returned to Paris.. We spent a week in Paris and stayed in an apartment in the Marais. It is by far the most interesting area if you want to live among the oldest buildings in Paris and you enjoy an eclectic and lively neighborhood/scene. Lots of pedestrian only streets. Lts of fun ethnic restaurants.

Worth visiting. We spent a day walking through this neighbourhood. There are many interesting historical sights. For us the two surviving medieval houses were of particular interest along with a remaining section of one of the old city walls of Paris.

A lovely neibourhood. All the houses are beautifull...the shops...too and In that area , you have Carnavalet museum, which is Paris museum, exactly revolution museum : a lovely painting of Loius XVII, a copy of Marie Antoinette bedroom when she was in jail... Emotion !

The Swamp. Very old stuff around here. Was walking down a side street and stopped to watch some school children playing with a ball against a stone wall. Come to find out, the wall was a thousand year old Roman fortification. Again, you can't help but trip over history with every step you take.

Lively. If you are in Paris on a Sunday there are several areas which would be closed. Le Marais is the perfect place to go to on a Sunday and is quite lively. This is a Jewish quarter with Picasso museums and great restaurants.

old and not at all cold. We have been fortunate to have been enjoying an apartment in the middle of le Marais for 10 days on our first visit to Paris. We have toured much of the centre of the city and walked various bits more thoroughly without finding an area we would rather stay in. Transportation to anywhere is easy from here (but probably easy from most places in the city centre) and the scale is human, whereas parts are so grand as to be less manageable. As soon as one steps off the Rue de Rivoli, the streets are quieter and in most places, it feels very local, rather than just touristy. Wonderful, hidden gems lurk everywhere, and one feels as though one is making a special discovery, though it is clear that many thousands do the same. Fantastic food everywhere. The first shop I've seen devoted entirely to honey. Wonderful neighbourhood to explore and to stay in, if you have the chance.
Amazing streets. Walk this streets amazing! Young Designers, small boutiques, Picasso Museum, spend the whole afternoon here always find something new

Felt very safe. As a gay man, I felt completely safe and comfortable walking down the street and holding my boyfriend's hand. Other than the feeling of safety, it has a great vibe with many great restaurants and wonderful access to the Republic metro station

Great neighborhood for exploring. This is a fun place to wander. There are quaint little streets, lots of clothing shops, tea stores, parks, it is an eclectic mix of people, loads of restaurants, and not a tourist tee shirt shopping in sight.

Top Sunday visit. such a nice area - go on Sunday when all other areas are closed but here as lively and wonderful. the Jewish quarter has great restaurants and excellent apple strudel at the bakeries. Also Picasso museum is here too.

Love Place des Vosges. Love walking around the shops as well as the square, Place des Vosges. There are beautiful galleries all along the square, great restaurants in the neighborhood, and even a playground in the middle of the square.
Old Paris, easy walking.. Good place to take a walking tour. Plenty of great old "palaces/homes", and a number of nice antique shops. Not as many good places to eat as other sections of the city

A Sunday well spent. We spent a delightful Sunday afternoon wandering through Le Marais. We spent most of our time around Rue de Roi de Sicile and the adjacent streets. The street art, the galleries, the quirky shops, the people watching - all were great. The cars are stopped on a Sunday which makes it very enjoyable. A great afternoon.

A wonderful area in which to stroll. This section of Paris has undergone quite a revival, while maintaining its charm and history. Even though it was raining, we still enjoyed browsing in the shops and admiring the architecture.

Fascinating and Intriguing Place to Visit and Stay. For the first time in several visits to Paris, we stayed in the 3rd arr. The neighborhood was terrific--a wide variety of restaurants, shops, bakeries, important sights, museums (especially the reopened Picasso), and the like. The best felafel anywhere, too. Rent an apartment if you can!

A lovely place to visit on a Sunday !. We really enjoyed our stroll around Le Marais, especially the village of St Paul (with it's quirky shops and places to eat) and the kids really enjoyed playing in Sq Louis XIII (Place des Vosges). It was a easy and relaxing way to spend a few hours a Sunday.

great walking tour.. Great place to walk around. lot of people watching and a very happening part of Paris. Lot of window shopping, cafes, and very historic part of town. Follow the Rick Steves tour book.
Super nice. Super nice quarter full of life and of art. Many museums can be found together with lots of shops and attractions. Just great!
musee carnavalet. Very interesting museum in this area( showing the history of Paris) and streets that make you feel like you have gone back in time.
Don't miss the Marais in the 4th.. We rented an apartment in the Marais and it was convenient to so many sights on foot. The metro is also very convenient. Lots of great restaurants and shops.
Less touristy part of Paris.. Great area with clusters of shops and restaurants. Perfect for emerging yourself into the city atmosphere and for general people-watching.

Shopping destination. After seeing the very expensive high end fashion districts, brands and department stores, the Marais was a great surprise. Huge variety in a small area. Great value and good food options in the middle east influenced cuisine

Cool Area In Paris. Le Marais is a cool place to explore in Paris. The great narrow streets, very artsy with great little shops and restaurants. Easy to reach by metro if you are not staying in that area.

Paris at its most interesting. This is our favourite area of paris. So cosmopolitan and bohemian. It isn he gary area and so nice to see so many gay men so safe and happy. The cafes and museums are all great and the parks and sites everything that Paris is about.love it.

ONE OF MY FAVORITE AREAS. Le Marais is a special place in Paris... you shouldn't miss going there. It's lovely; especially the tiny street called Rue des Rosiers; lots of shops, restaurants and people watching. Just a lovely area.

Great place to stay, and visit. Rented an apartment in the marais for our 5 day stay and so happy we did- centrally located, easy walk to notredame, bateaux mouches at the notredame quais, and most attractions, as well as a great destination in itself - cool vibe, very arts and fashion oriented, lbgtfriendly, close to the seine and multiple metro stops - ill definitely stay here again next time
Never a swamp!. One of the oldest parts of Paris, and containing the Jewish quarter which is attractive in itself. There are numerous attractions hiding for your discovery in the narrow streets.

A very old and fashionable district. What a nice combination...old Stones, fashionable shops, trendy and very mixed population in a very glamorous part of the city. It always has something to offer for all at any time of the day. Come and get yourself lost in these streets and discover the heart of Paris
Cool area. Very cool area - lots of nice shops, small bakeries, falafel shops etc. A great place to go for happy hour!

Still a wonderful neighborhood.. Although it's become very touristy in the last few years this is till one of my favorite areas in Paris. Great nightlife and good shopping. For restaurants you can't go wrong but I still love La Petite Cour for a romantic dinner.

Lovely area with much to do. Fantastic neighborhood with wonderful food, boutiques, and cafes. Wonderful strolling district to wander and get lost--very enjoyable. Extremely enjoyable if you like to eat and shop.
Trendy and fun..yet french. Trendy and fun. filled with creative contemporary shops and restaurants..yet it is still French. reminded me of Soho in London

Pretty Parisian Neighborhood. we rented an apartment on rue de Turenne and love the neighborhood. Close to Place de Vosges, L'As du Falafel, all the fashionable boutiques on Francois Bourgeois, nice pockets of parks, and old medieval buidlings.
Base station. We stayed at a place here for a week and what a great center for exploration! Close to restaurants, subway, jazz, and the seine. Look here for a stay
fun but..... shopping was fun but we ended up in a part where it was only for wholesalers...however we liked the shops we did visit. The food was more expensive that other parts of paris.

My favorite neighborhood in Paris for walking and eating.. My favorite neighborhood! So many cozy streets, awesome restaurants, and unique little boutiques. Jewish, liberal, and so many other historical influences.

Our favourite part of Paris to stay..... This is the fifth time we have stayed in Le Marais when we have come to Paris. It has great food shopping, and eclectic boutique shopping as well as great transport access. Beautiful parks to sit in and wonderful history.
If you don't stay here, at least visit.
Best place to soak in the paris atmosphere. Pedestrzianised around rue rambuteau and thebplace to browse on a sunday afternoon. Calm, slow living, where crowds are strangely civilised.
Paris france. took the hope on hope off bus there was interesting. , i think wg´henn our in paris try tt o see as much as u can

My favorite part of Paris. One of my favorite parts of Paris. Can get crowded, but with a different type of tourist. Great shopping; great place to spend a Sunday when much of the city elsewhere is closed. It's also great for solo female travelers who want to feel safe on the streets at night; there's usually enough people out that it's never deserted.

Great area to wander and enjoy the sights and sounds of Paris. A very cool area to visit with excellent food choices. Try the Falafel's located in the jewish area - excellent! Quiet parks can be found as well as museums to visit.

Should Be Called LeCharacter. As Paris has become even more glamorous and expensive, full of the worlds leading brand boutiques LeMarais maintains as much of the original creative style that used to be all of Paris. Anytime spent here is well worth it. Be prepared to feel the more original style of Paris as you wander the streets.
oasis. a wonderful space to enjoy on a hot sunday afternoon. beautiful flower gardens...enjoyed a beer under the trees just watching families play and other visitors soak up the atmosphere
Great place to stay!. We (grandmother (me), daughter and granddaughter) stayed in the Marais 3rd arrondissement. We had more fun! There is something for everyone. Great food and shopping!

Great area to stay in. My partner and I stayed in this district for 8 nights while exploring Paris. So many great restaurants, bars, shops and cafes. There were too many to make our way around. Great neighbourhood to stay in and would definitely stay there again. Otherwise make your way there for a Sunday stroll when cars are restricted and the place is buzzing with life.

Great shopping -and Falafel.. Great shopping area, commercialized now, but lotta fun. Used to be more individual, that great two-story bookstore is gone, replaced by jewelry and clothing shops. But if you dig falafel, there's a fab storefront -a counter up on its hind legs as 'twere- where they sell you a double-fist-size pita full of tahini, veg and chickpeas for 6 Euros. Well worth an afternoon, maybe two.

Hands down the best part of Paris. Stayed in a beautiful tiny apartment in the Marais and it really is the most perfect base for exploring Paris. At first I was a bit dissapointed as I think I was expecting more of an East London style atmosphere with trendy bars and shops. However once I started to explore I loved that it hadn't been completely gentrified in that way.

Charming neighborhood, worth the visit. Great to visit by foot ! Delicious restaurants, interesting shops, walking through Paris's narrow streets and encountering a piece of history almost everywhere, i've loved it !
Well trod gem of a neighborhood. This neighborhood is no secret to anyone, but I still like to walk its winding streets and stop into the shops and boutiques.
La marais sojourn. Fabulous and everything's open. Well almost . Grant atmosphere, cute shops and check out the Swedish institute fir deckchairs and gazpacho.
Could live here, if the prices were ok. Love this area to walk around and discover small treasures. Friendly atmosphere and good vibes in this part of a big city !

Interesting History. not much to see, but through the walking tour, I learned about the history. don't forget to eat Éclair. the best can be bought around the neighborhood..
https://bubblywife.wordpress.com/2015/08/21/paris-honeymoon-day-4-jardin-du-luxembourg-la-marais/

Great area to walk. The Marais was a fantastic neighborhood for shopping, walking, and for food. It's the location of the Jewish quarter so there is a presence of armed guards throughout but it's a great area to walk and enjoy the Paris culture.
Great cafes and shops. We stayed in the Marais district for a week and really enjoyed the cafes and shops that this area offers to tourists.

Just love the 3rd. Almost certainly our favourite area...spent countless hours just watching the world, shopping for produce and clothes (some great bargains to be had...found a coffeeshop that actually serves great coffee, it has a large boot out the front as a sign...drop in and see Lloyd, the coffee is as good as I have had in Paris!

Nom nom nom!. Not a fair title, cos le marais is not just about the food. The whole neighborhood is charming like no other with all kinds of corners to fall in love with and take photo's off. It's big too, lots of streets and hidden courtyards to come back to and rediscover. Definitely a favorite part of Paris for many, you can't not go there!

Great Neighborhood to walk around, shop and dine. One of the nicest, most vibrant area's in Paris. So many shops, restaurants, bars and people watching. You can spend all day walking around the area, but I actually preferred the night scene there better. It's very active with restaurants/bars for every desire.

LOVE IT!!. I absolutely adored this neighborhood! I had been to Paris twice before I'd ever even heard of the Marais. This is my new favorite area of Paris. The streets are so cute and quaint with the boutiques and art galleries, there are tons of delicious falafel options, and the Musée Carnavalet is a must see! Victor Hugo's house is also around here. In the middle of the neighborhood is the Synagog as well as lots of cool Jewish jewelry and book stores. I enjoyed just walking around and shopping. I will definitely be back!

nice place to visit or stay. spent 5 hours just wlking around this area, great for shopping and sightseeing, lots of lovely places to eat. We stayed in the latin quarter but would stay here next time.

Lunch . A great place to grab a falafel (green stall) and pastry (blue shop with Jewish candles in the window) from rue de rosiers, keeping the bakery on your left if you keep walking you'll see some black gates on your left, these lead to a nice little garden, a nice place to sit and eat your purchases.

Another great part of Paris. What a lovely, gun neighborhood. This part of Paris is extremely old compared to the "Haussmann" Paris. Architectural jewels everywhere but each one different, unusual. Also, reminders that this area had been a ghetto historically and a Jewish quarter and, not too long ago, Not a fashionable Quartier filled with great boutiques, fun restaurants and relaxed young people. A million miles from Avenue de Montaigne, both areas just as beautiful.
Lovely neighborhood. Lovely and livable neighborhood with everything you need. Food, shopping, cafes, and chic people. Not too crazy with tourists, fabulous place to spend your visit.
Great neighborhood. Great part of the city for shopping, eating or just wandering around. Avoid the main streets and get lost in those smaller and quitter.

Le typical Marais doesn't exist anymore. What happened there? Where are the french bakeries, the hats shop, the bookstores, all these particular shops that used to make this "quartier" so special? It's also meant to be a "gay" area, what a joke: they're just a few bars now! Same for the jewish area: gone! All you find now are the same big labels you see everywhere even in your own country. The typical parisians you used to cross in these streets? Gone! Either their homes are now rented for tourists'short stays, or hotels built everywhere instead. What's the interest? None. "Le Marais" is dead, and this is a real shame.

Not impressed. We walked along Rue de Rivoli which was lined with lots of cafes and shops. We walked through Hotel de Sully to Place de Vosges .We previously visited Place de Vosges in late January so it was lovely to come and sit on the grass by the fountain in the sunshine.We definitely need to return to spend more time in this area.

3rd, 4th, 1st or 2nd - Dont Worry Which One. Have stayed in both the 3rd (Le Marais) and 4th and the two are great spots for walking to the major sights. Both lead off the 1st and 2nd so don't be worried about which of the 4 arrondissements to stay in as each make walking a pleasure and all have absolutely everthing you will want from Paris.
Good area. This area is great not so touristy . We stayed in a hotel here. Lots of rental bikes to use the subway / metro is easy too..
Charming. A beautiful area with great shopping and restaurants. Better to take the small sidestreets than the main road.

Cute Streets and Shopping. Enjoyed walking around the cute streets and finding different shops along the way. It was rainy but we still enjoyed walking around and finding a little place to enjoy a nutella filled crepe!

Place to stay........... Stayed in this area on recommendation by a friend, it did not disappoint, so central to everything, has everything in walking distance, cafes, restaurants, shops, metro and all the main attractions.

Parisian Soho: Fashion shopping in Old Paris. As close as possible to London's soho. Great to have a walk, sit at cafes and watch people passing by, check art galleries - and a paradise for clothes-shopping.
Run!. For me the best neighborhood in Paris to walk around, eat and shop. Make sure to go to rue Rosiers and eat falafel!!!

Historic quartier. When I was studying in Paris, I did my stage in the 3eme. At first I was extremely bummed to not be in the hip 7eme, but I soon realized just how lucky I was. I could walk to Place Vosges and try to imagine Victor Hugo writing away. It's also not far from Centre Pompidou. And, there are some neat little restaurants tucked away. A faire!

Nice little community. When we first got to Paris we had rented an air bnb in le marais. Unfortunately that didn't work out but lil time we had there was great. Food, drinks and shopping are a step away...I did see young Jewish boys/men kinda harassing others to join whatever they were a part of..not fun! As for the police they would always be parked right in front of this famous falafel shop..don't know why..other than that had a great time wandering.

Do not miss out!. Le Marais is our favourite neighbourhood in all of Paris! You will find everything here... Amazing shopping, great restaurants, fun bars, superb architecture, wonderful old "hotels", world class museums, cobbled streets, the Pletzl and Place de Vosges...Oozing with History!A small area located in the real heart of Paris and totally walkable!

Amazing Area!!. This area is the best area in Paris for tourists, hands down. Shopping, eats, people watching, the whole nine. It also has some great Jewish stores and shops; it's nice to see that in Paris - the Jews in Paris don't shy away, given the historic anti-Semitic issues they continue to face in the city. Go there. You won't regret it.
Very Walkable Area!. Great shopping, good restaurants and not too far from the Picasso Museum. Take your time and enjoy the sights!
Great place to sit and meditate. We sat and listened to a busker singing in contraltor while eating our baguette cheese and salmon. Amazing gardens very peaceful

Perfect place to stay. Rented an apartment in Marais and it is the perfect place to stay and walk around for a leisurely stroll. Close to everything that you need but so many little shops, boutiques, restaurants, you're never wanting for anything when you're there.

Funky area but boutiques overpriced. This area had a really funky vibe with lots of boutiques, but after entering a few stores we found them to be really overpriced. This was unfortunate as I was hoping to hit the shops here.

Sad to see the need for so many armed police in this lovely quarter. Le Marais is a wonderful olde worlde quarter of Paris with a host of restaurants of every type and flavour and a mix of cultures. We had been keen to show it to our kids as we remembered it fondly from previous visits and in many ways it was as good as ever. But. Sadly it has become necessary for the armed French genarmerie to guard not only local places of worship, notably synagogues, but to have armed police outside every kosher shop and restaurant. On the one hand it was good to see them take things so understandably seriously, but on the other it did stop us in our tracks and it was hard to explain why they were needed there to our 7 year-old. Despite that we had a lovely meal and still look fondly on this quaint area of Paris.

best place in paris to stroll around with saint germain. simply my favorite place in Paris. strolling around you can discover lots of little restaurants/cafes, many artists displaying their art, art gallery, jewelry shops, and more. a great place !
Neat shops for gifts. Great place to buy something for family back home. Supposedly, This is one of the areas locals really shop.

Charming. We wandered around Le Marais a couple of times - especially around the Place des Vosges. There is an amazing tea shop, Dammann Freres, that was established in 1692. Tea is an excellent gift, not expensive, very personal and best of all not heavy!!! The Miss Manon Patissier and this area of Rue Saint-Antoine is a foodie's delight - cheeses, pastries and everything you could wish for. Not far away is the Musee Carnavalet which showcases the history of Paris and well worth a visit if you are not museumed out.

Le Marais - live like a local?. We stayed in this arrondissement our 2nd time to Paris; it is lovely and on our last night found the best local bistro (isn't that how it always works?). We will likely choose a different neighborhood for out next stay, but this area was a nice break.

Best place in Paris. This is my favourite neighbourhood in Paris! It's very dynamic and Parisian, quaint and romantic! It sprawls on both the 3rd and 4th arrondissements of the city. You'll find many nice luxury, independent, trendy boutiques, as well as a few chains such as Uniqlo, H&M and American Apparel. Le Marais also houses many "Hotels particuliers", museums (Musée des Archives, Musée Carnavalet and more...), bars and restaurants. It also serves as a miniature Chinatown (the main one is in the 12th arrondissement), the main Jewish quarter (mostly around the Rue des Rosiers) and as Paris's gay district (focused mostly around the BHV department store)!

Romantic weekend. Another very lively area with narrow lanes full of interesting boutiques, lively bars and good restaurants including lebanese for great Falafell and huomus. There is also a Jewish quarter and the lovely Place des Vosges a nice garden to enjoy a picnic

Very crowded on weekends during summer!!. We were here on both a Saturday an a Monday. Saturday was a zoo! The crowds were almost overwhelming. However, the atmosphere was far more calm and comfortable. Although aspects of this former old Jewish neighborhood remain, the area also includes lots of upscale shops and galleries. It is a fun place for a stroll.
Quaint, Artsy and Boutique shopping. Great area filled with unique shops and galleries. Definitely leave time to wander all the streets. Cafe's here outstanding.
Such a fun area!. Such a fun area to check out on Sunday's in Paris. A lot of other areas are closed, but Le Marais is wall-to-wall people! Cute shops and cafes!
Such a fun area!. Such a fun area to check out on Sunday's in Paris. A lot of other areas are closed, but Le Marais is wall-to-wall people! Cute shops and cafes!

Le Marais: Continuing To Evolve For The Better!. Much more to offer than Hugo's abode and the Picasso Museum. This district continues to become more hip but not fully gentrified (thank goodness). Begin with Place des Vosges and spend the day exploring it's galleries, shops and cafes--I recommend La Place Royale. Anyway, I'm sure you'll make your own discoveries. Just know this district continues to change and amaze.

Le Marais Visit. Excellent part of Paris. Ancient and historic. Great place to get a falafel. Good museums, shopping, deli food - just a wonderful place to walk and wonder. When making a trip to Paris, you need to visit this section of town. Conveniently located near the Place de la Vendome. Also contains the Jewish section of town. Men can get free blessings from the Hasidic Jewish men who line the streets.
Great nightlife. Amazing area but like everything in Paris it closes early. Must do on a visit to Paris. Great nightlife also.
Colourful, Artistic, Creative. Colourful, Artistic, Creative and an extremely exciting part of Paris. Highly recommend for all tourists to visit this area.

A special place for travellers. This is a fascinating area of Paris to experience. It is just 15 minutes on the Metro to Central Paris and is emrging from being a less privileged area into slowly being gentrified. It's history is worth reading. It is a fascinating mix of small eating places, the population is culturally mixed and part of its life is artistic and creative. It was here a century ago that Edith Piaf was born in abject povery and her life and music gives depth to the are. This is a place you can return to often.
Great Neighbourhood. We enjoyed staying in this area. So many great shops and restaurants. Another Paris gem worth exploring.

Exploring Le Mariais. This is a much touted part of Paris but it is so big, it is hard to know where to start. I always take the metro to Bastille and walk down Rue Sainte Antoine to Place des Vosges. If you need a wonderful haircut in Paris, you can book one on the way at Les Coiffeurs de la Rue. Place des Vosges used to be full of fab shops but now it is mostly very expensive galleries and cafes but the architecture is just sublime. I think this is one of Paris's treasures. If you want a traditional French meal at affordable price, go to Cafe des Vosges here, not all the other fancy cafes. Then find you way to Rue de Vieille Temple with all its cute boutiques, artisan studios and history. Exit Le Marais by the metro Hotel de Ville

A 17th century city within Paris. A must.. Beyong the Bastille Square, the Marais is a magnificent 17th century small city within Paris. Before King Louis XIV built Versailles French aristocrats had their Parisian mansions there. Then they followed the kings to Versailles. On the superb, unique Place des Vosges, our great writer Madame de Sévigné was born and in the XIXth century our greatest writer Victor Hugo lived there. His home is now a wonderful museum (free entrance) that I recommand. Its view over the square is really beautiful. Further on, The Carnavalet Museum (40 rooms on the history of Paris), the home of Mme de Sévigny when she was married, is worth a visit to discover a 17th century Parisian mansion. The Marais is a district very popular with Parisians for elegant shopping. A must in Paris
One of the most interesting parts of Paris. One of my favorite neighborhoods in Paris. Lots to see and do - Picasso museum, excellent shopping, cool restaurants. Plan to spend a day here.
great spot for sunday walking.....went to jackie o exhibit. my most favorite neighborhood, shops, galleries, cafes, bakeries, so many streets to wander through...wonderful

Very quaint and lovely place to visit. This quaint area is very different from the rest fo Paris and thoroughly enjoyable. After I left, my wife went there again. Lot's of Kosher restaurants and a number of memorable signs from the deportation in WW2

Shoppers and Eaters Delight!. The Marais is famous for the shopping and the restaurants. I promise, you will not be disappointed. Boutiques line the streets, next to cute little cafes and bistros. The Marais is one of my favorite neighborhoods in Paris, simply for the shopping. I always visit certain shops, such as Mariage des Freres for tea, Repetto to admire the shoes, and, of course, there are the beautiful vintage shops along the way. I could easily spend the entire day here, shopping and eating. Sales are in January and July, and they are good ones. Favorite clothing stores are Bimba y Lola, Sandro, Maje, Comptoir des Cotonniers. Best fallafel in the world at L'as du Fallafel. Excellent people watching. Bring your credit card, and feel confident as you order the felafel sandwich, it will certainly be delicious.

Spectacular. The Marais is beautiful with clean streets, magnificent architecture, trendy shops and cafes, quiet parks, and so much more. It's a perfect balance. If you're in Paris, it's worth a visit to this neighborhood, which many (including me) consider their favorite.

I think we explored this area the most. We were staying on Ile Saint Louis and it was very easy to cross the bridge and be in Le Marais. This was a place of royal residences for centuries but the revolution changed that. However, the area was revitalized. We particularly enjoyed visiting the Musee Carnavalet, Hotel de Sully, Hotel de Sens, Place des Vosges and Place de la Bastille. Le Marais is also home to the Picasso Museum which was closed for a while and is now re-opened - I spoke with someone who raved about it. One will also find lots of interesting shops and restaurants in Le Marais.

Marais maze. We went on a walking tour with Paris Walks in this area. Quite eye opening with the history of the area and the gardens and places we were taken were very interesting and places we never would have discovered ourselves. Some great shops there both eating and goods.

The real Paris with a special quality --Je ne sais quoi. you must see the Le Marais area with special streets , shops , cafes and museums ie the Picasso and Jewish Museum. If you want to see the real Paris is the a must!
Le Marais is perfect. Walking down the streets of Le Marais will get you in the Parisian vibe. With cafes, restaurants, shops, book stores, gays... it has everything! I just love it!

Quintessential Paris. One can't go to Paris and not mosey around the ancient streets of the atmospheric Marais neighborhood. It's all there, cafés,bistrots,patisseries, boulangeries and boutiques of all things French. And of course that's where BHV is - the favorite department store if the locals. Head to it...
Don't!!!!. Miss this area when visiting paris :-)Eat at the restaurant where lenny kravitz went L'as du fallafel

The marais is the best . Maybe not for everyone but the marais is my favorite area in Paris - if you are tired of the hustle bustle of the city during high season or just want quiet streets to wander with some lively cafes ~this is the backstreets of Paris that I love-

Magical. We stayed in the Marais for 5 nights last week and it was picture postcard Paris. The area is made up of a myriad of small winding streets cutting across the occasional boulevard. As you stroll around you pass numerous street cafes, small artisan shops and designer boutiques. Around every corner there is a park where you can sit and people watch in the shade. The streets feel safe. It was my dream destination and I didn't want to come home.

Stay in Le Marais. As a family of 4 (kids 10 & 8), I can strongly recommend staying in Le Marais district. We rented an apartment through airbnb and unlike other areas in Paris that close down in August, Le Marais was still vibrant. A diverse culture and a party atmosphere after dinner however we always felt safe walking home from a large variety of restaurants (ideal for fussy eaters!!). Plenty of Metro options best by but we often walked 2-3km to nearest attraction

Great place to stay. Marais is a great district to stay and feel like a Parisian. In every corner you discover small and cute cafes, bars etc while you can go on foot to many places of interest (Pompidou, Louvre, Place des Vosges). If I visit Paris again, i would like to stay there for sure!

Our first stay here, but not our last. This is our first time to stay in Le Marais and we are loving it. It has a wonderful neighborhood feel to it. There are so many small, interesting shops and cafes. Every corner we turn offers new delights.

The place to be and not to miss. If you want to enjoy Paris, les Marais can not be missed! great atmosphere, nice walks, music around , shops and restaurants! On Sundays some streets are closed to traffic so even more enjoyable. It is a wonderful area if you want to get the favour of real Paris. We always focus in the traditional monuments when visiting Paris however this "quartier" full of life offers you a sense of happiness and the answer to why Paris remains one of the most romantic cities in the world.

Charming district!. We went to Le Marais because we wanted to visit the Place des Vosges, but we were surprised to find how much this district has to offer! Apart from the many buildings of historic importance, including former residences of the French nobility, Le Marais features lots of interesting shops, trendy restaurants and museums. You can (and should!) spend an entire day exploring this charming area and visiting shops and museums.
Paris as I have always imagined it.. This was a great area for us. Shopping of course, but more my idea of a Paris I want to know than the more central Pont Neuf regions.

Really cool area!. Le Marais has become one of the coolest areas for shopping and dining in Paris. There are fewer tourists and many bespoke shops. Do not forget to visit Place de Vosges, it is awesome!
Sunday shopping!. Lovely area for shopping (including on a Sunday) and wandering. Musee carnavalet and places des Vosges highlights.

The best neighborhood in Paris. Le Marais is the lgbt/Jewish/hip neighborhood in Paris. I use to live in Marais for a year and enjoyed my stay. Everything (gourmet shops, restaurants and apparel shops) was within walking distance. Good vibe and very convenient.

The Marais is a must. For the discerning traveller this area is most rewarding. So get away from the overpriced chic of Place Vendomme and Concorde and come go to the Marais. No dearth of wonderful eateries, including the wonderful Falafel places, ice cream parlours especially Pozzetta and numerous interesting cafes. There is of course Place des Voges and its elegant restaurants but the little streets are the real gems to unearth.

Great area for browsing, great restaurants, wonderful bohemian feel.... On our last day in Paris we decided to have a restful day and wandered around Le Marais in the afternoon.. What a lovely area! There are lots of unusual and individual shops here as well as some really lovely restaurants. I also enjoyed looking in all the art galleries under the arches in the Place des Vosges and sitting in the park in the middle of the square on a hot summy day enjoying watching the fountains. Victor Hugo's house on the square, which is free to visit, is a recommended attraction. There are various cafes/restarants around the square which looked really lovely to. What a wonderful area of Paris! It's well worth a visit.
Charming arrondissement. Le Marais is a charming area, lots of great restaurants, good shopping, museums, hotels etc. Good vibe. Would choose to stay in the this arrondissement again..

Charming area to flaner (wander).. Good architecture. Trendy fashion shops. Place de Vosges with its arches is charming. Art gallery area. Good place for a coffee sitting under the arches. Sad this this was once the Jewish area. All that is left are a few felafel takeaways in the famous Rue des Rosiers. At least they left up the Goldenberg restaurant sign.

Best Area in Paris. If you're in Paris, you must spend an afternoon/evening in Le Marais. The best part of Paris in my opinion. Unique boutiques for shopping, great restaurants, just a great energy throughout the area.

Surprise. Surely Le Marais neighbourhood was the surprise of this visit. We had no idea that it held so much of the French history and culture. Place del Vosges with its several art galleries was a delight. And it was wonderful to come upon many chic boutique clothing and shoe stores around each corner between historical sights. The Jewish museum was worth the walk to find though security there was tight. Need more time to explore on our next visit.
Quaint and interesting neighborhood. There are many interesting buildings and shops to see in this neighborhood, just by walking around. Walk slowly and enjoy.

Le Marais - lively, fanastic, artsy and cultured.. Referred to as 'The Swamp', Le Marais was originally given to the Jews as a poor settlement area, earlier on in history. Now in modern times, with a touch of irony, Le Marais has become tres chic, trendy and packed full of eateries, cafes, shops and museums. It really has so many things to see and do. I would recommend having a physical map of the area or internet access for an online one, so as not to get lost in the winding curving streets (if you're trying to find somewhere in particular), otherwise feel free to lose yourself in the delight and hubbub of this stylish arrondissement.

Favorite area in Paris. Loved my VRBO rental in the Marais. Cool funky area filled with loads of restaurants and bars, including my favorite, the Lizard Lounge. I felt very safe as well. Easy walk to the Seine, Ile St. louis, etc.
Very lively area. it's fun to be at Le Marais, shops, bars, brasseries, lovely little corners and with many visiting sights at short distance.
Shop away. Beautiful and clean district, full of shopping malls. The let down was the price, everything was very expensive.
Nice walk. Used Rick Steves walking tour and walked all over Le Marais. Very interesting walk, which we all enjoyed. My daughter enjoyed shopping the boutiques along the way.
So Paris. Nice atmosphere, I really like the atmosphere there. overall is just great you can't miss it ... make sure you visit Place des Voges which is nearby

Le Marais - Our Favourite Area in Paris. We visit Paris every year and we always stay in Le Marais. This is such a central area within walking distance of many attractions including Notre Dame, George Pompidou, the Latin Quarters and many more. There is also the convenience of many metro stations - Saint Paul is on Line 1 as is Hotel de Ville. Chatelet is also in tjis area.If you love 2nd hand clothing shops this area is definitely for you. There are also many many good eating places and coffee shops. Our favourite is in Rue Rivoli opposite Hotel de Ville and it is called Cafe Bio.They use organic coffee and many different types of milk are available. They are close to Starbucks but a million times better and yes they do have a toilet available downstairs.The Jewish quarters are in the Marais so some great Jewish food. It is also the area frequented by a lot of gays so all in all this is an area of Pris NOT TO BE MISSED. We love it!
Je'taime Le Marais. Beautiful, vibrant yet peaceful at night. Lots of Metro stops and the best vegetarian/vegan options in Paris are located in or near Le Marais!

People watching with good food!. Great section of Paris with nice Cafes , pretty people and small Boutiques with fine Clothing. This and the neighboring section were full of young well dressed Parisiens and had a wonderful youthful energy .
Worth a visit. Fun place to hang out, shop, just enjoy the scene - a few nice museums in the area. Good food as well.

The classiest arrondissement in Paris.. My favourite arrondissement - spend time in Place des Vosges and just sit in the gardens on one of the copies benches and watch the people go by. On Sunday the area's closed to traffic so one can walk down the streets in safety - though it does get rather busy of course as all the Parisians come out too.

Great neighbourhood for sightseeing. We walked the length and breadth of Paris from here. Loved the Medieval streets and edginess of this district. Tons of little tucked away bars and cafes. Very easy walk to several Metro stations, Notre Dame an easy walk. Just down the road from busier dining areas, the new Pompidou Modern Art Centre and the Musee de Picasso.Highly recommended if you like "not posh but interesting" and want to seek out "other" areas of attraction not on the beaten track.

Lively District. We rented an apartment in the Marais through Paris For Rent. This is a very lively district that even Parisians are flocking to. The cafes, shops, nightlife, and food, are top notch. Every day at 2:30pm, at the St. Sebastian Metro entrance is a free guided tour of the Marais neighborhood. They guides wear pink vests and our guide was informative, fun, and gave us a great overview of the area. Everyone gives a tip, which our guide definitely deserved.
Lovely part of town. We stayed in this area and found it very safe and accessible. The metro gets you everywhere quickly the cafes are great and open late.
nice area. We stayed here and found it quite convenient to most places. we took either the metro, St Paul's station or a taxi which was always available

My favourite arrondissement!. My favourite place in Paris! My first ever time in Paris was in the beautiful Marais arrondissement. Filled with history, fabulous food, shopping and St Paul Market. Place St Catherine & Places des Vosges, the Seine, Elise St Paul and metro so close. I will be back in August to discover this area more!
Stroll the backstreets. One of my favourite areas of Paris, narrow medieval streets and boutique shops, bars and coffee houses, for when your fed up with the tree lined boulevards.

Lovely old Jewish district. We loved our walk through Paris old Jewish district. We had delicious falafel sandwiches in the Rue des Rosiers and visited the beautiful Jewish Museum nearby. The area is steeped in History and yet the streets are full of life.

Nice little area to poke around. This is a great neighbourhood to explore - some amazing street art awaits you if you wander down some of the side streets. Nice little cafes, outdoor vendors and cobblestone streets in the older part of the neighbourhood. Take a walk by Place des Voges if you are in the area - picturesque square with benches to sit and relax.

Walk around and enjoy. Known as the gay area and the Jewish area, Le Marais is a great part of Paris to walk around. There are plenty of cafes to have an espresso, lots of shops to explore, a Gothic cathedral to visit, and lots of falafel to eat!

Paris Cool!. We are staying here so we decided to go on a walking tour of The Marais. Our guide, a young local, assured us that this is the trendiest area of Paris, where all the cool people live, or want to live. The walk was great. Plenty of interesting streets, secret gardens, restaurants, cafes. Very lively and well worth a look. It's just great wandering around the area for a few hours and a great way to spend some of your time in Paris.
Trendy and fun. Great area to stay or just visit. It is trendy with out the tourist junk. Good markets selling fresh produce and wonderful cafes.
Lots of everything. If you are looking for food, souvenirs or shopping, this is a great place to explore. Small streets and lots of history combined with boutiques and excellent retaurants

Savor the Moments. Walking the streets of the Marais is truly a privilege and a joy. But you can't rush. You need to sit in one of the outstanding patisseries and have a café au lait or have a picnic in the Place des Vosges park. This is Paris as it should be experienced.

Great neighborhood with lively nightlife. Le Marais is a great part of the city. It has many bars and open cafes with a lively nightlife. There are also many boutiques and specialty shops that makes for a great shopping day. The added bonus, a wonderful LGBT community.

Heaven to all sewing bees. What a wonderful amazing place with the most beautiful haberdashery and material shops ever. Send the kids and menfolk to the museums and just browse... Buttons and trimmings heaven

Le Marais!. What a wonderful area of Paris!
So much to see and to do ... great for just walking and enjoying being in Paris!

Wonderful neighbourhood to explore!. The Marais has so many things to offer! The wonderful Jewish bakeries and delis, fabulous Felafel and kebab eateries, the great shops, and of course, the history. This area is also home to the Picasso Museum, Victor Hugo's house, the Holocaust memorial wall and museum, and much more, all contained in a relatively small, walkable neighbourhood. Well worth a visit!

Real french place to visit. Real french place to visit. a lot of small streets, cafe, shops and so on. Most popular place for brunch, french people can even come from other place here for breakfast. in many cafe there is even a big queue of waiting hungry people who came for brunch.its normal that you will share the table in cafe with other people, so popular this place :)

The Real Paris . Chose this area to stay on as it is the real Paris. Marie alleyways markets great food and local people. Very affordable place to eat and sleep. Experience the real Paris through the eyes of the French
Superbe!. One of the most energizing neighborhoods of Paris today...so many boutiques, small museums, charming parks and squares. Love it!
Good shopping. This area has more of a local feel, There are some cute small shops and a big department store. We stumbled upon some good deals.
Paris area with loads of charm.. Great area of Paris that was untouched by Haussmann. Narrow streets, great shopping and great food. My favourite area of Paris.

Savoring Lunch 0n Bastille Day. Had an exquisite lunch of assorted sandwiches and salad served in a bento box, a scrumptious Mango Cake and Marco Polo Iced Tea. Then shopped for tea cup and saucer and tea glasses to add to my collection. Enjoyed browsing in the shops and sitting on the steps of the cathedral to take photos of the street scene and to people watch.

This is the Paris of before the boulevards. The Marais is a great place to stroll and to see what Paris was before there was a push to make wide streets (to limit rioters is the story). It has nice shops and is a photographer's dream come true.

So inviting. We stayed in the 3rd arrondisement (Maris) for a week. The area is so comfortable. If you want to feel quintessential Paris, this is the area. We rented an apartment for the week, and lived like a local. Which is the only way to get the heartbeat of a city, especially one as beautiful as Paris. Notre Dame, Pompideau, shopping and eating were fun and friendly. The local shop keepers knowing we were tourists still gave us equal service.....just speak a little French as it makes all the difference. We ventured to the Jewish quarter and it was a step back in time. We felt safe the entire time, and it was not our imagination. I spoke with a high end vintage shop keeper at length who said we are a safe neighborhood (25 Javier) on Rue de Temple. I recommend the Maris to any family or couple. The Metro was a block away, walking was amazing overall we were thrilled.

A Great District. we spent a day wandering through the marais and absolutely loved it. we really loved Place De Voges - we saw some of the most amazing art galleries/shops we'd ever seen. we had lunch in a beautiful small pedestrian square and generally loved the style of shops in the area. each to his own, of course, but it ticked all the boxes for us.

Wonderfull nabourhood. Small medieval streets with plenty of atmosphere. Lots of interesting little shops and plenty of cheap but good food options. Beautifull houses and a wonderful place just to stroll around

Back in time. Open Sunday , closed partly for Jewish holidays , it is a lovely quarter where there is plenty restaurants .It is a nice place for shopping with a lot of original stores . Museum Picasso & Carnavalet

Ideal Place to Stay. We stayed in a great apartment in the Marais.Lots of groovy little restaurants, not expensive, BVH dept store, Great bars and fabulous pastry shops.Close to several Metro stations.Loved exploring this area with our family - 2 adults & 2 11y.old children.Would definitely stay in this part of town again.

nice way to relax away from lineups. We spent an afternoon there just people watching, eating some foods and looking at the narrow streets. Interesting shopping and found a little place that did lots of art work and they were quite talented. The tiny crooked streets to just walk around on are fun to do. Its a cheap free day to wander the streets and grab a few small items in shops and have a drink. Lots of stairs so be ready or wait in line for a little shuttle to move up the hill to the cathedral nearby. Sacre Coure
Great Walk. Very nice area to walk around. Of all our visits to Paris, this was the first visit to Le Marais, wouldn't miss it next time.

Massive smoking ruins the charm of this place. Such a charming area to wander around, but lots of young people, and they all seem to smoke anywhere they want. It really make it awful to walk around small streets, knowing you were going to be assaulted constantly.

Sit in a cafe and watch the world go by.. We stay here most years for a week and each year consider it the best part to stay. The Jewish quarter, the many museums and the proximity to the best sightseeing. There are many hotels and also apartment rentals in this area and whenever something is happening in Paris Le Marais seems to be involved. Parades, street parties or just strolling performers. There are excellent restaurants and cafes.

Parisian Living. We stayed around this area of Paris for a week and will definitely stay here again my next visit. The Sunday market has great varieties of items; from food to clothes and kitchenware. Lots of good eateries around this area too.

Great for a wander or a shop... If shopping is your thing, I can think of nowhere better, setting in pretty streets with plenty of places to eat and drink it makes for a great shopping day out, quite pricy of course.

Paris at its best. Definitely my favorite neighbourhood in Paris. Walking through the beautiful narrow streets, the atmosphere, the typical coffee places, the old Jewish "rue des Rosiers" with all the falafel restaurants... It's the perfect place for a walk through Paris's history. Don't miss the Jewish Museum and its amazing collection of Art and historical objects.

Nice stay in Le Marais. We rented a loft apartment in the Le Marais neighborhood. We loved being so close to everything. There were great shops and restaurants and the neighborhood is very eclectic. We heard from a native that it is the trendy neighborhood now. I love that you see all types of people from every walk of life. We enjoyed sitting outside at the café and people watching. Would definitely stay here again. Close to Metro, walking distance to Notre Dame, Hotel de Ville and other great places.
Best place to stay in Paris. Close to wonderful places to see, fabulous shops and hundreds of lovely restaurants and cafes, spoilt for choice.

Favorite Area in Paris. We try and stay in a different neighborhood each time we visit and this was our first time to stay in the Marais. I don't think we will ever stay anywhere else again! Love our temporary neighborhood with all the shops, restaurants, markets and sidewalk culture. Can roam for blocks and blocks and still stumble upon a new small side street or great place to grab a bite to eat. We have walked the Marais before during previous stays, but there is nothing like being able to enjoy the energy and breathing in the culture on a daily basis.
Le Marais is Paris. There's everything in the Marais. Individual fashion shopping, all kinds of food, Jewish culture, the wonderful tea-shop and museum, - all fun.

Unique area not to be missed. Such a lovely area with wonderful shops (expensive ones). Ate lunch in the courtyard at the Swedish center before going to the Picasso Museum. Walked then to the Place des Vosges which is a quiet and lovely square.

Trendy and lively. Great neighbourhood to visit with tons of shopping and fun things to see. I could have spent a few days shopping there, every block has several stores with unique items. Recommeneded for the fashionistas and those that want to see something entirely different from the shops along the Champs Elysées.

Small town charm in the heart of Paris. Marais is worth a walk through. Walking into Marais had the feel of walking out of France and into another country. I didn't have the falafel, but the restaurants were packed with lines out the door.

Great area to visit or stay. Friends recommended we stay in the Marais on this visit to Paris rather than the quiet hotel ares previously stayed at. and I'm please we did. It felt very safe and friendly. The maze of cobblestone streets are full of great shops and little eateries. We found museums we hadn't heard of and lovely neighbourhood gardens hidden away. Well serviced by bus and metro it was easy to find our accomodation even coming in by metro. Definitely would stay in the area again

Miss it.......and you haven't been to Paris!!!. Slightly off the radar compared to other Paris destinations, but this is the Old Quarter, the place where you can see the real Paris before all the tourists and tack began to set in. Great to just wonder and take in the atmosphere.Miss it.......and you haven't been to Paris!!!

Greta Quirky Neighborhood. Strolling through this ancient neighborhood was a highlight of our trip. Lots of great little boutiques, restaurants, shops, thrift stores. Not the least expensive part of town, but worth the time to just get lost. Which is very hard with GPS.

Don't miss this neighborhood!. Don't miss a walk through this neighborhood. Simply explore or follow a tour in your guide book. Some of the best falafel I have ever eaten was right here. Great shops and markets too!

A wonderful quarter to visit and enjoy. Le Marais has a little of everything. Hop of Saint Paul metro station and you will be close to St Paul et St Luis. If you walk to the Seine you will get to some great paper shops (Papier +). Cross the rue Rivoli and you will get in a wonderful region of shops, cafes and bistrots. UNIQLO also has a shop now in Marais. Walk a little and get to Place des Vosgues. Atmosphere is fantastic, shops are great, food for every taste!
Shop like a local. The best place to go shopping and be a real Parisian! You would be amazed by the different types of boutiques and stores there for the true Parisian shopping experience

Great location. We stayed in this location on our first trip to Paris with our 3 teenaged children. It was the perfect location to easily maneuver the sites. There are boutique shops, restaurants and grocery markets for ease and convenience. The only reason it's not a 5 for us is we were treated rudely when buying groceries or shopping. I get the feeling the people who live there do not like tourists, especially those who speak English. We travel often, love meeting people, and usually give people the benefit of the doubt. If you are accustomed to people being gracious and welcoming, you should prepare yourself for a different experience.

Le Marais area, lots of Art and Fashion!. I stayed with a friend for a few nights on Rue Des Rosiers before staying in Montemartre. It's in the 4th Arr. area, amazing art galleries, boutiques, fabulous restaurants. Very close to the Picasso Museum.....lots of great architecture! Don't forget to try L'as du Fallafel, super popular spot!
It is not possible to NOT love this area. Loads and loads and loads of beautiful small boutiques and sidewalk restaurants. Always full of life and a new world to explore behind each corner.

Le Marais, a personal experience for each one of us...... On the Viking extension, we were taken to interesting parts of Paris. On the walking part we went to Le Marais, which is the part of the city where so much vivid history took place the Jewish community resided there. The French were part of the sad events that took place during the time of WWII. The part that was so impressive is the block long panel with names all the people that were taken unjustly by the French. The Police are a strong presence since there are still those that want to create chaos.They are friendly but very cautious. it is a lovely part of Paris.

Worth a walking tour even if you aren't on a shopping trip. One of the things we enjoy most in Paris is just walking around the city's various neighborhoods. We don't come here to shop, and eating isn't a primary focus either. We just enjoy seeing the neighborhoods and mixing and mingling with the crowds. The Marais is a great place to do that. Wander up and down the streets. Check out the Place des Vosges. Take a quick tour of the Carnavalet, or duck into an out of the way church that isn't in anybody's guidebook. Grab lunch in a place that's more local than touristy. We spent the better part of two full days here during a recent extended trip to Paris. We were there in daylight and evenings. I'm sure there are dark corners you wouldn't want to blunder into at night, but that's no more true here than anywhere else. Enjoy a trip through this interesting quarter.

Unquestionably my favourite part of Paris. Paris is a wonder. But it is BIG! And there is just so much to see. How do you decide where to start?Well, you won't go far wrong of you choose the Marais district to begin your walking and wandering.The streets here are smaller, narrower, more intimate than much of Paris with its grandness and scale. Take the metro (it really is easy) and get out at St Paul or Bastille (yellow line). Wander Rue de Rivoli. Head down the wee cobbled streets, past designer clothing, shoes, artisans. Past cafes and patisseries, book shops and antique dealers. Pop into churches or down covered alleys into new wee streets. Lovely, human-scale and busy but with French life, rather than teaming with tourists like the lovely St Germaine area.I won't stay in any other part of the city ever again - look at the Grand Malher hotel if you want to stay in Marais - perfect location and cheaper than much of Paris, for the equivalent quality...

Fantastic Neighborhood!. Wonderful vibrant neighborhood that is full of great restaurants, shops and bars! Also, a great place for LGBT bars if that is what you are looking for! Definitely a great place to stay or at least to take a leisurely stroll through all of the streets.

Great shopping. July to August are the sales months and every store had tremendous bargains. Of course there are a million shoppers in every store, but Le Marais is a fun section of Paris in which to shop and not as crowded as some. The narrow streets are fun to walk and window shop too.
Lovely shopping and restaurants. Love, love, love the Marais area of Paris. Quaint and lovely, unique shops. Lots of restaurants and wonderful feel to it. Always love staying here.

Cool Gay Neighborhood in Paris. Tons to do in this hip gay neighborhood of Paris. Great restaurants, museums, shops and people watching! It spreads across parts of the 3rd and 4th arrondissements in Paris.Check it out.

Satisfying Parisian stroll. This neighborhood keeps reinventing itself and right now is very exciting. We enjoyed a great afternoon at the Picasso Museum, recently reopened, with a coffee on the roof top terrace and a great stroll around nearby streets to do a bit of shopping. Lunch at Cafe Breizh for crepes and a late afternoon tea at Marriage Freres, and it was a perfect few hours in the neighborhood.
Have an adventure. Le Marais is a great area of Paris for shopping, eating, and exploring. It is tourist friendly with lots of little shops, parks, and bistros to explore.

Trendy part of town. Get a recommendation on where to go in terms of restaurants etc. Can be patchy depending on which streets you go to. Pompidou worth visiting for modern art and Georges restaurant.

Gritty view of Paris. Then Marais is Paris warts & all - some get put off by this area & avoid it - they are missing so much! Well worth a visit - try daytime only if not sure. Heaps of interesting things / people to see - shopping is great! Never felt threatened or at risk despite what some may say about the area. Full of history & authentic Paris lifestyles. Just keep an eye out for the many pesky beggars / gypsies etc. - they are very skilful at getting your attention while others pick your pocket - keep your eyes peeled! But still not to be missed.
Fantastic Location. Trendy area. Home to the Picasso Museum. Excellent for food and shopping. Wonderful little boutiques, tons of coffee shops and a ton of great places to eat.

My favourite place in Paris. Le Marais is such a vibrant and interesting area - narrow streets of cafes, restaurants, really interesting and different shops and bars. And lots of them!! A great place to stay or visit.
Very Moving. As the old Jewish quarter (and still), it is a very moving experience to be here. The streets resemble what old, pre Hausmann Paris looked like.
Fabulous shopping area.. The Marais is packed with shops cafes and restaurants and some beautiful hidden gardens. A great place to spend a day just browsing sat in a cafe, Place des Voges is lovely.

The best place to stay in Paris!!. We had so much fun in Le Marais. We stayed at an airbnb near the Saint Paul metro. Everything you need is near there. High end stores such as Zadig and Voltaire, Guerlain, Sandro, also stores like H&M, pharmacie to buy all of your French facial products and of course the Monoprix!! Love love the Monoprix!! Le Marais is so central to everything!
Best area in Paris. At least one of the best. Architecture, lots of cafés and restaurants. Small shops. Always alive. You can get lost in the little streets for hours and never get bored.
This is the best of Paris. Great museums, great places to eat. Great streets to wander around. You can get to all of Paris from here, and much of it on foot.
Lived here a couple months. All day long there is life in this part of Paris, you can find good places to eat, to have a drink, museums, parks, and a lot of people from everywhere in the world.

Worth TWO days for us!. Four years ago we must have only skirted the edges OR missed the essence of Le Marais because this time we REALLY went prepared to discover what all my research told me was there to see and we walked for two days and had a wonderful time...shops, galleries, restaurants...and I'm still not certain that we got to it all!
Being a local Parisian. If you don't like being around the business of Paris this is the place for you to stay in. Enjoyed the quite neighborhoods with tons of restaurants and AMAZING shopping.

Marais Wears Many Faces. The Marais has one of the city's great markets for food shopping. It has a lot of the city's older hotel particular for architectural history buffs. It has a lot of stores and boutiques for clothing shoppers. It has the Picasso Museum, finally reopened after years of refurbishing. It has the Place des Vosges with its own unique history and many art galleries.It also has crowds of people walking and gawking. It seems everyone you will pass during the day is a tourist.
Great NIghtlife at night, Great Shopping during the Day. Eat at the Dome Tower Restaurant. It doesn't stand out, you have to find, but food was amazing and great ambiance.

Fantastic area packed with culture. My wife and I stayed here in June 2015. We absolutely loved this arrondisment. The culture here is thriving but nothing that carries over late into the night. We were able to do a walking tour of Le Marais. I highly suggest doing so. You can learn so much about this changing arrondisment.

A Favorite on Sunday. Many shops and restaurants open in le Marais on Sunday, and you'll often find street musicians as well, which we love. There are some wonderful art galleries in the Place des Vosges, the district's square and park, one of the oldest in Paris. Definitely a "don't miss" area of the city.

A gay area with small hotels and cafes. Enjoy a walk around this area even stay at a small hotel there. Many small eating places and not far to the jewish district for a cheap lunch and even more flavours of true Paris

Rich bohemian neighborhood. The Marais is a most attractive area to explore, stay and eat. There are a number of museums, shops and cafes where famous writers, poets and philosophers once frequented. Rich in history.

History and flavour. A borrough known for its Jewish population, with many good restaurants. The Picasso Museum is here, and the Place des Vosges, a must to be seen. Try to walk through its narrow streets.

Great for strolling and (window)shopping the quaint boutiques. Le Marais is traditionally known for housing a significant Jewish population in Paris, and for offering the most vibrant gay scene in the city. Lovely neighborhood, with lots of beautiful small boutiques, where things may get a bit pricey.

Perfect for a sunny afternoon. Beautiful shops, cute cafes (the Swedish institute is nice for something a bit different with a pretty garden in the back), the Picasso Museum, nice gardens to read a book or take a nap, the best Falafel in Paris on Rue des Rosiers!

The Epicenter of the Capital City. This is the most trendy district of Paris, not far from Notre Dame de Paris, the River Seine, The Beaubourg Center, and many museums and touristic attractiosn make it a MUST SEE!! the Picasso Museum, the famous "Place des Vosges" , with many Art Galleries under the arches and typical restaurants around the Park, the "Hotel de Cluny" a marvel from the Middle ages ( there is a Mluseum of the Middle ages in Europe right threre) and many other attractiosn for the delight of the visitors of our City!Don't miss the "rue des Francs Bourgeois" with so many Arty and tredny shops. If you are lucky, tyou will enjoy street musicians and singers, and don't miss the "rue des Rosiers" where one can eat fallafells and oriental pastries. I found a unique fashion shop, rue des francs Bourgeois, in a old factory, with a huge original chimney and a museum that present the former activities in the nineteenth century.This area is a unique neighborhood with so many things to do! I live nearby for more than 20 years and I go there almost every week for a diner, a snack a photographic balade, I never get bored of it!! this is my home town! ENJOY!

Nice walking neighborhood. I walked back from the Picasso Museum to my hotel northwest of Republique and thoroughly enjoyed the stroll. It was a nice spring day and I took some of the back streets. Lots of trendy shops, cafes, restaurants and some very cool art galleries especially around the Picasso Museum.

You're in the Center of Everything!. Loved staying in this area. Very easy to use both the buses and Metro. I'd recommend taking the bus to begin your day as you pass so many beautiful sights. At the end of the day when you long for convenience - then hop on the Metro. Great shops and dining, too.

Tourists & locals. Great place to spend 2 weeks to head off & explore Paris. Local coffee places to start the morning..Jewish, Parisienne pastries. Nearby bus stops to start exploring( do get a map). Local places for dinner if you make it back to the area. We really liked La tartine for irregularly timed meals. Interesting shopping, several very good museums. A good local experience

Great walking and shopping, even on Sundays!. This area is filled with interesting cafes, delis, restaurants, bakeries, boutique shops, parks and historic buildings. It is the only place we found with stores open on Sundays. Perfect place for a rainy day -- lots to see, do and eat.
It is very romantic ,but gay area of Paris. They are very popular for restaurant and a lot of very good Jewish food,but also many gay bar.For me when I walk around I feel very romantic.
Very fun!. Great food, great people watching, great shopping! Nice way to take a break from the usual touristy things and just enjoy an afternoon/evening
Entertaining. Fun place to just sit and people watch - we sat near the museum of modern art and just watched the world go by from street entertainment to children in the waterpool.

So many little side streets. Take your time wandering through Le Marais in and out of the little side streets. Close to the Musee Picasso, just off Rue du Parc Royal, lies the quiet Square Leopold Achille - a little piece of tranquility. This s only one block from Place Des Vosges

The best neighbourhood in Paris!. Loved this trendy area. Wonderful shoppes and restaurants and very safe to walk around at any time of day. We rented a tiny apartment and loved it. I'd stay here again on my next visit.

Beautiful Neighborhood and Architecture. We visited this neighborhood to go to the Picasso Museum. Beautiful buildings, a wonderful shopping area for everything from art ,clothing, an African interior store, patisserie's, and bistros.

Spend a relaxing weekend here. Great small shops opening on Sundays; small museums nearby in Musee Picasso, Musee Carnavalet, and the Musée des Arts et Métiers (science design museum). Close to Place des Vosges, a beautiful small park with restaurants and cafes surrounding it. Must visit.
Lively example of Paris in the Summer. Mobs of people having a good time strolling, shopping and eating their way through the heart of Paris. What a delightful place!

Paris in the Springtime, or in fact, anytime is wonderful.. This is a great area to stay in Paris. Easy walk to Notre Dame and loads of interesting, individual, chic shops and restaurants. Very attractive squares and buildings and great museums.

The spirit of Paris. The stones of le Marais emit a sense of history and the magic of centuries past. A real neighbourhood, including the Jewish quarter, the gay quarter, arty, foodie, fashion-y, and just exuding a joie de vivre. My favourite quarter since 1991. I would not stay anywhere else - though the transport is so convenient that it's easy to go everywhere else.
My favorite part of Paris. It s so exciting to lost yourself in the small streets in Le Marais. Many interesting local shops or boutique and restaurants. Also, some branded shop in the main road.
Go on Sunday. Since most stores are closed on Sunday, leave La Marais for Sunday to eat, shop, and walk. Great hip ambience.
Stunning historical neighborhood. Lovely Square and neighborhood that used to be the Kings "party house". Victor Hugo fought to restore it and we throughly enjoyed our exploration of it.
Beautiful!. Absolutely atunning! So much to see and do, awesome location, but would recommend going early in the morning to avoid some of the tourist crowds.

melancholy and buzzing. Great buildings and full of friendly locals.
Pull up a chair at lots of different street side cafes and watch the world stroll by. Particularly taken with the area near Museum de Picasso.
feeling good. We always book in a Le Marais hotel when in Paris.Full of restaurants, shops, people, nice for walking around and feeling the Paris air.

Must visit !. This area is a must-see in Paris. Not only is it the historic Jewish "quartier" with kosher restaurants, synagogues, etc., it also is where the nobles' "hotels particuliers" and the female-run "salons" of centuries past were located- many of the buildings have been renovated over time and are beautiful (check out some of their courtyards and beautiful entryways). The area also has museums (Musee Carnavalet,the refurbished Picasso museum, Victor Hugo's house on the beautiful Place des Vosges), great places to eat and lots of boutiques. It's just fun to walk around, tho be aware that in the summer there are lots of tourists.
Filled with history and shopping.. One of the best areas of Paris for eating, looking at historical places and museums and shopping. Go on Sunday when many other areas are closed.

The most exhilarating area in Paris. We opted to rent an apartment in this area, and were not disappointed. It is vibrant, friendly, chaotic, colourful and easy to get around. There are hundreds of cafes to choose from, shops galore and wonderful attractions like the Pompidou Centre and the Picasso Museum.

Enjoyed shopping in Marais district. We went on a sunday and there was a street music party going through Marais, my 6 yr old daughter really enjoyed the music. Loved the small boutique shopping . It was great, had a good time in the Marais area. Totally worth going.

Hip vibrant area of Paris. The Marais has a vibrant night life with many hip bars and cafes/bistros which are found in this area. There is also good shopping in this area as well as big name stores such as Zara and H&M.

Walk around, take it all in. I think Le Marais is my favourite area in Paris. A blend of cultures, religions, boutique clothing stores and a wide variety of food. The biggest queue is always outside the felafel place in Rue de Rosiers. Allow a few hours in the area. You will not be sorry.

Not for everyone. We heard this was the "gay district" so we wanted to check it out, but weren't impressed. I guess you have to be young and into some hearty partying or too-expensive boutique shopping in order to enjoy it more than we old queens did.
best arr of paris. people watching ++. best place to people watch, best place to get falafel, best place to wander, best stores (lots of small boutiques and concepts), overall, go here. its worth it
Wonderful area. I think this was our favourite part of Paris. We did a self guided walking tour to experience the area and fell in love with it. Such atmosphere and character.

Gentrified. Marais is not as fun or interesting as it used to be. There are still some nice cafés but the shops are a very mainstream mix of the Kooples, Maje etc.. nothing wrong with these stores, but if you want young new designers you need to go elsewere.

Stay in Marais and walk everywhere. Great place to stay.10 minutes to nearly everything.Walk to metro 2 minutes and lots of great little cafes and bakeries etc.Beware of the street sleepers on matresses though and never speak english near them or you are at their peril.Same for al of Paris though.Worth a stay in a little apartment on Rue Beauberg.Views of Notre Dame and very few tourists to boot.
Fun area. Great food and enjoyable people. Amazing architecture (like most of Paris). Just a fun place to explore by foot.

Really Fun, Great Paris Experience. A lot of fun on our visit on a Sunday morning. Bustling, lots of vendors on the street. A LOT of people. Lots of people walking with falafel and shopping in the markets and on the streets. A really great paris scene.

Great Ethnic & Street Food!. We loved this arrondissement! It was lively, fun, and filled with shops and wonderful places to eat! The falafel, crepes, and patisseries were some of our favorite of our entire time in Paris. I would most definitely recommend staying or spending some time in this neighborhood!
Lively neighborhood. We enjoyed this neighborhood. Very lively. Great restaurants and shopping. Easy access to Metro and rest of Paris. May be a bit too alternative for some.

too crowded. Would have enjoyed walking this district if it wasn't so crowded when we went. It was the day after the US Supreme Court ruling legalizing gay marriage, which was highly celebrated in this arrondisment. Lots of shopping in boutiques and chain stores, ethnic food and Jewish bakeries, and the Pompidou Museum of modern art

Great neighborhood. A great neighborhood in Paris to stroll through. Wonderful shops and restaurants. We are in Paris for three months. Are staying in the St Germain area and wished we had chosen to spend one of the 3 months here. If there is another long trip to Paris, we will certainly look for accommodation in Le Marais
