Cool place. If u are looking for something vintage, do not hesitate visiting this area. Lots of vintage clothing including the kilo shop which has several branches in other parts of the world.
Nice day out but near the center of parid. This is a small, great museum and neighborhood with lovekt Matisse works. Nice day out of the center

The Marais - wonderful old Paris experience. The Marais continues to be a true Parisian experience. Interesting small boutiques, Delightful cafes and bars. Don't miss the Marche des Enfants Rouges - look for wonderful crepes from Alain or hamburgers with frites across from him. For delicious crepes (including gluten free) try Cafe Breizh. Don't miss the Place des Vosges and Picasso Museum.

Just a joy. Fabulous district to visit. Packed with superb buildings that are architecturally and historically important. These days it is very trendy and with loads of restaurants, trendy galleries and fashion houses. It's a lovely place to wander around, with plenty of places to stop for a break, including the wonderful Swedish Institute, which is away from the crowds, and on its own is a good enough reason to pay a visit. Loved it.

Very Nice Neighborhood, Kind of Busy Though. Marais neighborhood is vibrant with beautiful buildings, excellent shopping and cafes. The main drag is pretty busy, but luckily the tourists don't venture far from the main street, leaving you lots of charming side streets to explore without the crowds! The parks and buildings are well worth the trip. Perfect place to grab a seat in a sidewalk cafe for some excellent people watching!

Petit Versailles. From the Place Henri II to the Picasso Museum, le Marais is the haunt of those who wish to find the heart of Paris, not grand, human scale and caters to every gourmand and every other taste from Jewish to Gay and beyond...

one of my favourite parts of paris. everytime i'm in paris i spend some time in marais, the best street food and pastry can be found here. to discover the small hidden streets you need a map or book a walking tour.

A great district. This district, centrally located, is one of the areas which escaped Baron Haussmann's redevelopment of Paris in the 19th century, so is full of little, narrow, winding streets and loaded with character.It has had quite a history, being a wealthy area, then down at heel, then a Jewish area and now, very trendy and popular with younger people and the gay set. There are lots of cafés, bars, Jewish delicatessens and Arab cuisine. Also, there are lots of fancy, innovative boutiques, menswear shops, artists studios and artisan jewellers. You can window shop for days.There are also museums, such as the Carnavalet, the Picasso museum and the Pompidou centre. The Place des Vosges is one of the most beautiful squares in Paris, fringed by galleries and cafés. It's one of the few places in Paris where you are allowed to walk on the grass.It's a good idea to take a walking tour, as the area is reasonably compact, but contains lots of secrets which come alive when explained. Later, you can wander around aimlessly, with no plan in mind and just see where your feet take you. It's perfect for that. It's also the home of Jaques Jenin, the famous chocolatier, where you can try their rich, bitter hot chocolate, or buy their handmade, scrumptious chocolates.I keep coming back to this area, time after time and on the last two visits, have stayed here. It's probably my favourite area in Paris.

My fav neighbourhood in Paris. I think this is the best neighbourhood in Paris. I would highly recommend walking the cobblestone streets and sitting at a great bar, having some wonderful Parisian food and people watching to your heart's content. A must see on each of my visits to the City of Lights.
Do a walking tour. We did a free (tip supported) walking tour of this beautiful trendy district with a Parisian guide. Lots of different architectural styles and a rich history. Very trendy.
Our hotel was on Blvd Voltaire. Blvd Voltaire was a busy tree lined street with bars and restaurants. The Marais has little arcades with Artisans workshops.

wonderful to walk through. We have friends who always stay in this area so we spent the day walking and stopping to eat or shop. It was a busy, crowded area, but not being in a hurry, we just enjoyed it at our own pace. We may look at staying here on our next visit.
Paris Gay Pride weekend. Lots of resturants in this area, decorated for the weekend but not a problem for most people, nice atmosphere.
loved the marais. L''As de Falafel was one of our favorite meals in Paris! Loved the narrow, winding streets. Wish we has more time there
windy streets, shops and bistrots galore. highly recommend taking a stroll through Le Marais with its old windy streets, boutique shops, and huge variety of restaurants

Lovely area. Wished I had hit it during business hours, lots of lovely shops and unique shops. Saw a two story vintage/thrift store that was packed with clothing, shoes, bags etc. Very quaint area, definitely worth the time

Walk and enjoy the sights in this area of Paris. This is a wonderful area of Paris to walk and see the sights. See the Picasso Museum, Carnavalet Museum, the Jewish Museum and the Pompidiu center. Come back for a few hours on each visit to the area. There are plenty of restaurants here. Go to the rue des rossiers and sample some of the food here- Jewish and Arabic foods to be tasted. Go to Freida Kahn's deli and bakery which is on a corner of this street and enjoy the food. Tell her the 2 twin brothers from Las Vegas sent you.

Pavillon de la Reine. I am always staying there, place des Vodges across the street, many gaalleries, a jeweller you'd say..Iam living in 1900...in the rue des Minimes there is le Salon by le thé des écrivains a spot where you can drink tea, eat and read and buy books

Best neighborhood in Paris. For the young, hip and savvy this is the neighborhood to hit. Similar in vibe to the Meatpacking and Tribeca districts in NYC, the streets are lined with contemporary shopping and chic cafes. Plan a day or two to wander the streets, don't pass unassuming side streets or you'll miss out on amazing food and shopping. Super safe even late at night, great for couples but also for families, lots of people with strollers and little ones in tow. Many of the streets are pedestrian only which makes walking and exploring safer. There is a huge gay population here which makes the nightlight really fun and vibrant. Restaurants range from walk up casual to semi-fine dining, options and prices range from cheap to moderate (literally nothing outrageous about the pricing anywhere we ate)

Lovely area to walk through. Just walked around this area with my teenage granddaughter and had a delightful afternoon. We weren't looking for anything in particular but found the little shops interesting.

Worth a visit..better yet a stay!. Great neighborhood for eating and sightseeing. Visit Place du Vosges, Pompideau Center and Picasso Museum. Lots of small boutiques for shopping. Lively, young crowds.

Great place to stay. Found a great place on airbnb next to the Marais and loved the ambience, the unique quirky culture, restaurants and coffee shops. Go buy a ticket for any of the museums at the FNAC and avoid the lines and plenty of places to buy shoes :)
Free Tour. Beautiful and great tour. A gem. A must to see in Paris. Several tours a day at reasonable times. Free except tip the guide. A lot of walking.

Charming. Stayed in the Marais area during a 5 night visit. A nice change from the main tourist spots. Found a charming perfumery and other interesting shops and restaurants. Stayed at the golden tulip - very nice.
Shopping in the Marais. My favorite shopping -- lots of boutiques with affordable clothing that has French style. Many places to eat or get a beverage, too. Wonderful to walk around.

Feel like a local in Paris. The Marias is full of narrow streets that feel you have gone back in time, lots of charming restaurants, shopping and smaller museums. It doesn't feel touristy except for Rue des Rosiers in the Jewish Quarter; the rest feels local. Very close to the Bastille area, which also has the same vibe.
Worth a walking tour. Gentrifying at a rapid rate (not a surprise for Paris), so go see soon. Get a walking tour if you can. Place des Vosges was special.
Best part of Paris. Very nice part of Paris, lots of shops, restauant, fees very cosy. Always good to be there and beat the big crowds in other parts, though it is pretty crowded too here

Used to be hipper. Uniqlo. It's there. Don't get me wrong. Just doesn't feel that hip anymore now that the big chains have moved in. Still a nice walking around place, but don't go expecting to see endless blocks of independent shops.
Great place to stay. We stayed in the Marais district and it was great. Lots of restaurants and close to most major sites.

Best district in Paris!. We absolutely loved the charm of this district...so many things to see! Close to the Seine, Notre Dame, Hotel de Ville and other landmarks. So charming with tons of beautiful architecture. We love this area!

the essense of old paris. it is must be place to walk around in Paris . All those magnificent sandstone palaces recalling the times of Louis 14th & Henry 4th. On rue de Rivoly two wooden karkas buildings remains from 13th century civil construction proving that medieval Paris was far not so nice as it is now.
Everything you need. Very lively atmosphere. Great shops. Amazing architecture. Central location. We stayed in Hotel St Paul du Marais. Would go back for sure.
Classic and varied. Loved everything about Le Marais--the variety of shops, restaurants and cultural offerings and of course, La Place des Vosges at its heart.
Charming area. Good central location with lots going on without being noisy. Many and varied places to eat drink and be entertained.
Lots to see and explore. Many quaint streets, restaurants, and bars. Love just walking around the neighborhoods. Spent time dropping into to the boutique restaurants and stores.
Don't Miss the Marais!. We loved Paris but the day we spent exploring the Marais was especially wonderful. Tiny cobblestone streets, lovely cafes, bookstores and great food.

One of my favorite Paris neighborhoods. A very fun area to walk in, up and down small streets with lots of shops, cafes, museums......easily reachable from Notre Dame, or Bastille......lots of history here.....include Place des Vosges and Village Saint Paul in the wandering.
Worth a visit. Nice neighbourhood to walk aroundwith beautiful buildings. If you go, don't miss the Place des Vosgues, it's one of the nicest squares in Paris.

Independent boutiques and the best falafel in town. The Marais preserves its medieval street (most of them destroyed with the creation of the boulevards) where you will find middle range shops, bars, restaurants and the best falafel in town.
Favourite part of Paris. I adore this part of Paris. So much to see and do great restaurants. Great shopping. Very handy to all other attractions by Metro.

Best neighbourhood in Paris. We always stay in Le Marais. It's trendy, fun and filled with true Paris locals and artists. The restaurants are plenty and the shopping is fantastic. Walking distance to everything!!!!
a great neighborhood. the marais is filled with boutiques and restaurants. there is always something new to discover in this historic quarter of paris.
Historic Paris. So interesting just to stroll this district, tasting the food and enjoying the ambiance of one of the older areas of Paris.
The marais. Fabulous area, this is a good place to stay, I felt safe on my own and there were plenty of activities and people around to mix with.
Best Shopping and History. Do not miss the Marais! It is a gem and the shopping is wonderful...great falafel shops too... Place de Voges is a great park.
Maybe a bit tired. Still interesting but we have visited a three or four times over the last 20 years and I think it's getting a bit tired and loosing it's lustre as an attraction.
So Chic and Cool. You must make time to go to the Marais..fantastic shopping, very much a Boho feel to it..restaurants are local and so so good..

The Greenwich Village of Paris. No, Montmartre is NOT the Greenwich Village of Paris, since it has become way too commercialized to the point of being a caricature of itself. Le Marais is. We stayed here and loved it for its little shops and many delightful restaurants. There is nothing truly spectacular here, but there is a very good feeling in the air.
Real Paris. This is re you get the feel and charm of Paris. Great restaurants and bars. Walking around the streets with the historical curiosity makes the trip worthwhile and rewarding.

Paris yes. I loved this District. Felt like the real Paris. We sat for hours at small cafes sipping lattes, strolled the District. Bought cheese, pastries, shopped for clothes - the whole nine yards. It was wonderful.
Forget The 1at Arrondismontr. for those who want truly warm French hospotality, this is the area to go to and stay!!! Great bistros and no overload of other tourists!!

So Much To Do. What a great place there is so much to do. A very relaxed area plenty of bars/cafés (some of which are great to sit outside and people watch). Wonderful market that's nice to browse around at leisure. A true little taste of Paris.

An exciting vibrant place!. We loved our visit as it was alive with locals and tourists, food everywhere you look and an atmosphere of lively enjoyment. I would definitely take visitors there as there are some good museums there too.
Great shopping area in Paris. Great shopping area in Paris. So many wonderful funky little shops in this area. A must see in Paris.
Great sunday walk and shopping. Lively area where you can stroll the streets full of boutiques and little bistros. Love to visit Le Marais on sundays! :)

I just love this district. For years I have loved this district and still do. Boho. Lots of little interesting streets, loads of shops, restaurants, bars, and places of interest and easy to get to other parts of Paris.

Stayed here for 13 days and it was wonderful. We had a wonderful time staying here for 13 days. Highlights;
--Place de Vosges--home of Louis the 13th
--Bastille Market on Sunday and Thursday. One of the great farmers markets anywhere in the world
--Hundreds of fine restaurants
--Great old architecture

Great shopping, lively district. Long gone Jewsih quarter, now filled with trendy shops and restaurants. I loved it, but had hoped that some of the old qualities remained....very hard to find. As a couple of women friends travelling together, the bars are filled with gay men....so look for restaurants with a more varied crowd. And, the shopping is GREAT. After visiting the Pompidou Centre we had a great afternoon wandering the little streets, exploring the shops and watching the world go by.
Cozy and convenient. I stayed in this area with my mom and girlfriend for about a week and loved the vibe of the area, food choices and it's location.

Beautiful Neighbourhood. I had never been to the Marais until today after all my trips to Paris and I am glad that I finally did. There are many shops and excellent restaurants. No visit is complete without relaxing in the Place des Vosges, which looks like a post card. Plan to spend at least a few hours in this neighbourhood and you won't regret it.
Lovely place and very lively. Very central and loads of bars and restaurants to visit. Very busy at night and nice feel to the place

You can find everything. You can find everything.Really.
Beautiful people,interesting buildings and places.
Try it day and night.

Marais district. Loved the area. Next time I will stay in this charming district.
Charming restaurants, shop, and french Brocante on the weekends.

Great Bars and shops. Walking the Marais makes for a wonderful afternoon of browsing- many shops, art galleries and restaurants and bars - at the end of a long day of walking Paris , stop at a Bar and sit and people and dog watch

Hippest Palace in Paris. This is the only place we will stay in Paris. Marais means swamp but don't let that discourage you. Nearby you have the Place de Vosges, Note Dame, Rue de Rivoli and more great restaurants than you can imagine. We walked to the Louve, Latin District and the Eiffel Tower (That was a long walk!) We rented an apartment on Sevigne Street and could not have been happier

Harmony of modern&classic Paris. Very unique place showing 2 different Paris. While walking along small shops and local fast food serving Falafee make sure you don't miss bigger gates looking like official doors from outside, but if you go in you can discover a great Hotel ( rich house) with nice gardens open for public. Shopping is quite interesting with local brands "Lola" "Believe" and many local designers. Nice for walking, no too crowd.

Live like the locals. I stayed in a tiny studio apartment and absolutely loved it. Everything is so close and the cafés and wine bars are amazing. Definitely a great part of Paris to stay in. If you like great quality organic food you can't go past Le Pain Quotidien on rue des Archives.
Crowded and very touristy. A disappointing experience. Were there on a Saturday. Small streets crowded with tourists. No interesting shops.

J'adore le marais. This section of Paris is probably my favorite. There are other sections that I enjoy as much, but nothing tops a stay in the Marais. Good people; great places to eat, easy of transportation; walkable; small markets, boulongeries; cafes, shops. It's got most everything you want or need. You can zip over to Notre Dame and the left side in a few minutes. I want to live here.
This area can't be missed. You could spend days wandering the streets of this area. The food, the shopping, the peaceful streets, the noisy bars, it's all worth staying here and not just a visit.

mooch around the Marais. For the picky little shops where you find those bits and bobs that in later years you rummage through at home and all your memories of Paris come flooding back. Well all those shops are in the Marais. Complete with little mouthwatering cafes and chocolate shops. Take your time, the Marais will surprise you pleasantly.with its music and poetry.

The happening place. We stayed in the Marais on this visit to Paris. We walked all over Paris during our 4 day visit - from the Bastille to Notre Dame to the Left Bank, Eiffel Tower, Luxembourg Gardens and Champs Elysee. While all of Paris was alive with activity (especially on a Sunday when they close streets for fun) the Marais was non-stop alive well into the night with restaurants, cafes, bars and people walking through streets closed to traffic for the day. A fun, new neighborhood to explore.
Vibrant and urban. Nice and vibrant area of town. Great for walking, popping in to the occational café etc.. Well worth a visit!

Le Marais, a beautiful quartier. After three months in this glorious city, the Marais is one of the places where I spent my last day in Paris, this time. This quartier oozes history, but doesn't most of Paris? Victor Hugo wrote masterpieces and Jim Morrison spent his last hours in the Marais. My husband and I headed to la Place des Vosges, the heart of the marsh and a lovely park that was crowded with picnic-ers and children practicing cartwheels on this sunny Saturday (May 30th). We stopped at Nectarine (16 place des vosges) for lunch on the terrace overlooking the park where the service was warm and welcoming and the food, tasty. As we crossed the street back to the park, we passed a young musician playing classical guitar in a doorway. It all tugged at my francophile heartstrings as I bid farewell to one of my favorite places on the planet.One museum in le Marais, Arts et Metiers (located near metro stop by the same name), is often overlooked by visitors yet worth a visit if you are into history, and especially the history of science and industry (pls. see my review of it from last year). Of course, the Marais is home to many musees that are worth a leisurely visit, such as the newly renovated Picasso Museum and the Carnavalet Museum (free for visitors) which showcases the history of the city of Paris. I recommend budgeting time and a few euros for their gift shops. Do not miss the Archives Nationales where historical documents are on display, showing signatures of Jeanne d'Arc and Charlemagne, among others. And you must stop by 34 rue des rosiers at the L’As du Fallafel for lunch; be prepared to stand in line for a while, but much like Ste. Chapelle, it is worth the wait!

Magical Marais. I think the Marais district is the oldest part of Paris. It's a great place for a break. We went last week and it was a refreshing interlude. Lots of restaurants and bars as you would expect. The level of service is part of the fun and it doesn't matter if you speak French because the waiters etc were unfailingly helpful and mannered. The place de Voges, Victor Hugo's house, the Shoah museum, the reopened Picasso museum .....lots and lots to see.

A most beautiful neighborhood, tucked away but central. The architecture here is so fascinating. You can really feel the history, but there is a creative, ebullient atmosphere. There are lots of small galleries showing some of the most avant garde pieces I have ever seen. The Carnavalet museum is massive, and deserves at least a full day to do it justice. It is full of historic displays and artwork related to the history of France. The cafes in this area are bustling but the service is quite attentive, personable and even entertaining in some cases.We did see two soldiers in one of the main squares with automatic weapons, which served as a stark reminder that the attacks earlier this year happened in that general area. But this did not feel menacing, simply protective.Having seen many areas of Paris before, I can say this is one of my favorites...there is no heavy traffic to worry about, it is not noisy, and it has the coherence of a city within a city. Totally charming.

A month in the marais.. Just got back from spending a month in the Marais. What an incredible experience. So many things to see and do. Just head out in the morning and walk the streets, shop in the little shops and eat at a great sidewalk cafe. Didn't do much at night so I can't attest to the nightlife but the days were always filled with new discoveries.

Great Area of Town. Ran into lots of merchants that didn't speak english.. We stayed in the Marais and loved it! Little cafes and shops galore! Some restaurants had english on their menus, some didn't.We always felt very safe walking the streets. Always seemed to be people out walking around!At first we stuck pretty close to Rue de Rivoli, but decided to walk other streets. They were much more quaint. Plenty of quaint places to eat on Rue de Turenne and Rue de Britagne.Definitely a great part of town to stay in. The escalator exiting the St Paul Metro station was always a great site! By the time we were on our way home, we were tired of climbing steps!

The most beautiful part of Paris. 'Le Marais' means 'the marsh' & it was once a marsh before it was drained & filled; it's the 3rd & 4th arrondissements of Paris and is the most beautiful part of the city -- the only part completely untouched by Baron Haussmann's massive demolition & reconstruction of the city under the reign of Napoleon III. The heart of the Marais is the enchanting Place des Vosges, the largest public square in the quarter. From it, you can walk west down the rue des Francs Bourgeois to explore the rest of the area. The best streets to explore are the rue des Francs Bourgeois, the rue Vielle du Temple, the rue des Archives & the rue des Rosiers -- the main street of the old Jewish quarter. There are dozens of great 'hôtels particuliers' -- grand mansions from the 16th, 17th & 18th centuries -- including the Hôtel Carnavalet, which houses the Musée de la Ville de Paris; the Hôtel Salé, which houses the Musée Picasso; the Hôtel Guénégaud, which houses the Musée de la Chasse et de Nature; and the Hôtel de Soubise, which houses the Musée de l'Histoire de France & the exquisite Salon de la Princesse, a Rococo masterpiece. Make sure to see the Hôtel de Ville, Paris City Hall, which is a 19th century copy of the French Renaissance original and which is one of the most beautiful buildings in Paris.

Visit the Marais!. Take a walking tour of the Marais, if you have the time (make the time). Old city. Narrow winding streets. Beautiful gardens. Great false building facades bordering beautiful squares and parks.Very nice shops. Wonderful bakeries. Get coffee in a cafe! Get something Kosher! Get something Mediterranean.Get some macarons! Take it in and enjoy!

Falafel. Very interesting part of Paris with many twisting winding pathways, Place de Voges and Victor Hugo's apartment. Of course, one must try the falafel at La's on the main street and eat it at a playground soaking in the atmosphere.
Warm and welcoming. This very special area of Paris is warm and welcoming. The Holocaust Memorial is sacred and meaningful. We felt safe throughout our time here.

Best Arrondissement. It's where I stayed. To be precise, I stayed less than a 5 minute walk from the Saint Paul metro station. It's an old part of Paris, but it's the heart of Paris as it was constantly explained to me. We were minutes from the Seine. Blocks from Notre Dame. It was a great. Rue de Rivoli felt like one of the main streets. I don't have perspective into other arrondissements, but in Marais, I felt like a Parisian. Lots of locals stopping at the boulangerie to get bread and start their day. Children out and about in the morning. I don't know if I would explore Le Marais if I had less than a week in Paris. You might want to see the Pompidou which borders Marais. There are some other classic hotels and museums in Marais. We also ate an awesome Jewish restaurant that had very moist, savory falafel. Best meal my fiancee had in Paris.

Best place to get a fallafel. But you have to choose between the self proclaimed best in the world (l'as) and the best on the street (forgot it's name). We chose the one recommended by Rick Steves, L'as, which translates to the "Ace." Sit inside and order the plate.

Great area....but. We really enjoyed this area the first time we went on our trip. So much so that we decided to go back again. Our second time was a bit different in that there were 2 seperate restaurants that refused to serve us because we spoke english. We greeted and asked for a table in french, they sat us with menus and then ignored us. At 2 separate places. We then wandered into another pub (closer to the main street) where we were treated like gold! Don't give up!

Interesting allyways. We had a 3 hr walk through this area. Discovered hidden ally ways and streets,reflecting by gone days. Lovely old palaces, which are being used for various purposes e.g. museums etc. There are buildings which show architecture of the old days.

One of Paris' most elegant areas. I am a bit reluctant to give Le Marais a good review because it has grown so popular of late. It is my favorite part of Paris - great food, wonderful shops, and a collection of lesser known, but truly fascinating museums (Musee Picasso, Carnavalet, Art et Metiers, and many more).The Marais is the oldest section of Paris, the original home of the Knights Templar. It is rich in history and heritage, filled with interesting architecture, and, lately, with trendy boutiques, avant garde galleries, and much more.You could easily spend a month in this part of town and not experience it all. I'll leave the details to the guide books.
The center of attraction. This area is completely walkable. Great for shopping and entertainment lots of gay bars and activities nearby. Very safe and shops are open later.

Visiting Le Marais. We spent a week Iving in an apartment in the Marais. It is the remaining old area of Paris whichnwas not modernised after the Revolution. There are very nice restaurants, Patisseries, cafes and fashion those who like shopping. It was easy to reach the Metro on foot,walk to Notre Dame, Ill St Louis and cross the river to the left bank.There are modern places to visit such as Pompidou Ctr and numerous museums. As it was the are where jews have lived for centuries you will find food outlets which reflect their presence.
Lively Le Marais. Go in the evening and walk the streets of Le Marais. There are clubs, music and a fun atmosphere. Enjoy

The Best.... The Marais district was and is the Jewish section of Paris. Ast one time there were many Jewish restaurants there.Today the outstanding, inexpensive place to eat i A1-Falafel. Here is the best falafel sandwich I have every had. In one week we ate here three times. Delicious and cheap and fun.Many of the Jewish businesses are gone and replaced by yuppie stores. There are still Jewish bookstores and and gift and trinket stores.

A neighboorhood to stroll through. When walking from the Southern part of Paris to the more central area around the Louvre, take the time to walk through the Marais. Very often there will be markets (food, antiques,...) and you'll find yourself embedded within the local people.
Love this neighborhood. I love staying in this neighborhood. It is great for dining and walking around and just hanging out.

Take your time. One of the best part of the city. Full of musuems - Pompideu Center, Picasso Museum, Carnavalet Museum, National Archives, Museé Cognaq, etc. These old renovated "hotels" from the 15.-17. century are itself something to wonder.This is also one of the prominent Jewish quarter. Many good jewish restaurants, synagugues.The Place des Vosges one of the most beautiful square in Paris

Great Place to Wander and Shop. Great place to spend a morning or afternoon. Food and shops are everywhere and line the streets, but you can find quiet and peaceful areas too. I found a few hidden looking gardens and courtyards that were beautifully manicured and clean.

Great place to stay in Paris. We stayed a week in Le Marais and found it to be central to all the main attractions in Paris. There is great food to be found in every corner (bakeries, markets, cafes and bistrots), and the shops open on Sunday unlike other quarters in Paris. It is also very accessible to the metro and getting to and from the Airport by train is very doable. Many museums are within walking distance and so is shopping! A great neighborhood to be in and we are glad we chose to stay there.

The area to be.. Area 3 has it all. Food, lodging and shopping for your wife. We've been to Paris many times over 20 years and it only gets better. We explore new areas each time but always come back to Le Marais.

Full of intersting things to see and do. This is a great neighborhood. If houses the George Pompidou, the Picasso Museum, the Jewish Quarter and the Mansion walk along with lots of other things to do and see.If your time allows, this neighborhood deserves a full day.

One of our favourites. If you have not had lunch at La Tartine you are missing a wonderful treat. It is a famous very old wine bar and noted for it sandwiches (tartine) however we can't go past their wonderful salads with a glass of wine - delicious and their coffee is excellent too!
My 3rd visit to Paris. Love this area of Paris. Beautiful buildings and nice quaint museums. Here you can find some very nice kosher food as well.

A taste of old Paris. Le Marais is a wonderful place out of time in Paris. Haussmann's great work missed this very old neighborhood leaving us a wonderful treasure of narrow, winding streets, interesting buildings, including two of the oldest surviving houses, great shops and quiet gardens. Take time to explore and check out the by-ways. We found a lovely garden-Le Jardins des Roseirs --Joseph Migneret-tucked inside a block of buildings. It commemorates a hero of the French Resistence and is a remarkably peaceful place to refresh you soul.

Great Visit. I feel a little silly writing a review for a neighborhood, but we really enjoyed spending a week in Le Marais. So many great restaurants and boutiques to explore, beautiful architecture, street art, galleries. Le Marais has a comfortable feel to this New Yorker. Many Parisian neighborhoods feel a bit like a museum: pretty, but in a state of detached preservation. Le Marais feels more alive, more like a place to live and enjoy yourself.We stayed on the beautiful Place des Vosges, the oldest planned square in the city. Really enjoyed our time there.
Pleasant to walk around. Good to walk around. There are nice design stores and great ice cream. Women in the group loved it!A few squares made the neighborhood even better

A warm corner of Paris. You can see small parks full of young people relaxing, several bistros/bars along its streets and various hip boutiques. It attracts people who like bohemian lifestyle more and there are lots of local social gatherings/ actives going on.
Trendy neighbourhood. Particularly in the evenings it is very busy. Lots of bars and restaurants offering French and ethnic food.There are some with live world music.

A Good Place to Deliberately Get Lost. If you want a day away from the major sites, visiting the Marais is a great option. There is no particular goal. Just wander the streets enjoying the shops and cafes. Well worth the time.
Quaint Neighborhood. This area is very quaint and quiet compared to the rest of the city. The Picasso Museum is a must see. There are so many restaurants to choose from and the shopping is great!

The best place to be. Marais is the best location for any turist. It is the place to be in Paris with close proximities to landmarks and museums. Particular vibrant caffe shops at the step of the door makes great enjoyment of Paris.

Lovely neighbourhood - filled with energy, art, colour, eateries. Le Marais is an area that is buzzing with energy. It is quite different from the places on the other side of the river. There are lots of quaint art shops, paper shops, galleries, eateries, clothes shops, book shops and beer pubs. This seemed like a younger, fun place and had a lot of affordable eating places. It could be a nice place to stay if you want to be in the midst of some energy, buzz and eclectic mix of people and places.

A more pleasant neighborhood area. It is bustling, but in a good way. Easy to walk around an convenient to metro and bus. Local shopping, grocery and boutiques. From our hotel Malher we were able to use metro to anywhere in Paris and even train to Giverny. Several good restaurants as well.

Take time to wander this area. We had great fun walking into the vintage clothes shops, strolling the streets and hidden squares, and people watching. A fascinating area of Paris very different from the rest of the city.

Enjoy the Marais. An historical place in Paris.
Good shopping as well ans typical places such as Place des Vosges.
Go to Notre Dame just after.

Exiting place. I love Le Maria's.You have a great selection of restaurants and very nice boutiques and small art galleries.I always find the place very exiting ,the energy is always great .Of course there is monuments to see as well ,one of them the most famous one is the house of Victor Hogo ( I'm not sure if it's open for public,but you can see it from outside) that located in the hearth of great art galleries of the district.

charming neighbourhood. Lovely place to walk around in and truly experience Paris. There is a little street where we had awesome falafels - possibly the best ever that I have had. Quaint shops line the streets and add to the ambience of this neighbourhood

Central location, Old world character, many eating places. Wonderful locality with old world character, welcoming eating places that are open late and location is central, easily accessible to the train station and underground

Fun area to explore. Such a variety of boutiques, galleries, shops, cafes, bakeries, etc. We loved the Market L'Enfant Rouges. There we had Moroccan, Italian, French, Middle Eastern and Japanese lunches and dinners. Also have fresh fish, produce, cheeses, sandwiches, bread, crepes, flowers and more! Loved it. There are also organic markets, grocery stores and take out places in the area, in addition to the Jewish section with some bakeries, falafel & deli.
A great walking tour.. This was an excellent walking tour of the Jewish Quarter of the city, and well worth doing. We went with a tour guide from Viking Cruise Lines.

A delightful historic district definitely worth a visit. We spent our first full day in Paris walking in Le Marais. It's an unforgettable place, full of charming squares, streets, cafes and shops and beautiful historic architecture. Highlights are Place des Vosges, a large public square defined by rows of distinctive "townhouses" on all four sides, and Musee Picasso, in the stunning Hotel Sale, with several floors of wonderfully curated works in all media by this great artist. The museum was slightly crowded, but a much more enjoyable experience than the overwhelming (though fantastic) Louvre.

Life in le Marais. I stayed in the Marais, and I will only ever stay there when I return to Paris. There are fewer tourists who stay in the 3rd arrondissement, so you have more opportunities to interact with the locals. It's better if you speak French (even a little bit), but most of the people can help you in English (even a little bit). Enjoy the large variety of shops, cafes, parks, and people. Sit and people watch and have a cafe creme, a glass of Chardonnay & cheese, and my favorite - the cafe gourmand. This is an espresso with a variety of miniature desserts. Each cafe offers different types of cafe gourmand, and it's fun to explore each cafe.

The Lower East Side turned into SoHo. Used to be a bit of a run down area, mostly Jewish. Now it's full of one trendy overpriced clothing, jewelry or makeup store after another-street after street. Many of them are global brands, so we have the same ones in NY. Some of the "art" galleries are embarrassingly cutesy. There were soldiers with machine guns in the doorway of a children's school, in front of a synagogue and at a cross street in an older section. (One assumes that they are there because of the murders at the kosher grocery following the Charlie Hebdo massacre. Like most governments, France closed the barn door after the horse bolted.) There's three reasons to go: 1. See the Place des Vosges, the first planned square in Paris with a pretty little park and solid bourgeois apartments all around, 2. the recently-opened Picasso Museum, although unfortunately a large portion is going to close from the middle of June to the middle of September, and 3. the original Mariage Freres, one of the best, if not the best, tea shops in the world.

Great Sunday Morning Stroll. This is a perfect spot to visit on a Sunday Morning as there are plenty of places to visit and dine. A wonderful option if interested in the history of this section of Paris.

Shopping, meh. Nothing special. People will tell you this is THE place to shop. I was not terribly impressed. There were a lot of chain stores and only a few small, original boutiques. If you want to shop at chains, you could do it anywhere.

good for a sunday. Sundays can be a bit odd in France as many places close but not the marais. spend Sunday afternoon strolling through the cobbled streets and explore the shops boutiques and there is even a little vegan eaterie called "hanks Vegan" burger on the rue des archives.

A cool area of Paris with lots of shopping boutiques. We kind of wandered around the north of Marais in the Chinese part of the city before coming south towards the quartier de Marais. There are lots of expensive boutiques geared towards tourists and cute cafes and restaurants. We went on the rue des rosiers and then wandered towards the Carnaval, the church St.Paul and found ourselves in the courtyard of the Hotel Sully which leads to the Place Vosges. The little square is beautiful with a nice fountain. We then walked towards the cemetery to the East only to find it was closed by 530 pm. Overall a very interesting neighbourhood to explore. We are at the famous L'As de Falafel

Rented apartment for 9 nights. Single women felt very safe in the Marais. Convenient to all major sites. Affordable cafes and many small shops for food to cook at home. Great small boutiques. The best was we could walk almost everywhere we wanted to go.

Paris Young Nightlife. Worth a visit in the evening if you would like to go out for a few drink. We found this area seemed to have a much younger vibe that St Germain so we didn't stop off anywhere but rather walked around and soaked up the atmosphere.

A day well spent...... The best way to enjoy the Marais is to wander, let your mind go free and just walk. Enter the long narrow alleys and ask the local salespeople whats great for lunch. We have met so many people and with our best french ask questions about other shops and restaurants. Its a very laid back part of Paris and has some of the coolest shops and food markets ever. Find a true boulangerie and grab a coffee and hang. Then on to the next shop. The big brands are mixed with the locals and thats exactly what the Marais is to me. A great mix.
Interesting neighborhood. Even if you're not staying here, it's worth a walk to/through to see the former site of The Bastille, several wonderful little museums, and the like. Unique neighborhood.

Fab location. Our hotel was in le Marais and our closest metro station was rebublique. This is only three stops from the gare du nord so really great if you are travelling on the Eurostar. Only 10 stops to the champs elysee, 11 stops to the Trocadero for the Eiffel Tower and only a few stops to the seine!

A bit of everything. We spent a couple of hours walking around and window-shopping. There is a buzz about the place and it's full of independent shops, selling all manner of goods. Well worth a visit, even if you don't buy anything.

Village of St Paul. Stayed in an Airbnb apartment on Rue St Paul. Great location, close to Metro and many other attractions. Clean, safe neighborhood. People very friendly. Beautiful patisserie on the corner.
Great part of Paris. Just a wonderful area in Paris. Food was outstanding. Places de Vosages is gorgeous. Easy to get to by walking and Metro
Great fun. We had a walk and really enjoyed the friendly atmosphere and the masses of beautiful shops that make you relaxed and put you on a good mood!

Two weeks as Parisiennes.. We took a small studio in the Marais for two weeks. It felt like we belonged. The cafes were always busy, there was every kind of shop, we could walk to the city centre and to the Place de la Republique and on to the Canal St Martine. We loved it.

Liveable. We spent a week living in an apartment here amongst the locals with our teenage children. Everyone was very welcoming. We could walk to Notre Dame and other places and then come back to peace and quiet. Plenty of food options and transport. Came across many beautiful significant places on our strolls. Did some geocaching in the local area

Always a great place to eat, shop and stroll. The only downside was that so many shops were closed on a bank holiday. However, enough wrenopen to have a very enjoyable stroll and window shop all the quirky boutiques as well as the high street shops. Don't visit Paris without a trip to the ever-cool Marais
Very nice. Absolutely wonderful place to walk around and enjoy the atmosphere. Shopping and cafes in abundance.

True Paris. Le Marais is truely charming, many small street with food shops ( mostly. Jewish) cafes. A must is a Promenades Goumandes Cooking School in the 3rd arr. Paule Caillet is a marvellous cook and I recommend her classesf

Busy. We just wanted to walk around and look into the shops and take in the vibes of the area. While it was nice, it was very busy. I was hoping for more quaint but it seemed very commercial. Been there, done that.

One of our favorite areas in Paris.. My husband and I spent a couple of days walking in the Marais. We went to the Place de Voges and ate at Ma Bourgogne (19 Place de Voges - apparently famous but just ok) on one day and were disappointed that Victor Hugo's apartment was closed for renovations. Another day we went to the to the newly opened, renovated Picasso museum, walked a bit, and ate a fabulous lunch at Swartz's Deli. Lots of window shopping!

Very nice but that means a crowd. A sunny spring Sunday, wall to wall people, locals as well as tourists; this place is "discovered". That is because it is very nice though, small streets, lots of restaurants, a few interesting churches and museums, eg Picasso and Carnavalet.We stayed in an apartment on Place du Bourg, Tibourg, and as we sleep with the window open I can tell you this place go on until the wee small hours. The restaurant opposite seemed to be still serving meals at 3am.There are some very good restaurants and some cheap eats, just takes a bit of searching.

Boutiques and bookstores. I loved walking the streets and seeing the boutiques, markets and bookstores. There are lots of great sites, such as the Place de Voges and tons of outdoor cafes to have a glass of wine.

Shopping and fruits :). Very nice if you want to see the real parisian life. It has some shops from all around the world with very cool collection. Nice for shopping and you can stop by to get freshly cut fruits/ juice.

Would recommend the Latin quarter instead.. Would recommend the Latin Quarter instead. I've stayed in both Le Marais and the Latin Quarter. Both exude a great energy though I prefer the cafés and shops in the Latin Quarter over Le Marais. Respectfully those in the gay community will likely disagree with my assessment.

cosy, warm with a lot to see. This part of Paris is very friendly There are a lot of small streets where you can find cafes, restaurants, museums, gardens, shops, markets. It is a little bit like a little village inside Paris.But it is difficult to park a car, and sidewalks can be narrow and busy if you have difficulties to walk.
Shopping shopping. Lovely old world streets with many many shops with quirky and fashionable items. Coffee shops to sit and watch the passers by. Definitely worth a visit.

Disappointed in the Shopping. We visited Le Marais because we heard the shopping was good. There are also a lof of other non-shopping things to do in in Le Marais as well. For shopping, I thought we would find some local shops with decent prices. But instead its very trendy, expensive shops, with several global chain stores included. The place was jammed packed with tourists. We found the shopping to be disappointing in that regard. But my review isn't a full one since there are a lot of other things to do in Le Marais. Place des Vosges a busy little park to get some sun. There are a few well known smaller museums as well. I would go back again but avoid the two main backbone shopping streets and visit the history instead.

Fantastic to just walk around. Do not forget to look up at the buildings as well as at the shop fronts. This old area of Paris houses some great museums and good restaurants as well as some great places to buy cheap seconds of clothing and designer labels.

Best neighbourhood is Paris!. Loved it! It is truly a neighbourhood and quite distinct from the other arrondissments. We were lucky enough to rent a flat for our stay and found Le Marais to be charming and interesting - full of little neighbourhood boutiques, great cafes, and interesting side streets, some of which are little mini-neighbourhoods, like the Jewish section around Rue du Pavee. It is perfectly located for walking to many of the most interesting parts of Paris and very convenient to the Metro if you do not wish to walk.
The best falafel. Go there if you have time! I've ate the best falafel every. Such a cool part of the ciyFull of amazing bars

A wonderful neighborhood.... Short and sweet: I loved this neighborhood. Wonderful shops, great larger-store shopping as well, excellent cafes, charming people. It is, to a degree, similar to sections of my native San Francisco. Well worth spending some time here.

Must Do Heritage Walk. We started the walk in the morning after having morning coffee. You can see the place by guided bicycle tour as well but walking is best. You can see Picasso Museum and many heritage buildings like national archives. We had our breakfast in one of street side cafe. We had Cafe o'latte and Chocolate Crepes. It was good. We continued our walk seeing many tiny gardens meandering streets and many other things. On one of the corner of a building. we saw a mirror. We took our photograph and posted of FB. It was like by many. we finished our walk at Center Pompidou.

Beautiful area of Paris.. Le marais is perhaps my favourite part of Paris, many little shops, cafes, little squares great architetecture And a gem of a square called the place des Vosges, almost perfect.

Shop till you drop. Loved this hip area of Paris. There a so many boutiques with uniquely Parisian clothing/accessories at great prices. The vibe of the area is very urban and fun. I spent a morning strolling le Marais and really needed more time!

Shopping, restaurants and museums. Plenty of shopping if you choose. Several museums in the area such as Picasso. People watching and walk to Places de Vosges are great options. The old Jewish quarters are one of the oldest areas in Paris.

You can't help but love it!. One of my favourite parts of Paris. Full of coffee shops and bars, bijoux shops and characterful. If you do nothing else, just sit outside a bar with a Kir Royale and people watch - it's a great way to spend an hour and will give you a real insight into Parisians.

Great to walk around. This is a great area to walk around, grab a coffee and croissant in one of the many cafes or marvel at the long queues in the Falafel cafes knowing they must do great falafel.Hotel was in the area so it was easy to reach but it feels a more authentic Paris than many other places.Well worth a visit
Part of Paris I never fail to visit. Lively area, good restaurants, caffes, museums, shopping. Great for slow strolls, people watching, sitting in the sun, just enjoying life!
Atmospheric, many lovely authentic places to eat. Busy area in the evening with loads of buzzy cafés, in the daytime full of quirky and individual shops

Le Marais. I remember when residents were trying to restore the Marais... I expect they regret that now! It is all chi/chi'd up and has none of the old flavor ... but a good place to visit for its little shops and restaurants (though the best one with the best jazz has gone ). I miss the old street parties and dancing to an accordian with all the urchins having a great time... but it is nice for tourists now.
Great neighbourhood. Trendy nieghbourhood just a few Metro stops away from the 'touristy' area. Near the canals, which is full of nice parks.
Stunning. One of the most beautiful and diverse areas of Paris, we loved strolling through the streets and we wished we had more time. We will return!

Fun, historic, cool. We loved this area of Paris. It is a lovely area from which to walk to mant points of interest. The Hop On Hop Off bus is also close by. The Batobus which we loved is a 15 minute walk away. Lots to do & see including cafés, restaurants, shopping.

Great area to wander. If you are looking for the charm that Paris is known for, check out the Marais section of Paris. This is where the Picasso museum is, but every street offers just a bit more of Paris than you might expect. While many wander the Champs Elysee, I choose the lesser traveled streets of Paris.

Just lovely. If you like to wander, popping in to little boutiques and enjoy a welcome stop at a pavement cafe then this is the place for you. Wish we had found this earlier in our trip - on the list for next time.

Great place for an afternoons stroll and lunch or dinner. This is a lovely area to stroll around. There are many little shops and lots of cafes and restaurants for people watching. Easy to get to on the metro...get off at St Paul. Simply lovely!

Great neighbourhood to explore. This is the first time I have stayed in the Marais and it was a great neighbourhood. We had fun walking around and it has very convenient access to anywhere else you might want to go in Paris

love this place. our hotel advised us the marais for visiting and eating on sunday
like it
nice shops restaurant and a lot of people
very fun
fashion and gay area. Do not miss the Place des Vosges, it is a beautiful plaza, full of art galleries and nice boutiques. The streets around are all interesting and full of life.
Rich Jewish history + Chic Parisian Quartier. Only in the Marais can you eat kosher falafel (from L'as du Falafel) and walk down the street to one of the many clothes stores to buy expensive shoes.

energy. we spent our first Sunday in the Marais. it was packed with people, but it gave one a sense of community.
filled with little shops on a variety of streets - so much fun!
Beautiful. This is one of the best areas in Paris. Place de Vogues, the restaurants, shops , art galleries perfumeries etc are quintessential.
nice area for shopping. nice area to walk around, lots of different shops even small typical French "boutiques", worth a visit when you are in Paris

Eclectic .artistic,lively.. Busy area with lots of winding streets,but well sign posted. Pompidou Centre/Gallery ,Picasso Museum and the Carnavalet Museum are all worth at least one visit.Place de Vosges is good for people watching ,having a coffee and shopping for beautiful leather goods,I really mean handbags..Some great restaurants and not all expensive.Good area to visit in the evening too.

Great walking attraction. This is one of those places you should go for walk and discover its small streets and unique restaurant and stores. With a strong Jewish influence you will find typical restaurants and markets selling great Jewish cuisine. This place has also some interesting bars with a wide clientele.

Historic area of Jewish cultural interest.. We visited the Jewish History nd Cultural Museum at Hotel St Aignan at the edge of the Marais, which had an interesting special exhibition. We also fancied a kosher meal and there is a good choice in Rue des Rosiers.

Wonderful area to spend an hour or 2 or more. I've been here many times and each visit shows the growth this area is undergoing. It's slowly losing its "old feel," and is gaining many high priced boutiques. Really expensive shops. (Still nice, but very expensive). If you're Jewish (or not) and want to see some beautiful Israeli art, jewelry and ritual items, this is the Place to come. Rue de Rosiers. There are still a few places to shop and there's also kosher delis, bakeries, etc and best of all, L'as du Felafel, is the best felafel outside of Jerusalem!

Good area to stay when in paris. a great area too stay as there are plenty of cafes, bars and restaurants which are open when other areas are closed. With good transport to the centre of Paris and the Gare du Nord etc.

No longer the quaint neighborhood, but worth spending time in.. I regret the quaint old Marais where we stayed in 1991. But there are so many things worth seeing there. If you are near Chatelet and the river, the best route is to cross the bridge and walk to the left of the Cathedral, then across the bridge to Ile St Louis and an immediate left across the Seine. You are right on the street that becomes the Vieux Rue du Temple.

Off the beaten path. This is a part of Paris where you can see everyday life. Take your time and enjoy the ambiance of the area, enjoy a coffee in a sidewalk cafe, or take a picnic to eat in the Pace des Vosges.Victor Hugo lived here but his house was under renovation so we couldn't go in. We still enjoyed strolling around the area.
Take a Stroll. Its a unique neighborhood with great food and interesting people. If you aren't staying here try to visit.

Perfect for a Sunday stroll. The downside of visiting Paris is that most things are closed on a Sunday. Fortunately Le Marais is open on a Sunday. Perfect for vintage shipping. While you're there, stop at a cafe and people watch or just enjoy the area.

home away from home. close to everything, next to les Halles, Ile Ste Louis, plenty of restaurants, local bistro type food and ethnic to fine dining, this area feels lived in and frendly and a home to many. The public areas are well used, people are down to earth, helpful and accommodation here is available both in rented apartments and hotels. Not pretentious, or over the top. Comfortable and accessible.

Perfect stay!. We rented an apartment in the 3rd arrondissement, Les Marais. We could have not asked for more. It was really convenient since the metro station was 5 blocks away from it. The neighborhood is the oldest in Paris, and the architecture is something to admire.There are a lot of restaurants and cafes in the area. It's perfect for getting lost and discovering new things every day. Rue des archives was our street.
diverse and colorful. one of my favorite places in Paris... so diverse and open minded and fun! really good food as well... love it!

Lovely neighbourhood!. I loved this neighbourhood; fun, funky, interesting and unique shops - not chain stores (there are some, but for the most part, boutiques) - you feel as though you've finally actually hit the 'real' Paris. Light years away from the Champs Elysees, it doesn't feel incredibly touristy. Take your time, walk the neighbourhood, and enjoy lunch at one of the many popular restaurants.

Full of atmosphere.. This area, whilst being touristy, is also extremely multi-cultural with a huge mix of nationalities. Smells of different quisine fill the air as you walk the very busy streets and boulevards and traffic noise is constant. Varied places to eat and obviously some places look best avoided. Nontheless we walked for miles through the area without feeling in any way threatened despite looking like your typical tourist.Focal point is, of course, the Pompidou Centre with its outside architectural skeleton which holds different themed exhibitions etc. Comfortable walking too, to other tourist sites not too far away.

Visiting the Marais. During our most recent visit to Paris, we took our walk thru Le Marais. From visiting the small shops and boutiques that line the streets, to buying glasses at Anne et Valentin our favorite eyewear store, to shopping at Merci and finishing the day off by having a falafel at the best place in the city "L'au du Falafel" it's the perfect way to spend a day in Paris
Best part of Paris. Beautiful shops, restaurants, cafes, street music, perfect location - close to the river. My favourite part of Paris, and definitely worth a visit.
great area to wander around.. Great shops, bars and restaurants, a big bonus is that everything stays open on a Sunday which isn't the case around most of Paris

Sunday afternoon stroll. The Marais is a popular place for Parisians to stroll on Sunday afternoon, and it is one if the few areas in Paris where the stores are open. Place St Catherine is a nice square rimmed with outdoor cafes and the Place de Vogues is a beautiful garden filled with French families when the weather is nice.

A Cornucopia of Quaint, Quirky and Modern. Easily the busiest area of Paris we saw. Streets were packed with young/old, all ethnicities and fabulous shopping! Not walkable from 1st arrondissement. Be prepared for crowds, but well worth a few hours.

Can be very charming or much too busy for comfort. We have either really enjoyed our walks through the winding cobbled streets or couldn't wait to get away. It depended on how many people were visiting at the time. Rue des Rosiers and du Temple can be so filled with people you can hardly walk, especially on Sundays. That said many people really enjoy the hub bub so I wouldn't want to discourage anyone. It's worth a visit. The area around Place des Vosges is quieter.
Great funky cafes and parks. Narrow, scenic streets and lots of great restaurants, cafes, bakeries, and parks. A happening place with a neighborhood like ethnic feel.
Bars and Restaurants. This area has numerous bars and bistro's that are all very good, most have happy hour 5pm to 9pm, and food is all very good.

Fabulous area. The Marais is buzzing with life. What ever you need, want, desire is here. There is an extraordinary mix of people. Great food culture. Great fashion. Perfect for people watching. Get lost down little laneways, thats what I seem to always do. See the Jewish schools being protected be armed soldiers as a reflection of our sad world, look for homes owned by jewish families who were deported to concentration camps in WW2. This area is so full of history and sadness. Every lane, every door holds a story. Find the wall of old Paris, it is next to a sweet little primary school.

Jewish and Fashion Sector. Rue de Rossiers is especially attractive walk through several blocks of fashion shops leading into the Jewish food section of Falafels and traditional jewish foods. Three blocks north is the Picasso Museum, recently opened after an 8-year refurbishment, and an overwhelming example of the range of Picasso throughout his life.

The place to be!. We rented a delightful apartment in this area and it was so easy to visit other areas from here. We dined in nearby restaurants and shopped in rue Rambuteau. The Jewish quarter was most enjoyable on a Sunday when all the small shops were open and the streets were traffic-free, along with a token security presence.
Cool little area. Explored the area a little bit after visiting the Memorial de la Shoah (Holocaust museum), nice bakeries and coffee shops

only area where restaurants are open on sunday, nice shopping. We arrived in Paris on a Sunday and the concierge of our hotel directed us to "Le Marais" to get something to eat. This is the old Jewish area of the city and still holds most of the Kosher restaurants. The thing is, since many of the shops and restaurants in other areas of the city are closed on Sunday, Le Marais gets filled with all types of shoppers and diners. We ate at Mike's Diner. I had an excellent hot pastrami sandwich and my husband ordered a chicken burger which surprisingly came with a sunny-side up egg on top of the patty, under the bun. There are many nice stores there- Zadig and Voltaire, a kind of upscale Zara type store, Ted Baker and a bunch of vintage clothing stores. If you're going to shop vintage clothing, I think Paris is a good place to do it. A nice area, great if you are looking for Kosher food or synagogues, or if you are a would-be Sunday shopper or diner looking for places to go. Go by metro or cab as I didn't see too much parking around.

Stay Here!. We rented an apartment here for our time in Paris. It was our first trip and we loved it! You will eat well, meet great people, have easy access to the metro and still stay in a true neighborhood where you can blend into the city. All of Paris is at our fingertips when you stay in Le Marais.

Excellent place to rent an apartment. We were one block from Place des Vosges which is a beautiful park surrounded by galleries and cafes/restaurants. We were on eastern end but walked thru the Jewish and gay areas. The were many small shops that were interesting to see. Best advantage was proximity to Bastille where you can catch metro and many fine shops.

I Bit .... ... and I bought: Two lovely little Paris dresses in Le Marais. What a great place to window shop and actually buy when you're like me and can't afford the high prices of the couture shops. So enjoyed the winding roads, the interesting people and businesses and churches. A must visit for a taste of real Paris.

Charming. I like so much this area, full of nice cafe, bar, stores and museum, a nice walk to go around and to place de voges.Lots of designer shops, home decoration,very trendy shopping are. Tou have couple of very nice museum int he area, Musee Carnavale, Picasso, the national Archive. It is an area rich in history. Make sure you. Go and walk around the area

Great area for shopping!. If you like small boutiques, friendly sales people, great shopping, narrow streets, terrific service and great restaurants this is the area to be in. This is my favorite area in Paris. There are great restaurants on every block and the shops are incredible. I can't wait to go back. A great hotel in this area is the Pavillon de la Reine.

Over rated district. A good place to go for some specialized shopping or for eating. But the environement is dirty sometimes filthy. A real fauna is wandering in the streets there day and night...and after 10pm you'd better avoid taking the small streets. Not the best area to promote the wonderful city of Paris. Nothing romantic there indeed!

The old Jewish Quarter is very interesting.. I loved the old houses, the museums, the interesting shops and restaurants and delicious patisseries and in general the unusual feel of The Marais. If you want to have a really interesting walk around an historic area of Paris, arm yourself with a guide-book and set off to explore this area of town. It's full of unexpected vistas and pleasant surprises.

Great area to stay. As a family of 6 it was such a terrific area to live in for 10 days. Easily accessible to the river, metro stations, parks, museums, galleries, gardens, sights, hop on hop off bus, cafes and restaurants. We would only stay in Le Marais from now on.

So much to do and eat. Great atmosphere, history and food. The Carette has the best pastries, bar none. It's located across from Victor Hugo's home and Place de la Vosge. A lot is going on, but not crazy crowds as in Montemarte, even though it was a Saturday.

Hurry Before It's Just Boutiques. This once genteely chic district is rapidly gentrifying with a new upscale chain stores forcing out the one-of-a-kind shops and small hotels. Two years ago it would have been a five star destination, but now not so much. So popular it's become streets are blocked off on weekends, so visit during the week. Seek out the small shops and buy something so maybe they'll survive a few years longer.

What's the fuss all about?. My husband and I walked miles up and down the streets of Le Marais and perhaps I am missing something, but it wasn't all that great. There are so many nicer pockets of quaint and Parisienne areas to walk that I don't understand why everyone claims Le Marais is so wonderful. There were a few places that were photo worthy, but not as I had expected. I've been to Paris many times and this was a disappointment.
Wonderful historical, wonferfully alive area. Crowds as usual but the stroll around the area is always congenial and the cafes inviting. Several of the galleries have interesting, well-executed art.

A true Parisian neighborhood. A stroll through these alleys gives you the feel of walking through the Parisian magic. You get to see a whole lot of beautiful architecture, statues and even impressive shops and restaurants to sample around. There is a collection of both high end and low budget eateries and shops and therefore something for everyone who stumbles upon here.
Interesting Area. Great walk down the riverside from the Champs Elysees, great little streets and shops to see. Interesting Area especially on a Sunday morning, there may also be a market.

Wowza! You have to see this!. Narrow streets, lots of people, lots of stuff to see, etc. We walked by on a busy Sunday afternoon, it was really interesting. We probably should have stayed there longer. We took the time to grab a falafel at King Falafel Palace and enjoy the overall experience. It's worth the detour!
Best place to enjoy real Paris. I loved visiting this area. Great authentic Paris. Wonderful people, street vendors and street artists and musicians. great food and drinks as well.

Vintage shopping delight. Don't leave Paris without visiting this area. It has a lovely young vibe and some great vintage clothes shops to rummage and a beautiful square and cloisters to wander through.. For lunch don't miss out on the superb Falafel and a cake from Jewish bakers to eat in the many parks and main square.

A lovely district of Paris. This is a charming section of Paris with narrow lanes, shops, cafes, etc. Most places are open on Sundays (not so in rest of Paris). The Chatelet museum, the free museum of the history of Paris, is in this area and well worth a visit both for the artwork and for the beautiful period rooms.

Avoid weekends. We know the Marais for more than a decade. It has changed a lot. There are more boutiques and tourists now especially on the weekends (all shops are open on Sundays). Therefore I recommend you to visit during the weekedays especially in the morning. The Place des Vosges is so beautiful and tranquil at this time of the day.
Can't miss it!. Marais is the juif neighborhood and has beautiful streets and places to see... must go to Merci store and Place des vosges!!!Musee Picasso also!!!
worth visit day and evening. little and narrow streets, shops and markets, restaurants and coffee shops, Jewish quarter - very pleasant for scrolling along the day and evening!!

Don't miss this old part of Paris - a fun place to shop.. It is always fun to wander around the old streets of the Marais, with its small boutiques and restaurants tucked in - up and down the small streets. Crowded, yes, but in a nice way. A favourite of ours for many years.

Vibrant and Defiant. I visited on a sunny Sunday and apparently had the same idea as nearly everyone else in Paris. The area was mobbed, but in the most upbeat, positive way possible. The streets -- notably the Rue des Rossiers -- were alive with throngs of people dancing, shopping, eating, talking, laughing and generally having a carefree Sunday out and about.Walking the area -- the Place des Vosges, the traditional Jewish district, the Bastille -- is enough reason to visit, but I also enjoyed a brief spin through the Carnavalet Museum and poking into the artisan shops in the nearby Village de St. Paul. Go to the Marais; it's a happy place!
City in a city. To regain your breath wander around though this part of town with iTS small streets and smal but beautifull shops.

My new favorite place to shop in Paris. Le Marais is chock full of hidden gems around every corner and cobblestone street. From the expansive and elegant Place de Vosges to Rue des Rosiers and all of the little boutiques in between there is something for everyone.

Your own private Paris. This area is small and village like, with narrow streets and old buildings, nothing like the grand boulevards around the Seine, or the grand shops of lovely St. Germain. It has everything you could want in walking distance: Poilane for apple tarts and the best croissants, a bakery by Rambuteau metro won best baguette, best fromagerie right by St. Denis church, great fallafel and middle eastern food and Cafe des Musees, Breizh, and best of all for breakfast Rachels, Mary Celeste, Fondations' coffee at the little park right by, eating Poliane's croissants...and the Muse de Carnavale where you see the history of Paris, and so much, much more. Photogenic, atmospheric, and your own slice of heaven. We did love our hotel but next time, and apartment is our thought, so we can shop and cook and buy all those beautiful ranunculus boquets ! Oh, the Marche Des Infant Rouge (please excuse any spelling errors on my part) and Chez Omar...we totally fell in love. Lucky you who is reading this to prepare for your visit! Bon Voyage!

Lovely, happy and enjoyable. During our 7 days in Paris, we went to the Marais almost everyday, even if just for a coffee. You can find here the trendiest restarunts, beautiful shops and nice people. The location is excellent and close to many museus and the Jewish quarter if you're looking for Kosher restaurants. Great - don't miss it.

great place to shop!. Everyone says it, but it really is a nice spot for shopping! Cute boutiques and stores, ranging from more affordable to more expensive, but there is definitely something for everyone. All the staff at each location spoke English, which made it easy for me to ask questions, and they were all very helpful in general. If you're visiting Paris, it's a nice location to find some different pieces to bring back home!
went before dark. great food (crepes and fallafels) and atmosphere and moulin rouge! pretty and neat part of town. lots of character.

Fantastic neighborhood.. After 40 plus years I finally stayed in the Marais. Of course I had visited because my favorite Place in Paris has alway been the Place des Vosges, even when I was 18.This quarter is so full of life and museums. If you want o splurge treat yourself to a stay at La Pavillon de la Reine. Not to far from the Picasso Museum is the Rue Rosniere with all the falafel shops and a great deli called Mickey's deli. If alternate lifestyles bother you go ahead and skip and regret it.

Rue Montorgueil. Street of small shops for wine, cheese, meat, baked goods, etc. A jazz band playing on the Saturday we visited in search of the "best macarons in Paris" at Stohrer. They were delicious, and the store is beautiful with murals on walls and ceilings

Trendy, central and historic. Sandwiched between Les Halles/Pompideau Centre on one side, and one of the best Sunday markets in Paris (Blvd Richard Lenoir) on the other; and just north of the Seine, this area of narrow streets, ancient buildings, trendy shops and restaurants, and several very interesting museums (Carnavalet and Picasso to name two) is a must. This Jewish quarter is perhaps more Paris than the Tour Eiffel and the Champs Elysses. Try a falafel on the Rue de Rosier, or go to the New York style diner Schwartz for a burger or pastrami (can be hard to get in, and slightly over-priced; but trendiness can cost). Or just wander around the alleys of the Marais and discover things for yourself. A smallish area, but you won't see it all in one go. Yes, there are lots of tourists, but it doesn't feel touristy; and there are lots more young people, many of whom are students.

We never left our neighborhood. Imagine a week in Paris without ever getting to the Eiffel Tower or Arc du Triomphe. Well, with all the small alleys, side streets, out of the way gardens, art galleries ... we found that a few museums and just strolling out our back door was the perfect vacation.

A bit Too touristic. The area is nice, but too crowded as it is the main walking district in central Paris. Be carful when choosing restaurants - there are meny who are not to picky about the quality and service of these..

Cool place. Stayed in the Marais for 5 nights, and really loved the area. Walking distance for Notre Dame, Quatier Latin, and the Left bank. Great bistros, where Parisians sit (outside in the cold) drinking eating and smoking.. :-) Great shops, and the Picasso museum is in walking distance.
Sunday plan. Very nice place, charming atmosphere.Don't miss musee carnavalet.Shops open on sunday. Ideal place to go on sunday

Lovely to walk around Le Marais. It is a tangle of medieval laneways, hip bars and restaurants, boutiques and a thriving gay and jewish community all squeezed in. We joined locals queuing at the takeaway window of L'As du Fallafel, the best in town and worth the wait, but had to eat it in the street the same as everyone else.
Shoe shops. Exploring neighborhood today and realized the Rue de Turbigo is crammed with georgeous shoe shops for men, women and children. Off the tourist trail so prices should be good.
One of the most fun places in Paris. Can walk here all day - lovely chic boutiques, beautiful cafes and bakeries, bars to hang out in evening (from fun to trendy to classy) -

shopping, eating, FUN !!. Perfect place to shop at the various brands like MUJI and other affordable french brands and designer brands....lots of eating options at the place des vosges....must have the falafel at L’As du Fallafel...cream puffs at Popelini....carette for madelines and croissants....visit Le Marché des Enfants Rouges - the oldest covered market in paris....absolute delight....and the best part is that its open even on sundays and on week days till late...!
This neighbour hood is full of great little shops. So much life and so many small shops to discover. This area is by far the best part of Paris in my opinion.

Walk down rue Rambuteau, and see 5 Wonderful French things.. I caught the metro to Rambuteau Station, started walking down Rue Rambuteau, until I came to Hotel de Soubise. Popped inside to the Museum of French History and of French Archives for a quick look then continued on down rue des Francs Bourgeois until I came to rue Elzevir, turned left into this and saw the welcome sign 'Hotel Cognacq-Jay.' I stood at this building with high expectations, for I had checked it out on line, and it looked great. However, a workman said, "Not open, closed." I was not happy! There was no mention of that on line in English, and I just checked again now, and there still isn't! However, in French translation - it says "Opening May 9, 2015." So walking on I came to Hotel Carnavalet, the Musee of Paris. This is well and truly worth a look. Continuing straight on I eventually came across the Place des Vosges, the famous beautiful Park Square, with its very old rich houses. Finally I went and found the cute Gothic building the Hotel de Sens - now the holder of the Forney Art Library.So, after a cup of coffee at the nearest Cafe- I decided that the Marais was okay. But some time I am going back to the Cognacq-Jay Museum - I just looked it up again, and it looks even better.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia

It very cool area. I like this area, but like Saint-Germain better. Its small streets and if you just wonder around you will find all kinds of stuff. Just like Paris you just need to start walking and exploring. We found a great Crepe place and Flaffal place as well.
Oldies but Goldies. Old and romantic streets. You can smell the old days ambience. Also there is lots of art galeries and stores. Enjoy it.

My favorite part of Paris.. Or maybe second favorite after St Germain, both these areas, especialy le Marais with its small curved streets and small boutique retain some unchanged Parisian charm. The jewish quater is my favorite are here and its also pretty convenient to go back and forth to St Germain and the latin quater.
Nice place to hang out. Nice and trendy place to visitMany gardens to relax and enjoy the quiet in the center of the cityMany shops
Old Paris. Enjoyed the history of this old part of Paris ..beautiful architecture tiny streets beautiful hidden gardens

my favorite neighborhood in Paris. This is my favorite neighborhood in Paris because of the diversity. High-end shopping with low-end bars and bistros. Upscale visitors and blue-collar workers share the streets. There is something for everyone!
Fun fun fun. Great people watching and shopping. No real bargains here...also nice restaurants and cafes to choose from. It is very crowded though.

Marais. Went to the Picaso Musee and walked from metro to museum, stopped for Orangina at lovely cafe and then walked to the ille le cite through the Marais. Lovely area with small parks dotting the neighborhoods
Nice area to walk in or hours. Good shoppping. Nice resturants. Plenty of small streets to explore - a very good area to spend some hours in.

Missing it Already.... Spent 7 days in Paris based in an apartment on a quite residential street in the 3rd.
