We did all the tourist stuff in the other districts, but each day we longed for our return to the Marais. Charm, great people, wonderful markets and local eateries, museums and so much more. We found ourselves inevitably eyeing the local real estate listings and dreaming of a permanent return...
Love the Old Jewish Quarter. The oldest neighborhood in Paris. I rented a great flat here during my stay. A bit of a maze, but it's such a beautiful neighborhood.
Wonderful. Lovely and quieter part of Paris. Lovely food, architecture and wine. Great base for exploring the East side of Paris.

Wander and soak in atmosphere in buckets. We wandered from St Michel along Rue de Rivoli to reach Plas de Voges. This is a great way to enjoy an area of Paris that has lovely shops, cafes and many restaurants. Lay on the grass at Plas des Voges and soak up the atmosphere with many others. We had a very enjoyable and tasty lunch in a side cafe. A perfect way to spend half a day or more.

Great shopping. We stayed in the Marais area of Paris and loved all the beautiful shops for both men and women's clothing. There are also great falafel shops and everything is open on Sunday which is rare for Paris. The area is busy on a Sunday because the shops are open.

My favorite part of Paris!. I loooove this neighbourhood and I was back again and again there with my husband during our short stay in Paris this week. It somehow reminds me of Schanzenviertel of Hamburg but bigger. It is filled with restaurants, shops, bars, food stalls of different levels, from a quick simple Kebab for a few Euros or a classy French bistros that sucks your wallet out to of course, Japanese dishes. During after-work hours around 18ish (which is livelier than in the afternoon), the area is buzzing with people chilling out, sipping their after-work beers or wine, or clanking forks and knives, mixed with bursting laughters of joy. My husband and were walking along the area going through the atmosphere of the cafes/restaurants we passed by. We enjoyed our stroll and stumbled upon some places we never thought we would find. Here, Any cafes there are perfect to sit and watch the world go by. Along the walk, we went through Lopsided building, stone cobbled pavements, small alleys and turns, curved streets and roads that lead to surprises, Le Marais is a lively, vibrant, soulful ancient part of Paris that one has to explore by simply walking. We've been there several times and never got bored.
lovely quart. the oldest neighborhood in Paris, with shops, cafes, bars, markets...always lively and interesting...here you can feel the real Parisian life.

Parisbestlodge.com "Crazy View" apartment. Just got back from staying 8 days at parisbestlodge.com. We stayed in an apartment called "Crazy View". The place is centrally located to all major attractions. The apartment is small, but was very adequate for me and my two teenage daughters. There is a living room/dining/kitchen area as you walk into the place. The kitchen was compact but had all you could need (no oven), as well as a washer and dryer. The sofa makes into a double bed. TV, phone are provided. The place was absolutely clean and decorated "Parisian" style. The bedroom has a double bed. Again, the bedroom is small, but there is a closet, bed, nightstand. Lots of windows and light. Bathroom is small but fine: shower, sink, mirrored cabinet, toilet. Thierry is just wonderful! He is a wealth of knowledge and wants to make your stay as enjoyable as he can. I would recommend this place for a couple, small family, girls getaway. You've probably read about the 4 flights of stairs (no elevator). It is manageable.....just don't bring luggage that is bulky or heavy!
Lovely place for a walk. It is the prototipe of atemporal París.. It is a special environment where to walk relaxly and enjoy tipical parisien

Chic Paris meets in Le Marais. Le Marais is the oldest neighborhood in Paris. There are restaurants, stores, bars- all the visitor needs to experience in Paris. One can have a lovely high-end meal or a falafel for 5 euros for which one stands in line on the street while watching the world go by. Lopsided buildings, cobbled pavements, narrow passageways in a labyrinth of streets where scores of souls have passed, Le Marais is a living portrait of medieval Paris,
very nice and tipical barrio of paris. with a lot of renovation, the Marais aria is worth because of the numeros shops, cafes and nice retaurants at reasonable prices.

This is a beautiful area of Paris!. Unfortunately, the Picasso Museum was closed when we arrived, so we didn't get to do what we came for. (We came on a whim and didn't check hours before we arrived.) However, we strolled around a bit- there are museums and very old and beautiful buildings to look at. We had a great pastry at a local shop! We will return the next time we visit Paris and spend the day here.

Fashion paradise. What a great area! Shopping paradise, tons of small specialty shops, vintage stores, and cute boutiques. Book Localers Le Maris Fashion tour to make sure you don't miss any bargains!
Restaurants and vintage shops!. Lovely area for shopping cheap in Vintage-shops on Rue de la Verriere. Lots of fine restaurants and music in great neighbourhood.Don´t miss!

Paris at intimate scale. Royal homes from centuries ago became the Jewish area in the 20th century, and are now ateliers and museums. between the larger properties are small townhouses with boutiques and architects offices. Many nice restaurants for a glass of wine or two and small plates from international cuisines. Not really for young families.

Fun to walk around in the old "Marsh" area. This are used to be a marshland, thus its name. Now it is a delightful area of restaurants and shops, famously known for the falafels. Even if you're not hungry (but you will be once you catch the aromas), it's worth a short visit walking around and just Paris as the Parisians see it.

The heart of Paris. Our apartment was on Rue de Temple in the heart of Les Marais. 5 minutes walk from the Pompidou Centre, 15 minutes walk from the Seine, easy metro access to all the major landmarks.The joy of the location is you are surrounded by Parisian life and can live like a local. Within a ten minute radius are award winning boulangerie, charcuterie, fromage and the best chocolate in Paris - Jacques Genin.To really get a sense of the produce and history of the area I would recommend doing the Paris by Mouth Tour in Les Marais. We spent a great 3 hours getting to know the area and tasting some wonderful food and wine.

The historic Paris district. This is without a doubt the most historic part of Paris,lots of lovely streets,alleyway's and great shop's ,cafe's and cool restaurant's make this a must go destination on any trip to this wonderful city.I would most certainly think Paris was built around LE MARAIS;translates roughly as THE MARSH or THE SWAMP.We love to go at night when all the cool cafe's and bar's are opening ,the atmosphere is so special.If your planning a trip to Paris,you really should pay this district a visit,it is that good,the real Paris.

Funky town with a French accent. Bit boho but still reeking of Parisian chic, great boutique shopping, excellent people watching, beautiful architecture, interesting boutique and large museums, fresh markets within walking distance, easy transport to other iconic sights. All adds up to a must do. In fact try staying in one of the apartments near Place des Voges, you won't regret it. Love it....

Perfect Neighborhood. Our hotel was at place de la Bastille..easy to get around by subway..15min walk to Jim Morrison s grave..15 min walk to Notre Dame Church...walking distance to Lombard street and the restaurants and bars and shopping ..we found the neighborhood safe we had no issues walked everywhere the week we were there.Lots to do!
just away from all of the hussel and bussel. nice wee village feel to Le Marais. You somehow don't feel like you are in Paris. Lots of cafes, bars etc. Place to chill.
A nice stroll. We walked along Rue De Rivoli heading towards Le Marais. There are many quaint little shops and we enjoyed a beautiful afternoon exploring the many side streets and eateries.

Renaissance. Place des Vosges is at the heart of the Renaissance Paris. Noble men have fought duals on the square, Victor Hugo lived in an appartment which can be visited at a corner. And there, next to it, is Rue des Rosier and the Jewish district.

What a change. We have always loved Le Marais for its quirky shops and vintage options. After not having visited Paris for a few years, however, we found Le Marais, very altered. Gone are all most of the little boutiques and with trendy chain stores having taken their place. Very sad.

Knowledge and wisdom of the guide makes a tour. I went on a walking tour, starting at the hotel de ville, Paris through the Marais with the most amazinglingly knowledgeable human encyclopaedia tour guide STEPHANIE. Her knowledge, passion and enthusiasm was amazing, adjectives cannot describe this tour. I thought I knew the Marais area. But no way, learnt so much, the old grey matter is still, one day later trying to absorb all the information. 3hrs, walking through the Marais, 3hrs discovery and learning the history of the Jewish people in France from almost the beginning of the time Paris existed, well before the Romans. Please go on this tour if you think you know Paris le Marais, and have a passion for knowledge and history. Paristrip excel in caring and choosing its guides.

Walking with style. It was my first walk through this network of secret streets and alleyways. Little shops beckoned everywhere. Happily, not too crowded. A very atmospheric part of Paris, about five minutes' walk from Notre Dame and worth every step. BHV dept store also great.

Charming area with lots of history and character. We spent a whole day Exploring district's narrow streets, drinking coffee and shopping in small boutiques. Make sure to stop by at Picasso museums, located in the heart of Marais district.

Nothing special. Maybe we missed the best bits?. We looked forward to visiting the Marais district, but there really wasn't anything stunning about it. Some nice shops and cafes, yes, but nothing spectacular. I have a feeling that we might have missed the best bits.
shopping destination. best place in Paris for cheap vintage and trendy shops. Many boutiques, and design shops, that are not on the high street. Good places for food too.

Good area, walking distance to everything you want and need. This was the second time I stayed in this area (previous visit was in a private apartment on the Ile St. Louis, which I would say, is the ultimate but not always possible!) and I would say this is my "go-to" area now. Easy walking distance to the great restaurants which we found on the island; close to transport, easy walking along the river, lots of shopping on rue Rivoli and other adjacent streets. Check out the Place des Vosges and all the little streets between Vosges and Rivoli. Lots of great little hidden streets to wander around and get "lost"!

Must Experience!. The Marais is vibrant and busy with high end boutiques alongside glitzy cheap jewel stores, restaurants running from Felaffel and Noodle stands to French Haute Cuisine, and of course you have the food market of Les Enfants Rouges. There are the noisy and not very clean main streets on which you will find the Pompidou Center ( I still can't understand what they were thinking when they built it...) and the big Les Halles shopping center but also the lovely little streets, all of them beautiful with small hidden gardens and churches that you just fall upon when strolling in the area. All you have to do is get away from the main streets and walk along the small ones. You are sure to find hidden gems along the way. The cafes are lovely and there are endless pattissiers- boulangers where you must throw caution and calory counting to the wind and enjoy your eclair au chocolat or whatever your choice of pattisserie might be. We booked a vacation rental for our stay in Paris in the Marais and for me it is the best place to live in for a short stay in Paris. Step out in the evening and you have an abundant choice of good restaurants, walk around in the afternoon and watch the elderly petang players in the public neighborhood park, buy your breakfast baguette from the local boulanger, and just feel the vibrancy of the neighborhood. A wonderful place to stay, and if you are staying elsewhere, you can spend a whole day in the Marais and you will probably come back for more.

Authentic and Parisian !. Like many others, this is my favourite part of Paris (admittedly, I haven't seen all of Paris), I love the originality (no same 'ol' same shops) and the atmosphere. The boutiques are excellent and I literally spent all day in and out of shops, mixed with coffee stops and people watching. The food on offer is excellent and well priced. I went with a group of four others and it wasn't for all the group (no souvenir and tat shops either). My advice, decide what you like and choose accordingly.

wonderful shopping. There are countless little shops with very unique and not necessarily expensive finds in this area. The narrow streets, old buildings and authentic Parisian cafes, patisseries and chocolate shops make it simply charming. Easy to get turned around bring a detailed map with you.
Great atmosphere. Always a great time out in the Marais, can get VERY busy at times which makes it difficult to find somewhere to get a drink without pushing through a crowd.

Favourite part of Paris centred around the Place des Vosges. Art galleries and cafe jostle each other under the arches of the historic Place and ancient mansions, many now museums, abound in the area.

Don't miss this area!. Super fun, hip and happening neighborhood. Fabulous restaurants and shopping. Plan on spending a day in this area. Also a great location to stay....close to Notre Dame, Ile St. Louis and walking distance to the Louvre and Tuilleries.
Jewish quarter with great falafel. This neighborhood was fun (but crowded) with cute alleys and narrow paved roads. Pick up a falafel when you're here (we did)!

Interesting area close to attractions. We have had accommodation. In this area on two different trips. It is walking distance to a lot of attractions or the metro and buses are easy to use. Many restaurants in the area and not to forget the cream gelato shop near the Pompidou Centre.
Nice Neighborhood to Explore. Interesting walk, interesting residents with several attractions, good place to find a cafe for lunch

Hip Cool and Not to be missed. Le Marais is a world unto itself. So many cool street side shops and restaurants and it's just lovely to walk around.
We went one evening and peeked into a couple of nice small galleries.
there are a few shwarma places here - any are good and are delicious!!
Lively exciting area. This location is great. We rented an apartment for 4 days through a Yahoo site and could not have been happier. Having such a great home base added to our experience.

Do not miss this area. Such a wonderful and vibrant area. Lots of nooks and crannies to get lost in. Fantastic shopping and bakeries. Visit the St Paul area too. You will need to carve out a full day to do the area justice but if only a few hours do not miss out visiting.

Charming cobblestone neighborhood of trendy shops, delish restaurants and Jewish history. This ancient Jewish neighborhood of Paris has much charm and very trendy hi fashion shops interspersed with delicious bakeries, delicious kosher restaurants featuring local delicacies and Jewish deli and hands-down the best falafel in the world! It's the Parisian version of NYC's Soho and Hollywood's Melrose. Great fun!!
my fav. Based on my first visit, Les Marais is worth more than it's average three stars.My favourite place. I really enjoyed it .Must say best place beside the Eiffel tower
Typical french neighborhood. Many subways, buses, near the most important place to visit, many hotels, bars, place where Victor Hugo lived, visit la Place the Vosgues, and many museums around.
Touristy but good. Make sure to get yourself horribly lost. That's when you find the good places. Try the little île as well.

Lively and fun. During the day it has many boulangeries and patisseries which brighten up your day, and in the night it offers great pubs and bar to hang out in.
Other than that, it's a beautiful neighborhood. Definitely worth a visit!

One of my favorite parts of Paris!. Every time we go to paris we somehow end up spending most of our time in le Marais. It's such a great neighborhood with everything you could ask for. A ton of different types of restaurants and cafes. Markets, the Pompidou, the Jewish quarter, great boutiques...everything! After you finish seeing the must see attractions, head to Le marais and enjoy the real paris!

Culture, architecture and good shopping!. Don't forget the Picasso museum. It is a Pearl now and the exhibition is very well done: by themes and not chronologically: women, bullfighting, portraits etc....

A great neighborhood. Wonder thru the streets and explore the many boutiques and a few French branded stores. Within the area are the Jewish Museum and lots of very good delis. You will always fine a line at the falafel shops scattered along one of the main streets. An easy Metro ride over or a nice walk from other parts of the city.

Wonderful. Take a boat trip - don't go on the Bateaux Mouches as there are other cheaper alternatives. I took an hour-long trip with commentary on a boat that was immaculately clean, had an airy feel, had very clean toilets, and gave good all-round vision. Go to mooring 3 on the right bank and buy a ticket. You see such an array of Paris from the river and it is a very pleasurable and worthwhile experience. A fantastic way to spend an hour!!

Charming streets with great shopping. Enjoyed walking through the winding streets. Surprising artwork on the walls here and there. Interesting shops to browse. Can easily spend the day getting "lost".

lot to see!. I love le Marais, it's a really great neighbourhood, lots of stores, cafés, galleries and museums. don't miss it. Carnavalet and le Musée de la chasse et de la Nature are both terrific...highly recommended actually!
Our favorite neighborhood. We have stayed at Le Pinot Noir apt in the Marais twice. Great food. Cute shopping. Easy to get anywhere in Paris from this neighborhood.
Great Place to Stay. We stayed in this district and will most definitely stay here again. It is peaceful with plenty of great restaurants. The attractions and train stations are so close too!

Raidd Bar. Oh Raidd, words cannot adequately express what a FANTASTIC place this is. Raidd is more than a bar, it is an experience all on its own. I was here every other night. AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING. The crowd is yes granted 95% gay men, but what else are you expecting? I do not know if it is because of my Latina looks, but everyone is extremely friendly, and NOT pretentious. I met soo many outgoing people. The energy, the music, and of course the "showers". Yes, expect to get a drink or two spilled on you, but that's because everyone is dancing and not pressed up against the wall. AMAZING, I cannot rave enough about this place. *LADIES: if you are trying to go alone here, as I did on a Thursday night, tell the bouncer that yes you are in fact aware it is a gay club, otherwise they might try to discourage you. Also, it is a 1 girl per guy policy.
Wonderful part of Paris. Enjoyed walking around this bustling interesting part of the city, great shops and restaurants, wonderful architecture and history.

Le Marais. Le Marais is a great place to stay and/or walk through. It is full of smaller museums, parks, cafes, boutiques, markets, monuments and churches. Our apt was located here and we thoroughly enjoyed it and its surroundings. It is close to all transportation. It is very diverse and lovely. It is a great place to start your Parisian exploration.
Shopping and eating in the Marais. This area is full of great restaurants and shops. Also one of the oldest parts of Paris. Worth spending a few hours walking the small streets.

Everything on your doorstep here in Marais. Friends recommended an apartment in Rue de Turenne and as first time visitors to Paris we didn't know any different. But here we are in quiet little street with cafés, boutique shops, tourist attractions, transport and more right on our doorstep. Feel like we're living amongst the locals here rather than amongst the tourist class and feel like we could our whole 2 weeks just exploring the charms of Le Marais. Musee Carnavalet and Musee Picasso each only 10 mins walk away as is Place de la Republique. Feeling very lucky to have landed in this part of Paris!

shop shop shop. great shopping area for affordable shopping,walk down Rue de Rivoli for shopping and restaurants stop in and visit the beautiful churches and museums in the area . The Metro stop at Saint Paul will put you right in the middle of it all

Worth the stop. I was somewhat troubled to take my family here since the Charlie Hebdo issues, but security is great, and you see them everywhere in the Marais. Worth the stop is Restaurant Le Dome...a wonderful place with gorgeous architecture and delicious food.

Favorite Neiborhood in Paris. Traveled with my mom and two teenage daughters to Paris in May and had a blast. We stayed in a nice condo in Place des Vosges, which is great in itself. Being in the heart of the Marais district was so much fun. I found it to be much like many areas in downtown Manhattan. The stores are mostly boutique but the variety is excellent. There are so many good restaurants to choose from nearby and Metro stations are plentiful. This was a great walking neighborhood to soak in so much of the culture and history Paris has. Highly recommend.
Wonderful quartier to walk around in. Full of trendy boutiques, excellent museums (Picasso, Cognac-Jay, etc. etc.), the beautiful Place des Vosges and all that is what we think of typically Parisian.

Charming part of Paris. Another charming part of Paris full of great boutiques, even better patisserie with the best creations of master bakers. Historic bars and restaurants .... Jewish quarter and falafel food...

Wander around and enjoy, sure, but watch out - food quality/value is pretty poor compared to Paris in general. Been coming round to Marais, and spending time shopping, staying, eating , years on end ..... the place has been 'gentrified, with quaint shops giving way to upmarket boutiques (not an improvement) , while most of the restaurants and cafes are so 'spoilt' by the heavy tourist patronage that their standards have dropped, while prices have arisen .....Every meal we've had in the Marais district the past few years, has been 'below par' in quality-price value, and even mediocre restaurants are full to the seams twice every night ... Visit, by all means, but be smart enough to eat 'elsewhere'...

A village in the city. If you love a neighbourhood feel in the city, Parisian parks, the sound of happy children, food markets, quiet hidden squares to eat falafel, cafes for people watching and that feeling you're more like a local in Paris, this is the place to come. Don't miss the Ville St. Paul, a village within a village and the Place de Vosges. This district is a wonderful part of Paris to explore and will make you wanting to return for more.

A village in the city. If you love a neighbourhood feel in the city, Parisian parks, the sound of happy children, food markets, quiet hidden squares to eat falafel, cafes for people watching and that feeling you're more like a local in Paris, this is the place to come. Don't miss the Ville St. Paul, a village within a village and the Place de Vosges. This district is a wonderful part of Paris to explore and will make you wanting to return for more.

Great place to live in 1973. Very central, good connections, many attractions reachable on foot.You ought to live there for a year or so to really start appreciating its advantages.For just a visit look at the Museum reviews

Love this neighborhood. We stayed in an apartment in the Marais. It was perfect, close to the metro, close to boutiques and restaurants and a store across the street from our apartment. We could wander the Marais for many days and not be bored.
Lovely area to stroll. Liked - lots of museums, shops, cafes. One of the best areas of Paris to wander around, it down for a glass of wine and food. Disliked - weekend crowds.

Always a delightful place to stroll through. One of the nicest areas in Paris, one we are in love with. The Place des Vosges is beautifully alive, particularly at end of school time, and walking around to the various 'Hôtels' gives an idea of what Paris was 3 centuries ago. At least for the well-off... If your first stay in Paris is more than 3 days long, it is a must.

lived here two weeks. bustling with activity, a wonderful boulangerie right around the corner, convenient food shopping at Monoprix--this area has all you could ever want. convenient locations for travel by foot, bus, or metro.

Marais- Beaubourg area of Paris. My two sister and I stayed in an apartment on la rue Beaubourg while we spent four days exploring Paris. This was an ideal spot with a couple of boulangeries and a local Carrefour just a few minutes away. The area was great; some excellent small restaurants of every ethnicity, lots of fascinating little shops, two Metro stations within minutes walk and also only minutes away from the Pompidou Centre. I felt very safe in this city and was amazed and pleased by the friendliness and helpfulness of every Parisienne we met. (Not what I remember from previous visits). We walked almost everywhere because it was easy and pleasant, only using the Metro to wend our weary way home a couple of evenings, and for Montmatre and the Sacre Couer. We also used the hop on and off boat which was great for a different view and enabled us to chill a bit while taking in a different perspective. We visited Notre Dame (marvellous on Sunday to hear the organ and choir in the service), the Tuileries, Place de la Concorde, Champs Élysées, Arc de Triomphe, Musee D'Orsay, Eiffel Tower, Louvre all were amazing. I recommend an evening trip to the top of the Pompidou Centre to see the shimmering Eiffel Tower, on the hour for five minutes, We breakfasted at home, stopped for coffee breaks, light lunch and evening meal wherever we happened to be. We spent about £250 each on top of our Eurostar fare and apartment fee. We had a marvellous time and saw and did everything we wished. To be recommended.
Great area of Paris!. Great area of paris to eat, shop or hang out at the park on the grass on a nice day. The jewish museum is nearby and there are many great spots for drinks or food, night or day.

Chic area of Paris.... if youwant understated class, this is the place to be. Good restaurants, nice shopping, great hidden palaces, and art in the Place des Vosges. And have a Mexican cocktail in the TexMex at twilght opposite the school of dance - a unique experience.

Nice Charming Interesting Neighborhood. I personally like this neighborhood because, unlike much of Paris, this area still has small streets and small squares, full of artistic shops and great restaurants and cafes. This area boasts the homes of many famous French authors and is worth a visit. I like to stay in an apartment on the Place De Vosges.

Our home while in Paris for a week. Loved, loved loved Le Marais. The proximity to Ile Saint-Louis, Notre Dame, and the wonderful restaurants and shopping of Le Marais make this region a gem. Our apartment was right in the heart of Le Marais. We had food markets, bakeries, Starbucks - all a quick walk from our home. Plus close to the metro. Perfect place to stay!

A must see experience in Paris.. The fascinating cultural stores, restaurants and cafés of the Marais is just one aspect of this exciting place. Had a delicious schawarma (kebab-style wrap) there today. The only hard part was choosing at which place to eat on Rue des Rosiers. They all look so tempting!

A Vibrant Area.. We usually rent an apartment in Le Marais every few years for a couple of weeks and love exploring the many smaller streets and shops. There are the main attractions such as Picasso Museum, Place de Voges, Square de Temple and Musee Carnivalet but so much more. Many small street markets can be found, especially at the weekend and the area is so vibrant. Public transport, especially buses, is the best to be found in Paris and you can enjoy day and night trips to all wider areas.

Great buzzy area, lots of restaurants, bars, shops, things to see and do. We stayed in Le Marais and could not have hoped for a better area for a weekend trip.It's one of the few buzzy areas on a Sunday, as Paris can be quiet on a Sunday, so we were thrilled to be there. Some great restaurants (Les Philosophes & Chez Marianne we can recommend), vintage shops (the kilo shop, brilliant), homeware stores and much more. Just wander around from street to street and get a little lost while stumbling across different things. Much more interesting than the main shopping strips.

Very nice. Visited this neighborhood because our guide Tomo from Paris Charms & Secrets tours told us about it. We have had some amazing fallafels and we loved to hang out in those narrow little streets. We took Temple street and Old temple street as well :)I felt like a real Parisian for a few hours.

Still the marvelous Marais. Feel free to stroll the Marais in safety. A discreet police presence, plus a very obvious one in front of Jewish houses of worship and institutions can be taken one of two ways: as a reminder of the recent events of January, or as the city's visible commitment to order and civilization. Come for a felafel, soak up the atmosphere, shop the Rue du Rosier. Enjoy!
THE PLACE TO BE ON SUNDAY. Le Marais is the place to be on Sunday as most stores are open on Sunday, unlike Paris where almost all the stores are closed on Sunday. Fun people watching.

Lovely, if you like shopping. We rented a gorgeous appartment in Le Marais. The area is without a doubt gorgeous but the shoppers made it slightly unbearable. The weekend was VERY loud with young drunk teens screaming through the night for no apparent reason. The highlight was Place de Voges. A very old brick square in the heart of the neighborhood.Lovely to relax and eat in one of the restaurants.

Shop like a Parisian. This is the new hot ,chic,Parisian neighborhood. It is in the 3rd and 4 th arrondisement. There is great shopping with lots of name brand shops like Kiehls, diptyque . Sites to see include Musee Carnavalet and Victor Hugo's house. There is also great underground mall shops and plenty of patisseries and gourmet shops.Don't miss this area of Paris!

Wonderful Neighbourhood. you can have a very delicious breakfast at a nice comfy french cafeam sure you wanna try the crepe , grape fruit juice and jam n butter ;) then have a wonderful walk in the nice quite streets of Le Maraisa photographers heaven

Wonderful Lunch on the Square. Many of the shops are chain stores, but it's not plagued with the tourist bric a brac like so many areas. Stopped in one cafe on the corner of the square but it was crowded and pricey. Walked further down the sidewalk and had lunch at a lovely place with black walls with shelves of books and nicknacks. Delicious food, fun waitress. Creme brulee was incredible!

Vibrant but safe. Excellent selection of Resturants, bars, cafes etc. Very good 'vibe' even in the busier establishments. Felt very safe walking around, even late at night. Well located for Metro directly into the centre of Paris. Would definately stay here again.
Shoppers Paradise. This area of Paris is undoubtedly worth a visit if retail therapy is for you. Shops, restaurants, bars, no Macdonalds to be seen. Heaven.

Great area of Paris, feel like a local not a tourist. Staying in Le Marais was a great choice, it contains Vosges Park, a beautiful square with Victor Hugo's house & Hotel Sully ( home to National Monuments of France) & some of the oldest streets in Paris. Great little boutiques, boulangeries & bars too
Perfect Place. It's such a perfect place for shopping, spending time hanging around, have some drinks. It's calm and trendy.

cute. we went on a Sunday, it was a nice walk although most of the shops were closed, but you get the chance to visit the market "La Bastilles" which was nice. We also ate at Chez Janou and it was great

Mostly residential. It makes for a chilled out stroll and there are some pretty buildings, some with some historic or religious importance. But it's very quiet with many places not opening until just before lunch time, and there weren't nearly enough tempting Jewish bakeries and eateries for my liking. It is quite charming but if you're only in Paris for a short few days I wouldn't put the Marais at the top of the hit list.

The most interesting part of Paris. This was so cool, it is a mix of different people, I believe that here you can see the real Parisians. Beautiful architecture, you can walk for hours and shop if you want, grab something quick to eat, but if you want to get the best of the area, we suggest that you take a tour guide, we went with Chris from City Free Tour company and he told us all about the history of this amazing area!

A gem. And to think that a couple of decades ago, one could have bought an apartment there for a song...Le Marais, the 3rd arondissement, is the old Paris in a modern surroundings. Most of the buildings are old, dating to a few centuries ago. there was even a medieval cloister open to the public along the Rue des Archives.Now that it has become a tourist attraction, the cafes and stores have become a bit pricey and crowded, but you can still enjoy sitting among those ancient buildings sipping a cappuccino and munching a croissant.For the shopping, visit the nearby Rue Saint-Antoine and don't forget to visit the Place des Vosges and a beautiful and cheap eye-glass frame shop on Rue de Birague.Enjoy!

Great home base for stay in Paris. We stayed near the Place des Vosges and the Place de la Bastille in the Marais. We walked from here to the area around the Notre Dame. We felt safe and totally enjoyed this area.
Great place to wonder around. Originally the Jewish ghetto filled with history. Get an architect's guide to walk around and spot all the old beautiful buildings.

Lovely neighborhood, nice shops and most wanted falafel. We came Sunday afternoon, atmosphere, buildings, streets were super lovely.Some of the shops were open here although in general in Paris shops are closed.In this neighborhood it's must thing to do, eat falafel but good luck with the lines... They can reach up do hundreds of meters.... Don't worry though, here is lots patisseries & delicates shops like everywhere in Paris. Incredible & lovely city it is.

Charming place. Really charming place.
One part is kind of a Jewish area and the other kind of a gay area but both cutlure seem to live together perfectly.
I loved the streets. Quiet with good people. perfect for cofee or diner.

In Paris - Visit Le Marais. I love to visit the area of Paris known as, Le Marais. There are plenty of ways to get there: Bus, Metro, Boat or my favorite - walking down Rue de Rivoli. Walk past the Hotel de Ville (Paris City Hall) and emerge yourself in some great window shopping. Eventually on your left you will see signs leading to Le Marais. A wonderful mostly Jewish neighborhood full of shops and restaurants. The streets are typical Paris - every corner you turn leads to something interesting. As a history student I stop along Rue de Rosiers, remembering this is where the Vichy and Nazis rounded up the Paris Jews. They were then sent to Drancy and later onto Auschwitz. The sadness I feel is lifted by being there and seeing this now vibrant community that has survived the worse that Man has to offer. Stop and have a lunch at one of the many venues, visit a shop and spend time in this most extraordinary place, in a most extraordinary city.

Nice surprise. Came upon this charming neighbourhood after getting off the Batobus at the Hotel de Ville stop and just started walking. What a wonderful change from the busy hectic pace of some of the other districts. Nice boutiques, cafes and wider sidewalks I think. Authentic local shops and just a different feel here. Would love to spend a few weeks in this district....truly special.

Perfect area to stay in Paris if you can afford it!. We spent two week in a lovely large studio apartment in the Marais at the end of the year. It was perfectly located to many things you want to see/do/eat! Close to many bistros and bakeries as well. Very neighborhoody.
Great fun. Really fun area with lots of great shops and amazing little cafes. We plan on staying in this district next time we visit Paris.
Fabulous. Stayed in Marais for five days. So much to see and do. Great shops, good restaurants, fun vibe.Convenient to Metro- great place to stay.

A must to visit in Paris. Such a lovely neighbourhood! Good for shopping or just looking ;-) not the everyday stuff but boutique's with different stuff or clothing brands. Tea shops, jewellery. Also nice restaurants for lunch or dining. If the weather is nice.... Go and chill at Place des Vosges. We havent seen all of Paris, but for what we visit this was the best place!!

Great for shopping. Le Marais is one of the nicest neighborhoods in Paris. It is great for sightseeing as it houses many great locations worth visiting such as the Place des Vosges, the Place de la Bastille, the Archives, the Hotel Sully and many great Churches such as Saint Paul-Saint Louis, Saint Gervais-Saint Protais and Notre Dame des Blancs Manteaux and the newly opened Picasso Museum on the Place du Thorigny. Le Marais is also a shopping Mecca with many grocery stores, wine shops, ready to wear and specialty boutiques.

Once was marshland, now very trendy. Lots of boutique hotels, lots of construction, very sought-after place to live. Borders the Seine, hence the marshiness in times gone by.Go to eat there, it can be fun.

Go on a Sunday if you Can. We stayed in the Marais, which is becoming increasingly popular. I would suggest you go on a Sunday if you want the Parisian experience - buskers, people watching, and shopping. It is definitely less-busy during the week, so head back again for shopping.
Touristy. I love Le Marais but it is quite crowded. There are some great boutiques and some of the best Jewish bakeries in the world!!!

An authentic neighborhood. Narrow winding streets, buildings dating to the Middle Ages and shops, boulangeries, restaurants, cafes of all kinds-- not to mention fabulous museums in the neighborhood -- the Marais has it all. This is a neighborhood of real people and real businesses, not tourist schlock.

My favorite quartier in Paris. I had the distinct pleasure to have lived very close to this, my favorite quartier in Paris, for many years. With seemingly endless little cobblestone streets of architectural gems around every corner, a plethora of great places to eat and drink and shop. What more could you ask for? Too many choices to write about here (though I have reviewed some eateries here). Do yourself a favor and go discover it for yourself. Simply impossible not to be impressed. Tip! though the streets are closed on weekends (something I longed for for many years. Couldn't believe so much traffic was allowed through those tiny streets) I recommend going during the weekday if possible to avoid the hoards of people, just remember to look out for cars and bicycles when you inevitably have to step off the tiny footpath to get around people taking photos, or just to move forward.
This is a very nice area for walking and shopping. This area east of Centre Pompidou is a very nice area to walk and to shop. Not too busy.Also very close to the Notre Dame

antic, true neighborhood, full of history. stroll thru the little narrow streets, of the original paris, you'll find everything in a cultural mix, and please finish your afternoon by visiting the Shoa museum. It will surely make you feel bad, strange, nauseous, but such a way to appreciate the world we live in today. If you feel home sick, stop by Breakfast in America in the St Paul district

Excellent shopping with local parisiens. To truly experience shopping with locals please try shopping in Le Marais. What a wonderful experience. We stumbled upon the area and the shopping and thoroughly loved the experience shopping with locals. Not to be missed.

The place to be on a sunday. A bit rough around the edges but that is what is fun about this area. A lot of stores are closed on Sunday but a lot of them are still open and there is plenty of fun shopping and people watching to be done. Most of the restaurants are open and provide a sort of indoor/outdoor area that is covered with clear plastic in some cases so you can still get the effect of an outdoor cafe in February, but not really, because in many places they still allow cigarette smoking in these areas, and it really is inside. Food in general is cafe-type food, nothing outstanding, but I may not have known where to eat. Galleries are generally not open, but you can still look in the windows. I'd like to return during the week and see more of this boho area.
great place to stay. We rented a two bedroom in a walk up and it was a great decision. Never stay in a hotel, go on AirBNB to find a local apartment.

Interesting area. We visited Le Marais as the location for our walking/eating/drinking tour given by "Paris by Mouth", which was very good. There are lots of cafes, food shops and a lovely market full of food, wine, flowers and other goods. At the end of this market is a wine cave, really worth a visit. We thoroughly enjoyed it. The Pompidou Centre is a short walk from Le Marais, as is the revamped Picasso museum.

Little doses of perfection.... ...everywhere you turn. An art shop with exquisite wares. A boutique with softest leather. A book shop I could lose myself in. Delight of a place to window shop...or really shop!

Cross between Hampstead and camden. What a great place. Beautiful falafels chic independent retailers and lots of narrow streets to wander through.
I visited this place on my 3rd visit to Paris as recommended by my wife who did all the great research before hand

A very jumping place. The Marais- rue de rosiers has changed a lot. The restaurants are mostly middle eastern food- delicious. The boutiques are younger and hpiper. The place was full on a winter lunchtime. We ate at Karkaz- a dairy restaurant and browsed the shops. It was safe.

An arrondissement not to miss … the 3rd is Le Marais!. Le Marais is the place to stay …
Le Marais is the place to shop …
Le Marais is the place to eat …
Don't miss it … when you visit Paris!

Picasso Museum is now open. The Picasso Museum had been closed for 5 years, but it is now back, totally restored and much, much bigger than before. There are now 4 floors of works of all his trajectory as one of the most inventive and creative artists of the 20th Century. A must see in Paris.
Great place to wander around.. Many great restaurants...... Benedict is my favorite. Many mom and pop shops and lots of food shops. The Shoah, Holocaust Museum is a must. Visit Epicerie Provencale.

Adorable. Could there be a quainter place than Le Marais in Paris? With its boutiques, its excellent falafel, the superb and moving Jewish museum, and the excitingly louche gay scene, I can safely say that this old man in his twilight years enjoyed his visit enormously.
Great area. Bustling with energy and small designer shops. Great area for experiencing the Parisienne cafe society.

Cool area with some good options. One of the best neighborhoods in Paris, good area to be based. Sure it's a good place to live with several bike rental points, restaurants, groceries and stuff. Totally recomended.

Lively district. A lively district with many restaurants and fashion shops. The key though is to get off the main street (that is rather tourist oriented) and discover the little 'local' restaurants/bars. Found a great little restaurant called 'Le Soleil en Cave' with great food and wine, and very friendly owners (that were thrilled to have a non-local in their establishment!)

A Most Wonderful Neighborhood. While we have always stayed in the 8th, we love just walking Le Marais. The mood of that neighborhood is so warm and welcoming. We also love the diversity of the architecture, and the wealth of cultural attractions, so close at hand.
If we were ever to stay elsewhere, than the 8th, Le Marais would be our firsts choice.
Very beautiful and peaceful. I loved this place.. it was my 3rd time in Paris and it surprised me.. Place des Vosges, the streets close to it, restaurants and galleries there are really nice.

Free concerts in the marais. fun streets, great shopping, but very crowded.on sundays there are free classical concerts in the Eglise Merry. even if you don't like the offering, a sit down is always a great break

A Seventeenth Century Neighborhood. Many, many 17c buildings and churches. The great Place des Vosges formerly a royal palace with a charming park at its center. Several museums housed in former homes of nobility. Numerous good restaurants. Great for strolling and a short walk to Ile St Louis.

Don't miss this wonderful part of Paris!. There are important sites and museums here, not to be missed. The restaurants, shops and atmosphere are great. It all combines to make Le Marais a wonderful stop on any trip to Paris. The Shoah Memorial (Holocaust Memorial) is located here and is quite interesting, a painful reminder of the fate of more than 70,000 Parisian Jews, deported from here to Nazi death camps during World War II. The names of each of the Paris victims are carved on a series of massive walls as you enter the building. Inside, there are fascinating historical exhibitions and a room where through walls of glass you can see the card catalogue of files kept on each Jew in Paris; there is an index card for each and every one, chilling evidence of a terrible time in the history of France and the world, and a lesson for the future. It is a fascinating, enlightening and sobering place to visit.

Beautiful. Such a gorgeous place - grab a coffee and and bench and chat away the sunny days....Have your camera handy, if only for the quirky shop fronts. And for those that like to photograph their food - you wont be disappointed.I love this area - if on your own, then stick your iPod on and wander.x

Favorite neighborhood in Paris.. What a great place! Walking around, shopping and eating couldn't get any better. A wonderful place to spend a day or two. Many museums, a lot of cafes, and great shops.

Great place to walk around, good food. Loved the falafel at the popular place on the Rue de Rossier, great cafe--Cafe Marais, for watching neighborhood. Good store next door for souvenirs and knick knacks at a reasonable price.

Visit. We have stayed in the Marais neighborhood for many years and I reluctantly recommend it to visit because it will get that much more crowded when I am there. That being said it IS worth a visit. Convenient and lots of restaurants and small shops (although increasingly more are chains) and the wonderful Shoah Memorial.

Akin to Greenwich Village, in the 90's. Le Marais is the 'hip' Paris neighborhood, young and vibrant with small shops and the Picasso Museum, great intimate restaurants and so much more. It's less crowded than some other neighborhoods, too.
Amazing area!. Perfect area for shopping, eat something, go for a walk and feel the city's ambience. Lovely neighborhood

Gay Paris...what more can I say?. Really cosmopolitan. Restaurants for all tastes, cafes, bars etc. Great churches. Pompidou centre, if you like art, or other art galleries. Tourist shops too. After dark, another side... gay bars and clubs open. But it's okay. Stayed here many times.

Atmospheric, lovely district.. The Marais is one of the most parisian parts of Paris. Well worth the visit. Wonder around and you will discover many interesting sights. If you want culture, Musee Picasso is in the middle, the Jewish Museum is on the rue de Temple, if you are after mens shirts, rue de Turenne is full of so called wholesalers specialising in mens wear. Historic and nice Place de Vosges is another attraction. So many individual shops, a relief from all the multiples you see in other parts. A good idea is just to get lost in the narrow streets and enjoy Paris.

Sunday brunch and shopping paradise, also good for late night. Le Marais is the trendy neighborhood in Paris, it is great for people watching in any cafe, but also full of boutiques that open sundays as well as trendy Restos for Brunch, just make sure you make a reservation. you can visit the square of the Hotel de ville and walk from there to the Georges Pompidou and stravinsky fountain, then go down in the streets behind until you reach the Seine again. given the bohemian character of the place this is also great by night go to the bars near bastille

Place de Voges is an oasis of joy, symmetry, and tranquility. Named the most beautiful square in Paris and well deserving of this name. Inside the square are children playing, older,people walking about, a beautiful statue,, an attractive place. The buildings surrounding the square are symmetrical, well maintained and the arcades have lovely art galleries. The Museum of Victor Hugo is worth a visit. Free on Thursday afternoon.
WIndow Shop Heaven. Great place to wander. It is easy to get lost a bit in this section. The recent attention in the news to this area not withstanding - there are some very cool things to see.

Nice place to explore on Sundays. I loved walking around this neighbourhood on Sunday afternoon watching the locals around. It is one of the few places in Paris that is open on Sundays. The streets, the open areas (around centre pompedeau) and bustling activities make it pleasurable to visit on Sundays.I heard the place is also very good for the partying scene, though I did not visit any clubs.

Too bad it has been taken over by the "In"- stores. No longer the authentic piece of old Paris, the neighborhood stores have gone and made room for splashy and fashionable stores selling the wares that you find anywhere and online too. Gone are the jewish stores and the days when exploring the Marais was exciting.
Romantic walk!. Walk in the Marais and vist the Place des Vosges. Eat in small corner brasseries. Very romantic. Need 3-4 hours to see it well.

Beautiful area of Paris. I loved the Marais, its such a beautiful part of Paris for shopping, walking and having a coffee. I've visited this area three times now and I love the little Jewish delis and the coffee shops with some of the best coffee I've ever had.

A Great Location. When we visit Paris, we stay in Le Marais. This location allows you to immerse in neighborhood life. Many little boutiques with art, jewelry and clothing from new and exciting designers. There are wonderful restaurants at every turn and markets to pick up a quick dinner.

A nice area. This is a nice area to stroll around and ejoy the atmospere and the architecture. Probably the highlight is the Place des Vosges and its park, but take a little time to go into the back streets and there are lots of pleasant little squares with shops and cafes. This is an area much appreciated by the locals - with reason.
The best area in Paris. The best "balade" in Paris. You can walk from Bastille to Beaubourg, though Le Marais. Lot of café and hype shops to stop.
For wandering. i spent an afternoon wandering around le marais; quirky shops, interesting little alley ways and a buzz in the air. Stop for coffee and watch the world go by.

Different Cosmopolitan place. This "Cartier" is quite different to what you are used to see in Paris. You will find a lot of arab people and food, even long lines to get a falafel pita. There are also french restaurants and theaters as well as nice stores, the Picasso Museum and many things to look at.

My Favorite Neighborhood, Still. Ten years ago, this was the best. Not so many knew that this was the place to find great deals in hotels, eating, and shopping. Moreover, it is an original Paris neighborhood, one which was not given a new face during the renovations of the 19th Century. Every time I am there, I discover new things. My mouth still waters for the delicious poppy seed pastries of the delis along the main street of the Jewish Quarter. The late night drinks and chocolates in the cafes, the wonderful people so open and friendly, the cheap and friendly wine bars, the great ethnic variety of the eateries in just one neighborhood, and the proximity to a great part of the best of Paris from this neighborhood make the Marais my unquestionable favorite. And yes, if your are young and gay, it is the club scene to end all club scenes. For those who are into shopping for the best brands, and I am not, this is one of the newer venue for all that. To me, this has detracted from the place's original charm and attractiveness. It has also caused prices to soar in cafes and certain, but not all, restaurants. Good news, it is easy to avoid the few main street that cater to the more materialist class. Find the unique and the historic. Explore lanes, and go through open doors into private places. Sit somewhere in the Place Des Voges and listen to the haunting sounds of a cellist playing from an alcove, and imagine the life there 500 years ago. This is still, for me, the best of Paris!! Footnote: one of my favorite life memories is walking a deserted, sparkling, cream-colored, half-lit Marais lane late at night during a sudden, unexpected snowfall--the absolute quiet, the beige snow-flake shadowed light--the sense of place, and the recognition of its timelessness is now, most gratefully, a part of my permanent consciousness.
Beautiful. Take the day and discover the beautiful Marais - so many beautifuil streets filled with cafes and shops.

One of my Favourite Places in Paris. Like the falafels that can be found everywhere here (check out Rue de Rosiers), Le Marais is addictive. Within walking distance from so many other interesting areas be sure to visit this area for fantastic food (both taste and price), a great atmosphere and swanky shops. Wander about and visit picturesque Place des Vosges, Pompidou Centre etcRecommended places:- Chez Hanna (Rue de Rosiers) - delicious falafels at very reasonable prices. Be prepared to wait though as this is a popular place.- La Droguerie (Rue de Rosiers) - great priced crepes. Came for lunch and was greeted warmly by the friendly owner. A few seats inside to sit down at or you can take away.- Uniqlo store - in a converted factory this is a must visit for all architects/interior design fanatics. SO COOL.- Various second-hand clothes shops where bargains can be found if you have the patience to trawl through the racks/mountains of clothes- BHV department store - great to wander about, imagining you could have everything- Maison Georges Larnicol chocolate shop - if only you could bottle up the scent of this place. Sells decent-priced macarons too and is a feast for your eyes and nose.
With Bryan Pirolli. Amazing vibe and so much history! Will return as there again this year as there's still so much to see!

Perfect spot to stroll and windowshop. Le Marais has a great history and I won't go into it here, but it's the perfect place to visit on a sunny day. Stroll down its lovely, quiet streets and pop in at the gorgeous shops. There's something for everyone: boutiques with design furniture, patisseries, book shops, the works. If you like to wander, this is a good place to see on foot.

"The" place to stay in Paris. The "swamp" (marais), is well located to enjoy Paris on foot. It was for a long time the garment section of Paris and it has retained a lot of the character it established then, I stayed there often in the 1089 because it was both central in inexpensive. Then it became a "pink" centre for several years. Now it is a mixture of artistic and commercial. The hotels in this area can be cheap or expensive, according to your willingness to pay, but the location, near both Notre Dame, the Opera, and the Left Bank, make it a good choice.

Wonderful area, Open on Sundays +++. Best falafels with a wide range of cafes. Very safe and beautiful area with lots of refurbished 17th century mansions. Also a huge plus is that most of the area is open on Sundays.

Great neighbourhood with lots of vintage shops.. Nice streets, cosy little shops. A lot of clothes shops, by own designers and vintage clothes. A lot of restaurants. Good to walk trough to Bastille or Louvre.
living neighbourhood. this neighbourhood is the latest fashion among the locals and the tourists. lots of trendy Parisian cafes and lovely designer boutiques

Awesome District in Paris. Le Marais is a fashionable district in central Paris with lots of nice, trendy restaurants and art galleries. It is located on the Right Bank of the Seine River and parts of it are in both the 3rd and 4th arrondissements. This part of Paris was originally a swamp until it was drained hundreds of years ago. The name of the district is still called “The Swamp” or Le Marais. This swampy beginning is the opposite of what it is today (a very trendy area).My wife and I have visited this district on other trips and returned for part of one day on this November trip. My wife wanted some shopping time on this trip so we spent part of one our day visiting this charming part of Paris. There are lots of trendy boutiques in this district. There are also some interesting museums in the Marais including the Musée Picasso and the Carnavalet Museum.Le Marais a great place to walk as it has interesting, ancient and windy cobblestone medieval streets. This is one of the few areas in Paris that has retained its small medieval streets. If you get tired after shopping and walking take a break in the beautiful Place des Vosges. This is the oldest and probably the nicest public square in all of Paris. There are lots of benches to sit down and people watch and relax. You will see lots of locals and tourists in this square. You can also visit Victor Hugo’s old home as it is inside this square and is now open as a museum.Overall I really enjoyed strolling through this awesome district in Paris and highly recommend that you visit it when you are in Paris.

History and winding streets. Wandering through the Marais is heaven. Little shops, winding streets, delicious bistros, plus the Place des Vosges-you can't have a better day. Plus great museums are everywhere.
Chick!. Fashion, Trendy, Cosmo, Chick or however you wanna call it, lots of bars, restos and things to see. It’s known as Paris gay neighborhood, but as a tourist place is great for anybody.
Great vintage shops!. Once you have done all the must sees, Eiffel tower etc. This is a cool neighborhood particularly for vintage shops, which had awesome fur coats.
Great for walking around and shopping. Cute area with some great boutiques as well as known name brands! Lots of restaurants and cafes and this area is fun at night!

After the tour Eiffel etc. this is the best place in Paris to visit. Loads of great cafes and bars, an interesting and amazingly vibrant Jewish quatrer, but don't visit that on the Sabbath (from Friday night to Saturday night) lots of small interesting clothing (and other)shops. Some of the Jewish cafes and takeaways are unbelievably popular with lengthy queues, so get there ahead of the crowd. Great and beautiful architecture including of course the Place des Vosges. Then there is the Picasso Museum, again an early visit is required to beat the queues.
Cool shopping area. It is a mix and match area, has all kind of nice shops and restaurants. But, also have small museums for visit. People are very nice in the area, and food are delicious.

It's fun, it's crazy, it's full of life. This area, the 3rd and the 4th, is a maze of museums, cafes, shops, shops and more shops. You can go in any direction and be sure you'll get lost but eventually find your way to where you're going. Each time you'll see something new in this old historic neighborhood and it's a definitely must-see.

terrific atmosphere. though touristy is it still unspoilt and thye atmosphere is intact
a visit to the place des vosges is a must

Cheese , chocolate bakery & more. Food everywhere, also it is a bustling vibrant place, different from the other district, the pastries from Miss Manon is absolutely delicious, Benoit chocolate is divine

My favourite area of Paris. Lovely to wander around all the little streets, great Jewish bakeries and cake shops, plenty of traditional Parisian cafés, lots of individual boutiques as well as some of the bigger name places. Peaceful neighbourhood with a lively friendly atmosphere.

Authentic local experience!. We have been to Paris 4 times and always stayed around Vendome, closest to luxury shopping. Though I appreciate the convenient access to the top designer shops & department stores, my best 'authentic" local Parisien experience was in Marais, an area known as the Jewish Quarters. It's now very trendy, but the shops have very neighborhood-feel. I was able to go to local candy shops, cheese shops, grocery stores, creperie and best kosher bakeries. The BHV is also a more affordable department store than Galleries LaFayette or the Printemps. There are a lot of knick knacks there that you can't find at higher end shops. Access is quite easy by Metro, by foot or taxi. It's not as far as it seems on the maps. Maybe 20 minute walk from The Louvre. Spend an afternoon there and also eat the best falafels in the area. Go, go, go!!
over rated. It seems to be THE place to be but in my opinion it only applies to a certain kind of people. If you are not like this, do not go, nothing really special
Shopping and Wandering. This area has a lot of restaurants/cafes and has a friendly vibe. There are a lot of shops if one is interested in shopping.
The stylish district in Paris. My favourite place to stroll over and the place to buy beautiful things. Lovely restaurants and tiny shops. Another must in Paris.

place des vosges le marais. Excellent location,where is located this square place des vosges,where used to live the famous writer VICTOR HUGO.Great restaurants around and as a curiosity the great french actor JEAN MARAIS has taken his name from the name of the quartier,transletd in english marais means swamp.

Our favorite area of Paris. We spent 2 days wandering around this magnificent neighborhood. Filled with awesome little shops and restaurants! A little further away from the river is Le Haut Marais, which is another great little area!

Fun Neighborhood. Rented an apartment in this neighborhood around Christmas and had great fun visiting all the shops and cafes in the area. A short walk to the Metro, BHV, and Notre Dame. A truly wonderful location for an American in Paris.

Come on Sunday for fresh food and markets!. Le Marais is a pretty big area in Paris - so I will attempt to narrow it down for others!The area of Le Marais which is open on Sunday is the one located at the corner of Rue de Bretagne and Rue Charlot (shops are along Rue de Bretagne). Located here are the shops open and patroned by locals - your Boulangerie (bread shop), butcher, charcuterie etc. There is a nice local market nestled at 39 Rue de Bretagne 75003 Paris which has lots of local produce and is worth a visit. On a Sunday, do NOT go to the other part of Le Marais which is located near Hotel de Ville station as there is nothing open and you will be wasting your time.

Nice area. The Le Marais district in Paris in the troisieme arrondiesment is a hip, trendy & bohemian neighbourhood. Funky clothes shops, boutique hotels, restaurants & bars are all over this area. Most places are open on Sundays making this place very alive on Sundays. Do not miss a visit Place des Vosges! A great destination to visit and spend time watching, shopping, soaking up the brilliant atmosphere. Recommended!

La Marais is the place to be on a Sunday in Paris. Paris is very quiet on Sundays. Most of the stores are closed. La Marias is the place to be!!!! Lots of the restaurants and shops are open. Street entertainers come out by noon. Great place to people watch.

Walk it, eat there and visit its splendid museums. So, there is lots of small coffees and pattiseries, great fashion shops and amazing museums. Just get lost there and discover them! You have nothing to loose. I can recommend the quartier juif and this little portuguese shop called something like comme à lisbonne... but you will certainly find other treasures. Place des Vosges is a must.

Les Philosophes and shopping.. Les Philosophes is a great little cafe/restaurant at 28 Rue Vieille du Temple. A little expensive. If you want a salad this is a good choice. Excellent shopping in the area of the Marais. Don't be afraid.
Worth it. We went to Le Marais to visit Place des Vosges. It was a nice walk and the destination: Place des Vosges was truly beautiful. We sat there for a while just enjoying the view.

One of my favorite districts!. If you like bargain shopping, late night cafe's and more of a night scene, this district is for you! If we are not already staying in this district, my boyfriend and I always have to visit the Marais. The streets are beautiful, and the shopping and ethnic food stops are so worth the day visit!
Old Paris neighborhood. Lovely small museums in the area, and lovely boutique hotel options for all. Restaurants and fashion galore.
good district to stroll. Nice district to stroll through, tho you won't necessarily feel you are in anything totally different. But there are some good restaurants and shops in this area.

Amazing area!. This was one of our best experiences. We strolled the streets of Le Marais, ate some fabulous falafel, pressed our noses up against the windows of amazing bakeries and marvelled at all the fabulous people. This is a must visit!
Nice !!. This neighborhood is really nice !! A beautiful place, nice shops, good reataurants !! Place du Voges has interesting art galeries and goods perfumeries. Also good restaurantes !

Colourful area. i love to shop in the Marais to drink lots of coffee eat falafel and visit the museums in the area. As I tip if you are going to the Musee de Picasso book a time slot for 11 Euros and avoid the crowds. Small winding streets very Paris as it was before Baron Haufman made the grand boulevards.

STAYED LIKE A LOCAL. Stayed on the border of the marais and Bastille so got to enjoy best of both suburbs we had the market across the road with amazing food stalls fresh veggies great cheese stunning breads and we had the Marais which is full of great shopping cafes restaurants and close to most sights with lots of metro stations which were so easy to use. Saw a lot of Paris which was amazing but the Marais is for me the best
Wow! This is an amazing district. Within this area you can get off the well worn tourist route and start to see how the locals shop, eat and live. Well worth a day to wander around.

Do Not Miss Hôtel de Sens!. This neighborhood is famous enough and should not require any introduction here. It is charming and rewards a ramble. You will be rewarded by strolling around the streets and keeping an eye out for interesting architectural features here and there. If you are lucky enough that your wandering takes you to 1 rue du Figuier 75004 Paris, then you will encounter Hôtel de Sens, a building of eminent charm. The Hôtel de Sens has a cannonball lodged in the wall above the main gate and so do not miss this.http://www.coolstuffinparis.com/cannonball_hotel_de_sens.php
The gipsy feeling. This gives you the old paris feeling. Lots of good bistros, nice cafes and restaurants. Nice boutiques (not chain stores). Artstores and galleries.
Great nightlife, lots of options!. Stayed in this area of Paris and loved how lively it was, packed with bar/restaurant/shopping options.

Surrounded by flowers. My friend and I were walking through the Marais on our way to Notre Dame. Suddenly, we found ourselves surrounded by flowers, plants, bulbs and seeds on both sides of the sidewalk, as far as we could see. It was a cool, overcast day and that burst of color raised our spirits.The Maison de Ville has extraordinary architecture, and there are always events, clusters of school groups, and displays in the plaza in front of the Maison.

Great for living local. Mornings at Marche Montorgueil just west of the 3rd Arr and also Marche des Enfants Rouge just east. There are some rougher-appearing areas, but had no issues and departing from St. Denis on the Metro allows access to most sites with 1 train change.
Best neighborhood to stay in while visiting Paris.. Best restaurants, cafes, boutiques. Reasonable prices. Several centrally located Metro stops so you can be almost anywhere in the city in minutes.

Wonderful neighborhood with character for long walks. Le Marais (sandwiched between St-Paul and République) is one of the hippest parts of the city, packed with modish hotels, vintage boutiques, restaurants and bars. Is also known for its numerous art galleries and design shops.Wonderful neighborhood with character for long walks. Highly recommended!!!!!

Arrondissment with history. Do visit Rue de Rosiers, also near Hotel de Sens for Village st Paul - quiet in winter, but in summer these courtyards would be marvellous, full of antique and craft shops. We liked the signs that gave history of area or building, and a lot of course about WW2, and treatment of the people.

Great for January 1. We asked ourselves where to go on January 1, when so many places are closed. Well, there you will find beautiful small streets, a lot of people, open stores and great places to eat, while a whole good part of Paris is still sleeping. And i'm sure it's lovely every other day also.
Lovely. If you want to visit a Paris with not many tourists, this is the place! Nice boutiques, great restaurants and bars.
Charming and unique. Small, charming streets, beautiful St Paul church, several nice boutiques, cafes and restaurants. Great park at Place du Vosges.

My favorite place to walk around the city. Trendy, cute, fashionable... the Marais is a great place to walk around and get lost. Get a falafel and do some shopping, or just eat your way through the macaroon shops. My favorite place to wander !
So fashionable. Beautiful neighbourough! a lot of a cafes and boutiques. Charming museums like Carnavalet or Cognac Jay. And la Place des Vosges, amazing!!
charming. Loved the Marais with its chic boutiques and cafes. The Place de Vosge has wonderful galleries and restaurants.

Get lost in the streets. A wonderful neighborhood in Paris. Different from Saint Germain with large gardens "Le Marais" is a narrow streets but is very charm.
Go throught by walking and feel the atmosphere in the afternoon.

Favorite Neighborhood. So cute! There are so many little boutiques, bakeries, and cafes. I could spend hours in this neighborhood, and I did! The neighborhood has changed over the past few years, but its still my favorite in Paris!

A nice place to stay in Paris. Stayed in an apartment with ParisBestLodge in this area. It is a good place to stay. Lots of restaurants, cheap eats and groceries. Close to some place of interest like Place des Vosges, Hotel de ville, walkable to Latin Quarter, Ile de la Cite, Notre Dame, etc.

from another era. one of my favourite areas in paris. one of the most original. the quartier of jewish people which i love. the quartier of victor hugo and the falafels :P and there is the best brunch in all of paris, at ''la boheme''. trust me, i'm fat and a dirty lover of food

The most Parisian neighbourhood. The marais is a wonderfully atmospheric neighbourhood with old houses, beautiful boutiques, monuments and history - and a touch of the modern with the centre Pompidou too. Well worth a good walk around.

We walked Le Marais for an afternoon. Le Marais is always an interesting walking visit, we enjoyed our afternoon wandering without a destination in mind. It seems no matter how often I visit, I find something new.
the real paris. This is the place where you can wonder feeling you are in ancient Paris ,A whole different feeling ,Delay your purchases till you go there!!

Great Area!. We stayed here for about a week and cannot fault the location, everything is close by and the area felt safe and very convenient if you are coming from the CDG airport. We looked at staying near the Arch/Louvre and am very happy that we didn't. You'll be able to get to most Paris tourist attractions easily if you base yourself in Marais.
Cool place to hang out !!!. A lot to see, discover & explore - from bars, cafes, restaurants, galleries, museums, book stores, etc.
Nice to walk and have a Falafel. The Marais neighborhood is very nice to walk around.Don´t miss the Falafel at "As du Falafel", just delicious, in a simple place !

Great to Stroll through Historic Paris. We explored this area in light rain and still had a great time. The narrow streets were untouched by later urban renewal and are still filled with 17th and 18th c buildings, including many fabulous mansions built in the 1700s. Rue Franc-Bourgeois is a main East-West street and is filled with contemporary fashion boutiques. Be sure to visit Place de Voges, the first urban plaza created in Paris. The Picasso Museum reopened in Oct 2014 and is still drawing crowds so book tickets on-line. Many side streets are filled with fascinating small shops.
Always wonderful. New Year's Eve 2015 was sensational - people on the streets were happy, the stores and restaurants were great!

Great Walking!. Love this area and repeat on every trip to Paris. Go the the Old Jewish Quarter. Great shopping, good little food spots and several interesting museums. See the Picasso exhibition. Can be crowded.

My favourite part of Paris. I can't say enough about this part of Paris. After visiting it on my second trip to Paris, and staying in it on my third, I will only stay in Le Marais now when I go. I've used it as my central "home" area now for three trips and have been very happy. I love the charm and the age of the buildings. There are loads of great restaurants, so you don't have to stray too far from your hotel at night for a great evening. Metro stops galore, so you are always just a few minutes from any other part of Paris that you may wish to visit. Shops, boutiques, cafes, history, beautiful things to look at. What more could you ask?

Quiet and beautiful. We visited Le Marais on Christmas Day. It was very quiet, which we enjoyed. Known as the Jewish quarters, we had expected more shops to be open, which they were not. Except for that a relaxing walk.

Chic Arrondissement in Paris. This is a chic and hip area to be strolling around in on a Saturday afternoon where you can get lots of shopping done and the best way to explore Le Marais is to wander around without a map. The different cobbled alleyways can hold many surprises for the inquisitive one.

Best Shopping District. There is no better shopping in Paris than in the Marais. The cobblestone streets are busting at the seams with the cutest local boutiques and cafes. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time to explore the many winding streets of this area. Every time we return to Paris we dedicate a day to this section of Paris and always find new, edgy shops.

Feels cosy and unusual. There are parts of Paris completely saturated with big brands. Le Marais has some of those, American Apparel, for instance. But it's also a place to wander around markets, find cute little stores that are one-offs, eat oysters and drink wine at vendors on the footpaths; stroll through the Place du Temple and admire the ducks; be utterly alarmed by the Parisian disregard for pedestrians and the 'spontaneous' places they park; wine sellers of all kinds; book shops; restaurants; patisseries. And if you can find an apartment to rent there, it's just perfect - the Republique metro will happily take you everywhere. Love it.

Trendy But Very Disappointing Restaurants. On visiting the area on the evening of the 28th december 2014 have a drink and something to eat, we were shocked at the high number of resturants that were empty, clearly the menu's were very boring, dated and have not changed for the last 12/18 months. Although prices are moderate, clearly people are fed up with the same food selection, food quality is also an issue.There was clearly a lack of Christmas Fun in the area.Wake up businesses you are loosing business and people......

fun area to walk around. Fun to walk around, some great/good museums and good food.Get off the main streets and wander around. Some streets leading to the Place des Vosges feel like they are loosing their character.

Great area of Paris!. I've visited the Marais for years but haven't stayed in a hotel there since one of my first visits to Paris when the Marais was very undeveloped. For this visit with 7 other members of my family (children and grandchildren) we stayed in the Marais and loved it. Restaurants from very good to very casual; shops of all kinds including really good vintage shops; great little gift shops; very good museums. Our visit in December was perfect - not so many tourists. I'll go again at this time of year and stay again in the Marais.
Love the Marais!. Great location with fab restaurants and boutique hotels! Changed a lot from ten years ago but still fab
Interesting neighbrhood. Rosiers is the street with a number of food places including L'as Du Fellafel. The Authentic Fellafel is also good.

The Paris of my dreams. This arrondissement is my favorite thus far. We are trying to spend time exploring each of the districts in Paris and I was delighted to spend some time in Le Marais recently. It is a beautiful area. There are so many quaint shops and great restaurants to enjoy. Le Marais really is what I dream of when I dream of Paris.

Felt like authentic Paris. My wife and I visited a Paris for a week in October. We try to have a local experience when we visit a city, and not view it from the outside (so no tour buses or guided tours or packages). We did our research went with an open mind, intending to simply walk around the arrondissements and take in the city. 5th and 6th are of course highly touted and somewhat touristy but a must visit/explore. We also loved la Marais (3rd and 4th) perhaps the most. We were staying on Ile Saint-Louis so close to everything. We enjoyed strolling Rue de Rivoli, which had everything from fruit stands, local clothing stores, cafes boutiques and locals hurrying about their day. It was busy and metropolitan but with enchanting side streets to explore (Rue Saint-Paul - explore the cobblestone alleys full of antique stores) and very local dining (search Place Sainte-Catherine on google maps for a cluster of restaurants on tiny neighborhood courtyard).

Take time to explore this suprise package. This is a hugely unassuming area and you enter feeling like you are coming to a nice little quiet neighbourhood that should be nothing special. But then as you explore the little streets and laneways, the suprises never stop. Picturesque little boutiques and cafes are everywhere.
