Big brand names clearly want to have a presence here, but small family businesses are not forgotten. This isn't an area for fancy eating, but great for casual food and for window shopping. If you need to buy something, be prepared to spend some serious cash.

Coming back strong!. Le Marais is the location of Place des Voges which was home to some of the wealthiest residents of Paris and still has a very high end ambiance. Near the Bastille and surrounded by very active residential areas, Le Marais is home to many artists and musicians. The restaurants are many and excellent and the main court yard in the center of Place des Voges is a wonderful place to take a bottle of wine, a baguette and your lover for a romantic picnic!

Best area to explore. Helps if you have a GPS activated phone as the streets twist and turn a bit. It can become more challenging after dark, but once you learn your exit from the metro and which way the river is no issue. It is a great place to explore shops, bars, clubs and the city museums that are in close proximity to each other. Great food, Iranian, Jewish, Chinese, Parisian.

Shops, restaurants. Go to La Royale for lunch. Great place. Walk around this area and just lose yourself in this area. Find a boulangrie and buy yourself a pastry. Sit on a bench with a cup of hot chocolate if you go in winter and watch the people go by. Ah man what a time! Super!

Maybe better in summer. We stayed in an apartment in the Marais -Rue Charlot- in December, and while it was an authentic French experience, I'd re-think my choice for subsequent visits. The Marais is serviced by about 4 or 5 metro lines. This is great and can get you wherever you want to go. The downside is that the closest is about a 8-10 minute walk, the furthest more like 10-15. In summer this would be perfect, but in winter when it us dark by 5pm, and often cold and wet it becomes less appealing- easy to get lost (street signage is limited) and tricky walking on slippery icy cobblestones. In summer/ spring The Marais is the go, but think carefully about this choice in winter.

What the Village & SoHo & Meat Packing were if they were 1000 years old!. Shops, galleries, restaurants, cafes, bars, falafel shops, trendy boutiques, chocolate – where tourists mingle with locals. We stayed there tice, and probably will again. Metro One stops, including St. Paul. Food shops (yes, even cheese). Walk to Picasso, as well as Bastille for restaurants and its incredible food market.

How did I ever move away?. Okay, let's be honest, having moved to London, I miss Paris terribly. But really, the 3rd has to be my favourite arrondissement. It's a perfect place for a stroll, the shopping is fine and varied, especially on a Sunday when much of Paris is taking the day off. The Rue de Rivoli is fun, but move over to the small streets - the ru de Rosiers, and the area around there and you can find some really fun places to visit. Well worth the effort.
Fabulous!. Great food, fabulous shopping in little boutique stores and one of a kind places like Merci. Incredible area!

Great area for a stroll. We stayed in at the Pavillion de la Reine in the Le Marais area so we had plenty of time to stroll the neighborhood. We came across a ton of boutiques, bars, art galleries, and eateries. We spend most of our time on rue des Francs-Bourgeois, rue des Archives and rue des Rosiers. These streets have a ton of fashionable stores and the streets get a ton of foot traffic is you want to just sit on a bench, enjoy coffee and a sandwich while people watching. There were also a ton of walk-up falafel eateries in this area.Marche des Enfants Rouge is in the Le Marais area and is a great place for food if you like the fresh food market scene.Some key attractions to visit are Hotel de Ville, Place des Vosges, Victor Hugo Mansion, Musee Carnavalet, Musee Picasso.

Sunday shopping. This neighborhood was recommended by our concierge for shopping on Sunday as most shops in the area are open. We were amazed at the number of shops and masses of people here on Sunday - definitely the day to go. For people watching and shopping opportunities for anyone.

My favourite arrondissement. This is,the place,to wander for a day to discover true Paris. stroll past the fashionable clothing stores along Rue de Rivoli near St. Paul metro station, stopping to admire the pastries in the patisserie. Go down Rue Veille du Temple, stopping as The Philosophers cafe for a coffee. Then continue down to Palais des Thes for an amazing choice of teas. Backtrack to Rue des Rosiers for a look at the jewellery and clothing shops as well as Jewish delis and boulangeries. Etc. etc.
Fascinating area. Centre of Jewish Paris, with so many kosher eating places. Mostly falafel and shwarma style, which were packed at Sunday lunchtime. Also where the Picasso Museum is located

Great Shopping. Get away from Paris's history for a little bit and blow some of your hard-earned money in its unique boutiques. Avoid the chain stores and explore the lesser-known one-of-a-kind stores. You (and your wife) will enjoy it immensely.

wonderful area. love this little neighborhood. good location to have good food, bar, and just hang around the area. it also is a good location to shop, especially if you love those small boutique more than shop in the big store or department stores.
Walk and explore. Spend a day wondering here with no destination in mind. It is full of wondrous and curious places, shops, cafes and parks.

Perfect base location. I rented a studio apartment for 5 weeks in the Marais district. Within walking distance are the Carnavalet Museum, Plas des Vosges, Picasso Museum, the Jewish Quarter, the Pompidou Center and much more. Getting "misplaced" along the colorful back streets where I discovered inviting cafes, quaint shops, multiple patisserias, and picture card photo ops all made this a perfect neighborhood for a long term stay.
Nice area. I was expecting something more traditional and romantic but is a really nice area with many bistros,restaurants and shops

Genuine peek into old Paris. Absolutely adored this part of Paris, this was a genuine peek back in time to old buildings and beautiful winding cobbled streets, littered with contemporary cafes, restaurants, shops and even clubs! We spent a lot of time here and enjoyed every second! At night it got a little awkward, with every single person begging us for money, however that's like any big city. Give Le Marais a go!

Put this on your list to do in Paris. This area may not be as popular as notre dame or latin quarter, but take time to go to Marais. It is very distinct area, very ethnic, and is the location for Place De Vosges. You get a different perspective of Paris and learn more of its history.

Best place to stay in Paris!. We absolutely loved staying in the Marais district, it is perfect for meandering the streets and visiting gorgeous little shops, back street cafes and fab hidden away restaurants. The general vibe of the area is friendly, relaxed and absolutely perfect for people watching whilst you're sat outside one of the many cafes enjoying a coffee or vino rouge! We visited several other areas on the Sunday and lots of the shops etc were shut but when we got back to our hotel in the Marais all the streets were buzzing and everything was open so clearly it caters for the evening crowd. Would definitely stay in this area again.

Stayed here for 2 Weeks. Loved this area. Stayed in an apartment just near Centre Pompadeau. Just walking up and down the narrow streets with all the cafes, restaurants, shops and buildings was a joy. At night time it comes alive even more.From where I stayed I could easily walk to many of Paris's sights. If I come back, this is where I will return.

Cosy area. With all the small and narrow streets this area is perfect for exploration. Small shops, bars and restaurants "everywhere". Be sure to bring a good map or that your phone is well charged. You will need that Google map because you will get lost in this area. For sure :DI'll recommend this area any time

Living like a local. I love visiting all the shops in this area because you get the sense that you aren't in all the tourist areas. I have improved my french by speaking with the locals and exploring the different and new little shops. This area always has something going on.

First time and probably last time. I had always wanted to visit Le Marais and finally got around to doing so this year. I guess that you might want to go if you have already visited Montremartre, Quartier Latin, or Saint Germain des Pres. For me it lacked the charm and uniqueness of the other regions.

Le Marais is a great place to stay for a Paris visit. We rented an apartment for 10 days in Paris on Rue Volta near the Arts et Metier Metro Stop. The Marais is a very old neighborhood with lots of restaurants, other metro stops, grocery stores, bars, and of course the nearby Arts et Metier Museum of Inventions and Mechanical devices. In addition, at #3 Rue Volta (right across from the Laundromat), is the oldest house in Paris according to different sources. It certainly looks it. By the way, do not go late to the laudromat. You'll want to start any laundry before 8PM as they close at 9PM. By the way, to save money and time, it would be quicker to wash your clothes in your apartment and carry them to the Laundromat to put them in the big industrial size dryers that cost 1 Euro for 8 minutes. Our clothes easily dried in 16 minutes. We walked all over the Marais and found many specialty shops including a wonderful Boulangerie-Patisserie across the street, a Monoprix that had really good prices on their food and cheap prices on Diet cokes (in the large Liter bottles), and Champagne for less than 3 Euros per bottle that was wonderful (brand was Montparnasse--just like the tall tower on the South side of France with the observation deck). There is a Carrefour grocery up the street, but we found that although the Monoprix was smaller, it seemed to have better prices and was easier to find stuff. But the Carrefour has all kinds of stuff including a basement with lots of stuff you might need for your apartment. The only caution is that we like to sleep with the windows slightly open if possible during the fall and early winter. We were able to do that as the weather was wonderful in early November, but with the bars and night life, there were several nights where it is obvious that a lot of people in Paris are night owls. Sometimes some inebriated Parisiens would come stumbling down the sidewalk singing in French or yelling in French. But after we realized that night life in Paris is not like the night life in our quiet neighborhood at home, we wore ear plugs and were able to sleep right through the party animals heading home from the bars. No, it didn't remind me of when I was young as I could never stay up but a few minutes after midnight! Musts be nice to be young and in Paris and have the money to go to some those places. One of the restaurants we checked out advertised a Cheeseburger with pomme frites (French fries) on their outdoor chalk board, but the price for this combo (without drink) was 26 Euros. So it must have either been one heck of a big hamburger or it is just the allure of eating American food that would make some one pay that much. The drinks were comparably priced, so it was out of our range. Besides, there are McDonald's in Paris and if you get desperate for a hamburger, you can always go to Mickey D's. No, we never went to one of the McDonald's in Paris, as there were too many restaurants with reasonable prices for local food that was great. Because the Marais is an older neighborhood and not really a touristy area, we never saw that many tourists, nor is there a McDonald's in the Marais (the Third Arrondisement). In some of the stores and restaurants, people spoke English, although our apartment owner did not speak much. So if you plan to stay in this area, you might want to brush up on your French or spend some time learning some of the most common French phrases you'll want to know. If you also need help, almost every young person you meet there is going to speak English. Although many older people don't speak English, most young people do and they are usually glad to have an opportunity to practice. Even the ones that are afraid of making mistakes will jump right into English if you try to ask a question with your French. At that point. Although you hear stories about how the people in Paris are rude, we never ran into a single rude person there. The Paris of old with the reputation for snooty people seems to have disappeared. Or maybe we just didn't go into any rich places where there might be snooty people. I will admit that my wife has a major in French and I've studied French for a year with a lot of emphasis on correct pronunciation of French and a several thousand word vocabulary (no, it's not bragging if it's a fact). That may have helped, but I'd encourage anyone who visits a foreign country to at least make sure they know the basic greetings and what is considered polite. Just as an example, anytime you enter any store in France, you always acknowledge the clerk and say Bonjour and they will acknowledge you and respond in kind. Never walk into a store and just walk by the clerk without greeting the clerk when you come in. That is considered rude on your part and you might be treated rudely even though you don't realize how rude you've been. A little preparation goes a long way if you want to put your best foot forward, which I would hope we all want to do when we are visiting foreign countries.
Fantastic area. Many cafes and restaurants ,shops,small and nice traditional streets with the best cafe CASSETTE with fantastic coffee and macarons

Really Old Paris. This part of Paris was in a very bad state up to the 60ies and 70ies. The famous baron Haussmann who changed the city in 19th century didn't have time to transforme completly Le Marais. Therefore you can find there lots of private mansions from 16,17and 18th centuries.. Some are museums, some banks, some others administration. It's good to stroll in the area which is not very big. The Carnavalet museum has beautiful section with the original interiors from the destroyed by Haussmann houses and couple of rooms with items from the French Revolution. In October , the Picasso Museum was reopened and it attracts the crowds. I like a more discret museum Cognacq-Jay with a beautiful collection of 18th century paintings in an old private mansion. If you are tired you will find there many nice small restaurants.Le Marais is also the only one part of Paris where the shops are open on Sundays

Favorite Arrondisement in Paris. This is our favorite area of Paris. I have stayed here twice. I rent an apartment and shop, dine out, see the sites. It is close to everything. It is relaxed enough, but also hip enough.

The best neighborhood in Paris!. A couple of steps away from Gare de Lyon station, close to Bastille and St Paul, you can start your visit from elegant place des Vosges and end it at Beaubourg. Best shopping and eating in Paris, a couple of museums (Carnavalet, Picasso), lively streets. A full day in Paris!
Nice and cosy markets. We spent a couple of hours walking through the area on a saturday. Had some wine at a cafe, and enjoyed looking at the people and variaty at the markets. Well worth a visit.

Authentic Paris. Haussman destroyed most of the older, medieval buildings in Paris to make his impressive, uniform structures you see today. So, the Marais is one of the few places to see some of the older architecture and get a feel for the winding, meandering, narrow streets of the past. Plus, there are great shops, cafes and sites.
great location. We stayed in the Marais and would go back there again. It has a great feel. Safe to walk around and great restaurants. Walking distance to lots of museums etc.

Le Marais - the place to stay. Close to so many of the parts of Paris that are good to visit. The buses - especially #69 (no joke) - take you to the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay, department stores, and a great way to see Paris.
Interesting neigborhood. Lots to see with lots of variety. The old Jewish quarter, hip restarants and lovely old buildings. The reopened Picasso is a must

a Parisian's Paris. Not always cheap, but always interesting. Restaurants, shops, art galleries, the Picasso Museum, the guiet Place de Vosges, and hidden corners like the Place de Sainte Catherine du Marais. The sidewalk cafes are a great place for people watching.

What a discovery. I was only in Paris for three days in total and visited here twice! I am not a shopper but I loved all the boutiques and the amazing atmosphere. Will be coming back with some money next time!

A must for strollers and shoppers. Such a cute area of Paris not to be missed! Unique boutiques make up nearly every street. It was a welcome relief of global chain stores! We aimlessly strolled up and down the streets and found little treasures. Also lots of cafes to stop in when your feet get tired. Dont miss this area of Paris.

Another sliver of Pariseine history.. Paris is a walking city with its many districts. The Marais definitely a visually interesting district. Take a private walking tour of you can (we booked Corey at Localers for this tour but they have many offerings and we also toured with Biance for the shopping district) as there is too much to see and miss unless you have seasoned companionship to guide you.

Our best food in Paris. We went to church on Sunday morning, which put us near the Pompidou Centre and Rue des Rosiers, a street that was supposedly famous for its Jewish food. So after church, we went to the Pompidou and took in the funky architecture and modern art (not my favorite). By then, we'd worked up a good appetite, and we made our way to the Rue des Rosiers. The whole street had the coolest vibe about it, with several falafel places vying for our custom. Each one had a sign proclaiming it as the best in Paris. We decided to try the one that didn't make that claim, because we admired their humility and honesty. Lo and behold, it really was the best falafel in Paris, or at least the best one we've ever had. I wish I knew the name of it. But it's one of the last ones on the left side of the street. I had the schwarma, which was amazing, and my wife and daughter had the falafel. We loved it so much, we went out of our way on a subsequent day to have them again. A word of warning: don't eat your falafels in front of the little Jewish bookshop on the side street, or you'll get an angry little grandma berating you in French while she pours water on the sidewalk and sweeps away your inevitable spills. We also enjoyed the Place des Vosges and the general sights around Le Marais. Fun part of Paris (as if there are any non-fun parts of Paris).

The place to be. La Marais is a neighborhood over by the Bastille so not quite immersed in tourist land. Benefits of this area are that you can find actual French restaurants (mostly off the main streets) not stuffed with tourists. Walk up to the shopping areas, there are open farmers markets on Thur and Sun which helped us save on food. Patissarie on the corner covered breakfast. Sat has the flea market up on the Temple Square. Get away from the Bastille and it gets a lot better. High end stored in near (but not on) Rue de Turenne, I think on Rue de Charlot. Housing in this area really made Paris fun.

The old and new side-by-side. Walking around La Marais district is a reminder of how the old (Ancient Paris' Jewish Quarter) can mix with the new Paris of upscale boutiques and restaurants. There are still plenty of reminders is the past, such as shops and food stands, but it's giving way slowly to modernity.
Trendy and traditional. Le Marais somehow manages to be very trendy and very historic and traditional at the same time. There is no in-between.
OFTEN OVERLOOKED. An oasis of calm. Many people are unaware of this quarter. Full of history and quite charming. as you would expect some very good restaurants to suit all budgets

Lovely area to wander around in. We spent a couple of hours here walking the streets and popping in to art galleries/shops. The staff were really friendly and helpful - even when they knew we weren't buying anything, but just interested in the artists.

The spirit of Paris. I stayed LE Marais,during my recent trip and could not have been in a more quaint and charming area! Everything was nearby, cafe's, markets, charming and reasonably priced boutiques. This is the Paris that you've read about!

Vibrant neighborhood. I stayed in the Marais for 7 days and loved every minute of it. My hotel was off the Rue Rivoli near St. Paul's Church and metro stop. Very centrally located in Paris. The neighborhood is young and hip. Plenty of restaurants and shops. It was very easy to get wherever I needed to go either by foot or via the metro. The neighborhood is quiet in the morning and picks up in the afternoon and is very active at night. Tons of bars and cafes open very late. I will definitely stay in this neighborhood when I return!

Place des Vosges and Picasso.. Breathtaking, elegant architecture in a beautiful square. Restaurants and Bars all around. The Picasso Museum is in a fine old mansion nearby, beautifully restored; the gallery is extensive over three floors, laid out in periods/styles of his life. Make the effort - it's worth it BUT pre-book or queue for ages!

Lots of history. was recommended to go here by a friend (who had been on a tour through the area). Lots of cool small stores. Lots of jewish history and food stores and bakeries. Picasso museum is in the area too.

Wonderful hideout. As a frequent visitor to Paris over the past decades, I rented an apartment in the Marais and felt as if I never had to leave this amazing little quarter of town. The area is alive with cafes, restaurants, bakeries, shops, boutiques, museums, etc... Happy Hour is found on every corner. There are some amazing Jewish bakeries and falafel eateries as well as fun bars and festive cafes. The location is as central as it gets and access to all metro lines. The streets are tiny and narrow so vehicle traffic is at a minimum. This is truly the place o be in Paris where there are very few hotels or tourists to be found.
the best area in paris. the marais full with nice stors , shops and restaurants just walk around ane loos your self in the small streets .spend at least half a day .
Lots of places to eat.. Loved the small streets and a great choice of restaurants to try. You must try falafel in pitta bread, its delicious, good for lunch.

A Poorly Appreciated Area of Paris. We've been to Paris many times and have stayed in various areas, but none better than our location on this trip. We stayed just north of the Centre Pompidou on the edge of the Marais. The museums, the restaurants and the shopping in this area are all terrific and the narrow streets give the place a feeling of a more authentic, earlier Paris. This is truly a central location with a number of metro stations providing access to the rest of the city.

great 'neighborhood' to wander around. This arrondissement continues to charm us, even with some 'big name' stores in place. Everyone is friendly, and it is quite easy to find delicious food and wine! Felafel is famous in this area... we even had a drink at the same spot twice (great corner, great people watching) and can't remember the name.

The place to be on a Sunday!. Le Marais is buzzing on Sundays as it's the place to be. The shops are open and there are so many cool boutiques although they're not cheap so may be best to shop here when it's the sales! You have all the trendy boutiques there as well as some sale shops too. Rue des Rosiers is the street with the falafal shops and Jewish bakeries. So you can re-energise as you stroll around the area. Highly recommended place to visit if you've done all the sights in Paris.

Too obvious to give it a title.... The Marais area in Paris is a treasure chest right at the heart of the city. It features many of the most exquisite properties in the city centre, and is an intrinsic part of the town's history. You will never have enough time to see it all at once !

Great little area.. Was a busy area, but lovely to see, id say its all about the specialist food you can purchase here, we ate from a little falafel place, and it was one of the best snacks i had in Paris.Lots of cool people, milling around, great to people watch,

Serious and Fun. This section of Paris used to be populated by the Jews of the city. So, go for the serious stuff - the history of Jews in Paris. The Shoah Memorial, the synagogues, the food. Now it's primarily populated by the LGBT population, and let me tell you - the stores are FANTASTIC. I broke the bank in Le Marais. All shop keepers speak English well enough to be helpful, and incredibly friendly.

Compact. Le Marais is a lot of things for such a compact place. Being the Jewish Quarter, there's a heavy presence of vegetarian and kosher restaurants that are open well into the afternoon. At night, the place transforms into a mostly gay district, where dive bars and gay/lesbian clubs are abound. BHV and many smaller stores, both retail and specialty, can also be found here.Centre Pompidou and Les Forum Des Halles are both a 5 minute walk away.Although local crowds frequent this area throughout the year so it's never quiet, most tourists are gone by mid to late October.
The Best Quarter in Paris. my favorite quarter....no mass shopping, but rather the most wonderful little shops with local products. and, the BEST coffee at the cafe-o-thek.

Shoppers paradise. Visited after 4 years and was sad to see that it resembled an open air shopping mall. Used to have more flavour and was less commercial and special. But if shopping and delicious falafels are your thing, then don't miss Le Marais.

YOU MUST. Easily the best place in Paris- I would definitely try and stay here if I came again. Amazing food, some really funny bars- we went to La Perle and met some very interesting characters who took us on to Raid Bar- don't ask!- but the point is that this place is fun and felt quite safe.
Great for a Walk. There is so much to see here, from place vosges, to the fashion shops, bars, restaurants and musuems. It is very busy on Sundays.
Stay here!. Beautiful Parisian neighborhood. Excellent food and within walking distance of many Paris sites - Notre Dame, Picasso museum, St. Pauls.
Quirky Chic in Paris. If you like Greenwich Village in NYC, Brera in Milan, or Covent Garden in London, then you will love the streets and shops and restaurants in Le Marais.

2nd time in Paris. This is a neighborhood that first time tourists dont have enough time to go! But it's very nice there. I would reccomend to go on Sundays, because as everything is closed, there they have some restaurants and some stores keep open!

fun. What a place, there's everything here, various take-aways, restaurants,coffe shops locals and well mostly tourists. One interesting thing about this place was the amount of second hand clothes shops. You could buy anything by the kilo. It can get quet crowded especailly during the weekend.

Wow. What an area. The Marais has become THE area to visit in Paris though you will have to fight with the crowds of locals who flock to the area at the weekend. Full of wonderful boutiques, cafes, restaurants and bistros.

Beautiful Area. This is a great area to stay, eat, people watch, and wander. We stayed here, and found a number of nice cafes and restaurants in the area that were very welcoming. The other plus is the Jewish Quarter has all their shops open on Sunday when many stores are closed or start their day very late. A good choice to eat or stay.

Great walking area in Paris. This is a walker-friendly sector of the city, plenty to see in one of the most historic areas. Whether for an opportunity to sit and contemplate Parisian life over centuries or to chat over a coffee in one of many cafes, this is a relaxing venue.
Wonderful neighborhood. We enjoyed all the shops and activty here. A Paris Greeter gave us a 3 hr architectural tour in little nooks and crannies that we would have never noticed.

Stay in the Marais. This is one of my favourite parts of Paris and I try to rent an apartment when I stay here (as I am now doing for the month of November).The Marais is an eclectic mix of cultures - you have the Jewish quarter, the gay quarter, artists and a bar scene that makes it an exciting place to stay with something always going on.I am near the Village of Saint Paul which has great markets on a monthly basis, there are twice weekly produce markets as well to keep the cupboards stocked.You are close to Place des Vosges - a wonderful square to sit and read a book on a lazy afternoon. There are some great cafés / bars here including Rivolux on the rue de Rivoli.You are spoilt for choice with cheese shops, bakers, patisseries, restaurants, wine shops and of course the famous tea house Marriages Freres. If you wandered down rue des Rosiers you will also find long queues for the best falafels ever.Lovely area of Paris with many nooks and crannies to explore - one thing not to miss is to go to rue de Cloche Perche and see one of the last remaining 14th century buildings still standing - gorgeous piece of history tucked in a little corner.There is also a jeweler located there and many fab gifts will be found inside, including some quite clever watches.
Paris family trip. This is a very quaint neighborhood with lots of shopping. There are name brand store and one offs, Lots of pastry and goodie shops. We even stumbled into an old dry goods stores.

Shoppers' Paradise. It's gotten a bit over-crowded. It's now host to more than a few chainstores. Getting in anywhere without a reservation has become something of a challenge. But Le Marais--the oldest section of Paris--is a must-go destination for anyone but especially style-hunting shoppers with its narrow winding streets filled with chic boutiques and plenty of cafes and restaurants to keep your energy up. Make a day of it. Meander a bit and get lost. Stop for coffee and blinis on the Rue des Rosiers (home to the historical Jewish quarter). Shop some more. Get lost again. Stop for wine. Shop some more. Repeat.

Perfect combinations of shopping and Parisian atmosphere…. We went there the past weekend, and it was amazing as always. All shops are open on Sunday (which it is still pretty rare in Paris), there were Christmas lights, music on the street, and some streets were closed to traffic. Awesome! We love everything of that area, and go back every time. Of course we stopped by Place de Voges.. beautiful!
Beautiful Area. Its a very nice area to stay in. Loads of restaurants and full of hustle bustle. Close to a couple of metro stations. Its paradise for food lovers. Very safe area as well.
It's what you think of when you think of Paris. Le Marais is by far one of the best areas in Paris. The shopping there is still local, and the food is amazing in the old Jewish corridor.
Great!. We loved walking around this part of the city. Great stores, incredible little restaurants make this area a great find.

The Marais - Best Neighborhood To Stay in Paris. I've been to Paris many times, but this was my first time staying in the Marais. Renting an apartment here and being part of the local scene was so much fun. Vibrant, picturesque, charming, filled with restaurants, cafes, boutiques, museums, and walking distance to nearly everything the city. My new favorite place to stay in Paris. After two weeks around Paris we agreed there was no other neighborhood we would rather have stayed.
Excellent street art. Some great street art in this area if you are into that sort of thing. Lots of falafel places and also nice jewellry.

Great place to wander and shop.. The Marais was just a great place to wander the streets, shop, and take in the feel of Paris. Lots of great restaurants and sidewalk cafes. Be sure to take in the Jewish district also.

Worth a visit any day.. A most interesting place to visit on a Sunday where the streets are pedestrianized until 6pm. This is the old Jewish quarter, and many orthodox Jews and rabbis were about. We saw a very long queue for falafel at a restaurant window. Must be good, but we did not join the queue. Photographers would love this place. The streets were crowded and our French friend constantly reminded us to be careful about our handbags.There was a jazz band busking nearby opposite the exhibition hall, and this added to the festive atmosphere on a Sunday.Many shops were open and it was fun wandering in and out of those, looking at what we may want to buy.

Don't miss it!. Not far from the metro, the Marais is the old Jewish section of Paris which has become trendy. Start by seeing the Palaces Des Vosges in the oldest square in Paris. From there work your way over to Rue des Rosiers for a little shopping of the latest Paris trends without the high prices. Don't miss having lunch at L'as du Fallafel. The lines can be long, but they move quickly. Some shops are closed on Saturday, Sunday is best.

One of my favorite places in Paris. I felt like I was transported back in time, walking through the streets of the Marais. It felt almost medieval, and exactly what I was searching for history-wise. I loved learning about the history and culture, and how the neighborhood has changed over the years. Looking forward to visiting it again!

Rent an apartment here and enjoy Paris. We spent a week in Marais in late August. Having rented an apartment just off the Rue de Tureen we were able to see Le Marais on a daily basis without the hustle and bustle of the usual tourist areas. The district is very historical and with ample shopping and restaurant opportunities it opened my eyes up to a more enjoyable, laid back Paris. We had easy access to the Metro and being reasonable centralized could walk to a lot of the main areas of Paris, if we so chose. I was pleasantly surprised at the friendliness of the locals and the courtesy most of the drivers seemed to show each other.
Loved the streets!. I loved the tiny streets of Le Marais, I went there to eat Shawarma at the jewish restaurants, which by the way was amazing! Had a great time discovering and shopping.

A must see for shopping!. Wonderful neighborhood. lots of shops and restaurants and the real feel of Paris. Be ready to play hockey and football and dodgeball walking down the streets. They can get narrow and they are not made flat or straight. The folks don't like moving over for you especially if you are a couple. It is a great place.

Not just the place of Falafel eaters!. I live in the Marais and I see thousands of visitors coming and wasting their time waiting to get their Falafel and that's all! No, Marais isn't just about Falafel. It's about the history, about the art and about the culture.
Trendy. L'as du Falafel Experience the freshest sandwich in the trendy Marais district off the beaten track shops with eclectic items

Very trendy shops. Great little streets, shops lovely fab bars and restaurants queues for falafel bars , smelt amazing. Definitely worth a visit . Book Picasso musuem as it was an 1 and half hour wait
Very nice neighbourhood!. We managed to walk through many nice markets and enjoyed the neighbourhood totally. Will definitely go back next time.

What a quaint place to browse!. I hadn't been to Le Marais in previous trips to Paris, as I tried to squeeze in all the 'mandatory' sights, but this trip, I felt so much more a part of Paris as I browsed Place des Vosges, Rue des Rosiers, Rue des Francs Bourgeous - marvelous atmosphere - well worth a wander.
Marais is loosing its originality. Too many global brand names which normally are in the big Malls in USA and UK are moving into the Marais. The authentic village feel is getting lost, very sad.

Where the Locals Hang. The Marais is exactly where you want to go to experience Paris like a true Parisian. We rented an amazing flat off Airbnb and spent 2 incredible weeks here.The cobbled streets, the bakeries and shopping boutiques were truly spectacular. Hundreds of restaurants to choose from -- from regional French, to crepes and gelato, to Italian.You MUST go to L’As du Fallafel. Honestly, the best falafel I have ever had. The line around the block goes quick.

Marais, c'est Paris!. Le Marais, for me, it is the best neighborhood one can find in Paris!! There, you can find e eyrhing you look for, and everyjting you are not!! It's the heart of Paris: you find yourself at home, the coziest restaurants to the oddest ones!!! Art galleries, parisian people, delicious bistrôts and brasseries.....everything you dream in just one place!
Beautiful district. Tons of parks, restaurants, and cafés line the streets in the Marsus district. Kids play soccer on the streets at night and older men play games in neighborhood parks.
Lived here. We lived around the area Republique which is near marais. wonderful cafés and there is a good breakfast restaurant named Allens Market where we ate Texas Scrambled Eggs a lot. Delicious!

Disappointing Other Than Places de Vosges. We visited this area of the city twenty hears ago. Place de Vosges is worth seeing with its covered walks and park, with some cafes. Otherwise, as we walked around and through it over to the Les Halles area (really disappointing), we conclded that it had lost a lot of its former charm. Unless you are visiting the Picasso Museum, not worth spending a lot of time there in our view.
Medieval and Jewish Paris. Museums ,Restaurants ,Medieval streets and buildings ,Fashion boutiques ,Le Marais has it all . Make sure you walk around Vosges
A great place to explore.. Walk around and explore the Marais. You will stumbled upon some Paris treats like Victor Hugo's house and Place Des Vosges.

Morning stroll through Le Marais. We followed Framers 'Walking Tour 3' (see http://www.frommers.com/destinations/paris/658468#sthash.RRxa52cs.dpbs) through Le Marais. Having both been to Paris before this time we wanted to try out the less obvious tourist spots. The tour starts off at Hotel de Ville the facade of which is decorated with 378 works by 230 sculptors, including Rodin.Highlights included:- Eglise St-Gervais-St-Protais which is beautifully gothic in style. It's immense and I was in awe of the people who built it.- No. 11 and no. 13 rue Francois Miron are two half-timbered houses that were built in the 14th century. - Hôtel de Sens - One of the hôtel's most famous residents was Marguerite de Valois, whose life inspired Alexandre Dumas's 1845 novel La Reine Margot. It looks like something out of Harry Potter but is now home to the Bibliotheque Forney which is open to the public (in the afternoons). - Hôtel de Sully - the interior is not open to the public but it's courtyards are. It is beautiful and reminded me of a mini Versailles. There is an exit at the north-east of the gardens (2nd courtyard) which is a short cut to the beautiful Place des Vosges, where Victor Hugo once lived.- Rue des Rosiers - famous for its delicious falafel I would highly recommend this tour and do stop off for some falafels!

Cool area. Go there , worth a couple of days , good museums although check when the Picasso is re - opening Great shops and a fabulous young vibe about the placeOne of my most favourite parts of paris

I Need More Time!. Planned a Sunday in September in the Marais after 12:00. Headed first to the infamous Falaffel restaurant and stood in line to then take a seat inside. Terrific. The vine of the neighborhood, a burst of energy, the galleries around the square.... just so much history to absorb. I must plan better next time and give two full days to that part of my exploring Paris. And....great shopping!

Eye-opener. We did a walking tour. It was great and very informative. Didn't realise what went on in Paris, and learnt a lot more at this time. It has old and new of everything, and the history is told in words as you look at the streets and buildings. Definately worth a look.

Lively and super chic. lots of people, restaurants bursting on to the pavements, boutique shops and vintage stores - but everything too expensive to buy. unique items. cool people. narrow streets. You can walk to the Pompedou and Notre Dame from this area.

Walking tour. We took a walking tour of the Marais and loved the guide !we have been down there many times because we stay close by on the I'lle St Louis .the area is rich with history. Victor Hugo's house is also there in the big square

UP AND COMING - UP AND ARRIVED!. A changed area from a decade and more ago - now with lots of good restaurants and cafes with very affordable prices as well as good 'boutique' hotels. Interesting local life which makes strolling through the area an absolute delight - not the centre of the city but an interesting place to spend a week and plenty to do and see, as always I recommend taking an apartment.

The best place in Paris. According to me, "le Marais" is the best and the most beautiful place in Paris ! Famous thanks to the movie rabbi Jacob with Louis de funes this district is the most representative of the Parisian way of life and fashion. it's also a great place for shopping and for buying trend clothes :) But also to visit the carnavalet museum !
trendy hotspot for good food & shopping. trendy hotspot for good food & shopping. visit chez marianne for kosher food : the falafel is gorgeous ! visit the re-opened national museum of Picasso

Gay Paree!. This area had many restaurants, shops, art galleries. And I had the Beef bourguignon from Les Philosophes here. We passed by many gay clubs, cafes, and other establishments. Certainly a bustling nightlife!

Still exhibits another side of Paris. Le Marais is the Jewish section of Paris. It is also the artistic hub of the city. The area has many theaters, restaurants, jazz clubs and other entertainment to entice the visitor.

Stall Shopping. We went for the markets, got some nice atypical souvenirs to take home. Also, I love to bake and the Marais has a plethora of shops for the professional baker. As an amateur, I felt like a kid in a candy shop. There is two tier pricing, so you can expect to pay the higher price if you are not a professional.
Saturday afternoon walk. Wonderful, as always, it is a fantastic part of Paris with small shops, art galleries but there were too many people

A Historic Delight. Place des Vosges is one of the most beautiful squares in the world. Red brick colonnaded houses, all in the same style surround a beautiful public garden.Rue Saint Paul nearby, towards the Seine over the Rue de Rivoli, has lots of antique shops and Village Saint Paul - a series of yards off Rue Saint Paul - also has lots of interesting poster, clothing & antique shops to explore. Rue des Francs Bourgeois at the top of Place des Vosges, is full of interesting clothing shops.
Great shopping and falafel!. Well worth a visit! Shopping was very varied and not all too expensive. Also great cake shops and falafel take away
great district to stay in. Lots of shops, great bars and restaurants, good apartments and hotels, plus very central.. who could ask for more !
Great Neighborhood. We did the Rick Steves Marais neighborhood walk and very much enjoyed. It included a picnic lunch in the Place des Vosges and a visit to the Carnavalet Museum and Pompidou Center.

We loved this neighborhood. A great area to stroll in, shop, have dinner or a drink! We enjoyed ourselves immensely exploring the narrow winding streets and little shops. The Parisians were friendly and helpful, and we had a great time.

Everything you need. Go to BVH store.Lunch at 5th floor of BHV store.Nice streets.Nice Jewish area,Gay happy hour very good all over.Avoid school vacation, to much people aroundGo to the book store Les Mots a la Bouch, very nice gay material.Do not take the train RER during rush hour.Do everything else such as Tower, Louvre, etc

Charming old world Paris. If you can look past the souvenir hawkers, this is a really charming part of Paris and you can easily imagine it in the days of Toulouse Lautrec and the Belle Epoc. There are lots of charming little streets with quaint architecture and getting lost among them is a treat for the senses. The jewel in the crown however is Sacre Couer and it is worth the trip up the hill just to visit this beautiful church and wonder at the views of Paris from it's steps.

Flaner's top. Bobo's best location in the ville, loose yourself in this chic village's narrow street, wandering in fashion boutiques, design hotspot, cafe de tea and hip Bistrot. Make sure to be blasé comme il faut!
sunday shopping in Paris. Much of Paris seems to close down on Sundays. Not so Le Marais. Its a hive of activity and for those who like some retail therapy, the shops are open.
Coo vibe. Old Jewish quarter,now favorite of the Gay community and young trendies.Nice shops and restaurants,just across the river from the Latin Quarter.Good to walk around.

The Fantastic Marais. There are quite a number of small museums here that are very interesting.I love the way the area has to a part; escaped the drawing board look the rest of Paris has. Love it I do, but the Marais has a more natural look about it.

Stayed in this trendy part of Paris. We rented an apartment though special apartments. Although we were without a phone and internet service they did compensate us for the inconvenience. If you want to live like a Parisian this is a great place. Local markets, small cafés, and restaurants. This is away form the touristy areas. Quieter and very french. We loved it.
The "Real" Paris. Allow yourself an afternoon to stroll these streets for "local" apparel shops and bistros. You'll feel like a real Parisian!
Love the Marais. Love this area of Paris. Try to stay here often. Just fun walkingthe streets and window shopping. Food really good here, love street food here, especially the falafel!
Full of charm. The old quartes was renovated several years ago and is now hip and trendy with a lot of beautiful boutiques, aet gallerise, restaurant. Great to walk in the narrow streets.

Marais, to walk your streets is heaven!. Long the aristocratic district of Paris, it hosts many outstanding buildings of historic and architectural importance. It spreads across parts of the 3rd and 4th arrondissements in Paris (on the Rive Droite, or Right Bank, of the Seine) Walk the streets, spend some time over coffee in the Place des Vosges.
Touristy. The Marais has lost a lot of its charme since it's all about tourism and commercialism. Expensive shops and cafés, hardly anything local.

love it, love it, love it. Aside from my favorite little park, Place de Vosges, the Marais is an area with such character, great museums, fantastic shops and restaurants. Street entertainers were around every corner. A great place to shop and eat on Sunday when many other areas are quiet.

Loved this area of Paris. This little area of Paris had me running in circles. I would head out from the hotel and get lost right away. Fortunately there are signs everywhere redirecting me to where I wanted to be. I found every recommended bistro, but not always when I was looking for them. I did find the best crepes, the best coffee, the best chocolates, and the best boulangerie, though, and never went without a fab. meal.

Former gay district still good for a visit. Although the gay bars, strange boutiques and bric-a-brac stores left or moved to the fringe of the area with the Beaubourg Le Marais stays a nice place to stay and wander those small streets. Of course it still has some great museums to visit like the Victor Hugo house, The Picasso museum and more. But the district lost some of its true charm to designer chain stores, prices in the bars that doubled and American students doing the 'look how bohemian I am' - routine.

always fun to hang out. I just love wandering around in the Place de Vosges and the surrounding area. While there are plenty of chain stores around there are so many cool little independent places it just a wonderful place that you can ramble and enjoy!

If you want to experience an authentic neighborhood... Go to Le Marais! We were lucky enough to stay in the neighborhood, and it was better than we expected. Take the metro (1) to St Paul, and have a walk around, a coffee or a glass of wine. The cafes and bistros aren't as packed as in other locations.

Fantastic stay in Le Marais. Just spent 6 days in Paris, our 1st trip and we were so pleased that we chose to rent an apartment in Le Marais. There are so many lovely shops, restaurants, beautiful buildings and things to do in the area and nearby. We walked to The Bastille market on the sunday (amazing), Notre Dame, The Latin Quarter, along the Seine. We would definitely stay in Le Marais next time we go back to Paris :)
place des vosges ouhh. great place qwith luxury art shopping, restaurants, luxury cafés, lots of trees, I recommend it to everyone in Paris

Just so great.. So pretty (Place des Vosges). Such great restaurants (l'as des falafels, blue crepe bar (?)). Such good vintage shops. Liked being in the Jewish quarter. Thought the Musee Carnavalet was good (but disappointed that the section on Revolution was closed. Guide book suggested 'trendy' - well, not sure about that...but it was less chi-chi and more diverse than some parts of Paris.
Take a Walking Tour. They close the streets off to traffic on Sundays. Go on Sunday and take the Walking Tour. You can find it on line. I think Rick Steve's recommends the Walking Tour.

crowds and shopping on sunday. Visit on sunday : OK if you like watching people or window shopping (open on sunday - a good thing ?) and like eating snacks. Lively atmosphere. Place des Vosges is a must see.
Amazing boutiques. A beautiful hip area in Paris. I loved strolling the streets of Le Marais and the shopping was incredible too. Next time I am in Paris I want to stay in this area
Best. Best place! Best ambiance! Best choices of food! Really a must! The mixture of cultured is really impressing!

Just enjoy getting lost. Combination of old and new, lovely little shops , good restaurantsHistory: Jewish and french, , pay a visit to 2 free museums : carnavalet and victor hugo,Soon piccaso will reopen too

Le Marais reminds me of the Castro in San Francisco. Interesting neighborhood - lots of gay bars. Close to Hotel de Ville and Notre Dame. Would stay again but make sure your hotel has good sound proofing!
Good place for a meal. Good place to try something unique. There are many isreali restaurants in the area and they are rather good.
Noisy. We rented an apartment here, 95 steps up! Ugh. Very historic and "French" but the close quarters make it noisy and a little dirty in some places.

A Very Nice Historic part of Paris. Le Marais is a well preserved historic part of Paris,of residences where the aristocrats and upper class people use to live. All the residences face square which is nicely landscaped with trees and gardens. The gardens are unique as they have both flowers and vegetables together incorporated in the a sculptured landscape.The architecture is very well defined and beautiful. The home of author Victor Hugo, is an musem which is open to the public. It displays not only his rooms, and work areas but also those of his wife, both are unique.

Cool. Stayed at neighborhood hotel. We ate most dinners in the Marais. After checking most of the 3 stars I think it was avoid choice. Be careful venturing far from the monument at night. Stroll through Les Vogues and relax at cafe. Lots of night life take the metro to Bastille

Boa caminhada | A nice walk. É uma região muito gostosa de se caminhar, passear, fazer compras, comer falafel ou achar alguma feirinha ou brechó para fuçar! Aproveite para se perder. Se não gostar de muita gente, evite os fins de semana.---It's a very nice region to walk around, buy clothes, eat falafel or even find some cute little street fair or thrift shop to tweak. Take some time to get lost in these streets. If you're not a crowd fan, avoid the weekend.

Interesting area with good restaurants.. We took the walking tour of Marais with Discovery Walks which enabled us to learn about the area and discover "hidden" courtyards and gardens along the way. Worth a visit.

Always entertains. Rue des Rosiers may be the central of any visit through the many streets and shops in the Marais. Much personality and blending of cultures. Grab a falafel 'emporter' (to go). I like "mi-va-mi" (Rue des Rosiers x Rue des Ecouffes). The building is red. Eat your falafel as you walk or carry it to Square George Cain and sit on a bench while surrounded by beautiful old stone building art (go toward Place des Vosges, turn left at Rue Pavée, cross Rue des Francs Bourgeois where Rue Pavée becomes Rue Payenne and stop in Square George Cain)Backtracking to Rue des Rosiers, there is some nice shopping that is not your usual American chains. I like IKKS. It's fun. Relax. Enjoy walk is a shop you might never think you would go in.
Le Marais. Charming and the oldest part of Paris. Bohemian and full of quaint roads and shops and wonderful buskers.

What a neighboorhood. This is the pretty calm neighboorhood of Paris where history is mixing with modernity and fashion ! Artists seems to love this place . Thanks to our private tour guide , we had an awesome evening in this lovely side of Paris

Another favorite Neighborhood in Paris. Le Marais is another wonderful part of this wonderful city. This is where you will find narrow streets, chic shops, wonderful cafes, great museums, beautiful squares, great galleries, and the remaining old mansions of the wealthy Parisians of long ago. It is intact and historic in ways that other parts of Paris are not. This is a section for wandering enjoying all the little jewels that walking a truly great city allows. If you love Paris you have to spend some time getting lost in Le Marais. You will eventually find your way back to something that you know.
A must Go!!!. Trendy and very flamboyant! This neighbourhood of Paris is a must go and see, check a bar or a restaurant and sit for a drink or even dinner, absolutely gorgeous!
Nice neighboorhood. It is the kind of neighboorhood you cant miss in Paris , with its lovely streets and small shops ! anything to remember the good old paris is in there !

Fun and Interesting Place. Went there on late Sunday afternoon to dinner time. Wow this is a fun place to go. Stores , restaurants, bars, etc are open on Sundays. It has a very relaxed and casual atmosphere. Except for some bikers who got upset because the streets are crowded, didn't bother us at all. Paris streets are so narrow anyway. Don't miss this place when you are in Paris

Always a good choice. Another day in Paris and you don't know what to do? A walk at the marais is a perect idea.
Grab a cup of hot coffee and a croissant and wander around for some good people-watching.

Good for museums, little shops and just strolling around. We went to the Marais for the main purpose of going to the Musee Carnavalet. After getting off at the Metro stop is St. Paul, we followed the signs to the museum. Along the way, there were little shops, some of them of familiar chains. The neighborhood is more quiet and less crowded than other areas favored by tourists. There are many lovely buildings. We had lunch at a cafe after visiting Carnavalet. We enjoyed meandering through the streets with more interesting shops- a photo gallery, a shop for notions, a store with second hand bric a brac. Place des Vosges, where the home of Victor Hugo is, was our next stop. After the Maison de Photographie, we finally left. It was an enjoyable day for us. Other visitors to Paris should explore this area.

Open on Sunday. If you have nothing to do on Sunday, try shopping and people watching in the Marais and the close by Jewish quarter. I truly enjoyed, to my surprise, a ten-minute massage on the street. My franglais discussion with a helpful salesperson in l'Occitane was a perfect relaxed entry into shopping. Don't miss the UniQlo

What's not to love?. We rented an apartment in the Marias for the entire month of September. We had an absolutely marvelous time and highly recommend the Marais for a short or long term stay. Everything is here and what isn't here is easily reached by a short Metro ride. One could, if one was so inclined, never leave the Marais and have a spectacular vacation!

Where I'd live if I lived in Paris. The Marais was ideal for our home base. It was easy access to everything we wanted either by bus or metro. It was a comfortable neighborhood with great bistros and cafes.

Shops and streets to discover. If you enjoy the back streets, the twists and turns, the new restaurants and shops ... get to Le Marais. It's easy to find on the Metro, near Notre Dame and the low-numbered Arrondisements. The streets really do twist and turn. The variety of button shops (from a manufacturing era) to chic boutiques keeps the place interesting at every turn. History of the Knights Templar fill the area, small museums, historic author's homes, and much more. You must go ... and discover!

A favorite. The narrow streets and charming stores make this one of my favorite neighborhoods to stroll in. The Place de Vosges has such great history. We picnicon a bench here and then stroll thru the fine art galleries nearby

Wonderful Neighborhood. Our apartment rental in the Marais was just delightful. We were within minutes of an award winning croissant bakery, a wonderful chocolatier, 3 or 4 super restaurants and very convenient Metro access. Quiet, safe, historic, vibrating foodie scene, great location with walking to the Pompidou and Picasso and half hour rides to almost everything else in Paris on the Metro. Wonderful location and neighborhood

A Savory Blend of Past and Present. On our last full day in Paris during a recent trip, my wife and I were pleased that we took the time to visit Le Marais for a good part of the day. Even after visiting a number of the wonderfully restored historic mansions and sampling the wares of various retail stores, we were surprised to see how extensive Le Marais is. Plan for a full day there, as there's dozens of attractive sites and shops to explore.

Favorite area in Paris. Beautiful, historic and quiet neighborhood in Paris. Very trendy art galleries antique shops and boutiques as well as a few museums are located here - most notably, the Picasso and Paris Historical museums. Some of our favorite food in Paris due largely to the Jewish bakeries and falafel places. Great departure from the rest of Paris. Much of this neighborhood still feels as though it is authentically tied to its roots.
Wonderful Neighborhood. So many streets to explore; so many wonderful bistros; so many shops and such good people watching. Spend a meal or a day, or many enjoying.

Wonderful day of wandering streets. Did an amazing tour with Richard from Eye Prefer Paris
Secret gardens Lovelly sqaures quaint streets teaming with History Romance and Mystery Love this area of Paris

Superb. Great place for walking, shopping, having fun and chilling out . Nice bars and restaurant. Small Parisian cafes and narrow streets. Shops are open on Sundays. All shops and boutieques are perfect. Nice galleries . Every person will find something interesting in Marais area!

Touristing heaven. Having just spent 10 nights in this area, I can't believe there could be a better location for a tourist in all of Paris to rent an apartment. Everything you need is just outside your door. Transport, supermarkets, restaurants, cafes, shopping, street markets, culture, beauty, history … the list goes on. We stayed just off Rue de Rivoli and were only a few minutes walk from all of the major attractions, but were far enough away to feel like it was a night time haven. We truly felt as if we were part of the community, and I would never consider staying anywhere else during a stay in Paris.

Free walking tours. There are several free walking tours in various areas of the city guided by young adults wearing pink vests. We took the one in the Marais which lasted about 2 hours and took us from the meeting point through various parks and small streets which we would have otherwise missed. Historical and architectural highlights were pointed out. Of course, we went by the famous falafel and pastry shops which we returned to subsequently. At one point two of the group made a wrong turn and the guide went back and found them. The guides earn their wages by tips, left up to the individual walking group members.

Best quarter in Paris. Le Marais is one of Paris's quarters but it is the best one. Narrow streets, little shops, tippical cafes good restaurants and fallafel. Very buesy all dai till late night. In the quarter some good museums and beautiful cathedral. Don't miss.

A great place for a stroll. We really enjoyed a leisurely Sunday stroll through this fascinating area. Street musicians provided entertainment as we stolled and there were interesting museums to see, speciality shops to browse in and a good choice of restaurants for those wanting to dine.

Great market area. Very cool area, lots of trendy eateries, bars and cafes. Maybe stay away from all the italian joints (all over Paris really) that aren't run by Italians and are on the corners usually just luring tourists

A fascinating beautiful neighborhood. A visit to the Marais is like walking back into the 16th & 17th centuries.A fabulous restoration program about 50 years ago has preserved this area which has some of the oldest buildings in Paris.

A lovely area to stay (and shop)!. This is the first time we stayed in Les Marais on our 5-day visit, and we loved exploring this wonderful part of the city. There are literally hundreds of cafés and shops, all within walking distance of the St-Paul métro. My favourite place? Place des Vosges.

nice. nice area to walk around
a lot of historical buildings and monuments
liberal and interesting restaurants, hotels, bars

A bit disappointed in the Marais. I'm not sure what I was expecting; this is known as the Jewish section of Paris but it wasn't obvious. There were quite a few lovely galleries, but museums were all closed the day we visited.
Fashion and Restaurants. Start at the Place Des Voges, Paris greatest residential square from the 17thC, go on to dine at Boffingers, traditional Belle Epoque brasserie, be sure to book.

Wonderful Parisian experience!. We were in Paris late September 2014 and stayed in the Marais district. What a FABULOUS location! Neither my husband or I had stayed in that part of the city before, and what a wonderful surprise it was! Our hotel was conveniently located near the Hotel De Ville, the Seine River, restaurants, taxi cab access, the Metro, shopping, Centre Pompidou 5 minutes to the Notre Dame, etc. There is so much life, charm, character, and more in this area- and we were so very happy we stayed here. We spent many afternoons strolling along the streets, shopping and soaking everything in. I would high;ly recommend staying in the Marais!

Unique, Eclectic, Diverse Shopping and Food. I love going to the Marais. It's the most eclectic, interesting exotic area of central Paris. Its the Jewish Quarter, so many shops are closed on Saturday, but other days, especially Sundays are a blast. The place is packed on Sunday with folks enjoying falafels, ice cream, ethnic foods, cool unique stores and a really diverse crowd. You gotta go to La Falafel, but there is much more.

The best spot in paris. This is the only spot in Paris that all the shops are open on sundays. There are lots of pretty boutique, nice cafe's and art galeries. İf you like walking around you will see lots of beautiful, narrow streets full of nice people...
great area. Friendly atmosphere, great restaurants. Great place to stay close to the center of Paris yet fairly quiet.

Place Des Vosges. We didn't fully explore the Marais District, but what we saw of it left a great impression. Be sure to visit Place Des Vosges, which is a tranquil spot in the middle of a busy city. The art shops are spectacular, we so enjoyed "licking the windows" (the French term for window shopping) and seeing the creative work of local artists.
Great restaurants and shopping. Stroll around by Place des Vosges and the Musee Carnavelet - there's so much to see. Lots of hip shopping and little corner restaurants and squares. Not to be missed.

Check out both the 3rd and 4th Arrondissements. You can't check out all of the Marais in one visit. There's so much to see. It's not just the Place des Vosges. Visit the Carnavalet museum, walk all the little streets, Stop for a drink or lunch. Soak up the history. Templar Knights? Marche des Rouges Enfants? Rue St. Paul. Research all the little cafes and bistrots. Return again and again.

A different side of Paris. This is so different to the rest of Paris - well worth a visit. Narrow streets, Jewish traditions thriving in your presence, lovely cafes and shops and the most famous falafel shop!

Best place for walking. Compared to other areas, this seems the best place for just walking around, admiring the streets and buildings (almost all are old) and you get interesting shops and arcades everywhere plus brasseries on every corner. Good place to stay but if you don't stay there, it's well worth a visit just to soak up the Parisian atmosphere. Seems safe at night too.

Great Area. Loved the interesting narrow streets, lots on different shops. Stopped at Sacha Finklestein's to buy some cheesecake, couldn't believe we had to queue to get into the shop, we had dropped in some years ago & walked straight in, how things have changed! Everything we purchased was excellent - great tasting but not heavy. If you're in the Marais, drop into Sacha's.

Great mix of Parisian Trendy with Old World Atmosphere. A great area to spend time just strolling, people watching, shopping, café and restaurant visiting. Le Marais has it all, including a couple of interesting museums. Soon the Picasso Museum will reopen, adding yet another attraction to an already very attractive neighborhood.

stroll, shop and people watch in this lovely neighborhood!. The Marais is one of those neighborhoods that attracts a variety of people and accepts everyone who choses to come! There are all the boutiques you can imagine from clothing to specialty food shops. It is mostly a walking area, so whether you are shopping, having a cafe or a meal you are in a pedestrian place, vibrant but without the noise and pollution of traffic. The architecture is beautiful, all the buildings have a fresh, clean façade, and there are some gems not to be missed such as the Archives de Paris and it's gorgeous hidden garden, or the various green areas where you can sit and people watch or let the kids run and play. The neighborhood is gay-friendly and most of the boutiques are open on Sundays, a major plus! Don't forget there are some unique food offerings such as l'As du Fallafel or La chaise au plafond, that are worth the stop. So unless it's raining cats and dogs, head over to the Marais for a memorable time!

nicest quarter in paris. in my opinion it is the nicest quarter of parisfirst ,the amazing place de vosge with stunning old but well preserved building and art galeries;and a beatifuk garden in the center.and the nice streets all around,and the nice shops,buildings and yards

When in Paris "Stay in Le Marais". One of the oldest areas in Paris, the land was reclaimed from The Marsh (Le Marais) in the 17th century and has undergone several metamorphoses. PreWWII this was the Jewish Quarter and still has that influence - especially food. Some of the best Falafel shops are here. Packed with historical buildings and Musee - such as the Picasso and the wonderful Carnavalet ; accommodation of every type and price and restaurants likewise. I always stay here when I'm in Paris.
Interesting place in Paris. Not as quaint as Saint-Germain but interesting to explore on foot. Lots of shopping and cafes. Flea market behind Hotel de Ville several times a week.

Everything you want in Paris is in Le Marais. We rented an apartment in this area. We normally stay in St. Germain. We were extremely impressed!!! Our place was near the St. Paul Metro. We had everything at our fingertips. Will definitely stay in this area again and again.

A unique part of Paris. We are staying in the Le Marais district of Paris this time around. We have rented an apartment here (but more on that in another review). We have visited the Le Marias district on many occasions in the past because each time we come to Paris we like to visit the Pompidou Centre and (when it's open which it will soon be again) the Picasso Museum (a must visit when in Paris) both of which are in the Le Marais district. Le Marias is very busy and has lots of shops of every type plus a great selection of restaurants. There is a real vibrancy to the Le Marais district which should be experienced whenever you pay a visit to Paris.
Good way to discover to Paris. If you see people on a public holiday, walk around seeing life, stop by cafes, quiet time along the Seine- this is a great place in Paris.

A treat to enjoy.. Went here on the recommendation of a friend looking for the Place de Voges and discovered a really quaint and beautiful district. Lots of beautiful wine, cheese, boulengerie, shops in addition to many high end fashion brands just off the Place de Voges. Small squares with play areas for children were dotted all over the place and the place was really Paris alive. A must to take a stroll through through. Plenty of impressive local Bistros and bars to top up as you do so.
Unexpected Delight. A most interesting area to stroll in, many unexpected delightful parks, courtyards and shops. Not the usual tourist locales but a true feel for life in Paris
Dynamic. Such a great feeling in this quarter. So open. So vibrant. So much fun just walking around. Great street art work too

Bustling, alive and well. A history-filled place that has become trendy and full of boutique, high end shops mixed with Jewish tradition. Easy to get to via Metro (St. Paul stop) and lots of exhibits. Check out the Photography Museum and the Bibliothèque Forney. Just saw a wonderful exhibit of spoons in a private collection from a master spoon maker. Simply great. Who would have thought that spoons would make a great little exhibit.

Walking through Le Marais is worthwhile. On a weekend in Paris, with sun, wandering through the Marais is quite pleasant, you can do it with to check some the relevant sites mentioned in the guides, or just move around. For lunch, the Marché des Enfants Rouges is my suggestion.

Our home away from home - Le Marais - Rue du Parc Royal. We spent almost a month in this neighborhood and became totally familiar with the local restaurants and stores. Our studio flat was located on Parc Royal only a 10 minute walk to the closest Metro station of St. Paul on Rue de Rivoli. This was our hub in District #3 and from here we explored Paris in every direction. Streets are lined with historic buildings, many of which were old hotels. Cafes abound and the weary traveler (you will be weary from all the walking) can find refuge on almost every street. A delightful place to find many museums as well as stores for the ultimate shopper. The Place des Vosges is a marvelous square with cafes and a beautiful park. This neighborhood must the heart and soul of Paris.

I feel "Paris" here.... I asked my Parisian friends where I should go if I wanted to see and feel real Paris, and all of them answered "Le Marais". I knew they are right when I was there. Just let yourself getting lost there (in day time). Just wander around, feel the atmosphere, have a coffee and see the neighbourhood. I was lucky that I found a boutique in a small street selling truly handmade and reasonably priced French fashion and accessories when I was "lost" (and I am not sure if I will find this shop again but it is what made Le Marais charming).If you really want some comfort for your orientation, you can try starting from the a-bit-too-famous Rue des Francs Bourgeois where you can find Uniqlo (btw, just go inside the modernly-designed yet historical building to have a look even you are not fan of this brand), Ted Baker, Muji, etc. Rue Vieulle du Temple is another good option.Mariage Frères has a tea house (30 rue du Bourg-Tibourg) and prices are reasonable for decent quality of tea. And the famous Pierre Hermes is close by and less crowded than other shops in city. Of course as other reviewers commented, there are plenty of other outdoor cafes and restaurants if you like watching people. Looking forward to visiting Le Marais next time already!

Wonderful Place to Stroll. This part of Paris is a wonderful place to stroll -- just don't go there on a weekend when it is absolutely jam-packed with people. A walk down Rue des Rosiers is a must as well as a stroll through the magnificent Place des Vosges.
susa. Wonderful area in Paris. Very old , cosy and comfortable. And beautiful indeed. Great restaurants everywere. Best area in Paris.

Don't miss this gem. We visited this area to fill in some time. We were rewarded with a beautiful area filled with quaint shops and unusual architecture. The highlight for us was the Place des Vosges.

Fun! And Great Falafel. Great people watching and window shopping, though rather crowded and felt like Venice at its worst at times. We'd been here before -- this time we showed around a Japanese friend who hadn't heard of it, but totally loved it. Any of the falafel places make a great meal at a reasonable price and a change-up from French food.
Great little area for shopping and nightlife. We loved wandering the streets of Marais, plentiful boutiques, cafe's and restaurants. Plenty of nightlife options as well.
Wonderful neighborhood to explore.. Take your time and spend the day walking the neighborhood. Visit the many antique shops. Enjoy the small local restaurants away from the tourists.

Best part of Paris for an old New Yorker. I was instantly comfortable. In the bustle of The Marais neighborhood ... The resonance with Greenwich Village and the Upper Side of Manhattan, with playful threads of upper East Side glamor all made welcoming, strangely comfortable music. ... It is a frame of mind ... Walk to Notre Dame, easy subways to all the iconic museums and landmarks . This is where we'll return.

Fun neighborhood, a bit spreadout. It's not the latin quarter or st. Germain, but its is good to stroll through. Rue des Rosiers is the place to see! Very active street with lots of street food.The rest of the neighborhood is pleasant, seemed safe and active to walk at night (we were there on a Saturday night).

Lovely area, a lot to see, nice for shoppping. Start from the Bastilia roundabout , through Place des Vosges, to Pompidu Center, wonder around the lovely streets and shop spread all around.good restaurants and many places to stop and rest.

Best to go on Sunday. As a colour designer the Mariais is full of beautiful old buildings and colour. My camera is constantly clicking. But on sunday a lot od the streets are closed down for pedestrians. There are wonderful little restaurants that sell street food, ice cream humous, couscous, bakery items. There is just great food everywhere. The clothing stores are plentiful and small. The interiors are all charming and i could have redone my entire wardrobe. No Gap here. Muji is here, along with The Loft (not Ann Taylor), Anges B, and the list goes on. Mt favourite yarn store can be found here too.

Your one walk to choose during your trip to Paris!. Say, if you have only one chance of taking a walk and you want to see as much typical Parisian cityscape as possible, then my suggestion would be to start from Notre-Damed, head to Ile Saint-Louis crossing the Seine on the Pont Saint-Louis. Continue Rue Saint-Louis en Ile until Rue des Deux Ponts and then over the bridge towards Marais. Once you get across the brigde, it's time to get lost and just wander around and admire the architecture, do some shopping and just relaxing in cafes. Besides the beautiful squares and major buildings and mansions, theres also the Carnavalet Museum if you want to take a closer look at the Parisian history - the permanent exhibition, which is quite extensive especially in terms of paintings, is free of charge.

SO much to see, do and eat!. We stayed at an Airbnb property right in the heart of the Marais district (Rue des Hospitalières Saint-Gervais) and it was a great experience. So much better than a hotel as you're really living right in the middle of "Paris Life". The Worlds Best Falafel bar is just around the corner, both of them! However you CANNOT miss Le Eclair de Genie or Meert for their respective sugary delights. Meert sells vanilla butter creme filled waffles that apparently were a favorite of General de Gaulle. You have to try them. Visit Crepe Suzette on the way back if you're coming off your sugar high!Le Eclair de Genie is a great representative of the new craze in Paris, eclairs. The displays are enough to make your drool. The eclairs look like jewelry! There are just too many restaurants to list, just go to any and you'll have a great meal!
A fun place to visit. There is a good feel about The Marais. Some trendy little shops, good museums, ( Victor Hugo Maison is free) and some super art and jewellery shops
Little boring if you don't like shopping. We went there on Sunday, following recommendation for special atmosphere. The atmosphere was nice, but not much more.
A wonderful area to wander. Just enjoy yourself walking around this beautiful part of Paris. We enjoyed the artistic window displays and drooled over the pretty pastries. Such a joy!

Great Neighborhood. It's lively without being crazy with cafés and restaurants and it's close to the Hotel de Ville, Ile de la Cité, etc. i would stay there again. Place des Vosges is the historical highlight.

Victor Hugo Slept There. We went on a guided walking tour of the Marais and learned about the fascinating history of this very old section of Paris. I liked observing a section of the wall that once encircled the original city center that was constructed in 1198. I also liked visiting the museum dedicated to the victims of the Nazi occupation and the partisans that tried to save them. Wear comfortable walking shoes because some of the cobblestone streets are murder.

Shoppers Will Love. This has better boutique shopping than the Champs-Elysees, which is about as exclusive as Michigan Avenue in Chicago (i.e., not very). Nevertheless, Le Marais is not what it used to be--now too gentrified.

historic and lively. This was a wonderful place to wander on a Sunday afternoon with follow up visits for some last minute shopping on Monday. The narrow streets are full of lively young people, pleasant cafes, and interesting galleries. One of the few areas not Haussmann-ized, a few medieval buildings have been preserved as well as an amazing church, Saint Gervais et Saint Protais, site of one of the largest civilian deaths from German shelling during World War One on Good Friday.

A great location!. It is located near St. Paul station...easy access to all other areas in Paris. Stayed at a lovely boutique hotel, Hotel Caron. Right behind us is a square with many restaurants. Great history...wonderful cafes. Can' beat location !
