Stayed here. Stayed in this region in apartment. Close to Metro, Bastille, and Seine. Worth walking the area. Locals and tourists alike.

Quaint, upmarket and trendy. Gorgeous cobbled streets, bars and restaurants - boutiques and galleries all packed into a small area. Really wonderful location and you could easily spend a day window shopping and sipping coffee here. Can't wait to return

Bohemian and Fun. Our Hotel was in the Marais. This is my second trip to Paris and have stayed in the Marais both times. It's arty and fresh. Lots of great boutiques and plenty of first class restaurants. The location puts you within walking distance of many other attractions, but be ready to enjoy a stroll.

A really interesting neighborhood. I had a walking tour of this neighborhood and itbwas very interesting.
It has a mixture of all kinds of people with lots of shops and restaurants as well,as several museums and important
Attractions
Place de Vosges. One of my favourite squares. Absolutely adored the leisurely walk around the gardens, the art galleries under the arches and a super glass of white.

Bohemian Paris at its best . This neighborhood imbibes the true bohemian atmosphere of old Paris. I love the small cafés, little shops that sell charming trinkets and the quaint passages. No wonder it's inspired so many great French artists and writers.
Nice Area. Lovely area to stay and lots of small restaurants. We enjoyed the nightlife and it's very central located.

Loved it!!! So authentic!. We felt so at home in Le Marais! We rented an apartment in the 3rd Arr. Just a short walk to the end of Rue St Martin and we were in the coolest part of Paris. Patisseries, clothes shops, fruit markets... everything we needed. I would stay here again for sure!

different atmosphere than Paris. We visited this area on a Sunday. Because a lot of Paris is closed on Sunday this is a nice option. The streets are very narrow and filled with several historic buildings and lots of retail offerings. There is gelato and pastry to spare as well. On Sunday there is also a nearby market at the Bastille monument offering fruit, fresh flowers, cheese and even live music. Be prepared for crowds.

Old Paris. This is very my kind of area. Authentic Europe. Cobbled streets, lots of street artists, amazing french mime artists. Oh and theres a pipe building too which is free to go into till the 2nd or 3rd floor and you get a good view of paris and well as the eiffel tower from there. Lots of small shops, just what i would imagine old authentic paris to be like. I got some really cute stuff like a necklace with my name made out of wire from there. Amazingly, the guy only took 10 minutes or maybe less and i did bargain and got it for 3 euros. please bargain over here!!

Falafel Heaven. L'As Du Falafel is outrageous; there is a reason for the lines and the wait. Get on the line on Rue Reviens and wait for a taste explosion! If you have room after this, the kosher bakery offerings are both kosher and distinctively of high Parisian quality. Leave you scale home and enjoy.As for shops here, they are outstanding and all price ranges abound.I love the district's vibe; Parisian yet eclectic and multi-cultural. A happy district for sure. A visit to Holocaust Museum is worthwhile, yet slobbering. The mood lifts at the excellent history of Paris museum called Carnavalet.I would not miss this when going to Paris; go on Sunday when the atmosphere is electric and other sections of town are sleepy with closed stores and attractions.
Chic but still unconventional. 17th-18th centuries Houses, cool shops, romantic views, the jewish neighbourhood, Place des Vosges,the art galleries.

Historic and Trendy. I go to Paris at least once a year and always spend time in Le Marais. This area has become a hip, trendy district and attracts mobs of tourists, especially on Sundays when many streets are closed to vehicular traffic. Its offerings range from gorgeous buildings of historical and architectural importance to charming boutiques. I love to visit beautiful Place des Vosges, the oldest square in Paris, and often duck into Comptoir des Cotonniers for a look at casual (but not inexpensive) women's fashion. Good restaurants and cafes abound. Just check the outside menus to determine where you want to eat. My favorite for salads and sandwiches is Carette at Place des Vosges. And the best falafel I've had outside of Israel is at L'As du Falafel on rue des Rosiers. Many delis and cafes here specialize in kosher food. That's because Le Marais is a major center of the Paris Jewish community.Myriad museums beckon in Le Marais. I especially like Musee Carnavalet, which is free and focuses on the history of Paris. As an Art Nouveau enthusiast, I find this museum's reconstructed shop of the jeweler Georges Fouquet -- decorated by Alphonse Mucha - to be absolutely spectacular. Musee National Picasso in an elegant 17th-century townhouse has been closed for years for renovation but is expected to finally reopen soon. I enjoyed the original so expect this update, which has more than doubled the public space, to be outstanding.I highly recommend checking out Le Marais to become familiar with this fascinating Paris neighborhood. Simply wandering and window shopping can be extremely rewarding here.
Nice old part of Paris. Liked shops, restaurants and jewish quarter. Special boutiques, and of course the Place des Vosges and the Musée Carnavalet.
Great Experience. Older part of the city, true french ambiance and quaint streets and buildings. Lots of clubs and vibrant night life with a huge selection of restaurants and bistros.

I've seen better places in Paris.. Le Marais is definitely among the most beautiful things I've seen in Paris such artistic cathedral and iconic buildings all spread around here though the huge area, except those few sightseeing there is nothing interesting... houses, shops, pubs and little else. We loved strolling through this historic neighborhood, but Paris being a city full of fantastic attractions, do not waste too much time to come and visit here.

Vibrant aera in the center of Paris. Le Marais is more than the gay area of Paris, in 20 years it has become a trendy place for fashion and restaurants. A lot of galleries and shops have opened and this is a must see area. Visit also the Jewish quarter, Place des Vosges.

My favorite neighborhood in Paris!. What a beautiful place this is. We enjoyed getting lost in the maze of incredibly picturesque streets. Many shops were closed (August), but the window shopping was good enough for us. Don't miss As du Falafel!

A fun place to visi. We strolled for a short time through the Marais. It's a funky little neighborhood kind of like the village in NYC. Nice shops, plenty of places to eat, and a mix of all different kinds of people. A colorful place to visit for an afternoon stop.

another must-see place in Paris. another must-see place in Paris; go out of time, walk the streets, visit the museum of Judaism, monuments, enjoy the virtines of chic shops, and lunch at a Jewish restaurant: they are very cordiasi and the food is wonderful, be sure to eat a vegetarian falafel!

Fabulous Area. This is such a great area to visit that's a little bit off the beaten path. It's a great little area with tons of character and less tourists than many other great areas in Paris. Definitely visit!

The trendy chic new district. We walked around Le Marais to get a feel for the area and it's riches. It has plenty of old parts and then the new and converted parts. There is a range of food. From spice shops to a street of falafels that require two hands to eat.

Great Walking Neighborhood/Old Architecture. We stayed in Le Marais neighborhood and loved every minute of it. There are all kinds of shops and places to eat. The architecture shows off some of the oldest in Paris. There is always someone walking around at all hours of the night. We always felt safe. Cafe's are everywhere and sitting at one people watching is a joy.

Amazing neighbourhood!. First time staying in this neighbourhood. Rented an apartment and pretending we live here. Paces and restaurants everywhere. Wonderful streets to explore and the Place des Vosges has to be one of the most beautiful spaces in the world.

Opens on Sunday but too crowded. If you're looking forward to shop on Sundays in Paris, here's the place to be. Narrow streets & huge crowd to be expected. Many cafés, restaurants & boutiques. There was an old band group who performed by the street & we bought their album for €10. Great music!

Paris's West Village. It seems like every major city has its own West Village, and Le Marais is Paris's. You can walk around there at all hours, and it's vibrant with small shops, bars, restaurants, and is far more intimate than Champs-Elysees or other parts of the city. It's also close to everything and yet still maintains a Village-y character. Good place for lunch or coffee if you're not into the nightlife.
Good on Sundays. Most of Paris is closed on Sundays, so the Marais is a good place to see people and to grab some food.
great neighborhood!. this is a fun and funky neighborhood with boutiques, art galleries, and cafes galore! Tiny narrow winding streets and people everywhere
Vibrant. Vibrant area to walk around on Sunday when much of Paris is closed. Lots of option for coffee / lunch / snacks. Try somewhere off the main tourist routes to avoid queues.
Loved our stay in Le Marais. Close to subways, great places to eat and shop and a wee bit off the beaten track. I'd stay here again in a second.

Open for business on Sunday. This is the neighborhood that is open for business on Sunday, when much of the rest of Paris is closed. Place des Vosges is a must-see any day of the week. We had an excellent walking tour by Discover Walks.

Great place to wander around. A must see part of Paris. Lovely little cobblestone streets, gorgeous shops and fabulous places to eat. Catch the metro and get off the main road to really enjoy the experience

Great way to spend an afternoon!. Walking this neighborhood, filled with shops and cafes is a great way to stroll around and enjoy an afternoon. Some areas are quite crowded but you can walk some side streets and become isolated from everything else. Many local shops will be closed on the Jewish Sabath (Saturday) so shopping for truly local merchandise will be a challenge on a Saturday but there are still plenty of places to shop and eat.
enjoyable. The marais area is great to visit. Lots of nice shops, cafes, brasseries and just generally some lovely streets to wander around.
A quaint neighborhood !. A pretty oasis in the heart of Paris ... Filled with cute cafés and shops and cobbled stoned walkways ! Don't miss a visit while in Paris !
Very quaint district. Lots of cafes, houses of notable people from the past, oldest district in Paris. We particularly liked Le Metro Cafe.

Gone but Not forgotten. I guess change is inevitable, but if you've been a soulmate to one of the greatest neighborhoods on the planet the changes are heartbreaking. yes Place des Vosges is still there, and yes there are still a few great spots but Rue Des Rosiers is now clothes boutiques and trinket shops,,sold out to foreign interests without any regard to its history. as well so many old haunts gone,,nothing worse than to see the boulangerie sign above the door of some fashion chain selling the same stuff as in any other city ,.,.ah globalization, the curse of the cannibal capitalist culture,.,.
Great location. Stayed in an apartment in this area great location lots of bars and easy to great around metro is great
Getting more trendy every visit!. We need to spend more time here next visit. So many interesting places, cafes and restaurants to sample!
Loved it. Vintage furniture and clothes, great cafes, tiny cobbled streets with loads of character - go there!
old paris. the walk on the streets of the Marais are really amaizingdo not miss this strol by the history and desinga lot of boutiques with nice things.
Sunday fun. Le Marais is one of the only areas in paris where you can shop on Sundays and as a result, it is fun and buzzy - good people watching and cute restaurants.

Wonderful place to visit. A lovely neighborhood, with shops (open Sunday), bars, restaurants. There is the gay part, lots of fun and a jewish part. The area is small with small streets and cute authentic places. Take your camera.
Love this area. I do almost all my shopping and eating in this part of Paris. It has the best clothing shops- 11Paris being one of them.
Charming part of the city. A delightful area of the city, filled with history, culture, relaxed squares and boutiques. You can even picnic on the grass!

More trendy boutiques than quirky shops. I noticed a fair difference since my last walk around the Marais some years ago. there are now a lot more trendy upmarket designer boutiques from global chains. These shops now outnumber the more quirky local independent shops.
The Marais is still great for a leisurely wander, but is losing some of its bohemian character.

Great walking area. Walked east and north from the Louvre. Had lunch in the Marais at the Cooperative brasserie. Great casual food, wine and a creme brulee. The very old buildings and charm in the Marais come through very clearly. Well work a walk about.

Kind of like the East Village. Le Marais is kind of like the East Village in Greenwich Village, NYC. We loved walking around and went to the Musee d'Judisme, as well. Went to the old Jewish quarter and had the best falafel at L'As Du Falafel.

Enjoyed walking around Le marais. We spent parts of a few days in & out of Le Marais. We especially liked the Jewish Quarter and enjoyed eating at a Kosher falafel restaurant. We did some shopping, although many stores were closed for the August holiday.

Get lost in the alleys and lane ways!. The best parts of the Marais are car free narrow streets and lane ways packed with small shops and eating establishments. Saviour twists and turns and just for the heck of it, go down some interesting lane ways and alleys. See if you can find the magician's museum!

Take the time to wander in this lovely district. We wandered into this district almost by accident having enjoyed strolling around Ile St Denis....lots of lovely restaurants, shops and pretty, interesting streets. We didn't even use a map - just set aside a couple of hours and wander. A real treat!

Great area. The Marais is filled with wonderful little restaurants, shops, boutiques. It's a lot of fun to wander around the narrow streets and it's just a bit off the beaten tourist path. One of my favorite areas of the city. Go!

falafel with the locals. Thank goodness for google maps for helping us navigate in the Marais. Last time we were in Paris in the '90s we walked all day and never found a deli. not this time! We like the Place Vogues and shopping around it - an ancient tea shop was a favorite.

A Happening Place. It had been recommended to us by both our cousins and Rick Steves to include a trip to this lively neighborhood. So glad we did. We wandered the narrow streets, visited Victor Hugo's home, ate the best Falafel of our lives and just enjoyed soaking up the local vibe.
Fun getting lost. Walk in any direction to find interesting shopping, eating, and sight seeing. From the hotel de Ville to the Temple park there were things to discover at every turn.

Fun neighborhood. The Marais is an historic district in Paris, but not many of the major tourist attractions are located there, so it tends to have a more local Parisian feel to it. It's kind of trendy with a lot of art galleries. The Jewish section of Paris is in the Marais and also the Picasso museum. Lots of restaurants and shops, and also a great place to find a hotel that is perhaps a little less expansive than in the center of the city but still very close to the Metro to get around.

Historic District Still Thriving. Our local guide gave us a two hour walking tour of the Marais and we learned so much more than we would have by merely strolling through the streets. It's amazing that old buildings can survive and thrive and remain in high demand. Obviously this district has evolved over the centuries, attracting new and different inhabitants and visitors. Definitely worth the trip.

Lovely shops and restaurants. I feel like this is the Camden of Paris. It has queues bars/cafes/restaurants and lots of lovely individual and shops.I would really recommend if you want to see a more laid back area of Paris,l

The shopping precinct in Paris. A nice area to spend a day shopping, hundreds of little stores await your visit with friendly staff, beautiful presentation and original products. There are some repeat stores but none of the really large standard kind of stores you find in all main streets around the EU. Definitely worth a day of your time even if you do not spend anything.

Busy & trendy shops.. Very well located area to rent an apartment ( if going for 5+ days/nights ). Many pastry shops, wine shops, catering services if you want to eat at your place, or to take to " Place des Vosges " for a neat picnic in a park. Or indulge at the many cafés/ bistros. You can walk to Notre-Dame-de-Paris or the Louvre from there.

Excellent place to stay. We stayed in the Marais district on a recent visit to Paris. The location is central, walking distance to most of the major sites and an enjoyable place to roam. People are friendly, food is good, and the unexpected finds are what makes a visit to Paris so enjoyable.
Trending Neighbourhood. Best time to go to Marais is Sunday afternoon. It is crowded, but a lot of nice food, and trendy shops. There are nice parks for kids too.

lovely neighborhood. I went on a walk to this neighborhood early on August, I loved Place des Vosges, the old buildings and nice shops around. I found some very nice scarves there.
.

every street has a secret!. if you like large avenues etc... do not come here! But if you like history, beautifull houses, squares, ancient buildings, ancient books, musea.... and shopping...this is definitively the place to walk, to be, to enjoy!

Wonderful area to walk. We loved walking through the area. it had such a great vibe to it. Shops, cafes, stores of all kinds. With the Jewish Quarter nearby providing a wonderful atmosphere as well, the Le Marais as a lot to offer.
Paris as in movies. Nice cafes, restaurants, shops selling clothes from not (yet) knowm designers. Musicians in the streets. Open even on sundays

Chic and interesting. We followed a short walking tour of the Marais found on the internet. The tour included the Place de Voges, which is beautiful. Plenty of backstreets and only a small amount of traffic, well populated by locals and tourists, enjoying the small neat shops. A smart area and a pleasure to amble through.
Cool, hip neighborhood.. This is the epitome of people watching culture! What a fun, unique neighborhood. Great shopping too!
Love the marais on Sundays!. When they are closed everywhere, everything is opened there on Sundays, do not miss Place des Vosges and the free museums.
This is such a lovely place to stroll in the sun. Super shops, great architecture and lovely gardens well worth a visit. Nothing to dislike try the patisseries.

My favorite part of Paris. I have been to Paris 5 times and I always stay in the Marais district. It is centrally located so you can walk to just about anything and the #1 subway line is right outside your hotel door. Paris is basically a walking city and there is something to see everyplace you walk. I found that by the end of the day I was at least 3 miles from my hotel in the Marais district and it was so nice to jump on a subway and be back to my room in 10 minutes. There are plenty of little cafes where you can get a crepe or Panini to go right around the corner. There is a man that roasts chickens on a rotisserie and the juices fall to the bottom where he has little white potatoes. What a great idea and he only charges a few dollars for enough food for a meal. This part of Paris has become a very trendy place to be since I started going there 15 years ago

A great oasis in the city. We went twice during our stay. Like a village with the city with outdoor cafés and many small shops which where mostly high end, not the touristy stuff. This would be a first stop on our next visit. A great way to break away from the hustle and bustle.

Very touristy. We walked the Marais on a Sunday and found it very crowded with long waits for any type of food. We detoured a few times which helped and the Place de Vosges was quiet and nice, although Victor Hugo's house was so confusing to enter (different payment plans-) that we declined.

great shopping. I like the variety of different shops, big clothing stores alongside retro second hand stores, shoe shops, bags, quirky souvenirs. Also some great places to sit and people watch and of course historic buildings.

Not Worth The Walk. We walked from our apartment in St. Germain and were disappointed. The former site of the Bastille is nothing but cheap souvenir vendors and Victor Hugo's house is definitely a waste of time. The only saving grace was Place des Vosges, which is beautiful and relaxing.
neighborhood. If you´ve seen St Germain de Prés, no need to visit this place at all. Narrow streets, 3-4-floor buildings... more of the same.

essential stroll. to walk the square at the heart of the Marais is to see art galleries, restaurants, habitations and antiques in this splendid classic square - the Marais is full of picturesque spots and wonderful shops - absolutely essential viewing

Lovely area. Great area for a stroll. We visited Carnavalet museum then walked and had lunch. The Paris map is difficult to follow however so we got a bit lost but you soon come across a metro station.

The place i liked more in Paris! Lively and colorful!. Everything is there! Street artists, great variety of street food, small bistro & restaurants, beautiful stylish clothe boutiques and also designer boutiques. This area of Paris is also full of people on Sundays because the market is open! Great place to taste falafel, shop, drink coffee and enjoy the music of street local bands...
Fun to visit. This is a neighborhood to visit, full of people, life and stores to discover, we loved the stroll and loved the architecture in the small old streets

Central location to all of Paris. The Marais is a great location. There are many restaurants, bistros, brasseries. There are good hotels (I like Hotel Villa Mazaran). There is a giant one square block department store. It's a few blocks to Notre Dame and Ile de la Cite, a few more blocks to the Louvre and a ten dollar cab ride to the Arc d'Triomphe.
Still has a feel of old Paris, trendy shops, quiet squares, atmosphere. Not hard to escape the crowds and discover beautiful peaceful gardens, trendy shops, quirky antiques, and always a bar nearby

Great shopping and history. Nice area to just walk around. Lots of cute shops and history. Is a Jewish area in Paris. Easy to get to. At night the area is bustling and you can get the best falafel outside of Israel there. Stop and have a coffee outside to just watch the people.

Fantastic area. I normally stay in la rue de roi de cecille. This are is amazing and sooo typically French. Its safe and s packed with little pop up bars, restaurants and a great atmosphere. Make sure you visit this little area when you are in Paris and lose yourself in the fabulous streets, mini parks, libraries, squares etc etc.
Awesome.

Beautiful. There is no better place than the Marais. It is filled to the brim with twists and turns and beautiful buildings. Just go an explore for awhile, it is filled with history and surprises. If you have time go into some of the vintage shops and stop by Rue de Rosiers, which is the centre of the Jewish corner. The best falafells you will ever have are to be found there.

Safe, convenient, interesting neighborhood. There is no shortage of great food and hotel options in the Marais. Within walking distance of many of the major attractions, with easy access by metro to all of them. We would definitely recommend a stay in the Marais district.
Walking tour of Le Marais. Great walking tour of Le Marais. Learned so much and had a great experience Walked on small side streets and got to see things we would have never seen from a tour bus
Awesome Neighbourhood. Lots of really great people and places to explore, go off the beaten path and down some smaller allies and roads, you'll find all sorts of new and exciting places.

I really enjoyed this area. What a great place to lose your way and just walk in Paris!Get a feel for boutique shopping, cafe's or just look at the buildings.I know you've probably done a lot of walking already but this area is different in a very good way.I will do this again!

distinct city neighborhood. much to explore. shops, restaurants. Open on Sundays when the rest of Paris is not. would like to spend more time here and be more knowledgable about where to eat and shop. Like just walking around and seeing things and people.
Not on a Sunday. Read others reviews and thought brilliant. It was not on the Sunday that we went, everything closed and streets were dirty. Also not that easy to get to.

Get lost!. More than any other part of Paris, the Marais retains some of the truly ancient Paris feel, with its twisting alleys and streets. Don't plan a visit, just wander. It's so small you can't get really lost, but stumbling on treasures is its greatest attraction. Finish at the Place de Vosges, which is simply gorgeous.

So lovely. As we discovered Le Marais area my wife and I have fallen in love! Everything is so French and we really enjoyed all this old houses, small streets, shops, restaurants, and beautiful hidden gardens. The real Parisian touch and style.

A must see district in Paris. This area is such a historic and interesting part of Paris. Adding to its history is a wonderful area of modern cafes and restaurants, shops and interesting small avenues off the main street.

Sunday at end of August. Bustling and alive with people. One of the best parts if Paris to visit. The streets were crowded, few cars, everyone walking and enjoying the day. I very highly recommend a walking tour (2 hrs) to get a flavor and then take off on your own and get lost in the street of people and the vibe. This is our French vacation and wow , I am loving it!

On lost beauty. I have visited Le Marais several years ago and I was very disappointed because it lost most of its beauty to become a shopping and bistro area. Several shops of antiques have been replaced by expensive art gallery full of bad followers of Wahrol etc. Places de Vosges is always wonderful but most of its old shops have disappeared.
a different feel of Paris. The small streets, the little shops, the friendliness of the vendors gives one a differnt feel than shopping and eating in the other districts

One of the most original quarters of Paris. I love the Marais. There is much to discover. Unfortunately there are not many quarters left in Paris with so much originality and small streets. There is great shopping, culture, museums and food. All you can wish for. Just don't get lost. It is not easy to find your way around in the Marais.
Was Once a Sleeper. But now the place is trendy and money is flowing in. Falafel places are very good. An enjoyable afternoon.

Well worth waiting for. We were told of this area of Paris by a friend who visits there often. It was a short metro ride from our hotel in the the Republique area and we went there every day, enjoying the boutiques, bistros and rich cultural diversity. Never have I seen so many different types of food shops and restaurants in such a small area and we sampled many of the set menus,including snails and frogs legs, Mexican and Lebonese. Many of the more interesting shops and stalls were down the side streets and we really enjoyed wandering and discovering new things every visit.

party, walks, history, shopping...what else. I live in this neighbourhood, what else could i say???WONDERFULL! It is so central and easy to get to, so many antic clothing stores, big brands... Evry thing is there!

Le Marais. This is by far one of my favorite neighborhoods/arrondissements in Paris. If you want to experience life as a Parisian in a neighborhood with shops, restaurants, and the most beautiful hidden gardens, Le Marais is the place to visit or stay. Shopping is quieter and less rushed than on the Champs Elysee. Cobble stoned streets lead to hidden shopping gems and antique shops. I love this part of Paris with all of its museums and gardens. If you are in to the LGBT scene Marais has a substantial one...and great places to eat as well.

Awesome location. Stayed at a relative's apt. in the Marais. Great location. Could walk to most things and an easy subway ride elsewhere. Very historic district- would recommend getting a guided tour to learn it's history.

Lots to do here. This is a lovely area to explore, full of history, boutiques, boulangeries, cafes ans bars. The Place des Vosges and the Carnavalet Museum are well worth a visit. Otherwise, follow the road, explore the side streets and enjoy.

Cool Area of Paris. This is a really interesting neighborhood in Paris with quirky shops, good food and some beautiful architecture. It's has a little bit of a different beat from the other neighborhoods and can be a welcome place to spend your day, a little differently than the normal touristy hotspots.

Stunning romantic area. Took the metro from our hotel to this area to walk in every day we stayed. The streets are beautifully tree lined and the historic nature - Victor Hugo's house - as well as the quadrants, small churches, cafes and shops are beautiful. There are some lovely restaurants and cafes where we ate every day!

Highlight of our trip. My daughter and I were not having a good time in Paris, until we explored this area. Our visit was in early June this year. Terrific place to walk around as there are lots of interesting shops and food places. From American Apparel to a quirky little bookstore/art gallery, it's a fun place to wander around (without the imposing, dark-suited security guards that we experienced in most other areas in and around Paris when we browsed in the shops and boutiques). We felt safe and simply enjoyed the overall experience of the look of the streets and buildings and cool vibe. We made a reservation to have crepes for dinner at Breizh Cafe, which capped off our trip to this area (but that's a different review!). Our favorite chocolatier and dessert place, Jacques Genin, is less than a 10 minute walk away, but we had already made our trip there the previous day. Definitely a great walkable area to take mature teens/young adults, for its friendly shopping and fun exploration. Fairly easy to get here by metro (we travelled here from the Latin Quarter). If I were ever to return to Paris (which is not likely - again, that's another review!), I would definitely return to visit this area again.

great place to stay. we have been to Paris several times and this was our first to stay in the Marais. LOVED it! Very fun, vibrant neighborhood. Good base for things to do. We enjoyed just walking around, there are great falafel, crepe and clothing shops. Try Rentavilla for a nice place

To walk, To see, To eat, To drink, Too shop!. Such a beautiful part of the city that is full of life. Everything you could imagine. Lovely cafe's, cute bakeries, fabulous vintage shops, tight streets with asian cuisine...what is there not to love!
The real Paris. One of my absolute favourite place in Paris. Cozy and modern, no matter how old you are, you always fit in. Lots of kind of restaurants, shops and beautiful environment.

Everything eclair!. We joined a walking tour of Le Marais, and decided to explore the place at another time. This place is probably one of the hippest place in Paris. And if you're a foodie, would appreciate the assortment of dessert places and food spots around the place. One of the places we stumbled upon was L'eclair de Genie on Rue Pavee. It was a shop of everything eclair you can imagine. There were fruit and creamy desserts, but the salted caramel fanatic that I am went for the salted caramel flavoured one. And it didn't disappoint. Just a tip though—go on a week day when the shop is empty and you can take your time getting confused with the selections. The line just to get inside the shop is quite long on the weekend.

Best area in Paris. We stayed in an apartment in Le Maris and we loved the area, the bars and restaurants are very chic and not like the tourist traps. Also has lovely patisseries and little boutique shops. Wouldn't stay anywhere else in Paris!

Fun part of the city. Visit the Place des Vosges - buy some bread, cheese and fruit and have a picnic. Walk through the streets and explore without a map. It is fun to get lost. You never know what you will find.

homeless among the art galleries. Not sure why the Marais is so popular, since it is dirty, there
aren't any attractions apart from the Pompidou, and the gypsies hang out in the nooks and crannies surrounding it. Head straight across the river to the Left Bank!

Avoid the tourist hordes. We stayed in a lovely quiet apartment on a local side street; very central yet allowed us to avoid the madness of Notre Dame, etc. We could walk to all the well known sites or take the metro or even buses easily. We chose to walk and felt more part of the local community finding good restaurants and quirky sites every time we went out.We have stayed in other parts of Paris before. Le a Marais is by far the best with plenty to do on the doorstep or av15 minute walk away.

best touristical area in paris. it s a really nice area, i suggest visiting musee beaubourg, personally my world favourite, and all the nearest street;it s plenty of galleryes and nice shops and bars, very good to hang out with friends or girl and discovering interesting new thingsbefore entering, pay attention to the prices of restaurants, to avoid surprises !
Quintessential Paris. If you want to really experience Paris, go for a wander here. Shopping and eating are everywhere. Place des Vogues is a great place to start
Very nice!. We had dinner at Chez Marianne a very small restaurant where you can choose from a lot of bites and compose your own dish.

The coolest area of Paris. A very authentic and cool area in the same time. Lots of lovely eateries and quirky little shops. Main brands as well as new and upcoming designers. Lots of interesting museums and art galleries. You can easily spend a whole day in Le Marais and enjoy every minute of it! Highly recommended!
Pleasant to walk. There are many small restaurants & bar, the gay district of paris so the atmosphere is strong, it's fun to take a ride over there

One of the most interesting areas in Paris. The Marais, the Jewish quarter, is an area of Paris made up of small streets lined with cafés, shops, restaurants and museums. The Place des Voges is a wonderful place to sit and watch the world go by or have a picnic. Every time we go we find something new, the most recent being the National Archives. This building was an old palace, one of several in the area that are being renovated and opened up to the public. The little parks, which join them up, are lovely to walk through. The archives are worth looking at just to read the last letter of Marie-Antoinette but there are many other interesting finds plus beautiful old rooms.

Shopping tour in Le Marais. I took a shopping tour with Richard Nahem of Eyepreferparis.com. I had specifically asked him to take my friend and I to local artisans and other "made in Paris or France" boutiques. He delivered and took us to lovely local shops. He was a great tour guide and knew the out of the way places.
quaint and lively. great place for food, so many options. Very lively, friendly atmosphere and some great bakeries and dessert places.

Try to avoid weekends. We were privileged enough to have a friends apartment in the heart of the Marais for a week and while we hit all the must see spots for tourists in the city - our favourite neighbourhood was the Marais. Simply walking the ancient streets, exploring cafes and the numerous parks and people watching was a delight. The parks are oases, beautifully maintained and each one unique...many of the locals take their sandwich and flask of coffee (I think it was coffee!) and delight in their surroundings...many of the parks have free WiFi. For a different type of eating experience visit the Marche des Enfants Rouges where under tented canopies various food stalls offer their fresh wares - there is seating too. Give yourself plenty of time to enjoy these streets and if you can avoid weekends...but not at the cost of avoiding the Marais!

Great collection of shops and restaurants. This is a small, walkable, very neat section of Paris. You will find interesting shops, and great crepes and falafel shops. It's an easy walk or metro ride from anywhere in the city.

Great for shopping or wandering. I love the Marais because it is so easy to just get lost in the "French-ness" of it all. Beautiful architecture, adorable shops. There is so much life and character on every street.

Great for walking and watching. I love this area and have visited many times. The latest time was with my husband and we went to museums and poked our noses into gorgeous courtyards, drank much coffee and had some lovely meals. The shops are fun and there are a couple of great vintage clothes shops, which are reasonably priced. The Musee Carnavalet is a delight and the nightlife can be interesting, especially at the weekend.

Lovely, lively old section of Paris. Full of some of the oldest buildings in Paris, beautiful "Hotels", secret gardens, great boutiques and restaurants and also home to some of the best nightlife in Paris.

Beautiful area away from too much touristy stuff. This are is great for walking around. Get there in the yellow line and off at St Paul. Visit place de la Voges. It is a beautiful park. Restaurants are all around it and a great place for gelato in one corner. Also a small play park for kids. Restaurants were open until 1/2:00 am and people were out and about quite late.

Easy walk - good for a few hours. Lots of quick service restaurants, reasonably priced. There is a relatively new Holocaust Museum that tells the World War II story quite effectively. Like most of Paris, it is a bustling area.

Good district for walking purposelessly. Altough many guides and articles recommend Latin Quarter for walking and socialize with locals, Le Marais is a better district with more open shops and crowded streets. (and distinctive streetarts)

Incredible neighborhood - tips for vistors. The Marais is one of the most beautiful parts of Paris – and one of the only areas that preserved the narrow streets and architectural styles of Medieval and Renaissance Paris. Historically, it was the Jewish quarter, and in modern times it still is… but it is also a funky, hip area for people to hang out in or to go antique-ing. A stroll in this neighborhood and you can find kosher butchers, trendy clothing boutiques, breathtaking architecture, antique shops, and many shops with Jewish paraphernalia. Just be sure that you stop for lunch at the world famous falafel house called L'As du Falafel (located at 34 rue des Rosiers, closed Saturdays). Unfortunately, they do not have a website, but this is the place where celebrities come to get their falafel because it is so delicious.Two other great lunch options are Breizh Café (109 rue Vieille du Temple, closed Mondays and Tuesdays) and Le Loir Dans la Theiere (3 rue des Rosiers, open every day).These are some things worth checking out in the Marais:The rue des Francs-Bourgeois, rue Vieille du Temple and rue des Archives are the three principle strolling streets for the shops, cafes and general ambiance. Many of the shops there will be open on Sundays. While on the rue des Francs-Bourgeois, make sure to pop your heads into the courtyard of the Carnavalet Museum to check out its wonderful gardens, beautiful this time of year! The buildings are in fact two adjacent Renaissance mansions.Place des Vosges- Take a stroll at Place des Vosges (metro: St. Paul or Bastille, lines 1, 5, and 8). This beautiful square is the oldest square in Paris and was inaugurated in 1612 under the name Place Royale. In 1800, it changed its name to honor the administrative department called Vosges (located in the north-eastern France) because they were the first department to pay their taxes. Napoleon himself referred to Place des Vosges as the ‘jewel of Paris’, the most beautiful place in the whole city.Victor Hugo's House- A notable inhabitant of number 6 Place des Vosges was the author and poet Victor Hugo. Hugo lived here from 1832- 1848, after he completed the Hunchback of Notre Dame. His former home is now a museum dedicated to him, which features an impressive collection of his drawings and paintings. Open from 10am-5:40pm. To see the permanent collection is free, for temporary exhibits the price is 7.70 euros. It is closed on Mondays.While you’re over there, make sure you stop at 4 rue du Pas de la Mule – there is a gem of an artisan chocolate shop there called Josephine Vannier. The creations are unique – chocolate masks, mini pianos, replicas of vintage ads… (Closed Monday)Hotel de Sens – this majestic Medieval building is now an art library. It was built between 1475 and 1519. Stop for a moment to admire the elegant formal gardens – grab a bench in the sun for a bit of relaxation time! And look on the outside wall of the third floor for the cannonball lodged there in 1830. 1 rue Figuier 75004Village St. Paul – nestled between rue des Jardins St-Paul and rue Saint-Paul just south of rue Charlemagne is Village St Paul, an incredible antique, art, and artisan market! The interconnected courtyards allow you to enter along any of the streets mentioned above. This is really a unique place to go – many Parisians don’t even know about it! Open every day.Hotel de Sully – walk through the main courtyard to see the Greek-inspired statues in this beautiful mansion, built between 1625 and 1630. 62 rue Saint-Antoine.Carnavalet Museum- The Paris history museum has artifacts on display that chart the history of Paris from Gallo-Roman times to present day. Some of France's most important documents, paintings, and other objects from the French Revolution are housed here. 23 rue de Sévigné 75003.Open from 10am-6pm Tuesday-Sunday (Closed Mondays). To see the permanent collection is free.See the link for more details http://en.parisinfo.com/museum-monuments/232/musee-carnavalet-musee-de-l-histoire-de-paris?1The Museum of Jewish Art and History- This museum showcases important Jewish art, artifacts and culture, much of which was destroyed during World War II. This museum pays tribute to the rich history of Jewish people in Europe and in particular France. It is open from 11am-6pm and the cost is 6.80 euros per person (audioguide included in price). Located in the Hotel de Saint-Aignan, 71 rue du Temple (this is not a hotel, it’s a ‘hotel particulier’ which is basically an inner-city mansion). Learn more here: http://www.mahj.org/en/index.phpLa Memorial de la SHOAH- This is a research center dedicated to WWII. It is open from 10am- 5pm (Closed Saturdays), is free of charge and features documentation and photographs of significant value. Also has temporary exhibits on Jewish writers, artists, and others who have or are doing great things for society. If you have any Jewish family that were in Europe during WWII, you can look them up - For more details, see here: http://www.memorialdelashoah.org/getHomeAction.do?langage=en17, rue Geoffroy-l'AsnierThe oldest food market in Paris, Marché des Enfants Rouges, is also in the Marais (the northern part). If you have time, you should make the visit (even if it is all covered in scaffolding right now)! If you do decide that you want to take a look, just keep in mind it is best not to go between 1-4pm during the week, as some of the stands will be closed for lunch. It is closed on Mondays. Follow the arrow along rue des Archives on the map until reaching rue de Bretagne. Rue de Bretagne turns into rue Froissart further east, which you can see on the map. Make a right on rue de Bretagne and after about a block and a half you will see the entrances to the market on the right.
great town to shop. This town reminded me of Soho in New York--great shopping in this town! Great cafes! Very friendly shopowners
The oldest Paris. The oldest Paris, beautiful creators shops, you must visit the big bazar near the city hall...A lot of restaurants around to eat the real croque-monsieur.

My new favorite area of Paris!. In trips past, I gravitated to the Latin Quarter and St. Germain de Pres. Le Maris now replaces the Latin Quarter. While the Latin Quarter still has great restaurants, Le Marais has the better atmosphere, in my opinion. The shops were quaint (though chains are taking over, which is unfortunate), the atmosphere peaceful, fun and devine all at the same time, and the shopping was great (less expensive than other parts of the City, yet still trendy). I will return to this area. A great way to spend a day strolling the square, including the art galleries and the free Victor Hugo museum.
favorite. I loved this area, easy to walk around - great shops and restaurants, great overall vibe. If I lived in Paris this might be my neighborhood! Be sure to visit the store Merci.
A little disappointing. Some nice shops and galleries, but we were expecting more from the deli's. Also, we were aggressively hounded by men trying to sell us religious articles.
Nice happening neighborhood. We followed Rick Steves walking tour and saw much of this hip and happening neighborhood. Recommend!!

A must visit area. Full of life and amazing mix of people and cultures.. Been coming to Paris for 25+ years and always make a beeline for the area. If you have never been to Place des Voges you are a missing a treat. You can spend many hours wandering around Le Marais just absorbing the atmosphere.
Best Shopping. The Marais district, including the Rue de Rossier, has amazing shopping...don't miss it! Boutiques and upscale known brands...sale week is especially good.

Nice area to walk around. The Marais is the old Jewish center of Paris, and still features several active synagogues and kosher shops. There are other things to see as well: the Templar center, a few gardens, lots of shopping.

A real trendy area of town. What was once an LGBT enclave, the Marais is now a very hip, upscale chic district with bars, brasseries, shops of all kinds and funky people to look at. On a Sunday afternoon, it can be most entertaining.Streets are narrow and the small town feel of the Marais is warm and inviting. I always go back to it every time I'm in gay Paris.

Historic district with some of the best architecture in Paris. This part of Paris still has many private historic mansions, some of which are museums and can be visited. This district is perfect for walking, eating and shopping. Very central and convenient. You could spend several days visiting different parts of the Marais, with highlights such as Ile Saint Louis, Place des Vosges, Musee Carnavalet and more!

Quite and Expensive. The Maris is unlike any other neighborhood. It streets are very narrow and it reminds me of Avignon. Lots of shops and cafes, but is it is expensive. To get there just walk to the back side of Notre Dame and cross the bridge.

Too noisy for my tastes. I was recommended to stay in this area for my first-time stay in Paris. I have enjoyed my stay very much, but in walking throughout the city, I would have preferred elsewhere. This part of the city has an ambitious and fun nightlife. I prefer a quieter area. I think I may have preferred the St. Germaine area, but truly not sure.
Marais visit. Great area with lovely art galleries. Charming neighborhood. Busy cafés in the evenings. Lively spot.

walking is great for your health. We knew beforehand that we were in for some serious walking exercise around Paris if we were going to see everything close up therefore, as we were staying in the 7th arrondissement, a stroll over to the 3rd was no great stretch but we trained it anyway. While walking the Marais district, time just seems to stand still as we stroll down narrow lanes, picturesque rues and stopped at sidewalk shops and interesting photo ops. My wife is into doors therefore Le Marais was like a sweet shop for her. My suggestion is to walk around and take it all in for yourself, Enjoy.

My favorite Paris neighborhood. Wonderful parks, small old streets with an "Old Paris" feel (a feeling destroyed in the rest of the city during the Hausmann and subsequent renovations), lots of small cafes and some wonderful gourmet restaurants, good shopping (especially men's fashion). It is the heart of the city's old Jewish and gay communities, too. Easily accessible by several metro stops.
Always great. What a lovely neighborhood ! The best quartier in Paris, full of shops, restaurants, little parcs, great for people watching.Love it !

In my opinion the best area of Paris.. This area is simply beautiful and charming.. Tons of great shops and restaurants! Lots of Parisians and less tourists in this area.. There's also a big gay & Jewish community in the area.
Trendy. Funky, trendy neighbourhood. Great to walk through and find the designer shops! This is where I bought my Pandora Charm of the Eiffel Tower. :)
Not what you expected. Small streets,concentration of some nice boutiques and the not so explendid Place des Vosges. Lots of tipical jewish food
Lovely neighborhood . We had friends who were staying here and visited them. We had a lovely time. Great bars, restaurants and shopping. Beautiful spot to stay in Paris

one of the most interesting area in Paris. Admire the beautiful Place des Vosges, stroll though multiple little streets to find unique shops, stop by at a bar or a gem of a restaurant, enjoy the diversity of the crowd

Beautiful Le Marais. There's so much going for this neighbourhood but I can see it's at risk of becoming too gentrified and probably for most Parisians that ship has already sailed. If you like trendy boutiques and hip galleries you will be in heaven. For the wandering curious tourist armed with camera (i.e. me) there are lots of winding old streets and quite quintessential looking restaurants/bistros (like Chez Julien for example).So despite this being a hot spot for Paris Fashion Week and being home to Karl Lagerfeld's boutique, there's still lots of character and some insight can be gleaned into how the place must have been 50-100 years ago if you study the architecture. High points are Rue des Rosiers but it can get quite crowded with tourists around Murciano, the kosher jewish bakery. Others include the beautiful and aristocratic Place de Vosges, the vibrant gay community and of course the orthodox jewish community going about their daily business.Compared to the usual charmless tourist guide book recommended places like Montmartre and seedy Pigalle, this really is a must see district.

Excellent for walkers. This was the best neighborhood for architecture, walking, shopping hands down. Read a guide for where to eat though - most of my food here was overpriced/average. Some great sit-down food in the plaza at Pompidou & enjoyed walking while I ate when I chose todo that.

Great place.. I have always loved this part of Paris. I live here some of the time, so I won't run it down too much. Problem is, it is no longer the Marais I knew and fell in love with. It was once a little "gritty" shall we say. Full of quirky little shops, lovely local cafés and restaurants. The streets were a little unloved so less touristy. Now it all seems a little antiseptic and corporate. The quirky shops are largely gone, and the lovely Jewish shops on Rue de Rosier are disappearing, to be replaced by yet more overpriced "boutiques". As if we need any more!!. Everything changes, as it should, but it is sad when these change are not for the better. Le Marais was once the place to see old Paris. It is becoming another area of chichi high street shops. To see bits of old Paris, look at the lovely Place des Vosges, the back streets of Pigalle, the working market on Rue Mouffetard, and some of the non tourist streets around Montmartre. Yes, honestly, there are secret places there. Don't rely on me to tell you. Look around, there are great treasures to be seen and beautiful quiet spots to be found. When you find them, do as I do and keep them secret, then they are always "yours".
must visit. cool and hip neighbourhood with shops that sell all sorts of weird and wonderful things and stay open late. nice cafes and bars and the area could keep you busy for a good 2-3 hours.
great neighborhood. This really is a delightful neighborhood, cannot believe how many truly boutique shops there are here as well as charming small bistros etc...worth a day of wandering about.

guided tour. walked on historical traces with a guide. Le Marais is really nice to visit, full of life and for breaks many restaurants, also one of the oldest of Paris, invite the visitor. Lovely Buidlings,restaurants, shops, museum and more

Get a real taste of Parisian living in Le Marais. Great just to wander around the little streets, nice shops, people-watch from a street cafe! Next time we're in Paris we'll aim to say around here - feels nice and lived-in.

A great place to visit.. I have just returned Paris. I live in Las Vegas and go to Paris almost every year. I won’t go into the regular stuff you can read in any of the Guide books. Some of my thoughts are:The Marias is still growing at a fast pace. Many new stores and restaurants opening all the time. And not just on the main streets. I suggest you go down the smaller side streets and you will find many interesting places. It is an exciting area of Paris. Most of Paris stays the same and that is alright because it is so great. Not the Marais, it is changing every week. The great old buildings and they are old are still there on the small crowed streets but the ground floors are being made into commercial clothing and retail stores of all kinds. I walked all the streets, I was in Paris for 3 weeks. A joy to just walk around the Marais.I like to get a sandwich on St. Antoine and walk over to Place Vosges and sit in this very lovely park and watch all the people and have lunch. A very nice and peaceful place. I’m not that much into history but I suggest you read about this place. I visit here every week.Twice this trip I would go out the north side of the park and to the right and up the next street to Café Januo. A wonderful small Café that never disappoints. I get there around Noon to beat the Paris crowd that eats around 1pm. And it will be crowded.I love the Marais area. I always stay at the Hotel du 7th Art on St Paul, a small affordable place that is a bit away from the noise of the Marais. The Marais is almost always crowed but on weekends it is Party time. Lots and lot of people, Parisians and tourists all together and having a good time.From almost any place in Paris, just take the Metro Line 1 to St, Paul and your there.A wonderful place to visit.
Stroll Through Winding Streets. Paris before Hausmann. Shopping. Sidewalk cafes on narrow medieval streets where pedestrians rule. Take a few hours for an immersion in Parisienne life.

Great exciting area. This was the old traditional Jewish section of Paris but is now one of the hip sections in terms of shops and restaurants. It is a charming area, there are plenty of distractions, and you can amuse yourself for several days. If you have been hanging around the more monumental or formal areas of Paris, the Marais offers an interesting and diverting alternative.
Fun Walking. Lots to see in this quadrant. Love the Place de Vosges and the winding, little streets. Great pastries abound. Great walking and noshing part of town.

Love this area :). So great to be in the Marais ~ love all of Paris but this is a great area & so easy to walk around & get lost in! Have fun! (get the falafel, eat at Breakfast in America on rue mahler, eat gelatto at any of the small shops :)
A favorite. This is an area that is a favorite of mine in Paris and wonderful to walk the small streets and discover the little restaurants.

The cool Paris.. You'll regret not visiting Marais if you do so.The architecture is like Soho in London, many small designer shops, restaurants, nice people with alternative styles, nice falafel :) etc.Great for a walk on a sunny day, you feel like you are at the coolest area of Paris. Nobody showing off, just smiling faces and happy people.
Mixed experiences. Shops are great with real price bargains in their sales. Restaurants are poor in general, with some notable exceptions... Not the popular ones!
Lively!. Lively, upcoming (if not there already!) hip hangout in Paris. Great atmosphere, good food and plenty of choices. Get lost in the streets and you'll be surprised at what you can see and do!

charming and crowded. packed with people on narrow streets - take one of the free walking tours to get the most of it. Liked narrow cobblestone streets and my son liked the clothing stores. it was a hot day and super crowded so that was not fun
Many, many restaurants. The Place de Voges area is great for any type of dining you would want.Many art galleries and we also found a small laundramat.
This place rocks. There is so much happening here. The Rue des Rosiers is a must, as is the Place des Vosges. The shops are quaint, the Jewish quarter has great character. It is a must stop in Paris.
Hotel Saint Paul. Our central hub was Hotel Saint Paul. The Marais is a bit busier than my last visit 15 years ago. But you can still find those nooks and crannies that exemplify the Old Paris.

LOVE the MARAIS. Lovely walking and definitely buy some cheese, baguettes, and fruit for a picnic later in the day. Go to Rue de Rosiers- the Jewish Quarter- it's simply adorable, delish food, and incredible history. Include the Jewish museum too! This area is just fabulous for strolls and a real taste of Paris life! What a treat!

Quirky Quartier. Le Marais is my favourite part of Paris - it's full of tight, winding streets, vintage stores, cool (and expensive) fashion shops and falafel! The atmosphere there is lovely and welcoming - it's one of the gay areas of Paris so don't be surprised to see lots of gay bars and clubs, too. A favourite Sunday afternoon activity is wandering through a few vintage stores, buying falafel and eating it over at Place Des Vosges, the oldest square in Paris and the location of one of Victor Hugo's residences.

Just the place to stay in Paris. Very easy to get to from Gare du Nord, even walkable with suitcases, as we did, after arriving on the Eurostar. Mind you the Parisians thought we were mad. Everything close at hand and the little windy streets a real treat with none of the touristy stuff or sleaze of Montmatre or Pigalle. Heaps of eateries, most with the obligatory gay couple or ten. A really great location to base your stay in Paris.

Great shopping! Great lunch spot!. We stumbled across several blocks of cool, unique reasonably priced shops in the area close to Place des Voges. St Paul's church was beautiful to see; and we found a great crepe restaurant across the street. Easy metro access to other parts of the city. Wished we could have spent more time here than just one morning!

Fabulous for walking, shopping, parks, eating.... A wonderful area of Paris; it is home to the oldest home in Paris. Narrow streets, boulevards, cafes, galleries, shops, churches and Parisians living their normal life, it does not get much better. It is a wonderful mix of residents, tourists, businesses, arts and parks.

great little place with a fab atompshere. really nice bar that has a little restaurant behind it too. Great location and lots happening. As a lone traveller it was a super place to sit and eat in peace whilst not feeling alone. Food was good too.
A cool beautiful place. We always go here. Cool wine shops, wine bars, Chez Prune, and Antoine and Lili. Fun to watch the boats go by and for an evening stroll before dinner.

Fun and friendly area.. This is a great place to sit in a café and people watch. There are many restaurants and bars. Many trendy fashion shops in the area. Make sure to stop in at the BHV for some great buys.

real Paris. real parissian atmosphere
...good area for walking, shopping in small typical french shops, nice restaurants
(but big gay community in every bar)
Stroll and enjoy an old Parisian neighborhood. Le Marais has the Musee Pompidou, the Musee Carnavelet, very untouristy shops and restaurants. You'll experience La Vraie Paris in Le Marais.

Quaint and walkable area. We enjoyed wandering around this area of Paris; found the remaining parts of the medieval walls of old Paris! Lots of fun and funky shops and cafes - charming narrow alleys and lovely buildings too.

Elegance. Once my favorite neighborhood of Paris, still one of my favorites. You can find whatever you imagine, from small elegant boutiques to great restaurants, bistros, bars and cafes. In addition, Place des Vosges is the breath of freshness in this beautiful neighborhood. Every time I visit Paris, I will definitely spend as much time as I can afford in Marais. If it happens to be in Paris during the weekend it is highly recommended to spend most of your time in Marais. You will find that most parts of the city will be "dead", but Marais will be more lively thatn any other day!!!
Very quaint. I love the Marais neighborhood, it is old Paris, medieval feeling. Place de Voges is a wonderful park to picnic and there is a playground for the kids. I go every time I am in Paris.
Get lost in this cute area. Lots of shops and places to eat on these beautiful streets. Spend a few hours walking around this area and you won't be disappointed.

Flâner dans Le Marais. The hustle and bustle of normal day life in Le Marais is so much fun! Lots to do and see! Le Musée Carnavalet, Centre Pompidou, Place des Vosgues are all in the area. Great restaurants and shopping.
Feel Paris atmosphere. Have a walk on sunday afternoon, shops are open, go to place des Vosges for a drink. Just walk without a destination ad discover this quarter. That's Paris

Very nice neighborhood. Great for just walking around enjoying the atmosphere and great nightlife! Historical renovated buildings. We had a great walke from Hotel de ville to Republique square and back to La Marais for lunch.
Lovely Area. Lots to do in this area if you just want to wander around looking at the buildings and doing a bit of shopping.

Restaurants and shopping. Interesting place to visit especially on Saturday. The streets and restaurants are full of life and people. Great shopping, mainly clothes. AU petit fer a chevalier in 30 rue Vielle du Temple is small but nice place for lunch. Good coffee and gigantic duck and ham salads at very inexpensive prices.
Hip and Historic. One of the nicest arrondissements in Paris. Lots of great little boutiques, wonderful restaurants and charming cobblestoned streets. Lively at night, so very safe.

Disappointingly seedy. We stayed in a hotel in the Marais, as we knew it was an easy walk to central Paris attractions, but were disappointed - it was a seedy area, with depressingly tatty shops, and we struggled to find a restaurant of any charm. It was like staying in Leicester Square in London - very central but not very pretty.
Just wander. Take your time, stop for a coffee and something sweet, but just wander. It really is a beautiful part of Paris, and close to many major attractions.
This is real life in Paris. Small streets, small shops, restos and terrasses, ideal to wander around. But weather needs to nice.

Try the Falafel. A brilliant cultural mix in one of my favourite places in Paris, a relaxed atmosphere with good shopping, art and street performances. Excellent way to spend a day, and my girlfriend swears by the falafel.
The Holocaust Memorial. The Holocaust Memorial and museum of the Shoah are very moving, especially the wall of names of the 76,000 Jews rounded up in Paris in 1942-43 and shipped to the death camps.
Great neighbourhood !. This time in Paris we decided to stay in Le Marais which we both rally enjoyed. A nice section of Paris with a lot of good restaurant, shops & bars.

Great area!. Another pleasant walk in the heart of the French capital! A vibrant area full of nice little shops from well known international chains, designers etc, to more independent shops where you could even find some retro treasures from now and then! You can get lost in little old streets but it will definitely worth it!

Interesting buildings. It has quaint cobbled streets tucked away from the main road. Interesting buildings and a beautiful park called Place des Voges. The area is full of great cafés and restaurants. Good place to lose yourself for half a day.

Great neighbourhood, specially on Sunday. Love this area, full of shops, good food, interesting places, nice area around Place des Voges.
Love the jewish bakeries, and the falafel.
Vibrant. The whole area is a buzz of activity. Amazing! There are many restaurants serving delicious food. So much choice in so little time.

Wonderful area to stay in Paris. We made the Marais our 'home' during our recent Paris visit and were rewarded with a wonderful blend of cafes, bakeries, restaurants and stores that our entire family enjoyed.
Walk and walk. Not so much open on Sunday morning, after 1pm is the time to go. Needs a good whole day to explore. Lovely shops and a couple of good museums.

Marais shopping walking everything. The Marais is such an exciting place to visit. There is the fantastic Carnavelet museum for one thing, plus all the fancy shops plus little creators to discover . Some things cost a fortune and then suddenly you will find the perfect gift to take home to a loved one for next to nothing. The roads are small and winding and even after visiting the Marais many many times I always get lost. There is the Jewish quarter where the cheese cakes and strudels are to die for. The history of the area is somewhat disturbing but interesting as stories of the past always are. I always have a little sadness whilst moving around and reading how many people were deported from this building or that. The gay community are well represented in the Marais which is always fun, beautiful people strutting around, plenty of coffee shops, restaurants and bars where all are welcome.

Le Marais. We spent a day wandering around this area and it was incredible.We found the Jewish section and it was really great, also visited the memorial to the Jews murdered by the Nazi,s in the 2WW, how could people treat others this way.......
Discover Marais. There's always something new going on: bars, restaurants, shops, galleries... and is almost always open! Find here the coolest shopping in town

Glorious. Set in a beautiful district of paris the Musee Rodin was just breathtakingly beautiful. The gardens are beautiful dotted with extraordinary statues. Many of tortured, muscular figures evoking the weight of troubled human condition. The thinker was the highlight. Rodin's house is grand - full of statues and painting, and the ..."the kiss" - 2 naked lover entwined in each other's arms, just beautiful. A visit an absolute must.

The Perfect Spot. This is the perfect geographic spot to stay if you are coming to visit Paris by foot. It is close to everything; walking distance to the main Paris attractions (Notre Dame, Louvre, Picasso Museum, Toulleries, L'Orangerie, Champs Elysee, Concorde, Pomipdou, Opera, Madeleine, you name it...is walkable from Le Marais).This is not a quiet neighborhood, hustle and bustle day and great part of the night. Irrefutably gay but family oriented at the same time.Great little boutiques, restaurants, cafe´s, bars and clubs. If you want to experience Paris this is the place to be.Don't come if you are close minded, backawards or going to roll your eyes at same sex couples kissing, walking hand-in-hand, goths, cross-dressers and transexuals. Because this is their neighborhood. This is where they live and reign supreme! But it is open to everyone!

Love the Marais!. Less touristy, but pricier shopping and cafes. Are all of the young people in the Marais models? Every shop had gorgeous, impossibly thin clerks in them. We strolled through one morning en route from Bastille Marche to Centre Pompidou. Stopped at Places Vosges with its stunning homes and lovely courtyard-like park. A true oasis in the city. Vosges and Marais are a must see.
Le Marais. Le Marais on the right bank hides many interesting things. The small churches, the restaurants, the parks, the squares. This is an up and coming area of Paris.

A slow and easy walking tour.. I decided upon a self directed walking tour of Le Marais after reading a NatGeo book on Paris. It was a good decision. It was just a few minutes from my hotel and I spent about two hours just wandering the streets. Had a great lunch at a beautiful restaurant just opposite Place des Vosges. It was a little pricey but the atmosphere and presentation made it worthwhile. The narrow streets, unique shops and the apparent lack of urgency made for an interesting experience. I wound up at Pompidou Centre - not my favourite place.

Quaint area... must go. We got off the subway at Le Marais and immediately fell in love with this area. Wonderful boulangeries, shops and cafes. Lots of winding cobblestone streets with beautiful flowers. Wish we could have spent more time.

Lively on Sundays. We always take an apartment in the Marais. Lots of life, shops, galleries, eating places and more. Home to the Place des Vosges, Picasso and Carnavalet museums, beautiful "hôtels particulier", Jewish quarter, numerous falafel restaurants and at its edge, the Marché des Enfants Rouges. It's not the only great quartier in Paris but it's got a lot to recommend.
Great place to walk and eat. A great neighborhood to get the best felafel, see the medieval sights and visit a vibrant neighborhood that is away from the maddening part of Paris.
Great shopping and eating. Full of homeware stores and inexpensive boutiques, Le Marais is a must-see. We ate at Les Marches des Enfants Rouge at a creole restaurant, food was exquisite!

So nice and lovely. Our first visit was on a Sunday. It was fun on that day, but almost overwhelmingly busy--because the Marais is the city's Jewish quarter, many of its shops close on Saturday and instead open on Sunday, when shops in most of the city are closed. That makes it a very popular destination on a Sunday! We returned on a Tuesday and found the neighborhood easier to navigate and enjoy.

Alas, not the same without the venerable Goldenberg's. As the Marais gets branded "boutiques" and is yuppified it loses the flavor, literally with the closing of the famous Goldenberg's restaurant , of the Jewish neighborhood it was.

Not our favorite area. So many like The Marais but it just doesn't do anything for us. Huge, busy streets (Rue de Rivoli) and a maze of streets that are kind of junky, we have walked through many times in our 10 trips to Paris.The best part is Place des Vosges and The Carnavalet Museum, both worth a visit. Add to that the Pompidou and for us that's it.I'm sure there must be a charming restaurant or 2 but we've never found them. It's filled with small falafel places.Will we walk through again? Probably, but we stayed in a hotel there once and never again.

Great Shopping and Visit Place de Voges. I love the Marais for great boutique shopping and cute cafes. I took a few friends there when showing them around Paris and it was one of their favorite neighborhoods for architecture and shopping too. Go there midday and grab lunch at a cafe or bring a sandwich and eat in Place de Voges.

Shopping Heaven. This is the place to come if you want to get some non-touristy shopping in...boutiques galore and quaint little restaurants/bars to stop in for an espresso or glass of champagne; fuel for the shopping, obviously ;)

Our favorite area. We always try to experience different parts of Paris. But we always go back to the Marais district. It is young and lively, with many good restaurants. We love to go to L'As Du Falafel. It is a very casual Israeli sandwich place. There are also fun little shops in the neighborhood to buy things.

Great Area. We love to visit Le Marais every Sunday that my wife and I are in Paris. Mostly everything is close in Paris on Sundays. Le Maria's is open and ready for business. Nice retail shopping for the young at heart. Excellent falafels. You can't miss the long line ups. It's a great couple of hours meander through the old 'Jewish' district of Paris.

One the liveliest districts in Paris!. Narrow streets, beautiful sights, museums, communities, trendy shopping, people walking or riding bicycles. Also, the jewish presence testimonies the historical side of this quartier. We loved the second hand shops and of course we found some super vintage clothes! You should not miss a nice walk there!

Always a good place to wander. The Marais is an area we always enjoy when visiting Paris. In addition to the bustling shops, there's great people watching, especially while occupying a bench in Place du Vosges. (On a beautiful day, families and school kids complete with tourists for benches and grace space.) And there are plenty of spots for picking up a snack, a coffee, or a sandwich as you wander the narrow streets. Carnevalet is a wonderful museum for checking out the artifacts of City's history.
Gorgeous architecture. Great architecture, boutique shopping and some great cafés and restaurants that you need to look for.

One of the highlights of Paris. Where to start? I love strolling through the Marais. Firstly, it has some of the most beautiful and poetic street names in the city. You will find many little restaurants/cafés/bistrots and boutique-y type shops in its little streets. Other highlights...Place des Vosges - Arguably the most beautiful city square in Paris (with all 4 architecturally identical sides facing on a beautiful garden in the middle). Victor Hugo once lived in one of the buildings hereRue des Rosiers - You'll find some excellent Jewish restaurants here (fantastic falafel)Nightlife - Many of the bars and cafés are hopping here on the weekend especially. It can become a bit noisy.

C'est jolie!. Le Marais is just a wonderful place to walk and visit old buildings. There are multiple tiny courtyards of interest. This is a very visited area which has great ambience for families or individuals.
great walking. This is my favorite area for walking in all of Paris with many excellent ethnic sites as well as avant garde clothing stores.
Interesting bustling neighbourhood. Nice neighborhood fulled with every type of shop imaginable. Locals seemed quite friendly for the most part and the food selection available was great.
Take a wander. A great are to wander around in take your time to get lost and find some of the nicest areas in Paris

Perfect place for a stroll. With this many windy streets, chic boutiques and beautiful bistros, what is not to like?? A very old and interesting part of Paris where you can go on Sunday, when the rest of the city is pretty much closed down. Strolling through the Marais for a day is like going back in time. Also a great place to practice your french!!

Stroll with a printed guide...or get lost walking...just do it. This was a rediscovery. We had visited Le Marais before, but there was something special about the experience this time. While the skies were gray, the mood was certainly not in mid-Spring. From fund cafes to great shopping, plazas, and hsitoric spots, Le Marais has something for everyone.

Tourist nonsense. Yes there are some nice restaurants and I particularly enjoyed the Jewish area with its delicious bakeries but this is very much overrated. Having read the reviews I expected a lot from this place but it turned out to be full of upper end stores like Forever 21 and COS and packed with tourists and the usual pick pockets. There's nothing charming about this place. If I wanted to shop at these stores I would have stayed at home.
Stroll, Shop & Fallafel . Great neighbourhood to wander around & browse at the lovely shops. Don't miss out on a famous L'As Du Fallafel and homemade lemonade!

Good fun. Nice to stroll around, shops and restaurants create a great atmosphere. For a fun lunch go to the L'As du Fallafel' at Rue des Rosiers, eat in is better than eating very messingly on the run. You still need to queue for a table but it goes quite quick and good value for a decent fallafel. Bon appétit! Enjoy!

Charming. Quaint area with rich history. Try walking around 6:00-9:00 p.m. when everybody is out. Don't miss Place de la Bastille with its crowded cafes, frequent music concerts in the courtyard of the Hotel de Bethune-Sully, or my favorite place to sit and people watch: Place des Vosges.
Great walking around neighborhood.. Loved the streets of the neighborhood. The shops are not too fancy and show great French styles. You can get lots of ideas just by looking in the windows.

Fabulous neighborhood. Stayed at a lovely hotel in this perfect neighborhood. Great food, relaxing cafes, exceptional parks, hidden gardens, wonderful open air market, and easy access via metro and bus.

Couldn't have stayed in a better neighborhood! . We took a chance on renting an apartment in the Marais and had a great experience! We were on Rue des Archives. There were cafes/restaurants/bars everywhere as well as shopping and markets. The metro was maybe a 5 minute walk. In the evening after a full day of sightseeing, it was an interesting and lively place to stroll.

Best area to stay in while visiting Paris. Stayed three weeks in the Marais and we were able to easily visit the whole of Paris from our great location. We were visiting family who live in the Marais and we rented a condo nearby and just fell in love with the area. There are restaurants and bakeries and shops and parks and fromageries and wine shops and fruits and vegetable stands everywhere. Metro stops and buses at every corner makes it easy to get around when you do want to go visit away places. You can easily walk to many of the famous places and museums since it is so central. Next time we go to Paris this is the area we will return to.
So lovely. I loved this area with great shops, nice buildings and surroundings. It felt very genuine and I would love to come back and have more times to stroll around here.

Great neighbourhood. Make sure you visit Le Marais on Sunday afternoons when all other neighborhoods have closed shops and Parisians flock to Marais for entertainment. Get lost on the small side streets and catch an outdoor theater piece at one of the many art schools hidden off small walkways.

Sunday shopping. besides everything you can get about Mare, you have to know one of its secrets - yes, its possible to shop here during sundays! So if you are limited in days and want to find some stores with Japanese brands or something really nice, but not so famous and classy as chanel is, you are more then welcome to shop in Mare.
