WOULDN'T STAY ANYPLACE OTHER THAN THE MARAIS.. We loved the quiet location with easy, walkable access to the Parisian highlights. Lots of charming, cozy restaurants and little shops made our visit easy and very comfortable. We wouldn't stay any place else.
No better place to stay.. Don't just visit. Lots of great hotels make this, for us, THE place to stay in Paris. Easy metro access and a world in and of itself await you in this magical place.

One of the liveliest areas in Paris. Le Marais was one of my favorite areas in Paris. A lot of the stores there remain open on SUndays when everything else is closed. I love the way there are so many things to discover there. New shops, bars and restaurants. There is also enough crowd for people watching.

Vibrant Sunday Walk. We were lucky enough to vist Marais on Sunday. It was buslty and packed as most of Paris is closed, but since Marais is the city's Jewish quarter all the stores are open on Sunday. Many of the other reviews cover most of the stores and restaurants. If you're in the mood for a very lively bustling crowd with lots of action, a jewish-mid eastern flavor and mostly local stores then go.

A superb part of Paris. From the Village of Saint Paul to the Les Vosges Squarevia all the small shops and galleries and some very old restaurants. The Marais is by far one of Paris most beautiful parts that should never be missed or skipped !!!!

History in the 4th district. The Jewish quarters, yes! But also The French revolution, nowadays The Opera Bastille. Time warp?! We spend time stroling around and browsing, taking pictures, had a glass of wine, ate around Place des Vosges& soaked up the sun in that beautiful square, reminishing about Victor Hugo and the likes... Oooh Paris!

Great walking neighborhood. La Marias is home to the orthodox jewish community in Paris. We enjoyed Falafel and strudel. Shopped in the religious stores. And, visited one of the oldest continuously operating synagogues in France. The community has a really unique environment and finds itself positioned next to a busy chic shopping district. Well worth an afternoon visit.
Paris on your skin. It's the beautiful and full of history Parisien neighborhood .Boutiques with hand made glasses to hand made chocolate .... Paradise with a metro station :)

Great neighborhood--very busy on a Sunday. We made a couple of visits to the Marais during a vacation in Paris. Our first visit was on a Sunday. It was fun on that day, but almost overwhelmingly busy--because the Marais is the city's Jewish quarter, many of its shops close on Saturday and instead open on Sunday, when shops in most of the city are closed. That makes it a very popular destination on a Sunday! We returned on a Tuesday and found the neighborhood easier to navigate and enjoy. If you can find a tour that will give you the history of the neighborhood, it's worth it. We took one with Paris Walks, an English-language tour group that meets at Metro stops. The tour was about 2 hours and really gave us a sense of the neighborhood's roots and history--fascinating stuff.The area is filled with cute shops and nice cafes. I was particularly impressed with the paper stores along Rue de Pont Louis Philippe--Papier+ and Melodies graphiques were standouts for their gorgeous cards and colorful papers.

charming neighborhood to stay, visit shop, eat. we stayed in le marais during our recent visit to paris. the neighborhood varies from end to end. we stayed near on the eastern end, which has some nice quiet residential streets, lovely shops and cafes, and of course the place des voges, which is a wonderful spot for a quiet picnic in this hectic city. of the areas we visited this was my favorite neighborhood.

Loved exploring. We stayed in a hotel on the edge of Le Marais and walked around the area every morning and night after touring the city. It was easy to access from the subway. We found great pastry shops and restaurants. The people were very friendly and helpful. We would love to stay there again.

Absolutely lovely. we stayed in the Le Marais which is very close to all main attractions but retained the neighborhood appeal - the streets were immaculate and although there were many restaurants and bars it was very quiet at night

Full of character. For our recent trip to Paris, we booked an apartment on the Rue St Antoine, at the Bastille side of the Marais. This proved to be a good choice. This area is full of character, and includes some good cheap restaurants, lovely place/squares, chocolatiers etc. Just a few hundred meters away was the Place de La Bastille, where there is a weekend market. To the North is the wonderful Place des Voges, or to the North West, the Pletzl area, full of Jewish eateries. If you are a walker, it is possible to visit St Germain and/or Notre Dame fairly easily. Along the Rue Rivoli, even the Louvre is reachable, past the Hotel de Ville. Further afield, the Champs Elysee can be reached from the St Paul Metro station.

Great neighborhood. Lively area with great shops and food especially LA's for falafel which is made fresh as you order but bring your own napkins as they only give you one and you will need it, the best falafel this side of David's in Haifa. The Jewish museum is also worth a visit.

Marais = quintessential Paris. Utterly charming. Lots of little shops, bars, cafes, bistros, boulangeries, patisseries and very neighborhoody. You'll see nannies out with their little charges, busy business people grabbing a quick espresso before work, people buying their baguette for the day, conversations going on. Very easy access to the Metro. My stop was St. Paul. There's the Place des Voges as well as Victor Hugo's house within walking distance. You might see some amateur artists at work. If you're a fan, you have to visit his house. There's also the Shoah Memorial, a museum dedicated to French jews. Sobering and heart breaking yet inspiring when you see the section devoted to the resistance and those who helped the Jews escape. Sit outside at a cafe. Walk and wander. You'll love it.

Only if you like Designers. The Marais was a huge disappointment. I have visited Paris several times and this neighborhood has been gentrified to the point of being "Disney-esque". Gone were most of the local merchants, replaced with Micheal Kors, Kate Spade, yadda-yadda. 15 euro mini cupcakes. If you have never been to Paris, sure stroll along the streets and see the well kept attractions there. You will not have a problem speaking and hearing English spoken all around you.

Free-spirited and full of hidden treasures. The Marais is one of Paris' most open-minded neighbourhoods, minus the Pigalle-ish trashiness. Plenty of small art galleries, curious shops and historical symbols. Keep on walking towards Bastille and enjoy some time at Place des Vosges.

Lodged in an apartment in the Le Marais during my stay. If there was one neighborhood to get the essence of Paris, Le Marais would be the place. I arrived at the Rambuteau station and learned that I was a 2 minute walk away from the apartment where we were staying. Even in the midst of people singing at 3am, and sharing very passionate dialogues with others it was a very pleasant stay in Le Marais. I would return to that neighborhood again because of its authenticity.

A lovely view of Paris.. Fascinating area. Don't miss the Shoah Memorial, a difficult and heart wrenching experience, but a must see. Place de Vosges is stunning, walking under the Cloistered promenade, we encountered good musicians playing, and refreshing art galleries. Just sitting in Rue Antoine and watching the world go by is a worthwhile pastime.

nice stroll. have the time just to wander around with no defined route. Get the ambience of Paris (despite the tourists) in a well maintained neighbourhood. Don´t miss place des Vosges, and if you are hungry, taste a Falafel.
lovely trendy gay friendly area. So much better and more Parisian than Champs d'Elysee. Nicer people, nicer shops. Pleasant walk to the Notre Dame Cathedral.
Stop and Enjoy a Felafel. The Marais is a fun place to walk around and window shop. Stop and enjoy an authentic felafel at one of the many sit down or take away places.

Great neighbourhood. We stayed in this area and would highly recommend it. It has a village-like atmosphere but all the major attractions are walkable from here. We almost always returned to the area for dinner after a busy day sight-seeing.

Great Area of Paris to Stay and Visit. We stayed at a hotel positioned right at the junction of the Marais and Bastille neighborhoods. We were walking distance to all of the major sight in the Marais. It is quieter and more residential than the more tourist focused parts of Paris (like around the Louvre area), but still busy and full of beauty and history. Don't miss visiting the Carnavalet Museum that provides an excellent history of Paris ( and best of all , it's free). The walking tour of the Jewish Quarter is also a must see; old Paris at its finest. Many great cafés to stop for lunch and a late afternoon glass of beer or wine.

Lively and interesting...don't miss the Pompidou. Very lively area, lots of shops, restaurants, and a huge department store right near the Hotel de Ville metro stop that was much more affordable than Le Bon Marche. If you like modern art, or even think you might, be sure to go to the Pompidou. The Nikki de St. Phalle and Jean Tingley fountain outside is wonderful...kids would love it! Inside, there was a huge variety of art and it was the least crowded and quietest of all the museums we visited. And the views from the upper floors are amazing.

A great area to stay. We rented an apartment in this area, just one block from rue Saint Antoine. Everything was so convenient . Metro M1, Fromagerie Laurent DuBois, Aux Desirs Manon, Petite Versailles boulangerie, and Monoprix grocery store all within 2-3 blocks. Restaurants, cafés and take out places all close by. You can get good falafels in the upper MARAIS. You can walk to Notre Dame easily.

A must do walk. We stayed on the isle de louis and walked in several times in the week both to have food and seek out clubs.le Maris has something for everyone but we didn't find much raucousness just people enjoying their space.we had food at two little cafes which were both good parisian food.a beer at one cafe in the afternoon turned into a great conversation with locals.I do recommend reading all the menus around you to get an ideas of prices and dishes.I used french inion soup as my base for price as it is simple and so should be priced accordingly.those that were too much we stayed away from.however I ate it three times in paris and each time it was different!Amazing on the different takes people have on such a simple dish.I am looking forward to coming back to paris and Le Marias.have a ball Mike

Great location for long stay. We rented an apartment in Le Marais for three months, Jan to Mar 2014 and, when we go back, we'll stay in the same area. Lots of great restaurants close by, good shopping, a superb open air market at Le Bastille, and easy walking to the Louvre, Ile St. Louis, and Blvd St. Germain. Plus the metro stops are close by. As is Place des Vosges, the most beautiful square in Paris. Excellent location for short or long stay.

Delightful neighborhood. On our recent trip to Paris...everyone was advising us on staying in the Latin Quarter or St. Germaine...however...my husband loves to experience authentic neighborhoods when traveling. He chose a flat in Le Marais. It was more then a wonderful experience. The atmosphere...the shops, the cafés...perfect for the experience we were hoping for!
A tourist show.. Tourists watching tourists eating falafels. Not very interesting shops. Lots of people. Wouldn't recommend it.

Last Tango in Paris?. Busy area but the heart of Paris. Plenty of pedestrian only streets with dozens of small shops. Delicious cheeses, crepes, etc. Plan a day there. Dicey at night but lots of action.
Enjoying the evening Looking at Hotel de ville. This area is posh, hotel de ville, centre Pompidou just a stone throw. We sat down for a while after along walk infront of hotel de ville
le marais. undiscovered gem with no crowds we did the free walk with we gowalkingtours.well worth it the place des voges is amazing also very interesting jewish history to the quarter

J'aime Le Marais!. We rented an apartment on Rue du Bourg Tibourg for a week in May. We had heard from others and also read that Le Marais was a good neighborhood to stay in when visiting Paris. Spot on! There was a small supermarket across from our apartment, lots of shops and cafes and bakeries within a stone's throw, and easy access to several train stations. Everyone treated us well, and we felt quite safe walking out and about. I would absolutely recommend that area to a friend, and I already dream of returning!
cosy, trendy & great for a sunday in Paris. super cosy, trendy, upcoming neighbourhood, go there on a sunday since all the shops are open and go for the best falafel in the world at "l'as du falafel"

We loved this area. This was our first visit to Paris and stayed in the Marais. We walked a ton while there and visited a lot of different neighbourhoods. We always felt safe, no matter the time. We loved the restaurants and the shopping in this area.

One of the oldest parts of Paris. We walked to Le Marais (The Marsh in French) from the Eglise Saint-Sulpice (a several kilometer walk). Originally a royal enclave, Le Marais evolved into a Jewish quarter when the royals moved out. The area has evolved since WW II. It still features many art galleries, the Pompidou and Picasso Museums are there (the Picasso is still closed for renovation) and many small antique shops. Since the 1980s, the area has become more eclectic, it seems to have become the principal district for Paris' gay population. Be sure to visit the little shops in Village St. Paul, the Place des Voges and the Hotel Carnavalet (see separate reviews).

Favorite place in Paris!. This area of Paris is rich with Jewish history. It was predominantly empty after World War II and rebuilt into a highly Jewish populated area. It is home to a Holocaust Museum, and many Orthodox businesses. It is also an excellent area for shopping and dining, very quaint. Hands down my favorite area in all of Paris!
Beautiful. The Le Marais was a wonderful area/district with great boutiques, food,cafés. It's the most sought after and I can see why!
Rue de Rosiere, Jewish neighborhood. The Marais has a street called Rue de Rosiere which offers many different choices of Kosher cuisine in Paris. You can taste the best croissants on Earth.

Place de Vosges -- picturesque, historic and now a magnet for the chic. The Marais bustles with life and diversity. Once an undesirable ghetto, it now is fashionable and a magnet for the chic and artistic. Place de Vosges has great galleries and restaurants at ground level (protected from the elements) and a beautiful little park in the center of the square. This is a neighborhood to stroll, shop, sit in an outdoor cafe for a coffee or apertif and watch the fashionable world go by. Do not miss it.

Marvelous Marais. One of my favorite places in the world! Bought a piece of a Paris apartment here in 2010. Enjoyable walks, cafes, shops, sites, museums and world class people watching year round (and always on Sundays when some streets pedestrian only).

a good stroll. well this place is in the centre of paris a good place for just visitng n discovergin paris old paris n some musems n having a good stroll n ofcourse with good food not that expensive abordable food and u hve american diners also i nthe corner for a good heavy burger n taht a good place to visit once while u in paris

Ahh, Le Marais. Le Marais is a nice place to walk and window shop. Ate lunch at a little restaurant with great service. It rained and slipped into a beautiful church. All the people in Le Marais were friendly and helpful. Get your camera out, beautiful old building, flowers galore and small cobblestone sidestreets.
best of paris. shopping and eating equals le marais. where else can you eat the best falafels outside of Israel. its a very friendly place to wander around and feel so welcome

Meander through Le Marais!. Every time we visit Paris, this is one of our first stops. A messy falafel, a bit of history at Musee Carnavalet or the Picasso museum and shopping at Cos are a great way to spend an afternoon.
Walking Tour of the Marais. This was a truly wonderful walk; just did not get enough history. Beautiful buildings, colorful flowers, great markets, just fun! Favorite location.
Walking tour. took a walking tour with Adeline (Esprit de Paris) and she was wonderfully interesting and showed us hidden gems in the Marais district - I would definitely recommend a tour with her.

Great home base while in Paris. This was a perfect place to stay in the city! We rented an apartment not far from the Saint Paul metro stop, so we were just minutes away from most attractions. Also just a short stroll to Place de Vosges, Notre Dame, and other great sites. Lots of restaurants, little shops, and practical stuff like a grocery store.

An unspoiled and not touristy aerea in Paris.. Loved the narrow streets, the Brasseries on the corners where you can sit outside without all the traffic to hear and see as you have a lot of other places in Paris. Nice small shops. A part of Paris I have not been to before, and and I loved it.

Have to visit. The area is bustling with people. Great shops and is open on Sundays. Many cafes to enjoy lunch. Some French designers have their shops there such as Sandro who discounts his prices 40% from the prices in the U.S.A.
quaint, hsitoric and a must. just walk along rue des Rosiers and other small streets. just try falafel at L'As du falafe. An experience !!

Interesting neighbourhood. Check out this neighbourhood and discover its friendly ambience and worm bars and cafes. At night very vivid and full of nightclubs which you can access for free. Take your time to just walk around and appreciate the great architecture and smiling locals!
Great area to stay whilst in Paris. Whenever i visit Paris i always stay in Le Marais,i feel it is the best place to stay,very central,great shops,hotels,and great eateries.

Just wander. The Marais is made for those who like to wander around and discover. Macaroons, Pastis, stroll by shopping and great restaurants. Wear comfortable shoes since you will not want your explorations to end too soon.
Nice area. Lovely area with great shops, nice buildings and surroundings. It felt very genuine and I would love to come back and have more times to stroll around here.

Traveling back in time.... The Marais is a must-see neighborhood in central Paris. One of the oldest squares, the Place des Vosges, is found here, surrounded by colonnades, and where Victor Hugo once lived and wrote. You'll find the Victor Hugo museum here. When I fisrt visited Paris, I brought my six-month old baby there for a visit to the park, and it was then that I discovered how much French people love babies! Everyone was charming and cheerful. The area is full of lovely boutiques, and there are cafés and restaurants where you can sit and absorb the atmosphere. I highly recommend a visit!

Hotel Palace de Vogues. La Place Royale or any other sidewalk Bar, and there are plenty in these Corridors, is a great place to have a drink and people watch. A Vodka tonic for two will cost you $24 and is a nice afternoon break.
Interesting area. Mixture of shops, restaurants and visitors made it a fascinating area to visit. Didn't have time to visit the Jewish Museum, but will do on our next visit
just loved it!. although i have visited Paris 3 times , this was my first time at Marais.I loved it!The ambience, the little shops, the restaurants and cafes all have a special flair ..
Fun neighborhood. Lots of color and action; fun restaurants, bars and cute shops. Easy, walkable neighborhood. Jazz bands playing on a couple of corners; great sitting at a cafe soaking it all up!

Just a great way to spend an afternoon. This area of Paris around the Place des Vosges in full of small restaurants, bars, boutiques, galleries,... Wandering around without any specific direction is simply one of the best ways to spend an afternoon in Paris.

Great place to go on Sunday. Lots of shops and restaurants to wander round. If you want lunch or a coffee turn down one of the side streets and you will find cafés where the residents go and pay 50% less for food and drinks. You can walk out of the Marais to place de Vosges which is worth visiting the art for sale here and is fascinating and can be very tempting. The restaurants in the main parts are packed from 12 to 3 on a Sunday.

Great for browsing the individual shops. A criss cross of streets and lanes hiding designer and individual boutiques, as well as cafes and museums. While away half a day browsing and window shopping, and visit some of the art galleries and Place des Vosges while you're there

This is now our favorite neighborhood in Paris!. I don't remember who it was that suggested that we base our recent stay in Paris in the Marais district. But once we found an affordable boutique hotel there (Ecole Centrale Hotel), it was a natural thing to spend a day exploring the district, and we were instantly in love!Rue St. Antoine, the Village St. Paul, Place des Vosges, Rue des Francs Bourgeois, the cafes, Musee Carnavalet, and on and on. Then on the northern side of the district - our hotel was right near the intriguing Musee des Arts et Metiers, and we had wonderful breakfasts at the Cafe of the same name, and we walked down the Rue Turbigo with its many restaurants as well.If we ever completely lost our minds and decided we wanted to live in Paris, we would without question want to live in the Marais. Is it affordable to live there? Probably not - although the northern part (the 3rd arrondissement) is probably more residential and affordable than the southern part (the 4th) with all its medieval village feeling and so forth.

Living history: past, present and future. Le Marais is an area that you can spend weeks or months exploring - a day is just the starter. Great food, off-beat stores, locals living parisian life. Wander and enjoy!

A Jewel of a neighborhood. Wonderful neighborhood with lots of great cafes and shopping.
The original old Jewish neighborhood with ethnic foods.

a different Paris. We followed the tips in a magazine about where to visit while in the Haut- Marais. We most enjoyed the corner of Rue de Bretagne and Rue de Charlot. Sit in the outdoor cafe Charlot for a cafe au lait and croissant avec marmalade. We struck a conversation with a film producer showcasing a film in Cannes, saw incredibly well dressed people, families, shopclerks from our window on Parisian life.
Quaint & Chic. We loved strolling through this area... we got off at the Bastille stop on the Metro and walked to it. Make sure to stop at the felafel store for a tasty treat!
beautiful place for an afternoon stroll. What a beautiful place to take a leisurely stroll in the quiet of the afternoon. This is a special spot not to be missed.

A Lovely walk. Come with a map and an appetite and be prepared to wander. A lovely neighbourhood to walk and explore - pretty architecture, food, museums, shopping and people watching. Definitely worth your time.

Right place for mid-range shopping. I stayed in St Germain Area for my 1 week trip in Paris, but I found Le Marais neighbourhood more to my liking. It is definately a bigger and more crowded area than St Germain but the mid-range shops, departmental stores and range of cusine makes Le Marais a more conducive place to stay and visit. You can easily spend a day just walking around and window shop at Marais, St Germain is a smaller area, more personable with cosy cafes and restaurants and upmaket shopping. If I come back to Paris someday, I will want to try staying at Le Marais Area.

Awesome place to shop,drink and hangout. Ok, this area is one big tourist trap. I have drank and eaten at all the brassiere in Paris, and this area charges the most. Sometimes 6 or 7 euro on food items. Be aware.

probably the best thing to do on a Sunday. all stores and restaurants are open and if you are not in a shopping mood, museums, gardens and galleries will feed you from the place des vosges to the Musee Picasso (if it re-opens one day)

It was nearly razed to the ground!. This was a wealthy district in Paris in the 1600s. When king Louis XIV moved his court to Versailles in the latter part of the century, the courtiers had to follow and some of their beautiful 'hotel particuliers' (town mansions) fell into disrepair. The houses were taken over by less well-off people and the area became such that there was talk of destroying and modernizing some parts. The minister for culture Andre Malraux saved the Marais in the 1960s, pointing out what heritage it contained and it was restored. Narrow streets of medieval tracing and proportions alternate with beautiful facades. See, if you only have limited time, the lovely Place des Vosges with the pink brick and stone facade, and the Musee Picasso housed in one of the former mansions. Good for a leisurely wander taking in the meandering streets
Great area to spend the afternoon. Excellent food with great variety of Jewish food. Good small shops to browse. Enjoyed walking through the whole area.
Our home away from home. We rented an apartment there this past week- second time around. What a fantastic neighborhood to stay in or visit. A true treat.
wonderful neighborhood to visit. walking around, visit the museums, visit the lovely little stores. A calm place, not far from the city centre.

Great Area to Explore. Le Marais is a wonderful area to explore. The is lots of history here as well as charming shops, galleries and restaurants. You can see the Place de la Bastille, which is a busy traffic circle today, a Picasso Museum, tour the house where Victor Hugo once lived in Place des Vosges with its red brick and stone facades built in the early 1600s, visit the old Jewish Quarter which was established in the 13th century where today you can find great pastry and falafel - Chez Hanna is very good.

Wonderful area. There is something to see at each turn - providing you make the right turn! I strongly recommend a tour of the area. It doesn't have to be expensive. Discover Tours is a free (but tip supported) tour by locals or simply type into your browser "self guided walking tours of Marais district" and various options and routes will be presented. There are so many diverse and wonderful things to see - and remember Marais area is open on Sundays when Paris city is closed.

Comes Alive on Sunday. By now, Le Marais is no secret. It's jam packed with restaurants, cafes and shopping and filled with Parisians and visitors alike. It's a wonderful scene and a must to visit and a fantastic place to base yourself in Paris.What we didn't know before we stayed is that Le Marais is one of the few neighborhoods that is open and alive on Sunday's. Unlike the rest of Central Paris everything is open for business and Parisian's are out enjoying their weekend in Le Marais.

No longer authentic. Le Marias used to be a quiet and elegant area for walks admiring the renaissance architecture. Now the place seemed to be swamped by tourists and even the old shops are converting to cater for mass toursim. Not quite coach loads of package tourists but it's getting there.
Another side of Paris. Stroll along Le Marais on a slow day. Visit the Place de Vosges, a square that Thomas Jefferson said was the most perfect in the world. Yes, THAT Thomas Jefferson.

Great Walk. We walked through the Marais several times as we were staying on Ile St Louis. It is vibrant, alive with people having a good time. We enjoyed the art galleries, the old Jewish area, the cafes and mostly the atmosphere.

A must-see in Paris. and my favorite borough to browse along when the sun is out...one of the oldest bourough of the capital : full of clothes stores, places to eat. (one) of the oldest houses in town as well as middle ages typical ones are located rue François Miron, 2 minutes away from st paul metro station.rue des rosiers is the street full of jewish stores, really nice as well.10 minutes away or " filles du calvaire" metro top on line 8, there is the oldest open air market in town, le marché des enfants rouges ( closed on monday).. a nice place to explore for a lunch. but you'd better be patient...

Lovely neighbourhood. Quiet and calm, its a lovely neighbourhood. Place des Vosges is particularly impressive (check out Victor Hugo's apartment, free to visit). Beautiful shops, nice restaurants and less touristy than other Paris neighbourhoods.

Marais Walk. We did a Rick Steve's guidebook walk through the Marais, starting at the Bastille Metro stop, and ending at the Pompideau. On a sunny afternoon, just a perfect outing. Delis, galleries, great people watching.
Bustling!. A very busy place in the evening for the gay community. Visited Le Cox and Spycee clubs. The drinks were well prices and music brilliant.
Street Scenes. A busy, bustling neighborhood in the heart of Paris. Spend an hour or two walking, dining, and just soaking in the flavor of one of the most unique sections of the city.

So chic. Once upon a time it was the jewish neighborhood - there are no jews anymore Once upon a time it was the gay district - there are no gays anymoreOnce upon a time, the gouvernement wanted to destroy this old,smelly neighborhood,- it is now restored with amazing taste and luxury.I am a bit nostlagic of the Marais before it became a line up of expensive cloth shops and strollers, families and bobos...but I must admit this is perhaps the most beautiful part of Paris, with buildings going back to the 15th century everywhere...

Place des Vosges. This quarter is very nice, a little bit cheaper than downtown. It´s nice just to walk there. You must visit Place des Vosges where is house where Victor Hugo lived. Also there are lots of old former palaces in this quarter.

So Much to See and Do. Le Marais is an intriguing quarter, which has been steadily evolving over the years. There are beautiful, historic buildings like the Hotel de Soubise (an old Parisian mansion), the Musee Carnavalet and the Place des Vosges.There are traditional shops and eateries in the Jewish Quarter, but it's also true to say that the area around Rue des Rosiers is now much changed, with modern paving and upmarket boutiques replacing some of the famous old businesses such as the Librarie du Marais and the fomer Goldenberg's restaurant.It is still a fascinating and charming area to explore though, and your visit there will be time well spent.
Lovely shopping. If you like to walk and window shop, this is the place to be. Interesting shops include Merci, cotelac. Don't forget to stop by at Popelini's for the choux pastry.

best neighborhood. we rented and apartment there and eve loved the location. Small streets, cafes, modern people, ortodox jewish, all mixed. Love it. We found great places to eat, best boulangerie, Picard (if you rent an apartment must buy food there) and the best was to walk in the streets. Always somewhere new to go.

beautiful medieval quarter. Gorgeous area of Paris to stay in. Many cafes & beautiful historical buildings. Quite clean and felt safe walking around at night. We have stayed in Paris 3 times & this area is our favourite.
The place to stay for walkers. This area is close to all the places regular visitors to Paris like. And the restaurants and shopping aren't bad either
Beautiful District. Do not miss this area! Home to winding cobblestone streets, many outdoor cafés . Loaded with magnificent architecture , shopping and parks. I fell in love with this area.
Lovely neighbourhood. Perfect area for just chilling and walking around, eating a falafel, listening to the buskers, talking with your frinds, going into small second hand shops etc.
Mariage tea shop. Always make an effort to visit this venue - they do over 400 teas - I had Violette with violet and raspberry macarons. This is the original shop although there are many more.

Great area to explore and stay. Wonderful laneways, great shops, cafes and restaurants, excellent little surprises every time you turn a corner - the perfect area for exploration, and a great place to stay!
Ideal for sundays. Beatiful area with many parks, Jewish restaurants, famous shops and many galleries. A good alternative for sunday, where all other shops in Paris are closed

Go for a walk. Armed with a guide book, we set off to have a walk around the Marais. So much to see, so much history, coming from Australia, where history is comparitively short. No shortage of good food.

so many beautiful buildings and historic sites. If you have a detailed guide of Paris, be sure to wander through the narrow streets of the Marais. Many beautiful places! Good restaurants . And as I understand it, this place is very popular with Parisians themselves - Sunday huge number of people with their entire families walking the streets.

Very touristy, but worth a few hours. Big difference from my last trip (March 2002). The streets near the Place de Vosges and the park itself was full of tourists on a Sunday afternoon and the shops seem more "chain" and touristy than authentic. However, it's a pleasant way to spend a few hours walking around, admirng the architecture, and finding a boulangerie a few blocks from the tourist zone where you can get a wonderful pastry or baguette sandwich for 3-5E.

Le Marais district~. Go "window licking", as the French say for "window shopping" in the Marais district of Paris! There are many adorable shops and the walks though out this area are a pleasure for the eye.

Great neighborhood.. Interesting, artsy, the old and new blended together in a small enough area to explore easily...lots of variety in excellent small restaurants/brasseries for a variety of tastes....more informal and casual than some of the other areas.

The happening place in Paris. Just go! Young and fun and buzzy! My favorite place in the city.
We loved it!! We would compare it to Soho, Tribeca, in NY.
Walk around the Marais. Just lovely to walk around and look in the shops and people watch. Narrow streets, small shops and cafes. Lovely.

Wonder around and explore this neighborhood. One of my favourite places on my recent trip with my partner.
Lots of independent shops and bars and a few other know brands thrown in.
So many restaurants to choose from too.
I interesting bars, fancy chocolate shops, great peole watching.
Loved this area.
Living there for 17 days. Wonderful area, very central to everything. Fantastic restaurants and corner bars. Easy metro access

Lovely area. What a lovely area, easily my favourite part of Paris. If you are getting a cab, ask them to drop you at the junction of Rue Vieille du Temple and Rue des Quatre-Fils (it is a big area) or if on the metro arrive at Saint- Paul and head to Saint-Sébastien – Froissart via Rue Vieille du Temple and the surrounding streets. There are some great shops and cafes, we also found that the further north we went the more local the place felt with some nice bars on the way to Saint-Sébastien – Froissart and Oberkampf, if that is still classed as Le Marais. Enjoy!

One of my favourite Parisian neighbourhood. I generally go to the Marais to check shows at various galleries, but also to buy great art books at Mona Lisait. This area is quirky and fun to discover. Too bad that the traditional neighbourhood merchants are squeezed out and replaced by another overpriced boutique.

Beautiful place to amble around. True Paris. This area is amazing and true Paris. Lovely small streets, cafes, brasseries, shops including boutique and named brand. We loved this area and felt we really were on holiday. Easily accessible from everywhere too.

The Old Grandeur. My only regret is that we could only spend a few hours in Marais. It is such a delightful neighborhood. When we were there on April13th, they had the Antiques festival for two days in small shops and alleys. We didn't buy anything but just walking around was interesting enough to love this part of Paris. The cobblestone streets and magnificent old buildings with cafes on street level were picture perfect.

Don't plan too much - just walk around and sit in one of the restaurants. No need to plan too much for this neighbourhood visit.Just walk along saint germain street and enjoy the atmosphere.Find a nice cafe and sit there looking at people walking down the street - this is where the real fun is...

Discovery walking tour. Very interesting. About two hours long. Good stories and facts about the area w/ lots of tips on shopping, eating etc. Tour guide Sara was very knowledgable and kept the very large group moving and on task!

Great architecture shame about the bland international stores. Enjoyed the architecture and historical feel but felt that (as in many European cities) the original local character has really suffered from the plethora of 'upmarket' bland international chain stores. However still a good area to stay with the choice of restaurants and general atmosphere.
wonderful!. a beautiful place to visit in Paris! There are many small shops to visit and they are also open on Sunday!

From swamp to quintessential Paris neighborhood. Yes, the word 'marais' in French means 'swamp', because that's what used to be on this spot a few hundred years ago. But then the bigwigs moved in, built a few grand hôtels (big, BIG mansions), and the place filled up with shops and restaurants. Then it went into a long decline. But it was still home to a great deal of the Jewish population in Paris ... until the Nazis rolled into the city and carted every Jew off to the concentration camps. Awful stuff. But many Jews returned, and the neighborhood started to come back to life. Starting in the late 20th century, though, the Marais became the gay neighborhood, and we all know what happens after that - massive gentrification. The Marais is where you come to get a feel for old Paris, with medieval-like tight streets, winding this way and that; where everyone walks or sits in cafés; where you wind up trying to select which wonderful restaurant to have dinner at on any particular evening. The hotels in this neighborhood have typically small rooms, but with wooden rafters, French doors and beautiful appointments, they tend to be very, very homey. Some newer hotels, like the Jules et Jim, are modernism personified and perhaps more fun for the younger crowd. There's something here for every sensibility, and the neighborhood definitely caters to the more modern trends; there's a reason why they built the Pompidou Center in the Marais. Yet the old world exists in the craft of the restauranteurs (suggested: Le Bouledogue), the authentic nature of the patisseries (e.g. Huré and Pain de Sucre on Rue Rambuteau) and the crafts, from places where you can have your own belt made, to leather bags that are made by hand. It's been my favorite neighborhood in Paris for 25 years, and it's where I rent an apartment when I come to town, to better enjoy being a part of the ebb and flow of the Marais.

Le Nicest Neighbourhood. Filled with cute boutiques and a wide variety of ethnic restaurants, le Marais is a great district to stay in, especially if you can find an apartment to rent. Everything, including the metro is within walking distance and the louvre is a short bus ride away. If you can, stay there!
Great location. We have an apt for two weeks which was recommended to us and which we got via home a way.co.uk. The 4th, Metro Saint Paul so easy access and good walking everywhere.

perfect area. would definitely stay again.. the area is the 3rd er. great location for easy walking to all of the major attractions. several metro stations but you don't really need it. Paris is smaller than we thought. it seems easier to walk around Paris than it does London. lots of Plat de jour bistros for arounf 15e. highly recommend chilling on the lawns of the Place de Vosges. if looking for accomodation consider high floors for the best views and there are plenty around this area with many 19th century hotels and apartments.

Fantastic Walk. A lovely area to walk around. Interesting buildings, lovely individual, small shops. Jewish Quarter for good food. Small, quiet, squares to sit and relax. Also in Place des Vosges. Small cafes for coffee.
Historic district revived. Enjoyed walking around and eating in a local kosher deli/restaurant Lovely shops Beautiful Place des Vosges

Lifestyle of ordinary "Parisiens" plus the Jewish community. Went to beautiful Place de Vosges first to the house of Victor Hugo. It was a sunny spring day and everyone relaxed in the parc inside the square. I got myself a delicious icecreme round the corner then headed back to the park and relaxed under the trees. Then walked along the Rue des Francs Bourgois and along Rue des Rosieres. Wonderful athmosphere and so many highly interesting small shops. Busy with locals not only tourists.
Lovely morning's stroll!. Well worth a couple of hours, including people watching in St Catherine's Place. Place des Voges also lovely.
Favorite arrondissement in Paris. Having spent 12 days, all over Paris, this was by far my favorite neighborhood. It is full of galleries, markets, cafes, and historic architecture.
A Sunday Stroll. On sunday's the Marais is closed to traffic and the shops are all open. The food in the area that you can't go past is the kebabs, but be warned you will have to wait.

An adult Disneyland. When you're little, walking around Disneyland is a magical, slightly bewildering, experience. Everything you see transports you to another place, another time, a world of infinite possibility. Walking around the Marais recaptures that sense of wonder and delight for adults. From the countless cafes and restaurants, where I've had some of the best meals in my life (and at affordable prices!) to cathedrals and simple streets that seem to have been lifted out of the past just to be presented to me - or to transport me back - wandering in the Marais is a visual feast the even the rest of Paris is hard put to equal.

Don't miss Rue Rambuteau. Rue Rambuteau is a mostly pedestrian street full of restaurants and interesting local shops, buzzing with life, make sure you walk this as part of your visit to the Marais district, so nice to avoid traffic.
Wonderful quarter, nice bistros/restaurants and interesting shops. I always enjoy to stroll in the Marais area, enjoy the people out on the street and explore interesting little shops.

Lovely area.. We have just returned from a week break here and its a lovely area. Nice food shops a great market near the Bastille. The shops are lovely lots of unique art, jewellery, clothes and gifts. We also noticed a lack of gypsy beggars which made a nice change. If we go back we will definitely stop in the area again.

A New Latin Quarter. Our fourth long visit to Paris, 15 days, and we decided to leave the Latin Quarter and St Germain area for less expensive and more local areas. Le Marais is wonderful. There are very nice restaurants (we are not 5 star people) with good prices and the apartments are very affordable by Paris standards. The area is younger and more French, you may need to speak a couple of words, or be skilled at pointing, to get what you want in certain stores, but that is part of the charm. You are in France, learn a little of the language and enjoy the culture.

Busy but not stuffed with Tourists. We stayed in the northern Marais and really loved the area. As long as you don't get too close to the Seine it's mostly locals and independently owned shops. I picked up a couple of beautiful scarves for 20 euro at one shop, yes, you can pick up one for 5 euro beside Notre Dame...but they won't be as pretty! Walking through the Marais really made me appreciate how over-commercialized the US is. The streets are very close and it's difficult to stay on the sidewalk sometimes, so I would really recommend a stroll through the Marais if you're pushing a stroller, but honestly I wouldn't recommend pushing a stroller anywhere in Paris.

Just loved it!. A group of us visited Paris and stayed in the Marais district, and absolutely loved it - great bars, restaurants, lovely independent shops. Wonderful little streets to wander around, and little parks to sit in. Easy access to all the major Paris attractions, yet quite peaceful with a "village" feel to it. Next time we visit Paris we would definitely stay in this area.
Amazing. I fell in love with the neighborhood. the local food and clothes shops were adorable. shop there, champs elysees is so over rated.

Lively. This is the place to stay if you want to see local cafe society at night. Plenty of bars, some interesting shops and a perfect square kept largely as it was when first built. Somewhere the students go to hang out on the grass and the children play in the sandpits

We always love this area. I cannot think of anything to dislike about Le Marais and some streets such as the Rue de Turenne have improved notably in the past few years. There is more than the Place des Vosges, though it is so relaxing to sit and watch the world go by as we did on a warm March day. I would advise visitors to find a walking guide, plan the day and make sure to take in the Hotel du Sully and Hotel de Sens.

Hip, funky area with lots to do. Ironically, this is the area where my boyfriend and I realised we had lost our passports and had nowhere to stay/not much money left, but we still managed to have a brilliant time wandering the streets. Le Marais has beautiful old school apartments, quirky shops, cafes and a mix of authentic Parisians. It is not so touristy as some other areas in Paris (considering we were there in July), yet still has some wonderful tourist attractions such as the Musee Carnavelet, and Victor Hugo's house. Unfortunately, our circumstances prevented us from visiting these, but our time in Le Marais was still lovely and memorable.

A great place to visit.. I live in Las Vegas and almost every year I travel to Paris.I love the Marais area. A wonderful place to walk around. I usually have a nice lunch and then walk around and shop. Small and very interesting stores are opening up almost every month. I think this area is the best place for clothes in Paris. Very chic and very original !!I usually stay at the Hotel du 7th Art on St. Paul. A small but wonderful place. I walk from the Marais down St. Antoine to the Bastille. This is a very interesting place. Reminds me of Union Square in NYC. Lots of people around and they are either protesting or gathering in groups to talk politics and such. I sometimes have lunch and sit outside and watch it all.If you are staying in another area of Paris, take the Metro line 1 to St. Paul or to Bastille.
friendly neighborhood!. We walked all around-- cute shops, nice restaurants, and a great bookstore. The sculpture area next to Centre Pompidou is really fun and a nice place to sit/relax.
Nice walk. It's a nice area to relax and walk around. You'll find one lane streets with shops at both sides and less tourists.

Away from the crowds. Lovely little side streets filled with small art galleries, bistros classy boutiques. Architecture amazing. Good photo opportunities. Visit the Place de Vosges, Picasso museum and Jewish quarter.

Fantastic first visit to Paris. Loved the Marais (when can we move here?)! We stressed out about where to stay in Paris. Our likes tend to be the following: Stay out of areas that are commercial or overrun by tourists. Be near the action, not in it. Close to public transportation. Withing walking distance of a few major sites.Be in a very historic area that has not been completely gentrified. Find a place to stay that won't break the budget. The above is what we found in the Marias. Our street had 2 bakeries, a couple of small cafes, one restaurant that was beyond fabulous, a few ethnic eateries that were out of this world, fruit stand, small grocery store, a couple of wine shops, a meat shop, a fish shop and a place to stay that was very reasonable (small, yes but it was a clean apartment with a kitchen, washer 1 bedroom, large bathroom, looking into a tiny courtyard and best of all...the quietest place I have ever slept).I will always stay in this area when visiting Paris in the future.
Interesting but not as much fun as we had expected. This area was fun but somehow seemed a bit down at heal and grubby. Still worth a visit though if you have time.
Place des Vosges. Stunning! This has to be one of the most beautiful squares in the world. Amazing history, architecture, cool galleries and shops and cafes.

Nice neighborhood to stroll. I really enjoyed strolling the neighborhood in Marais...nice shops and restaurants with many quaint pedestrian streets. The cafes were very crowded because we went on a Sunday because everyone says that this district is lively on Sunday unlike so many other parts of Paris that completely shut down on Sunday. There were even some street musicians. There are Pizza places, traditional French cafes, and gelato.

Love it!. Cute very Paris-ish neighbourhood, with very nice cafes and shops. It's worth a stroll while in Paris, excellent option on a Sunday, since everything here is open! Nice designer shops and little plazas where people just lay in the grass and read a book or have a snack. Don't miss it!

shops and restaurants near Notre Dame and Louvre. This neighborhood had a major department store, which was fun to visit in another country. It also had many, many more small shops and restaurants. Many of the stores we saw on Champs Elysee were here too. Also, good people watching.

Best neighbourhood to stay in Paris. We stayed in the northern part of the Marais for the month of September. It is hands down my favourite neighbourhood in Paris. It is very safe and centrally located. We could walk to the bastille, Republic or the Seine within 20 mins. There are so many great cafes and restaurants, not to mention the best shopping in Paris! I would only ever stay in this arrondissement!
A busy area.. We visited Le Maraus on Sunday, all the shops and cafés were open as the businesses are mainly owned by the Jewish Community.It was lively and all the restaurants and cafés were busy.
Charming Environment. Le Marais area is wonderful to walk and explore with lots of small restaurants, beautiful boutiques, small hotels and historic charm.

Very Paris. Spent half a day in Marais and have the best of paris. Place was filled with vibe and at the same time nice to sit along the street and enjoy the city. Plenty of cafe and fruit and vege shops. We got off at St. paul metro and walked along the Bastille and also all the way to Pompidou. Really liked the falafel shops along.

Lose yourself in the Marais!. I loved just wandering around the streets of the Marais, exploring the little boutiques and wishing I could eat in every single restaurant or drink in every single cafe! Not as touristy as other parts of Paris, it's the area that made me fall in love with the city.

Sundays at Le Marais. I loved everything about that Sunday at Le Marais !The streets were bobbling with cult people !We were lucky to find also a indoor handcrafts market with incredibly nice French made jewels, clothes, art,etc. We ate at Le Philosophe wich had an informal atmosphere and good food.
Lovely neighborhood stroll. We spent an entire afternoon shopping in vintage boutiques and high-end shops, drinking wine while people-watching, and enjoying fantastic falafel from a local stand.
Walking Tour. We did a great walking tour around this area. The guide was a Parisienne and had amazing knowledge of the area. The tour was free - the guides expect tips!

Lively mix of fashion and food. Staying in The Marais for the first time after 3 previous visits to. Paris and fining the great mix of restaurants, fashion and home wares shops, cafés and proximity to everything fantastic! Can run along the Seine in the morning to Jardin des tuillieries, hop across to the Ile de la cite and a stones throw form so many historic sites!

An historic area still very alive.. Le Marais is not only the trendy-fashion-gay-healthy-famous place des Vosges. It is also one of the oldest neighbourhods of Paris with its locals and its ordinary life. You can visit one of the most beautiful squares in the world, the Place des Vosges (XVII th Century) or one of the oldest houses of the city (XIVth Century) like if you were in a movie. There are also old aristocratic palaces like the Carnavalet museum and entire streets from the XVII th century. Also the old jewish city was there -and is still there with its kasher restaurants, shops and cafés. There are also many fashion boutiques in bobo style open on Sundays so the Parisians come in the Marais for Sunday brunch and shopping. Come in the morning because in the afternoon the streets are crowded.

Le Marais - must-see part of Paris. Atmospheric part of Paris (especially on a Sunday afternoon) with small streets, excellent selection of shops and cafes. Lovely to sit in the grounds of the Vosges Palace and to visit to Rue de Rosiers for the smells of freshly baked breads

Felt like a Parisian. Stayed in this area for a week - loved the little delis, bakeries, fruit shops and wine merchants. But beware the streets reek of urine during the weekend until the street cleaners come out with their massive hoses again on weekdays.
Cool and lovely. The area is lovely because of the pretty and interesting shops. You can also go in the evening and dine in one of the typical lovely restaurant of the area.

The area is very different at night.. In the day time the area is relatively quiet with everyone going about their business, but from early evening the bars fill up and the clientele stand around on the pavements and the whole area is very vibrant. Some interesting shops

Great area to explore on foot. The Marais is a nice old area of Paris to explore on foot especially up and around the Rue du Temple. There are many outside cafes but beware as a cup of coffee will cost you around 4 euros. There are also small custom shops. In the same area is the Pompidou Centre and also a similar area to expore on foot called Chatelle Les Halls although much of this area is currently under reconstruction.
Lively street and cafe scene. What a vibrant and lively area with shopping, cafes all along the narrow streets...definitely worth a visit...easy walk from the Louvre

Take off at saint Paul metro station. Take off at saint Paul metro station and walk to rue De rossiers and around it....you will just enjoy it !lots of shops, coffee shops and a great atmosphere.I was there during the day time but I understand that also at night time it worth a visit.
Worth a visit. We visited the area on a Sunday & ate in the area. It was very busy but worth walking around the small streets to soak up the atmosphere of the area & visit local parks.
Interesting area adjacent to Bastille.. Plenty of artisan shops and smaller ( relatively speaking) museums in this area. Place de Vosges an oasis of calm Marche d'Aligre well worth a morning visit.

Great value for money. First, they offer a taxi service that picks you up at the airport; the driver is very punctual, speaks good English and is lovely. The hotel is a wonder and great value for money. We were happy to have been here. Everything in this hotel was very clean and fully functional. Very good modern hotel, very clean, spacious and well-insulated, good beds and plenty of comfort. We had a room with Jacuzzi and it was very nice. Very friendly staff. Good breakfast varied and generous. The reception is very friendly and professional; our room was spacious, modern, and extremely bright.
Hidden Gem. Visit the Place Des Vosges, it is beautiful. The cafés have the real feel if Paris. A great place to explore on foot.

A lovely area of Paris.. I like the different types of shops and the fact they are not tourist shops the Bakery behind the Saint Paul Metro sell some amazing cakes. Also a great place to walk around, the narrow streets, and plenty of restaurants to choose from. There is nothing I dislike about this area of Paris.
less tourists. I loved the fact that it was a bit out of the usual tourist trail - place des vosges was lovely in the sun

simply lovely. Le Marais is one of the most charming and authentic parts of Paris. You can enjoy shopping, eating, drinking, sighseeting or just walking and smelling the authentic 'air de Paris". I really love it!
Place to visit on a Sunday. Spent several hours taking in the sights in the neighborhood. It is a great place to spend your Sunday. Several shops open, lots of cafes, bakeries and beautiful churches.

Favorite neighborhood . This is by far the best district to live in and visit. Architecture and history abounds and restaurants and bars are everywhere. To top it off you get some of the best shopping in the city.

great area.... ....to eat, drink and spend some lovely afternoon.there is a lot of architecture from 17th century that makes the walks sweet.we found a nice square where we spent few hours sitting on the grass.

A very fun neighborhood. We spent the morning walking through Le Marais and stopping in the shops. It was fun and relaxing. We tried to have the falafel at the world famous restaurant, but the lines were too long. You may want to go for brunch, in order not to waste an hour getting in at lunchtime.

Tres biang!!!. This area is alive and kicking. There are so many opportunities to watch people. So many bars and cafes and so many friendly Parisians. The Place de Vosges was but a stone's throw away from our hotel. We could not but give what succour we could to as many street people and their chiens as possible...

Worthwile a walk. it's a nice neighborhood to stroll around in, glance at shops and have a bite and a drink. Go off the main streets into smaller ones and you'll find the most surprising houses "hôtels particuliers"..

I would definitely go back..... The jewish quarter and an example of the older Paris with narrow, cobbled streets and tall buildings either side. I didn't get to stick around I. The evening but I was told lots of funky trendy bars and clubs, gay bars etc.It reminds me of how Carnaby Street ,ought have been many many many moons ago; vintage clothes shops, eateries and funky little shops and boutiques.We at at 'Mickey's' kosher restaurant - quite expensive but gargantuan portions and very friendly waiting staff

One of my favourite neighbourghoods in Paris. I love Marais! So much is happening there! Little cafes, a lot of second-hand shops with vintage clothes, ethnical restaurants and more. One of the best ways to see it.is just to sit in a cafe and watch the world go by.

Bar Hop. In Le Marais you just have to sit around and look. Check out a few bars, cafes and order a drink and watch. It's priceless, it really shows you how things are in the outskirts of the main centre of Paris. Gives you a better idea of how the city runs.

Charming neighborhood!. I discovered Le Marais during my 3 days stay in Paris last February. Small streets full of design & clothing shops, cafes, bistrots, petits restaurants and art galleries. Go to Place des Vosges, is the oldest planned square in Paris and one of the finest in the city.
A true jewel. Just a short walk from Norte Dame and so worth it. Beautiful especially on a cloudy day the Windows are like nothing else.. Try to avoid queue with advance tickets.

Great area to people watch and stroll. My wife and I visited Paris in February of 2014 along with our 4-month old baby boy. Trying to navigate a new city and language can be difficult but become a bit more difficult with a child. Strolling through Le Marais was great. We were able to find several cafes to sit in that were all friendly to us and our baby.The streets were easy to walk with a stroller and we had no issues.This neighborhood is a must see for all who visit Paris.
Flat in the Marais. I stayed in the 3rd arrondizment and it didnt seem as touristy as other areas, was a great base and seemed safe

Lovely, lively and quirky. Unfortunately, we visited le Marais near the end of our trip to Paris and would have liked to spend more time exploring and enjoying this lovely district of Paris. Full of interesting shops and bars & restaurants. Great place for people watching.

Love the area. Full of great shops and little restaurants. Place des Vosges is one of the nicest squares in Paris. Get lost in rue du Temple, rue Rambuteau, discover the old Jewish quarters and shop, the Picasso museum...

The gay center of Paris. A very interesting mix of outrageous gay boutiques and bars and history of Paris. Apparently this is the `it` part of Paris where Parisians also come to hang out, not only tourists.

Wonderful shopping in little specialty shops. Marvelous collection of shops selling handmade paper products of all kinds
Lovely coffee shops and little winding streets.Something for everyone

Amazing area go Paris. We spent our first visit to Paris staying in the Le Marais arrondissement for 6 nights. It's an incredible area and will definitely return one day. The shopping & dining here is terrific. We spent many hours wandering around - and don't forget to check out all the little side streets - you'll be surprised at all that you find. It's also a great base to get to most of the top tourist destinations, an easy walk down to the river and also within a stroll of 2 metro train stations. There's everything from your high end shops to street stalls. The local produce and flower markets were also amazing. The local boulangeries produced the most amazing croissants and there's also a Monoprix Supermarket for all those types of necessities.

Vibrant area with lots to offer. Definitely worth an afternoon. We spent about 3 hours wandering round the shops and soaking up the atmosphere. Make sure you go down the side streets as most of our favourite shops were off the beaten track.

First Marsh, then Ghetto, now almost unaffordable. During the 1st week of Feb 2014, my wife and I spent a week in a very well appointed small apartment at Rue Amelot, 100 meters from the St. Sebastian Froissart Metro station on Line 8. This was our 2nd sojourn in the Marais, although whenever we visit Paris there is always something interesting to bring us back for a day's walking around the place It is, in fact, a great place for walking. Where we were gave us access to Place Bastille, Place des Vosges, Hotel de Ville, and Pompidou Center in 20 -40 minutes. Although it is jammed with cafes, bars, brasseries, bistrots and restaurants, we do not find the food especially good in this part of town. Indeed, on this visit, it wasn't particularly good anywhere in Paris, and my wife and I came down with GI episodes on two consecutive days that wiped out 48 hours from our very limited schedule. There are some very upmarket traiteurs around with very gourmet take-out food, but as with restos, Paris prices are ridiculously high and well above those of the South. The whole of the Marais is well served by Metro and bus circuits, but walking is the way to get around, weather and energy permiting. Among the places not to be missed are the Musee Picasso ( temporarily closed), Carnevalet,, Hotel de Sully, The Jewish quarter is around the Rue Vieille du Temple and Rue Rosiers, containing lots of delicatessen shops, the Museum of Jewish Art and History, and the Memorial to the Shoah. Rue des Francs-Bourgeois and Rue Sevigne contain some very expensive fashion and perfume shops, and nearby is the Hotel Lamoignon, a handsome 16th Cent, building now serving as the Historical Library of the City of Paris..Place des Vosges hosts a large number of fascinating art shops, as well as the Musee Victor Hugo and L'Ambroisie, an unaffordable 3-star Michelin restaurant, but since the departure of Fauchon there is no decent food shop close by. The Village of St Paul is quite fascinating, and quite rich in ecclesiastical buildings, notably Eglise St Paul-St Louis. Not far away is the Hotel de Sens and the Lycee Charlemagne, both close to Metro Pont-Marie (Line 7). The entire area is spotless, well decorated with shrubs and flowers, and probably the safest in the city.

crazy. its the place that unites the traditional and the hip... you will find everything and anything : old churches, synagogues, trendy malls, medical supply shops, sex shops and gay bars... you name it they have it ... i love it there
Open on Sundays!. Very pleasant area of small shops and boutiques close to Bastille.My wife loved it as it is in the old Jewish quarter and open on Sundays

A Very Vibrant Area. Made two visits to this fashionable area of Paris during our stay. Like sections of many cities in the UK this was an area which had fallen on lesser times following the moving away of some commercial businesses. However given it's central position in the city it has become trendy again and particularly at weekend it is very lively. Think of a comparison to the Covent Garden area in London. Many specialised shops rub shoulder to shoulder with tourist traps and there is a huge range of restaurants and cafés to suit all culinary requirements and budgets. The area around the Pompidou Centre is popular but walk down any side street to find discoveries

Do your best to get there!. We returned to Le Marais three times during our recent trip to Paris for shopping and eating, and found it much more interesting and distinctive than Champs Elysee, (which to be fair, does have to be done/seen at least once to appreciate the beauty of the boulevard). Narrow cobble-stoned streets, the Jewish section, small cafes and food shops offering tasty delights, and terrific clothes shopping make this a wonderful, charming area to explore and complement your trip to Paris.

Favourite part of Paris. Amazing shops. The vintage scene is LARGE here, you can really get caught up in all the amazing shops.The cafes are quirky with a homely feel. The streets are tiny, the buildings are amazing.

Quirky, fascinating Le Marais. My favorite area (so far), in Paris. We stay at a bare bones flat in a 16th century building, eat in the area and generally just watch the people go by. It's just north of Notre Dame and down from the Pompidou. It's a short walk to Hotel de Ville and across the river to Boulevard St Germain.My favorite day: listening to two ancient ladies, who spoke no English, explain the intricacies of the French self serve washer to us (we speak very little French, and understand less). Outside a queue forms for the Jewish bakery and a très chic 20 something in high heels leads a Llama past.Nearby at La Bastille we arrive just as thousands and thousands of cheering Parisians welcome the newly elected President for a speech. I recommend you view Notre Dame and then take a walk through Le Marais.

Loved my apartment stay in Marais. Thanks to everyone on Tripadvisor who rated Marais. Your views convinced me this was the place to stay in Paris and I loved every minute we were there....alas..only 4 days. My first visit to Paris, and loved the apartment we rented in such a super cool neighbourhood on Rue Rambuteau. Only problem...it is so good here (relaxed, food, boutique shopping, cafes, interesting walks, macarons, ...) that we didn't quite make it to many of the"must see" Paris tourist sites....c'est la vie. I am content with knowing we found the best Macarons in all of Paris just around the corner from where we stayed. And now have a wonderful excuse to return...so much more to see and do..
Ideal for sunny days in Paris. Lovely (& busy) streets, many shops, and beautiful little gardens where you take a rest from walking and simlpy enjoy the atmosphere.

The heart of Paris. We are heading back to Paris in 12/2/14 for our 3rd visit. We would not consider staying anywhere else. It is old Paris that never got torn down when the city was rebuilt with all the straight streets. Long, cobbled streets, loads of bars, restaurants and shops. Loose your self for hours walking the streets soaking up the history of a landscape & architecture that hasn't changed much in centuries.Rent an apartment in La Marais for your stay and live like a Parisian. Great location for The Louvre, Notre Dame, Pompidou Centre, The Seine and many others.All ages will love this area. from a romantic break, to a holiday with the kids to a cultural excursion there will be no one dissapointed.

Cool neighborhood. My favorite neighborhood in paris, especialy during the day. At night it is overwhelmingly gay. If you think I am being mean go at night and you will see what I mean. It is a fact. During the day there are great restaurants, amazing shopping open on Sundays mostly. Good Chinese too in the Marais Nord.

The Only Place to Stay For Me. We have visited Paris on several occasions, but this visit was our first stay in the Marais. We were not disappointed. We rented an apartment for 12 days here, shopped locally in the many fine shops, ate at fantastic restaurants and truly felt like we were Parisians! This was the Paris of my dreams! This was Paris like the movies!

Quaint and very Parisian.. The only shops open on Sundays. Filled with boutiques, cafes and Parisian chains. Is Paris's version of Soho. Great for a romantic stroll or a "girls shopping day". Lots of quaint jewelry stores. Don't miss the Zadig and Voltaire location on Rue Francs Bourgeous, has best selection in the city. If looking to blow some big bucks, a visit to l'Eclaireur is a must.

Very convenient. We rented an apartment in this district. We were right around the corner from Republique metro stop which is a big hub. this made it extremely easy to get anywhere in the city if we chose to use the train. While walking was our preferred choice of transportation, we found it convenient to catch the metro after a long day of sightseeing and only being a block away from "home".
Changing place. The marais was an old Jewish quarter but now trendy with only a few Kosher bakeries and falafal shops on Rue de Rosiers. Worth a 1 hour walk or lunch

Fabulous!. Haven't visited for a while but always go back.Fascinating, friendly and fun, you have to visit the Marais district if you are in Paris.Full of different ethnic quarters, each with its own buzz, and atmosphere, not to mention cuisine!Loved bringing my mother here, we always had great time.The area is lively, interesting, has good cafés, shops and of course at its heart is the Place de Vosges and historical connections to Victor Hugo.

My favourite arrondissement. This district is one of my favourite in Paris. Very charming streets, many cafes, brasseries, boulangeries, great place for shopping, many hidden gems among the buildings, and it is the place where you can walk to most Parisian points of interest, museums, many art galleries, etc... and of course many many drugstores which are absolutely amazing. Don't forget to stop by to see medieval houses on Rue François Miron. It is something! It is a quite safe district, during day or night. I highly recommend it!

The historical part of Paris. Le marais is the historical part of Paris. You have to go in "Le marais". It's a peaceful district composed of the Jewish district, the gay district and historical district. There're a lot of small Streets, arty galleries, good trendy restaurants. Take your time, enjoy a glass of wine, a coffee or eat a fellafel!! If you go to "Le marais" don't hesitate to go to the Jewish museum (art and history) and place des Vosges. It's very safe and pleasant.

We spent quite a bit of time in Le Marais. Though we were based on the other side of town, we spent quite a bit of time in Le Marais during our recent visit to Paris. In addition to the shops and restaurants, we were drawn by the "Jewish tour" highlights, as well as the sights relevant to Victor Hugo's life.

Excellent place to base yourself while in Paris. We rented an apartment in this neighbourhood, close to the Pompidou Centre. It was a fantastic choice! Everything was within walking distance....Notre Dame, The Seine, La Place des Vosges, tons of cafes and restaurants, museums, shops, etc. A couple of metro stops were close by as well for those times we ventured further afield. It was a lively, busy neighbourhood, yet quiet enough at night to be restful (to be fair, our apartment WAS on a side street). If you want an interesting, historic, vibrant, central and safe place to visit or stay, we would highly recommend Le Marais.
Walking Tour. We took a walking tour with Brigitte of Paris Walks - a fascinating walk with much interesting information. Highly recommended.

Average Shopping. So many told us that the shopping here was great. The boutique were ok for the clothing but expensive with a limited selection. Most locals were going to the stores we have in America.

WALK INTO THE RENAISSANCE. In the Marais, a great treasure is La Place des Vosges, a huge (ie. huge) square of identical town houses bult in the Renaissance, (the first public square in Europe), built by the France's hero-king, Henri IV. (The houses now sell for more than $1,000,000 US.) At the centre of La Place des Vosges is a large lawn and garden, fountains, shade trees. One can stroll around the entire Place under its shaded arcade; the ground floor of the houses has been given over to antique shops, book shops, art shops, and a few cafés; one of the houses is the home of Victor Hugo where he wrote Les Misérables: it is a museum, open to the public.
So well maintained. Can you imagine being part of this time episode having coffee with Victor Hugo. What a new Paris experience this was.

A nice quiet corner in Paris. Grab a coffee on the go and sit to relax.
Close by there are plenty of bars with the chairs placed on the street. Very parisian.
A great park
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Get away from tourist life.... Hip clubs, great little brasseries featuring all sorts of international cuisines, all served with French flair. Coquille St. Jacques with Thai basil...a revelation! Lots of everybody here...except tourists! Straight people, gay people, but most of all...friendly-as-can-be people...not your typical thoughts of what Paris might be...and that is what makes the Marais so refreshing.

Love the Marais!. Save your visit to this lovely Paris neighborhood for Sunday when other stores and museums are closed. You'll find unique ethnic restaurants, boutiques and museums, including the Picasso Museum.

Lots to do. We stayed in this area, and would recommend it to others as there is a lot going on. This area has tons of shops and restaurants (open late into the night). Many are located down historic cobblestone streets. It's also contains, or is walking distance to a number of attractions including the louvre, Norte dame, the two islands, musee d'orsay, jardin de Tuileries, hotel de ville, centre Pompidou, and musee Picasso to name a few.

Paris HQ. When you stay in Paris, you'll soon find out Le Marais is one of the most "strategic" neighbourhoods in Paris. It contains a handful of touristic attractions (by foot) and, as if it weren't enough, it also offers an unusual architectural delight - Le Marais is where the old meets the new in Paris.

Great area - Chic meets old school!. From small Palaces and castles to high end designer shops and local restaurants, this area Is the 'IT' district in Paris. Its flamboyant-chic meets old school. It is definitely worth a visit, you will not be disappointed.

favorite hood. Once the Kosher Canyon of Paris Le Marais has evolved into a chic, artsy neighborhood with great cafes, shops and the wonderful Place des Voges for great people watching and Musee Carnavalet for some Paris History
Great location. We had a great apartment, which was walking distance to The Bastille, Notre Dame, Louvre, Pompodou Centre, Place de Vosges. Would definitely stay in the Le Marais again.

Wonderful Neighborhood. This is such great neighborhood just to stroll around in! If you get hungry stop over for crepes at Breizh Cafe. They are outrageous and out of this world. Love everything about this neighborhood
A place to visit. A lovey place in Paris not far from some of its beautifull attractons. You have to stroll in the streets to get impregnated of the parisian spirit.

What was old (very old!) is new again!. Le Marais, one of the oldest sections of Paris, is a little gem. Once the Jewish Quarter, and still a place of wonderful Jewish history, is now becoming a most fashionable center focusing on newer designers and boutiques with lovely, beautifully arranged and decorated little shops. There are good restaurants--hey, it's Paris, and wonderful little restaurants are, literally, everywhere-- interesting browsing for hours. Most worthwhile visiting (there's even a Picasso museum, though not the best at all, although the building it's in is beautiful!) and, again, extremely accessible using the ever-convenient Metro.
Always lovely. Just loved walking around. Unfortunately the Picasso museum is closed for renovation.. Have a warm falafel at the Ace du falafel, stoped by boutiques and enjoy the atmosphere.

Colourful. Very colourful neighbourhood. Lots of good pastries places and ideal for promenades and having a drink. Just relaxing. Not to mention that my hair-maker was there :) Should totally see and experience it!

Good for pubs and clubs. All of central Paris is a series of pubs, eateries and clubs. Over time, Le Marais has maintained its reputation as a destination for such things but is competing with Pigalle and the Latin Quarter for quality and choice (certainly better choice and quality can be found in some parts of the St Germaine. It would probably be best to buy a guide book that caters to your taste or pick up one of the many free guides in hotels to really pinpoint your interests and their locations.

Very nice area of Paris to spend time. We recently visited Paris and stayed a few nights in Le Marais district, a quieter and less touristy area of the city and very much enjoyed this area of the city.  Le Marais covers a fairly large area north of the Seine River. Important attractions in this area include the historic Musee Carnavalet and Musee Cognagy-Jay as well as Musee des Arts et Metiers and Musee Picasso for art lovers. These museums as well as other historical buildings and squares in Le Marais help make up probably a couple days worth of attractions to see in this part of the city. Other historic and interesting places to visit include the elaborate Hotel Villa, Opera National de Paris Bastille, the symmetric and lovely Place Des Vosges as well as the Bastille monument called Colonne de Juilet. Several other historic manor houses and hotels and squares make up Le Marais notable attractions. In Le Marais, you can also find many small art galleries, quaint shops, restaurants, cafes and bars. We enjoyed Creperie Suzette on Rue des Francs-Bourgeois, near Musee Cognacy-Jay. We also had a delicious street-side crepe just outside the farmers market at Bastille Square. Also, the best dinner we had during our last trip to Paris was in Le Marais at a lovely restaurant called Qui Plume la Lune on Rue Amelot.Overall, we very much enjoyed Le Marais district and would be happy to stay in this area of Paris again. This area of the city is well worth at least a day to explore and to enjoy the fine collection of museums, historic buildings, monuments and public spaces that can be enjoyed here.
