Great location, near hip boutiques restaurants and bars. The Marais is where to stay if you like South Yarra/Prahran or Paddington/Surry Hills. Close to everything, including great boutiques such as Colette and Isabel Marant in the nearby 8th and 11th. Great cafes and bars. Try L'Ardoise for dinner, you wont be disappointed.
nice neighborhood. Check out les Place de Vosges. This is a beautiful square with great galleries. The Marais neighborhood is wonderful just to walk around and see the architecture and window shop.

Worthwhile, like most areas.. We took a walking tour. In fact, we walked for an entire week all around all areas of Paris. I did not think the Le Marais area stood out, but it is was definitely worthwhile. We like the 9th arrondissement better for walking. We did not go to Shoah Museum, Bastille, and the markets by the Bastille in Le Marais.

Should be in your list. Don't forget to pay a very necessary visit to Le Marais. It is a wonderful neighborhood, very quaint and warm.You will find many nice restaurants and cafes. Interesting shops and a unique bohemian flare.

Filled with Parisian character. A short walk from Notre Dame, A visit to Marais area is a must on your trip to Paris. You can spend anywhere from an hour to a whole day in the area. Quaint cobblestoned narrow streets lure you into the interior. There are cafés to sit at and people to watch.

what to do on Sunday. the only place open on sunday, full of colours, open shops, trendy places, cafés terraces, desing shops. On sundays the streets belong to pedestrians, but watch out for cyclists who are angry.
Le Marais. Did enjoy walking around the area with it's very quaint buildings and narrow streets. A fascinating area. Some of the buildings are very beautiful. A very historic area.

Wonderful place. This is where I stay in Paris and this is what Paris means to me. This neighbourhood is a wonderful collection of streets, cobblestones, buildings, museums, shops, cafes and people. I have stayed here 3 times totalling 3 months and I am sure there are still streets I haven’t found. Great things to do during the day and great things at night.
Quaint---charming. Comfortable area of Paris--this area had a warmth ---there are many small cafés --interesting shops---and it is an area in which real people live

Village in the city. Great to walk around and lose yourself in the labarynth of history, culture, shopping dining....Worth spending a day or half a day. Walking distance to a lot of other attractions too.
Wonderful, friendly neighborhood. Lots of interesting history to this part of the city and lots of great places to eat, drink and parks to just relax with friends.

The loveliest area to visit. Don't go to Paris without walking around Le Marais. Apart from the stunning Place des Voges, the tiny back streets are full of terrific shops and cafes. Big names are creeping in but it still has an unspoilt charm almost unique now in Paris.

Not far from Centre Pompidou. The little shops are worth the walk into the 'ancient pre-Haussmannian' part of Paris. Plenty little cafes and shops you'd never find anywhere else. There are a lot of of 'wholesale' shops.

Still one of my favourites in Paris. This is a great place for a romantic stroll through the gardens and around the outside of the square. Little shops and restaurants can be found to delight you and if you have the money, then stay in one of the very expensive hotels.
Very nice place. This is my 5th trip to Paris !!! And I decide that this district is the best in Paris to make you a Parisian for few days A lot of shops bistro etc ..... Enjoy

Meander and window shop. The Marais is full of galleries, boutiques, cafés and old world architecture. Whether you want to shop, eat or absorb the historical details of the neighborhood, be sure to set aside time to walk through the Marais.

The swamp. Le Marais means swamp, but this district is anything but. It is full of wonderful cafes and shops and it is medieval in structure. The streets are narrow and charming and there are metro stations scattered throughout and its a short walk to the left bank and Notre Dame.

Don't miss the Marais!. This is our favorite neighborhood in Paris! We love the restaurants, the falafel, and the shopping, bars and hotels. It is truly lovely, and just stopping at. Places des Vosges for a short stop has yo be on everyone's list of things yo do in Paris.

Put your walking shoes on. The Le Marais District starts right outside the Hotel Des Ducs d'Anjou.This is such a historic area of Paris.It takes you into the old Jewish Quarter...the history here is amazing..as you walk savour the aroma of the cafés and just take a look at the queues outside some of the shops selling Falafel's.Check out the traditional bakeries.Just take your time to look and take it in.I could say Why oh Why do I love Paris.Well each time I come here..and walk the streets I learn more and love it more.

Feeling like a real Parisian!. By far one of my favorite days in Paris was just wandering around the Marais. The little streets are so charming and there are hidden treasures everywhere - for example at the southwest corner of the Place des Voges, there is an entrance into a hidden garden! Be sure to check out Rue Francois Miron, no. 11 and 13 for great examples of 14th century Parisian timbered homes. Really it is just a charming area to get lost in for an afternoon!

A walk around Le marais. Ignoring the numerous shops that are located here, walking about the back streets of Le Marais gives you a feel for the stereotypical idea that we have of narrow, crooked, Parisien streets.There are lots of good shops along the main streets here and a lovely walk from there, through Place de Vosges and just walking aimlesslessly around all of the old street is a delight.It's a wonderful are photogenic area of Paris that seems to be overlooked at times by the tourists.

a nice neighborhood to visit - very charming. We booked a private tour fo Le Marais through Unique Paris private tour as they recommend it. I had no idea what the marais was, but I was not disappointed, this neighborhood is charming, small streets, lots of small shops and good restaurants/ food shops. It is paris as you imagine it.
Good area. This is a very popular area with great night life - lots of shops - very busy and charming at Christmas

The real heart of Paris. The Marais ('the Marsh') is the real Paris. Becoming trendified, but still the best place to wander arpund. The northern end (3rd) is best - s end (4th) now touristy, but Place des Vosges a must for its beauty. Ignore the overpriced crowded Left Bank.
Numerous kosher eating places. Basar,chalavi and pseudo kosher,so look for the tudat kasher.Best kosher restaurants near champs elisee and in 19th arrondisemont

Funky shopping area. I love strolling through Le Marais with the many shops and restaurants, its like shopping in Soho or Chelsea in NY or Notting Hill in London, if your lucky you may even hear the choir singing as I did...

Shopping on Sundays!. Unlike many shops in Paris, the ones in the Marais are open Sunday afternoons. Hooray! And a great collection of Parisian and international boutiques as well as great cafes for lunch/brunch. Also the historical roots of the Marais as the "Jewish Quarter" of Paris are still in evidence - there are still active synagogues and restaurants like Chez Marianne.

A jewel in the heart of Paris. Spent many hours with my partner walking the streets of the Marais, eating in its cafes, browsing its patisseries, taking in its sights and visiting its museums. It is without a doubt one of the nicest areas in Paris. It is unspoiled and totally free of many of the negative aspects of many other areas in the city. Its cafes are of a very high quality. Its patisseries are the best in Paris. Its museums are the finest and least crowded you can visit and its people are a pleasure to deal with.And I truly hope this is how it will remain going forward.
Nice place to see. Shoppes open on Sunday and nice restaurant and things to see and do , the park front the place is nice and have small play ground for kids

The heart and soul of Paris. No trip to Paris is complete, without a stay in, or visit to Le Marais. Steeped in history, elegance, and romanticism, it is essential to understanding Paris. Museums, churches, the Place des vosges, great cafes, hip bars, and some great boutique shopping. It's all there, and so much more.

Love this district. I always try and stay in one of the small boutique hotels, of which there are many, near the Place des Vosges in the Marais as it is a district that abounds in charm and has everything needed for a visit to Paris. The narrow streets are an eclectic mix of chic modern boutiques and old style craft workshops, with something for everyone including a fantastic 'bead shop'. Museums, great architecture, good restaurants and cafes and of me, I just love having breakfast in the Pain au Quotidien. This is an area in easy walking distance from most of the places I want to visit - Just love it.

Too many "Wholesale only" stores. Loved walking the Marais - quaint winding streets. But too many of the shops sell only to other retailers and not to the general public. Boo!!!! As there were some awesome scarves and purses to be bought!
Wonderful. We walked the streets of Le Marais for hours & hours . Many exciting shops - different from main stream Paris. To me this is what Paris was many years ago. Don't miss it

Fun Spot To Walk. We enjoy walking around the different neighborhoods in Paris and the Marais is one of our favorites. While it is somewhat inconvenient from the Metro, it is worth seeking out. There are many,many shop windows to browse and small cafes to sample. The Picasso Museum alone makes it worth the trip. The Place des Vosges reminds you of what grandeur was here at one time. It can be crowded so chart your path beforehand.
Would Stay in Le Marais District Again!. I loved this district and would stay only here on my next visit to Paris. It is centrally located to everything!

This was a poor area of Paris which has become trendy.. Le Marias was a poor area of Paris which has recently become trendy. There isn't really one special thing to "see" in the area; now, there are a number of trendy shops, and it is just another Paris neighborhood to visit and buy some souvenirs or some snacks.It was the "Jewish" quarter; so, there are some store signs in Hebrew. Just as New York City has "Little Italy" and San Francisco has "China Town," this makes it a tourist attraction; if you find this interesting.
great area. you have to walk around here. Lots to do. Many shops and cafe's to stop in for a quickie...................................

Perfect for a wander. My daughter and I decided to just start walking from (I think) the 1st arrondissement and eventually found ourselves here - perfect to explore - just take a turn and see where it goes - the queue outside falafel shops very long so we missed out on sampling their great smelling product

Great neighborhood!. The Marais is a great neighborhood in Paris. It has some of everything--interesting little streets, like Rue des Rosiers, wonderful shopping, museums, good restaurants and bakeries--had the best macaron there along the rue de Rivoli--wish I had taken note of the bakery name! The little ones were 70 centimes, much less than you'll find elsewhere, and so fresh and soft and wonderful.

The only place to stay in Paris. So charming, and beautiful, especially at Christmas. Every store and building seeped in Parisian history - cobbled streets, chic fashion, friendly cafes, what more could you want?
one of the loveliest areas of paris.. just walk the streets and enjoy the great atmosphere.try the new Miznon bistro, great food in pita from the cheff Eyal Shany, its lovely
Epic Neighborhood. This is a tradition neighborhood from Paris.A must-go visit while there, where you can taste the typical French culture.

How to remember Paris.... I visited Le Marais on the last day of my holiday in Paris, and it was definitely the way I want to remember Paris. We had lovely meals there and spent the whole afternoon looking at the fantastic architecture and beautiful little streets that comprise the area. I also had one of the best eclairs of my life, but unfortunately I can't remember the name of the shop. It is a bit off the touristy-beaten path, which is just perfect for what I want in a city. I very much intend on returning and spending more time there.

Le Marais sans les Marias. This Paris quarter is worldwide known for nice and cosy bars for homosexuals. But for straight guys like me it's cool as well. Beautiful artisanat and clothes shops. Go there if you look for something special (anything)

Great area for visitors to stay. We stayed in Le Marais during our visit in Paris in September and it was a great experience. We rented an apartment through Air BnB and picked Le Marais because it was within walking distance or metro to all of the tourist destinations. At every corner, there is a cafe for people watching and places to eat.

The real Paris - cobblestones, pedestrian only walkways, restaurants, boutiques, doggy droppings. Staying next to the Louvre, Le Marais is not only adjacent, it is a real find (for those who believe that Paris starts and ends at the Left Bank and/or the Champs Elysees) of character, style, openness and that is not seemingly bound to the standard closures on Sunday and even Monday. Yes the Paris highlights are magnificent but areas such as Le Marais are beguiling, inviting and always interesting. Don't miss this area even only as a relief to the manic crowds at the major sites. As an added advantage, it is not polluted by the ever present groups of apparently immigrant street kids who only see tourists as an opportunity for pickpocketing or some other swindle

My favorite area in Paris by far. Le Marais or "swamp" is one of the oldest district of Paris filled with old museums, hidden mansions, paved streets but it's also home to all the super trendy decoration shops, great bars and restaurants. It's always busy unless you decide for a Sunday afternoon where you can get lost in the little streets or eat the best falafel or have a drink watching life goes by..

Fabulous neighbourhood. Le Marais is simply wonderful. It's really close to Notre Dame (short walk across the bridge). The French Marais are really trendy and cool but not pretentious. Lots and lots of restaurants and bars in the area, including a few very reasonable Japanese places on Rue de le Verrerie. Super!
not as good as st michel district. Wr took a aftetnoon visit expected no cars vobblestine pedestian access only WRONG,! Cars busy everywhere . So glad we stayed in st getnain st michel district

Fun!. I went to le marais and made the mistake of going down rue de rivoli. Whilst its a great street for shopping, the crowd was just ridiculous and it wasnt a very pleasant experience. Come Sunday I decided to go back and give le marais another chance - this time I skipped rue de rivoli and went deeper in to the smaller less populated alleys and oh my god was I blown away. The shops are plenty, the food everywhere, the people nice and helpful, it was just a great experience! I bought a few things and walked around the streets for hours and got "lost". The gay area is here too and it's such a fantastic place! It was also a short walk to the pompidou which was charming as well.Definitely go to le marais on Sunday! Impeccable!

Walking around. This district is one of my favorite in Paris: there are boutiques of local designers, galleries, small and quite restaurants, second hand shops and brands... it is perfect to spend a whole day walking around without a plan.

Paris at its best, that is Le Marais. If I could choose one place to live in the world, just on how great, lively and beautiful it is, that would be La Marais for sure. Not only because that is: - the oldest part of Paris (the oldest church, a LOT of museums all around), - the most artistic part of Paris (some very, very important galleries in the world of contemporary art, a lot of them), - with young and clever people all around, - the most amusing part of the city (night life and cafes so lively), - with the most ultimate Parisian street of them all: Rue des Francs Bourgeois, - with a lot of quite good, not the most expensive restaurants all around, - the gayest part of the city (a lot of it happens there, with a lot of places for a very gay going out), - with some great oriental food places, - the most Jewish part of the city (with a couple of streets with quite orthodox Jewish stuff, with a great food, pastry, etc), - on the metro line 1, so easily approaching the most important venues of Paris, - by the river Seine that is just around the corner, so you can easily go for a fresh air and passing over to the relaxing Île Saint-Louis, - having some extremely fun, unexpected and fancy shops, - with one of the most important museums of the world - Beaubourg (Centre Georges Pompidou)... You need one great travel just for enjoying the Marais. Trust me, I know what I am talking about.

Get lost in Paris!. This was the old swamp area of medieval Paris, now a super-trendy area with great shops - mostly boutiques, and some superb architecture. There are many restaurants and bars and it is a gay-friendly area.The Place des Vosges is a stunning square architecturally, housing some great eating places and art shops. The Jewish quarter is close by, with its magnificent synagogue. Brides and grooms can be seen under the arches of the cloisters in the Place having their wedding photo's done!The Marais is easy to get to and very pleasant to explore. Aim for the metro at St Paul or Hotel de Ville and then walk away from the river.
An experience not to miss. I can't see how anyone cannot want to stroll slowly around these streets. The bars, restaurants and shops will keep you happy for hours. Just wander around....

Nice walk. Marais is a nice area to walk around but unfortunately the shopping was disappointing. The area is very trendy but the clothes sizes are ridiculous. Ladies above a U.S. medium and men who are muscular or tall will have difficulty shopping in Paris. The French just seem to built "narrow" and the clothes reflect that. There also weren't very many home stores which was also disappointing.

Disapppointed. I used to LOVE Le marais. I grew up in France and went to school in the Marais. In my youth, it was strictly a Jewish neighborhood, and it's lovely, winding streets, with charming names, brought you back in time to the middle of the 19th century. This year, we returned and made the mistake of visiting on a sunday. The place was mobbed, the streets full of trendy shops, the Place des Vosges, once an elegant and stunning square, was overwhelmed with people and children. We left as quickly as we could. If you visit, make sure you don't visit on a sunday.

Best area of Paris. We loved this area of Paris for its authenticity, small shops and bistros. If you are staying in this area, you will find that it is a central location, that is easy walking distance to the Pompidou and Bastille. In addition, it is populated with Metro stops that will take you any where you need to go within two transfers (for the most part).
Lovely Stroll. Lovely neighborhood in the middle of Paris, close to Hotel De Ville. Unique shops, nice streets, many restaurants.Another Paris gem.

Excellent place for a Sunday visit. As Paris closes down for Sunday, Le Marais should be jammed and is,but not by tourists. Heavy shopping underway,by very stylish people walking in streets closed to traffic. Places to eat and the very worthwhile,free Musee Carnavalet.

A Must for Sunday. I love to walk around Les Marais on Sundays. Many of the stores are open, which isn't true elsewhere in Paris. There are lovely little cafes, picturesque streets and wonderful old buildings. There are several Maisons Particuliers (Individual mansion-like townhouses) which are now museums (e.g. Museum Carnavalet, Picasso Museum) and well worth visiting, as well as the Place des Vosges.

Amazing area. Stayed in Le Marais for a week.Depending of where you say, you could be within walking distance of upto 3 metro stations. If you don't want to catch the metro, you are within walking distance of most of the major Parisian attractions. Shop at Rue di Rivoli or walk down abit further to get to the Ave. Des Champs elysees.Amazing selection of boutique shops ranging from clothing to art and food. Very high profile designer boutique shops to. and High profile department stores. Everyone dresses so well in this area, and on the weekends, it was very very busy. I felt safer in Le Marais then i did anywhere else.

Exciting area with lots to do. We spent a week in the Marais and found it the perfect place to be. Public transport went past our door to take us all over Paris. The area itself was alive, wonderful little back streets to wander with lots of suprizes to encounter along the way. Beautiful buildings, museums and galleries and some wonderful antique shops . Lots of restaurants and food shops and some interesting churches. We could have spent the whole week discovering this area as there is so much to see there. There is also the fresh food market in St Gervais Place on a Saturday morning and Wednesday afternoon and this was a great place to get our fresh produce, including great fresh fish.

A walk worth the trip. We've always stayed in the 5,th 6th, or 7th arr, but couldn't get an apartment there this time. Instead, we were in the Marais and it turned out to be great. We are foodies, so loved the restaurants and the nearby cooking stores (La Bovida, G. Detou and DeHillerand.) But also, rue de Montorgueil, a virtual restaurant and foodie row!

We spent a week in Le Maris. This is the place to be. There are quaint shops everywhere, charming streets, museums, and close to the Metro. There are apartments to rent. Ours was small but well equipped.

Interesting. Gorgeous buildings, lots of interesting things to take a peek at and places to stop for a snack (or pick up some fresh produce). Great for a less intense time of just wandering- feels really french.

I love this neighborhood!. The Marais is one of my favorite areas to walk around in Paris. I love walking down the old streets or popping into the many small parks that crop up every few blocks or so. When the weather is nice, it's wonderful to just sit down and people watch or even just take the time "to smell the roses". There are many interesting shops to "window lick" (a new term shared with me by a fellow traveler) ranging from pastries to chocolates, leather goods and beautifully tailored clothes. There are art galleries in the covered walkway of the Place des Vosges and an antiquarian flea market in Rue St. Paul. The place is not lacking in variety or picturesque spots. The Picasso Museum is located here as well among other places of interest to see. So you can do a lot or you can do as little as you want. This neighborhood will charm you no matter what you decide to do!

lovely to browse around in. I was lucky to be part of a group who had with us a guide to walk us around the Marais for around 3-4 hours. There are many interesting historic buildings there and it is worth having a guide or at least a good detailed guide there. In addition to the history the quarter is full of interesting little shops, chocolate shops and pastry shops you could die for and cafes and bars. We kept coming back to the Marais time and time again during our 5 days in Paris and each time found new and interesting things to see and do. Just be warned that Sunday's the place is swarming with locals and tourists so it is very crowded on some streets.

Great place for a home base. Get location...easy to get to the metro as well as buses, shops of all sorts within walking distance as well as several very nice restaurants. Couldn't ask for more. Not really anything to dislike

Paris Apartment. My 5 travel mates and I wanted to stay in a "typical" Parisian apartment during our 4-day stay in Paris, so we searched Trip Advisor for recommendations. We were 100% pleased with our choice of an apartment in the Marais district of Paris. It was on the second floor of an old multi-unit building, accessed by a spiral staircase or squeaky iron door elevator! The apartment was well-equipped; we felt very comfortable there! Grocery stores, shops, restaurants and subway stations were very nearby. If you want to live like a Parisian, bypass the fancy hotel and stay in the Marais!!
sunday is the day. i had not been to the marais on sundays for a while. well it's happening more then ever. galleries, shops, people watching, restaurants it's all there and fun
Bustling hip area. Le Marais was a bustling area. Took the Metro. Had lunch wand walked and walked. Cute shops galore. Went to the Jewish Museum, was impressed with the collection and history.
Very lively!. This is a great little neighborhood! Lots of shops and street performers. The whole atmosphere here was lively and fun.
Great area !. We took a taxi here ,it was fun to walk around,it wasn't that quite ,a lot of young people.A lot of bars ,restaurants and shops,it was fun to explore this place.

The new Montmartre,vibrant and style!!. We visited this part of Paris last week,to me is the new Montmartre!!Vibrant,full of interesting people,fashion,bars,restaurants,art galleries,famous designers.You can start by the Rue des Rossiers ( the old jewish street) try the most famous restaurant kosher sandwiches of Paris(L'As du Fallafel), and walk by the streets until arrive to the most beautiful place of Paris(Place des Vosgues) and enjoy the beauty and peace of this old square of Paris.You can also visit the Shoah Memorial and the old sinagog of the Marais.To finish you have to try one of the best creperie of Paris,La Droguerie.
Wonderful area. By far our favourite area of Paris. Our hotel was in the area and we spent hours wandering the streets here, so much to see. Highly recommend to anyone visiting

more than i hoped for. Stayed in this neigbourhood for a week, and I am in awe. Its not very quiet, has lots of young people in the streets and infront of the restaurants at night, its vibrant, lively, very parisian. From what I saw most of the people are locals. Lots of shops, bars, restaurants. Also its full of historic sites. We were lucky enough to rent a place there without even knowing all of this. And its also very safe. Even if you are not staying here it is worth the visit.
Lovely area. We really enjoyed exploring this area and wish we'd had more time there. Would definitely consider staying in this part of Paris on a future visit!

Terrific place to visit!. We took the metro here and we absolutely loved it! It actually felt like a small town within the giant city of Paris. Lots of little shops and fashion boutiques, great food, and lots of activity. The Place des Vosges was very peaceful and a perfect place to take some photos. The only disappointment was we went to try some falafels and the lines were so huge, we decided to come back another time. I love to travel to places like this. It's not advertised as a "main attraction" but can totally make your trip!

Super area. This is such a beautiful part of Paris, found in the 3rd and 4th arrondissements. The people, shops, food and general atmosphere were all fantastic. Old Paris. Cobblestone streets. Historical buildings. Picture-post card photos from every angle on the Right Bank. Many galleries. Very stylish area. Charming area.

Great shopping district. Lots of stores and cafes to roam around. A lot of streets with great shopping. Rue Rossier not what i was eecting but all around is worth checking out if shopping is your stuff.

Great neighborhood. I discovered this area on my 4th trip to Paris, and am so sorry it took so long. Upbeat neighborhood, safe, lively but quiet, lots of shopping and dining and very close to the city center. I have stayed in the Latin quarter, on illle St. Louis, and in the mouffetard, this looks like a great choice for my next stay. Had an extra day and did all my Christmas shopping at some unique and reasonably priced shops here.

Full of character and history. Le Marais is more than just a part of Paris; it is a lively, historic community with great services and amazing architecture. It would take weeks, no months, to cover its narrow streets and alleys. Around each corner or down a hidden passage, is another unique building or square. And speaking of squares, the Place des Vosges is breathtakingly beautiful.

Stay here for a week and live like a stylish intellectual Parisian.. I can suggest renting an apartment. We rented a walkup for a week. The view was so spectacular of the Paris rooftops that we eventually didn't mind the walk. Suggestion #2: buy your food at the neighborhood markets then cook breakfast and dinner at home. Enjoy real Parisian cooking and save 70% on your food bill.
Safe , fun!. Lot of lovely boutiques, must visit for girls. Safe stylish area.Nice jewish bakery, shops, fun to have experience.

Lovely. The Marais is a nice, trendy area behind the Hotel de Ville and the Rue de Rivoli. If you're looking for nice little places to eat or for stylish boutiques, or even antiques, that is the place to go. Make sure you don't miss the Musée Carnavalet (history of Paris) and the Place des Vosges, where you can visit Victor Hugo's house as well.

Perfect Place to Stay. The Marais is a great place to set up your Paris vacation headquarters. It is in the heart of Paris and close to many transportation options. It's really hard to go wrong by staying here.

Nice to see a lively Jewish community. Went before the holiday of Sukkot so it was fun to see the sale of lulavs and etrogs (holiday items) on the street. Also visited the large muse of Jewish history and the Shoah memorial. Had the well known "best" falafel on yelp and other kosher treats. Took a free walking tour which gave a nice overall view of the area. Enjoyed the art galleries around the Place de Vodges. Picasso museum is stil under renovation so closed and Victor Hugo house closed on Monday. Windy streets were confusing to navigate but charming if you don't care where you end up!
Good Sunday idea. This area is full of fascinating shops and cafes that are open on Sunday. Really good to stroll around, perhaps try a falafel or cake like the locals.

Fascinating area ---. We loved this area! If you can, do one of the Paris Walks. We did two whilst in Paris - one of which introduced us to this area. You need to be pretty fit as it's a good, solid two hours of fast paced walking. Had we had another few days, I would have loved to have gone on another one - which is focussed on the Marais area and its writers!!! Hemingway etc - so that will need to wait for our next visit ..... We didn't go at night but believe the bars and cafes are alive and vibrant. Really interesting place and I bought some nice souvenirs at some of the (many) tourist shops there as well. Many cat things if you are a cat lover as we are!!

Old town paris.. You must stroll through the Marais to get a sense of what Paris was like before Napoleon III hired Haussman to remodel the city. The maze of quaint streets will keep you wandering and entertained for a good 2 hours. If you like falafel, the best in town is in the heart of the Jewish quarter. It's worth waiting in line for a taste.

A lesson in Jewish History. This trip to Paris we treated ourselves to a guided tour of the Marais (Pletzel) by Chantal Biton. We have visited the Marais at least 8 times in the last 14 years, but with the assistance of a knowledgeable guide your understanding and appreciation of what is there and what once was there takes on a new dimension. Chantal was able to get us inside 3 of the small synagogues to view the unusual arrangements of both Sephardic and Ashkenazi bimahs. We learned about the migration to Paris of Jews from across Europe and North Africa as well.
Marais quaint but very busy. Some lovely boutiques and artisan shops. Lovely Jewish quarter go to Place des Vosges a lovely preserved square.

I live in the Marais when I stay in Paris.... Marais and the surrounding area (Hotel de Ville) offers a safe neighborhood within which you can shop, eat at great restaurants visit the sights. Technically you can walk to most sights except the Eiffel Tower, Sacre Coeur and a few others. You can walk to the Louvre if you love to walk, but if you are in Paris you should be walking to enjoy the beautiful building and the architecture in general. The restaurants in the Rue de Rossiers are overpriced so try other streets. Enjoy Paris...

Is the Marais the 3e or the 4e arrondissement?. We stayed in an apartment in the Rue Rambuteau some years back and absolutely loved it so much so that we wanted to do it again as there are so many boutiques and small specialty shops selling absolutely everything around that area, just up from the Pompidou Centre . There was so much character and personality and interest there. This time we thought we had again booked an apartment in the Marais (4e) but it turned out to be the 3e in the Rue Portefoin, just off Rue du Temple which seems to be a street almost totally devoted to shops selling wholesale Chinese made costume jewellery with hardly a food shop in sight and only a couple of restaurants - just jewellery. Also there are many people sleeping on the streets including an entire family of 5 people. Although the apartment here is quite nice I would never stay in this area again so my advice would be to be very particular about which postcode you stay in. The 4e is great, the 3e not so. Check the map of Paris before booking. I wish someone had given me this advice before I booked.

Exciting, busy and fun area!. We went there on a Sunday and it was packed. We toured the Museum of Jewish History and then had lunch in one of the area deli's. There's also a lot of very hip boutiques in the area. Great old buildings beautifully restored.

Nice neighbourhood. It's a really nice place to stay. We rented a tiny apartment of 9 sq meters for 70 euros a night. It's a popular place, but not crowded with tourists. If you want to sit in a cafe, or a bistro, brasserie, you're in the right place. Prices are not so low, though.

A great location from which to see Paris.. We were located here for a week during which we walked and saw almost everything. (Well, not EVERYTHING, but you get the idea). There are great little cafes in the neighbourhood for morning espressos, as well as late night food and drink. It's only a few blocks to the Pompidou and its surrounding amenities, and a block or two more to the Seine. The Chatelet metro stop is easy to find and connects to most train lines. Head north east for some less touristy but still wonderful finds. We'll be back.
Artsy neighborhood. Nice neighborhood with lots of good restaurants offering affordable menus. You can visit Victor Hugo's house and buy original perfums. Worth a visit.

Great shopping area.. Get lost in this neighborhood and stumble upon amazing boutique shops. Perfume, clothes, shoes, everything... There's also a nice park with fountains, great for pics and people watching.

Lovely area. Interesting area very close to other good places to see. Most of it is not as touristy as some of the surrounding areas. I was looking for the Jewish section but found it was just one narrow block,

Great, cosy, interesting part of Paris. Le Marais is a village within Paris. Its interesting. Great shopping and food. Easy access to all the sights - we rented Velib bikes and cycled easily to the Effiel Tower, Musee D'Orsay etc
Place des Vosges. One of the great squares of the world. It might be crowded but it stills feels that you have taken back into the early seventeenth century

Good shopping district. None of the tourist crowd you'll find near Lafayette, a lot of good qualitative boutiques at every corner - my favourite: Crea Concept on the corner of Rue des Rosiers, two blocks down opposite Metro St. Paul is a nice cafe Le Bucheron (good chocolate tarts!)

Nice Neighborhood With Character. After staying at the Hotel Paris Rivoli, I found the neighborhood to feel very safe and a little less touristy than other areas of Paris. The selection of cafes was excellent as well as the local Monop market. As with an other reviewer, the Sunday open market was a great experience too.
Perfect on Sunday. Love this area and always go there on Sunday.Lot's of shops open and plenty of cafes and restaurants open.The atmosphere is fab!
Charmed. Charming neighborhood. Safe, fun to walk around, and great little sidewalk cafes. A good taste of Paris.
A tour not to be missed.. Karen of Sight Seekers did a magnificent job on this tour. Informative with some humorous anecdotes.
Chic Paris. Safe, central, friendly, cultural. Everything you need is at a walking distance, including Metro stations.

Le Marais is absolutely charming.. We rented an apartment in Marais and found it absolutely warm and wonderful. I always hear how the French are so rude. Nothing could be further from the truth. I learned a little French before we went and it really helped a lot. The business and cafe personel were helpful and anxious to serve. Its really important to say Bonjour to the owners when you enter their stores, that is a huge courtesy, and the restaurant staff work there as their livelihood, its not a job to get them through school. Be respectful. The Marais appeared to be washed down at night, hence, its very clean and well maintained. Most places speak some English. Our favorite thing to do was find a nice outdoor table, drink wine, and people watch. The cafe staff will not rush you or ask you to leave so they can have your table (imagine that). We will definately go back. Apartment renting was wonderful as long as you remember there is no consierge to answer your questions or book reservations. We couldn't figure out how to turn on the tv and a couple of the kitchen appliances were hard to figure out. The apartment owner spoke no English, therefore, communication was not the best. We felt like that was all part of the experience and how can you be disappointed .... you're in Paris!

Too commercial. Since my last visit some years ago, the character of this area has been spoiled by the sheer number of fashion shops, mainly high street names. Most of the small independents have been priced out.
Paris with a Teen. Nice area for a stroll and shopping - lunch at King Falafel Palace was great too. Be prepared to queue for the good restaurants especially on a Sunday
Walking tour with Stephanie from Viator. Very knowledgeable and friendly. Asked us questions to make sure we understood. neat lttle area with plenty of resturants and shops!

;fun neighborhood, galleries. Tis is a neighborhood well worth visiting. I is a part of Pris that was very down and out in the 60's and has been recently been restored (and gentrified). Th streets are great to wander. The only disappointing thing is that , like so many areas around the world, the shops have been taken over by chain stores.
Best neighborhood to stay. We rented an apartment in this neighborhood. The location is perfect with many many take aways, delis, groceries, restaurants and cafes.

vibe delux. A vibey, ticking area in Paris,lots of little restaurants,good variety of shopping,accesable metros,near lots of museums and galleries and feels french and not too tourist.Felt safe and hired an apartment which was the best for our stay

Glorious, especially the Place des Vosges. I love the Marais with its small winding streets that are the way Paris was before the Grands Boulevards were build in the mid 19th century. Lots of shops and restaurants.
The oldest part of Paris. If you are in Paris this neighborhood not to be missed. As most of Paris is closed on Sunday and Monday the Marais is open

Need several days to soak up the history. Walk leisurely through the Marais on a Sunday when many shops and sights are closed. It's easy access by foot, bus or metro and provides another view of Paris architecture,
Les Marais. Great for wandering and discovering. Full of ethnic restaurants. Some good value shopping - window or otherwise!

The best neighborhood to get lost in. What's not to love? Great walking, art galleries, cafés and shops. If you want to skip the touristy parts of Paris, the Marais is perfect for you. Not crowded and something a little special down every side street.
walking tour. Fascinating area of Paris. We did our own walking tour which we had taken with us, easy to follow and fascinating area of Paris.
Great location to stay. The Marais is a great base for a Paris visit. Wonderful restaurants and sights to see. Very lively at night.
great area of Paris. lots of culture, great shops,great places to eat.great market at le halles. can walk to a lot of the main attractions
Scenic. Beautiful and quaint area to walk around in. Cute little shops in cute little hideaways. Simply wandering around was fun.

Really neat district of Paris. We visited the Le Marais district on a drizzley day; but, still enjoyed it! Lots of little shops and restaurants everywhere, lots of churches and buildings to photograph....a photographers delight.You can get to Le Marais by either bus or subway. We took the subway since the subway station was right around the corner from our hotel.We went on an afternoon; but, were told that the district really comes to life after 9pm...we can't vouch for this as we had other things to do in the evening.The only difficulty that we had was trying to pick a restaurant for lunch. All of the restaurants had a "formula" menu where you can pick different courses such as appetizer, main course, and desert for a fixed price. Prices in the area ranged from about 10 euros to 20 euros per person.
My favorite district in Paris. Best district. Reminds me of the West Village in New York City. Few tourists, great boutiques, amazing restaurants and still accessible. C'est ce bon!

Must visit!. This neighbourhood is so cozy and alive. Lots of small shops and restaurants and cafés. Perfect if you want to spend some money, or just want to look. You can easily spend a whole day here.

Homey Neighborhood. one of the nicest districts in Paris!
a lot of shops to walk around to see, amazing coffee shops and little restaurants as well as bars and pubs
very amusing walk and people are super nice u'd love all u see around there, definitely worth exploring while in Paris

I always go back to this neighborhood!. What a diverse place! You can go from the most innovative boutiques to the old Jewish quarter in the space of a few minutes. I like to just wander around and see what is in store. Be sure to have a cool drink or a coffee at a sidewalk café and just watch the vibrant life of the Marais go by.
love it. loved all the windy side streets lines with cafes bars and interesting shops - easy to get lost in the pathways :)

Nice authentic Paris!. If you want to see real Paris this quarter is a must! I stayed there twice and really enjoyed it! Lotsa shops and bars around! Within a walking distance to any attraction in the downtown!

Loved this area of Paris. My husband and I spent almost an entire day in the Marais. My husband wanted to tour the Jewish Museum on rue Temple. Before and after that, we did quite a bit of exploring. There are many wonderful streets full of shops, cafes, bakeries, etc. -- really almost too much to take in. My husband particularly enjoyed finding a pastry shop that reminded him of his childhood. We would stop frequently as we walked to study the street scenes and take pictures. My husband got a wonderful shot of two incredibly well-dressed women who seemed like characters right out of a 1950s Audrey Hepburn movie. Anyone considering a few days in Paris should definitely put the Marais high on the list of things to experience.
Very nice neighbourhood. We have enjoyed all the streets of this area, a must go when you are in Paris. Nice cafes and nice people with art galleries and small shops...

Wonderful arrondisement. What a vibrant community! We walked through many districts (often walking more than 10 miles a day) but always appreciated our return to Le Marais. So many little cafes, boulongeries, patisseries, charcouteries, restaurants, marches, fresh produce markets (don't know the word for these) - absolutely wonderful. We would return here in a flash!
charming. enjoyed the ambience, architecture, shops. Casual atmosphere. Beautiful buildings, more real , great patisseries. Hidden courtyards

Intriguing part of town. Le Marais has a lot of interesting things to do. It is the rejuvenated Jewish district of Paris, has lots of good little restaurants and cafes, an interesting museum called the History & Art of Judaism, and is Gay Central, as it turns out! I ate at a nice cafe called Korcarz, passed the Pompidou Center, and had a gelato at Raimo Glacier.

Stroll and Shop and Enjoy. Marias contains lots of little shops on lots of little streets that are simply everything you want to experience when in Paris. Bought a gorgeous little dress from Elizabeth Anne that I will treasure for years. Take time for a break in a chic little cafe and chat over un verre de vin. Sweet Marais.

Great place for a Sunday visit. We visited early on a Sunday morning and pretty much had the place to ourselves. The French sleep in on Sundays so enjoy watching Paris waking up. We started with the Place de Voges which is quite lovely. And so we just ambled along enjoying this delightful area. By lunchtime it starts to get a little busier and picks up the pace in the afternoon. Lots of nice little restaurants to choose from. Recommended for a Sunday morning.
Great destination. what a great place to tour, visit and get lost in. Avoid the morosity of the local retailers and absorb the beauty of the environment, and you will fall under the charm

Lovely taste of knishes. I spent some time wandering around the Marais during my recent trip to Paris. It was wonderful, I had a knish for a snack and a falafel for lunch. The multi-ethnicity of this neighbourhood was tremendously enjoyable!

My Favorite Arrondissement. If you love art, great food and shopping, don't miss a day in the Marais. It is known for great Jewish delis, and I can vouch for that. It is also a district that is very gay friendly, so you'll find great shopping and great restaurants.

An evening in search of a kosher dinner. During our trip to Paris in June, my wife and I decided that we wanted a kosher dinner in the Marais, the Jewish Quarter of Paris. We started at the Place de Voges which we last visited over 40 years ago. It had changed completely. It was beautifully maintained, child friendly and inviting. We had a lovely stay but had difficulty finding a Kosher restaurant because it was difficult finding Rue de Rosiers. However when we did we had a wonderful meal at an Israeli themed restaurant. By the way there are a few museums in the area. Unfortunately one of them, the Picasso Museums was closed for renovations. In sum the Marais is worth the adventure just bring a better map than we had.

Nice walk for a Sunday. Went there on Sunday which I think is a good day of the week to go as most of Paris is closed for shopping on Sunday and the Marais is open due to it being part of the Jewish quarter. A lot of small shopping boutiques and bakeries were open. We spent about 3-4 hours strolling the area.

Our favorite neighbourhood when visiting Paris. Every year in september, we spend a week in Paris and stay at the Beaubourg Hotel, right by the Beauboug museum, our favorite. Great value, especially if you book well in advance. We love the neighbourhood, so young and lively, at the same time within walking distance to so many places. From the Chatelet metro stop, we go directly anywhere in Paris as well as to the airport.
Go on a sunday in the old Jewish quarter.. Great shopping, food and people watching. Pay for two days for the hop on/off bus. See all of Paris 4 different routes.
Love this area interesting shops and cafes. I loved wandering around this area with interesting shops and cafes with great coffee and macarons, so easy to get to on the metro
Charming!. This is a must see in Paris. The old Parisian feel is everywhere, and the streets are lined with beautiful, old architecture. Check out the falafel eateries too!
Crazy Fun. Fantastic place to potter and poke about. Fascinating history, great bars.... Very crowded on Sunday but great atmosphere.

Best sunday location. On sunday where nearly all the shops are closed in Paris , you should visit Marais. Many nice stores , should eat fallafel and also if you have a child the park at the palace des vosges will be a great visit.
A chance to see the real Paris.. A good area to explore but even better for a guided walk with Paris Greeters. Gives you an insight to the Paris away from the main tourist areas.

So much to see and to do. So, it is hip and young. It is history and beautiful architecture. It is wonderful shopping. Yes it can be touristy and crowded. It also has tiny fabulous boutiques of clothes, accessories, art. And museums...a treat, a real treat.

Amazing area. I LOVED this area and will go back every time I'm in Paris. It's full of amazing buildings and is a great place to wander around getting lost. There's so much history there. My favorite area of Paris. And the shopping is amazing too!

Great for walking tour. Atmospheric area of small streets with little shops, boutiques, great cafes and bars is a lovely area for walking tours. My latest find is Merci (111 Blvd Beaumarchais), a concept shop housed in a 19th century regenerated fabric factory. It's three lofty floors contain an array of furniture, fashion, stationery, flowers and household goods. You can drink great coffee in the onsite cafe, part of which has book-lined walls. Speaking of books, the Red Wheelbarrow English bookshop is also in Le Marais (24 Rue Mayet).
nicest area in Paris. This is Paris at its best. Very cosy atmosphere, enough huzzle and buzzle to feel you in Paris but quiet enough to wander through little streets. Nice cafe's and pubs

A shadow of its former glory. This is the centre of eclectic fashion and the oldest Jewish quarter. The number of Kosher establishments is falling and although packed with tourists is not as buzzing with Parisians as it used to be. Worth a visit if passing.

Great place to wander. This is a great area to wander and absorb some of the essence of Paris. You will see great shops mixed in with history. For the most part the shops are pricey, but many items are unique. It depends upon what you are looking for and how much you wish to spend.
Fascinating district. Pretty streets, the glorious Place des Voges, rue des Francs Bourgeois and its lovely shops, bars, cafes etc, rue des Rosiers and its Kosher food shops etc etc.
Le Marais. Probably my favourite area in Paris. Its so very French but escapes the large tour groups. Its refined, simple and classic French style.

Close to everything best location. We stayed in Le Marais in an apartment for 8 days, this was a great choice. The location is perfect for a tourist to this wonderful city. It is walking distance or a short metro trip to all of the major attractions. The area is full of wonderful restaurants all within walking distance and the streets are lined with some of the best boutiques in Paris. As other reviewed shave mentioned do not miss the Place des Vosges, just beautiful. We also did a bike tour of the area and it was brilliant. Would highly recommend this area to anyone travelling to Paris.
delightful area to stay. The Marais is so close to everything, you can stroll to many attractions easily. There are great restaurants and shops around.

Just enough of the unfamiliar with the familiar. I have been travelling to Paris on an off for 40 years and I still discover things about it I never knew before. North Americans think of it as an old city, but much of what is familiar about Paris -- the wide boulevards, the Eiffel Tower etc. -- were only constructed in the 19th century. But the Marais is an amalgam of the new and the very old Paris...great clothing boutiques, neighbourhood restaurants, and beautiful plazas like Place des Vosges. We always go back to Marais, and I always shop for men's shirts there. There is no better place on the planet for colourful men's shirts.

Old Paris. Le Marais is the closest you will get to the feel of medieval Paris and has more pre-revolutionary buildings and streets left intact than any other area in Paris. A glance at some of the beautiful buildings and houses indicates the wealthy status of the former residents. After the revolution, much of the area was abandoned by the rich, and poor bohemian types moved in. The area was considered so squalid at this point it was nearly destroyed by city officials who wanted to modernize Paris. You should keep in mind that before Napoleon showed up the Marais is what most of Paris looked like, a labyrinth of cobblestone alleys. The rest of Paris was razed by Napoleon and Haussman who wanted to build huge avenues and gigantic squares such as the Place Concorde. These are now the glory of Paris, but they were originally conceived so that armies and artillery could be moved around the city to keep the poor in check and defeat invaders. On a more metaphysical level, the purpose of such broad space is to make the citizen feel small and powerless when faced with the giant civic machine of government, or an obedient army. In the Marais we are privy to the small and approachable Paris of the past, the place to wander in maddening circles and never find your way, the place to hole up and read Sartre or Camus in a café window or stare at that Parisian beauty with her slim cigarette and wild scarf. The Marais is also the most famous Jewish quarter in Paris and in much of Europe, still maintaining strong traditions.

Wonder area with Great history. Wonder historic area of Paris with the same charm,culture,shops and food to enhance it. Worth an afternoon stroll through what was the old Jewish quarter in Paris. Just a lot of fun and a place we always stop when we are in this wonderful city

Great Neighborhood.... for history, shopping, eating and wandering. You may want to spend a day or two in the Marais. It is so diverse and interesting, you could spend an entire vacation just in the Marais. It is two arrondisemonts, so get a good guide book.
Getting lost. What a wonderful place to get lost in, strolled the old mansions and wonderful shopping! People are warm and friendly.

Has become excessively "trendy" but still very much worth a stroll. The Marais has gone upmarket since I first lived there in the 1980s. The streets are cleaner, and many new boutiques restaurants and bars have opened. After the grotty atmosphere in and around Montmartre, the Marais sparkles.While you are there, do not miss the Place des Vosges (the old center of Paris) and try and visit the Madame de Sevigne museum (called the Musée Carnavalet) in the Rue de Sevigne (just up the street from the fire station and quite near the St Paul-Marais metro station). This shows the fascinating history of the city of Paris. Good tip: it is free of charge.

Must visit!. I did the Marais Walking Tour with one of the tour companies. This was a good idea, because it is like a maze of small streets and alleyways. Along the way we saw the boutiques of up and coming designers and galleries. Do not miss the famous falafel restaurants.

great area to wander about. Jewish quarter -so don't go on a Saturday as all shut. Fabulous street food - falafel etc - such an experience to queue and worth the wait. Wonderful street music, and super small shops.

Great central location. We selected Le Marais as the place to stay based on a desire to be very central but a little biased to the east - being close to Notre Dame/Ile St Louis. Also we were drawn to the cosmopolitan nature of the area and the interesting Jewish section.We were not disappointed. It was a brilliant location. We rented an apartment through Airbnb that was on the Rue des Archives just up from the Rue de Rivoli with a great department store (BHV) opposite and 10 cafes/restaurants within 50 metres. Easy walking to Notre Dame/Left Bank/Place des Vosges.The only drawback was the night noise. We were on the 4th floor and directly above what would have to be the nosiest bar in Paris. We were there in the heatwave of late July and with no air-conditioning had to leave the windows open. Need I say more. Still at least we were able to pop across the road to the department store to buy a fan - which we left in the apartment.Apart from that we loved having a week in Le Marais.

Take the time to wander.. One of our favourite parts of Paris. It's a great area to stay in with many restaurants, cafes, food shops (especially the patisseries) and bars. It's perfect for watching the locals as they go about their business. So much to see as well with beautiful buildings, several museums and don't forget Place de Vosges. It's an easy trip into the very heart of Paris from here as well, either by Metro or walking.

The place to stay in Paris. Le Marais is an ideal part of Paris to base yourself. Located in walking distance to everything Le Marais offers a great selection of shopping restaurants and transport. Night life and evening dinner hotspots are located throughout the district with a melting pot of nationalities and walks of life. The main metro line runs between other major lines making access to major tourist areas reachable in minutes without the need for taxis.Best areas to locate yourself are streets that run of Rue Sebastopol as this is the main road that runs from Gare de Nord down to the river.
Do not miss walking in the area. Loved walking in the neighborhood. nice little cafes. pompedo museum is in that area too. Make sure you try the Amerino ice cream there

A great walk. We used a Paris greeter. A nonprofit that gives visitors a chance to see a part of Paris through the eyes of one of its citizens. This area is full of shops,historical buildings and restaurants. This is 17th century Paris.
Best Place To Stay. So many shops, so little time. Many restaurants - take your pick of type of food. Many bars and so much character. Been to paris 3 times, would not stay anywhere else.

An excellent neighbor to walk thru. We followed Rick Steves Marais Walk. We visited the Hotel Sully, ate a gelato in the Place des Vosages. We walked thru both the old Jewish section and the more recent gay section. The Carnavalet Museum gave a good overview of French history

Intriguing area, worthy of an afternoon. We had not seen Le Marais previously on visits to Paris and wanted to be sure to check it out. We spent a few hours walking the streets particularly following the path from Eyewitness Travel's book on Paris. There are lovely parks around nearly every corner and a surprising number of upscale stores and boutiques.Le Marais also boasts some interesting history with the home of Victor Hugo and the Picasso Museum. The arcades surrounding Place des Vosges remind us of squares in Madrid.We will probably go there once in a while just for a change of scenery.
What a fun area of Paris. Narrow streets, wonderfully restored buildings in one of Paris' oldest neighborhoods teeing with activity. Great art, great food, great bars, great shopping, it has it all.
Atmospheric neighborhood.. Somehow we had never visited this neighborhood before. Fell in love with it. Narrow pedestrian streets, lots of action, street musicians, charming!

Fantastic place to stay. We stayed in an apartment in Le Marais, what a brilliant location! Convenient to walk to other cool parts of Paris, but so hard to venture far as the temptations of Le Marais are so great! Boutiques, shops, restaurants, cafes, bakeries, delis, etc.. All within meters of the front door. Loved it.
Lively and Beautiful. This area was the Jewish Quarter and still maintains that atmosphere. Now there are many beautiful shops, interesting restaurants and don't miss a rest in the Place des Voges.

Beautiful architecture, great food!. The architecture of Le Marais is so beautiful, I wanted to take a photograph every block! We stayed at the lovely Hotel Paris France, a tiny boutique hotel in the heart of the Marias with the same beautiful architectural details. We also enjoyed the delicious patisseries on rue de Temple and the statue at the Place de Republique and if you want an unforgettable truly Parisian lunch or dessert, with the best coffee in Paris, go to Le Carrett in the Place des Vosges, with more gorgeous architecture and unforgettable French onion soup and desserts! We loved Le Marais and Hotel Paris France, highly recommend staying there and we will return!

A timeless place. The Marais is the traditional Jewish quarter of Paris. Though no longer isolated and somewhat recovered from the great tragedy, The district offers some of the most unusual shops and restaurants in the city.. Hidden gems of museum displays and small hotels make the Marais one of the really special places in Paris. Perfectly located at the St. Paul Metro stop the whole area is extremely convenient to anywhere in Paris and well worth spending some time.

Lovely walk. This was close to where we were staying. Some really great boutiques, also some historic buildings people can walk through, jazz artists playing on the streets and then chanced into Fleux store in Marais.. OMG you have to visit this store if you are into cool funky home decor.

Walking Tour, A Must. This area of Paris is on the smaller side. The benefits to Le Marais are the walking tours you can take yourself on...It's known for it's Jewish quarters as well as the the chic and upscale boutique shops. My favorite part are all the old mansions that are now used for museums. (Plus, most are free!)There is plenty to see!

Far from the madding crowd. We spent a week in the la Marais in September and we loved it. A vibrant community away from the busier tourist centres but just a quick ride to get to most attractions. Plenty of restaurants/cafes/bars to choice from. Our faves were Ravat, Au fil des Saisons and L'Intention. The only annoying thing about the area is that there are so many good looking people haha.
Lovely area if Paris. This is a lovely area of Paris, slightly away from the centre but well serviced by shops and restaurants without the bustle and hurry of other areas.

The Marais - favorite in Paris. I discovered the Marais years ago, and it continues to be one of my favorite areas of the city. I frequent Mariage Freres tea shop, both to buy tea and to have the afternoon tea and treats. The Picasso musee is in this area of Paris. Also Place de Voges. It's an interesting area for artists - Picasso lived there as did Gertrude Stein and Alice B Toklas. The small lanes are charming, and it's an easily walkable area. There is alot of history in the Marais. Many years ago, it was the Jewish area of Paris. The best kitchen store, Dehillerin, is wonderland for those who love to cook. The Maille Mustard shop is on 6 Place de la Madeleine. I have visited the Marais every time I've been to Paris, and always found it to be so pleasant, interesting and always surprising.

Thoroughly enjoyed strolling the streets. We are staying in this area and decided after a couple busy days to enjoy what the neighborhood has to offer. What a delight particularly away from the main roads. Many places to window shop and great little cafes to sit and enjoy the food and wine and watch the people going by! Went to see Musee Carnavalet which was a real hidden gem and free! If you have the time would recommend having a look.
Le Marais - two-faced. The part of the Marais located around the Seine is stunningly beautiful but farther out it gets pretty rough. Many, many too many cheesy tourist shops

The Marais is the place to be. Never having stayed in the area made it very special. We spent a week in Paris and much of the time in the Marais. We loved the Jewish flavor of the area and its rich Jewish history, although sad to learn that many of the deportations during WWII were from this area. Now it is a fabulous, hip area with lovely restaurants, bars, boutiques and a beautiful park.

A meandering stroll. Interesting small museums and small eateries offering multiple small dishes were great. The Jewish Arts and History Museum was hard to find but interesting once located, Picasso was closed...bummer!
Trendy. Great little area for walking, eating, shopping and people watching. Keep to the back streets for the most picturesque parts of the Marais.
Le Marais. First time that i've had time to visit the Marais area. Fantastic boutiques and some of the best restaurants.
Definitely worth a visit. A sweet, rich and diverse area, where you will find to do both day and night. Feel safe and inviting.
Trendy. Very trendy and chic area and also very expensive. Clothes in Paris are very small sizes. Hard to find anything above a 10.

Great part of town. We have always stayed in Le Marais when in Paris. It's an eclectic and exciting neighbourhood which combines the best of old buildings, cobbled winding streets (which escaped the attention of Baron Hausmann), a wide variety of great restaurants and food stores and shops of every description plus some very interesting people to look at!Place des Vosges in the middle of Le Marais is the most beautiful square in Paris and the area is very convenient to all the other major tourist sites.A great place to stay or visit.

The place to be!. We stayed in a small studio in La Marais for a week. The area is fabulous with winding streets leading to lovely stores, packed cafes, green space, galleries, great food, and friendly people. Not to be missed.

History mixes with upscale shops and little eateries. This is a fascinating section of Paris. Beautiful Hotels Particuliers which are now museums (Musee Carnavalet - museum of the history of Paris), the Picasso Museum, the Place des Vosges, with at No. 6 the apartment where Victor Hugo spent many years with his family. Terrific little restaurants, fun shops and serious ones (Karl Lagerfeld). This is the old Jewish neighborhood, with much history and architectural interest. Not to be missed!!

Afternoon walking and fun. The Marais is a great area to browse. You can spend a few hours meandering the wonderful old streets and enjoying the great boutiques and shops; visit the Place des Vosges for its serene glimpse of 1600s elegance, and soak up all the culture of the Jewish quarter. An excellent way to spend an afternoon, along with a falafel picked up from the Rue des Rosiers, and followed maybe by a nice local cafe stop for a drink before you head elsewhere.

The Paris we Love. If you haven't visited the Marais (or even if you have), we suggest a walking tour so that you will find places you might not see on your own. There are parts of the Marais full of very interesting Jewish history, great shopping areas, lots of green areas to sit in and relax, all levels of restaurants, wonderful neighborhoods to wander. Try ParisWalks tours for exploring this and other parts of this captivating city.
Tourist Mecca. A good reason to avoid this area as it is absolutely overrun with tourists. Nothing notable unless you enjoy shopping at chain stores.

an artistic neighbourhood. One of kind place, with amazing places to eat, a lot of very nice art galleries, a lot of shops , great just taking a walk enjoying the super fashionistas people , and the nice buildings !

Great place to stay. With it's many shops and restaurants, and slightly cheaper accommodation than the close arrondissements on the left bank, the Marais is a great place to stay in Paris. It's a bit quirky, very old, not so touristy, and very close to all the major attractions.

Great area to wander around in, but it sure is touristy!. This is an excellent area to wander around in. The shopping is excellent, and the shops are open on Sundays, unlike much of Paris. This area is slightly bohemian, but it has gotten popular and is often rammed with tourists. Place de Vosges is nice for its cafes surrounding a nice green square, but again, this area is super busy with tourists. Walking down the streets, there isn't enough room on the sidewalks and you are constantly dodging the cars that are passing by. Overall, I would recommend a visit if you have time and want to do some shopping, but this is not the quiet bohemian area that it used to be. Think Soho in NYC about 10-15 years ago: it used to be alive with artists but now has lots of high end stores and is crowded with tourists

One of our favourite places in Paris. We love to wander the streets in Marais. So much history, and so vibrant with its chic shops. Not as expensive as Rue de Rivoli. We plan on spending a few more days there, just watching the people and perhaps doing some quick sketches. Photos for sure.

Rented an apartment here for a week. Absolutely loved the neighborhood as a place to stay, wander, and eat. There was a grocery literally across the street and a patisserie at the end of the block (fresh baguette and croissant every morning for breakfast!). At least four restaurants with sidewalk seating on the little square down the block. As far as I'm concerned, this is how one should stay in Paris.

Take a Walking Tour. We took two tours of the Maris - one was a food tour organized by La Cuisine Paris (English Speaking), and the other was a "volunteer" tour that I learned about from a brochure I got at a spot on the bank of Seine. Both were great! The food tour "Bellies on Foot" took us all around the Marais to the bakeries, delis and other food specialty shops. The guide explained a lot about the shops and the foods and she purchased something at each stop and at the end of the tour we sat down in quiet room at La Cuisine's cooking school and tasted all the wonderful foods over a delicious bottle of wine.The "volunteer" tour was billed as local Parisians showing you the city (in English). Our guide, Justine, was fantastic. The tour is free, and the guides do them for tips - 5 or 10 euro per person is what I would suggest depending on how pleased you are with the tour.I also walked the Marais on my own in-between these two tours. I loved the area, and saw something different each time. Although I enjoyed wondering on my own, if you don't have that much time in your schedule I would definitely recommend taking a walking tour and not wandering on your own. There is so much that a guide can explain about the neighborhood that will make your time there much more meaningful and memorable.

Avoid going on weekends, but very nice arrondissement!. Be prepared to walk in this beautiful neighborhood! It looks like Paris before Haussmann has destroyed a large part of the city to give way to Boulevards. Avoid going on weekends cause you will have tourist plus the french people going to shop for clothes (expensive most of the options, but good designs). Trying one of the Jewish specialties its a must! Buy them take away and go relax at the place de Vosges (10 min walk), one of the iconic places of Paris!!

Charming part of the REAL Paris. We rented an apartment for ten days, and loved the proximity to so many attractions, great shopping boutiques and patisseries. Very safe and extremely helpful and friendly locals.

Party!. This area is filled with gay bars and clubs. Try the Gay Moulin for dinner, the owner is a riot. Grabbing a taxi when the clubs are closed is a problem and the metro is closed at that hour, thus best get some other type of transportation or leave early.

Sunday afternoon promenade (Must go!). A Sunday afternoon walk in Le Marais introduces you to real Paris. Get lost in all the beautiful streets and don't forget to admire the scenery over your head.Oh, also, perfect to stop on a terrace and have an afternoon glass of wine for people-watching.
great shopping. Great sites and shopping in Paris! Nice architecture and shops of high end...close to many other good sites...

One of our best tours. We spent a day going to neighborhoods and ate our way through Marais. One small area remains from the time when it was the Jewish area. We ate so much that afternoon in Marais and hardly regret it as we walked over 7 hours that day. There is a Jewish Museum, too down a side street. The small shops have great finds at good prices for everything.
A very pleasant mornings stroll. My girlfriend loved this area. Get off the Batobus at Hotel de ville and then wander around the streets and little shops

Stayed in Marais. Picked a hotel in Marais after reading so many tripadvisor reviews and was glad we did. So central to so many good eating places, must do locations and boutique shopping. Parisians out out in force in this area at weekends

Amazing for Gays. During the day Le Marais is a great area where you can find many boutiques and great food. At night it's THE place for gays, as there are many bars and clubs for them. Unfortunately I had a bad experience there as I was walking with some friends and we wanted to enter one of the bars, but the guy at the entrance didn't allow us girls to enter. Just guys. That was seriously rude and offensive.
wholesale. If you are a fashion retailer, le marais it's your working spot with tons of wholesale clothing and accessory boutiques

Lively and interesting, not for prudes at night. Great range of quirky shops - eg lots of vintage clothing, one-off design of all kinds - restaurants etc in a very cosmopolitan area. Large number of gay clubs and its a centre of the gay scene, so don't go if you get upset seeing men kissing each other in restaurants (we saw this several times), and six foot men with rugby shoulders in full drag when you walk past the clubs (as we did). My wife and I really enjoyed our stay here, and felt very safe all the time.

What a beautiful and vibey neighborhood in Paris. A very good base to stay in while visiting Paris. Otherwise, make the effort to come and visit Le Marias. Their is an amazing atmosphere at night with artists performing music, street cafe's etc. Most of the buildings are old and original, giving a very charming ambiance.

Amazing area to walk in and seat in one of the café, brasserie or restaurants. The atmosphere, clubs, houses, workshops are all beautiful. It is in the center of everything and walking distance from so many places.
shopping little heaven. lots of good find in the neighborhoodvery hard to find a parkingeasy to get lost but kind of fun to get lost in all kinds of different design shops...

Nice, fun and open on Sundays!. A nice part of Paris, with good ambiance and personality, nice shops and perhaps more important, everything is open on Sundays! Get lost in the small streets, enjoy a cup of coffee or a glass of wine in one of the many bars, have a nice meal, check out the macarrons at Pierre Herme..and enjoy what's best about Paris!

Great area to stay in Paris. We spent a week in an apartment in this area and thoroughly enjoyed it.So close to everything.Felt very safe at all times.Easy access to transport ,shopping and the usual tourist attractions Got to know Rue Du Rivoli

Lively, vibrant, artsy.. Lots of small galleries and artsy shops make this area fun to wander. We rented a room for a couple of weeks a few years ago, and really loved the atmosphere and charm of this historic section of Paris. It's becoming a bit trendy, so catch it before it loses its magic.
Love the Marais. Love all of the Marais! Can walk all over and close to everything. Loved the cafes...and people watching.

So much fun to explore the old Jewish area of Paris and now home to Gay Paris.. I loved the contrasts of Falafel shops with Ted Baker boutiques almost side by side. The Place de Vosges is most fun at lunchtime. You can watch school kids and adults picnic and frolic in the park. The bldgs. are Royal dwellings of old; now they are just for the super rich. You can stop by the Victor Hugo home and explore when the wind picks up or the drizzles of Paris interrupt your karma.

This is the place to stay. We have spent a week in the Marais district and have found it charming. Cafes abound and the streets are delightful. It is easy to walk to many of the sites and the buses are convenient too.

Free walking tour. We booked a free walking tour(Paris greeter. fr) from the states and made arrangements online to meet our greeter when we arrived in Paris. The greeter George spoke English and was a super friendly and knowledgeable man. We toured 2 neighborhoods, Le Marais and Bastille. There is no way that we could have received so much first hand knowledge from a tour book.This is a great group of volunteers who accepts donations for the organization.
A tourist haven. What was once a Jewish enclave is now a shoppers delight with a few Jewish food shops for those looking for something "different".Still good fun to shop in a different environment.

Great area to walk around and catch a bite.. We spent some time walking about the Marais area since it was near our hotel by the Louvre. Our only problem was that there were so many restaurants we didn't know which to choose :) Every turn we made presented another half dozen restaurants. There seemed to be a young professional vibe here - not teenagers but not your parents, either :)

Paris' BEST Neighborhood!. You cannot go wrong with a visit or stay in La Marais! There are wonderful hotels (The Hotel Duo is my favorite), shopping galore, and restaurants for every taste and budget. The proximity to the Metro, Notre Dame, Centere Pompidou, and many other attractions are just steps away. This could be one of the best kept secrets in Paris!

LOVE!. This was by far my favorite place while I was in Paris. Don't get me wrong, everything there was great but the shopping, boutiques, cafes, people, everything was great! I bought all my best souvenirs from this area. I have to say I enjoyed much more than Champs de Elysee. All the stores there were the same stores I could shop anywhere but in Le Marais the variety was wonderful! If you aren't planning to visit there make it one of your stops!
Trendy. We stayed in this area and it was fun. Lot's of great food, markets, restaurants and people. Wander the streets...safe and clean.

A nice walk. My husband and I did a walk around the Marais neighborhood and really enjoyed the history and lovely old french ambiance. We went to the Place de Voges park and the Carnavalet Museum.The Museum is free and has a lot of french history. Walking around this neighborhood is fun, safe, and lovely
Great!!. Great people and amazing stores, a lot of cool brands and really cheap prices. It is one of the popular places in Paris where young people goes.
Fun area!. Really fun area to go hang around, good relatively inexpensive shopping as compared to the rest of Paris, great falafels! A good break from the standard French fare.
Very charming!. Great neighborhood to stay in. Plenty of affordable restaurants. Easy walking access to many museums.
We stayed there & loved it. We rented an appartment very close to Republique metro station on the 3eme Arr. The place was a real gem & we'll go back many times.

Interesting Historic district to explore. ineresting lanes and alleyways, you can feel the history as you walk the streets. Interesting cafes, fashionable art galleries, quirky shops, patisseries and people.
