You can feel quite sad in the jewish area, at some locations its a place to reflect on how these people suffered and feel greatful that nazism didn't prevail .If you are interested in modern history, WW2, these areas In Paris, the Normandy beaches and many French towns and villages you can be told the stories and also feel a connection to the bravery of allied troops, the French people and the French resistance.

Visiting Paris. Le Marais is a historic area of Paris that should be visited every time when you are in Paris. Walk the aristocratic neighborhood and la "Place des Vosges" (have a café au lait with a croissant to die for), "Le musee Carnavalet" which explain Paris history and let you to discover Paris from a different angle. Walk & walk to discover Le Marais

Nice Neighborhood. This area is very nice but expensive. It has the cute narrow streets with many nice restaurants. It is quite PArisian and what a tourist would imagine Paris to look like. I walked around here a lot.

Lost authenticity. Le Marais is a very old and historic area spreading on the 3rd and 4th arrondissements of Paris. It was an aristocratic neighborhood and la "Place des Vosges" and many beautiful Hotel Particuliers show this heritage. Most of themain Hotels Particuliers have been restored and transformed into museums like "Le musee Carnavalet", which was the house of la Marquise de Sevigne, l'Hotel Sale which became the Picasso museum, and la maison de Victor Hugo on la Place des Vosges. There was a strong Jewish community in le Marais and the pretty rue des Rosiers is still a major center of Paris Jewish community. Now it is also a neighborhood with a strong gay community. In the cute narrow streets of the Marais you will find lot of bars, fashionable restaurants, art galleries and trendy shops, the latest one the Karl Lagerfeld shop, selling expensive little things in a small shop. When I visited recently there were shoes with a heel in the shape of an ice cream cone, I didn't inquire if it was part of the decor or real shoes. There are also many vintage shops and less exalted second hand clothes shops. After a long walk we decided to have lunch rue des Rosiers and we sat at the terrace of a tiny falafel restaurant instead of having a take-away like we did once (in another restaurant). This was a mistake and a major disappointment. We wanted to share a plate because I was not very hungry and have two drinks but we were informed that we had to order two main dishes, so we took two falafel "on a plate". We were brought two plates of something which were not falafels but small boulettes of what must be left when the bigger falafels are shaped, sinking in a sort of sickening hommous sauce without any garnish at all, even not one salad leaf. For this we paid twenty six euros which I found a rip off. No wonder that there were only tourists sitting there. The big, good, cheap restaurant of my youth where students used to go: Jo Goldenberg, closed down and is now another boring clothes shop. For the old Parisian, le Marais is just a disappointment, going the same way as le BHV. They say that you have to live with your time so I prefer to leave the place to the new comers and keep my nice memories of a place which disappeared now to start to look like an attraction at Disneyland.

Wow!. This was my first trip to Paris, and the Marais was a lovely neighborhood to stay in. Felt very safe, with lots of sidewalk cafes open late, people were super friendly and nice, food was fabulous, history buff that I am, i was overwhelmed with riches in that regard, and it was within walking distance of almost everything. Plan to stay in that arrondissment again in another month.

Best area in Paris. Not many tourist in this wonderful area. Small shops with "parisian" style, wonderful restaurants, and the best way to pass a relaxing moment at Paris. The most "Parisian" experience you can get in Paris.

A food step in the gay community.. This neighborhood is lovely and convivial. All of this small streets make me really curious about the live here. Everybody seems know everybody. It seems really pleasant to live here. I took a seat in a coffee and observe the passengers, there is a strong gay community there. Also many restaurants and coffee belong to gay and lesbian personalities.Also if you want to do shopping this the best place in Paris to find your unique clothes.

LOOOOOOVEEEEE. What's there not to love here. Adorable little streets to shop on, great comfy little terrasses to devour a book with a café crème on and great shops. THIS is waaayyy more parisian than les Champs Élysées.

Lovely District. the Marais is a fashionable district, with many trendy restaurants, fashion houses, and art galleries. I really enjoyed the shops - that offered genuine Parisian merchandise - especially the hat store and jewelry stores. A lovely area to stroll the streets, have a delicious lunch and shop til you drop.

A Great Location. We rented an apartment for one month in Le Marais. The location is wonderful. The Metro is across the street. Also there are bakeries, cheese stores, wine shops, fruit makets, grocery stores, clothing shops and of corse Starbucks within one or two blocks. It is an upscale, safe neighborhood.

Beautiful district. This is a fun area to see when in Paris. Shopping can be pricey, but fun to walk around, see the square (Vosges Square). Eat at one of the bistros. People watch. It is a very nice area that you may not have heard of or it may not be one of those locations someone would suggest, be we really enjoyed it.

Great place to explore and get lost in. My wife and I ended up on accident. I am glad we did. Once I found this place I went back everyday to enjoy food in the Jewish Quarter. There are plenty of places to shop and eat here. Its worth the visit.
Marais diversity. Lots of creative clothing and food shops mixed with parks and historic buildings and galleries. Loved it.

Filling time. It was OK, last day, all the shops were shut in Paris, so went here where the shops trade as it is the Jewish quarter. Nice quirky alleyways, and quite different shops from the rest of Paris.
Good ambiance !. Just to walk look at the hotels particuliers and boutiques. Don't miss Mariage et Frères tea boutique.

A great area to lose yourself in.. The Marais district is a great area to lose yourself in. Narrow streets, a wonderful atmosphere, boutique and mainstream shops, great cafes and restaurants, what's not to like!The area around Rue Vieille du Temple is great. Lots of people out and about sampling good food and clothes shopping.If you're staying in the Marais, you're within walking distance to places such as the Pompidou Centre and Notre Dame is literally down the road. It's also incredibly well connected with the metro train system and bus network.
lovely walking lanes, funky shops and bars.. An afternoon well spent wandering around the lanes. Safe area. Go without kids to enjoy the numerous funky bars & cafes. Hip homewares shops.
lovely area. wandered round had brunch. fantastic relaxed atmosphere which gives you a taste of Paris living. lovely little local shops, even visited a local greengrocers for some fresh fruit

Great atmosphere among locals .... If you want to get away from the tourist area while remaining in close proximity to many of the monuments...The Marais is a wonderful little treasure in the heart of Paris. Plenty of nightlife, cares and bars....we felt safe walking around at ight?

Love the shopping and falafel.. We stumbled upon the cute 4e neighborhood of Marais on rue de Rosiers simply because I had read how delicious the falafels were at L'As du Falafel. Man, people were not kidding. That is seriously the best sandwich/Falafel I've ever had. After finishing our sandwiches, we walked around and did some shopping. Lots of cute shops in the neighborhood!

Forget the Champs-Elysées!. The food, shopping and sight seeing in this district is AMAZING! There are tons of Jewish bakeries and the best Falafel restaurant in Paris. Also, the stores there are mostly independent designer stores, so you can find a lot of unique stuff!
Charming neighborhood. Great falafel! Charming area with wonderful shops. Visited a couple times while exploring other areas.

Better than in the guide books. I loved the relaxed atmosphere, the diversity of visitors (young and older, French and foreign, Jewish, Moslems or others) and the narrow streets with interesting shops and restaurants.
During a weekend there was an exhibition of African designers in a market hall. Exotic.
This is the touch of ancient Paris. Don´t miss it.

a small 'quartier' in a big city. The marais is the old Paris:small streets,,nice 'boutiques',little tastfull restaurants of all kinds,relaxed atmosfere,nearly no cars,etc.
We went there already many times and discover each time something new!This time it was bakkery shop with a big choice in artisanal 'marsepain'.Next time in Paris, we go there again for a half day 'flannerie'.

A Walk through Jewish Paris. August perhaps not the best month to do the walk as many of the eating places we were hoping to try were closed, but did enjoy the little streets and boutiques among the buildings of past and current jewish interest to us and the main synagogue on the edge of it.

Relaxing stroll. Walk from Beauburg to Place des Vosges. On the road, buy some food at Monoprix in 71 Rue Saint-Antoine. It will be used for a Parisian-style pic nic on the grass in the middle of the place.

Wonderful Morais. The Morais is the best spot in Paris!
Affordable with great restaurants, bars and accommodation.
Close to central Paris and with a vibrant and young community.

Paris at its best. The Marais district has probably been subject to same kind of hype that befalls any urban district in a major city which is deemed 'trendy', but there is so much more to the area than the kitsch shops, bars and restaurants. The area is the centre of a vibrant gay culture, and this rubs alongside a traditional Jewish district, and a tourist hotspot. There's a genuine sense of good-humour, diversity and welcome. The restaurants are wonderful, without either being cliched or over-priced, and it's possible to get some excellent cocktails on nearly every corner!
most beautiful church. the architecture is wonderful. a must see even if you are not religious dont miss it. go to the top and see the bells

The Marais on a quiet day. Our objective was a shop in the arcade opposite the Louis XIV equestrian bronze statute. It was early. A coffee and croissant was at hand. We were wistful to walk here for 1 hour, as it was soon to be our last day in France.
Loved the vibe!. Staying in the Marais was PERFECT! The location was close to Notre Dame, the Metro and TONS of great restaurants and bars. We felt super safe and very French!

Le Marais walking tour. Did a walking tour of the Le Marais district on Sunday morning...took about 2 hours, and there were about 20 people in our group. Guide was an American who'd lived in Paris for 19 years. Really enjoyed the history of the area that he shared with us...brought this area to life for us. Next time we're in Paris, we'll go on more of these walking tours...company was Paris Walks, email paris@paris-walks.com.
Great little area of the city. Great food places and Gelato in many different flavors. It is what I always envisioned Paris would be.

Le Marais. I loved le marais so much I spent two days wandering around and going in and out of the boutiques. There is an abudance of cool shops - for the home, cutting edge fashion, vintage clothing, and good food. As an old jewish area there is lots of good places for falafel including the very well renowned l'as - a takeaway where the queue was very very long. There are good vintage "kilo" shops where you pay by the kilo of the clothes you buy and other expensive clothing shops like fred perry, sandro, the kooples. There was an amazing bookstore i visited but I cant remember the name - literature fills the ground floor when you enter and then a spiral staircase takes you beneath the street into two small rooms filled with coffee table books on everything - sex, art, death, spiritualism, fashion, history, culture. Really beautiful books which I spent the guts of an hour poring over.

Soooo rich in history. If you are in Paris , its so worth hoping on the Metro and heading away from the touristy chaos and going to Le Marais . My husband and I booked a walking tour with " Meeting The French " and were not disappointed . For close to three hours we strolled city streets, back alleys , old neighborhoods rich in history as well as churches and mansions. Our Tour guide was extremly knowledgable and helpful. We ended out tour with a stop at a tiny little off the beaten track cafe that served delicious bowls of coffee and scrumptious pies and cakes for a ridiculous low price ( sorry I can't remember the name ) however we had enjoyed Le Marais so much that we stayed for dinner and ate at a Bistro right by the Metro Saint Paul ( again my apologies ..I can't remember thename and have misplaced the business card ) there are however dozens of amazing resturants, cafes and bistro's in Le Marais that are amazing so you really can't go wrong . We also found a lovely supermarket right at the station 2 second walk , and stocked up on water and snacks for the hotel room .

All Charm and personality. It never fails to inspire ,excite and entertain me! It keeps me going back for more every time I return to Paris it has all the culture and small streets of the old great food and restaurants at every turn and it's so easy to get lost and discover all new turns at every corner

Love this area, being part of the local life is what it is all about. On previous trips, we have tried to fit in as much as possible and "seen and done it all". This trip is different. We get up late, have a quick breakfast, then by mid morning, we are looking for our coffee and "treat" (a piece of tart tartin, or a shared pastry), then focus on one thing to do.We loved the Big Bus tour as it provides a good orientation of Paris.It is safe to walk almost anywhere at night. We often see young girls on their own and we have always felt safe.The Marais district offers everything that you need, great places for coffee, great shopping, a good "vibe"all around.We booked an apartment rather than staying in hotels and are thrilled with our choice.

The old and the new. The medieval streets are picturesque, and contain some beautiful historic mansions and the Carnavalet Museum of French history. Recently many of the boutiques and bars have been updated, and some funky art shops can be found amidst the many clothes shops there. It also has a strong Jewish community, and interesting kosher shops may also be found particularly in the rue des Rosiers area. Lots of tourist now visit, so it is usually busy.

A vibrant, friendly hip, but not hipster, community. We had ten days in la Marais and would happily stay there again. There's great transport, fantastic cafes, restaurants, delis and speciality shops. Wonderful parks, particularly Place des Vosges, as well as lots of shopping options - some of the major labels as well as more edgy stuff.

My favorite zone. Love the stores......cozy stuff, bakeries, foie gras and delicious delicatessens. Very parisian.......writers, students atmosphere, not crowded. Go to Place des Vosges to lay down pn the grass during spring.

A jewel of a neighbourhood. This neighbourhood puts the trend in trendy! It's its own little enclave with cute boutiques, museums, restaurants, cafes and apartments. Be aware that the local entertainment is aware of the ambiance and they feed it for the beautiful tourist experience. You don't have to go far to find a performer singing opera, or an accordian player performing La Vie en Rose on a street corner. And, in spite of all this excessive tasteful beauty on street corners it is still a great place just to wander and get lost in for a few hours.

We stayed in this funky neighborhood. We stayed in this great artsy neighborhood where you can walk to everything. It's very active and fun in the evening with restaurants and bars not really kicking into full gear until 10:00. There's something great to look at at every corner .

Great for a walking tour. We wandered around this charming neighborhood and loved the juxtaposition of Jewish and gay culture rubbing elbows. Rick Steves' walking tour was a good starting point, but there are lots of detours to be made.

My Favorite Neighborhood. The beautiful and harmonious Marais district is my favorite neighborhood in Paris. There aren't a ton of blockbuster sights or museums (although the Carnavalet and the Shoah memorial are worthwhile stops), but the area is perfect for strolling and browsing through shops. Spend a few hours one afternoon or evening getting lost and discovering the backstreets of the Marais. Plus, my favorite restaurant in Paris, l'As du Fallafel, is in the Marais's Jewish Quarter - you won't regret eating here!

Great on Sundays.. Shops are open on Sundays in this area between the back side of the town hall and the Place des Vosges.But .... like other hidden gems, Le Marais has been gaining popularity, especially amongst tourists. Slowly chain stores are entering the area.But stil, if you have some time left on a Sunday, visiting the area and the Jewish part, is a good option.

So Much Fun So Cosmopolitan. You are in Paris and you don't spend a day in the Marais? What's wrong with you!!! There is so much to see and do - Place des Vosges and Pompidou; perfect rhyme scheme there so I'll quit, but don't forget all the brilliant restaurants and bars - oh, and it is the gay center of Paris.

This is THE place. This is probably the nicest area in Paris. Full of first class shops, famous for the falafel, nice cafe and bistrots, it's really so nice to walk around. You can combine this walk, with another walk at Saint Paul area and a break at place de Vosges.
Beautiful just to walk along. Get in it. Let yourself go. Walk just like you've been there for all your life. Soak the non-monumental Paris in.

Loads to see and do. Lovely area for browsing around and all the quaint little shops. Nice little eating places behind and tucked away as this is where the locals eat and what better place to eat.... the locals are great and if you cannot talk the language they will try and make themselves understood. glad we visited this area and ate with the locals. remember all restaurants on main roads are double the price and not very homely. prefer the homely little places
Good shopping and dining. The Marais is nice, and there's a fantastic music store called fnac in their Forum. Three flights of dvds, cds and equipment at very reasonable prices!

A unique atmosphere. Very Parisian, with great people watching opportunities, and shops. The shops are not your large chains, but individual and unique so good for buying that something different. Great cafe culture here, and as the light descends into night time, a great party area, with a huge variety of nightlife to suit all tastes and budgets. Don't miss it!!

Nice area to walk around. Lots of boutique shops and food/pastry stores to wonder around this area.If you got a few hours to kill and don't mind wondering around (fairly aimlessly) then you can find some nice little shops

Everything changes. Universal truth, but the Marais has gone from being an interestquart wither, with many diffent sorts of shops and restaurants, to one that features high end shops, many of them chains, and restaurants that cater mainly to tourists. The wonderful old Jewish quarter is disappearing rapidly. The museums are still there as well as the old churches and historic houses, but in between these, the Marais has lost it's spirit and character.We have loved coming here year after year, but this year will be our last visit. I can find Gap and Lee in the States.

One of the really best places to be in Paris!!. Hi there!Use to live in very different areas in Paris and I have to say that one of the most charm full place is without any doubt the Marais!Great cafes & great places for art and the somptious "places des Vosges".You might find there a very special vibe and a very strategic location near everything as Bastilles & rue des rosiers & art gallery &design places and good music.To go and go again !highly recommended.Cheers! Oliver.

les bon vivants. This place never sleeps, we were there during the music festival, it was crazy fun. so many people in the streets. all the restaurants were open till late. you just have to walk around and go from one bar to another . Funky places.Otherwise it is very nice area for shopping, having dinner, or in the afternoon have a drink and just sit around and look at the people. A very lively place.

Sunday in Paris ? Le Marais. Whether you are a jaded parisian or a fresh tourist spending hardly the first week of your life in our beautiful capital, you're not stranded on your sofa (appartment or hotel room one's) on Sunday. Get to the Marais, enjoy all that the place has to offer from International Fashion store to Kosher retaurants and the best EggPlants Caviar you'll ever taste in your life at Sasha Finjkelstein store rue des rosiers. You love design: plenty to shop around. You want to feel in Historcal Paris ? walk to nearby Place des Vosges. Want to feel a more american vibe ? Have a hamburger at Schwartzs rue des Ecouffes. Want to feel the jewish vibe of the area ? Sasha Finjkelstein of course but also the Gefilte fish restaurant rue des Ecouffes as well.

Always a lively place to visit on a Sunday afternoon. Head here on a Sunday when all the other shops in town are closed. Great cafes, Mediterranean and kosher food. Lots of shopping - mostly international brands but there are some French-based brands as well that you cannot get elsewhere. You just have to look or know what to look for.

Musee de Picasso. We wanted so much to visit the museum; housed in Hotel Salee (sic) but unable to locate and later while dining at a terrific café were told it was closed for 'renovations' - on our list for next trip!

Le Marais. The Marais district has become very trendy and upscale--full of expensive jewelry and antique shops. Work your way over to Rue des Rosiers for authentic falafels--two restaurants across the street facing each other but you cannot go wrong in either one.

Make the Marais a Stop on Your Paris Tour. The Marais is a quirky section of Paris located in the 4th Arrondissement. Lots of shops and restaurants, as well as the FREE Musee Carnavalet which is awesome! Also very worthwhile are the place des Voges and Victor Hugo's house. The Musee Picasso is also located here, but we were very disappointed that it had not reopened after renovations in time for our visit. In any case, the Marais is a MUST while in Paris!
Great part of town. We were pleasantly surprised with Le Marais mostly because it is not over-run by tourists. There is a great selection of stores and restaurants.

Our favourite area in Paris. We've been there a few times before so we were delighted to get a hotel deal just S of Republique, NNE of the main Marais area. Being August there were an awful lot of restaurants and shops closed and it was disappointing that the Picasso Museum is still undergoing refurbishment. But it was still an interesting area to walk around - very necessary as it has a large area with no metro stations. A good route through the Marais is to start at the Seine and walk up Rue Vieille du Temple, diverting down Rue des Rosiers, where Hannas does great falafels with a much shorter queue than the place further East.

Quaint and lovely. Before heading over to Paris, I did quite of bit of research. I knew Le Marais was a neighborhood I wanted to explore. It was there that I was able to purchase a scarf that was hand made by a French textile artisan by the name of Muriel Geoffrey. She was as charming as her little shop and spent a great deal of time having me try on many different colors and styles. As one would imagine, they were not cheap. However, I felt it really important to return with a true Paris treasure. The shop consists of five women who create works of art by using their hands and their imaginations. They don't take American Express, so bring euros or debit/cc.

Fabulous historic area of Paris. Packed full of narrow streets and old buildings a walk through Le Marais is like a time warp. Victor Hugo's house overlooking the place des Vosges, the most beautiful park in Paris in my opinion, is a must see. Sip a coffee in one of the bistros in the arcades and pursue the many art galleries. Visit the Jewish quarter too.

Walk it to appreciate it.. Walk the Marais. It's not huge but it's fascinating and eccentric and you need to immerse yourself in it. Do a little prior research (book or google) to get the best out of it. Place de Vosges is lovely and a great place to eat a packed lunch. The museum of Jewish life in Europe was rewarding and worth the hour we spent in there. The Marais is best done early in your Paris stay as it brings you and Paris together in a way that a visit to the other more obvious attractions doesn't .
Wonderful to walk around. If it doesnt rain, go there for a walk, you will find lots of little shops that ususally you cannot find elsewhere.

Awesome neighborhood. We rented a flat in this area and it was perfect. A great location and central to everything. On the Summer Solstice the entire streets close down and turn into a giant dance club which was incredible to experience. Lots of cute cafes and boutique shops here.
Paris!. The Marais is a very special place. There is a huge variety of all kind of art, fashion, architecture, terraces .... Here you can breath what Paris has to offer.

A neighborhood for a Sunday. This is a fun neighborhood that offers lots of Sunday Brunch possibilities. It is an ancient neighborhood, at one tme a jewish getto. The rements remain with backeries that have become up scale boutiques but retained the traditional signage and architecture. Good News! You will see lines at the famous Falaffel stand, discover antique silver stores that sell by the pound, the fabulous Museum of the City of Paris and perhaps if open The Picasso Museum.

Wonderful streets for walking around. Take your time and walk the many streets of the Marais and discover the history of Paris in the Musee Carnavalet, Victor Hugo's apartment and many other places...many have no cost to enter! Lovely parks for sitting and eating lunch and great stores for shopping.

fashionable neighbourhood. i love Le Marais for the plethora of second-hand shops and all the trendy Parisian labels (The Kooples and Sandro are my favourites) in one area. i also particularly enjoy the falafel on Rue des Rosiers! get lunch time treat for cheap.

The happiest arrondissement in Paris. Take the Metro to Bastille or walk from Notre Dame and hotel de Ville. You enter Place des Vosges,the most beautiful square in paris. Notice the delicate brickwork,the small variation to the mansions, the exquisite park with its sculptures and tended gardens and the children playing. Did you know,that Les Miserables, was written at number6,where Victor Hugo lived. Its worthwhile to see what the area was like at the hight of its grandeur by visiting the Carnavalet Museum which is filled with the history of paris.  Grab a coffee and enter rue Thorigny for the Picasso museum. If you are interested in the Jewish Quarter just stroll up Rue de Rosiers. This was once the largest enclave of jewish community in Europe. Today, the street is packed with delis,bakeries.old hamams and eateries especially fallafel joints. Yummmmm. The Rue St.Antoine in the center is marvelous with the square of St.Catherine being my favorite at night for its amazing atmosphere in this small square ringed by old apartments and giant trees with soft light filtering down through the leaves and the glow of street lamps. There are nice bars and restaurants strung around the perimeter of the square to sit,eat and sip a glass of wine. The Marais is also known for its numerous art galleries and design shops,a bit like Soho in Manhattan. The high end art in some cases is an enormous waste of beautiful space,in others,very satisfying art. If you are interested more in early 20 th century artists,go to Rue de Seine in St.Germain for a better spot to look. You have by now a raging thirst.....so head to La Cave a Bulles for a huge choice in artisan beers. Enjoy the small crooked medieval lanes are alive with bars,eateries,because this is the closest you can get to medieval Paris which is packed with pre- revolutionary buildings and streets left intact. This is my favorite historic district in paris. As you amble further,you notice the influence that the chinese community have contributed on Rue du Temple and Place de la Republic. Other features of the neighborhood include the Musee Picasso,musee carnavalet and the brilliant Musee d'Art et d'histoire du Judaisme. You are now walking in the shoes of famous personalities like,Robespierre,Hugo,Galliano and Dominique- Strauss-Kahn For a good nosh try Chez Marianne,Pitchi poi and the Jewish bakery for incredible pastry.And remember not to miss out on a quiet read at the City of Paris History Library. This is the area where walking with a copy of Sartre and Camus is considered tres cool

Always worth a visit. Many times here in the past, yet still worth a stop for its color, variety, and sense of history. Touristy, yes, especially in August, but that can be overlooked. Lots of nice cafes as well.

I love this part of Paris. I want to go back! Everyone was nice. Saw some very cool meshing of cultures here that I hope can be encouraged everywhere - gay, Jewish, Mediterranean, etc....Just a great vibe, great food, nice people. Did I say I want to go back here???

Lovely area with very cute boutique shops. The Marais is a lovely area, with lovely little boutique shops as well as some very trendy ones like the Karl Lagerfeld store and it is open on a Sunday, which is rare in Paris.
Very nice place for walking. I like everything there streets, statues, historic places, churches, Pompidou center....small shops....everything is great and wonderful

Nice area. It's a nice area, but it's a little expensive. You might find nice cafés and restaurants in other neighborhoods, but less expensive. Though, It's worth to walk around to see the beautiful architecture.
window shopping. Visit this part of the city to pass small boutiques with fashionable and extravagant clothing, bags, decorations, or sit in a nice restaurant to watch people pass by...

Different kind of Paris. Paris is amazing, beautiful city that you can explore for weeks and still not see everything worth seeing. One of the parts that must be visited and is quite different than the rest of the city is: Le Marais. Many buildings in that area are medieval, from 17 and 18 century with gorgeous, breath taking architecture. It's a tourist spot with great restaurants, cafes and stores. Le Marais was and still is a Jewish and lately a popular gay community. It's friendly and full of people, not just tourist, but locals too, as you can find cheap eats in little kiosks, especially the best falafels in the city as well as sweet and savory crapes. Laidback atmosphere that surrounds Marais is so relaxing that you'll want to come back again and again.

A fun District with great restaurants. Well, this is the gay and jewish district and it is fun!The restaurants and general vibe in this area was great.I'm not sure I'd stay in this area (not that it isn't safe - it could be loud though) but I would definitely have a meal or two here. Fun place. Worth a visit and a meal.

street chic and uber hip. this a great arrondisement in paris home to great sidewalk cafes...cool independant shops and great gay bars. If in paris you should either stay in this area or visit frequently. The vibe is great and the people very friendly.

Brilliant for a mini walking tour. A neighbourhood not to be missed. Try getting off at the Bastille metro stop and walking through Place des Vosges, along Franc Bourgeois (take the side streets too), down rue Pavée crossing Saint-Antoine (St Paul metro) and continuing onto Francois Marón to finally turn left and cross Pont Louis over the Seine. Take your time and ramble through the galleries and shops. Stop for lunch and make a day of it. You won't be disappointed.

We had a fabulous day. The Marais is an interesting quarter in which it is easy to get lost. Do your homework before you go. It has an old Jewish neighborhood with kosher eateries and bakery, and some lovely boutiques. It has a hippy vibe and is full of all sorts of interesting Parisians. There are some nice restaurants and cafes in the area--like in most of Paris. It was a fun place to wander with no destination in mind.

Charming area full of cafes and shopping. Where Bobo meets Weho. Trendy in places yet it doesn't abandon the charm of old Parisian streets. You can shop for a picnic with ready to eat gastronomic delights, or find a cozy cafe to people watch. A great way to spend an afternoon or evening.

Great area!. Crowded on a Sunday in July, but worth it. Loved the atmosphere, cafes, shops, quaint streets. We ate the best falafel sandwich ever although it had to be consumed while sitting on a ledge by a doorway!Getting goodies from Sasha Finkelstein,s bakery reminded me of my NYC roots.

Great stay at this neighbourhood.. We stayed at this neigbourhood for 3 weeks and had a great time. It's my third visit in Paris (stayed at 6th and 7th before) and looking forward to staying at La Marais area once again on my next visit.

Worth a visit. The are reminded me a little of Bath in England. It's very tasteful with little shops, galleries and cafes. Place de Vosges is worth a visit - so is the Musee de Victor Hugo. Lovely park in square.

Quaint and chic. This is a very quaint area with lots to discover. It is easy to get lost but so much fun too! It is an expensive area by comparison to other less touristy areas but is has so much charm that you don't mind paying for this. They have amazing patisseries, the boutiques are divine and if you like beautiful old churches, go and fins St Louis St Paul. It is a beautiful church with beautiful altars, the windows are a work of art and while we sat meditating, we hear chanting in the background. Beautifu! Love Le Marais - go and explore it!!!!!
Lots of shops. Very typical Paris.. We liked all of the Marais that we were able to see. There is a good open market on the boulevard of rue Richard Lenior on the weekends.

Lesser known, but well worth a visit. The Marais: Read up on the history of this colourful area. It will enrich your experience.We were entranced by La Place de Vosges, a beautiful square over which a statue of Louis XIII stands guard. It is surrounded by interesting galleries and upmarket shops. Places of interest would include the homes of Victor Hugo and the famous Cardinal Richelieu, leading character in The Three Musketeers by Alexandre Dumas and founder of the Academie Française. Richelieu is also said to be the world’s first Prime Minister. Adjacent to cobbled streets with bohemian boutiques and cafes, this part of Le Marais provides a wide sociological spectrum of Paris from the 14th to the 20th century. Look out for the café Les Philosophes, meeting place for Jean-Paul Sartre, Albert Camus, Gustav Flaubert and other members of the existentialist movement. It is still popular with students and nouveaux intellectuals, so you will be lucky to get a seat, far less a table. A very pleasant quarter in which to spend some time.

What a lovely place to roam!. While we were in paris a few friends from Reims travelled to Paris to meet us and suggested we meet in Le Marais. Le Marais is bustling with people and things to look at, with something interesting round every corner. We found a tapas restaurant to watch the world go by at and the staff were animated and friendly, plus my plate of charcuterie and fromages was splendid. I can't wait to go back!
Must have missed the streets?. Wondered around looking for the right area but must have been off target. Nothing exciting - was expecting a lot!

excellent shopping area. It's always fun shopping in this area because of the variety of boutiques that are located here. One should be prepared to spend some money because there are plenty of things to buy that you can't find anywhere else. There are quite a few nice places to eat, too, like Les Bonnes Souers.

Wow...don't miss it.... sunday is a perfect day to stroll in "Le Marais"...great restaurants,i meam this is a very ethinic area,casual an lay back,and pack!!!The croweded makes this area even more festive,put something in your mind relax and enjoy,this is "le Marais"

St Paul in the Marais. Take the metro to St Paul in the heart of the Marais. Just near the exit is the stunning parish church of St Louis-St Paul. Go in, be charmed, pray and light a candle for those gone by. The beautiful front altar is flanked by equally fine altars. The paintings and statues at the front echo God's forgiveness. This working church has a long history to tell, but you can check that out.Opposite, walk up the street to the right. You will come first to Musee Canavalet (the museum of the history of Paris, and a must) and later the Musee Picasso. On your return, take a prix fixe, two course lunch at 15 euros. Over lunch, you can decide if the marquise madame de Sevigne, whom you met at the Canavalet, should be remembered by a brand of fine chocolates bearing her name. Guess aristos have to work these days. Round about, traiteurs (delis), shirt shops, shoe shops, Monoprix department store super bargains ... jostle for your interest. Prices on sale are as good as Dubai. A coffee or ice cream perhaps as you watch the world go by? Oh, there's a fine domed church down to the left. And more.

Do not miss out. This is a wonderful area to visit. There is a sense of energy and fun among the residents, shopkeepers and tourists. A very diverse number of places to visit including Hotel Sully, the Shoah Museum, fine stores and very ethnic restaurants. We had a great day walking around the area.

Beautiful Paris - if you had one place to visit..... Lovely to revisit this area after 20 years absence and to see it hasnt changed at all. I still ooh and aah at all the beautiful and interesting indepedent shops and little galleries that have such personality, beauty and curiosity about them. Streets of little finds and fabulous restaurants, beautiful parks and fountains to splash in which cost nothing to enjoy. Dont come to Paris and miss The Marais.

Historical area that is still thriving. We went on a walking tour of the Marais district. The two young women guides were very knowledgeable and were enthusiastic about informing us of their city, of which the Marais district played a significant role in the development of the city, and of France itself. Many thriving communities, and in the Jewish Quarter, on des Rosiers, there are several places that offer the "best falafel in the world".
Wish I had visited the Marais before. I have lived in Paris and visited Paris many times. This year was the first time I had been to the Marais, I have been missing out. Its great, just go there.
Love the cafes. Love the quaint shops, coffee shops and vibe in the tea. Stayed in cute little appartment in this tea.

Always a delight to explore. I haven't been in this area in the summer on Saturday and Sunday, but let's just say.... I think everyone else was there as well. It was VERY crowded but this only makes it more festive and a great place to be! The shops are amazing, and I kept thinking.... why can't I find these things in the USA? Looking forward to my next trip, and next time I will most likely stay in a hotel in this area since I seemed to spend the majority of my time wandering time in this area.

Best district in Paris!. Best shopping, some of the best food and treats, and great for people watching! This is absolutely one of the best neighborhoods to just wander aimlessly and take Parisian life in.
FAVE AREA.. Yes when im stuck for somewhere relaxing this is my zone. Between the Pompeedoo and Saint Paul this, as others note, is a place to relax and take sone deep breaths.Love it.

Great place to roam. This area is what Paris is suppose to look like, parks and small, cozy streets with four story buildings, many turn of the century chateaus. . Just walk and find the Picasso Museum, boutiques, restaurants, and street entertainers, or just people watch.
Galleries and food. Nice area with lots of galleries and shops to see. Small streets give it a cool feel. Lots of tourists.
Wonderful area with bars and boutiques. Nice to stroll around observing people, to shop or have a glass one of the cafees or bars in the area.

Wonderful area of Paris. My husband, two daughters (ages 11 and 14) and I rented an apartment for two weeks on a street adjacent to the Place des Vosges and loved this area. We rented through Haven in Paris, which was a fabulous experience. The Place des Vosges is beautiful, and the area has many nice shops and restaurants within easy walking distance. Metro stop " Bastille" was the one we used. The Victor Hugo house museum and the Musee Carnavalet are within a few blocks of each other, both are free, and both were very interesting and worth seeing. It wasn't too far of a walk to Pere Lachaise cemetery, either. We loved all the unique shops, the cafes and restaurants in the Marais were busy but friendly and relaxing. We always felt safe and comfortable in this area, and would not hesitate to stay here again. Les Petite Marches was a favorite neighborhood restaurant that we went to a few times!
I loved this area!!. Good restaurants and great shops and boutiques. Close to many sites and the metro. Busy, but not crowded. Had a great stay in a flat here!
Hard to find district. The Marais district was extremely hard to find. The Jewish museum in this district was very enlightening.

Excellent Sites of Medieval Architecture. One of the oldest and most chic neighborhoods of Paris this is my favorite place to stroll. The medieval buildings date back to the 1200's. the restaurants and brasseries are quaint. All of them have a special flair. Enjoy the sites and then sit down for a coffee or hot chocolate and watch the people. Plus the Pont Marie to Ile St Loius is close for a great view of the Seine.

Magic Neighbourhood of Paris. Often missed by most tourists who come to Paris, which is not necessarily such a bad thing, the Marais neighbourhood has a poetic vibe of its own. Filled with museums (Pompidou, Picasso etc.) the finest to visit is the Musee Carnavalet (two buildings and gardens). The Carnavalet is about the history of Paris expressed in art form. As well, you can experience the unusual boutiques, brasseries, and shops in this neighbourhood - often at much less cost than other areas in Paris.

Do the walking tour. Had fun on a walking tour of the area. So much of interest and a wonderful buzz. Had an excellent lunch at a restaurant but can't remember the name - long queues outside for Sunday brunch/lunch.

liked this as our home base. We usually rent an apartment in anohter area of Paris, but as this was a last minute trip, had more trouble finding something. SO, we decided to give the Marais a try, It was great. the little streets have all kind of little independant stores and beautiful little parks. It can be crazy- Sundays- but that adds to the fun. I didn't rate it 5 stars as we found that it wasnt' as easy to get early morning pastries ( my husband likes to go out and bring back an assortment to have with coffee) and since we like to walk everywhere, it was just a little farther from the centre with all of the attractions we like- Tulleries, Luxembourg gardens, seeing the Eiffel tower at night. Having said that, we would stay there again. With some research there is good restaurants in this area, and the Bastille market is a good one,not too far of a walk.

Shopping, culture, food galore.... Stayed at the Hotel Grand Mahler in the Marais which is so well situated. Nice walk down Rue de Rivoli. Then of course there is the Marais itself ... so much to see and do. Loved the buzz.

Too many great eateries .... The Marais has lots if restauarants, but try TresOr for a terrific seafood salad with a pichet of chardonnay - yes - chardonnay -on their terrace. A very pleasent way to pass a Saturday lunchtime.

Lots of Cafe's. Easy access to the metro which by the way is easy to figure out, you just have to know where the start is and where the end is, and where you are. Lots of Cafes for around 20 euros, some shopping, close to a lot of attractions if you want to walk like Notre Dame.

Fascinating Part of Paris. While Le Marais has a fascinating history, like much of Paris, it is also tragic because a large Jewish community lived here before the Holocaust. The Jewish Museum here has fascinating exhibits and is definitely worth visiting. And if you're a fan of falafel, stop at Las Falafel, which you'll know by the line. It is so delicious!

A must see for Jews. so we saw it. Had the the leanest and most healthy pastrami sandwich in my life here (pardon the oxymoron) The famous falafel stand was packed not sure what the alure was but a nice and different neighborhood with nice, non ethnic shopping nearby.
Great area of Paris.. Lovely atmosphere, great falafel, perfect for an evening stroll! Beware of shop opening times - they tend to be later here, and some are shut Saturdays for religious reasons.

A great neighborhood. This is one of the most interesting and diverse neighborhoods in Paris, traditionally the Jewish quarter, there are great kosher delis here and wonderful things to see, boutiques and art exhibits to wander into.

Charming neighborhood!. We stayed in this neighborhood and it proved to be a great choice- it has easy access to several metros, and also the neighborhood in if of itself is full of adorable restaurants, food boutiques, clothes boutiques, not to mention the old Jewish neighborhood where you can eat falafel or pizza, place des vosges, Victor Hugos' house, and so much more! Must see!

Wonderful area of the city. You could easily spend a couple of days exploring the warren of streets here..I'm not a great fan of shopping but i must say that I was lured into a few stores. There is something about a french shirt that i could not resist. Tons of places to eat and have a glass of wine...and plenty of streets steeped in history to get happily lost in..

Loved it. We stayed in this arrondissement. It is the oldest original part of Paris. The way Paris would have looked like years and years ago. Narrow cobblestoned streets etc. This is the Jewish section of Paris and there are many synagogues and Jewish restaurants, foods etc. There are plaques on many buildings commemorating those who died during the Holocaust...We found a small efficiency and felt like it was our Paris home for a week.

Great area.. Le Marais district is the Jewish/gay district in Paris. As such it offers great food and great boutiques and shops were you can find very different and unique products. It has great energy and lot's of great restaurants and cafe's.

Great shopping. Lots of little boutiques, eateries and shops. Some are crazy expensive, some are not. We found many that had good European fashion but without the mortgage costs. Ended at the Pompidou for some over-the-top modern art.

Beautiful, close to center of city, good restaurants.. The Marais is a lovely section of the city. Lots of the cheese shops are here which makes for interesting smells as you stroll down the sidewalks. High number of Jewish residents so some great restaurants with middle eastern food. Great shopping if you know where to go. There are little secrets that you may never know about if you don't do a little bit of research. Close to the river. Walking distance to Ile St. Louis. Just a perfect area to be in. More quiet than some of the other arrondissments.

Favorite neighborhood for strolling. This is one of the best neighborhoods for strolling and for smaller museums. Visit Victor Hugo's home (fascinating), as well as the Picasso museum...eat lunch in the lovely garden behind the Picasso museum...and then stroll the plazas and small alleys of the neighborood. A perfect day in Paris!

Walking in the Marais. I took a walking tour of the Marais with "Paris Walks" and found the guide (Brad) good & informative. I would recommend NOT doing this walk during the very heavy tourist season as trying to keep sight of the guide amongst the throngs of tourists was at times a challenge. However, I loved the area and enjoyed being able to eat kosher food with no problem.

The Archives museum and more. This district is not as overwhelmed with the teeny boppers or the harried tourists. The Archives is a wonderful museum, surrounded by any number of nice bars and restaurants.

Love this area!. Great shops, great food, ethnic beauty. Love quaint streets. The people were very friendly. Family favorite is Camille Restaurant and Les or L'As Du Fallafel is soo good but the line is too long.

Not as good as its reputation.. We found the Marais a bit gritty compared to other favourite locales. The restaurants and bars we found to be average, and the shops too. Much prefer the Latin Quarter.

One of our favourite parts of Paris. We stayed in an apartment in Le Marais during our weeklong Paris holiday and loved the area. Very central to a lot of sights and metro's, but also a lot of avenues where you can wander around without being smothered by the crowds.
best neighborhood in paris. Le Marais stands out for its great atmosphere, high value food and boutique shops. highly recommended for those with tourist-site fatigue
Così. The real Paris:different stores, galeries, artists, people that want to be free and soft.Modern place, " sympa".Is my place in Paris.

Charming neighborhood with great atmosphere. We stayed in the middle of Le Marais for a few days and consistently found some of the best restaurants, boutiques and a great, authentic atmosphere. Part of the neighborhood has a large nightlife scene while most of the neighborhood is quieter. Small restaurants, cafes and creperies grace the streets and you can find almost all locals at cafes like La Perle. It also has many boutiques and high-end wear for sale.Stop and get a falafel if you visit and enjoy it in one of the many small parks, as the falafel is incredible. Overall, perhaps a little crowded on a few of the oldest and smaller streets but it has a wonderful atmosphere and fantastic food.

Lively Area. This area is very lively, full of cafes, bakeries, restaurants, boutiques and other stores. It's what most people picture of when they think of a Parisian street. The area between the Pompidou Centre and Hotel de Ville is very lively.
Best place. People in Marais are super friendly. And the small shops are the best part of the area. Also lot´s of childrens playgrounds
Sunday Fun. It's probably the area you would want to hangout during Sunday if not in a museum. Interesting shops and good food as well.
Lots of fun. Great to walk around and shop, enjoy the cafes and Parisian atmosphere, a walking tour would also be a great idea. Crowded, but there are less crowded streets, too, if you find them.
great area. great area, many design shops, quaint boutiques and kosher restaurants, cheap and fancy. Very atmospheric

Beautiful at night. Good idea to bye tickets on-line at home before departure to avoid the long ques, entry was easy! We had dinner close by and then went up at 1030pm at night, the views are spectacular!

Does it live up to the hype?. Perhaps we were expecting too much edge, but despite following a guided walk, we weren't too inspired by this area. Still down-at-heel in many parts, and downright snobby in others.

Love the Marais!. Some of the lesser known attractions are most worthwhile. After visiting the Pompidou, the Marais is a short walk. Shops, cafes, and plenty of landmarks abound. Don't hurry. Just enjoy.
I love the Marais. Even with the horrible heat, it's still wonderful. Great shops and quite beautiful. A touch of elegant old Paris.
Great Place to Walk Around In. Leaving the Musee Carnavalet, we spent a bit of time walking around the Marais. Lovely, historic area, chockfull of history and, more mundanely, cute boutiques.

One of the best neighborhoods in Paris. Full of winding, narrow, charming streets and funky stores, the Marais is terrific. Leave yourself a full afternoon to explore and try to go down as many of the streets as possible. Also, some really terrific food here so be sure to have lunch or dinner, or both!

Great for food, drinks and shopping.. We loved exploring this arrondissemont and would have liked to have had more time in this area. It's filled with shops and restaurants - great for stopping at a cafe and people-watching.
Fun. This is a fun place to go with some excellent places to eat. Nice boys and girls to meet. I was there on the Gay Pride weekend and the area was buzzing.

A Sunday afternoon delight.. The Marais houses the old Jewish quarter of Paris and now houses some gay bars and restaurants. My husband and I went to see if there would be some old synagogues and falafel. Falafel we found, old synagogues we did not. However, what we found was a delightful shopping district, good Israeli shopping and falafel, and some wonderful garden restaurants. We dined on delicious pastries, bought some unique gifts, and took in 2 different street performances - a 10 piece Klezmer band and a 3 piece jazz trio. You can sit in the gardens of the Palace Vosges and bask in the sunshine. It was a great place to "chill" in Paris on a lazy Sunday afternoon.
Best place in Paris. I love this place, and it has the best restaurant in Paris "Chez Janou". Very lively and stores are open on Sunday!
Lovely part of Paris ..... .... interesting history, many small, but nice bars and restaurants, a "must see" is La Place des Vosges.

Gotta go. Great food. Interesting shops. Wonderful people everywhere. The Jewish museums and Holocaust memorials were the best organized and "most approachable" museums we were in in 5 days of touring. Very moving experiences.Be sure to stop at the old restaurants on Rosie (something like that) Street. Great falafel.

Appreciation for my Judaism. After touring Paris non stop for five days, I was ambivalent about going to Marais since I was so exhausted. Last minute decision and so happy I did. Loved walking down Rue des Rosiers. I was impressed by how alive this little Jewish community is. I was amazed at how many kosher markets, bakeries and felafel shops there were. I loved people watching and surprised to see mixed within traditional shops there were so many trendy boutiques. Marais is a must see.

Best place to walk about on a Sunday. Just to stroll about the old streets amongst its old intricate buildings is pleasurable. Plus on Sundays, stores are open here.. it's good for window shopping between building gazing..

Lovely neighborhood and fun to browse. We stayed close to the Marais and enjoyed walking here. Nice shops, historic places (old Jewish area, Place des Vosges, Hugo House, Musee Carnavalet, Hotel de Ville, etc.), lots of places to eat including ethnic meals, and close to Pompidou, Seine, Ile de la Cite, and new Opera. We took a walking tour (Paris Walks 1) through the area to learn more about it. It seemed to be an old part of the city. Go there and just walk, walk, and walk some more!

Great vibe with wonderful shops, restaurants and bars. This was our "default" hang-out since it as near our hotel and the major sights but was also a vibrant and colorful neighborhood to explore. Lots of great places to shop, eat and drink (we quickly found our favorite bar and were regulars by the time we left LOL)Paris is a great city for "people watching" and this area rivals the river walks and in my opinion far exceeds the Champs Elysees.

Full of History as well as Hip. Narrow streets with preserved older architecture, with several museum options. The Jewish Quarter was the highlight for me, since I am Jewish. Fascinating to see Jewish French culture. Great options for ethic food. There was some information about those who perished from the Nazi invasion. The Marais is also one of the great places in Paris to hang out and go out, especially if you're young and/or single.
best area to see Gay Paris. Cafes, restaurants, interesting shops for clothing, hidden treasures can be found in the lanes of the Marais district, I could spend my whole holiday there.

Great area to wander. This was my fourth visit to Paris, but my first to wander the streets of Le Marais. What an enchanting part of Paris, so many shops and so many churches to visit. Walking around in this area of Paris was a favorite of this visit.

A favorite area of mine. After walking around, especially at the Place des Vosges (where one can visit Victor Hugo's house... he was a fine artist, not just a great poet, novelist and playwright). In the middle of the square, there is a park to take a little rest, then one can fill refreshed and go on walking and shop (we bought a small Turkish rug, at a reasonable price in that neighborhood).

Romantic and quaint with a splash of crazy. This is one of the best places to stay in Paris. The southern area, down near the Seine, is cheek to jowl with amazing restaurants, bars, cares, bakeries, funky clothes and furnishings. The area retains its ancient charm Ina way that most of Paris can not. I highly recommend an afternoon and evening adventure. Or, better yet, stay there and get a bigger dose.

Beautiful and centrally located district. We stayed in this district in June and it was perfectly located, and very quaint. Lots of little boutique shops and restaurants around, although the clothing stores are VERY EXPENSIVE! There were a few subway stops in the neighbourhood that were really easy to access, and so much was within walking distance as well that you would never need a cab.All shops we visited had lovely owners with smiles on their faces that made you feel very welcome in the neighbourhood.

Eclectic Neighborhood. Le Marais is a maze of shopping, museums, squares, and people. Hotel rooms tend to be VERY small here, but the ambiance is unmatched. L'Escurial and Royal Turenne Restaurants afford plenty tables for people watching. Clothing stores in the Marais are very upscale. Fun place.

Best area in Paris to shop and dine!. We stayed in Le Marais and I would highly recommend this area to be a bit away from the other touristy areas. Great restaurants, great shopping, very walkable area.

Popular with LGBT; vintage clothing abounds. I took my daughter to do some shopping based on reviews. We were a bit surprised by the crowds of homosexuals but she found plenty of vintage clothing stores. Overall worth a short visit.

Amazing District, Diverse and For Everyone!. One could tell there were people from all over the world visiting this historic French neighborhood. We had a wonderful time walking, window shopping and chatting with some shop owners who ere clearly proud of there wares and they community. This is a "must see" while in Paris!

Our favorite part of Paris. This vibrant and trendy part of town benefits from it's rich history as the heart of Jewish life in Paris as well as it's current mecca for Paris's hip and happening Gay community. It is a mix of old and new that is not to be missed and from our experience one of the only areas in Paris where the food is consistently good.Roam around and don't miss the Shoah Memorial, Europe's only holocaust museum.

Many Boutiques. Kind of groovy but it reminds me of Soho.Many stores that we have here in New York so I was not so impressed there are better stores in other parts of Paris, like the Latin Quarter, by the Opera and by Vendome.

The place to be in Paris. The nightlife there is wonderful and walking the streets in the day time is really delightful and interesting. So much to see in the Le Marais. Wonderful. I will stay in the Le Marais next time I visit.

the heart of paris. the perfect location to discover Paris, Famous place des Vosges, rue de Rivoli, place de la Bastille, the Opera Bastille, very lively neighborhood, l'île de la Cité, every place worth going to is @ walking distance.
I hardly took any kind of transport. Although nearby there are 10 bus lines, 3 metro line, and a taxi station.

A must do, especially with Eye Prefer Paris Guide, Richard.. This is the best experience, a great artisan precinct with a wide variety of artisan shops from jewellery, to clothes, to bags, to food. Outdoor markets fabulos and there is nothing you cannot find in Le Marais.

Great area for history, architecture and shopping!. Beautiful part of Paris! very much a neighborhood community feel. Every shop and restaurant we stopped in was friendly and helpful. Easy to get around and really a pretty part of Paris.

Very Lively Sunday Afternoon. Shops in many parts of Paris are closed on Sunday, but in Le Marais, most are open. A very lively place to stroll on Sunday and there are lots of great places to shop and dine. Can be crowded.

One of the most interesting areas of Paris. The more time we spend walking in the Marais, the more we love it. It is full of surprises - wonderful buildings, little village areas, great examples of very old Parisian architecture which are so rare in other "Haussman" areas, and marvellous shops,cafes,bars and restaurants. Don't miss the Place Des Vosges but don't eat there. Do your homework and you'll have great food in the Marais.
Walking on the streets. Old and narrow streets full of French cafes and restaurants. Tourists all over the place. Excellent atmosphere.

Many gems abound. I really liked the hustle and bustle of this area of Paris. I was here with a friend and we had dinner in the area twice as well as a night out, visiting several bars. Would definitely recommend.

Wonderful food with a nice feel about it. Yes there are plenty of tourists out and about here, most noticeably in the summer, but what a wonderful place to find delicious food (try just about any place in the Jewish Quartier on rue des Rosiers) but also feel the history pulsating beneath your feet as you stroll along wondering what wondrous thing you will find next. Just go there, be there.
Less crowded on a weekday. It was a nice surprise to find the streets less crowded midweek when we arrived. Last time we were there was a weekend and it was hard to move freely.
Beautiful Jewish quarter. Away from all tourist highlights, this is another 'must see' and 'must spend some time'. We loved being here and relaxing at the Place du Voges!

Bohemian Atmosphere. We rented an apartment in the Marais arondissment and loved the choice of restaurants, shops and proximity to the sights, especially the Pompidou Centre and Notre Dame. Great range of vintage shops for super shoppers. Harry Potter fans can get photo on Rue Nicholas Flamel (Philosophers Stone)

This is a great neighborhood. This is Paris' Greenwich Village. It's trendy. It's gay. It's got great restaurants. It's safe. It's Jewish. It has great clothing stores. Le Marais ("The Swamp") is a great part of the city to stay in as it is also where real people live and has wonderful amenities.

Vibrant Jewish Quarter. Must go here to experience an old fashioned style of Café life and get to a proper Kosher Restaurant. Lovely vibe here and next time I will stay in this area too - must try the caraway seed bread - awesome!!

Great neighborhood to rent an apartment. Rented an apartment for 8 days near the Musee Picasso. What a delightful neighborhood to stay in. Not far from the Seine and Il de Cite, but far enough away from the high tourist areas, to feel like an authentic Parisian neighborhood. Well worth exploring even if you are not staying there.

great eats and a fun area .... Rented an apartment in this area for a few days and really liked the classic elements to the place we stayed, very handy proximity to the metro, great food options, bakeries everywhere, people all seemed quite friendly .. would definitely stay in this area again.

Wander and enjoy!. Delightful shops and cafes abound in the old Jewish quarter. A fabulous area to wander and explore.....artesian chocolate shops, spice shops, and lovely artisanal shops are located along it's narrow cobblestone streets. A lovely place to enjoy an afternoon!

Everyone need to experience The Marais. Staying in the Marais was a good decision for us for this trip. The tour we had explained the history, which is rich and extremely interesting. It's a happening place, with literally thousands of restaurants, bars, creperies, tea rooms, etc. You never have to walk far for a cafe or glass of wine. Since we are in our 60s, we will probably try a different area next time where is might be a bit calmer, but then again, it was fun to be in the middle of all of the action.

Truly enjoyed visiting and staying in Le Marais for a second time.. The Marais seems to have everything to make a visit to Paris delightful. It has many nice shops and restaurants, is easy walking to some of Paris' top tourist sites like Le Louvre and Notre Dame, and has access to the famous and efficient Paris Metro to enable visits beyond comfortable walking distance.
Beautiful. This is a very beautiful rather upscale area of Paris. Made for a very pleasant walk. Lovely architecture as is much of Paris of course.

Fun Paris neighborhood. A quirky Right Bank neighborhood that's fun to walk around, and much less crowded than more famous districts like Montmartres. Tourists haven;t discovered Marais yet. Walk to Place Catherine and eat a one of its funky cafes.

The shops were wonderful. We walked around Le Marais for an entire afternoon. The shops were wonderful and each one was more enticing than the last. We bought souvenirs for the family but best of all, we found some beautiful sweaters and clothing. We went home with French sweaters that gives us great memories of the shopping.

One of the must stroll area in romantic Paris. This is not the most well known place to see in Paris but this is charming especially if the weather permits. Stroll around the small streets. You are in the heartland of historical Paris with hidden gardens, art galleries... If you stay a full week in Paris, you have to go there (Picasso Museum...)/

Great food and great place to stroll and window shop. Lunch food heaven. Try the Apple Strudel at "Florence Kahn boulangerie" after you eat one of their sandwiches on an onion roll. The Marais district is in a great location for getting to the Pompidou Museum and even over to Notre Dame. You'll need to walk off the food anyway.
lovely area to visit. great vibe . Lovely cafes. Good food & lovely shops too. Quite expensive but worth it . Fascinating area to visit

Vibrant neighborhood. Over the years, during yearly visits to Paris, we always spend a day in the Marais. Originally a swamp, and now a chic shopping district with a myriad of boutiques, the Marais is a rich and historically fascinating district. You can still see signs of the Jewish section in its stores with "Yiddish Specialités" or you can vusit the many museums dotting the steeet. Do not miss La Place des Vosges, my favorite spot in Paris. It's an elegant square surrounded by beautifully harmonious buildings that contain restaurants and art galleries. Le Marais is not to be missed!

Old but now So NEW. The Marais is the trendy place that has been gentrified and upscaled in the last few years. It is what Paris was before the grandure of the Napoleons and Haussman. Transformed is the old Jewish quarter and the gay Marais. It is now trendy and chic but wander and find the old Marais of the small crooked lanes that was Paris and see its Jewish history and the Museum of Jewish Art and History (71, rue de Temple). The Place de Voges, is a beautifully historic square and not to be missed since it was built by Henry IV in the early 1600s. Victor Hugo lived at # 6 while he wrote Les Miserables. If you want to know more about the history of Paris then the Carnavalet Museum (23 rue de Sevigne) is where you must go and it is free. The Picasso Museum is at # 5 Rue Thorigny but check since it seems to be under a never ending renovation. The Marais is between the Place de la Bastille and the Pompidou Centre so it is a good place to spend more than a day to get a feel for Paris now and the past.

Best place to stay in Paris. I have stayed twice in apartments in the Marais and recommend it. Two "very mature" ladies felt extremely safe in this area. There is so much to see and do that it was a pleasure both visits I stayed here. I have stayed in 4 other areas of Paris but would return here from now on.

Great Walking Area With Much to Do. Many things to do in this area seven days a week. Visit the Jewish quarter, watch the street performers, shop in the many small stores, stop and get a snack. Relax in the park at Place de Voges watch the young lovers, visit the home of Victor Hugo. If you have the time this area is worth more then one visit.

Best place to be on Sunday. Most Americans think everything is closed on Sunday but all the Parisians are walking, shopping and eating in the Le Marais on Sunday. Don't think you have nothing to do, come here and people watch. The is also the location of my favorite store in the world Alaia.

Loved the Marais. Lots to see and do in this area. Markets, museums, cafes, Jewish centre, vintage shops, boutiques and locals. Easy walk around and very safe at night. Enjoy sitting on the grass at Place de Voges with a sandwich and fruit.
Have to go the the Marais district. This was a highlight of Paris - loved the Marais district - lots of boutique shops and small windy streets. Lots of history. Spend at least 4-5 hours here.

The Heart of Paris.. Forget the Ile de la Cite, this is an endlessly fascinating area of the city to walk around and find something interesting on every street and passage. This was the area that baron Haussmann did not modernise in the Second Empire, so the medieval street pattern remains, as do many buildings which have visible medieval origins. Restaurants, bistos, and cafes without number, and quirky shops and workshops add to the charm and interest of this quartier.

Love this neighborhood. Lots of outdoor cafes and pastry shops. A real feel for the Paris experience. We had coffee at Open Cafe and then lunch at another bistro. We were warned about pickpockets in this area, however.
This is where I always stay.... I Love this neighbourhood of Paris.It is charming , intimate, fun.What I love most is Place des Voges...The history of this neighbourhood is still so palpable...

The American place to be?. This is a lovely neighborhood which is very central to a great number of Parisian attractions. This area is known by some Parisians to be very North American dominated but we wandered through it and didn't find it to be particularly so - it seems to be as multi cultural as many other Arondisments. Very vibrant area and very enjoyable to wander around.

Best neighborhood in Paris. I could walk around for hours and even days in this neighborhood with so much to see - Place des Vosges, the Carnavalat (museum of Paris), great shopping and bistros. I've stayed in this area twice, and can't imagine staying anywhere else.

A little city in a big city. Marais has a personality of its own. Good food, quaint shops, narrow streets, great museums. A fun, all day excursion. Just walk and enjoy the feast for the eyes and tummy.
Love this area!. Very clean and safe and peppered with lovely little cafes and restaurants. Great location to walk to many sites and transportation was easy to find.

Great neighborhood. If you enjoy exploring different neighborhoods in Paris, Le Marais is one of them. Bastille, Place des Vosges, Victor Hugo house, Jewish community, cafe Phares..they are all part of Paris history. If you visit, I highly recommend to follow a self-guided walking tour (can be found in Internet) to go through the back streets to really get a flavor of this neighborhood.

Oh my good, what a pleasant surprise!. Marais is with no doubt the most romantic and most beautiful part of Paris. Cute little streets from 17 th century, parks, shops, crouded with people, jazz bands playing at squares, several old churches... Just magic. Worth a visit.
Gorgeous Neighborhood. Chose to stay in the Marais because of how central it is in the city. Found it to be uber-chic, and full of local shops - everything from wine and cheese to high end clothing.

A different side of Paris. Jewish part of Paris, this is definitely a place to visit. Best discovered by leaving the underground around the Hotel de Ville and walk your way through the old and small street. Fantastic experience.

Cool Paris : the Marais.. It's our favourite in Paris , shops , restaurants , cafe' , in our last visit there was the brocante de rue de Bretagne , really nice. Don't miss the Marais when you plan to visit Paris.

Wonderful wander around Le Marais!. We spent a full day just wandering around getting a small taste of Le Marais, so many lovely side alleys and shops, cafes and bars as well as the Place de Vosges. Beautiful buildings of course and we had a great food and bar experience! Really looking forward to going back for more exploration and restaurant experiences!

Wonderful. We rented an apartment in the Marais for a week and had a wonderful time getting to know the neighborhood and exploring other parts of the city from our home there. Lots of nice restaurants and shops, galleries and parks. Easy walk to the river and Metro.

Well worth a stroll. The Marais district is becoming popular with visitors but is still not on the usual visitor circuit. Narrow streets, lots of small interesting shops and some great 'hotels' (Town mansions). There is also the Picasso Museum housed in one of these 'hotels'. The Place des Vosges is lovely and much more historic than Place de la Concorde (it also didn't witness any guillotines!). A pleaseant area away from the crowds and grand boulevards.

Great neighborhood. Stay in Le Marais and felt that I was staying in a piece of history. Appreciated the Delis of the old Jewish section and the character of the entire bohemian area. Great central location from which to explore Paris

I could walk around this neighborhood for HOURS!. Wanna shop in Paris? Go to this neighborhood. A bit tourist-y in places, but great shopping.Lots of amazing history here as well. Medieval houses, fun little shops.A must visit in Paris.

Great walking area. Few cars, but lots of construction at Les Halles. Looks like it will be a while before it's done. There a lot of shopping in this area. Grocery shopping is excellent on Rue Saint Honore betw. Louvre & Pont Nuef and Rue Rambateau beta. Beaubourg and Temple.
Super Cute Area to Shop. We had a lot of fun strolling up and down the streets for a few hours. Have your pocketbook ready! It was nice to see a lot of non-American stores!

What you think of when you think of Paris. I love the Marais. It's a great place just to wander, but bring a map since it's easy to get confused with all little streets. Lots of great boutiques, cafes, restaurants, museums, etc., and a mix of both the Jewish area and the gay area of the city.
Lovely walk, oh the history. A visual treat...I'd you need a break from the throngs at the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay...take in some fresh air here

Interesting area in Paris. Not quite off the beaten path but definitely not as touristy as other parts of Paris. Well worth it to spend a day walking around the shops, cafes, parks, and museums. Must have the falafels!

Don't miss ths!. The Marais has more good eateries than you can sample in a year! But it also has the museum at the Hotel de Carnavalet. This is Paris's historical museum. There is Proust's cork-lined bedroom, Marie Antointette's jail cell, portraits with accompanying ceramics of all the revolutionaries and Napoleon, etc., etc. Plus famous restaurants and shops through the ages. A bit of everything that happened in Paris is here.

Stroll the streets. When you consider that most of this area was swamp it is now a hustling bustling part of Paris that should not be missed.Easy to get lost so make sure you have a good map.Must see is the Hotel De Ville. Great restraunts and shopping

the place to be. This is the Paris we were looking for: lots of interesting little shops and restaurants, walkable, authentic-feeling quaintness. Sunday stroll down the old Jewish section of Rue des Rosier was great fun.
carming area. bring lots of cash. lovely boutqiues,shops and cafes with a hefty Paris price. The museum of Paris in the district is definitely worth a visit

A must see.. This part of Paris is very quaint and walkable with unique boutiques unlike the "fancy" Champs-Elysees and Galleries de Lafayette. Make SURE you get a falafel otherwise you're missing out on one of the best things Paris has to offer!

Bonanza of activities. I did a Classics Walks tour first and then went back on several occasions to further explore the area. There's so much variety in the area with plenty to see, feel, do and just be!

The Swamp. That's what the word means, anyway, but in the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries, when anybody who was anybody lived here, it was already a built-up and very urban area.To try to say anything about the Marais is like trying to say something about Old Regime Paris: you just don't know where to begin.So let's start with the layout of the streets. They are narrow, short, and tend to curve and change direction. Napoleon III and Haussmann never got around to redesigning the streets here for the Twenty-Eighth Century. If you want to imagine the circumstances under which Henri IV was murdered, just look around you.There are plenty of museums, almost-museums and sort-of museums here. One of the highlights is the Musée Carnavalet, which was the Hôtel Carnavalet in the bad old days. In other words, the place where Mme de Sevigné lived and wrote most of her letters. If you wander around here you can understand how she could live here without meeting her boarders - her daughter or others - except when she wanted to; the lady who was always writing about her near-bankruptcy actually lived in a palace. There's supposed to be a portrait of her here which I don't remember seeing, but I do remember a *Diana Bathing* by Boucher which is not as slick as the famous one in the Louvre, and therefore much better.There is a synagogue on the rue Pavée which was designed by Hector Guimard of Metro-entrance fame; he was married to a Jewish woman, at least according to French law. Some of the times I was there there was a note tacked up saying that it was open only for prayer, not tourism, but sometimes the sign wasn't there.Speaking of which, if you need strictly kosher restaurants, this part of the Marais has the only real concentration of them in all of France; a French Jew whom I asked about this agrees with me. You can also find strictly kosher groceries here; our main source was Epices Délices, also on rue Pavée.

Worth the trip. We initially went to this part of Paris to see the Jewish Quarter. We were somewhat disappointed as it was a very small area comprised of mostly bakeries.
