The remaining area was pretty cool. Lots of unique and funky shops for one of a kind purchases. Our hotel was actually by the Pont Neuf and we wound up walking to the Marais. We are not athletes it is just that close.
The place to be. Le Marais is great, it's like a small village in a big city. Plenty of restaurants and bars to go to and the best thing not that many tourists.

Place de Vosges, beautiful, beautiful and even more. Just an amazing district in Paris. Place de Vosges (the most ancient park in Paris and near Victor Hugo's house) is a great place to visit.After Montmartre, Le Marais was definetely my favourite visit in Paris. Also, if I am not mistaken, for Les Mis' fans, the church where Marius and Cosette get married is in Le Marais. Actually, Marius' grandfather is supposed to live in Le Marais.If you happen to visit this nice neighbourhood, which is quite calm and different from the rest of the city, you must try the Fallafel from The King of Fallafel. It is delicious and a different experience. Also, there are a lot of antiques' shops which is quite interesting.

Fun place but know where you are going.. If you want alleys of fun food and mixed cultures you will love this. Marais has lot's to offer, Picasso Museum, fun food in Jewish area, great Jewish Historical Museum (wonderfully helpful with ideas and directions) I know it is know for the gay clubs but a little old for that! Wonderful little shops to find unusal gifts!
A great area to walk around and shop. The Marais is my fave area of Paris to shop, walk and explore the small restaurants. Little boutique shops are fab !

Nice neighbourhood. Very nice to walk around, best is you drive with the Metro to Bastille and then walk back through the various streets toward Les Halles (Rue des Francs Bourgeois is a good one), do not miss to discover also the various alleys (Rue des Rosiers, Rue Vieille du Temple, , since you will find a lot of ‘hidden’ shops.On Rue des Rosiers you will find some famous ‘Take aways’ selling great Falafel (for example L’As du Fallafel, 34 Rue des Rosiers).If you are interested in affordable Photo prints, Yellow Korner at 8, Rue des Francs Bourgeois is worth a visit.In general the shops are not cheap, so except of the second hand shops, this is not a region for bargains.
Worth a visit. Area is worth a walk but there are much more interesting streets in Paris. Keep an eye out for a second-hand clothing store...a friperie store as known there. Good values.

Too much foot traffic. The RER B line stop for my travel was in the city, at Chatelet at Les Halles.We needed to reach Vendome; could not get bearings from Marias.Not enough Taxi stands could be found, for our needs.All people encountered were helpful, but could not communicate in English, for our needs.A male Post Office employee was most gracious to us w/explaination written in French.
The best. This was one of my favorite neighborhoods. I could have spent several more days just walking through the tiny streets and stopping to eat and drink at every cafe and bar I passed.

Marais true Paris. When in Paris the Marais is my favourite place to stay and hang out. You get to feel much more like a local. Lots of local wine bars, cafes, boutique shops, food shops. Local people of all ages but also very gay friendly in that French style.
great place to wander around. We strolled for hours in this district visiting the interesting Jewish district, quaint streets, buildings, restaurants and shops.

We love the Marais!. This is the best place in Paris. Forget the noisy, touristy places! Stay in the Marais and explore the hidden corners of this beautiful city. The shops are full of stuff that you don't see anywhere else. The restaurants are quaint and delicious. There are lots of French people who live and work here so you feel more like a native than if you stayed in some big chain hotel. I can not recommend it enough!

Stay here!. We stayed in this area for 5 nights. It is a seemingly safe area to stay and there are lots of cafes around. It is just near Notre Dame and there is easy access to the Metro. It is always easy to find your way back home as it is centred near the Hotel de Ville. Great spot for us to wander around!

A Foodie and Shopper Paradise. Le Marais is a beautiful neighborhood on the Right Bank known for its vibrant community -- LGBT-friendly shops and bars, cool boutiques and thrift shops, pretty parks and a bustling Jewish quarter. Highlights of our visit (we went back twice): the falafel and Jewish bakeries on Rue des Rosiers, the amazing food stalls at Marche des Enfants Rouges (offering Italian, Lebanese and Morrocan takeaway), the elegant Place des Vosges, with its arcade full of cafes and art galleries. Just note that some shops in the Jewish quarter will be closed Saturday and although most things are open Sunday (not the case everywhere in Paris) you're probably better going on an "off" day during the week to beat the crowds.
The gay district.. Lovely area. The restaurants were warm and friendly. It's not too far from anything, and it has a feeling of nightlife.
stayed in the Marais. Fun place; busy on the weekends, great to just walk around or sit at one of the cafes and watch the world go by.
Place to enjoy. Art galleries restaurant, and à real french atmosphere, you will love that area. Great little shops, shoe shops, clothing, cuttlery

Oldest Part of Paris, yet still one of the best. I love this part of the city. The shopping is the best and the best priced. The diversity of the neighborhood can't be beat and there is a cafe or two on every street. My wife and I always seem to find something cool and unique to buy in the Marais. You won't go broke shopping here like you might at the Place Vendome. Don't miss it!!

Artsy. Originally the jewish quarter, this area reminds me much of Soho in New York city. Extremely eclectic with high end shops and original boutiques. Also you may trip over one of the most famous falafel shops in Paris. Just ask, where it is, you won't regret it. Bon Apetit.

Nice Local Atmosphere. Our hotel was on Champs-Elysees which is a very touristy area. So, the day we ventured into the Marais district we were pleasantly happy! This seemed to be more of a local atmosphere although filled with many boutiques. This area had the best shopping in Paris...and the reason I say best is because the boutiques had some really cute clothes at more affordable prices compared to the shops in the St. Germaine area. We spent an entire day here. You will want to walk up and down every cobblestone street. Each street had cafes, boutiques and gardens. This neighborhood provided local flavor and less touristy fare. When I return to Paris, I will stay in this district.

Must be - and must see. What to say about Marais? Perfect for walking, taking small shopping-trips or just a little drink. Place des Vosges is a beauty, the handsome - and gay, Louis XIII is still sitting on his horse. Take some hours in Musée Carnavalet - free entrance, walk the narrow streets - when the pavement shines like silver. Le Marais is crowdy on week-ends, but I will always return. Always.

Great district! My favorite!!. My absolute favorite when it comes to Paris. Our guide was a local from here so she explained us the real parisian vibe through the streets of the magnificent gay jewish quarter.

THE PLACE TO BE SEEN IN. Wow this has to be one of the most interesting small areas in Paris. The Square around which the area revolves is perhaps the most beautiful Gay Paris. We went on a Sunday and appeared to be two of very few foreign tourists so if it's good enough for the local and there were hundreds of them it's good enough for me. Read up about it b4 visiting.

Northern Marais the place to stay, eat and shop. The North end of the Marais, just south of P.d.l. Republique, is the new hot area of Paris. Great shopping, restaurants and nightlife. If you walk south on rue Belanger, and turn right toward Temple, there are some great new restaurants and concept stores (ex., The Broken Arm) that are alot of fun. Great mens' shopping along the route. Then head to the Marche de Infant Rouge for fund eating opportunities.
Camille restaurant in Le Marais. We at an atmospheric restaurant called Camille and the foodvwas good too .highly recommended .Would book we were just lucky to get a table being Saturday night

Nice district with boutiques and history. We took a walking tour and I would go back to just walk around and do more window shopping! We did not go into the Holocaust memorial but the area around it had other memorial plaques as well.

Falafel in Paris. The Marais area in Paris in the 3rd. & 4th. arrondissement. A 5 minute walk from St Paul metro station. Predominently a Jewish area, but fast becoming a gay centre.  Very historic narrow streets full of cafes and restaurants,both kosher and non kosher, catering for all palates. Niches shops which weren't too expensive for a tourist haven. Very busy on Sundays when whole families visit to amble along and take in the sites. Well to remember that whole area closes down early on Fridays for the Sabbath. If you like falafel there are many restaurants and 'take aways' specializing in this cuisine, but be prepared to queue, even for the 'take aways' Many chocolate, boulangerie and patisserie shop will make your mouth water If you are Jewish a definite must, if in Paris. If your gay a definite must. If you are Jewish, gay and like falafel ......what can I say! Cannesdid ........ surfing syd

Great way to spend an afternoon. Wonderful to walk around and experience the shops and cafe's. Nice to experience the parisian streets without crowds. Rue pieton is great to experience.. Grab lunch or a coffee at a cafe and relax.

Trendy. This area is easy to reach on the metro line 1. Very trendy stores and many cafes. Streets are narrow and its fun to walk thru and people watch. There are lots of smaller shops with fashions and second hand boutiques also. Wine stores and markets too.
Fun, artsy!. We enjoyed walking the streets, enjoying the shops and watching the people. Have cafe at a sidewalk bistro and people watch to your hearts content.
Nice atmosphere; not too crowded. Walk through the Marais; quite streets, squares... Great shops. Not as crowded as the classic Paris hot spots.

Explore!. My favourite part of the Marais is definitely Rue Sainte Croix-de-la-Bretonnerie. Make sure you check this funky little strip out on a weekday or Saturday, and then on a Sunday, head back, and see what it's like when it's a 'rue piéton' (walking street) - all traffic is blocked off, and the food stalls come out on to the street and sell. The smell alone is worth it!
Le Marais nice way to spend an afternoon. Lovely area to wonder around and have lunch in one of the many cafes. We enjoyed the park and going through Hugos house.
Oozes Charm. Find a cozy tea salon, like Mariage Freres, and while away the afternoon. Check out the intriguing shops, buy a falafel and be transported.
Great neighborhood. Lots to see and do. Spent the day walking and exploring and found great bistros in the area. Definitely worth the visit.

Fantastic. We were at Boulevard Temple and loved the location. 15 minute to the Seine and the subway was in front of our building. Grocery stores were all around as were markets and wine shops. The Clown Bar was out back and should not be missed. Every day we walked around a corner and asked "How did we not see this".Paris is wonderful as is the 3 rd. Don't wait, come and see the Le Marais and enjoy.

Lively and streets are closed on Sunday. Not only are the shops beyond awesome but they close the busy streets off on Sunday. It's one of my favorite areas in Paris and for so many reasons it's hard to put in words. It feels authentic, dated and modern at the same time, quaint, cute, sophisticated, and fun. SO much to see and do there.
A unique section of paris.. A mix of New Yorks Lower Eastside and Greenwich Village this small village has good bakeries, falafel stands and small shops.
The oldest part of Paris has a face-lift. Do go to the Places des Vosges with the many Art Galleries and restaurants that inhabit this unique part of Paris away from the main Tourist sites.

Wonder, Get Lost Most Of All Enjoy. Marais is a beautiful laid back area of Paris. Plenty of interesting shops and lovely spaces including parks. Wonderful architecture and museums. My advice is come to Marais and get lost around the cobbled streets and enjoy.
Full of Life. We love Le Marais. Always interesting people watching and full of niche boutiques. We highly recommend this place.

A must while in Paris. We were told by an elderly woman to visit Le Marais that it was true Paris. It was fun to walk allover the place, see place Des Voges and sit in the garden at the musee des archives. We also did some window shopping.

Le Marais is a district in Paris which surround the Place des Vosges.. Le Marais is a beautiful area of Paris which is nice to walk around and just look at the architecture and shop. The Place de Bastille column is within walking distance as is the Place de Vosges, which are also wonderful to see. There is a shop with original lithographs, postcard, and hand sketches once used in advertising and a shop for music boxes, old and new. It is magical and has the feel of a shop from the early 1900's.

The Perfect Place to Roam!!. Staying in Le Marais gave us the opportunity to really connect with this area. Le Marais has so much to offer , the shops, museums , galleries, restaurants and cafes, the whole area oozes history.The area has a real multicultural feel we stayed on Rue au Maire , a narrow cobbled laneway that had several Chinese and Vietnamese restaurants and an Italian Restaurant run by a gentleman from Bangladesh. There is a strong connection to the Jewish community with the Museum of Jewish on Rue du Temple and adjoining the Park dedicated to Anne Frank.Strolling down rue de Bretagne you can enjoy the pretty Square du Temple with it's flowers pond and children's playground. A bit further along the Marche' des Enfantes Rouges is a market offering all sorts of fresh produce.The Place des Vosges was a favourite of ours, surrounded by a Colonnaded walkway it is a place of art galleries and cafes and also housing Victor Hugo's apartment.We had a 10 day stay here and feel we barely scratched the surface of this amazing place.
Very lively neighborhood on Sundays!. Very old part of town, but full of antique shops, cafés and nice people. The perfect stroll on a Sunday afternoon.

Base yourself here!. Met up with some friends from the US, and we shared a rented apartment right on top of the St Paul's Metro. Perfect compromise between authentic Paris street life without some of the excessive cost or posing. Loads of shops (from department store BHV to boutiques of every description), ranging in affordability from the kiddies treat shops to the high end art palaces of the Place des Vosges. We enjoyed breakfast in pavement cafes, very late brunch in organic restaurants on rue de Vielle, and enchanting dinner in the delightful Bistrot des Comperes in rue Charlemagne. After many years both visiting a local office in Paris and occasional domestic jaunts, this has been the best stay by far.

Culture and Atmosphere.. I often stay in a small boutique hotel near the Marriage Frere tea shop, this is a particularly charming district, fashion, food, and history. Many excellent commercial art galleries and small museums.

Historic, beautiful and fun. From the elegant Place des Vosges where Victor Hugo once lived, to the Shoah Memorial that documents the Holocaust, to the trendy Rue des Rosiers, the Marais has something for everyone. Allow several hours to take in all the sights and wear good walking shoes so you can enjoy it all.

Great Gay Friendly Area. We stayed in an apartment in this area, would highly recommend it. Lots of gay friendly places to eat and shop without feeling like you don't fit in. Would definitely stay in this area again and the cafes and restaurants are top notch.

Shops and lovely spaces. Lovely area off from the metro St Paul. There are lots of little shops, N African restaurants and the old Jewish quarter. The Place de Vosges is well worth a look , but you could spend a nice afternoon just pottering about. It's very relaxed - nothiing like as hectic as the Champs Elysee of the Rue Rivoli etc, and it's Paris's main gay area and has a very upbeat atmosphere.
Loved it!. Highly recommend this beautiful neighborhood. The architecture and shopping were incredible. Bought a beautiful necklace (French designer) at the bazaar -- still love it.

Very cool.... I loved the fact that Le Marais is where the Jewish district is. Very nice eateries, the atmosphere is enchanting, and one can stroll for hours. Restaurants are nice and the bars are nicer.

great night out. We went here for out last night in Paris and wished we had visited earlier. Lots of cafe, bars serving snacks rather than full meals. Great atmosphere. Lots of boutiques. Nice interesting narrow streets

dont miss st paul village if you visit le marais. we always stay in the Marais in Paris as we love the local feel. So many travellers to the Marais miss one of its highlights; the village are of St Paul. Here you will find lots of small artisan shops and galleries. My favourites are at the back of the main drag, where second hand dealers sell beautiful Christofle and lalique silver and crystal stemware for a fraction of the new price. Even if you cant afford it, or dont want to be bothered with cleaning silver, it is beautiful to ogle at - simply as works of art. One shop even sells old forks that have been fashioned into elegant cuffs which went down well with my teenage daughters
perfect parisian stroll. spent an afternoon strolling around the Marais: amazing! Shops, cafes, museums and the marvellous Place des Vosges: not to be missed.

A great part of Paris to stay. Our hotel, Jules and Jim, was in Le Marias and we found the whole area of interest, with buildings and architecture to explore, bars and restaurants to enjoy and enough people watching to keep us entertained each evening. A great centre for exploring other parts of Paris since it is easy to walk around.

Eclectic mix of historic people watching and good food. Compact district approached from Chatelet les Halles and Hotel de Ville on right bank. Contains the Jewish quarter of Paris - all life goes in here day and night witth world food music and drink - history is to the fore with 'Hotel Particulaire' to wander around many free to enter as they are offices and museums of Paris. The Marais has many museums - on Sundays the area is pedestrianised and with many shops open on a Sunday can be very busy ! Full of quirky shops and pop ups - fab choice of cafes and bars for all ages tastes and sexual dispositions! Photography heaven - check Paris Muse website out for walking tours! Enjoy! :-)

City bus tour of the Le Marais. We took a city bus ride down the Seine through the Marais district. We ate at a McDonalds that was near the cemetary. Food was great. We saw a lot of sidewalk cafes from the bus. We rode from the Eifle tower all the way to the end of the bus line, and then took the Metro back to the hotel. No commentary on the bus, but cheap, just one metro ticket.

A great place to wander. A lovely part of Paris to wander around . We had lunch in a deli in the Jewish Quarter. Really tasty and filling, I was disappointed that I just couldn't find any room for a piece of apple strudel !!

Victor Hugo. Maison Victor Hugo 6, place des Vosges. Fascinating temporary display on Hugo homme politique includes literary works too. Reduced price for over 60s 3E50 (full 5E). If you can't do the French there are cards in each room in English to help!

Great neighborhood to wander. The Marais is one of the most beautiful regions of Paris. Its historical buildings host different stores, small boutiques, cafés, bistros... You can spend hours, days, months wandering thru this maze of small streets and squares and you'll always find something interesting. Its main square, Place des Voges, Rue des Rosiers, Rue des Franc Bourgeois, Rue de Turenne, are maybe the main ones, but as you go deeper in these small streets you also leave behind some of the tourist feeling and dive into a more "local" atmosphere.

A great place to stay. This is such a lovely area of Paris, full of bistros, bars, quirky shops and bijou hotels. It is so accessible for the Metro, the main attractions and within walking distance of the Seine and Ile de la Cite.

The place to be. We had a tour with My Hush-hush Paris walking tours through Le Marais which was a very smart move . We would never have learned that much on our own about this very Parisian district. History, good stories, fashion and gourmet food! Just great!
Shopping.... Full of shops and cafes. Also full of people... Nice to walk through this quarter, although you might want to avoid late Fridays...

Atmospheric area of Paris. This is a perfect place to wander and soak up the Parisian atmosphere. Home to the Picasso Museum and the Bastille Market, also lots of shops, cafes and restaurants and street entertainers.
Great atmosphere. Always a teat to wander round the shops in the Marais District. Some visual gems although not kind to your wallet:-)
Fab!. Get off the streets and look inside some of the mansions if you can. The home of Henri Mansard is open to give you a glimpse.

Charming. On our first morning we found a small Parisian market where we ate the best baguette sandwich I have ever tasted . We stayed at Les Jardins du Marais hotel which is in a good location for walking and metro. We also went to the flea market in the Villages de St. Paul - a must see if you love that kind of thing.I found the people to be very friendly and would stay there again.

Diverse Exciting Area. When in Paris don't forget to WALK through Le Marais. This is the Jewish/Gay quarter an area where many Americans are buying up apartments. The hi-lite of he area is Place des vosges...a stunning former Royal Palace built around a large square. Le Marais is a great place to "people watch". and shop of course.

disapointed. At one time I think this might have been a nice area, but it seemed a little run down to me. There were many vacant premises. La place des Vosges was quite desertedand without the atmosphere I was expecting.
wow..great area. so interesting, we went with a free walking tour ( pay a tip only) and realized how interesting it is. Great shops and atmosphere

It's where we stayed and it wasn't tourist central. Mind you, there definitely are tourists in Le Marais - pretty much all of Paris is... but, there is certainly a more "Parisian" vibe here... more people spoke French than another language. As an FYI, it is "boys town" but if you're what I would consider to be a "normal" person than it shouldn't bother you.The shopping is good -- more local than chains -- and the food/bar options are good too. Close to the Metro (subway), but not super busy walking on the streets.I'd recommend staying and visiting here if in Paris...but, not if you're strapped for time, or if it's your first time in Paris as you'll likely want to spend more time on the Champs, Latin Quarter and so on.
Great Place for Strolling. From the Place des Vosges to Châtelet one comes upon interesting boutiques and lovely 17th century "hôtels particuliers." A must for understanding and appreciating Paris.
Shopping and eating and party at night!. fresh food, different nationalities,Asion Food, Maroccan Food, Italian.... at Market les enfants Rouges
Strolling the Marais. I like the Marais. A lot of history, great restaurants, shops, parks and bars. A nice place to be on a sunny day

From buttons to high fashion - there is a shop for everyone.. One of my favourite areas in Paris, the Marais is the place to go and wander. I love the little button and haberdashery shop just off Place des Vosges and the book shed/ cavern nearby on the corner. Grab a bagel from one of the bagel shops and just let the Marais streets take you on a feast for the senses.

Let yourself wander. Just head into the 4th Arr. for unique old Paris alongside hip new Paris. Great for walks and sitting at the numerous cafes on the quiet places. Look for all the vintage stores especially Rue de Rosiers pedestrian street. Place de Vosges exquisite even without leaves
Fun Little area!. great people and great shops! close to every major site in Paris! its a GLBT friendly area as well if that a concern.
Interesting walk. Lovely old buildings, lively atmosphere, great little stores, and place des Voges. What else do you need?

Something for everyone without the hassle. Very lively with lots of individual shops offering a variety of quality goods. You'll love wandering around soaking up the atmosphere. Plenty of bars and restaurants ( avoid Equinox at all costs !!!! ) Enjoy !

Paris walks tour of the Marais. Had a great tour of the Marais...my only complaint is that after 2 hours, it was too brief. What a fascinating part of town. Rich in many cultures and quite diverse. The next time I'm in Paris, I will spend more time in this area. Place des Vosges was quite nice...organized very well around a park that seemed to be frequented by many. Did not get to visit the Picasso or Carnavalet museums as it was Tuesday and they were both closed. Briefly visited the Memorial de la Shoah...must go back next time and spend more time. Saw the Hotel de Ville, the Pompidou Center and the Rue des Francs-Bourgeois.

Trendy neighborhood. I did a walking tour of the Marias district with Paris Walks and learnt a lot about the area I did not know. This was once a marsh and the eastern entrance to the city. After the royalty built their homes here, it became popular for the rich financiers. Later on when the royalty moved into what is now main Paris the place fell into disrepair with squatters occupying the big mansions. Now it is back to it's glory.
Character. This is a great little neighborhood with a few different stores. Old Paris. Falafel everywhere. Lots of interesting Synagogues and stores.

A good - and authentic - neighborhood for shopping, dining and people watching. This is hands down my favorite neighborhood in Paris. And that is saying a lot, because I adore the entire city. Like the Latin Quarter and the Opera Quarter, the Marais teems with life. It's chic but gritty, if that's possible. It crammed with everything most busy quarters offer: A variety of cafés and restaurants, boutiques and shoe stores, patisseries and cheese mongers, and hidden corners begging to be explored. Probably my favorite area is the one near the church of St. Paul-St. Louis because it contains everything needed to make a visit to Paris complete and satisfying, including some very modern and well-priced hotels. Sandwiched between the Bastille and the church, the busy stretch of Rue St Antoine is perfect for people watching. The Place de Vosge, Musee Carnavalet, and the Village St. Paul are favorite places to visit. We once saw a traditional chimney sweep in this neighborhood, and we've met delightful Americans and Canadians at the Red Wheelbarrow book store on Rue St. Paul. This neighborhood is so complete that once, when two visits to Paris bookended a trip to the South of France, we never left! We spent three entire days in the Marais.In my book, the Marais joins the Latin Quarter and Boulevard St. Germaine as three areas you should visit if your Paris trip is a short one.

Chic Shopping, Walking and Eating Area. Le Marais is lively both night and day, and the stores are open on Sundays. Lots of interesting boutiques to browse and shop in, with some being quite original. Don't miss walking in the Jewish Quarter ; lots of restaurants, small shops and old, interesting streets. Le Marais is an old, historic part of Paris. You must see the Place des Vosges and some of the small museums there, as well. Le Marais is also great for just strolling and people-watching.

Good vibe. Located walk away between Bastille and Les Halles, le Marais is the home of the Jews and the Gay Community. It is worth walking randomnly to find some hidden statues or green parks. I suggest going to Metro Bastille, look around the 'La Roquette' street and its infamous "rue de Lappe' and then walk though the Marais until you reach Beaubourg. It is a beautiful walk by a sunny day.

Great neighborhood, new favorite in Paris!. This area is so wonderful! Great bars, trendy restaurants, amazing people watching and fabulous little boutiques. We spent an entire day wandering the area from the center out to Hotel de Ville. Definitely take a day and enjoy this part of Paris - it's so much fun and beautiful! And stop at the Jewish Quarter to have some amazing falafel, and also check out all the lovely perfume shops :) If you want traditional "French" boutique shopping this area is great!

A chic neighborhood with several museums nearby. I choose this neighborhood because of easy transport access and a good budget hotel (Jeanne d'Arc). Bastille and St. Paul metro, and several bus lines, will get you where you want to go, then the quiet neighborhood will welcome you back in the evening.
LOVED IT!. My favorite area to shop and eat! Just get off at St. Paul Metro stop and hit the ground running! I bought great clothes and fun silver jewelry. Great for teens!

Love the Marais!. The Marais in Paris is such a charming area, full of small boutiques, art galleries and cute places to eat. go explore it with time, you can easily spend an entire day walking down it's small streets and stopping by anything that catches your attention. it is also the only area in the city which is open on Sunday! and - if you are into Israeli food - go get a great meal of falafel in one of the few places there which serve Kosher and Israeli food.
Great to wander around. The little streets in the Marais district are what you envisage Parisian streets are with some lovely shops and bars. Place des Vosges is a must.

great atmosphere!. great atmosphere and perfect choice for a sunny Sunday, mostly in France/Paris, where everything is closed.It is a lively area, full of people and options of restaurants/bars/shops. It's a must go!!
Very trendy district.. A superb collection of bars and restaurants for you to choose from. Be careful of some of the prices though. Shop around.

We loved it. This is a very historic part of paris with so many interesting things to see and do. We went back for a second visit in the evening. What a treat with all the little vendors and restaurants. It was definitely less busy than other notable attractions. You wont be disappointed walking down the narrow streets.
See the homes of Domonique Strauss Kahn, Jim Morrison and Victor Hugo.. I saw the homes of Domonique Strauss Khan, Apt .13, Jim Morrison # 17 and Victor Hugo, #6. What history...past and present.

mu home away from home. it started with a stay at the hotel sevigne, continued on with hotel jeanne d'arc...i stay close to metro stop st. paul...and have become familiar with the bus lines...best bus is #96 which goes from north to south...there are many places to have a good, if not great, meal esp. in place st. catherine..it is also a place with many sub-cultures that exemplify the history of the area...so the jewish community, the gay community, mingle with the boutiques...a fun and very parisian area to visit...

Fun neighborhood. This is a great neighborhood in Paris. We really enjoyed strolling around and shopping, window shopping for art, eating ice cream and get falafels at L'As du Falafel. Try the hebrew beer- its great! Don't forget Place de Vosges and Victor Hugo's house, which is free to see and a great exhibit of one of France's national treasures.

Great neighbourhood! Energetic, vibrant , colourful and hip!. This is the hyp part of Paris, as well as being the rainbow district, the great little Jewish is also here. Great food, lots of bars, boutique shopping... Electric !

Hotel de Sully. In the Marais do not miss the Hotel de Sully, two courtyards , one with gardens, beautiful interior staircase and ceilings. This resin ce is open to the public and opens on to place des Vosges, a reeal Parisien square where Victor Hugo lived. His house can be visited and free of charge.

Lovely old shopping area. This is a quiet, attractive high quality pedestrian shopping area.
Some of the boutiques are multi nationals but there are individual businessess, high quality eateries, jewellers etc all in a very clean well presented charming collection of bulidings.
There is also a very impressive national archive that is typical of the 18th Century splendour of Paris
worthwhile visit. We spent a lovely walking day around this area, quaint shops and the Place de Vosges is well worth a visit ....

My neighborhood in Paris. I stayed in a tiny hotel in The Marais and loved it. The old Jewish Quarter remains, but the area also has wonderful restaurants, shops, and museums. Close to everything you want to see in Paris, and it's like coming home after a long day of sightseeing. I would definitely stay in the area again.

Historic Part of Paris. We went on Paris Walks Tours of The Marias Circuit 1 and 2. This is an unspoiled part of the city. The old Jewish quarter, the rue de Rosiers and the modern Pompidou Center. Not to be missed!

Lovely, great history. I took a free tour with discover walks, and learned a good deal about the history associated with this area, including all about the bastille and Beaumarchais and the affair of the necklace, what "le marais" means, who has had a hand in making it what it is today, etc., etc. We went to several courtyards associated with private properties and also to the Place des Vosges and Place de Sully, both gorgeous. All very interesting, and in the future I'd like to learn more about the modern Marais.

Great shops, great atmosphere. Old aristocratic Paris and the Jewish quarter. Check out Izrael, L’Epicerie du Monde.Came across Amorino - gelato al naturale for the first time, mmmCentre Pompidou is nearby and well worth a visit as well.

Probably the most quaint district in Paris. This may be the most quaint and charming district in Paris, with its great selection of shops, winding streets, and lovely old buildings. It's a must if you're visiting Paris for the first time -- be sure to leave some time for strolling through it.
Great area. We stayed in a great little hotel in the area. Loved this spot. Lots of fun shops and great food. Street falafel all over. Nice way to spend a Sunday afternoon

sooo pretty. Feeling like being Amelie P. Stayed there for the third time, and will do so, in the future when coming to Paris. Previously I alwas used to stay at places around Great Boulevards, but ever since I stayed in Marais for the first time, I continued to do so...Charming, safe, close to everything, walkable, at least two cheaper supermarkets around St Paul st.,place where you can actually meet French people ( not much -2ethnic diversity" going on there, gay quarter and so on.Cons- expensive ( but so is whole Paris), can be noisy at night ( lots of bars, restaurants...), there is a danger of being driven over by a bus ( they have the funniest route), has changed a lot in past years ( adapting a more cosmopolitan look like the rest of Paris), not car friendly ( I actually do not mind that), no public toilets ( not even Mc Donalds- like loos). There is actually a lot to see and do in Marais, or just enjoy- eat, drink, sit around, walk...
Fun area. We stayed in this area and were pleased with the selection of nearby restaurants and attractions in walking distance.

My how things change.... Gentrification run amuck! Gone are the kitchey shops and quaint places, replaced by the same kind of up-scale shops in the 1st and 2nd. Some of the old Jewish quarter remains, but even that has gotten a clean-up.

The Soho of Paris. We love this area,,, smaller quieter streets, cobbles, markets and museums... and a lot of quirky boutiques. Its perfect for ambling through without a plan... or renting a bike from the street to go a little further.

Pack them in!. The marais is usually wonderful. On a Monday. After that good luck. People walk into you, you can't go to dinner (although food is good everywhere, especially love Chez Omar). But I have never seen so many people, travelers going to one destination. So sad

Le Marais district is a 'Must Do' when in Paris. Great district of Paris not far from Bastille. Museums, cafes, tearooms, designer shops, art and antique shops......everything you really want. There is a substantial Jewish area in Le Marais with lots of Kosher food and bagels, falafel etc. available at many corners and cafes. It is also now known as an up and coming gay area. Maybe getting a little bit touristy now, but still a great place to visit
gotta see it , Eat some Falafel. It is changing fast, catch it now before it is too Chic.Some great shops,wonderful cutlery place and vintage eye glass shop.
I love Le Marais!. Beautiful history...great falafel and shopping! Visit th emuseums and try all the wonderful pastries in all the kosher bakeries...DELICIOUS...GO!!!!

Our favourite area to stay in Paris. This area is like a 'village within the city' it has small restaurants, cafes and independent shops and there is a friendly atmosphere late into the night. We found excellent places to eat breakfast and dinner (even at midnight). Will re-visit again and again.

Le Marais an incredible jewel in Paris. Since we discovered this lovely quarter, we love having a walk close to Place de Vodges or we having e a drink in the Jew area or in the gay area. It's an incredible coin in the ville lumière.
The gay-borhood, filled with great restaurants. The Marais is a fun and easy to get lost in area. Great restaurants, St Eustache Church. It is a lot of fun and and fun to people watch
Hip and Fun. Great for shopping, eating and if you happen to like gay bars, its very much gay-bar central as far as Paris is concerned.
Best district in Paris. There is no better, quainter place to stay in Paris. Feels like a small village in the middle of a huge city.

Shop into the past. One of the oldest districts of Paris, the Marais gives you at any step the impression of walking into history. The middle ages, the Renaissance, the 19th and 20th century Jewish immigration, the contemporary cosmopolitanism and some of the finest cloths shops as well as tearooms. I love eating at La Bourgogne where you can always see some famous french people among the many tourists. It's located on the Place des Vosges, certainly one of the nicest squares in Paris, facing Victor Hugo's House.

A beautiful quarter that you must visit, especially on weekends!. The Marais is a really nice quarter to walk through and sit in a cafe or a restaurants. There are lots os of lovely little boutiques, most of them are quite pricey but it's nice for a window-shopping as well even if you're not buying anything.The most important thing to know about the Marais is that the majority of the shops and restaurants are working on Sunday and so while other parts of the city are deserted this quarter is lively and it's fun to be there!
Lively quarter of Paris. A lively place, an awful lot of pubs, restaurants and many others accomodating everybody's taste. A preferred place to go when it comes to partying and meeting people.
Beautiful quartier. The most beautiful quartier to walk by. Place Vendôme is precious. The streets are small and some shops are beautiful.
one of the nicest areas of Paris. Interesting streets and shops. It felt far more "real" than the more touristy areas. As with all of Paris there are more good pastry shops than are good for me.

Never stay anywhere else. It's just the best. It has everything. We have stayed here twice in two different locations. It has a fantastic vibe, lots of interesting shops cafes and museums and all the big attractions ( Notre Dame, the Seine, Centre Pompidou ) you can walk to. It's not seedy at all. Try and stay near St Paul metro - it's handy to everything. The bread and cake shops are to die for.

Amazing. Le Marais is truly what Paris has come to be about. It's quaint and cute streets speak Paris and Europe. Its a great place to shop, eat, and just wander the streets while getting great photography. It's perfect old Paris and has completely avoided modern commercialization, apart from all the newer stores. theres the busy center, then as you wander on the side streets you can go into all the french boutiques! It's truly amazing!

A stroll in the Marais. What better place on a Sunday afternoon to stroll around and see the varied array of shops with unique clothes ,jewellery and crafts. Plenty of opportunity to view current exhibitions and have a great coffee.

Vibrant, fun, full of charm. I walked and I walked and I walked through Paris, past roads full of boutique and luxury goods, past hordes of tourists, past streets packed with slightly run-down uninspired cafés and bistros selling overpriced beer and average food. Finally beyond the Centre Pompidou I found a gem, Le Marais. An area where I finally felt some Parisian charm and flair - artful graffiti on the walls, charming little bistros with dishes which illustrate invention and flair, independent florists and artisan bakers. After the tourist haven of Les Halles, the area oozes charm and vibrancy. I was drawn into the area to visit the Le Poilâne bakery, which is actually superb. The bread is fantastic and the shop was not too busy when we got there late in the afternoon on the Saturday. I loved the area so much that I came back the next day to try the bistros and went to Le Bar Bouille - the food is great and the crème brûlée is to die for (honestly). Anyway if you have a free afternoon in Paris, drag yourself away from that museum your guide book told you that you had to see and just go and try Le Marais. Good food, vibrant, far away from the tourist traps - what's not to love!
Great Area. Wonderful shopping beautiful people. This area is full of colorful stores eateries and drinking establishments

Great area for shopping and filled with energy. Maybe because it was a Saturday afternoon, but as soon as we got out of the metro St. Paul, we felt the buzz, even though it was snowing quite a lot. First the Hotel de Sully, its courtyard covered with snow, like a fairy tale, with little ones playing and having so much fun, then the Place des Vosges, it was a dream. Then all the little boutiques, principally the Kooples Sport on rue de Sevignee. And then all the residents buying from their traiteurs, pattisiers and boulangeries getting ready for the dinner, it felt like a real neighborhood. In sum, Le Marais is where tourists can go in Paris and feel what is like to be Parisian.

Fun for a night out... gay oriented!. Just walk around in Le Maraisaround 17h... you'll see lots of bars with terrace on the sidewalk so you can pick your crowd!some around 40, some younger (with more music then!)And some bars with open cruising spaces that are... very wild.
Nice Neighbourhood. There are a lot of great pastries, vintage shops and small cafes. I truly recommend this neighbourhood.

Place des Vosges. Arrive hungry when you choose to stroll through the Marais. There are too many fabulous places to eat, grab a quick snack and shop! I took my amazing pastry over to the Place des Vosges to sit in the sun and take in this beautiful square.
Well worth a visit. Something for everyone here, interesting shops, cafes, parks, museums and art galleries. This would be a good combination with a visit to Notre Dame Cathedral.
wonderful area with great restaurants and shops. nothing to dislike - many museums open on a Sunday which is unusual - this area has every thing you need for a short stay in Paris.
Quirky. Great mix of shops, cafes and restaurants. Just walk off the main road and down many of the back streets and just stumble across one of many pavement cafes and stop to watch the world go by

Lively, quirky and fun. Le Marais is my favourite area of Paris, whatever you are looking for (apart from expensive luxury shops), the Marais has it:- Cool bars- Delicious food at reasonable prices- Fashion- Chillout & Party- Beautiful buildings and gardensIf you pass by, make sure that you visit the Spaghetti Bar. Fun crowd, cocktails and good food.

Favourite area. On our recent trip we walked and walked several areas around Paris and this was one of our favourites ......winding streets filled with interesting shops cafes and restaurants..lovely market too..

Trendy and Chic. On Sunday the neighborhood become all pedestrians. Tons of Parisians in the streets, a great way to visit Paris and not fell like a tourist. Plus the shops are open on Sundays (closed every where else in Paris)

One of the best neighborhoods to stay in Paris: AUTHENTIC !. I have been to Paris many times: Montparnasse, St. Germain, Montmartre, etc. Like Montmartre, and St. Germain, Le Marais is authentically French, but it has its own charm. It is central (unlike Montmartre), and you have everything there: shops, walks, markets, restaurants, and a lot of bakeries : Oh, les millefeuilles ! A diverse collection: jewish quarter, asian, arab, and french too. Fantastic neighborhood !

Le Marais. I stayed in an apartment in Le Marais and loved it. It is a beautiful arondissement. It has beautiful buildings and is very safe. You have the Jewish section and the Gay area and everyone melds in just nicely. I thoroughly enjoyed staying there, every morning I would walk through this gorgeous park, with a pond, ducks, children's play area, older Parisians playing chess and a group of older Asian women doing Ta Chi under the rotund. I even saw a group of men playing table tennis, all rugged up with there scarfs and winter coats whilst it was raining. A fascinating little park that I looked forward to walking through every day. The cafes and boulangeries were amazing and it also has the best falafel shop ever. Would definitely stay there again.

the only place to be!. We rented an amazing apartment for five women on the main street. The whole of the Marais was literally at our feet. There are SO MANY good places to eat and buy special things-we wished we had had more time to just hang around there
Buzzing neighborhood. Le Marsais is a must for very visitor to Paris, vibrant and full of interesting little corners plus the outstanding Places des Vosges which is a gem of outstanding architecture!

The best place in the world. The marais is my most favorite place in Paris. It is filled with bakeries, treats and shops to cater to anyones delight. Start at rue Rambuteau from Georges Pompidou and make your way down all the way to rue des Archives. Turn right, turn left, go straight to find yourself at place des voges. You will quickly get lost in all the charm that marais has to offer. Hidden little streets, cafes, restaurants. Something new is always popping up, like the new japanese crepe canteen! A must!

My FAVORITE in all of Paris!. I spend the majority of my time in this neighborhood. There's tons of cute shops, cafes, the Place des Vosges, and two Metro stops to get here. I just adore strolling down the Rue Rivoli to get here and adore the arrival at the church of St. Paul as I make the stroll.I make the Monoprix a mandatory shop to brouse, and eat at one of several eateries before leaving. My favorite bar is Le Lizard, on the Bourg Tibourg. We all gather there when we've had alternate agendas each day. The changes from each visit are always exhilerating, my last visit I discovered a new location for my favorite perfumes. It's always a thrilling time when in the Marais.

Such a relaxed cafe surrounding. Great area for socialising. There are several gay friendly bars in the area too and great shopping. Coffee seems to be the order of the day till early evening when time for a beer.

beautiful area. i liked this area. it is my 6th visit in Paris and i really enjoyed this different side of the city. Less glamorous, but definitely cult !!!Gay friendly for those who are in interest :-)

Stayed 8 days in Le Marais.... Right next to Mariage Freres. Wonderful neighborhood for walking, shopping, sightseeing, and it felt like it still had the charm of old Paris. Also was central to nearly everything transportational. The only other neighborhood that I thought might be more charming is Montmartre with its cobblestone streets.

the oldest area in Paris. in this area you will see one of the oldest house, lots of museums, and very nice restaurants and bars. This area is special for open mind people because its also called gay area. There are lots of gay bars but not only that. Everyone can be sure that is welcome. And what I recommend to visit is LA RUE ROSIER, this street is very special because you can see the Jewish area and taste the delicious speciality called falafel...

Most interesting interior boutiques in Paris. Where to find all these little objects that complete your interior? In the Marais in Paris. Take a look and stroll the boutiques between the Centre Pompidou and the Place des Vosges.
Cheese shops, butchers, wine shops, cafe's and more. It felt like Greenwich Village in NYC. The streets curve and people watching is fun too. They have many small shops,with unique items.

Lively, Lovely. A wonderful neighborhood with great food, small shops, and steps away from Ile St. Louis, Notre Dame, Saint Chapelle, etc. Le Marais during the Music Festival is a blast. A neighborhood enlivened both by the young people it attracts and its rich history.

Great area to walk, eat and shop!. Lovely place, with many shops and eateries. Stop at a bakery and get a Christmas log for the holidays or delicious pastries to enjoy your walk. As you find interesting buildings, always try to go inside as you may be surprised by amazing mansions covered by their facades. The best way to get to know this area is by walking so I a, not recommending any specific place. Just walk around, discover, enjoy and relax.
lovely area could be better sign posted,. could be just a little more tourist friendly, somwhere to get maps of the area.esp closing times of cafes restaurants etc

A must-see. I stayed in two different apartments in the Marais. It is an architecturally beautiful area. And if you like gay-clubbing it is the place to say as all of the best Parisian gay clubs are within walking distance :)
NotWhat It Used to Be. The cattle and the butchering keep getting pushed out of town. The historic scene is being replaced by modern gardens and urban renewal The old bustle and charm are fading

Really old. The Place des Vosges is nice enough but there are also some interesting really old buildings in this area. The Musée Carnavalet is also close by but not well signposted so it took us quite a while to find it. The museum is well worth a visit and is free.

Full of charm. I wasn't planning on visiting Le Marais, but I'm so glad that I accidentally ended up there. You can get happily lost on its charming streets full of great little cafés, interesting boutiques and everyday Parisians. The wonderful Place des Vosges is certainly not to be missed; also, the Maison de Victor Hugo is just round the corner, so check that out as well.To sum up, you feel a sort of charm that doesn't come up in every Parisian corner, and it makes the perfect excuse to stroll endlessly.

Saturday shopping chaos. Shopping in the Marais on a Saturday afternoon is like joining a parade with all the fashionable Parisians. Every shop is friendly, and it's an entirely different mix of stores from elsewhere in Paris, with many affordable, local choices. Great with a girlfriend for an afternoon, with coffee breaks early and charcuterie breaks later.

Beautiful squares and lovely shopping ops!. Place des Voges is stunning and a lovely peaceful place full of the most stylish houses. the whole area is delightful and well worth a visit to stroll around just absorbing the atmosphere.

Atmospheric. Full of fashionable and interesting little shops, restaurants and bars but, more importantly, just an excellent place to stroll around. Close to the Louvre/Notre Dame/Pompidou Centre and full of the flavour of old Pris.
Was fun. Was fun and pretty to stroll about. Didn't spend a ton of time here, but we had a limited time in general. I would go down the side streets and see the little boutiques and bistros.
Winter Vacation. A good location to shop, seem museums, and many sights of Paris. We found the location fun and vibrant

If you like old this is the place. Very old windy streets with beautiful architecture. I recommend downloading a walking tour. We did a self guided tour which took 2 1/2 hours with a little blurb on each site it took us to. I enjoyed it far more this way.
Cute area among many other cute areas. A lot of nice places in le marais. A place to go for a drink at a bar or find a nice restaurant somewhere.
Great area to stroll on a sunday afternoon. This is one of the nicest areas I found in Paris. Little boutiques, bars, bistrots, flair, artists, crazy ppl... Relaxed and nice.
All time favourite neighbourhood. Great little area close to notre dame. This is the Jewish gay area of paris and has lots restaurants, cafes and little boutiques. Fun place to visit.
Lively Area,. I think all of Paris is wonderful, but this is abit special,,so much to see and do in a confined area..take your time and explore..

LOVE this neighborhood. We stayed close to Arts et metiers and there are 3 grocery stores nearby (if you rent an apartment as we did), some nearby clothing stores due North, and restos and bars due South. It's nearby the atrocious on the outside Pompidou, even though the inside modern art on the inside is delicious.For the ladies, it's also purse central! For the boys, it's boy central. It can be busy on some of the streets with the bars at night so choose wisely.

Great area to stay. Close to the centre of Paris, we stayed near metro st Paul. Lots of cafes, chemist, bank, small supermarket, bakery etc all around the metro stop. It's a lively and enjoyable are to stay in Paris.

Marais is perfect. I've been to Paris countless times and once I discovered the Marais I was smitten. This is a NEIGHBORHOOD...a cheese shop here, a wine shop there, cobblestone streets closed off on Sundays where you can walk and ride bikes with complete freedom. Wonderful boutique shops, Picasso Museum, Place Des Vosges, art galleries and more! My DREAM location if I ever get my millions and can buy an apartment in Paris. I have taken some trips to Paris where I don't leave the Marais...just wandering this area IS Paris.

Place des Vosges under the snow. The snowfall of mid january made the Marais more intimate and silent at night, and also a quite rare situation.On saturday morning, children could play in the white garden of the Square.

Trendy, lively area!. Just love this area that preserves the narrow streets and architectural styles of Medieval and Renaissance-era Paris. You have to take your time to explore the artisan’s boutiques, galleries, lavish squares, and fascinating history!
Great cheese shops: ). Nice quarter. Friendly people, not only gays: ) Lot's of culture and great night life. And a lot of cheese shops: ))
Make the Time to Visit. So much to do and see. Parks, shops, restaurants, galleries, people watching.As with all areas of Paris you will discover many surprises, but in particular Le Marais!

Worth a good amount of time. you can get lost here. Lots of art and architecture, food and bars. Lots of happy hour (usually 3 hours) allows you to meet local people. Second Hand shops are fun too. If possible do your exploring on a Sunday when everyone is happy to be cruising.
Great area to walk around. This was a new place for us to visit in Paris but it's great to just wander round & find things. There are some lovely food shops & a couple of little markets.

Will someone fund me moving here? Great place. Don't miss!. Do not miss walking this part of town. No wonder people are drawn to this area. Beautiful markets. Delicious pastry shops/bakeries where we watched Parisians buying bread for dinner on their way home; several people we watched couldn't resist and took a big bite out of their baguette while exiting the bakery! Small side street eateries with delicious food and a warm neighborhood vibe. Feast for the eyes flower shops ---- displayswith such variety of color you'd think Matisse had come back to life and become a florist. My favorite Marais floral shop was L'Artisan Fleuriste. A corner food market with the food so artfully displayed (wish I had written the name down) that it made me want to go food shopping (a task I never get excited at all about where I live in the states). Don't skip walking the Marais during the week when it is less crowded. I found it my favorite area of Paris, the area where I'd most like to live, and, in a city with so many outstanding neighborhoods, that's really saying something.

The Beating Heart Of Paris. The contrast between the 3rd and the 16th arrondissements couldn't be greater, from the grand boulevards of wealth with ultra chic shops to narrow little streets and boutique shops, galleries and eateries.When moving back to Paris we chose the Marais over the plusher areas to the west for the same reason that makes this an essential part of your trip to the city - it's different.Once upon a time it was a Jewish enclave - you could even call it a ghetto - and if you look carefully there are still strong remnants of that past, from the moving plaques on walls commemorating how children were rounded up to be shipped to concentration camps by the French and the Germans in the Second World War to the names of the streets and the old Synagogue near St Paul's. You will also find a surviving population in their hasidic garb, with the felafel cafes being another feature from this tradition.But before that it was where the rich and privileged of the Second Estate had their hotels particulaires, and there are many of them that you can now visit - from the Swedish Institute through the stunning Hotel Sully and Place does Vosges.But what the Marais is now known for are the shops and galleries, from specialist shops selling exquisite choux to pop ups shops, hundreds of art galleries and thousands of boutiques. There are Jewish, Italian and Asian food areas.Sunday is a best time to visit since all the shops are open and the streets are shut and pedestrianised.

Do not miss Hanna's falafel!!!. Charming area, combo gay village and jewish quarter.Lovely library inner garden that should not be missed...so pretty and hidden, just off the street. Well worth a day of wondering! Oh..and there is amazing food and shopping here as well.

My favourite place in Paris. Le Marais is full of charme. I enjoy walking its streets, laying down in Place des Voges in a sunny afternoon, visiting the art galleries, the Picasso and Jacquemart museums, listening to super gifted street musicians, shopping in the fashion forward boutiques or enjoying some pastry. I simply love it.

Don't miss this area of Paris!. We loved the Marais! Great restaurants, cool shops, terrific museums and a very interesting history......spent 2 days walking around and intend to stay here when we return to Paris for another visit......

The Best District for Fun (and affordable) Shopping and Little Cafes. Stayed in an apartment in Le Marais and loved the area! My mom and I wanted to go into every little restaurant and clothing store, everything is so hip! (But not annoyingly hip) And Le Marais is close to everything.

bohemian, cool and relaxed!. Le Marais is one of my favourite places! So many times been there and still willing to come back. The charm of it stays in the spirit of the people frequenting the neughborhood. Interesting cafes, art galleries, shows and so on... Replenishing!

Lost its charm. The Marais was the Parisian's artisans neighborhood, with the best craftsmanship ateliers ranging from couture to cabinet makers, with authentic Paris charm. It has now become ostentatiously gay and streets align cheap clothes boutiques of little interest. A few good galleries remain and some beautiful mansions are worth seeing.

Nice area to walk around. There is plenty to see in this small area of Paris. Lots of kosher restaurants, some judaica stores and the Holocaust memorial. It is a nice way to spend an afternoon/evening.

The Marsh, The latin quarter visit. The Marais is a Marsh Area that was built on in the middle ages. As you can imagine the original inhabitants did not have alot of wealth and subsequently it was the cheaper area of town. Nowaday's though after 16th/17th/18th/19th and 20th century evolution it has become a fashionable area to live eat and drink.Places to visit .... Les fountain des Invalides Square..(read the book PURE' most of the restaurants are good supplying quick reasonable food. It is the main area for Gay bars so not the parental place to take young questioning children for an evening stroll easily though in 10 years we have never been upset by some of the overt behaviour.

Perfect!. This has to be, hands down the best part of Paris! the cute streets, cafes, shops... it just has a feel to it that I haven't found anywhere else! We will also stay in this area. We walked to everywhere and I mean everywhere. The location is great, there are monoprix's on every corner and our favourite cafes are here too!
Paris at its best. Historic streets, the point virgule theatre, small restos and shops make this a great base to visit Paris.

Winter sales!. Could wander around Le Marais for days on end. Every corner you turn, there is another beautiful row of cafes and boutiques. The winter sales have been amazing in this area and for a perfume lover, it is absolute heaven. L'artisan, Fragonard, dyptique... I could go on and on. Wonderful.dont miss it.
great suburb to wander. It is the Jewish Quarter so you will find everything open on Sundays. Interesting independent shops and lovely little squares with great art galleries.
Cosy and open on sunday. Cosy neighborhood. By a book with tips about the streets and shops. Nice restaurants and small shops (not H&M, ...)
Not the best time of year. A cold December was probably not the best time to walk the streets. However, we did find a good cafe and enjoyed what we did see.
It was a bit disappointing. We expected more. We were just walking around for a couple of hours, but we did not find anything extra ordinary in this quartier

Window shopping, architecture, fun museums. Wonderful neighborhood for a day of window shopping, excellent food (try the Suzette Creperie), interesting museums (Musee Carnavalet, the museum of the City of Paris, and the Museum of Hunting and Nature), and a true appreciation of what the city looked like before Hausmann demolished huge portions to create wide streets and boulevards.

Excellent location to stay. We had an apartment just off Rue de Bretagne, adjacent to Le Marche Enfant Rouge, which is a market with everything from fresh fruit and vegetables, flowers, meats, cheese, and lots of ready to eat hot food too. The whole of the Marais is "handy" and we had 4 Metro stops all quite close. For a day visit, much to experience and wander around.

Not sure what the hype is about. This place is known for good shopping, but I wasn't able to find a store suitable for young people like me. I didn't like the styles of some of the clothing. I think I would rather shop at Printemps because they have more variety and the stores are more compact. We did buy some perfumes at Fragonard though.

Hit and miss. Trendy, interesting.., my advice would be to 1. Choose a reccomended restaurant before hand and go there, food is touch and go. 2. Go for shopping.
Keep to coffee

Le Marais is the best neighborhood to stay in. I have been to Paris on 7 other occasions and this was the first time for me to stay in Le Marais. I rented an apartment from Vacations in Paris and the apartment was right on rue St. Antoine. The neighborhood is one of the friendliest I have ever stayed in in Paris. The shops and restaurants are delightful. One could spend several days just exploring all that there is to see and do in Le Marais. I will definitly stay in this part of Paris again. Fabulous!!!

The cosmopolitan heart of a great city. This is one of the most attractive areas of Paris. It manages to seem genuinely French and local (with plenty of shops catering to the neighbourhood) while at the same time rich in culture and cosmopolitan. Visit the Place de Vosges, a lovely square with gardens surrounded by chic shops and cafes. Wander down streets full of small, smart and not too expensive shops. No trip to Paris is complete without spending most of a day here.

Beautiful. the area is simply beatiful, with the small streets and the differents types of shops all around. a great place to spend a nice afternoon walking and looking into shops, some shopping and window shopping. you will really enjoy it

hip jewel, great Sunday destination. We visited this le Marais for a bit of Sunday shopping based on Trip Advisor suggestions. We arrived at about noon having walked over from the Luxumbourg Gardens with a stop at Notre Dame and there were many shops and restaurants open. The tourists and locals seemed hip - the area was a combination of la Vielle Ville in Geneve and So Ho combined. Cobble stone streets, narrow alleys, small buildings, with a combination of one of a kind boutiques mixed with venues with more of an international presence. SO MUCH better for shopping than the Champs au Lycee which I found to be a nightmare. We had a lovely lunch at a cafe'. Do not expect the best table without a reservation. Our crowded choice was able to offer us a table for 4 near the door but we were happy to have a fantastic meal. sorry i cannot remember the name of the place...

Nice neighborhood, lots to see. Lots to see. Many very nice shops. Also, cheap ethnic (Jewish/Middle eastern) food. Historic Jewish Area with lots of Jewish shops, even bookstores with hebrew books, etc. The Jewish area is just a block or two from the subway station. We were there at nice and there were lots of people.

The New Hot Spot. This arrondissement was formerly the Jewish ghetto. Still many Orthodox Jews walk the streets. It's become an area filled with great boutiques, renovated apartments, where great restaurants abound and the little square is the home where brick facades were first used. (It's not real bricks-but the entire square was the first place in Paris to have brick like facades)...Home to Paris' very wealthy and some great art galleries.

marveilleux marais!. if you want eclectic shopping, fantastic food, and spectacular peoplewatching, go no further than the marais district. from falafel to pomme frites, you can find everything here. easy walking to all the sights, and friendly shop owners made our day in the marais so much fun.
Arty and Foody with great charm.. Loved the cafes, the quirkiness and the art galleries. Would spend way more time here if I could. Bought my husband a painting in this district.

Charming!. A beautiful place to wonder and discover - we found an art gallery tucked away off the tourist trail!If the weather is bad, sit and people watch in the many little cafés and admire the many churches and collapsing buildings.Tip: watch out for the dog poo!

Interesting walking tour. 90 minute walking tour run by Discover Walks who do not charge a fee just rely on tips. Lovely quarter to wander around with a Parisian who speaks great English. Would have liked a bit more history but a great way to see things you would probably not find by chance.

a walk in the back lanes of Paris. pebbled walkways and little cafes give Le Marais as a very bohemian environment. little shops loaded with goodies make it a very browsable area as well. if you're into vintage items, then this is the place to go.
Best place to stay and walk in Paris.. This charming area of Paris is home to Bastille and Place Des Vosges as well as great local shops and restaurants!

My Favourite. I loved the Marais. Came here x3 on a 7 day trip. The best falafel and shawarma in th jewish district, and very cheap (euros 4.50). If you see a big line up, stop and line.....its well worth it.
Lots of shopping; my fav are Ted Baker, Karen Millen, Gerald ???.

Walking in History and Discrimination of the Past. Not sure how to describe my feelings at taking a walking tour (while listening to an audio Rick Steves tour) through this neighborhood. The area is a residential and business area that is being gentrified. It once housed the heart of Paris' Jewish population.It has become much more trendy. The main (walking/narrow) streets (in the neighborhood, not the main roadways, are from a time of the past. Then again, walk in almost any Paris arrondissment and you can say the same thing --you are walking in the past, yet you are in the 21st Century.While here though, we did visit the Jewish Museum and were very glad that it was open. We were impressed with the exhibits and background/information that they tried to pass on. For me it was a painful visit. There was a lot of anguish as it recounted the many instances of anti-semitism, discrimination and persecution. The exhibits also actively sought to provide information related to Jewish holidays, religious items and "life" as it existed in the context to items on display. In some instances, what was noted differed with my own knowledge, background and education. On an upbeat note, we had Falafal & other middle eastern cuisine at a famous local eatery (Falafal King Restaurant). Viewed the shops and stores from another life time and felt the pain of what was and what now is.Having said all of the above, I must point out that I was glad that we made it here. Glad that we did the walk and glad that we visited the Museum.

A wonderful place to get lost. We made the obligatory visit to Notre Dame and then walked north across the Pont d'Arcole and through the Place de l'Hotel de Ville to Rue de Rivoli, where we turned east and then north through little winding streets in the general direction of the Place des Vosges. Was the highlight of our trip to Paris. Some reviewers complain about the number of tourists walking the Marais and there were certainly lots of them (us). However, it seems a little unfair for a tourist to complain about the number of tourists! Absolutely make a point of walking the Marais. Allow time for le shopping. And definitely make your way to Place des Vosges. One of the most beautiful places in Paris, and that's saying something.

Lovely area. Give yourself plenty of time to explore this wonderful area. Lots of interesting shops and museums and great walks. On this trip I stayed in this area and I highly suggest this. Plenty to do and see and worth the time. Research the area before you arrive to make the most of your visit.

Nice for a Wander- Some nice places to eat. Interesting shops, sight, and a combination of many villages all combined in one area; from the gay district to Soho, to the Jewish area to funky design all around the corner to each other with some great architecture and history to boot!

Great Neighborhood!. What a great place to be for Christmas! We were walking distance from beautiful City Hall--all lit up at night with ice skating and a merry-go-round--plus Notre Dame Cathedral, the Seine, cafes, bistros and bakeries...so much to see and do!

Le Marais - walking treat. Rue de Rosiers has wonderful delis and falafel stalls; Place de Vosges is a charming stroll and Hotel Sully offers lovely photo sites; boutiques are welcoming change from the Fauburg St. Honore. Great for a day trip.

Fun neighborhood, but can get a little crowded. We stayed in the Marais in Hotel Emile and it was a great location choice. There are a bunch of sites, boutiques, cafes, and bakeries all over the neighborhood. Getting to other sites around the city was very easy because the Marais is right off the 1. On the weekend, it got a little crowded during the day as everyone was out shopping. We enjoyed the weekdays there a bit more. Definitely a neighborhood to go to, especially if you're looking for good gifts for your friends, family, or yourself.

Best distrcit - quartier of Paris. Nice, informal, small streets, nice shopping, limited to pedestrians sunday afternoon. Lots of reasons to visit this district of Paris or stay in a hotel. Not exactly the cheapest quarter, but you will find a lot in compensation for your euros

Great neighborhood to roam on a Sunday. Since most of Paris is closed Sunday, this is a great place to visit. Not sure why all the shops here are open on Sunday, maybe it is the large Jewish quarter here, but it was a great surprise for us. You must get a falafel for sure, best we have ever had. There are lots of shops, cafes and great people watching. The streets were packed with people when we went. It a fun Bohemian sort of neighborhood with a range of people which makes it really fun.
Just Walking through. Just enjoyed the architecture and casual walk through the streets.There are many cafes to stop at, all good.

Great people watching and hot street food. We walked all over this area on a Sunday morning -- the Jewish Quarter shops were open -- and it was jammed with shoppers. The crepe maker's window was open and a hot raspberry crepe made the stroll even better. Some small streets are crowded, but quickly release into more open areas. Cafes are perfect for watching locals and tourists alike.
Not sure about this area. Maybe we missed the right streets. But I expected a lot more really excellent food shops.The architecture and the small narrow streets are really interesting.

Paris is alive. You can feel the energy walking through the Marais.Sooo many people. We finished our walking tour at the historical square Place des Bosques where Victor Hugo's house is and where Napoleon also used to visit. There's plenty to explore, from the flea market to the old ruins which are now part of the school to the Jewish quarter. Well worth the visit

My favorite part of Paris. I spent three days wandering around Le Marais, and I could have spent several more. The streets look like something out of a movie set, yet the each block is chock-full of small shops and restaurants. There's a great energy here, and it is my favorite part of Paris.

For foodies..... Go to the Rue des Rosier on a Sunday morning and get a fix of the best Jewish food in Paris, the Gefilte fish was to die for.............All the shops are crowded and the whole place is street theatre.
Favourite quartier in the city of love and lights.. Gorgeous people, boutiques, boulangeries, restaurants and walking distance to so many of Paris's beautiful attractions!

Real people live here!. This is still old Paris. Rented an apartment there and thoroughly enjoyed the neighborhoods, shops, markets and people. Great architecture and home to La Place des Vosges. Wonderful restaurants and walking distance to Ile de la Cite.

The Marais is a waste of time. For decades the Marais was a glorious place to wander, poke around, eat and generally have a lovely experience.No longer, sadly. The shops have junk, all of the hundreds of small antique dealers are gone, the place is overrun by tourists looking at nothing and if you do stop to eat it is a fortune. I no longer go there as it is a shadow of its former self.

Marais at Christmas. Amazing place to stay. We rented an apartment in this part of town and each day walked to amazing bakeries and trendy shopping areas in this old part of Paris. I would definitely recommend this area to anyone wanting an authentic experience in an upscale but not pretentious part of Paris

Marais Paris 3rd and 4th districts/quartiers/arrondissements. Marais can feel like a rabbit warren. But if you apply some logic it makes for much easier walking. Useful walking streets either parallel the Seine or run from the Seine. If you turn the district, mentally, more or less into a grid, you can find your way quite easilyUseful walking streets away from the Seine in the Marais.rue du Templerue des Archivesrue Vieille-du Temple which becomes rue des Filles du Calvairerue de Turennethese all run from rue de Rivoli.(which becomes St Antoine going east) The other streets listed stop at rue de Rivoli but rue des Archives runs all the way to the Seine without a break. It goes behind the Hotel du Ville.Parallel streets from the Seine rue de Rivolirue Rambuteau becomes rue des Francs Bourgeois rue Reaumur becomes rue de BretagneUseful Metro stops or sites that I like to visit and that I think, define the limits of the neighbourhood are:Centre Pompidou (Metro : Rambuteau) and the Stravinsky Fountain whose separate pieces represent his ballet Rite of Spring, I think of as the heart of Marais. The most important main exhibits of the Pompidou are on the 5th floor. It is well worth checking what is on before you go because some special exhibits can be amazing. The Atelier Brancusi is a personal favourite and is free, just outside the Pompidou. From there you go west to St Eustache and les Halles (Metro les Halles) Then go north to rue Montorgueil (a nice walking shopping street) northern limit to rue Reamur note : St Denis is a nice walking /shopping street just north rue Reamur (Metro : Reamur/Sebastopol)Then going east along the northern limit of Marais along rue de Bretagne which is a nice walking / shopping st Marche des Enfants Rouge is on rue de Bretagne through such a small alley opening you can easily miss it. It is cute but I thought, overrated as rue Bretagne has such lovely food stores. Rue de Bretagne goes to Cirque d’Hiver at Filles du Calvaire (Metro Filles du Calvaire) The Cirque d’Hiver is well worth a visit.The Marais district goes south from there along rue du Temple where you arrive atMusee Picasso (being refurbished and not opening again til at least mid 2013) then back to rue de Rivoli. Now you have the limits of the Marais defined you can go and get lost in the rabbit warren and more easily find your way out if you find any of these grid like streets. Enjoy.
Love this quaint neighborhood. We stroll through this quaint neighborhood every time we come to Paris. Good restaurants and shops. We love the Jewish Quarter for food and baked goods.

Delicatessen. Looking for a nice sandwich, a good falafel, nice designer clothes, this is your place to go. Full of life and style, the Jewish-gay-hood is the place to be for good quality entertainment.

Very nice shopping and walking area -. this area around the beautiful Place des Vosges is just great. We have discovered the nice man shops on the Rue de Turenne too, where you can buy very nice costumes for a very good price. To be recommended

Best Place in Paris to Get Lost. I’ve visited this district only at night—when its magic is at its peak. It’s easy to get lost in a very good way along the many winding, tiny cobblestoned streets (often pedestrian since they are too narrow for cars). The Marais is one of the rare areas in Paris that preserved the narrow lanes and architectural styles of Medieval and Renaissance-era Paris because most of Paris was overhauled in the mid-19th century under Napoleon III and architect Baron Haussmann. The Marais, however, still suffering from the ghostly echoes of the Revolution (much of the bloodiest moments were in the Marais), was ignored in the overhaul. Therefore, the district stands out as very distinct in Paris. It has its own unique blend of eerie enchantment that is impossible to resist.
