As you enter the district from the Notre Dame area, stroll the Rue des Barres behind the St. Gervais et St. Pervais Church, and you’ll instantly understand what I mean. There is a timelessness in the Marais, one that makes you wonder if a revolution is erupting down the street or if a noble’s vast mounted entourage in medieval regalia might soon stomp you down.Tourist crowds are thinner in the Marais, but there are still plenty of museums and landmarks to visit—chiefly being the Bastille Monument, Saint-Paul-Saint-Louis Cathedral, the Place des Vosages, Victor Hugo’s residence, and the Carnavalet Museum. Also, there are many charming, traditional tiny cafes and a lot of specialty shops, especially on the cobblestoned Rue des Rosiers in the heart of the Jewish quarter of the district. Still, the best thing to do in the Marais is simply to wander, imagine, and get lost.
Charming old part of Paris. Lots of art galleries and boutiques. Charming picturesque streets. Most sales persons speak English in this neighborhood. Excellent options for food, too.

Best place for a Sunday. Marais starts to wake up around noon on Sundays adn if you go around 11 it's nice to stroll before the streets get busy with shoppers, falafel fans, and people converging on the Place des Vosges. The Musee Carnavalet is definately worth a visit - if just to see the fabulous 'hotel' it is housed in. Beautiful. Marais has a great vibe and it's a unique part of Paris.

Go with free paris tours at 2:30pm. You will get the real Marais information and cul de sac etc. Try the falafel andsee thee designer clothes that are almost affordable as they are not the big names...

Great Walk. Certainly the Marais is a place to walk with no hurry. There are an infinite number of small shops, each offring something unique. For the history buffs, visiting th Musee Carnavalet is an absolute must. There you can be acquainted with the main characters during the french revolution an subsequently with the Napoleon years.

I can't imagine staying anywhere else. A slice of Paris that, even though it is changing, is still an outsider's dream what we have been led to believe Paris is like: winding streets, little shops, cozy cafes and friendly, yes, friendly people.

Historic.. Visited the Shoah Memorial. This memorial and building has the largest collection of archives on the holocust in Europe. Also great vive, designer shops, judeica stores, synagogues, and a wonderful array of foods. Found my hubbys favorite poppy seed struddel. Yum!
walking tour. Took a tour with PARIS -WALKS.Very nice experience.Good guide-learned a lot.In 2 HOURS you get a lot of information about the history and the prrsent of this place

Make a walk in Le Marais. Nice area to make a great walk. Start in the Garden of Luxembourg with 38 old houses around. The museum of Picasso is in this area. Also famous is the Rue des Rosiers; a Jewish part of the town with special shops and eatings. Also many galleries and small shops. Not far from here is the museum Centre Pompidou.

where paris shops. Loved staying and shopping in Le Marais. If you are planning to shop in Paris, but not all the top designers, this is the place to do it. Tons of clothing stores, including an amazing selection of Men's shops, jewelry, furniture and my favorite, yarn & fabric stores.
Marais District. Cosy little streets littered with a mix of designer stores, artisan shops, cafes, bistros, bars, museums. Lovely spaces to roam on a weekend!

The most chich part of Paris. We spent almost 5 hours in Marais and there is a lot to see. Area is full of people but if you give yourself enough time you can see hidden part of Marais full of nice royal houses from the 17th century. Area was abondonaded after French revolution and today id most known as a jewish part of the city. It is also a great place to have a lunch.

A smart and cosmopolitan area. This was a new discovery for us and we were very pleased by what was on offer from this area of smart shops, good restaurants, and interesting architecture.There were a good number of small individual shops which we have lost in the UK to the high street chains. A very pleasant safe area to explore with lots of variety on offer.

Cheap drinks . Easily the cheapest place in paris for cheap alcohol. Mud afternoon thry have non stop happy hours.
Lots of places to watch sport and places to eat too.
Extremely friendly and interesting place
fab vibrant area,. great food, lovely shops, delis, bistros, full of character, even enjoyed it in the rain! lots of shops selling Jewish gifts and food, beautiful synagogues.
Could spend days wandering here. Twisted cobblestoned streets, inviting boutiques, unique shopping, warm cafes, fascinating people....just what a day in Paris should be.

Really nice, but overcrowed.. This time round, The Marais was busier that we've ever seen before (even around the Holidays). It's a charming area with plenty of boutiques, cafes and restaurants. To avoid the pack, don't go on Sunday..or avoid The Marais al together. There are other really nice areas in Paris.

A gem in the middle of everything!. What a wonderful stroll through the Marais district! We found several beautiful neighborhood courtyard parks in places that we didn't expect to find anything more than shops and restaurants!The area is very diverse and appears to be accepting of all! The locals were friendly and helpful when I asked for directions in my broken French! Wonderful boutiques (a little pricey) but well worth the visit!

Great neighborhood. Nice cafes bars and restaurants. My favourites were Le Preau and Les Philosophes. A little too expensive for my blood. It's the NYC equivalent of the West Village. It's right near the Bastille which is a great student hangout with cheap stuff and also near the Places de Vosges, the oldest public square in Europe where the incredibly rich own but don't live.

do this tour with Eye Prefer Paris. Richard Nahem is a New Yorker that lives in Paris, so he knows what New Yorkers like and he knows exactly how to show you the "behind the scenes" Paris ....and you will fall in love with Le Marais.

Great Atmosphere. I had never heard of this before, it's the gay and jewish area and comes alive on a sunday (saturday being the jewish holy day). Spent a few enjoyable hours here in the company of two friends.

The most expensive ghetto!. Love everything about it - reasonable yet chic and fabulous restaurants like L'Ange 20, botique & food shopping at a bargain, awesome historical places like Les Vosges Place, Hotel De Ville, and very down to earth feeling will envelope you!

Excellent place to go on Sunday evenings. When everything else is closed on Sunday, this is such a great place to visit! Very crowded (at least in December!), but lots of very interesting shops and restaurants and just very old and beautiful with cobble stone streets. While the lively crowds added something the eexperience, the downside was the long line ups for falafel or very popular bakeries. I think going on a different day of the week would be worthwhile for avoiding the intense crowds.

My favourite part of Paris. This is a lovely part of Paris. The Place des Vosges is gorgeous. There are lots of great boutiques to be found on the neighbouring streets. If you are planning to visit the Picasso Museum please note it's closed until summer 2013.

Paris on a Sunday morning. The Marais stole my heart on a Sunday morning. I loved it so much that I decided to sacrifice a visit to the Louvre to experience the Marais again. Walking the streets of this lovely area, smelling the roasts and freshly baked bread and pastries, trying on the trendiest clothes and reading a book in a park of square - absolute bliss. Easily accessible by metro and close to other attractions such as the Pompidou centre, shopping centres and historical building.

Beautiful. We did a free walking tour of Le Marais and I could not recommend seeing the area more! It houses one of the most fashionable districts in the world and is full of successful Jewish fashion businesses. It also houses the old prime ministers mansion and some of the most upper class housing areas in France. After the tour we went shopping, had dinner and visited a patisserie for some macarons and it was possibly my highlight of Paris. One short visit and you will want to live there..

Great Place to Stay. We strongly recommend staying in Le Marais for your Paris trip. We stayed in an apartment for two months there and thoroughly enjoyed every minute. The accessibility to everything in Paris is really easy from Le Marais particularly from the St Paul Metro on Line 1 Yellow. Line 1 can get you through the heart of Paris rather quickly and efficiently. Accessibility to the Jewish Quartier and the gay area is greatest in Le Marais.
Perfect location. When visiting Paris, stay here. Walking distance to Left Bank, metro stations easily accessible, and everything is open - even on Mondays when Paris seems to shut down.

Great area!. We walked around Le Marais for an entire afternoon. The shops were wonderful and each one was more enticing than the last. We bought souvenirs for the family but best of all, we found some beautiful sweaters and clothing. We went home with French sweaters that gives us great memories of the shopping. We also visited the Jewish museum and saw relics from Jewish holidays from hundreds of years. After visiting so many churches, this was a change. The beautiful relics from each holiday and from the Jewish customs was beautifully displayed and we enjoyed this very much.

Loved this neighborhood. After hitting some of the "regular" tourist areas and seeing the crowds, we were always glad to head to our own little neighborhood, and the relative calm. There's enough to see and do here to keep a visitor very busy!!

Maria's remains a lovely area to visit. It depends what you want from Paris but we invariably end up in the Marais. It is full of small independent boutiques and it has a flea market for those who like shopping.It has loads of bars and places to eat. It is worth a visit.

Don't miss this area!. A great place to walk and get lost in. Unlike any other part of Paris....stylish, historical, unusual...a mix of high fashion, Orthodox Jews and gay culture...There is something called Discovery Walks in Paris and among the five walking courses they offer is a fascinating one of this area. Be sure to take it. It is free, but the guide depends on tips, so please tip generously! There should be pamphlets at your hotel.

A good place to get lost and discover. I always stay in Marais because it's a good place to wander in without an itinerary or somewhere else to hurry. It is worth experiencing on a Saturday, when it is packed with local people and you come across the Jewish community preparing for or just leaving places of worship. Queues of young and not-so-young wait for falafels or a seat in a favourite cafe. You can pause for a coffee and a pastry, or find a corner bar for a drink. There are small art galleries and pop-up exhibitions. And if you love tea, Marriage Frere is a must. Forget the planned agenda. Plunge into the tiny lanes of the Marais and enjoy!

Dirty fun. Dirty and gritty but we like hanging
Out there. No more words to include
Don't miss oldest part of Paris

this was a very cool area!. dont miss - this is a new area not much talked about in older travel books. very cool and trendy - close to Notre Dame, but very "neighborhood-y" and doesn't feel like a big city when you are there. cool shops and cafes. i wish i could have stayed and enjoyed the nightlife but I was only there 2 nights and didn't make it there for the nights. Reminded me of Soho in NYC a little.

Men Holding Hands. Imagine our first visit to Paris. We arrive at the door our rented apartment which like many is on a floor above the commercial street level. Something is peculiar about the cafe right below our room. It's filled with couples but they are all men. Some hold hands as they sip their afternoon wine. Oh no wonder, we have booked a room in the gay neighbourhood of Marais. The bars overflow with men at night, not a lot of gay women I guess. Never-the-less it was a great neighbourhood to stay, very centrally located and with some very interesting sights & shops in the neighbourhood.

Vibrant and Hip area of Paris. I love this Parisian neighborhood. It's great for modern hip shopping and also for bars and restaurants. Plus, there are plenty of shops open on Sunday, which is a plus. Don't miss the amazing pastries at "Comme a Lisbone" (37 Rue du Roi de Secile) and also the designer's market around the corner.

A mixed area with many opportunities. The Marais has culture, history and popular life. Worth looking round - visit the Place des Vosges for a sense of history and some of the shopping street to experience the Parisian gay lifestyle. All fun.
Lots to see. Very interesting area, lots of vintage shops, cafes , Place des Voges nearby is lovely. Little streets with so much activity

wonderful walking tour. We took a guided walking tour of Le Marais. The wonderful old buildings were amazing to see. We saw where a previous king lived, lovely parks and architecture. We also saw the four to five remaining building blocks of the Bastille when we came out of the Metro.The Le Marais gives you a sense of what Paris was like when Jefferson and Franklin were there and fell in love with the city.
Good shopping zone. Many shops, flagship and general. Prices are not so good, but the choice is. Very crowdy during weekends

Nice place to spend half a day. A really pretty area to wander round with small streets and interesting shops and nice bars. It is the gay area or Paris and that seems to add to its charm. The main attraction is the Place de Vosges - very pretty - Victor Hugo lived here - but only eat and drink here if you have a fat wallet!

Lovely neighborhood. This is one of the nicest neighborhoods in Paris. I loved the feel while walking around. So many nice shops, lots of historical places, and just the right balance of everything. I followed one of the walking tours I downloaded online so we knew the stories and significance of the places. Next to the St. Germain area, I would also like to stay here in the future.

Wonderful part of the city with a bit of everything. From shopping to dining to historic sight-seeing, Le Marais offer the full spectrum. Spend a few hours, at least, wandering around the area. It will be time well-spent. A real slice of Paris!

This long standing traditional restaurant is a most.. Incredibly, this long standing fort of good food from the Seas, has lovely perfectly cooked food, served by a very professional, well trained, efficient staff, at very reasonable prices. Their menu is one of the best buys in Paris when it comes to restaurants of this standing and caliber. The food is always correctly cooked and very reliable, the wait staff is very profesional and very well trained in traditional French service. The decor is a bit tired, but one soon forgets this small detail when the lovely perfectly cooked dishes are presented.You can get sea food and fish as good as at this place elsewhere, but never at such reasonable prices
Great neighborhood, big crowds. Really love the Marais. It is packed with people, lots of good restaurants and shops and a long though sometimes sad history.

A personal Favourite. Love it here. Loads of beautiful cafes, restaurants, boulangeries, boutique shops and small winding streets. Perfect. A real must to absorb if you want to capture a true flavour of Paris.

excelent place to visit on sundays. When you want to go back to the old Paris come here and have a walk and see one of the old parisien quartier you will not be disappointed. A lot of little cafe and little restaurants will keep you happy. But what is lost To many old shops have been replaced by modern fashion shops
Lots of History. Very old and historical Jewish neighborhood. we saw the old synagogue, and the very famous and different Centre Pompidou,

Great area to explore. It's a bit funky. Lots of places to eat, some of the best delis are in this area. Clothing, food, shoes, all kinds of shopping available. Some of the best deals can be found in this area.
Perfect place to just wander. These are the neighborhoods you dream about when you plan to visit Paris. This is a quaint neighborhood full of wonderful shops, sights and smells.

The Third Arrondissement. Le Marais is truly a multi-cultural, historical neighborhood. There are many clothing boutiques, ethnic markets, ethnic restaurants, along with the always wonderful French cuisine. When other areas of Paris have closed for the evening, there are always cafes open in the Marais. It's my favorite area to stay and eat while in Paris!

The Best Part of Paris. We recently spend 16 days in a rental apartment in the Marais. Being in our own space allowed us to feel for just too short a time the sense of living in Paris. Choosing the Marais is to be transported back in history. The winding streets, old mansions, charming gardens, and, recently, very trendy boutiques and cafes. I don't think I will ever again enjoy marketing for food the same way. So many cheese shops, bread makers, pastry stores, etc., etc. Soon the Picasso Museum will reopen, it looks like its going to be very impressive, although I kind of like the old one. Too - we were walking distance to the Pompidou Center - the Jewish History Museum, etc., etc.To be in the Marais is to be part of a real Paris. Young, old, vibrant, and always exciting.

Trendy area, formerly the Jewish quarter. Quaint streets, hip stores, and some remnants of its old life as the hub of Jewish Paris. Unfortunately, the Hassidim roaming the streets for converts on a Friday afternoon saw me as American and Jewish (which I am). It's the same as in my old neighborhood in Brooklyn--just leave me alone, guys.

The only place to be on a Sunday.. Did you know that no stores are open in Paris on a Sunday, this because it is a Catholic country. However in Le Marais everything is open !! This area is where all the Gay's live, it is alive and amusing and the shops and the sights are amazing, loved it.
Take a wander. Really great area to wander around. The Bastille market on a Sunday is worth a look - particularly if you are in a self catering apartment as the produce is fabulous.

Real Paris, as we all like to imagine it. If you've done all the major tourist sites and want to see something of real Paris, the Marais area is great. No iconic sites or particularly grand buildings, but small shops, markets and all the elements of real Parisian life. The Jewish quarter is here too which you won't mistake. I've read one description of the Marais that compares it to Greenwich Village in NYC, which I wouldn't disagree with, similar in style, but quainter. We spent a happy few hours wondering around Le Marais.

Good during the week, not so on the weekend. We rented an apartment in the Marais, which was very well located and meant we could walk everywhere but on weekends it seems that this arrondissment gets swamped with tourists and those living on the outskirts of Paris. For us, there were just too many people to really see it and enjoy it on the weekends. Weekdays though, when you don't have the crowds it's definitely an area worth exploring, particularly around the Seine and closer to the third arrondissment.

Location! Location! Location!. We rented an apartment (thru Trip Advisor listing) and feel it was an EXCELLENT choice. We were on the 6th floor (w/elevator) and on the bottom floor a boulangerie (fresh croissant every mornng). Metro Station Hotel deVille was at the end of our block, and the neighborhood is populated with multiple charming bistros on every block. We rarely planned where we would dine, we just walked and ate where the spirit moved us - never a disappointment and never overpriced. The Marais is in the heart of the city with all tourist attractions easily accessible. Safe, friendly, very "real". I would heartily recommend renting an apartment in this arrondissment to have an authentic "French" experience without breaking the bank.
gay in the best meaning of this word. Plenty of bars, restaurants fascinating if you are gay or not. Young people in one of the oldest parts of the city.

A great area use as your base to explore. Rented a wonderful apartment in the Marais district. Lots to see and do. Easy to join locals and not feel like a tourist. Clubs, museums and great places to eat drink and people watch

Good location for first timer. I rented an apartment unit at this arrondissment and it was an excellent choice in my honest opinion. My location was accessible to both Metro and Bus lines. Le Marais is a lively neighborhood and I enjoyed my stay in this location due to its proximity to almost everything.

Cobbled streets, boutique´s & cafes. This is a quaint area where you can wander at leisure all the boutiques, cafes, restaurants and pretty cobbled lanes. Very French and a great way to spend the afternoon.
Le Marais. A quarter with design and galleries galore, buzzing with people all enjoying the area, huge range of retaurants, bistros and bars

Location. Having 2 Metro Stations within easy walking distance and the availability of guided tours of the area which allows one to fully appreciate the history of the area and ensures the stay is even more enjoyable.

Stay here. If you can, find a hotel or apartment for rent in this neighbourhood. The Pompidou is here, access to the river and islands is here, Place de Vosges is here - it's all here! Charming cheese and wine shops, scenic back streets - I could go on and on. Instead, just consider basing yourself here during your visit and you'll see what I mean.

Great alternatve to the left bank. Really liked this location. Lovely narrow streets and plenty of bars, restaurants, boutiques, patisseries and delis. Very walkable to the river, notre dame and over to the louvre. We even walked to galleries Lafayette, took about 30 minutes. Definitely my choice for next time I visit.

Food ok but not memorable. Ok, on a holiday and willing to overlook this and that and hey you are in Paris. Have to say the food was pretty good but atmosphere felt a little nightclub by and overdone, not in keeping with the facade and surroundings. Waiter was colder than the white wine and the whole thing took us away from where we were. The ratings here are not are higher than they should be.

Great area to walk around. Our hotel was in the Marais, and we loved walked up and down the streets. It felt very safe, and there are lots of cute stores to go into. You can also visit sites like the Pompidou. And I've heard--but unfortunately didn't follow through on the advice, myself--that the Marais has the best falafel outside of Israel.

Had a blast wandering the streets. Our friends who live in Orsay led us up and down streets in this neighborhood. It was such fun I vowed next time I visit Paris to stay in a hotel there. Cafes, shops and narrow streets: the epitome of what Paris is.
Good for a Sunday. Good quality restaurants not too expensive. Easy to get to . Walking around is enjoyable. On a Sunday most is open

My Favorite Neighborhood in Paris.. Whenever I visit Paris I always try to stay in the Marais. The area is very aunthentic with cool cafes and hip shops. The Marais is the least touristy of all the Paris neighborhoods and the people are very friendly. This area reminds me of SOHO in New York and the very hip Northern Liberties area of Philly. My wife loves Le Marais and she always insists that we stay in this great neighborhood.

Marais Stay. Studio apartment in the Marais districtApartment #654 rue des Gravilliers– 75003 ParisOur apartment in Paris, booked through Special Apartments, was perfect for us. The office is just a short walk from the apartment, making check-in very easy. The two staff members we met, were extremely friendly and helpful. They walked with us to the apartment, pointing out things along the way, and showed us how everything worked, when we got there.It was a roomy, light-filled studio, with the bed located in a loft. The layout has been carefully arranged to ensure that the apartment feels spacious. It has been tastefully decorated to complement the old building. There are large windows opening on the street side, which were effective in keeping out sound, when we wanted to do so. It does have a lot of stairs, so you would need to consider this, when renting. On the ground level is a great Patisserie, and it is a very short walk around the corner to Arts et Metiers metro station. The small kitchen was stocked with quite a few essentials, and there is a supermarket a short walk away. The information folder supplied with the apartment is excellent, with instructions about everything in the apartment, and suggestions for trips, sightseeing, price-guides and restaurants.We booked for five nights and were sorry to leave at the end of our stay, as we felt very much at home in the apartment.I would highly recommend this apartment, and the Special Apartments company, for their professional and friendly service.Of course, the best part of this location, is the Marais district itself. There are many cafes, restaurants and bars to explore. The historic area is full of interesting architecture, including Place des Vosges, the Carnavalet Museum, a free attraction which traces the history of Paris, and the historic Jewish district, known as Le Pletzl, around the Rue des Rosiers, Near Arts et Metiers metro station is Musee des Arts et Metiers , dedicated to scientific instruments and mechanical contraptions. The Pompidou Centre is only a short distance away, and if you buy tickets in advance, it is easy to avoid the queues.

Wonderful area!. This is a wonderful neighborhood that has become a favorite of mine. Lots of great restaurants and small clothing stores. You can find pita places that sell a bargain priced pita sandwich. Highly recommend this neighbor hood.
Shopping. Many stores were closed - guessing that the recession has caused the downturn. But the ones that were there were delightful.

Friends live here, in a charming old building.. This is an old neighborhood, very expensive now, but with a lot of interest. Many boutiques, good restaurants, and some nice museums, including the Picasso, are here. Read the history of the Marais before your visit.

Great buzz in the Marais. Nice area, nice food, lovely shops. Great atmosphere. We went there by day, and also by night. The prices are definitely cheaper here for supper than in the other areas. I would definitely recommend it.

Cool place, reminding me of Soho in NY. It. Is an great place for long walks and shopping. However poor food is there but I recommend the Alaia shop on rue Moussy full of luxury goods. And the Eclaireur were u will find Margiela, Dries Van Noten and others...
Always lovely. Gorgeous wandering territory - lovely cafes and bistros, loads of charming little shops and interesting twisty little streets and alleys Great people watching.

One of Paris lesser-known gems. We stumbled upon Le Marais quite by accident. Having visited Notre Dame, crossed over Rue Rivoli, visited Bazar de l'Hotel de Ville we then wandered from the back entrance avoiding the hideous Pompidou centre and found ourselves in the Marais. It's a maze of small, narrow, bustling streets, with hidden cafes, boutiques and feels very french. Napoleon didn't touch this part of Paris when he demolished many of the other smaller streets to make room for his great marching military boulevards. There are many small shops and eateries to be found in Rue des Rosiers, and Place de Vosges is a small haven of relative green tranquility. We continued along from a visit to Musee Carnavalet to Place Sainte Catherine and ate lunch in la Terasse de Sainte Catherine - they make a wicked club sandwiche. Vert d'Absinthe is a tiny green fronted shop at the bottom of the square where all kinds of absinthe memorabilia can be purchased, from books, posters, the tipple, to silver absinthe spoons and glass goblets.
Great place to find vintage!!!. Forget Galleries Lafayette and Bon Marche - if you are seeking original style - check out the boutiques of Le Marais and find your signature style!!!

Nice & quiet. We stayed in an appartment in Rue Pavee in le Marais and found it to be a lovely, quiet, safe area at all times of day & night. Very handy for both the metro, St Paul, or just to walk to many of the major sites. There are many shops, cafes & restaurants everywhere. I would definitely return to this family friendly area in the future.
A district to visit. Listen to French people. This place has become a "must" when you visit Paris. Fashion / deco shops, bistrots and some of the traditional fabrics vendors walking the streets.

Stores, good art galleries and fun. This is a fun Parisian neighborhood with great boutiques, fun bars and restaurants
Everytime I am in Paris I like to visit Le Marais

Lovely area to visit on Sunday. We went to Le Marais on a Sunday around mid day. the place is so interesting, lots of little boutiques, cafes and non stop activities in the streets. If you like falafel and other type of Israeli food, Le Marais is the place to go. Many Kosher eating places and many range of shops. Don't forget to visit the chocolate places. The area in general is full of character.

Best place to stay in Paris. We always stay in Le Marais while in Paris. Having been to Paris a number of times and seen all the sights, my husband and I like to get lost in Le Marais, it is wonderful. We often just sit at one of the fabulous cafes and people watch, the french people are so amazingly different!!

from historical to trendy - the Marais. We stayed adjacent to Rue des Rosiers for the second time, for a week. Vibrant interesting area with small individualistic boutiques, the wonderful Musee de Carnavalet, a fabulous bead shop in Rue des Archives, and walking distance to a lot of the sights of Paris. Perhaps too many boutiques with a loss of some of the old Jewish food shops, but still great.

Good, but not what it was. People come to Marais to get a sense of Bohemian edge, decadent and artistic Paris... but as is always the case with these things, by the time tourists come for that, the place has lost its edge - almost by definition. So you won't get much of that, but it's still a nice place to stroll around, with some interesting little shops and still a few art galleries thrown into the mix... but don't imagine that you're seeing something cutting-edge here, it's all very main-stream by now.

Lovely area of Paris. Spent a wet Saturday morning just wandering around the Le Marais district and found it very interesting and a fantastic range of shops. The chocolate shops are wonderful and had some amazing Halloween creations to buy! 18 year old daughter loved the vintage clothes shops. Went back Saturday evening to find somewhere to eat but everywhere was fully booked.
Area full of character. Another great area for a stroll and some unusual shops. Narrow streets give a real sense of age and character.

Charming with a little grit. The Marais is a must-see part of Paris for everyone, but especially for LGBT travelers. Like much of the city, it has its own unique character of old buildings, labyrinthine streets and alleys, bars, cafes, galleries and shops. Some great apartments, too.
Le Marais on Saterday and Sunday - bustling!. the area of Paris is so alive and brings new things that it's never boring! In the evening this is more a calm area - no real night life.

Very surprising place to be. La Marais is a wonderful place to stroll the small streets and take in the shops and eateries. Many of them are Kosher offering great falaffel and baked goods. It is less busy that St Germain but definately go there.

A very special part of Paris. We have stayed in the Marais area of Paris on 3 different trips. It is unique in that it is not filled with tourists but if you can find a walking tour of the area there is a lot of history here as well as several museums. The Memorial de la Shoah is excellent. Take some time to enjoy the atmosphere.

Lovely old area of Paris. In the Rue des Rosiers there are lots of lovely small shops, reflecting the jewish nature of the area. There are lots of little cafes and places offering interesting things to eat. It seemed a very historical part of Paris with its narrow streets.and many museums. Place des Vosges is worth going to look at as the buildings are very impressive and symmetrical.

Le Marais between the lines. Thank you for a superbly produced newsletter. Well researched. Very relevant and quality insights that bring a freshness to our visits when we visit one of our favourite cities - Paris.Felix & PralineSouth Africa
Great part of town to get lost in. Between the windy medieval alleys, the great boutiques and the Place de Vogues I always pay a visit and dedicate a few hours to wander

I was a bit disappointed.. Maybe we missed something, but apart from place des vosges I wasn't particularly impressed. Yes the streets are narrow but there's not much to see unless you go into one of the museums. I was also disappointed as most of the shops seemed to be wholesale only. Minimum spend 100-150 euro.

Marais is a unique gem in Paris!. The Marais area of Paris is our favorite. Located on the Right Bank between the Louvre & Bastille, this is a trendy area with lovely hotels, wonderful restaurants, and unique shops. Very convenient to all the major sites and public transportation.

A taste of the real Paris. This was one of my favourite places in Paris. It's a pleasure to wander off and encounter true Parisienne life and get out of the tourist traps and queues for a while. We found a great local market selling all kinds of food and brick-a-brac that was far more charming than anywhere I've seen in the city. A great side step in the middle of a trip to forget the endless queues and recharge few care free hours.

Love it!. The Marais area is full of great restaurants and interesting shops. If you like to walk you will enjoy just wandering around. The Place de Vosges is worth visiting - a pretty place with some great galleries.
loved this area. great places to eat and beautiful old buildings. Felt more authentic Paris. did not have such huge crowds
Peace and quiet. Le Marais is a great place to unwind with its quiet streets, patisseries and atmosphere. Don't miss Place des Vosges and Musee Carnavalet.

Nice Market District. We ended up in the area a few times for tours and to visit Friends Overall its biggest advantage over Paris Overall ( as all of which is beautiful) is the high number of streets closed to traffic and the market is large. Les Halles Metro is modern and boring and being refurnished in to new housing.

The new chic of Paris!!. We stayed in the Maris this visit and got to know it a lot better. Great charm and atmosphere await you in the Marais and an amazing selection of restaurants to explore! Go hungry to the Marais - although not a fan of the falafel, there are great bakeries!! Such history - imagine which King of Europe stayed in which famous old hotel?????????

Nice walk. Be prepared to walk a lot. In this area you will find amazing parks with relaxing areas around lakes. From this area you will have the best views of Paris. It is like going back on time and thinking about the Kings and Queens. Make sure you read a little bit of history about Paris and France before coming to this area, you will enjoy the tour 1000 times better.
Great way to spend an afternoon. Lovely area. Small cobblestone stams. Easy to ander around and take in the atmosphere. We rode it it's bikes - check out velob - and loved it.
A wonderful wander. A lovely area to wander through, and browse at the many different shops, streets and small square. Some great cafes to stop and watch the passing parade
Walking Tour. it is wonderful to just stroll down every street and discover food and other fabulous things. It is old and quaint but VERY BUSY on the weekends. A wonderful was to spend a few hours.

Great area for a walk. This is a very good district for a walk - beautiful old buildings, sights and other tourist attractions, a lot of good restaurants and bistros, shops... Just everything you need :-)
Historical quarter. Lots of diversity here culturally and historically. Many interesting shops and eateries, as well as quaint winding streets
Small Shops. Typical european narrow streets with ecclectic shops and restaurants. Good place to do window shopping.
nice area. this is a nice area to visit, lots of shops, restaurants, night club, the only negative thing, the prices are quite expensive, coffee 3 euros but it worth a look!
Great Walk.. Enjoyed our walk through this district. With our guide book handy, we learned such greata things about this area.

Wonderful neighborhood. This is a charming area of Paris where you find great boutique shops and cares to while away your day. The Marais neighborhood is very quaint and you feel like you're with the locals. Great place to wander.
Crowded. Nice but noisy - some outdoor festival going on "our" Sunday. Don't see the uniqueness of this area.

Five wonderful nights in the Marais. We had a great apartment in the Marais and loved the vibrancy of this district, it was great just to wander arround and enjoy the atmosphere.The 69 bus goes from the Marais right into the Eiffel Tower and the St Paul metro is also handy.
Next to banks of Seine best place to stroll. Interesting neighborhood with lots to do and see. We spent a lot of time enjoying this Parisian area and recommend it to all.

Marais has a unique feeling. Marais belongs in a different time. You have in fact the feeling you live outside time, inside a film set.
What brings you back to reality are little shops with amazingly original and creative small stuff.
And the food...

Great area to stay.. In the 7th Arond., the Marais is away from the crowded, touristy and expensive areas yet just a few minutes on the Metro to any destination. Prices for a drink, a coffee or a meal are a fraction of what they are in the tourist spots.

So many streets full of interest. We chose to stay in an apartment in this lovely part of Paris, not 2 minutes' walk from the Louis XIII square with its monument and the 4 symmetrically placed fountains, each side surrounded by elegant old hotel-buildings beautifully restored. Restaurants aplenty; mid-eastern food to die for in Rue des Rosiers, specialist shops, historic places of interest; the big disappointment is that the great Picasso Museum is closed until well into 2013 for restoration.
Le Marais. This area is very interesting and picturesque. We enjoyed walking through here. Unfortunately the Picasso Museum is closed until 2013.

The Marais - Feast for the Senses.. Often overlooked the Marias has been turned into a very trendy area for food, wine and shopping in very trendy small boutique shops. Lots of locals mingling with the tourists lucky enough to find the area. Marais means The Swamp.
Classic Paris. If there is a more elegant square in Paris than the Place des Vosges, I don't know where. And the Shoah Memorial...very moving (and no, I'm not Jewish, but I am French.)

Paris at its best. My wife and I visited the Musee de Carnavalet in late September 2012. It is where Madame de Sevigne stayed when she was part of Louis XIV's court, and we know so much about his reign because of the letters she wrote to her daughter. The building now houses a very interesting museum, which I could best describe as an overview of Parisian history. It's also free, which surprised me.We spent a few hours there seeing the various rooms and exhibits and then walked back through the Marais to our hotel (Le Bristol). It was a wonderful Sunday afternoon and it seemed that all of Paris was out for a walk. We did a lot of window shopping, stopped for some chocolates, and eventually had lunch at a bistro. We realized we could have spent a few days there, but unfortunately we had to leave Paris the next day. Oh well, now we have yet another reason to return.
Great sightseeing. Hadn't been to this area before and a local American friend showed us around the area. Loved walking in this area. Great shopping opportunities.

Nice part of town. Nice boutique shops, cafe's and restaurants. I also recommend you to visit the Place des Vosges. Many historical buildings, small cobbled streets etcetera. A friendly and good looking, albeit not the 'smartest' part of town.
Incredible!. I loved walking in this district. Winding cobblestoned streets, cafes, and small shops. You get a real sense of what Paris must have been like at one time.

Love this neighborhood. Stayed here for four days - the perfect neighborhood. Great food, stunning clothing boutiques, eclectic shops, and lively overall vibe. Don't miss Rue des Francs Bourgeois for the ultimate shopping experience. And don't leave without checking out the baked goods in Korcarz and the onion rolls in Murciano's bakery - both on Rue des Rosiers. It's also quite central and convenient; we'd absolutely stay here again.
Le marais. Lived here fir a month. Tony shopping area. Also famous for falafel. Great patisserie on Ville du Temple just south of rue francs borgouid

Great Walk!!. This is completely the area to get lost walk around. Don't try and follow a map, but just wonder. I will say that cafes and shops in this area aren't so American friendly....say your bon jours and don't try and get chatty.

Wonderful walk through old jewish quarters. Wear good shoes and be prepared to be entertained with great shops large and small, breadth of things to purchase, and small eateries with slant to jewish , middle eastern food though basic french is all there. Go all over and end up at the place Vosges....

Worth a quick look en route to other attractions. The Jewish ghetto is long gone but the streets are still host to an orthodox Jewish community in Paris. The appearance of street lamps planted on the streets instead of hanging from the buildings tells you that you have arrived. Plan to go in the late morning or early evening. Not much is open or happening for the rest of the day. For the casual tourist, food is the main attraction, some middle eastern and some the remnant of eastern European taste. You can visit the site where the chief rabbi of Paris lived and pass several synagogues. But little remains or is offered to help the visitor understand the role that this ghetto played in the history of Jewish life in France.

We stayed in this area!. We loved the Marais district. Definitely would stay there again. It is so central to everything. We walked everywhere from our apartment. It offers many options. It is the old Jewish district, it is the G and L district and it is also a very arty district. You feel very safe walking there in the evenings.
Great area to just walk around. Le Marais is a wonderful neighborhood to walk with many great little shops and large gallerias as well. Takes you back to old Paris.
great area. Interesting area with lots of little side streets , good individual and stylish shops. Good choice of local restaurants. Place de vosges very nice
Great Neighborhood. Stayed in an apartment in this neighborhood. Loved being close to but out of the fray of the main tourist areas. Convenient to shops and restaurants.

The essence of vibrancy. Pink travellers aside, of which we are counted in the humber, Le Marais is a melting pot of bars, restaurants and boutiques catering for every taste, if not every pocket, as prices can be high on all fronts. Apart from these trendy considerations it's beauty derives from escaping the 19th century re-planning of Paris, so there are literally hundreds of historic buildings, many of them beautiful aristocratic townhouses. Many of these are now wonderful museums. A definite plus is Pozetto in the Rue de Roi de Sicile which with Bac a Glace serves the best ice-cream in Paris
take your time. must walk slowly to see everything-you will be pleasantly surprised by the stores,food places,and just the buildings themselves-well worth 1/2 day

A walker's heaven. Wonderful neoghborhood, with much to see and do in a small area. Especially recommend the Jewish neighborhood, the Pont Marie over the Seine to Ile St. Louis, the Shoah Memorial, the local restaurants, bakeries, shops. I stayed in an apartment here, which was a perfect location for seeing the city.

Fascinating area of Paris.. A must for all who visit Paris but get a guide to really gain an authentic knowledge of the area. Fascinating history dating back centuries to recent times. Art galleries inc Pompidou, synagogues, ornate residences of the wealthy in days gone by, interesting shops, and so much more.

Beautiful,unique marais. We have fallen in love at first glance with beautiful area of le marais.not so popular as Montmartre quartier but for sure as beautiful or even more(from my point of view).When we first laid the first step we were impressed by the uniqueness of plas de vosges and the By the bohemian atmosphere...another kind of bohemian atmosphere then in another areas similar to this in all around Europe.I can not imagine a more romantic evening stroll then in one in le marais

Great neighborhood. Paris as you would imagine it. Full of restaurants, cafes, boutiques, etc. Like a film set but with real people, eating, drinking, smoking, shopping and doing everyday stuff. After you're done with the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, D'orsay, Versaille and Galerie Lafayette, spend some time in this non-monumental but quaint and attractive Parisian neighborhood.

A great area in Paris. For convenience to major rail stations, metro, reasonable hotels and great selection of restaurants and cafes, the Marais area is hard to beat. There are also ample shops, museums and galleries hidden away in the meandering side streets.

Shop till you DROP!. So many fun cute fashionably unique and closet changing stores!!! Easy to walk around with many cafes available to stop for a break to enjoy people watching and to relax your feet or your plastic! =)

Worth a Visit. This old Jewish Quarter has been transformed into tony shops and the streets are filled with tourists, but this area is still worth a visit. Take the time to wander around, check out one of the most beautiful squares in the world, and maybe have a meal or snack.

Picked it on Purpose. This is an artsy section of the city of Paris, though I'm certain that there are many such areas. I like the tone of the place and the plethora of little restaurants populated with employed 30 somethings. We're 75, so we wished we had chosen our neighbor restaurant, BoFinger for at least one of the nights. Make reservations!!

The best little Jewish Quarter ever. If you love shops, cafes, musicians, beautiful people and old buildings and cobblestone narrow roads...then the Jewish Quarter and/or Marais is for you. Au Coton was our fave men's cotton shirts, stylish, mod and well priced.

A Sunday Must!. Take the Metro and don't get there too early - usually best after taking advantage of an early museum opening... the falafel stands are super - enjoy - but think also about that opportunity to sit and rest. Better to eat sitting down. The shops are interesting and unusual - not all are open on Sunday but more than most areas. Spend time talking to the shop owners and looking at the collections they have put together. Skip the chains... Go on to the Place des Vosges after and enjoy the park and the restaurants around it.

Visit the Jewish Quarter. Locals love Le Marais and enjoy some Jewish eateries and boutique stores. Probably the closes to the Greenwich Village Paris can offer. A must visit is a small Picasso museum.

Reminds me of strolling through Soho in NYC!!!. Great place to just explore and people watch. I stumbled onto Rue Turene and a row of shops specializing in Men's shirts. With Paris being the fashion capital of the world, I found some of the most stunning dress shirts imaginable. I wore one to work upon my return and received many gracious compliments.

Vibrant 'real' Paris. This part of Paris is bustling with life day and night. The little cafes and shops are fascinating and it is just about as convenient as you can get. Walk to the Seine in 5 to 10 minutes. Hear the church bells of Notre Dame!

Great area. This is up with St Germain as one of Paris's great walking and watching neighbourhoods; the small streets are full of interesting buildings, great cafes & lovely places like the Place des Vosges. This time the weather didn't let us sit out there, but it is still wonderfully peaceful in the middle of a capital city. Not to be missed & one day, we will make the Picasso museum -when it finally reopens...if it ever does!

Nice neighbourhood.... Le Marais is for sure one of the most interesting parts of the city.It is very busy,with lot of shops,cafes,and very touristy.You will enjoy wandering Le Marais.Try best fallafel in the city and feel real Paris...

lovely and lively neighbourhood. An absolute must. St Paul metro stop brings you to the heart of Jewish and gay Paris, with busy streets, green park to rest and great shopping streets. Always busy and bustling.

It's fun. Go to J'dus falafel. It's closed on Friday nights and Saturday. For people that keep kosher.... be aware that although there are several kosher restaurants, not all of them are. Be careful to check.

Beautiful - and free entry. This free to enter space is both beautiful on the outside and inside. We returned at night for the Gregorian Chant concert (18 euros each) which although stimulating initially at 90 minutes was just a little on the lengthy side for us and other audience members.

Excellent eclectic diverse arrondissement. Fascinating and diverse district of Paris - artisan clothes makers and designers, chocolatiers, interesting bars and bistros. Popular with Parisiennes and tourists. Close to the Seine and the Hôtel de Ville Batobus stop, walkable to lots of Paris attractions, and equally easy walk to several Metro stops. Quite gay in places, but interestingly so. Feels quite safe at all times, though not been out very late at night.

Old Paris, nice place to wander.. You wonder what you will see in Marais ? So many reasons to come here, one of the oldest streets of Paris are here, the Jewish culture neighborhood are here too. Great Falafel dishes, great restaurants, old and small streets full of charm, come here to walk around , get into stores, find bargains.........Just come !

A step away from the beaten path.. Walking from le Quartier Latin, via le Notre Dame and le centre Pompidou, you cannot but notice that at le Marais you once again see People from Paris. Wheras in the forementioned areas you se only tourist (I am not a tourist, I am a traveller). Le Marais has an abundance of shops, boutiques, bars and restaurant. You can eat world famous Kebabs in the jewish part of the area or visit one of the many gay bars.
Such character seldom found in cities today. Best neighborhood we walked thru in paris, second is st germain des pres, bring money, shops expensive, streets so nice, very turn so lovely

Definitely go on Sunday!. Everywhere else is quiet and closed but not here. Had brunch at a sidewalk cafe called le favorite and then off to Victor Hugos house for a free tour. Just walked around and bought chocolate and browsed the art etc..great day! Took the metro to get there and back and no problems.

I absolutley loved this area very modern with great little boutique shops and cafes. fantastic area to shop with heaps of boutique shops. If your into Vintage then this is the area for you. I did alot of reaseach before coming to paris on Vintage any questions ask away I'm an expert now. love this area
Busy area not to be missed. It has everything and everybody from all walks of life. This is the area to people watch. You'll be surprised at what walks by if you can tell. Very entertaining area :)

Beautiful charming quarter. Le Marais is a beautiful charming quarter with narrow and old streets, where traditional and alternative meet. Old extrordinary shops, bakeries, bookshops, giftshops, galleries...Old, amazing buildings, courtyards, small cafes and restaurants...Marais is a the same time old jewish neighbourhood and the gay friendly neighbourhood...you can see traditional jewish bakeries and other shops next to the gay and lesbian bookshops. Le Marais is a great experience.
Really great area. The Marais is a great part of Paris for history as well as shopping. It is a must visit area, IMO. Quaint streets, shops and architecture.
Breath-taking. Lots of history here. We had recently read the book Sarah's Key which took place in that part of Paris, so it took on special meaning. Tour with a guide was very helpful.

Completely gentrified .... Even the Cathedral of St. Paul has been scrubbed clean of the dirt that used to make le Marais a down-on-the-heels neighborhood. This area is now busy with trendy people dashing to and fro, rather than the simple neighborhood folk who used to walk down the streets. Several significant places in the area -- Picasso Museum, Place des Vosges, Musee Carnavalet -- make le Marais worth a day of your stay in Paris.

Do yourself a favour. We did a two hour walking tour of Le Marais. This really gives an insight into the history of Paris, from the original wall surrounding the city to the original wood buildings.If you have the time, do a guided tour of this area. You won't be disappointed.

Fun area. The Marais is a great neighborhood to stay in. I recently spent three days there and never tired of wandering around the streets. It is definately the place to be on Sunday as the shops there are open. The streets are crowded with tourists and Parisians alike. There are many sidewalk cafes and restaurants of all kinds in the area. It is very centrally located and is near several Metro stops. I will stay there again!
latin quarter. Get the best Hummus at the small bakery. Walk around the jewish quarter and visit synagoue. quite a few nice and reasonable price bistro around here too.

The place to be!. The Jewish, Gay and English area ... historically the Jewish area of Paris - more recently the Gay area of Paris ... but mostly you will hear a lot of English accents - because the Brits have invaded the Marais ... so if you like diversity and the architecture of one of the old areas of Paris - you will love the Marais. Lots of great cafes, shops and small museums dot the district. Take a Paris Walks walking tour of the Marais ... actually take two - since they offer two tours.
My favourite neighborhood in Paris. To just walk around or hand this is the place. Slower and nicer than the rest of Paris. Yes Montmartre is great but full of tourists.. this is a place to hang.
Falafel. Don't miss it. Nice neighborhood. L'as du Falafel on Rue du Rosiers st. Eat on nearby park bench.Don't miss Centre du Pompidou. More modern and great view.

Great vibes in this very special part of Paris. You can approach the Marais district from many directions. The easiest and quickest is to take the Metro to Saint-Paul. Walk down Rue de Rivoli which becomes Rue Saint-Antoine.There is a great diversity of shops and you are sure to find a number of them that you just get the urge to enter.Go down some of the side streets. There is also plenty to see there as well.There are also many places to stop and have snack and a drink.Word of warning! Watch your pockets! Pickpockets and bag-snatchers are waiting for the unwary. Crime is rife in Paris (not as bad as Marseille which is the crime capital of Europe, but not good), so protect your bag and your wallet very carefully.
Le Marais - take a walk. This lovely neighborhood has lots of interesting historical connections, being at one time a lively Jewish quartier, and today is still a great place to take a stroll!
Beautiful, trendy and Paris-y!. The only store solely dedicated to absinthe is located here. :)Other than that - trendy stores, beautiful buildings, and more.

Location, location, location. The Marais has it all. Proximity to major attractions, chic boutiques, numerous furniture, jewellery and art galleries, significant historic sites, wonderful food shops and markets, good bars and restaurants and above all, a friendly ambience. You feel welcome here as a tourist, especially in September when it is less frenetic. Apartments and hotels provide an excellent range of accommodation at all prices.

History!!. A beautiful neighborhood with a fabulously historic square. Many good small museums. Every corner had some historic reference. I ended up buying a book so I could learn more about Le Marais!
My favorite section of Paris. Really a fun and hip section of Paris. Ate the best falafel of my life! Great little boutiques and charming old buildings, crooked streets. Had a wonderful day there.
Nice shopping, charming little streets. the shops here are more unique to Paris/Europe and had fewer tourist souvenir shops. Very interesting. Highly recommend.
Great afternoon. Le Marais is just the best place to capture all the excitement of Paris. Lovely photo opportunities at every turn and a great atmosphere. shops full of interest.

Marais - the Centre of Paris. Not literally the centre of Paris, but an area which has captured many hreats for its atmospheric buildings, bistros, art galleries and outlooks. Fashionable in 1600, it fell out of fashion and became a poor district of Paris. Around 1980 it started to rise again, and now (centred on the Place des Vosges) it is again fashionable for the right reasons. I would tell anyone who asked to get a room here, and walk the streets (with your camera)..
A must see. A beautiful area to walk around and sightsee. There is a great falafel restaurant L'As du Falafel. Spend an afternoon in the Marais and you'll be glad you did.

The Marais RIPS!. And that's good! :- ) lotsa killer diller cafes, bars, shops, galleries, parks, people, kids, dogs, scooters, groove-cats, it's a place to pass through easily or lounge in comfortably. The Marais is awesome!

Funky neighborhood. Very eclectic neighbourhood,with everything from wholesale shopping to extreme haute couture, cheap ethnic dining to fine cuisine...our new favorite place to stay in Paris. Very safe to walk at night (take the obvious precautions), no problems at all.

Beautiful browsing. We had planned to visit the musee Picasso. Unfortunately it is closed for renovations until 2013! So we strolled the precinct, having a takeaway lunch from a local patisserie in Place des Voyages and wandering the streets back towards Notre Dame, via the sculptures of the Pompideu. We enjoyed quite a bit of shopping along the way! All in all, a lovely area in which to spend the day.

So Popular. You must never miss the Marais. Its colorful and old. Avoid it on Sundays since most of the shops in Paris are closed but those on the Marais are open and it gets over-crowded. Go there for lunch, go shopping and to the Picasso museum as well as the Musee Carnivalet, shop and then stay for dinner and drinks.
Lovely area. Loved this area of paris - lots of scenic little streets away from the very busy main roads. Some lovely bistros and restaurants too!

Loved it !. Great for getting lost, shopping for momentos and people watching. A real treat! I loved sitting on the plaza next to the colourful Museum and listening to live music or watching the world go by. My advice: put down the guide book and get lost, Le Marais (translated as the swamp) is one of Paris' gems.

A little yuppie-ish. I know that term yuppie is played out but I use it anyway. This is where EVERYONE wants to be. to eat, hang out and shop. Almost hard to find a place to actually eat during the day sometimes because everyone hangs here.
Ecletic!!. Good for shop and eat. Very trendy!!! any costume that you miss In lafayette or Printemps, you can find it on the main store in the Marais.
Bustling!. A stay in Le Marais, is definitely to be recommended... the beautiful Place de Voseges with the antique shops, a slice of calm in the middle of what is a vibrant and interesting quartier

A must see in Paris. Many wonderful art galleries, boutiques, and shops. Close to the Pompidou museum. The Jewish section is fascinating and be sure to get a falafel at the place with all the people and the green sign on the front.

Great place to take a walking tour on a Saturday. Went to this area on a Saturday. Lots of shops open; very busy little district. Great little cafes to sit and watch the crowds come and go. Area was clean and felt safe for walking around.
Well worth a visit. A fantastic quartier with a great atmosphere and lots of small boutique shops and an interesting Jewish quarter. If I lived in Paris I would visit as often as possible!

best walk around paris. just go there. you won't regret it.
spend 4-5 hours strolling around, making a stop every hour or so at a patisserie; have a great cup of coffee between the galleries and the little designers shops
Beautiful area. Traditional district with several old buildings. It is very beautiful to walk in the afternoon and sit in one of the many quaint cafes.
Very nice area. Whether for wandering or shopping, Le Marais with its quirky streets is ideal. If you're into making your own pieces of jewellery, I highly recommend the Matière Première shop.

The Marais, what a district to enjoy!. Been to,Paris several times when younger, always lived in Quartier Latin hotels, and private homes in 16th quartier at Trocadero with outstanding views.Now, i have discovered this fascinating quartier, full of attractions, trendy shops like "Mercy" ???Full of restaurants ,boutiques, and curio stores like in "village saint Paul".I shall definetly come back to Marais, with it's narrow streets and outstanding surprises like Place des Vosges, on a sunny day,with its garden full of young people having fun.Whatever you like , you will find in this district !
Parisian must see. Still one of the most trendy areas in Paris, great shopping and sightseeing opportunities. Once tired, time to take a break near parks

You could wander for days!. We wandered down every cute side street we saw, and there are LOTS! Great shopping, antiques, etc. and much better prices than some of the high-end areas. Also great people watching!

Meh. Friends kept telling me I would love the Marais because it was the hip part of Paris. I didn't find it that hip. Just kind of dirty. It's not as polished as many parts of Paris. There are some high end shops, but nothing that interesting.
interesting but scruffy. I like the little streets, cafes and small shops but didn't like the scruffiness of it or the beggars

Marais Museums. Visiting Paris last week I picked up a little booklet in the Petit Palais which featured about a dozen of the city's free museums. Three of them were within walking distance of the St. Paul metro station and were a real bargain. The Carnavalet,the Victor Hugo House and the Jacques Cognacq are well worth a visit, interesting buildings, some good paintings and furniture and a fascinating look at Paris past. Whilst in the area you could also visit the Shoah museum which is a sad and thought-provoking record othe holocaust. The Marais is a lovely area to wander in anyway and I much enjoyed my free day.

Great area for wandering. We were lucky to come across a market - Thursday morning - cheeses, lovely fruit and veg so stocked up for trip home. It's a great area for wandering whether it's daytime or evening.
Not to be missed!. This is a very cool neighborhood that's great for shopping and eating or just for a stroll. If you like falafel, head to Rue des Rosiers.

Imagine..... Wonderful renovations of old buildings make this former SWAMP area an elegant litlle "village" in the middle of Paris. Eat in one of the many Jewish restaurantsm window-shop the perfect lttle boutiques, take a leisurely oudoors coffee in the most avant-garde cafe you can find. Imagine you live just round the corner.
Charming area. Large and small streets filled with art galleries, cafes, bistros, charming shops. Get lost in the small alleys.

Le Marais. Beautiful old Paris neighborhood... Some great restaurants and bars.. A lot of the bars were mixed, some just gay.. We went into the Bears Den one night and went downstairs and there was Country line dance lessons going on!! What a hoot! These guys were having a great time!Another nice thing to remember is Sundays Most businesses are closed, however in the Marais youll have more shops open than elsewhere in the city

Bustle of life in Paris. We've visited this area many times before. This time, we stayed a week in its heart. Tons of activity. Endless shopping. Countless cafes. The age of the walkers seems to be getting much younger which means the future of the district will continue to be lively. We particularly love the Rosiers area with its Hebrew culture and great cafes.
Beware!. Only down point of our trip. was robbed by gypsies while sitting in an outdoor cafe. They create diversion waving paper in your face while another lifts your valuables off table.
Jewish and GAY!. Strange mix of orthodox Jewish people who were the first habitants of the Marais and a very gay gay community.
Excellent location!. It was a central location with access to everything a visitor needs -- restaurants, boulangeries, patisseries, the Metro and ATMs!

Great area to stroll, eat and shop.. Eclectic area. Lots of interesting shops and cafes. "Merci" worth going to . Interesting shop. Bohemian area. Vintage shops. Art galleries. Definitely a "Must go to" when in Paris. Great area to tour for younger generations...
Don´t miss Le Marais. Very trendy and nice spot...........you can find stores, restaurantes and cafes......a very ggod option every day specually sundays when almost all the places are closed

Le Marais, Not for Everyone!. This late summer I stayed twice in the Marais, at the beginning of a lengthy trip (mid July) and the end of same (early September) in the same place. I've stayed in this district many times over the last 25 years, a few times on my own, or with friends, my daughter, my husband. While I love the area, for its' architecture, cutural history and variety of restaurants and shops, it is not for everyone for, in my opinion, several reasons. VERY noisy almost anywhere you stay, and into the very early morning hours, because it is a real urban neighborhood and because it is full of bars and clubs that are hopping each night, late! VERY crowded especially in the evenings and nights, slowing your progress and forcing you into the streets that are often narrow and allow room for a car OR a person but not both. The gay culture is the dominant fact of life in this area and contributes to the late night bar scene which fuels the noisy atmosphere. There is a LOT of remodeling and construction going on and it begins early in the morning and closes streets, jamming car traffic, causing horns to blare and drivers to curse. On my most recent stay I found this to be more irritating and tiring than I have previoulsy which causes me to alert new travelers or even returning visitors, proceed with caution!

Best part of Paris!. The Marais is a must see part of Paris for any visitor. It is the oldest neighborhood of Paris along with being the Jewish and Gay neighborhood. Great combination! Fun bars, cafes and restaurants. Terrific shopping!

Can't Get Enough. I love the Marais. I've been coming here for the past 8 years. I have seen many changes in shops. Now it has many up-scale boutiques with pricey merchandise meant for tourist with cash to spend. However, it is funky and has it's own unique style. It doesn't shout "Paris" and for the first time visitor it can be a bit bewildering. But it lets you be you, Parisian or not. The many restaurants and shops keep you busy all day long. Sit at a cafe and watch the people go by in all sorts of garb. Go to the Rue Des Rosiers and then to the Place Des Vosges. Bobo,Bohemian,gay,straight, it is all there. See the church St. Gervais and the Jewish memorial. Check out the boulangeries and the great cheese shops and don't miss the monoprix either.
Not a secret anymore. This area is full of diversity and very enjoyable. Many, many shops and many, many people. Only problem is maybe too many people.
Charming shops and cafes.. Not the hustle and bustle of the Champs Elysee. Charming, quaint streets lined with many little shops and cafes. The place the Parisians come on Saturday and Sunday.

Lovely neighborhood, cute shops. The shops in Le Marais are very cute and unique, with items like handmade scarves and vintage handbags. Place des Vosges is also a great place to lounge on a sunny day.

Wonderful area. I was lost when searching for a hotel in Paris. SO glad I chose the Marais area. Close to all the touristy things but area didn't have a touristy feel. Lots of places to shop and eat and close to Metro. I will stay here every time I go to Paris from now on. We felt like locals and didn't feel like we were eating and shopping at tourist traps.

fascinating. Centrally located, convenient to transportation, walkable to Notre Dame and the Seine, many eating places, many small shops and just enjoyable to stroll about. For those who prefer kosher food, it is also close to or part of the Jewish area.We discovered a large green park which was established by one of the earlier King Louies sometime during the 17th century. Enclosing this park on all sides were beautiful buildings erected in the 1800's which allowed this park to become a quiet oasis in a busy city. My wife discovered that Victor Hugo also lived here during the 19th century and we went to visit his apartment which was now a small museum.--no charge for this.. . In the morning we saw the children out with their parent or nanny enjoying the park and its tranquility. Lunch time we saw many of the working folks sitting on the grass, perhaps near one of the 6? magnificent fountains and enjoying lunch. Late afternoon, the kids were out doing their fun things and early evening, it appeared that everyone was out, from the parents with children to older folks just enjoying the beauty and peace of this green respite.If we were to return to Paris, we would probably stay in this area and use the Metro and/or bus system to navigate Paris.which we did very easily during our visit.

Character, history and good food. The Marais is one of our favourite areas of Paris and we loved our wander through its quaint streets on a Saturday, especially the Rue des Rosiers with its plaques commemorating historical events and its little shops and restaurants. We enjoyed a leisurely lunch at Tresor in the peaceful and charming Rue du Tresor. Shopping is good along the Rue de Rivoli, especially at BHV dept store.

Gotta go there!. Fantastic neighbourhood of Paris. Not easy to navigate around, but the struggle is worth it. Hip restaurants with authentic French bistro food. Jewish neighbourhood, gay streets - it has it all for any traveller's interest. Very historic and great architecture.
Not a big deal. The area seemed rundown and not very safe somehow. I don't understand the attraction for it and why it's so highly rated. Almost chose a hotel there. Glad I didn't!

Rent Paris. We booked apartment with rentparis.com and it was a good experience from beggining to end. The apartment was well located and central to everything and spacious. Sure the dishwasher was crap but overall well worth the tarrif and a certain for a return visit. We really felt a part of Paris.
Trendy and tasty. L'As Du Felafel is a great place for lunch. Nice boutiques and interesting layout. Stunning architectural gems.
Got lost and loved every moment. This is a wonderful place to stroll around, window shop, drink espresso, people watch, visit galleries, etc. Paris at its best.

Interesting Area. This quartier is a very interesting one to explore. My wife and I went to this quartier to visit the Victor Hugo house, but afterward we kept walking around. There is a unique Jewish area - although quite dirty it is well worth seeing. There is also a very good museum open free of charge, just west of Victor Hugo's house.
Great Neighborhood. If you want to go shopping and want real Parisian Boutiques, this neighborhood is perfect. Nice people and Cafes line the streets.
Favorite area of Paris. Spend a few hours wandering around the Marais, one of the most beautiful areas of the city. Visit the famous falafel cafe as well!
Great Neighborhood. We loved this neighborhood, wasn't touristy at all, and had many local cafes and bar, and boutiques. It was safe and yet fun.

Remain open minded. If you like to see the extreme contrasts- Old ladies in chanel, toy doggies on pink leads on one corner and big hairy blokes in leather shorts and string vests on the other. Very great fun, enjoyable, pleasant and vibrant area to visit- just stay open minded and dont be afraid to talk to people and look at them in their eyes- you WILL have a hoot.
NOT TO MISS. to be walked and visited since the area is truly delightful...lots of shops restaurants, .museums and the gardens are incedible

Fun and lively area. Leave yourself time to walk around and see what you find on the streets of this area after you see the major sights. I happened upon a fun art gallery and came home with a small oil painting.
Marvellous Marais. We stayed 10 nights in an apartment, through Haven In Paris, brilliant area, would do over again and again
Lovely. Lovely place to walk through and shop. Grab a gelato to share as you sit in front of the fountains at the place de vosges. Enjoy a falafel at L’As du Fallafel !

A Blast from the Past!. One of my favourite areas of Paris!! So many lovely churches, the old synagogue, interesting boutiques, stores, and the Jewish Museum. We took a tour of the area with a guide and learned a great deal of Le Marais and its history.
great shopping!. It's open on Sunday so the perfect place to browse. So many interesting boutiques, well-priced, and places for a quick bite to eat. A little like Greenwich Village.

Interestingly good.. Known as the Jewish/gay area of Paris, le Marais is home to countless things to do, see, and eat. There is a great foie gras shop right next to the metro stop (Aux Ducs de Gascogne) on Rue St. Antoine. A few blocks away is L'As du Fallafel (Rue de Rosiers), where the best fallafel and shawerma is served. A couple of blocks from there is Vert d'Absinthe (Rue d'Ormessan), if you need to pick up some absinthe you just can't get in the States. Visit the Marais (I'm neither Jewish nor gay). You won't be disappointed.

Nice "small town feeling" in a big, big city. We went to Marais Sunday morning and was met by small antique shops, cafés, kebab shops and market stands. A really nice area just to walk around in for a couple of hours and soak up the feeling - of a very different type of "Paris."
Great area to visit. Go to Marais, enjoy the narrow streets and the little shops, cafes etc. Get out of the busy touristic areas of Paris and spend some time walking at Marais.

Where you can go on a quiet Sunday in Paris. When the whole city sleeps or go to church on Sunday one can walk to Le Marais and do what one does as if it were a weekday. The boutiques are wonderful full of electic stuff. I love rue Franc Bourgeois for its chic boutiques and cafes. Go to Guerlain to buy a bottle of Jicky for yourself or your wife/girlfriend; grab an ice cream at Amorino to cool off; or stock up on Kiehl's products...there are so many lovely surprises. But you can visit this area during the week too. If you like sushi, there are a number of restaurants serving lovely menu for about 22 Euros each. It is a feast!

Visit to feel like a real Parisian ... Le Marais is an amazing part of Paris with some beautiful buildings, fantastic shopping and delicious food. The area is the Jewish Quarter of Paris, and has some typically Jewish food shops and the like. However there are also some very fashionable clothes shops and more. There are gorgeous narrow streets that really make you feel like you've gone back in time.We went on a Monday afternoon and took a walking tour, which seemed like the best way to get a feel of the place. The tour took us from the Ile St Louis through Le Marais and ending up at the Bastille. At the end we headed back to our favourite part of the tour, le Marais, ate a late lunch and people-watched. As we only had a few hours to spare I didn't get the chance to go into any of the amazing looking shops which is my one regret! A re-visit to le Marais will be top on my to-do list when I am next in Paris.Tip - I've heard le Marais is a great place to visit on Sundays, as all the shops are open whereas in other parts of Paris they may not be.

Great village feel. Excellent place to get lost rambling thru the history, cares, restaurants and Places de Voges. Many other sites most tourists skip are here and just as interesting. Picasso museum still shut however til Sept 2013

A walk through old Paris. Although we had lived outside if Paris a number of years ago, we had never spent any time in Le Marais. It is nw a combination of old Parisian streets ith some lovely upscale hops. There us a wonderful falafel restaurant that is a lot f fun.
A very interesting area.. This area lived up to its expectation. We saw lots of Jewish shops and second hand clothes shops (vintage).
New little museum a must. The Museum of Jewish Art and Culture is in a beautiful old mansion and has a wonderful collection of art and artifacts. Well worth the visit.

Walk, Shop, Drink, Sleep, Eat, Party and Cruise. You can do all that here!I love this neighborhood for the culture, fashion, food and certainly the shopping and people watching.Get up early and enjoy the fresh baguette and some coffee, stroll the parks then shop a little before you have a lovely lunch at any of the bistros before you continue your adventure.The evenings you will find many bars and cafes welcoming you.It's a must go for everyone.

Beautiful. We visited the Ile de Cite and found it to be enchanting. Lots of lovely brasseries and bars to visit. We spent a wonderful evening enjoying the many bridges that lead off the island and also the lovely relaxing banks of the river. This is a must visit area of the city :o)

Boutique shops and Jewish cuisine. There are a lot of boutique shops and restaurants. Some are very touristy and some are actually quite good. I would want to return just for the famous fallafel place!
fabulous area. This is a hidden gem and there are great little bars and cafes. Its a Jewish area and theres loads of culture!!

A great Sunday wander!. This place comes alive on a Sunday with the markets and the falafels etc. The streets are closed to cars on a Sunday in this area so it makes for a nice relaxing time other than the queues in some places for the food!! Beautiful old district of Paris though and well worth a wander around! Some fab little boutique type shops too

Marvellous Marais. I always love a trip to Le Marais. I wonder round the beautiful little shops full of idiosyncratic delights from tea shops like Mariage Freres to interior design stores and niche-product shops (high street chains are banished!). I always go for supper (my favourite place I'm not going to share because it's too busy already). This time I discovered more of the Jewish quarter and ate the best pitta breads I've had so far, stuffed with falafel.
