There are two falafel shops that I'd particularly recommend and both are likely to have long, long queues outside: one is the L'As du Falafel, reputedly Paris' best; the other Mi-Va-Mi is across from it and just as delicious in my view. Even better, we sat down inside so avoided queuing.

A Great base in Paris. The Marais is a great place to base yourself for a visit to Paris as it is conveniently situated within walking or easy metro trip to most of the popular attractions that this amazing city has to offer. The Marais is also well populated with restaurants and shops to cater for most needs.Access to the River Seine and the Islands is easy and usually no more than a 10 minute walk, we stayed on Rue Sevigny near the Saint Paul Metro and had the beautiful Musee Carnavale very close by as well as the tranquil and enlightening Musee d'art et d'histoire du Judaisme which are both places well worth a visit.
Great spot. Great falafel (that was unexpected). A real buzzing place on a Sunday. Sat in Place Vosge with our falafel, a cold bottle of Sancerre and just took it all in. Worth a visit.

Charming!. Loved walking around and having falafel. Visited Place Vosge and shopped a bit. My boys also laid tefillin with the chabad guys there which was a special treat. A nice contrast to much of Paris.

Love the neighborhood!. Get your Fallafel early and enjoy the stroll on a Sunday afternoon! If you have kids, watch out for the graphic gay ads/trash from the previous night littering the road as you walk into the area from the west. The parks and shops were wonderful.
Perfect shopping in Paris. Exclusive, but also small independent shops that have a personal style. Nice restaurants. A bit hipster-ish. . :)

Shopping, Shopping, Shopping. If you like shopping.......great place to be.....all the big expensive brands......we went last weel of June and first week of July......during the 50% off everything year end sale.....great

Great place to stay. Close enough to everything, although having now waked to the Eiffel tower I wouldn't recommend doing this unless you have good walking shoes and a lot of free time! Plenty of places to eat, drink, shop, people watch. Was great on a sunday night.
fun wandering. really good second hand clothes shops, super atmospheric some spectacular little deli's amd great Jewish food.

Paris after dark - Le Marais is open!. We spent two weeks in Paris in June, 2012, and enjoyed three visits to Le Marais in the evenings. On all three occasions, we found much to like in this neighborhood of winding streets and interesting doorways. We had no trouble finding restaurants - the only problem was deciding which one to patronize! We thought that this area was much less "touristy" than other parts of Paris, so if you are looking for a quiet cafe in which to enjoy a coffee or glass of wine, here is your area. It's convenient to several Metro stops, although we enjoyed walking so much that we just strolled over - a big bonus is that many shops and eateries are open on Sundays.

Home away from home. We rent an apartment in the Marais for 6 weeks every other year. We love the winding streets, hidden gems of cafes and boutiques of every kind. My favorites are the vintage and ethnic grocers. If you are looking for the intimate, non-tourist side of Paris this is the place. Being rather centrally located this arrondissement is a great home base for the entire city.
Les Marias. Love this plan du Paris. Everything is open on Sundays and people are very friendly. A little bit of everything.

Beautiful, light environment with lots of cafes (restaurants). This was my favourite place - close to shopping, cafes, busy but beautiful streets, street performers, and the gorgeous Notre Dame. I stayed in St Germain but I should have stayed here. The Jewish quarter is here and this area is very close to the Louvre.

Fun neighborhood. I recommend walking this neighborhood using Rick Steves' walking tour as your guide. The Place de Vosges is not to be missed-- bring a book or picnic and enjoy this beautiful square. Make sure to get some falafel-- best I've ever had. Sunday afternoon is a good time to visit. Much of the neighborhood is closed on Saturday for the sabbath, as it is a predominantly Jewish neighborhood.

horrible rich ghetto. i don't know why guidebooks mention le marais' working class past as it is clearly so distant it has no bearing on the modern experience. it is a jumble of little streets full of very expensive boutique designer shops full of overpriced hand cream or hand bags. the cafes are all full of rich people enjoying their overpriced beverages.a horrible, horrible place that I will avoid on all future visits to paris as much as possible.

Wander and don't be afraid to get lost. This is the way Paris looked before Haussman. Wander around, get lost, when you need help consult a good map. There are several free museums in the Marais: Cognac Jay and Carnavalet are two that are worth a visit and also have clean restrooms. Find rue des Rosiers and buy a falafel sandwich for lunch. For a good map, I highly recommend "3 Plans par Arrondissement Paris" or Essential Paris, Three Maps by District. I purchased mine at a Monoprix store. It includes Metro Stations, Street Maps and Bus Stops--three for each of the 20 arrondissements.

A great neighborhood. A great place to stay in Paris. Kind and lots of locals in the bars and restaurants.of cool and hip not alot of tourists. We were trying to avoid the crowds and this area was great.

Love this part of the city!. Le Marais is so cool, especially if you are traveling with teenagers. My two boys loved seeing all the street entertainment, the various stores (and you know how boys hate shopping), the fantastic patisseries and the awesome restaurants (L'as du Fallafel is not to be missed if you are a falafal fan).

Interesting Neighborhood. We spent time exploring the Marais on Sunday afternoon. Many of the shops were open and of course the outdoor cafes for people watching. There were several old buildings to ogle . We spent time watching the Olympic wrap-up in French, at an open-air square with hundreds of people relaxing and picnicing. Very cool experience.
Best to visit on Sunday. Since it's the Jewish quarter it's nice to visit on sunday and have lunch. While your there, visit Musee Picasso and Place the Vosges too.

It's got it's own flavor.. We booked an apartment in the Marais and were not disappointed. We were located about 5 minutes away from the Centre Pompidou and had so much fun! You can walk to the Left Bank and we made it all the way to St.-Germain-De-Pres and back in one day. Great fun! Lots of metros and very close to Chatelet (a major metro and RER hub). Cool boutiques (Zadig & Voltaire, COS France, Lacoste, etc) and great food (pizza, falafel, upscale restaurants). Definitely spend lots of time there, and make sure to check out Rue des Rosiers, and some streetside art galleries: great fun, but watch out for pickpockets on the little streets as it does get very crowded at times.

Fantastic Location!. Best location in Paris, from my own experience and from the experiences of friends and colleagues who've been to the city several times. Far enough removed from the large tourist areas, but close enough to enjoy all of those things. More artsy crowd, and close to lots of shopping.
A Happening. This is where you want to be if you are artsy, fun and like good food. The demographics are interesting and if you hit the right streets you will love the vibe and the people.

special part of Paris. This is an excellent location for absolutely everything. Magnificent atmosphere throughout the 3 arrondissment. Great food, shopping and sights, cultural and art visits, cafes for coffee lunch or dinner.walk to nearly everywhere from Le Marais.
Marvellous Marais. We stayed in the Bastille area and we drifted around the Marais area on a traffic free Sunday. Another beautiful area in a wonderful city.

Lively and comfortable with many points of interest. Our hotel in this area was close to all transportation. The many cafes and restaurants are friendly. Many parks, shops and sites of interest. Great value.

L'As du Fallafel. Paris...le Marais...Israeli restaurant with light, savory fallafel served with 2 flavors of shredded cabbage, hummus with chopped tomatoes and cukes and a tart lemon drink....wow! Hebrew, French and Yiddish filled the air. Packed with people of such variety including men and boys of the ultra Orthodox. Flashes of a Fellini movie is another impression. Then turn a corner, another street that was different. Quiet and sober reading the two plaques on a school telling of the deportation of Jewish children and of one man who saved many others.

Great shopping & cafes!. Busy area with wonderful shopping and cafes.Check out the huge BHV department store that has lots of selection and good prices.Very noisy area so glad we did not stay in hotel here

Picnic in the Park. We visited this area specifically to shop in the marche. Among the must-sees are Victor Hugo's house. Afterwards pick-nicked in a lovely little park that contains a poignant reminder of the deportation of thousands of Jewish children by the Vichy government.

Lots better than Quartier Latin. not too touristy, plenty of bars and restaurants with a nice local feel to it.
Top tip: RENT A BIKE!! 'The metro is efficient, but Paris is better above ground.

Great area. My new favorite place in Paris. It is chock full of unusual and unique shops, no chains! The stores are charming, there are bars and restaurants everywhere, and the Jewish area has great falafel places. I had my favorite meal in one of them. Don't miss this area.

Away from the madding crowd. never having spent any length of time in Paris before I chose to stay in Le Marais as it sounded so quaint and interesting and perhaps not quite so touristy....I was certainly not disappointed. Rented a gorgeous apartment on Rue de Montmorency (through FeelParis) which was very close to Rambuteau metro and the Centre Pompidou. This area is still close to everthing (about a 30min walk to Louvre) but quaint and full of great cafes and unique shops. I also loved that I had amazing patisseries, fruit shops and delicatessans on my doorstep......nothing as nice as taking a stroll to pick up a baguette/pate and some red wine.... then enjoying it in one of the many lovely parks whilst people watching!!!!

After reading that this is the area to visit on a Sunday...we did!. Loved this area and the quirky little shops.The Place des Vosges is a beautiful square with a park, fountains and buildings with vaulted ceilings and art galleries and restaurants.Worth a visit.

Best neighborhood in Paris. This was our favorite part of Paris. This charming neighborhood has small narrow street, unique shops, several vintage stores, good restaurants and picturesque city scenery.

Step in history. Love the symmetry of place des Vosges. Love the arcade galleries. Rue des rosiers is a favorite . So many things in a small area, musee Picasso, musee carnavalet,Jewish museum,sort walk to place de la Bastille

Stylish Gayborhood, a Little Overrated. I have spent a lot of time in the Marais over the years, perhaps because I'm gay, thinking that it is an advantage to be in a place with a lot of other gay people, but my conclusion 15 years ago and my conclusion now is that the advantages aren't that apparent. Sure, you may be able to find a quiet bar here and there where you might meet someone, but I don't find the guys in Paris to be that friendly, and the "little group" mentality seems to be alive and well. I generally prefer more working-class neighborhoods; this one is chic and filled with boutiques I cannot afford and still lacks enough tantalizing restaurants for a town the size of Paris. That said, it is wonderful to walk the streets of the Marais, looking above at beautiful buildings and peering into all the unique cafes and checking out whomever happens to be there. There are also some good boulangeries here and there. I think exploring the place with someone else adds a lot of value, so if you have the chance to bring a good friend or a few others to enjoy the cafes and bars, it is a great place to spend an afternoon or evening.

Not sure what the fuss is all about. Went to Le Marais three times during my visit to Paris and can't figure out what all the fuss is about. I didn't see anything special that you don't see in other districts. The kosher bakeries are incredible that I have to say.
Always a delight to visit. Such a lovely area in Paris. Nice shops, lovely streets to stroll around. This time we discovered the lovely 'Place du Marché Ste Cathérine' just off the Rue St. Antoine.

Don't miss a visit to this area. The Marais is a cool and trendy place with superb pubs, restaurants and frequented by the locals as well as tourists. The Parisians are friendly and will talk with you if you make the effort.A must is a visit to Rue des Rosiers in the Jewish district to enjoy the fine kosher food available, as well as the best felafels and swarm as around.

Favorite place to spend the day!. We went late Sunday afternoon + evening and were surprised to find most of the shops open and full of customers. Most of the Right Bank shops are closed Sundays, but Le Marais was full of life. Great boutiques and cafes....try Globe du Marais and Mariage Freres. Great energy in this area....LOVE!

Open on Sunday! But Go Anytime.. If you've spent a Sunday in Paris - especially in August - you'd know that there ain't a lot to do in the shopping area. Almost every store we encountered elsewhere was closed.Le Marais pleasantly surprised us. Not only were the shops open, they were charming. Some fairly priced antique and vintage jewelry shops, darling boutiques with one of a kind type items, some of the usual high end up shops and several new designer boutiques. We ended up buying most of our gifts here in Le Marias. Chocolate from a little chocolatier, some unique Eiffel tour statutes, and a few other items that just had that je ne sais quoi.

A Lovely Surprise.... To be honest, the Marais was not high on our priority list during our recent trip to Paris. But right before we left the states, we decided to try and spend a little time there on one of our free afternoons. I am sooo glad we did.We started the afternoon at the astonishing Hotel de Ville, one of my favorite buildings in Paris. We explored the bustling Rue de Rivoli until arriving at Place des Vosges. We had an amazing time there watching the children play in the grass, the couples walking hand-in-hand, and just enjoying the chance to see the locals do what they do on a daily basis. We went to a wonderful little patisserie nearby and picked up some macaroons and then took them back to enjoy at the park. Hating to leave, we then headed west and just had a blast exploring the side streets with their cozy shops and cafes crowding the roads until we reached Rue Rambuteau. We headed south towards the Pompidou Center down Rue Saint-Martin and stopped into the beautiful Saint Merri church. Afterwards we continued south until we hit Rue de Rivoli and soon back to the Hotel de Ville.We had a wonderful time exploring but had simply ran out of time. I can't wait to go back because there are so many other side streets, cool shops, and classic Parisian culture we want to experience. We loved this little taste of Le Marais.

Pleasant neighborhood. We rented an apartment (v. small, 3 floors up) on a small street. Through a huge door, then through a barred gate into a central courtyard, then lotsa stairs up. Quiet, pleasant, many good bakeries & decent supermarket close, 2 blocks from the Seine.

Eclectic!. I was lucky enough to stay in this arrondisement for 3 weeks in a cozy apartment on the Rue de Rosiers. I loved this street and the shops and restaurants in the area! Primarily, Jewish, I loved eating at the Jewish boulangeries/patisseries and restaurants. The shops were quite nice, and included all price ranges. It's a unique neighborhood that I hope to stay in again next year!

Friperie Paradise. If you love vintage, go to Le Marais. Ok, I don't want to tell you which one is my favorite shop because I don't want to spoil the fun for you to hunt your favorite. But, you should go to Coiffeur Vintage at Rue de Roisiers. Most are 10 Euros. And don't forget to try the best Falafel sandwich! And a great picnic at Place des Vosges where you can get free wi-fi on the park.

This is where you should spend your Sunday!. Nothing better than walking along the narrow streets, getting a felafel and reach Places des Voges - one of the most romantic and beautiful square in Paris.The Marais is one of the few area that didn't go under the Haussmann's renovation of Paris. Today it's a trendy area, with lots of cool shops. Nearest tube is St Paul (line 1)

Boutique Stores.. start at the hotel designed by Christian Lacroix in the Marais and then wander from there. it has developed so much from 20 years ago when i lived in the neighbourhood. some god and some not so. however there are lots of boutique stores, second hand collections and neat places to visit. love it.

Fantastic for vintage clothes. Our apartment was in the Marais and I'd go back there in a flash. The area is walking distance to excellent shops, especially vintage shops (Frip) with great bargains. It also has the best boulangerie we found (Au Petit Versailles du Marais) with award winning croissants.Add to that the beautiful buildings and great restaurants and buzzing atmosphere, it's a winner.
Fun place to visit. Enjoyable walk with lots of sites to visit. Busy with tourists on Sunday. Places off the main street are more fun

BEST PLACE FOR SUNDAY. like most of the other cities you will be looking something different on sunday a paris...try marais...nice places to eat...so many colorfull people relaxing,you can enter to a coffee as ı did and enjoy unusual sunday noise .ıf you like second hand,there are shops around.if you like small boutiques,there are around.ıf you like hand made objects,you can find in this area.

A LOVELY DISTRICT. I loved my visit at Marais!There were nice small take-away restaurants with specialities from other contries ,especially Israel .Also small atelies and boutiques with nice hand made items!Very interresting
Excellent for shopping and restaurants. Le Marais is a quaint little area with lots of shops and cute restaurants. Go there to get out of the hustle and bustle of the city.
Make time for Le Marais. An area full of character, small shops and cafes - lively - a multi-ethnic part of Paris. Go the Place des Vosges with its stunning architecture and expensive restaurants.

Dripping in history and FOOD, FOOD, FOOD. Le Marais was definitely one of my best areas of Paris. In the heart of medieval Paris it was awesome walking along crooked lanes and taking in so many sights.A feast for the eyes, the old fashioned bakeries, wine shops and the Jewish Quarter. The incredible deli's (cheesecakes) and endless food. We lunched on schwarmas filled with fellafel, red cabbage, tahina and lots more. It was a taste sensation. If you visit Paris do not miss out on this area. It is a definite Must Do!

Busy but beautiful. When in Paris you must visit Le Marais area. It is so Parisian...make sure you get one of the famous Kebabs...from the corner shop the wait is worth it. Shopping there is an experience, but just relaxing having une cafe is just as good. Totally recommend.

Le Marais. Le Marais is getting a bit gentrified - chain stores taking over from the independents that made the area such a delight. The Jewish bakeries are still there and well worth a visit. The most disturbing thing I saw was a long line waiting to get into 'Breakfast in America'! As much as I love pancakes, that is NOT what I come to Paris for!
Great area!. Wonderful to walk around and enjoy the open cafes and shops. This neighborhood has a great atmosphere.

Marais a must visit. Should you be into history the Marais district is the place to visit in Paris. The quaint streets dating back to the 13th century and great atmosphere is a must.Take your time to stroll narrow streets with interesting shops, some with a Jewish flavor and plenty of cafes to sit and watch the passing traffic, all very French. There are some good places to lunch near the mechanical fountains at place Igor Stravinsky. The controversial Pompidou centre is also there.We were there on a warm sunny day and the overall atmosphere was electric. One of my favorite places in Paris to explore.The added bonus is that it is not far from Place des Vosges. We stayed in St.Lazare, near the train station and the walk only took us about 20 minutes.One word of caution, just watch the footpaths as can be tricky. I had a nasty fall on the old, uneven paths.

A different view of Paris. You have to just go and experience this historic and interesting place. We had a delightful lunch on the terrace of a Jewish deli. Food and service was excellent. People watching here is great. Probably my favorite part of my three day stay in Paris.

Perfect for time-travel. The heart of Le Marais is La Place des Vosges, closest Metro: St Paul or Bastille or Chemin Vert. Finished building by Henri IV in 1612, it will convey the 17th century atmosphere for a nice stroll.

Green and quiet. We visited Le Marais with a Discovery Walks tour, which turned out an almost private tour for us and another couple. This neighborhood is tranquil (we visited on Saturday morning) and drowning in green. It is a very nice place to get away from the busy streets of the city. Some places are still awaiting their restoration though and pose a striking contrast.

Le Marais was a disappointment. A walk through the Marais area was high on our list of priorities during our trip to Paris but we were disappointed. Maybe we did not find the best areas but it was all pretty ordinary. If you visit, make sure that you know where the best areas are.

Vibrant neighborhood in the heart of Paris. We stayed in the northern part of Le Marais during our trip and we had a great time exploring the neighborhood. Take advantage of the many wonderful restaurants, the great shopping, the Place du Temple (where there were free concerts during our stay), great bars, markets, bakeries, and etc... Truly the heart of modern Paris.

A large & varied district - worth exploring. This district lies in the north-east of Paris, between the Seine and Montmatre. It covers a large area and, like so much of Paris, is pleasantly flat and walkable. In fact we strolled round much of it and cycled other areas.There are fourteen metro stations in the Marais - from Republique towards the north and Pont Marie in the south, Bastille in the east and Hotel de Viller in the west. Take your pick and stroll around the many museums, churches, galleries and famous streets: try to visit the Jewish Quarter, Hotel de Ville, Rue de Rivoli and Place des Vosges (all towards the south) and be sure to try a falafel, an ice cream and some wine or beer from a bistro. People watching is what it's all about and can be great fun, and not too expensive.There are some very good eateries...Finklesteins & falafels in Rue des Rosiers...Robert & Louis in Rue Vielle du Temps...Cafe des Musees in Rue de Turenne all provided us with really good food...and everywhere are good bars and plenty of small shops..Do be warned though...it can become crowded in July and there are many down & outs and beggars/con artists who frequent the tourist traps. Graffiti is on the increase and not all the streets , benches & pavements are as clean as you would wish. Nevertheless, the gays are rarely evident, some of the buildings are memorable, and the locals we encountered were charming, friendly and helpful. I'm really glad we stayed in the Marais - it is an ideal base for further exploration.

Beautiful area just to wander around. Lovely walk on a Saturday full of people (also meaning ques to restaurants) and great athmosphere. Small streets for pedestrtiand and didnt feel as touristy as rest of Paris.
...atomosphere galore. The old Jewish Quarter still feartures delightful boutiques, and Judaica stores, with loads of felafel stands competing for an amaziing crowd of enthusiasts. Great fun.

Le centre de Gai Paris?. Ironically, the "gay" neighbourhood in Paris is one of the most delightfully subtle gay neighbourhoods around. It's omnipresent yet discreet.I loved sitting at the café across from the BHV department store on rue de la Verrerie and sipping a "pression" and watching the world go by.
The best shops and food. The Marais is the absolute best in all of Paris. The food is amazing. The people are friendly. The shops and boutiques are unmatched anywhere in the city. Visit the Marais!

Not only for gay people. Beautiful quarter of Paris with lots of little galleries and restaurants. Beautiful little parcs and gardens. And stop deviding the city in spots for gays, marocs, black, etc. It's a question of living together and in le Marais, they do.

I love le Marais. It's one of the most vibrant districts in Paris. I always come here for a falafel lunch at Chez Marianne on rue Hospitaliers St Gervais or a bun and coffee at the Boulangerie round the corner, where the friendly patronne will greet you in careful French. There is so much here: you can while away the hours people-watching in the Place des Vosges, browse in the marvellous Musee Carnavalet or eclectic bookshop Mona Lisait, enjoy cake and coffee in the Swedish Cultural Centre, see the Picasso Museum or Victor Hugo's house....
Stylish neighborhood. Lots of cultural attractions. Jewish delis and falafels. Just an excellent overall place to stay in Paris. Stores tend to open later in this area.

A Bit Disapointing. Perhaps we expected too much of this area from what we had read. The area was indeed quaint, but we found for the most part, the stores were targeted at the 20 something crowd, and we enjoyed the cafe's in other areas (St Germain de Pres for example) to be just as nice with more "atmosphere." They say to each his own, and while this is a pretty area, it is not somewhere we would go out of our way to visit, with so much else to see in the city.We are 50 somethings, so this mught be just the place if we were into the 20 something boutiques. The one interesting store we did find was a guy that sold keys to locks from the middle ages. Very interesting, but you had to be willing to pay 300 Euros plus to take one home.

Loved walking through the Marais. This is a fantastic neighborhood with great architecture, shops, and restaurants. Get a baquette and bring it to the Place de Vosges. You will feel like a Parisienne!

Jewish Delicacies. Our favorite place to be in Paris. We went to Sacha Finklestein to have wonderful breakfast, amazing poppy seed cake and a good cup of caffee latte. Must try the falafel on Las du Falafel.We went there during hanukah to see the street performer singing in rue de rossier. It was such a beautiful experience.
Some great cafes. This is the place to get your authentic Parisian atmosphere

One of the most atmospheric bits of Paris. I absolutely love this area. It has always been very atmospheric. Over the many years I've known it, it has become more known by tourists but it's still real. Lovely cafes and small shops too.
Best neighbourhood. We feel so welcome and local here. Highly walkable with food of every description.
Most shops are open on Sundays while others are not. I went there on a Sunday when most shops are closed. The Jewish quarters is a good place to see and visit.

Fine atmosphere in stylish Paris. Go to the Marais to discover the other Paris, quiet, stylish and beautiful. Lovely buildings, nice Rues and in the heart of it the Place des Voges, once Place Royale untill they took of the kings head at the revolution...
Lovely area. Lovely, charming area. One of my favorite neighborhoods to visit in all of Paris.

The best area to stay in Paris. Le Marais, translates literally as "the marsh" and is without a doubt the trendiest and most beautiful area of Paris.I am very biased I know but I wouldn't stay anywhere else. It is not only one of the oldest areas but a wonderfully safe area close to all attractions that can be walked easily both night and day. Predominantly gay and Jewish, there are exquisite upmarket shops, great cafes, restaurants, wonderful buildings built by the aristocracy, fine sculptured gardens and art galleries everywhere set off narrow cobblestoned streets.The centre of arrondissement 3 & 4 is the glorious Place de Vosges-Royal Square, the finest square in the whole of Paris. Hotel De Sully can be accessed from a corner of the square along with Victor Hugos house at No 6.From the Bastille ( French Revolution monument) the Opera House is worth a look for a performance and Arsenal has some excellent cruises quite cheaply priced along the Seine and River Marne with Canauxrama, just 5 mins from the monument. It is worth getting lost on foot for 4 hours in this character filled area. Rue des Rosiers is the centre of the Jewish Quarter and has some great places for a good meal while Rue St Antoine runs through the centre of the Marais and has lots of pastry shops, cheese shops, wine merchants and in general terrific shopping. An extension of Rue St Antoine is Rue de Rivoli making all attractions close on foot. (Louvre, Notre Dame etc) From Charles De Gaulle Airport take the RER train to Gare Du Nord and change to the orange line for Bastille(Direction of Place D'Italie) Tickets for the Paris Metro should be bought in groups of 10 (carnet) for E12.50. Otherwise an individual ticket costs E1.70 Don't forget to check out the Musee Picasso, Musee Carnavalet, Musee de la Chasse et de la Nature and Musee de la Poupee ( Doll Museum) All are good value.
Funky, chic, great shopping. Groovy little laneways spiral off one another... We enjoyed afternoon tea and some shopping here.
Dissapointing. Like most of Paris - Choose carefully. This once famous area has become run down and dissapointed us. Too much graffitin and loiteres with run down coffee shops is very dissapointing.

Wonderful neighborhood!. Le Marais is special in the sense that although there's no major monuments such as the Eiffel Tower or Notre Dame, etc. it still is a neighborhood that attracts millons of visitors each year. It seems to be on of those areas that has maintained "classic" Paris. The old architectural styles of the buildings, the old Jewish quarter, Place de Vosges, and the small alleyways are features of the Marais that add to its character. In addition, it has two of the best falafel shops, Chez Hanna and L'as du Falafel that are both work checking out.
Warm Wonderful Neighborhood. Great falafels, adorable shops, art galleries, just loved it.
Fun Streets. come hungry. there is lots of good stuff to eat. We really enjoyed the informality of the area.

One of best parts of Paris. The Marais part of Paris (3rd and 4th arrondisements) is quaint, hip and easy to get around. Great shopping and fantastic falafel. I highly recommend wandering around this area for several hours when in Paris.

Restaurants and shops. There are so many restaurants to choose from in this district, most of which are located on the little side streets off the Rue de Rivoli. Boutiques are dotted throughout the area, as well.

central location, pleasant neighborhood. We spent a week in Paris and rented an apartment in Le Marais. The side streets are quiet, thankfully as there is quite a nightlife in the district. The steady stream of gay bars were very full each evening and mostly concentrated on Rue de Temple and a few blocks beyond. I did dread the walk through the bars toward the end of our visit. The morning walks were much more pleasant but not much was open before 11 AM. We enjoyed the Jewish district and area closer to Place de Vosges. It was very busy on Sunday. The shopping in Marais is super great with a variety of shops. Some shops are closed on Sunday, some on Monday and others both days.
One of my favorite quarters of Paris. Lots of unique stores and delicious restaurants at an affordable price. Take a tour of this neighborhood by foot or bicycle and you'll find a lot of hidden gems.

Truly the heart of Paris!. Very lively neighborhood, lots of unique designer boutiques for clothes, accessories, home decor and art. Lovely small streets, with wonderful bistros, restaurants, cafes and pedestrian streets. Major /interesting streets: Rue des Francs Bourgeois, Rue Vieille du Temple, Rue des Archives, Rue des Rosiers, to name a few. Also small gourmet food shops on Rue de Bretagne. Must experience this part of Paris!

My husband got a boyfriend!. Lots of hot gay men to look at. Nice passive comfortable area. My husband has a certain look! shaved head and mustache.. Needless to say he got a lot of attention! nice place

Great atmosphere. As American Jews, it's always interesting to see the other Jewish communities. Althoug the Marais is a shadow of itself, it still has a great vibe to it. Lots of stores, Sephardic bakeries, delis, and synagogues in the area. Definitely worth a couple of hours for curiosity seekers. Le Marais reminds me of New York's Lower East Side.
Walk, eat and shop. Great tourist place. Lots of stores, cafes and architecture...

I've just returned from Paris.. Just returned from Patis. Again, it was wonderful. Although the weather was so unprdeditable. Sun one day and cold and rainy the next. I always stay in the Marais area at Hotel du 7th Art. I love the resturants and the shopping. The Village St. Paul is a new and growing place. It's right at Rue St. Paul and St. Antoine. The Metro is right there and on Line 1 you can go anywhere. When you get there get a "carte", 10 tickets and you will save time waiting in line each day. Although the new computer machines make getting a ticket very easy. Remember to press English on the first screen. Works great. My tips for Paris;1 - Learn the Metro before you get there. It will take you anywhere. At St. Paul metro they will give you a great metro map.2 - Learn some basic introductory French. Greet eveyone with "Bonjour" to start with and if you don't speak French, say nicely, "Parlez-vous englais?" and they will probable answer " impour" ,a little, but they will appreciate you tried. The French are very polite more than us Americans, get used to it. Enter any store or restaurant please start with "bonjour". Don't stand there telling them in English you don't speak French. They will just walk away.Their not being rude, just just don't know what your saying.3 - Lean some basic Menu items you will be interested in.4 - Walking in Paris is just wonderful. There is history everywhere. It is nice, it is clean, it is safe.5 - Get you Euro exchange in the states before you leave. Do not do exchanges at any airport.In Paris the best place is the railroad stations, "Le Gare", The locals go there.6 - If your in the Marais area them go down St Antoine to Place Bastille. Very nice.7 - Them wlak down rue Lyon down to Gare Lyon, the fabulouse train station. You've seen it in so many French movies, The great film "Le Femme Nikita" has a scene that shows the the interesting restaurant "Le Train Blue". A great place to visit. 8 - If your into French films as I am, then please visit Place Vendome, in the 1st. The Hotel Ritz and so many interesting places and stores are there. "Place Vendome" is the movie that made Catherine Deneuve a star. And check out the old movie "Hotel du Nord". The hotel is still there. Every year I have lunch there and the walk along the canal all the way back to the Marais and my hotel. I love the walk.9 - This year, in June, I visited all the places that Woody Allen used in his wonderful movie "Midnight in Paris".10 - I'm 75 years old and had terrible jet lag this year. So when you arrive, take it easy, 11 - Their restaurants are a bit different from what we americans are used to. You sit down and after a while someone might come over to serve you. You will carefully explain what you want and how you would like it cooked and the waiter will listen and bring it to you the way he thinks it should be. But it will tast great and you will enjoy it and after you will ask for a check and an hour or so later they will bring you one.12 - Paris is a wonderful place to visit. Please give yourself enough days and time to appreciate it. Don't rush around and make it all a generality. If you take your time, you might fall in love with it. I did !!
Great way to spend a Sunday afternoon!. I often stroll through. le Marais on a Sunday afternoon along with a stop at Place des Vosges
Nice little area. Worth a day to wonder around and enjoy the boutique and cute little streets.

Loved this Neighborhood. We walked around Le Marais several times during our recent trip to Paris. It is so lovely, from the amazing architecture to the Centre Pompidou. A wonderful place to walk and explore.
Le Marais. Interesting neighborhood. Many galleries. Variety of people to people watch.

Lots to see. The architecture is awesome! The shops are pricey. Great area to just walk through and tour. Tons of cafes with excellent espresso, great wine & food. Be sure to check out some of the patisseries.

Busy historic district full of easy going modern people.. We have been back on most visits to Paris but anyone in the city for even a couple of days should spend at least an hour or so taking a gentle stroll though here. Can be busy and their are some busy traffic streets but it is largely the narrow original medieval layout with some unspoilt and unchanged streets. Left to rack and ruin after the revolution it has steadily revived and may be at it's most fashionable, well maintained, interesting, vibrant, and attractive in a long time. Many attractions, not just the Place des Vosges but much else. Plenty of restaurants, cafes, bars, clubs and shops. Something for everyone.

lived here for 7 weeks. Lots to do. Much history as in all of Paris. This is the place where the beautiful people are and many gay men. This may or may not be the place for you. Up scale without being too upscale. This is the place for people with some degree of taste....if you don't have much, you may not fit in here....
While away some time. great area for watching the world pass by, lots of good resteaurants shops and local produce suppliers

free museums. It was lovely to visit the Victor Hugo house in the Place de Voges and the Carnavalet Museums both for free. We really could have spent several hours at just the Carnavalet Museum alone looking at all the furnishings and paintings with the history of Paris and the Revolution. It is like a mini Versailles. If you don't have time to visit Versailles, or if you don't want to fight the crowds; I would go to the Carnavalet. Another fun thing to do in the Marais is to go to the Enfants Rouge Market area for an ethnic lunch. The food stalls serve great, inexpensive Moroccan, Lebanese and Chinese dishes. Get there early, because locals grab the tables quickly.
FOOD. A little bit of historical Paris together with amazing Kebab shops. Get a falafel from the busiest shop, without a doubt the best in France.
Perfect place to base yourself. Restaurants, cafes, boutiques and close to major sites and metro

Good Nightlife. Many good bars and places to dance. Many of the bars are friendly even if you don't speak French. Always order wine, because I found it to be better than ordering cocktails throughout Paris.

Cute region with Must see buildings and streets. Narrow streets, beautiful architecture, galleries, boutiques, small hotels are all worthwhile to see, just walking by is a true experience, or buying an art piece or something for home decoration.
DO your homework. If you can find a local guide, this neighborhood is delightful. As in every part of this city, there's so much to be told here - find someone to walk through it with you.
Take a dance class!. Feel like a once-in-a-lifetime experience, sign up for a dance class at the centre de danse de marais.....

A lovely place. Lots of small shops, old houses, mysterious courtyards and small boutiques of designers.
Do not miss sitting in a Boulangerie for "un café et un croissant".

Nice area for a stroll. A very pretty area full of small streets with beautiful old Parisien buildings. Plenty of cafes, bars and restaurants to explore, as well as some decent shops. Gets a bit crowded on weekends but that's to be expected - it's a fun place to be whatever you feel like doing. Some beautiful gardens hidden away if you know where to look.

great with teenagers. Had an apartment for a few nights with our 2 young adult daughters. Great shopping. Nice little unique non chain shops. Kids loved the secondhand and vintage clothes shops. They found some real deals. Plenty of restaurants and interesting street activity. Walking distance to a lot of attractions.

Lovely and Lively Le Marais. Maybe it was the charming neighborhood or maybe it was the fact that my parents married there but we loved Le Marais.We spent an entire Sunday morning getting "lost" in the Marais. So much fun to explore the small streets. I plan to write separate reviews on the two restaurants we ate at but highly recommend having Sunday brunch at a kosher restaurant followed by a delicious falafel. Added plus - being filmed by a tv crew whilst eating our falafel. The Jewish Museum is nearby and well-worth a visit as is the Pompodou Centre.
nice place. just like to go heremany store there n i can try jewis food

Don't Miss Le Marais!. In our trips and longer sojourns to a Paris, we've always wanted to spend more time in this neighborhood. Recently rented an apartment on Rue Rambuteau there. The best! Street life active and genuine; Metro gets you everywhere across the city and only short walks to the all the museums, the Hotel d'Ville, Notre Dame and the Left Bank. But don't miss walking aimlessly around the Jewish Quarter, Rue de Rosiers and Place de Voges. Why one comes to Paris. . . .

Go on Sunday for a treat and for lunch. The Marais comes alive when Paris rests--the once opulent, then a slum, and again reborn area is now trendy and fun to walk through. Some of the best potato pancakes in the world, as well as other ethnic foods are found there, and are inexpensive.
My go to place on Sundays. We always visit the Marais on Sundays, when so much else is closed. Love the L'As du falaffal, the free museums, and this las time, went to Breizh Cafe crepes. Fantastic.
Great place. To eat and browse?just stroll around, sit down in one of the bars and enjoy life
Visiting Le marais. Great area with shopping and quaint streets. Be sure to visit Rue de Rosiers for the great falafel at the famous site. It is great, large and delicious.
great for the alternative lifestyle. love alternative clubs, great boutique shopping, cafes and restaurants.. this is for you.

Le Marais was the hit of our Paris visit. Luckily, someone tipped us off to this area, and it was delightful. Also, incredibly emotional because of its tragic Jewish heritage, and we were pleased to see many plaques commemmorating the many Jews from this area who lost their lives.
Great neighborhood. Great food, wonderful amenities. Great Parisian feel. Metro is very easy to find. And close to everywhere

A great, underrated neighborhood in Paris. We stayed in an apartment at Rue de Rosiers and Rue de vieille Temple. It is a great area, with lots of shopping, restaurants, and convenient to everything. Metro stops are closeby also.
Enjoyable area.. This area gets a lot of publicity. I enjoyed walking around it. I liked seeing the place where Henry II met his end, but it is not a real favorite of mine.
A lively quarter full of great restaurants. Don't miss the Place des Vosges and the wonderful and affordable Cafe Hugo.

Interesting neighborhood for walking and gawking. Watch out because the sidewalks are very narrow and the motorcyclists give the impressions that they are aiming to hit you. Some nice restaurants and museums, including the Holocaust Memorial the Carnavalet Museum and the Jewish museum in this increasingly less Jewish neighborhood. This is a good place to take a walking tour so you don't miss any of the sights while trying to avoid getting hit by motorists.
Must Stay Area of Paris. This is a must stay area. I found this even better than the french quarterI liked the area around Places Vosage
Excellent place to visit. We did a self walking tour downloaded from the net. Found the whole area charming and particularly liked the finish in Rue de Rosiers and the excellent felafal.

fascinating area. Visited the area on a Sunday full of locals having a day out and tourists filling the delightful shopping areas. Plenty of street entertainers to add to the mood, a fascinating area. How can you fault an area with at least 13 top museums and attractions, these took me more than two very enjoyable days.

A do not miss. we were there at opening time....the roses with dew drops and the sculpture in the garden, the sculptures in the house - beautiful, the Eiffel tower in the background...relaxing and peaceful

Wonderful atmosphere. There is so much to see and do, from strolling down Rue de Rosiers with its felafel shops - if the lines are too long, go around the corner to Schwartz for a deli fix. The tranquil garden of the Carnavalet was lovely, just sit on a bench and listen to the birdsong in the heart of Paris. The Place de Vosges is where families relax on the grass. The Picasso museum was closed for repairs, but there's always the Beauborg. The Shoah memorial was very moving, as were the plaques on a few schools noting that children had been deported from there. The Marais has a charm and a buzz, and great food.
Great part of Paris. It has that old world Paris feel about it and always had a welcome for our group.

After Saint Germain, my favorite part of Paris. I've visited Marais district with a guide from City Free Tour, as a part of their Marais Bastille tour. I will not go into details of the tour itself, rather I'll try to write about the area. It is, as the guide told as, next to Saint Germain and the Latin Quarter the only area of Paris that has survived the 19 century, and it is really visible. Very different from the rest of Paris, here is where you will get the most authentic experience of the parisian life. The only thing I did not like was the overwhelming crowd - it is sometimes even difficult to walk. But apart from that, a very sweet area and a must while you're in Paris.
Around the Marais. So many sights to see. Check in a guidebook for a walking tour. Also saw a Shoah (Holocaust) Memorial site that was well worth a stop - very touching.

Oy vay; such crowds!. Had to pass on a felafel because of the huge lines so we settled for Hungarian pastries and tea. Quite a buzz on a Sunday; I'd go on a weekday when the locals are working. Tons of lovely and VERY high priced clothing boutiques, a band playing, even a few stray Yeshiva bochers threading their way down Rue de Rosiers.

Bohemian and Bourgeois. They call it the "BoBo" for this reason. Came to Paris for our honeymoon stayed in a lovely apt. What a great neighborhood. Hundreds of shops and restaurants. Great walking district. Great food. Highly recommended!
The best neighborhood in Paris. This neighborhood has it all, small shops, restarants cafes and bars. Great museums and gardens.

Wish we had gone there earlier. Great area for shopping and eating........went as we had seen reviews on Trip advisor. Full of life and quite different from other parts of Paris. Probably our favourite area.
Lovelly old part of Paris. Narrow windy streets. Small shops, bars, restaurants.

Browsing and museums. Musée Carnavalet is recommended as a diversion from the retail overload outside the tranquil gardens of this museum. This gets an extra point as I was there at the right time when there was a massive night street party in different areas of the Marais ranging from French folk music to a rave near the Archives.The street party probably won't be on while you are there but it gives a good indication to the vitality and diversity in the area.

Walking tour in the marais. We took one of the discovery tours in the marais. our tour guides were very informative. It was a great way to spend the afternoon. We learned and got a much better feel of the neighborhood, that if we did it on our own. BTW, you must go to the falafel places in the marais, i believe called la falafel. YUM!!

We loved our time in Le Marais. Le Marais is a beautiful place to visit. We went to lunch in this area before we went to tour Notre Dame (which is just a short walk from Le Marais). It was so well cared for. There were cute shops, beautiful art galleries, and a variety of restaurants. We really enjoyed strolling around and exploring.

So many places to eat and things to see. Galleries, boutiques and restaurants. You could spend 2-3 days just exploring this part of Paris. No restaurant I have been to here was disappointing. The Centre Pompidou and many galleries plus the Picasso Museum will keep art lovers busy.

Find "the falafel place". A great arrondissement of Paris: fun, chic, rich in museums, sites and sounds of this great city. Avoid the high priced restaurants and find the falafel place on Rue Des Roissiers. Fantastic! Just look for the long line and don't be dismayed. It goes fast, and the only better falafel shop we've found is in Tzvat in Israel.

Relaxing romantic day spent in Marais.. Can't speak highly enough of this area. Have just spent one of the best days I can remember for a long time getting lost in the little back streets and coming across numerous cafe lined squares. A must see.

Cool. This area is very trendy and hip. It is home to both the Jewish community, and gay Paris. Apart from some ravishing architecture (La Place des Vosges), there are some quirky and delightful bar/restaurants, notably Le Petit Fer a Cheval and Le Pick Clops, both in the Rue Vieille du Temple. There's a nifty vintage clothes shop really close by too (can't remember its name). It's a short walk to the Pompidou centre, which is very lively, holds major exhibitions and houses the rather fab Georges restaurant on the top floor.

Shopping mecca!. My 21 daughter loved this area - plenty of cafes, narrow streets and boutiques galore. It is upscale, but not overly expensive. we had a great time, she got a gorgeous "French" dress.
Great browsing. Lots of smaller shops with clothes etc by local designers.

Wonderful place to get lost. We stayed in the Marais near place de voges and loved to wander down the street and just absorb the atmosphere. Loads of bars etc but we were there on 21 June when all Paris was out listening to music everywhere. Great time to visit

just walk around. The Marais is one of my favourite districts of Paris. It is older and does not have the "Grand Avenue" feel of the Houssman re-do that the rest of Paris has. Just walk around this area - which includes the gay neighbourhood and the Jewish quarter - in very close, if not overlapping vicinity. The shopping is great and there are also some wonderful restaurants - notably Le Dome du Marais - fantastic food and wonderful atmosphere.

Marais is a wonderful blend of old and new Paris. The Marais is a real Jewish quarter, a close knit community with Jewish shops, delis, bookstores, gift shops--you can buy a Mitzvah mobile. It's also the gay quarter (don't know how that works). It's also a hip trendy upscale district with terrific places to eat, shop, linger over coffee, some expensive, some surprisingly affordable. It has history out the wazoo like most of central Paris. It's also a real neighborhood where people live out their daily lives. So what's not to love? We enjoyed the little bit of time we had there. That said, next time we won't stay in a tiny garret apartment (small atelier, 99 winding wooden steps to the top).

Stayed Here and Loved it. I stayed in an apartment with family here and loved the area. It is definitely a hopping area with a lot of history. Also not nearly as much of a touristy area, so food is better and prices are pretty cheap. Great food, great people watching. What more can you ask for?
Great area. safe, fun, tons of great shops and discoveries just waiting around each corner. Love it here!!

Very interesting area. We did a Discover Walks tour of the Marais. This is a fascinating area. Our guide was extremely informative and yet very entertaining. Having the differences of the area highlighted was so interesting. A great area to explore and learn about

Great shopping district. My husband and I really enjoyed shopping here. The restaurants and bars looked great, too, although we didn't stop to enjoy that part. The Jewish quarter is right there, too, which was very interesting. Well worth an afternoon.

French character. We love visiting Le Marais. Boutiques, cafes, restaurants, and then Place des Vosges with Parisian families enjoying the cool of the evening, overlooked by Victor Hugo's home. Bring a baguette and some cheese and wine, sit on the grass, let the world look after itself for a while.
Marais. fabulous area to walk around, sites, shopping, people.

Favourite area in Paris. Winding backstreets, little shops to discover, cute bars, old mansions, boulangeries, Place de Vosges to sit and dream away in. Walk around here for 5-6 hours and never get bored. Ahh, to be back there right now...

Great place to wander and be lost. lots of great boutiques, interesting shops, near the Jewish museum, near Musee Pompidou (great comtemporary art and we saw the Matisse exhibition), lots of cafes near Hotel de Ville. Would recommend that one wanders the streets. Definitely worth getting lost.

Home base and destination in one. We rented an apartment in the Marais for a week. We could have spent our entire Paris holiday just exploring the immediate neighbourhood, and never gotten enough of it. We will do this again!
Quirky Paris. Visit this area if you do not have much time in the city. This Paris is different and quaint! And not so hilly.
Place to be on Sunday. This area is hopping on Sunday when most others are closed.
Place de Vosgues. Very nice place, with historical hotels where famous people lived, including Richelieu and Victor Hugo.
Another must see. Great area for walking and shopping. See the temple (skip the deli) and don't miss the Picasso Museum.
Very cool area!. Really nice area to walk around. Cool bars, restaurants and people.

Lots of shopping and people-watching. The Marais is your typical eclectic neighbourhood.Whether you're after the latest in fashion (from Italy, France, England), want somewhere to sit and have a drink or eat while people-watching, have a yearning to sneak a peek at some great hidden gardens, or visit some great historical sights or museums, the Marais has it all.It's probably best to find some walking maps of the area, or at least do some on-line research, otherwise you're likely to miss something important.Oh, and if you love shopping, you'll have no problem maxing out your credit cards on some must-have shirts, pants or shoes.There are a number of good cafes along rue du Temple and rue des Archives a couple of blocks up from the Hotel de Ville.Oh, and the Marais has a large nightlife - numerous (mostly gay) bars and clubs.
wonderful place to wander. you have to be in this area... cool locals, wonderful atmosphere and great architecture. definitely going to stay in this area again

Le Marais. Not to be missed on a Sunday where you can eat your heart out and enjoy the crowds and the atmosphere. Ate at Chez Marianne and it was impossibly delicious. The Jewish cake shops are to die for and gorged ourselves. An interesting area with different cultures represented and respected there. Dont forget to visit the Jewish Museum there and also the Carnavalet Museum. We also went during the week where more shops were open. It has become a trendy area and lovely boutiques abound.

Le Marais a walkers delight. Got off the St Paul metro station and started wandering down rue st Paul it is full of little shops heading towards the Seine. It doesn't matter which way you walk place is a myriad of cafes and lovely old buildings. Jewish quarter is also buzzing with falafel shops which at night attract a lot of younger set students etc. take an afternoon out of your visit to explore. Galleries abound. George's Pompidou centre quite unusual. Anne Francks gardens a must. The list is endless
This a great location.. This is the location I prefer in Paris. It's convient and interesting. Loads of apartment rentals available.

Quiet gem. This was an almost unexplored little gem during my first visit to Paris 10 years ago. Since then ofcourse, tourists have exploded on the scene so it isno longer hidden..Still worth a stroll in the morning (before it gets very crowded) and buy some of the tasty ice creams sold in this area. There is a very French quality to this area that will reel you in.
interesting. The old Jewish quarter. Full of little museums like the carnavalet. and a lot of litte artisanal shops and restaurants. A great walking area.

Beautiful quarter. Le Marais, I heard, is a gay-friendly quarter, also with a Jewish district (there are koscher bakeries and restaurants). I liked it a lot, because there are many little boutiques and shops that offer the unusual, and cute houses. In the morning the shops open only at 10 or even 11, which makes the quarter relaxing and quiet when you go there in the morning (like an antipode to the bustling city)We found a very good breakfast place: Au pain quotidien in the Rue des Archives. almost everything there is organic, and the jams and other spreads are just fantastic with nice bread.

Fun art/social scene with shops open all day Sunday. The Marais was ancient Paris's aristocratic area, then became the Jewish quarter, until World War II. This is a fashionable, colorful, artsy, fun area to visit. And almost everything is open on Sunday, unlike the rest of Paris. Start at the Place des Vosges, a lovely park filled with Sunday families and young people, and then explore the many art galleries, shops, the Hotel Carnavalet (Paris Historical Museum), and brasseries. Needing a rest, we stopped to enjoy lunch at Camille Restaurant on the rue des Francs Bourgeois. It's classic French bistro food, at a moderate price. The Marais is a wonderful place to go when you want to experience a lively and thoroughly "in-the-moment" part of Paris.
The Gay/Hip Area in Paris. Very Lively area/Gay area full of life cafes, bistros & restaurants, bars and shops. Ideal for a bit of Flanneur :-)

My home away from home. I rented an apartment in Le Marais during my eight-day stay in Paris and I adored it. More streets than you can keep track of, so if you find a shop, bakery, cafe or brasserie that you like, STOP and get your fill because you won't find it tomorrow (or even later the same day)! With basic traveler's practicality and common sense, Le Marais seemed very safe in the time period I would be out (10am - 10pm). It's a very upscale neighborhood and very busy. There are always people out and about.Chic boutiques and jewelry stores, art galleries that will take your breath away, true Parisian charm with the historic buildings, narrow streets and hustle and bustle. I couldn't have asked for more of a Parisian experience than to live in Le Marais for eight days. I missed it as soon as my airport shuttle was pulling away.

It's true, it is well worth a 2 hour visit. Last minute decision at 4 PM, took the Metro to St. Paul station on Line 1, and followed Frommer's recommended tour. St. Antoine, left on Sevigne, right on Ormison, left through square of marche catherine, right on Jarente, left on Turenne, right on Francs-Bourgeois, to Place des Voges park. Time to smell the roses. Backtrack alonf Francs-Bourgeois, left on Pavee (where we saw a 2 motor scooters accident). Right on Rosiers, where soon you are in the real Jewish quarter, yamulkas, torahs, and falafels, and all. Now, right on Vieille du Temple, left on Blancs Manteaux.You are in the thick of Marais, and you can work your way out to the St. Paul or Hotel de Ville metro station.We loved this trip - stopped for "some refreshments", and headed home.Yes, the Marais is wonderful, and worth a 2 hour visit.Maybe even a rental here the next time.

OK. Not as edgy or interesting as I'd expected. I'd heard great things about Le Marais but the real thing proved a little disappointing. It does not feel like you're in Paris - you could be anywhere in France that has narrow streets. Very little atmosphere and unfriendly, unhelpful staff in bars and restaurants. Feels like a tourist trap.

Lively and on-the-go. This is not the 'Grands Boulevards', it is a much more scaled-down arrondissement, which compensates with the locals being more friendly and the shops being more affordable. A great place to eat, shop and visit.
Great area to discover. Lovely old district, beautiful buildings. Around place de Vosage there are plenty of cafes, and galleries, you need plenty of time to discover everything.
Great relaxing area of Paris. I love the peacefulness of Place des vosges, the museum Carnavalet, the great restaurants, the history, the Victor Hugo house and the shopping.
Good feel. I wished I stayed in this part of town. The area hip, lots to explore, lots of intersting shops .....not like the department stores ... mixed crowd.

A taste of Paris of old. What a magnificent area to wander through. Cobbled streets, little shops and drowning in history. There are also modern touches with great restaurants and designer shopping. Best of both worlds. Far from the hustle and bustle of mainstream Paris city. Village like atmosphere.
Lovely area for a stroll. Very nice area to have a wander around, visit Place des Vosges. Very upmarket area.

Nice atmosphere but crowded. Avoid if you don't like crowded places because it has so many people and the streets are so tight... Also, you must be open minded cause this is the Gay's zone. But it's a really nice vibe and I think everyone must pass here at least once.

Best neighborhood in Paris. Great food, shopping, history, locals and tourists alike love it...affordable eats and small shops (few chains) as well as iconic locations like Marriage Freres tea and Place des Vosges. Metro one stations and near Ile St Louis make it ideal to access everywhere in Paris quickly. I never stay anywhere else!

Great place to get lost in. Just throw away your map and just wander in the streets around Place Vosges and Place de la Bastille. You will find quaint shops and the real essence of what quaint Paris can offer.

A wonderful neighbourhood. We had an apartment just off rue Rivoli and about two minutes from St. Paul Metro Station. It was so easy to walk to everything. I would definately stay in this neighbourhood again.
Fun. Great Food, Great Shops, SEXY Men, just overall a Fun place to be! At night all The Clubs and Bars spill into the streets and then it really gets fun!
Best falafel you'll ever eat!. Don't miss wandering around and getting falafel. The shops are great fun, very varied, and the food was inexpensive and delicious!

Loved, loved, loved this area.. As we had been to Paris two or three times before, we really wanted to focus on individual neighborhoods or districts as they are called and spend quality time in them. We were particularly taken in by the Marais district from the Place Des Vogses and Victor Hugo's residence to the eateries and boutiques. There are also other historic sites not to miss while meandering the medieval streets. Also, it is very lively at night complete with jazz clubs, bars and restaurants catering to an array of delectable cuisines. Had some fabulous falafel while there with many places serving it. There is so much character and charm in the Marais and a comfortable neighborhood feeling throughout. Additionally, there is so much more to explore from historic sites to tasting some great food.
a brilliant area. bars, restaurants, shops, calm and safe atmosphere - very bourgeois but in a good way !

Great Energy - Fabulous bakeries. We stayed 4 nights in the Marais district and loved the energy of this area. The little shops are so much fun, and lively bistro's and bakeries make this area a real delight.

Connect to Jewish culture and in every way. From the little Jewish museum which will raise a tear with pride and grief, to the bakeries and the best falafel in town, this district demands a walkabout. If you are into exploring neighborhoods, Le Marais and Monmartre are so worth it!
One of our favorite areas to explore. We loved the Marais just to walk around - many great galleries, shops and restaurants that aren't tourist traps.

Stay in Le Marais!. We've been to Paris many times and stayed either near the Champs Elysees or in St Germaine des Pres. This time we chose Le Marais just for something new, and we loved it. You get a real neighborhood feel and there many fantastic restaurants. We stayed in an apartment which allowed us to shop for food with the locals, and we found some wonderful delicacies.

One of the Best Quarters in Paris!. Best Creperies, Best Macaroons, Best Felafels!! Walk around Rue de Rosiers and then towards Rue Pavée and down to Rue Rivoli. You will find the best Felafels, macaroons, and crepes in Paris! and these streets are so incredibly beautiful. so typical Parisian.
Museums and local color. Great area to browseand spend hours at Musee Carnavalet. Go to St Paul Metro, have lunch at LE JEAN BART and just walk.

Lovely area to walk round. full of lovely little lanes with boutique shops or chocolatiers. Great place to wander around when you fancy a change from sight seeing and just want somewhere nice to walk, shop and eat.
Lovely, expensive and friendly!. This place is a beauriful mixture of several levels of Judaism and other groups, colorful, elegant, beautiful..

Not as adorable as it used to be.. I lived here for several years and now return as a tourist, but I need to find a new neighborhood. The Marais is a bit tired, run-down; there are still some good boutiques but the Marais is becoming old-fashioned. I can still find a wonderful salad, falafal, unique scarf/hat, and some beautiful buildings, but more fun, lively, charming, interesting neighborhoods can be found in the 10th and 11th.

A great district - be prepared to walk!. The Marais is one of the most fashionable and trendy districts of Paris - not nearly so posh as some areas, but filled with galleries, designer boutiques and wonderful bars and restaurants. It's a very large district spanning two arrondisement so give yourself plenty of time to stroll the main streets like Rue de Temple and the many side streets where the coolest shops are located
great food and access to everywhere!. Stayed at the beautiful Hotel La Notra Dame at 1 Quai Saint-Michel. Perfect location to shopping, food and metro! Front desk staff amazing!

Don't miss. This area has many wonderful features. See the monument on the site of the former Bastille, visit the Pompidou Centre for some extraordinary modern art and a faboulous view from up high and revel in the ambience of the Place des Vosges with its pretty park and beautiful houses.
Architecture and aura..... Just walk around the Marais, through the Place des Vosges and along the Rue des Rosiers and you'll see what I mean.
Great place to base Paris visit. The location, charm, cafes, grocery stores, easy walk to the Seine. We rented an apartment there for our family for 4 nights.
Great neighborhood for wandering. Shops of all kinds, wonderful architecture, and plenty of good restaurants.

The best district to stay in, in Paris. Beautiful historic buildings - you can spend a day just wandering around the district and marvelling at the beautiful buildings. The Rue des Rosiers in the Jewish quarter is delightful and worth a visit - lots of interesting boutiques and cafes to browse right through this gorgeous area
My favorite neighborhood in Paris.. If I were to move, I think tihs is where I wouuld like to live. Very active, young, fun, artsy, happening!

Wonderful trendy and vibrant neighborhood. It seems like every time I come to Marais, it's become trendier and trendier with more boutique stores. It's a great neighborhood to walk around in. As much of Paris, you have gorgeous architecture and buildings. But here there are no wide avenues and smaller streets. There are tons of stores here from small boutique start up brands, to designer labels/brands. There are many cafes, restaurants and bakeries much like the other neighborhoods.The crowd here tends to be much younger you will see in the rest of Paris. I'm sure the typical age of the tenant in the area runs much younger vs. other areas of the city.We had a wonderful lunch at Cafe Charlot. DEFINITELY head over to Place de Vosges park which is beautiful with 4 water fountains in each corner of the park. Plenty of benches and also grassy areas to have a picnic lunch. Also, it was nice there is free wi-fi in the park. You just have to log on to the page and sign up and you get 2 free hours. We logged on perfectly with our Ipads.There are several nice restaurants around the Park as well pretty much on all sides with a good view of the park so we'll come back here and eat at one of them. A really cool and vibrant area to walk around in.

Our favorite Parisian neighborhood. We love the small winding streets, interesting buildings, shops, cafes, the friendly, relaxed, happy ambience, the great restaurants, the overall character, the closeness to the seine

Best fellafel outside of Israel. Prepare to wait, but it is well worth it. The fellafel is perfectly crispy on the outside and perfectly tasty on the inside. The sandwich is large enough for two. A great value. The shwarma is very good as well.

More mixed, and not for the better. The Marais is now full of small stores to tempt the tourist. Some are novel, creative and interesting, but lots are not. Be prepared to wander to find the worthwhile aspects.

Place des Vosges. I was introduced to this area of Paris when I studied here. The area was named after the province that was the first to pay it's taxes and it remains a huge draw today. The food is very good surrounding the square, especially the toasted goat cheese salad at Ma Bourgogne. The Hotel Carnavalet encompasses the whole history of Paris and is a draw for historians.

Interesting and off the beaten path.... The Marais area was gorgeous... less crazy busy with tourists, more residential, terrific boutiques and shopping and bars (and gay bars). It is a lot of fun. Visit Places Des Vosges.
Great place to stay. I stayed in a flat in the Marais for a week - fantastic, authentic area and close to the sights. Great neighborhood vibe, shops and restaurants.
"Home Base". We stayed in the Maraise section for 3 nites while in Paris. Our place was close to the Metro. We felt very safe walking around at nite
What a nice quarter!. Marais is a charming quarter, really close to most of the main streets, boulevards, the river and the attractions, highly recommended!
That day. I walked the Marais the afternoon after Rabin had been killed. The silence was screaming.
You must go to the Marais district while in Paris. Excellent live band! Happy atmosphere. Colour everywhere! Beautiful young people - and not so young. A delightful place to wander and shop in.

Not My Cup of Tea. This area wasn't my cup of tea because of the smells from the food establishment, however, it's worth the walk if you have time and are over on that side of the Seine. I found it pretty dingy.
Best of the Best!. Las du falafells best restaurant in town. Any Town!
Read up and then go. Read the history of this area and then find walk, walk, walk the area. Place de Vouges is particularly charming.
Great neighborhood for fashionistas. I love the Marais, so much to explore with it's many streets to wander through and offbeat shops.

Food,fashion and museums. Go on a nice day. Plan to eat the best falafel outside of Jerusalem. Shop in the beautiful tiny jewelry stores for Paris-made unusual pieces. Go to the Carnavalet museum for a fascinating history of Paris. Enjoy the mix of chasidic Jews and fashion forward straight, gay, young and old. Sort of like Disneyland for the sophisticate. Walk slowly -it's always crowded. Enjoy.

Fun & Energetic Neighborhood. Being the original center of Paris - and the Jewish and Gay neighborhood - this area is hustling and bustling with everything fun. There are always loads of people walking in the streets - grabbing a drink or a bite to eat at the many eateries and/or shopping in the magnificent boutiques. Fleux is located in the Marais - and has the most fun and unique home goods. There are second hand stores (start with "frip") that have name brand clothes that are just a season old!

The best shopping in central Paris. The old Jewish quarter of Le Marais has a wonderful selection of good quality souvenir shops plus small boutiques - as the French call their smaller retail outlets. Prices range from reasonable to very expensive but there is something for everyone. When the shopping gets tiring try the the brassieres for lunch. For a little over €20 we had a delicious quiche accompanied by a salad of the season followed by a small dessert of chocolate mousse. Shopping continued with a visit which is a must to Place de Vogues passing more fascinating shops that sold truly different gifts if that is what you are looking for or, as in my case, a stylish jacket. When the shopping is complete spend a pleasant half hour just sitting under the perfectly manicured trees of Place de Vogues - how do they get the tops so straight all around the lovely gardens.
Great neighborhood. lots of boutiques, great people watching, central to many other parts of the right bank
cool. Nice shops, pubs and restaurant... Nice place to wander around and eat a falafel kebab

Interesting streets. This falls between the 3rd and 4th arrondisements. Nice place to imagine Paris as it was before the gigantic boulevards were put in. The narrow streets are picturesque and full of history. Explore it over a few days. The Jewish houses and stores, the quaint shops and cafes, it's got it all, plus some home-grown French shopping.

2 pairs flats ...vogue-themed michelle obama.wallet. loved the inexpensive First place we stopped. nice shops.
got lost trying to find synagogue but the NOT LISTED HERE
Museel Carnavalet- free! was about l'histoire de Paris and worth it!

Location,location,location. The Marais has it all. We stayed there for a week and will go back. There are Hip areas full of colour and life, quiet areas with parks and gardens, and any number of cafes and restaurants, mostly moderately priced. Ile de la Cite is a pleasant 10min from the heart of the Marais. We particularly enjoyed cafe Musee on R. du Turenne, the eclectic shops and eateries on R des Rosiers and adjacent R Vieille du Temple and Place de Vosgues.

Very cute neighborhood. Mainly went there to visit the old Jewish quarter (rue des Rosiers) and the Holocaust Memorial (Mémorial de la Shoah). Stop by the Jewish delicatessen shops. Have a "Mame Strudel" at Florence Florence Kahn shop -- la Gastronomie Yiddish. It was so delicious!!!!

Great for the young. We stayed in an apartment in the Marais. It's a great location, many restaurants and shops and many young people at night. I stayed near the Pompodeu. It's very easy to walk to Ile de la Cite and Notre Dame and Latin Quarter. Le Hale is virtually across the street. The Louve is a bit longer walk but doable
Lively Neighbourhood. Interesting shops, squares and a few museums. Very walkable along Rue de Rivioi and side streets. Lots of places to buy food or just look.
Great Shopping. I went shopping there. Also I couldn't find the cute little restaurant that we were recommended so we made it a day of shopping. It was great. I even bought my hubby some souvenirs.
Too tourist-popular now for five stars. Lots of interesting sites, stores, businesses, and old buildings. The best felafel I ever had. Marriage Freres tea room is one of a kind.

Marais is a good visit. The Marais district was interesting because it is so old...full of very narrow, angled streets and lots of shops of different kinds. This part of Paris wasn't bulldozed by Napoleon, and so you can see what the city looked like before its grand avenues and boulevards came into being. It was the first time that we had seen this neighborhood, and while we weren't sure that we would want to stay in this area, it was great to see it. We enjoyed the Carnavalet Museum and the Shoah as well (though it is hard to say "enjoyed" about the Shoah...more like appreciated). We would visit this area again.

It's a long way from the swamp!. The Marais used to be a swamp but it has come a long way over the centuries since then. It's now one of the most interesting districts of Paris with museums, some excellent hotels and more trendy eateries than you can poke a stick at. And you are just a short metro ride from all the major tourist attractions.
lots of restaurants/cafes. Quite a nice area of Paris with lots of eating places and streets to stroll along in the evening for a spot of window shopping.
Fun!. This is the place to stay for the happenin' local scene--tons of bars and restaurants, and even though it is the gay district, hetro couples like us felt perfectly integrated.

Tour with Reb Tom Cohen. We were extremely lucky to go on a a 3 hour walking tour with Reb Tom who is is an American who has been living in Paris for 20 years and is the Rabbi for a Liberal Congregation in Paris. The tour focused on the history of the Jewish Community in Paris. He is a wonderful person and had a deep and broad knowledge of the topic. It was a fantastic experience. I joined his congregation for services on Shabbat and it was also a wonderful experience.
A must. just being in this area is magical. Step back in time re: architecture, step into the future re: shop interiors and fashion!

If you love shopping, go there!. If you have sufficient time to explore the not-super-touristy part of Paris, I highly recommend visiting this area. As a shopaholic this is one of my favourite districts in Paris. There are a lot of independent shops that sell goods with a character. One of my favourites is an independent store owned by a stylish lady who married an Englishman (that's why we can communicate effectively). She stocks clothes designed by up-and-coming designers based in France and it's really exciting that I got myself a super cool jacket unanimously praised by friends and colleagues when I wear it in Hong Kong.Besides shopping, the neighbourhood itself is worth the visit - great restaurants & much more to see!

"A nice Sunday afternoon option". On the recommendation of a Parisian we visited this area on a Sunday afternoon. It is a quaint area with narrow streets – most without traffic, and smaller buildings. Unlike other parts of the city on Sundays, most shops are opened. There is a Jewish sector where you can buy falafel although being very popular you need to queque. It all provides a relaxed environment in which to stroll and enjoy the buildings, museums (e.g. Picasso Musuem), shops and street musicians. Also nearby is the nice square – Place des Vosges.

Love this area!. This is such a neat neighborhood and so representative of what I loved about Paris.
