There are lots of great, unique shops, the restaurant we ate at was excellent and I loved the feeling that everyone knew everyone and we were visiting their home. This is an area I'd like to spend more time in if I'm lucky enough to return to Paris someday.
A bit of all. This area has it all! Great restaurants and lots of them. Add shops of all sizes and price ranges and you can keep yourself busy for a long weekend.

Ancient Paris. All the flavors of ancient Paris had roots here. All the cache paris can pack in one arrondissement. Don't miss it and grab the hotel sale, Picasso's museum, brilliantly located in this enchanting district.

Just about the best place to wander in all Paris.. A very interesting and old part of Paris, now gentrifying like mad. The small Jewish area, a remnant of life lost long ago, was packed with people and falafel eaters, waiting in long line to sample tasty foods from exotic lands. This is a not-miss part of Paris everyone must experience.
Vibrant Area. The le Marais area is full of bars, restaurants, history. I'd recommend reading up on the area first and/or doing a self guided walking tour app (like we did)

A great neighborhood to find good food. Reasonable prices (for Paris) and very good food. I'm picky and in fact consistently frustrate my family with my claim that French food is so-so. This neighborhood may have begun to change my mind.

great walk. We walked from our hotel near the opera garnier, to this area, it is not as far as it looks on the map, when you get there, there are loads of little unique shops
and some very nice cafe's

Interesting Windows, Crowded with Tourists. I've been coming to the Marais to do research at the archives for over 20 years now. This time, everywhere I turned, all I heard was Americans. So although the Place des Vosges is lovely, and the window shopping is interesting - as it is everywhere in Paris - I wouldn't come here if you want a true Parisian experience or to feel like you're in France.
My favorite area in Paris.. This area is alive and vibrant. Make sure you eat at L'As du Falaffel.

Very nice!. I liked this part of Paris very much. It is somehow different than other parts (arrondismants), the streets are not as wide, and the buildings are not as big. However, it is packed with interesting buildings, museums, shops and cafes, each having its own story, so it is good that you come informed in advance, or have someone there to explain you to what to pay attention.There you can taste the best falafel and the best ice-cream in Paris, you can visit small museums with great collections and you can sun-bathe in some cafe. For shopping, I think it is the best in Paris, because there are many small shops that are not too crowded so you can take your time and enjoy choosing without any pressure. Very very nice place!
Great place to browse. Lots of little shops and cafes... jazz at night... great place to just window shop or find gifts... and you can catch a cab in front of BHV (Hotel de Ville) easily.
A great neighborhood.. Unfortunately I didn't have enough time to explore the 3rd & 4th district enough. On my next trip I will spend much mroe time there but the time I had was very special.

quaint place. Jewish atmospere. Nice small streets with very different shops.
Not too crowded.

LOVED IT!. The Marais is everything that Paris is! Twists and turns, full of interesting people, cafes, patisseries, boulangeries, galleries, charcuteries.....full of LIFE! I rented an apartment in the Marais, and would do so again. It's a perfect location to explore Paris by foot.
Gay Gay Gay. Great if you are gay and great if your not. If you aren't sure make sure you find out before you leave. Have a drink it loosens everything...wallet...buttons and the tongue!!
fashion at it's best. love this area. great people and shops steeped in jewish mysticism.

Favorite area in Paris. My favorite neighborhood in Paris! Lots of cool shops, boutiques, cafes and restaurants. It felt more pedestrian-friendly than Saint Germain Des Pres. It is kind of like Soho in London and NYC. Trendy stores and cool, hip crowd. Great atmosphere at restaurants and bars. It is exactly what I'm looking for when exploring new places. I found the best home decorating store in this area too, Fleux!
Lovely area to wander and shop. Le Marais is a great neighbourhood to wander the shops and stop and eat in the many cafes.

I could live here!. We stayed in a beautiful apartment in Le Marais. The lifestyle is something I could definitely get used to with lots of lovely cafes and restaurants, boutiques and patisseries. Very nice to just wander around and certainly to stay.Our apartment was in a beautiful building with a stunning courtyard and decor. The address is 16 Rue du Parc Royal 75003 ParisTake a look!
Gay neighbourhood. Lots and lots of amazing restaurants and cafes not to mention shopping!

what can i say that has not been said about the marais. Marais Marais so good they should have named it twiceits funky fun exotic stylish historic cultural vibrant tolerantpoetic musical in-captivating. Cafes bars for all tastes some really cool restaurants too, also caters for those who come aliveafter midnight clubs and bars gay or straight mix really wellClive Dublin
Stroll at leisure. We stayed in the Marais district. Great atmosphere - lovely little quirky shops and restaurants - far better than the Champs Elysee!
Interesting neighborhood for walks. Lots of small shops, boutiques, cafes, etc. Many good food options for snacks as well as for meals, drinks, coffee, etc.
To feel Paris, you have to walk it. Start here.. Love this neighbourhood. The little shops, the beautiful buildings, Pace de Vosges, just get on a good pair of shoes and enjoy it!

Marais was lovely.. Walking through this old section of Paris was excellent. Many shops, St. Paul Village was very enjoyable, and the Bakeries in the area were outstanding. The old Jewish quarters were unique.
The best area to stay in Paris. We lived in the Marais, we dined every evening in the Marais...It is simply the best area to visit and stay while visiting Paris

Jewish historic area. The Shoah Museum is there and very powerful. The street Rue de Rosiers is especially wonderful on a Sunday. There are falafel places and great Jewish bakeries as well as interesting stores.

Charming stroll.. I like to stroll through the Marais, window-shopping (okay, sometimes actually buying) and dallying at a pastry shop or cafe. It's a bit calmer than many other areas, and a tad up-scale, so don't go expected great bargains.

Le Marais. This is a wonderful neighborhood. Just a few blocks off the Seine and busy tourist scene, this neighborhood is full of specialty shops, great fashion shops and not too many chain stores. The stores are mostly all open on Sundays, and even a few are open on National Holidays like May 1. Plenty of cafes, restaurants and take away options. It's a wonderful getaway to stay here, where you feel like you are living like a Parisian. Place de Vosgue is absolutely wonderful. On Sundays, you'll see families picnicing, and there is always some type of live music going on filling the square. The surrounding buildings have a walkway under arches, and full of art galleries, a few cafes and a free museum. Wonderful place to sit and watch Paris life at its best.
Le Marais. Vogsues place is absolutelly must visit in Paris but it was little under maintennance when we visited it
A must of Sundays. A lot of nice art galleries, several worthwhile museums and interesting little shops all open Sundays. A must for a Sunday.

The oldest part of Paris given new life. I have only recently got to know this area, and I love it. There is so much history in these streets. Nowadays it has all been given a facelift which is wonderful, with smart shops, boutiques and restaurants. Yet, the atmosphere is such that I find this area of Paris to be one of my favourites now, and i feel quite at home there.
Charming. Take your time and walk threw Le Marais , starting from La Bastille and going threw le quartier Juifs, and go to Hôtel de ville de Paris
Great area. Great shopping. Individual shops. Lovely pretty streets. A wealth of very good restaurants and fabulous bars.

Interesting and atmosperic area of Paris. Staying here allowed us to visit outside the normal tourist hotspots but everything was still close to hand, including the Seine and Notre Dame etc.We tended to walk around and found places very accessible. However the area is expensive to eat out and wine in particular was a bit of a shock- nothing under 23 euros a bottle and we noticed that often couples only had a glass rather than a bottle. Full meals were the best value but we did find italian restaurants good vale. Would recommend a visit to the City museum of paris (free) and pere la Chaise cemetery.
A GREAT AREA. The Marais is a really interesting area of the city with many beautiful buildings and of course the Place des Vosges which is one of the most impressive squares in Paris.
walking, sightseeing & authentic. authentically maintained... hats off to that...well worth indulging in enjoying the beauty of the old buildings
Beautiful!. Lovely area of Paris. Cafes on every corner & fantastic shopping.
Gorgeous area!. Really nice area to wander around and take everything in. Very Parisian!
Great restaurants and shops. My favourite part of Paris; great shops and places to eat, and Place des Vosges is a lovely place to hang out.
Well worth a visit. The shops and restaurants are trendy and very good. The area is authentically maintained.

Great Place. Wonderful neighborhood of Paris. Close to everything but yet in it's own little, charming world, Between the Seine and the Bastille areas. Great shops, restaurants, flower shops, wine shops, chocolate shops, and a great place to enjoy the local life.
A great area. The Second Hand stores in this area are amazing! I got my best Italian leather bags here!

expensive and not worth all the hype. I liked the cobble stone streets and the small stores and bistros all around, very quaint, however, this area was supposed to be a gem in shopping, whereas it seemed more like an overpriced overrated tourist attraction.
Nice shopping on sundays. Roads closed for cars on sunday. All shops are open. Lots of nice and expensive shops. Nice local cafes.

Great part of Paris.. This a very interesting part of Paris and the Place de Voges is a beautiful park in the midlle of it. If you walk around the entire square you will find artists at work, gallerys, shops and very good cafes. It is a lovely way to spend a morning. The shopping in the area adjacent to the square in all the small streets is fantastic. The metro and the bus service is very quick.
Nice area. I enjoy walking around Le Marais. The cultural mix, the food, the variety of places to visit, and the easiness of access make it a worth visit.
Worth a walk around. Get out on foot and walk around, this is more of an absorbing-the-atmosphere thing than specific things to look at.

More fun. Another interesting area of Paris. Loads of good cafes, restaurants and shops. Nothing bad to say except did not have enough time to spend there. There is historical information abound for all these areas of Paris - try to check stuff out ahead of time.

Quaint Paris neighborhood. Narrow streets and quaint buildings versus the wide boulevards of Haussman redesigned Paris. Beautiful park at Place des Vosges. Rue de Rivoli has a lot of shops with high end stores and trendy fashion boutiques but more interesting getting “lost” in the smaller streets. If you’re socially conservative you might find the “Open” atmosphere a little shocking, but it’s not in anyway as sexually overt as the Pigalle area.

Fantastic neighborhood!. Get a free walking tour with Cris and Tamara from City Free Walking Tours to hear the history of those streets.It´s off the crowded touristic atractions but really deserves a deep visit.The highlight for me was the Place des Vosges.Also a good neighborhood to have a coffee in typical Parisian coffe shops with reasonable prices.Justo loved it!
Nice Neighborhood. Lovely shops and lots of cafes - very friendly people in cafes and shops.

lively. lots of bars! :D
can be a bit over-whelming with the number of streets around here, bars and shops, and everything else.
worth coming for a wander during the day before coming back in the night so you know where to go.

My favourite district in Paris. Stimulating and unique atmosphere of a historic neighbourhood with a mix of gay, yiddish and fashion-house cultures. The Place des Vosges is great for terrace-dining. Worth visiting for strolling and window-shopping on Saturday and Sunday afternoons when some of the Marais turns into a pedestrians-only zone.

one of my preferred visit in Paris. Once the jewish district of Paris and especially the oldest one, it is now one of the liveliest with everything open on sunday and the streetwalks full of young people. You can smell good odour of food and buy very trendy clothes in the same street

Sweet spot. We rented an apartment here for five weeks. The area is charming, reasonably quiet and feels safe. From here we walked every day all over Paris. Lots of bistros, grocery stores and boulangeries...everything that one might need. After visiting all of the arrondissements, we were reassured that we had made the right choice.

Le Marais - Great Central area to stay at. Well, it's long overdue. I was looking to give a review of Le Verrerrie by Paris Bestlodge at Le Marais but didnt find it as a selection last year so I didnt even try. But, researching another trip this year, I found myself reminiscing about our wonderful trip to France last year and how helpful all the reviews were. So here's my way of giving back... as late as it is. I still didnt find a section for ParisBestLodge under accomodations so this is the best section I could find.I contacted Thierry from Paris BestLodge to inquire about some of his one bedroom availabilities. I was originally looking around the 7th, but I'm so glad that we settled on 4th. It is so central and close to everything. Le Marais also has a wonderful flavor that I dont think the other arrondisements have. The restaurant selection was great and it's close to transportation.We were able to walk everywhere! We even walked to the Eiffel Tower a couple of times (once at night and once during the day). And this is with a 5 year old (not quite even). A good stroller helped so much. Dont know what we would have done had we not brought a stroller with us. She got tired from walking but the stroller helped us get around and she had no complaints. She even fell asleep a few times giving us more time to look around.I originally contacted Thierry for a different place and he offered us ParisVerrerrie. A one bedroom apartment with a sofa bed. It was perfect on the 3rd floor (no elevators though) and we loved this little quaint apartment. it had a very small kitchen that suited our needs. Dealing with Thierry was so easy. He then had us in touch with the apartment owner Eric and he was wonderful and helpful too. I had to mail a cheque for a deposit but they never cashed it. i then paid them when we met when we arrived at the apartment. They are so trustworthy.The only small issue we had with the apartment was that the hot water was a little on the sporadic side but it was not a big deal overall. Hopefully it's fixed now.Anyway, if you wanted to find a good reliable central place to rent while in Paris, I would totally recommend the 4th Arrondisement and ParisVerrie offered by ParisBestLodge at paris@parisbestlodge.com.Have fun in Paris. One of our faves is our visit to Monte Marte.

Greenwich Village in Paris. Not sure what all the hoopla about this area is, but we did walk the streets, shopped a bit, etc. Best part of our experience was dinner at a "tiny" restaurant (L'Ange 20) in the area, whch was excellent.

Great neighborhood full of food, museums, shops. Stayed in an apartment near corner of rue du Temple and rue Rambuteau. Wonderful little food shops including several always tasty bread and pastry shops. World class museums including Pompedeau, Jewish, French history, and several more.... Easy access to Latin quarter, river/islands.
Nature conspired against us in the Marais.. It poured rain while we were here so any review is really unfair. Had some nice food and wine here whilst watching the rain.
A very atmospheric district. We walked round on Sunday morning, which is a particularly good time to visit. The Place des Vosges is very attractive.Do not miss the Musee de Carnavallet.

We called it home. We rented a studio apartment in this neighborhood, in the 4th arrondisement. By the end of the 5 days, it was home. We felt like locals. Everything we needed was there: the phone place to buy a temporary SIM card, patisseries for our morning croissants, super mercat for groceries, internet cafe, laundry and millions of places to eat late dinners.The historic area is full of old world charm with tiny narrow streets and lovely buildings mixed in with trendy new boutiques and the right mix of 21st century needs. It was safe at night (although we are careful with our street smarts radar on at all times) and near the metro (#1 line for us). Athletic folks can walk to the Louvre and Notre Dame! Try to explore if you can.

It's great!. The Marais is wonderful. Eclectic, full of life, bristling with energy and home to iconic museums, restaurants, cafes and shops.
We have stayed in apartments many times in areas of this quarter and each visit I find something else to enjoy. There are mansions, families, food, alternative lifestyles and quaint streets to enjoy.
Wonderful. This neighborhood had it all -- we loved the Falafel -- Jaja restaurant --- violetteandleonie's consignment shop -- Jacques Genin chocolate and Pain de Sucre for pastries & marshmallows.

marais is a fun place to shop and sleep. We rented a flat for three weeks. We are in the Marai for the first time and we love it. far more regular folks, not as many tourist and fabulous boutiques and cafes.
Quirkey. A lovely part of Paris with lots of art, visit Place de Vosges

Great location to explore Paris!. We stayed in the Marais (rue du Temple). Easy and interesting walks to many of te major attractions. Also close to trains and buses if you want to go further afield. Many interesting shops and lots of restaurants, although we mainly ate in. We discovered the delights of Pickards freezers. Great range of frozen meals (canapés, entrees, mains, dessert). Restaurant quality food for a fraction of the cost. Outlets all over Paris. Has to be tried to be believed.
Great restaurants & shops!. Too many great places to eat, shop & see! As much as I like the Latin Quarter, the Marais was wonderful!
Very Hip. Rue Franc Bourgeois has the best small, shops and most are open on Sundays. While you're there, go to Musee Carnavalet and Musee Picasso.

Full of joie de vivre. Not at all "seedy", a wonderful area, full of excellent places to eat and unique boutiques - best visited in the early evening, just wander around to get a real flavour of the Parisienne!

Buzzing with life and creativity.. Le Marais is a lively neighborhood where people are constantly moving from shop to shop - or sipping wine at a sidewalk bistro. Close to the main attractions of Paris and full of surprises it self.

Great part of the City. Highly recmmend taking in Le Marais. It is an area people actually live in so there are shops as well as places to visit. It is also away from the man Paris areas so you do not feel as much like a tourist. Great restaurants .
fun area. This is our second time in this area because we liked it so much the first time. Good food, fun people watching and the Paris Museum was very interesting.
the Marais. love all the little independent shops and boutiques, and favourite restaurant in Place des Vosges
art and design. I loved the area. it was quiet in the morning. the shops were lovely. some building had street art on them.

Great for strolling. We actually stayed in the Le Marais for one week and enjoyed it a lot. It's a hip neighborhood mixed with old buildings, a lot of charm, small cafe's, lots of restaurants and cute side streets. Fun place to hang out in the evening hours.
Great Food. A trip to the Le Marais district is a must for good food (less expensive) and great shopping

Raidd & Le Depot. Raidd bar - nice place but overpriced and lets far too many 'straight' couples in to really call itself a gay bar.
Le Depot - great, good crowd (very few females and they are not allowed downstairs). Guys that go there know what they want and it's not difficult to get it either.
vintage shops and falafels. vintage shops here are the best i've seen around the world!!!

excellent. we took a 2.5 hour tour with Sight Seeker's Delight and walked around this lovely part of town with cobblestone streets and Jewish history. We stopped for a fabulous falaffel lunch and paid a visit to the holocaust museum which had an excellent exhibition on the history of the jews in france.

Attractions are spread out. Visited this district and 4 of its museums (Picasso, Carnevalet, Cognacq-Jay, Hugo Apartment) in 2006. Other than the museums, I found most of the Marais attractions to be a little spread out. Rue Rosiers is intense and definitely worth a visit!

Go if you have nothing else to do. We ambled outer way through this part of town, looking for something of historical significance that said WoW! But it was just a neighborhood, borderline dodgy (not as much as Montmartre of course) but full of art galleries with ugly art. Can't figure out how they stay in business. There are many boutique and cares/bistros. The outside of the Pompidou Center is in the border region of it. It is an ugly monstrosity and that is what our French friends think. We walked all the way to the Bastille monument. Rather a letdown as we say the obelisk in the traffic. All in all, nothing on the must see list although I do hear the falafel is great and probably the best thing about Le Marais.
Trendy and dynamic !. You want the latest ? the best ? the trendiest ? you'll find it in le Marais, this is also the gay quarter of Paris hence all the fashion and lastest are here !

great food, and cute shops. had excellent fallafel here on the street, and walked thru the streets and did some shopping lots to see and look at while you're walking around. Also the famous horse butcher shop sign is here on the corner of a building, now the shop sells socks!

Where to go on a Sunday. On a Sunday most of Paris closes down. They are to be admired for this. So what do you do. Well you can join the Parisians as families and couplesstroll around the Beaubourg and the Marais full of fashionable shops (most not part of a chain), a modern art museum (the Pompidou Centre) and the beautiful and tranquil Place des Vosges.

If you go to Paris make sure you go there. If you are visiting Paris, give yourself plenty of time to walk around its streets and get immersed into their life. Le Marais is my favorite area, with a great night life and a huge choice of restaurants. During the day you get to see many old places that are just hiding until you turn a corner. There are many examples of street art, ancient boutiques and narrow sidewalks that give it a unique feeling. It is also an excellent base for visiting Paris so I strongly recomment getting a hotel or apartment in this area and enjoy walking to the many attractions and walking back at night through the charming Marais.
If you like Bohemian walking areas this is for you. Cobble streets, small boutiques, great bars, just a fun area to while away a couple of hours
Special neighborhood. Depends on where you stay, but very authentic and upscale.
dont miss this fabulous area for shopping, eating, etc. loved this area of paris. Amazing boutiques, fun restaurants, tons of little places to browse. my favorite area of paris

Worth a full day to explore. Whether for the history or for the avant garde fashions displayed in store after store featuring tomorrow's top names in design, it will be dificult to pack it all in in a day. So much nicer than Les Halles or even Covent Garden

Not just for the gays. spent sooo much time in Le Marais, theres so much to see and do here , from bookstores to bistros , Fashion to Food , any just about anything else is available, great jewellry shops, a cute pet store and the most delightful bistro where we would enjoy an afternoon Ricard, a wonderful little gem of a place

Medieval Paris. The last remaining medieval neighborhood in Paris has feel all of its own. Go on a Sunday when the rest of Paris is closed and take a stroll down Rue de Rosiers. Stop in at L'As du Fallafel for lunch and don't miss Place des Vosges.

A good day's walk. This is a grand area to walk around, stopping to enjoy the architecture, the old and new boutiques, and the Jewish quarter.
The Musee Carnelevet, with free admission, is definitely worth your time.
Good just expect a lot of boutiques. If you are not into shopping and want a cultural immersion. I recommend a tour of this place versus seeing the asthetique shops.
Great shopping, great bars. Superb shopping, great falafel and great bars. A must see when in Paris. It's lively and open on a Sunday when a lot of other neighbourhoods are closed.

such a diffrent part of paris, and so beautiful. another place that can't be missed when you visit paris. the streets are beautiful, with a lot of restaurants, pastrys, and jewish bistro where you can eat the best falafel in town. perfect for a walk in the afternoon, lunch, photos. don't miss place de vosges in Marais

Our favorite spot. We took the Jewish history tour with Sight seekers delight and Karen brought us to this area. It was absolutely incredible. We walked and shopped and ate our way through this very old part of town. We even returned because there are so many little streets to discover in this area and not too many tourists are here. We loved it and will return as our first stop when we visit again.

Great place!. We stayed in an apartment in the Marais this trip to Paris. We loved the atmosphere here. Rue Rambuteau has many great shops. Go to Huré for macaroons and bread. On Rue des Rossiers try the falafels at Mi-Va-Mi. They are great. Place des Vosges on Sunday is fun. There are musicians performing around the square, and the artwork is amazing. It wouldn't be a complete trip to Paris without ice cream at Berthillon. Sit down in the restaurant for the full experience.
Just like Soho!. The Marais is Soho with history. Great shops and deep history of Paris and of the Jewish experience in the 19th century. It is teeming with life and action.
Great for a Sunday visit!. When almost nothing else is open in Paris on a Sunday, Le Marais area is definitely the place to be!

Atmospheric suburb of Paris. We came here for the vintage shops - of which there were several selling good quality, reasonably priced items - but came back for the atmosphere. Lots of interesting architecture and quirky shops, on typically Parisian narrow, winding streets.

Morning in the Marais. Visited early in the morning, no crowds. Place des Vosges peaceful, streets quiet. Able to appreciate area and see more, bit unnerved by the presence of armed police in Rue des Rosiers.

A lovely neighbourghood!. Lots of small and charming streets with both expensive boutiques and cheep second-hand shops. Plenty of small cafès and restaurants, and some great foodshops and bakeries. It is lovely to just wander around and stopping for a glass of champagne and some foie gras!
Very busy but great to stroll around. Traditional area of Paris, very busy but lots of shops and bars to wander around and plenty of 'Characters'!

Great Area, a real treat if u can book and stay around there!. It could be that Paris has so many faces and our memories about it it really depends on the area in Paris u will stay while visiting.Every time I'v visited Paris i've really enjoyed Le Marais, it's pricey indeed, expensive area with 4/5stars hotels, but within 1/2 km away of most attractions and lovely cafees. It's no need to drive to Louvre, L'Ile de Cite, Pompidou Ctre etc so treat yourself!

Walking through the Marais!. I walked for hours through the Marais and then found my self quite easily walking to the garden at the Palais Royale from here. The shopping, especially for food, is wonderful!
Cool place to walk. Walked around this cool part of Paris, stopping in cafes and cakeshops to re-fuel.

Great Neighborhood to Discover by Tour!. Marais goes by many names: the gay section, the Jewish section, the trendy section, the historic section (the Bastille was located here). Fascinating to take a tour here-recommend Discover Walks (free) or City Free Walks. Many private gardens and courtyards to discover. Also home to bobo (bourgeois bohemian) vintage clothing stores.
cute neighborhood. walked over here for some shopping, cafes and to see the park near victor hugo's house. very cute area
Great atmosphere. Every time we visit Paris we stop and explore the Marais. le Gay Choc is a fab bakery well worth visiting
HIP HIP MARAIS..... we spent a super day wandering this beautiful area. There were no crowds and the sun was shining, absolute heaven.

Lovely quarter of Paris. Intriguing back-streets with unique shops, falafel bars and the tranquil Place des Vosges. Take time out to relax in the sunshine over a glass of wine and soak up the atmosphere. Try L'As du Falafel for a street snack.

My favourite area in Paris. Lovely little area for shopping. Lots of standalone boutiques with unique offerings, from fashion to accessories (bags, shoes) to pastries. Come here if you're a fan of French brands like APC, Paul & Joe, Isabel Marant. There is also a tiny shop selling vintage Chanel bags and accessories that I always make it a point to visit when I'm in the area. Don't forget to check out concept store Merci too, where you can find designer stock priced down as well as their own in-house designs, cafes, furnishing and discounted Anick Goutal perfumes.
Great. Neighborhood. Stayed in an apartment just off Beaumarchais. Lots of cafes. Seemed safe to walk.

If Paris was the Mona Lisa, The Marais is her smile. The Marais is one of the most charming areas of Paris. As you turn every corner you find more delightful shops and beautiful photo opportunities. Wonderful fois gras shops, cheese shops and bakeries line every street. The street on which the St Paul metro lies could fascinate anyone for hours. However, as you venture deeper into the Marais you realize why the Marais is so greatly enjoyed by many. Chez Julien is a great restaurant to have a leisurely lunch. Years ago it was a bakery, although it has been converted into a fabulous restaurant with a great view to people watch.

You can find it all here! Something for everyone!. When you arrive in the Marais you do know you are in a different section of Paris! It is quaint and filled with history and details beyond the guide books. There are chocolate shops, chickens roasting to be taken home for dinner, bakeries, and all kinds of speciality shops. Alot of them are right by the St Paul metro station. But you need to go further into this neighborhood and you should do it with a pro. Try Richard Nahem "Eye Prefer Paris Tours". He is just perfect for this arrondissement! You will get to go to the best of the Marais, those little shops that have been around for years where you can sample some of their specialities. Talk to the owners and have them recommend the best of what they have to offer. He gives you history with an entertaining touch! No boredom here. This is also a fabulous place to find those presents to bring home! You can walk most of the Marais it is not as big as it looks on the maps. Make sure you allow time to stop for lunch, there are so many restaurants with so much charm, and good food too, of course!
Shopping was really not that good. Smelled like pee and the shopping was just bog standard "hip" french brands. We expected this to be the soho of Paris. It wasn't.
Great to walk Le Marias. Follow the crowds in the Marias and try to find the market courtyards, the old medieval wall of Paris and Place des Vosges.
Eh, maybe I missed the hype. Everyone loves it, maybe I missed those cute streets.

This is THE place to stay or visit if you come to Paris. The streets are narrow and full of character. We stayed in a flat that, I kid you not, was near 4 different bakeries within a 30 second walking distance from us. There are plenty of things to see here and eat.Check out the vintage shops scattered around the Marais. Or if you can't handle wearing used clothing, there are plenty of independent boutiques in the neighborhood.Don't miss Rue de Rosiers, there are at least 3 different falafel shops there and they are all very good and inexpensive.Ahhh, I'm still remembering our nap on the grass in Place des Vosges. Its a lovely square where you can have a picnic and people watch or just take a nap. The Marais is also near Notre Dame and the Seine, so make sure to take a stroll there as well.Just "Google" Marais and you will know why the Marais is a must visit in Paris.Paris, we will be back.
The Soho of Paris. This is a great casual area filled with boutiques, pastry shops, beautiful winding old streets, galleries, and cafes.
Charming and interesting warren of streets, shops and cafes. Small, individual shops, historic, and open Sunday's and at times when the rest of Paris is closed.

Loved Le Marais. We stayed here in May 2011, loved the area, felt safe, easy to get around, heaps of great cafes (and cheap) Loved the middle eastern food . On Sunday the streets are cloed off to cars and there a bands and the shops are all open. Great shopping and good markets. Loved it!

Wonderful neighborhood, but overrun with homeless and druggies. This should be one of the most charming areas in all of Paris, but there are homeless (men, primarily) sleeping on the streets, defecating and urinating all over the streets and sidewalks. While in a grocery, a disheveled 40ish man who appeared to be under the influence loudly complained about having to wait 4 people in line. The staff ran around front to staff another register, whereupon it became apparent he did not have the money for his purchase. Ordinarily, I would step up and volunteer a few pence to help a guy out, but he was so loud and obnoxious, openly challenging shoppers in the queue to give him the money. The cashier nodded to security, who escorted him out quickly, but as a tourist with a child, I found the incident disconcerting.

Fun lively district with good eats and shopping. Le Marais is a great little area with some excellent little bars, cafes and restaurants and a bunch of good clothes boutiques, if that's your thing. Apparently it is a jewish and gay area and it certainly has a vibrant, arty, bohemian feel. It is also quite centrally located in the 3rd arr. so is well worth spending some time wandering around.

great for aimless wandering - fab photo opps too. I first came to the Marais when visiting the Picasso museum and have been back on each subsequent Paris visit (9 so far). I just love wandering the streets which fortunately survived most of Haussman's demolishions. There are also lots of museums in the area, good eating places and fab shops. I found one called Hetoroclite which if you like lagenlook womens clothing is a total treasure trove!

Visit the "Jewish Quarter" on Sunday. The vitality changes on Sunday afternoon when the streets are filled with young and old lining up for felafel and pastries, socializing and shopping after the sabbath.
2 days in Paris. beautiful architecture, very lively, lots of "hotels particuliers" with gardens, little "squares" scattered in the area.

Great area to stay. I rented an apartment in the Marais for a week. It is safe and a great neighborhood. There are alot of charming boutiques, markets and cafes. You can walk to many places from this location.

High Energy!. This is a high energy neighborhood of Paris. The Marais (translated to "the swamp") was once the place of outcasts, but has since become a trendy place for up-and-coming young adults. The Marais boasts good food, good shopping, markets, and an overall contemporary feeling.
Beautiful area but crowded. I liked the Place de Voges but the rest was so crowded that I lost interest.

interesting neighborhood. Great place to check out on a Sunday when so many places are closed in other areas. (we weren't the only ones with this idea though, can't imagine how crowded it would be during tourist season) Interesting shops, restaurants, etc, historic sights of interest.
If you're looking for quaint, old Paris, skip it. Found it to be a very hectic shopping area. No old world charm.
Fun place. The Marais has a mixture of pretty buildings and cool shops. I didnt really go into any old buildings there but we walked around and sat in a very peaceful park. Very nice.
Great Place. This is my favourite nighbourhood in Paris. A lot of boutiques and restaurants - and great people watching!

An area that must be seen. This is a quaint section of Paris with mueums (Picasso is closed for renovation), shops, cafes, and wonderful Jewish history. There is a highly moving Shoah museum with a wall of names, listing the names and dates that the French Jews were killed during the time of the Nazis. On one of the schools is a plaque acknowledging the French role in complying with the Nazis in killing the children. There are many kosher stores, stores selling Judaica and small synagogues that are open to the public. Now a thriving gay community, this is a must see for all. I enjoyed it so much, I will go back later today.
good day and night. very special during the day -restaurants /art /stores /museums and at night goods bars -shows and all that good you want .I like there and always go to place des vosges too
No complaints. A nice neighborhood, decent restaurants, friendly service. Enjoyed the Cuban restaurant (I forget the name) in the area, on the corner. Lots of little grocery shops.

Very nice!. If you want to catch the real Paris of today, it is the place to be. Gay quarter but also artistic one, it is where you can have fun in friendly bars, and walk in the little streets of jewish quarter.

Very interesting, but much to see, and you have to be patient!. Le Marais is comprised of many different things, and many different types of people. The mix is vast, and one has to spend several days exploring the overall area to understand it. Le Marais is "not" just in the 3rd eme; it is also in the 4th. From art galleries and the Picasso Museum (currently under major renovation) to campy wholesale cheap luggage stores to good restaurants on Place des Vosges to crappy restaurants all over the area to fabulous Middle-Eastern cuisine at Chez Marianne on Rue des Rosiers to wild and crazy gays to conservative gays and conservative straights, and on and on and on, "take your time" or you won't be in a position to form an informed opinion!
Multicultural!. We stayed here a few years ago- found eateries were quite reasonable and multicultural. Lots of designers, quirky shops.It is probably more to the younger traveller's taste.
Le Marais. Charming area to browse cafes, streets and people watching.
Trendy area with plenty of Bars and Restaurants. lots of small side streets with bars and restaurants, especially the gai moulin

Interesting place and people. Very busy at the weekend but well worth a visit. Streets are lined with interesting shops with hebrew notices and artefacts. Stop at any of the many fallafel shops/delis for a delicious snack/meal.

Over run with all the usual high street shops. Once upon a time the Maris had character. Now there are all the usual French high street shops and other high end brand shops. There are a few places with character but not many. We explored the whole area too.It,s worth visiting the Musee Picasso and Chez Marrianne for lunch, but it is really a walk through between Bastille and Hotel de Ville.

Hidden secret of Paris. Le Marais is a hidden gem in the heart of Paris. If you are done with the most famous sights of Paris, then take some time to walk around in this wonderful medieval part of the city.Being saved from the city reconstruction projects of the 19th century, Le Marais kept its flair from the old times.Don't miss Place des Vosgues, where once Victor Hugo or Richelieu lived and is nowdays the place for art galleries.
Interesting area; lots of little shops/cafes. glimpse of old Jewish tradition. Just stroll about and explore; St paul village is nice; Place des Vosges is beautiful - Jewish temple/Maison Victor Hugo

Lovely little streets and certainly the best falafel carts!. I just love walking around the Marai! The twisty winding streets always seem so new and undiscovered! I find the best falafel sold from a window for just 5 Euros! A must try!!!

Elegant neighbourhood for local shopping. Great little area to shop at local boutiques. Absolutely loved the stores here away from the major chains you can find elsewhere. Would recommend to those who dislike stuffy malls and mainstream shops!
Restaurant Chez Julien. Very quaint and french, not a tourist restaurant. Prices quite high, but hey it is Paris, we have been twice now and will go back.

A great place for walking. I can't say much about a whole area of Paris that isn't very general. What I like the best about the Marais is the atmosphere, the small streets and shops, the best falafel I've ever had, sitting in a cafe overlooking the Place de Vosges, the Musee Carnavalet (which is free and a fascinating place for learning about the history of Paris), the market on Saturday morning, and the ease with which you can walk to the Marais from other areas.

Love the Area. Le Marais is a great area to walk around and enjoy the scene. Fun shopping esp around Rue Rivoli. Cute cafe's. Its a jewish and gay area so a lot of jewish food influence and very artsy area. def fun to walk around.

The most beautifull neighborhood in Paris!. Every time me and my wife visit Paris we spend at least one day at the Marais. The atmosphere ,the people , the shops and restaurants are really fun. Don't miss!!

A Potpourri of Paris.. From the outset, I admit I am biassed so I must declare my love for this little corner of the world. The last time we were in Paris we stayed in an apartment close to Gare St. Paul. It was a great decision because we were close to everything we wanted to see. The location was truly perfect as we were right in the midst of all the action. And what action it was! Because the Marais is a micrososm of everything Parisian, you could highlight a hundred or more things. For me, I loved the cultural diversity of the people. At the Marais, you will encounter businessmen, bohemians, people from the Jewish quarter, entertainers, crazy people, colourful restaurants, gay bars and lots of young people. The Marais has a 24/7 liveliness, it is so busy and entertaining. It has its share of museums and historic sites if that is what you want. However if you are interested in the day to day French lifestyle and you like people watching, the Marais is definitely the place for you.Tip: If you have a lot of luggage like we did, getting a cab to CDG can be a tricky business. We discovered a large taxi rank right outside St Paul Station. To our pleasant surprise, the fare for the maxi-cab was the same as for a smaller cab, Only 35 euros! .

Walk like a Parisian. Escape many of the tourists clogging the 8th and 9th and lead to the Marais. It's full of lively streets and cafes where you can watch the Parisian world drift by while sipping a local wine. It's also the place for boys who like boys.
locely quirky shops. loads fo interesting stores in this area and a great great creperie- crepe suzette!
Love this area. It is a wonerful area, with lots of character. Plan to visit when you are in Paris.

Paris on a human scale. Small medieval streets, high quality shops (no chains), very relaxed and ‘bohemian’. A real ‘must see’ even for first time visitors. Don’t miss the nice gardens of the public archives (Hôtel de Soubise), the Jewish quarter, the Picasso museum and the place des Vosges. On your way back, the Rue Rivoli has plenty of gourmet shops.
Interesting and romantic!. Ideal for a romantic walk, very nice shops and bistrots.You just can't miss it!
Old quarter. The atmosphere in the early morning, Place de Vosges. Museum Carnavalet.

A stroll through Le Marais. We enjoyed our walk around Le Marais and found a large outdoor market where we had lunch and took in the sights and the people there. We'd go back to this spot if we return to Paris.

Great Shopping and Strolling. Take the Metro to the Bastille stop. Stroll the small streets of Le Marias and enjoy high style shopping with the locals. Many lovely small boutiques and shops. Be advised - we did not see ANY public restrooms. The Starbucks across from the St. Paul's Metro sight was a life saver.

the area to visit on a sunday in Paris. Whiel visiting Paris you will see that most stores are close don sunday. if you want to avoid the overcrowded Champs Elysees you should go to the Marais. it's a very charming area with great stores and restaurants. Don't miss la Place des Vosges

Full of Life. Took a stroll through the 3rd arr. with my wife on a Sunday afternoon. Highly recommend a stroll down Rue de Vieille Temple and Rue du Rosiers on a Sunday. The streets were full of people, the shops were great and there are plenty of cafes. The last time we were in Paris (3 yrs ago) we ate lunch at Robert et Louise which was recommended by some locals. We loved it then but were not able to this time around:-(
Wonderful place to walk through. Spent a few hours walking around the Marais on our last day in Paris. It is truly something to see. It is well worth the walk!!

the real paris. walking around Le Marais on a sunday morning trying to catch timid rays of sun and munching on some croissants is for me the definition of a parisian weekend escapade and no other setting can do what le Marais does to your psyche, if you haven't seen Le Marais then you should add it to your bucket list
Definitely worth visit. The most parisian area in all Paris, full of shops, cool restaurants and markets.

Special neighborhood to savor. The Marais is just plain special. Wonderful architecture, small and cozy atmosphere, full of colors, sights and smells. It is wonderful to just stroll and get lost in this rich district. Sundays are especially fun when the rest of Paris is buttoned-up but the Marais is thriving. Bigger crowds on Sundays but with a fun and vibrant feeling. Can't wait to return.
Rather shabby. Huge amount of graffiti generally in Paris with seemingly no attempt to stop or remove it.. Le Marais is handy for the Seine and good Metro connections.

My all time favourite area to stay. Paris is such a strollable city and this area is a perfect base from which to embark upon walking / metro excursions. Intriguing area, loaded with history. Place des Vosges is a favourite haunt.

The very hearth of Paris. From St. Paul along Rue de Rivoli, going to the Hotel de Ville, the very hearth of Paris beats and stretches along its streets, the Jew district with its typical shops, the Museum of Carnavalet, and one of the most beautiful jewel of this enchanting city, Place de Vosges, with a lot of Cafes, art galleries and a doucer
Sundays!. When everything in Paris is closed on Sundays, go to Le Marais because shops are still open! Lots of young folk!

Boutique stores, galleries and Cafes. Within minutes walk from the City Town Hall, Le Marais is has an eclectic mix of cafes, stores and boutique hotels, many gay bars and restaurants are to be found also in this area.
I love the boutique art stores, I have bought some great small pieces here and some really special little restaurants, well worth a walk around.

The old Jewish section of Paris, the Marais. With its remnants of old Jewish businesses and synagogues, the Marais is a lively and funky area of narrow streets that are filled with interesting boutiques, a few big name designers, some restaurants serving excellent falafel (there's a huge lunch time waiting line to both eat in or takeaway) and is fun to walk around. There is a moving Shoah Museum that opened in the mid-90's and it is well worth a visit for the way it is laid out and the honesty with which information is presented.
a walk. Great neighborhood just to walk around. Many museums/parks that are less crowded.

Hard to find something to not like in the Marais. I stay in the Marais on almost every trip. Usually I stayed in the section in the 4th arrondissement, this time I had an apartment for two months in the 3rd near Rue de Bretagne. There are a lot of smaller hip restos in this area that are just for locals like Taqueria Candelaria and Mme. Shawn Thai. The oldest market in Paris, Les Enfants Rouge has a lot of small great places to grab a warm plate of organic chicken couscous, artisanal breads, French, Italian or Japanese food where you can eat at tables in the outdoor courtyard. It's March and it's packed with tourists mostly in the 4th arrondissement section but up in the 3rd there's room to breathe.
Lovely little place. Visited here as a number of people said we should go, and it was a great area with shops and cafes!
A must do on Sunday. Great place to spend a Sunday afternoon while many of the other shops in Paris are closed

Up. Try the Promenade Plantee which starts near the Opera Bastille for a walk up near the roofs of Paris. It's a long, thin garden of a walk a mile long built on top of an old viaduct. On the way back look in at the fantastic workshops built into the arches below.

small shops and great restaurants!. That's what you can find in the Marais! This quartier has some of the most trendy shops of the capital, it is also known as the gay quartier. Very lively, shops and restaurants, and bistros stay open late and has great foods.

Attracts the young crowd nowadays. I have been to Paris several times in my life and I have seen the Marais change from a cold and slightly abandoned neighbourhood to a place for the 'in crowd'. It's nice though, with lots of boutiques and lovely restaurants. The best thing, there are still the real french cafés too, generally overlooked by tourists, where one can order a 'petit serré' (watch it, you Starbucks lovers, here's some really strong stuff !) and just sit for hours reading a gazette or a nice book.

In a city of great neighborhoods, this is one of the best. L'as Du Fallafel, Place des Vosges, shopping, vibe...it's all here. Take the Metro line #1 to ST PAUL stop. Head up Rue des Rosiers and explore all around from there.

Best area to walk around. There is nice terrasse and beautiful cafe. Price are typically a little high and the food average but the narrow street are probably one of the nicest and relaxing place to have a drink, lunch or diner.

maybe the best area in paris!. Hi there!I’m addicted to the place as ..was living here for more or less twelve years near Place des Vosges and have been living in many places in Paris& around and can say..THAT IS AS FAR AS I4M CONCERNED THE BEST PLACE TO BETop restaurants & top bars & top designers shops & great and easy area with a very romantic atmosphere and eclectic indeed!you will love this area near the Bastille too but much more" hype " here!Great to go around the rue des francs bourgeois and take time to see all about the architecture which is remarkable& museums as the Picasso'sone & coffees & restaurant .all is perfect there!AND IN THE MUST DO..PLACE DES VOSGES!!Cheers! Oliver Behar from Marrakech.
Sunday in Le Marais. Loved the marais, buzzing on a Sunday.Grab a falafel, bottle of wine, cheese and a pastry and have a little picnic in place de Vosges.Good boutique shops
A well hidden oasis.. Quiet,calm and interesting. pleasant just to roam around without any hassle.
Sundays. A great area to visit on a sunday when much of central Paris is closed down. A real buzz to the place
Great meandering and shopping. Loved shopping in the Marais. Great concept stores. Reminded me of Soho in NYC but with much more character.

Great ethnic restaurants, reasonably priced. We walked around Le Marais and found many ethnic restaurants here that we reasonably priced. We enjoyed this neighborhood and will return to further explore.
Wonderful Neighborhood!. Wonderful neighborhood with lots of great places to eat.

What is the big deal about this district?. I hear all the time the the Marais is so worth it and very shi shi and fancy. I do not find this to be true. There may be some shi shi stores and new designers, but it's not a pleasure to walk through this area with its narrow sidewalks and lots of traffic. I hear the hype and get confused that maybe I am not in the right part of the Marais, but I walked through it twice this time and didn't love it.

Enjoy this wander around the old Paris streets. Take time to wander around this area, the classic Parisien architecture alone makes for great viewing, the wonderful Place de Vosges and some great shops and cafes to boot!

the coolest part of paris. great for gay, lesbian and straight bars, excellent restaurants and always up and coming fashion designer boutiques scattered across the neighbourhood. The new emerging part is between rue charlot and rue vielle du temple from metro st paul up towards republique
Wish I had more time here. Great shops and restaurants and wonderful for people watching.
Trendy and fashion. If you want to see what the modern Paris is all about you need to take a look at the marais, good restaurants and bars and a very exciting gay scene

A lovely area. Great to have a walk around.
If you're there take the time to pop into the interesting shops and take advantage of the great lunch menus offered whilst people watching.

Trendy location. One of my favourite suburbs in Paris - as its not to touristic you can experience real parisian life with all the charming cafes. The cobblestone streets are very historical and charming. Le Marais became very arty and trendy with lots at galleries and funky boutiques and its a short walk to Louvre, Notre dame Hotel du Ville and other great spots.
Weird and wonderful mix. From the Orthodox Jews (eat at L'As du Falafal) to the Gay mix, this trendy and fun neighborhood has something for everyone. Stroll, shop, eat, and enjoy!

Dynamic area and joyful melting pot. I had the opportunity to enjoy a walk in le marais during my trip in Paris and as i've had read a lot about the neighbourhood, i had an idea of what to expect. I was not disappointed and especially because there's just a lot to see there ! Restaurants, little boutiques, art galleries ... so many things and so many people also

A real neighborhood in central Paris. Plus the only place open on Sundays. Go! Eat great falafels. Shop interesting small boutiques. Take a break at great little cafes. And enjoy the real "Gay" Paris!

A beautiful place for a walk. There are many interesting sights to see, but in the early evening rush hour time, it is fascinating to people watch and enjoy the flow of the place. You'll be surprised by what you will find just roaming around, such as the interesting Jewish quarter. Be sure to circumnavigate the Place Des Vosges. The area has numerous shops and museums such as the Hotel Carnavalet (Museum of Paris) and the Hotel Sale (Picasso Museum). Le Marais is definitely worth the visit.

A bit of 'old Paris'. Atmospheric area of the city which houses both the Jewish community and a fair proportion of Arabs as well, and there is not a hint of trouble. Some delightful back streets and a lovely vegetarian Arabic restaurant whose name totally escapes me, but it had a red canopy outside (which probably doesn't help much!).The peaceful Place des Voges is in the area, which I would recommend for some Parisian people watching, or just a quiet spot to take in the surroundings.Certainly one of my favourite areas of this amazing city.
Great neighborhood to explore. This is a charming neighborhood with lots of retaurants, boutiques, and beautiful architecture.

Paris Walks - guided tour of the Marais. Excellent guided walk around the area, with much historical detail and a very knowledgeable and pleasant guide. So good we went on the Montmatre one the next day.

Amazing district. Fantastic part of Paris. Most shops open on a Sunday. You must sample some Falafel from one of the Kosher Jewish Falafel cafes. You can eat in or out. The cafe with the yellow facade is 5 euros for a take out vegetarian falafel. Lovely little independent jewellery stores.

great place to rent an apartment. we are staying in the area for a month and living like true parisians. great place to rent an apartment....you can always go out and find something to do....sundays is very popular here for "window licking" what they call window shopping.
le Marais : you'll find every things!. It's impossible to describe the Marais : you have just to go there, also on sunday and walk, look around, smell the air....you'll love it!
Live!. Shops, art galleries, fashion boutiques, rabines, families and bars...all mixed in one place but still under a relaxing vibe. the best place to eat and sleep

Wonderful seafood restuarant.. Outstanding fresh, diverse menu. real french recipes. (fish mousse with baby crawfish in lobster sauce was intriguing). very French, moderately expensive. Good for a business dinner.

Foodies wonderland. Brilliant is not a strong enough word to describe the area, loving our food allowed us to indulge, there is just so much to see and try and the other great thing waas the people watching, we just loved all of the atmosphere

Still worth it.... Though now super-crowded, both with tourists and all the same shops you find everywhere else in the world, it's still beautiful, quirky, interesting and you will always stumble upon something that takes your breath away.

paris as paris should stay. in this arrondissent you will feel paris as paris was, is and will stay. on a saturday you will experience the sabbath which is quite special, because many jewish shops will be closed.
Lovely area to walk around and soak up the atmosphere. Place de Vosges is gorgeous and the Musee de Carnavalet is lovely

Le Marais- a Must See, but on a Sunday!. Le Marais is a beautiful section of Paris, known for its Jewish Quarter. The best time to visit is on a Sunday when many Frenchman and their families visit, when the shops are open and the area is very colorful. There are at least 5 falafel stands to choose from for a quick lunch and delicious bakeries in the area. My daughter and I enjoyed the most delicious "moon" cake (which is made of poppy seeds) at one of these bakeries on the Rue de Rosiers, the main street in the Marais. Nearby is the Place des Vosges, a lovely park surrounded by art galleries. Also the museum dedicated to the victims of the Holocaust is in the Marais and has free admission. Do not pass up on visiting the Marais section of Paris.
get lost in this area.. This is a great area to take a walking tour or just wander down small streets and get lost.
What a neighborhood.. You'll find nice shops here as well as important museums (Picasso).

Great area for shopping, dinning, art and people watching.. One of my favorite areas of Paris. Some of the best shops and cafes are here. Some sections can be touristy (but high-end touristy, no fanny-packs here) but overall it's a great area to walk around and spend the day.There are many independent shops, trendy brand stores and art galleries in the area. Hip cafes and good restaurants are easy to find.The North tends to be more artsy and independent, while the South part of the Marias has more chain and brand stores. There is a small Jewish area around the Southern-Central section and the Western-Southern end is the gay village.

NIce neighborhood, good stores and museums. I went to the Marais Neighborhood on two occasions – the first was for dinner and to see the Pompidou Center, and the second was for shopping and visiting the Carnavalet Museum and Victor Hugo’s house. I started at the Bastille (and learned more about Bastille Day at the Carnavalet Museum). There are numerous restaurants in the neighborhood, and lots of small boutiques and great up-scale art galleries. The streets are very narrow and cobblestone. Place des Vosges attracted many students and mothers walking their babies. Very important while in France – watch out for dog poop on the sidewalks! It doesn’t appear that there is a leash law in France, nor a law about cleaning up after your pet…and the French pet owners don’t seem to care where their dogs go or who steps in it!
Make sure to go to Carettes. Fantastic little cafe, on the square. Lots of great little shops. Best atmosphere in Paris
so much history. saw a house that was the smallest house there. had lunch in a bistro with a girl i met thru the owner of my hotel. quaint shops although expensive...a dog toy was 15e!
Different.... Always nice, streets full of shops...A little place to discover in Paris
Cool neighborhood. The place to be on Sunday. Have a falafel, browse the vintage stores and other hip boutiques in the neighborhood.

a lovely town within Paris. a nice combination of old-and-new.
Jewish shops, gay comunity, fashion and design.
excellent walk for an afternoon can be combined with the close place de Vosges.
Looking even better now that it's gentrifying. An eclectic collection of shops, bars and restaurants, go on Saturday afternoon and enjoy the views.
Lovely neighbourhood. I did some shopping here, primarily I was there to visit COS and Karen Millen. It didn't have the huge tourist crowds, which was lovely. It all felt more french.
Best shopping in Paris!. I loved this area. They have the cutest boutiques and the best shopping in Paris. You will definitely find items you will not see anywhere else in the world...
Great for strolling through. Nice neighbourhood with a lot of character and charm. Perfect for strolling through on a nice sunny day.
Atmospheric.... a wonderfully atmospheric area of Paris, with great old shops, squares and little places to eat and drink - fashionable, quirky and endlessly interesting...

Why have I waited to explore this area?. Having lived these six weeks on the Saint Louis Island, I have had the opportunity to explore the Marais. i had no idea that I would like it as much as I love the 6th arrondisement. Shopping, food, galleries await. Sundays are fun as many places in other areas are closed.

Lively. Wonderful part of the city to wander and many places of interest to explore. (Note that the Picasso Museum is closed until early 2013, though.) Handy for Notre Dame and the islands, the Left Bank, Musee Carnavalet and with the Louvre not much further away - within 10 minutes walking distance. If you like shopping and eating the Marais has plenty of opportunities for both.

Marais -my favourite neighbourhood in Paris. Marais is great - it's an outstanding mixture of nice restaurants, cafes, fashionable boutiques, Jewish restaurants, narrow streets and even some medieval houses stil in good shape and, above all, don't miss Place des Vosges when you are in Paris ! Marais is full of flavour and character - really enjoyable!

Paris' Vibrant Neighbourhood. Amazing at night - inspiring in the early morning as Paris awakens. A surprise around every corner. The quintessential Paris neighbourhood experience. Take some time and get lost amongst the wonder...
Great place to explore. Go on a weekend day and explore. Great shopping and patisseries - and wine.

a must see visit when in Paris. As one can wonder old medieval, Renaissance and XVIIIth century Paris at its best with its unique stately palaces (hôtels particuliers, i.e. the city palaces where the French gentry used to live untill 1750 when in Paris, before it left later for the River Seine Left Bank). The former Jewish area is also worth the visit, especialy on a sunday when it is very lively and the Place des Vosges, Paris most magnificent square, together with Place de la Concorde ends a fascinating visit back in history and great art

Saint Paul, Le Marais. I just love the Marais! I recommend not only to visit La Place des Voges, also make a walk around it. Saint Paul I right there and has excellent galleries, stores, and bistros...
love it. we spent hours walking around le marais, don't miss Place des Voges, one of my favorite, Victor Hugo Museum, and Paris History at canavalet

The Marais, the best neighborhood in Paris. We stayed in a small flat at a reasonable price in the Marais. But the best was the neighborhood. Small shops and great places to eat. I imagine where ever you stay in Paris you might feel the same, but I can't imagine staying in Montemartre. The prices are higher there and you have to climb the hill every night to get home. And Ile Saint Louis is too secluded, lacking the joy of life found in the Marais.
My Fav Neighborhood in Paris. I love the shopping here and this neighborhood is chocked full of history.

La Place des Vosges dans le Marais. When in Paris you shoud go and visit "Le Marais" and the Beautiful Place des Vosges - where Victor Hugo lived - - it is one of the favorite Quartier des Gays " - many nice Art Galery - small restaurants and clubs-
Fun but crowded. A must in Paris, for the food, people watching, and graffiti, but beware of the crowds.

Every corner is a surprise. Le Marais is filled with buzz and vibrancy quite unlike any other arrondisement in Paris. For a tourist, I would recommend giving yourself a day to just get lost in the Marais. Turn a corner and you will spot some interesting shop fronts/stores/galleries (where some hardly have anyone in them and you wonder how they earn their keep) and if your budget allows for it, you'll definitely find something interesting (a vintage Chanel, one of a kind piece of clothing by an up and coming/aspiring French designer etc). There are good/decent restaurants too (Glou, Grazie, Breizh's Cafe, Candeleria etc).

The best place to stay. For the past few years my husband and I have holidayed in the Marais. At a very reasonable rate, we rent an apartment and it's a great place to be for a little while, if you can't afford to live in Paris permanently. We are surrounded by wonderful patisseries, restaurants, bars and clothes shops. We shop in the local supermarket and twice a week at the open air market at the Bastille. Most Parisians shop daily and many food shops in the Marais are open until late at night (about 10pm). We have wandered through the Place des Vosges and visited all the meandering streets behind it but we have also walked as far afield as the Sorbonne on the Left Bank, Ile St Louis and the Champs Elysees via the Trocadero. Walking, after all, is a wonderful justification for eating all of those scrumptious pastries.

Multi-layered humanity and great shopping. Visit this quarter for people watching, shopping eating and experience the continuation of the orthodox Jewish community going about their historic traditions without letting the twenty-first century get in their way. Experience the multitude of hip and groovy eating places and shops, and of course the Place des Voges.

Crowded but cool. Between the Rue des Rosiers and the Place des Vosges, so much hipness packed into such a small and historical area, with so many hip people to enjoy it with.... While it is a little sad that the traditional flavor of the neighborhood has disappeared, what has replaced it has its own charms - especially if you like to do urban chic shopping.

Le Marais. We visited on a Sunday to experience the Jewish sections of the quarter. The Jewish museum is awesome, as is the La Victoire Synagogue, whose interior takes the breath away. Crowds of Pariesians waalk the strees of the Marais on Sunday, and the restaurants are filled. And the street entertainers! Even a Russian orchestra.
Coolest part of Paris. best shops, most interesting history and street layout. Place de Vosge is a must. Great place to wander for an entire day
Edgy and full of character. Loved the small boutiques and the Mariage Freres tea house.

Teen shopping & accessories tour. Emmanuelle of Not A Tourist Destination was our guide for a private 3 hour shopping tour. She asked my 14 year old daughter questions about what she liked and what she was looking for, then showed us a good variety -- popular French teen stores or departments in larger stores, boutiques that specialize in "used" clothing worn once for model photo shoots, and great shoe shops. She recommended many things that fit my daughter's style and were in her price range - we did pass on the glitzy beret though! She aso gave advice where to eat and places to shop later. Perfect tour for a teenage girl and her mom.
Hidden gem. Small shops, delightful atmosphere. Not many tourists on Sunday morning. Interesting architecture.
fun neighborhood. must have the fallafal.Also has nice stores to shop in.

My favourite area in Paris. Small, cute, special, personal, full of colors, Paris into Paris, this is what the Marais represents for me. You can sit in a chair, drinking a te and looking at all kind of people passing around. Enjoy this moment! After that, have a walk in the little stress which made this place so famous and smell the amazing air Paris has!
Best neighborhood in Paris. I strongly recommend doing every last bit of the walk outlined in the green Michelin guide to Paris. It is so much fun and so interesting!

hidden Jem of Paris. Not many people know about this place and I think that's half of what makes it so nice. It isn't covered in tourist like Le Champs Elysse and the stores have things most people can actually buy instead of pricy designer stores. You can actually get an idea of what it is like to be French here.

Fun to explore.. Must do. Explore many boutiques, hidden residences, bakeries, restaurants, ancient churches, cobblestone streets. Spend several hours wandering and you"ll forget where you actually are! A true gem!

My favourite place in Paris. The wonderful little winding streets will entertain you by just searching for what you may find as a little treasure. Some great little restaurants in this area. Make sure you get to the old ancient square in the middle for a wonderful walk through the gardens
so quaint. This was the cutest place with wonderful shops and cafes and of course Christian Louboitin.
must visit. The history and the character that this place has, is what makes it stand out amongst it's peers. While there dont miss to have the most awesome falafel ever
Shopping.... Just wonderful, no cars, great shopping, great food !!

Very fun place to wander. My girlfriend and I spent an afternoon here just wandering around. There was a great atmosphere here, with all the little shops and cafes you will not run out of things to do. The layout of the streets and impressive style of buildings will keep you entertained. We had a great time shopping and snacking on little treats we found a long the way. This is a great place to find any souvenirs you'd like to bring home for yourself or loved ones. Be sure to leave yourself at least a few hours to enjoy the area.

Past Midnight. A wonderful evening with friends starting with Margaritas in La Perla, strolling through busy streets to a small neighborhood restaurant for dinner and ending around midnight over a bottle of wine in a Chilean bar close to the Bastille. This area is bustling, friendly and low key - a contrast to some of the snobby areas of Paris.

Beautiful Neighborhood. We visited the Carnavalet Museum and walked around the area. The area is very clean and there are many restaurants and boutiques. The Picasso Museum is nearby. The area is very elegant and wonderful to explore.
rich in history and quaintness. just a wonderful area of paris to get lost in. so many shops and interesting places to see. a must if you want to try a falafel sandwich!

Un must pour le dimanche !. Certainement un des meilleurs endroits pour passer un agréable dimanche à Paris. De nombreuses boutiques ouvertes, le centre Beaubourg à visiter, cafés et restaurants à volonté, ...
Great for shoppers. Spectacular shopping area. You should not miss this area as so much to look at.I am a sewing teacher and I gained heaps of inspiration from the elegant clothing shops.

Very nice place to walk around and eat. Very pleasant place to walk around. Try the small streets, so you can find really nice gardens that you can seat and rest a little.You can find many types of food there, but the best option is the "Falafel", a traditional mediterranean meal. It's good, big and with a very good price (5 euros - August 2011, for a traditional one).The Victor Hugo's house is in this neighborhood and it's free to visit, so it worth going there to take a look!
Something new around every turn. Great area of the city. Never know what you find down the little streets.
Fun area. A fun area to explore, old narrow streets, great value for lunch at L'as de Falafel
Amazing Area. The people, atmosphere, Jewish Quarter, great little bistros, fab boutiques and the overall edgy creativity in the air
Our favorite Neighborhood in Paris. We love this area and all the little shops and restaurants. It always seemed to be the section of town we most wanted to return to for dinner and a stroll.
The bohemia that the 5e was once. Fantastic vibe, bars, cafes, boutiques. The juxtaposition of orthodox Jews and Gay Paree living in harmony is delightfull.

Hip, trendy, local. Actually, I think Republic is becoming more local and more trendy these days. But Le Marais is one part of Paris that has always made me feel more at home compared to the more tourist savory Champs-E.
the most beutifull district of paris. cobblestoned,narrow streets and shops,fancy bars,cafe,old narrow streets with old sighns and suprb walking with window shoppings
Marais District. A hidden gem - a friend told me of it and we walked through it all. Very nice. Locals, streets beautiful. Worth the trip.

Just wander and enjoy. Smashing place to simply wander about for a day Place Des Vosges is very picturesque and we also visited the Museum of the History of Paris (sorry can't remember its proper name which was free entry but really interesting to see the development of Paris over the centuries. Loads and loads of shops, restaurants and people watching to keep you entertained for the full day.

Great Area to Spend the Afternoon. Not the Gay area I was expecting.. This is a great area of Paris to explore, but it has a reputation for being a gay neighborhood. In the afternoon, most gay bars are closed until 5 pm or later. We had hoped to meet some gay locals in the afternoon for recommendations for nighttime entertainment, but we just had to come back at night and follow the crowds.

Lively and buzzy area with lots of cool bars!. Strongly recommend this district of Paris - best to get lost here - there are a number of fun bars like Andy Wahloo and others plus great to have a crepe and coffee near the Pompadou Centre - very buzzy area

One of the must-see areas of Paris.. I was staying in a hotel near the Marais and I walked through the beautiful Place de Vosges each day, a calm oasis even when full of people, with plenty of park benches and cool fountains. I'm a lover of architecture so the buildings attracted me. The Marais contains restaurants, interesting shops and historical buildings, not far from the Seine, and is less frantic than the main tourist sights. Well worth a visit.
Well worth a wander!. This area has real atmosphere but feels less touristy than other areas.

Our Favorite Neighborhood. This was our first time spending nearly a day in Le Marais. This neighborhood boasts interesting architecture, beautiful park areas, small boutiques, and the Jewish quarter and delis that are very popular, like Micky's Deli.

not so great. Having read many reviews we headed to the Marais. It's very nice and it has character but it's limited to a few streets and a few shops. The nearby Place de la Bastille and Boulv. Beaumarchais are very lively and have nice bistrots.
Great neighborhood!. Trendy and old. One of the most beautiful places in Paris.

Definitely the best area to stay in Paris, busy and fun, but not too touristy. Just back from three days in Paris staying in a tiny studio apartment in Le Marais - a lively, well located district of Paris. Rue de Bretagne is a great place to buy fresh food, picnic food or to simply dine at one of the many excellent bistros. It is also close to the Bastille where markets are held each Thursday and Sunday mornings. The food is amazing - so fresh and tasty. It was worth getting an apartment so we could cook and eat this great produce.

The old Jewish quarter. I undertsand that this is the old jewish quarter and retains some of the mystique of that era. Full of winding streets and alleys. Great little bistors dotted throughout. Ate at a couple of memorable ones and forgot to get cards. I doubt we will ever be able to retrace our routes...
The Old Paris. Tranquil streets and local cafe's - the real Paris. The Place de Voges is a must see of elite housing.
Great Location to Stay. Many restaurants, close to Notre Dame...Metro...interesting merchants

The real Paris. This is the real Paris.Not crowed, small winding roads. This is the only medieval part of Paris witch was not demolished by Hausmann.You have to walk through it.Nice shops, cafés, brasseries and restaurants.You have the Picasso Museum, la place des Vosges. You are at walking distance from all the major central places: Louvre, Notre Dame, Centre Pompidou, the Seine river, the Bastille, …Plenty of hotels in the neighborhood.

Gorgeous, Quaint District. My favorite neighborhood in Paris - I could spend days here just wandering through the shops and sitting at the cafes. Some prefer the bustle of other areas, but this neighborhood was just the right mix of art galleries, markets, and cafes for me.
Great area for shopping and culture. This area had it all for me - fasinating small museums, chic and unusual fashion and jewellery shops. Great for exploring off the beaten track!
The BEST Neighborhood!. It's got it all, History, architecture, antiques shopping fun food and whatever you could possible want!
The area. Part of Jewish Paris which is a little Ashkenazi and Sephardi and ketsat Israeli.

Bike about tours. we spent a great day cycling around paris with a bike about viewing tour. went everywhere but loved the Marais. It felt like the heart of paris was here. we could easily have spent a day just drinking in the atmosphere. lots and lots of history too. well worth a visit .
Very interesting neighborhood for a stroll. Lot's of interesting cafes, boutiques, shawarma places, and bakeries to check out. It was quieter than the busy areas, and was fun to explore.

Le Marais. A wonderful neighborhood to visit while in Paris.
Artsy and a nice Jewish Deli.

Lovely. My favorite neighborhood to get lost in, and also to stay in. I always stay here if I can, and regret it if I don't. Great shops, restaurants, art galleries, people watching and the Centre Pompidou which always has the best exhibits.
Bohemia. I like the vibe in the Marais--bohemian and nice shops. eat at Chez Hanna on rue des rosiers. Picasso museum is within walking distance.
A lively ancient quarter. With its small and narrow streets, its museums, shops, restaurants and what-have-you, it is an area you can"t afford to miss.
