The most inclusive area in Paris. I love Marais - I go to Paris up to 2x per year and the Marais is a must do - favorite cafes and even starting to recall the waiters from time to time! Also superb shopping and of course - great people watching! :) Go Go Go, dont expect anything, just take in the atmosphere, sit down and be lazy!
Best part of paris. The marais is my favorite area of paris - wonderful shops- great bistros - colorful people watching - great cafes - check out the St. Paul area in the marais too!!
nice stroll. It's nice stroll through the narrow streets, and make sure you stop at Finkelstein for a traditional Yddish sweet or savoury snack.
Great place you have to visit. The friendlyness and special shops and great restaurants. Try Cafe Charlot corner Rue Beranger and Rue Charlot you will love it especially for breakfast

Interesting. This is a Jewish, and gay area, with very friendly people, a trendy place.If you can walk in the small streets , and not just the manin streets you can find beautifull shops, with unique things to buy, great little cafe's and not as expensive as other area's., If you are in Paris for at least a week, then take one day or half a day to spend it there.
lovely. lovely small parisian streets with beautifull litlle shps

Le Marais District was the perfect location for me.. I stayed in a small boutique hotel that was very comfortable and hospitable. My idea of fun and the way to get to know a city and its ways is to do it on foot. I walked easily to the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay, and Notre Dame to name a few. However, I did walk about 15 miles in a day....as a warning. There are buses and the metro too but in this trip I did not use them. I wish I had a better map of the city as there are many, many side streets that are not on maps but are well worth exploring. I'd suggest investing in a really good map.

Trendy and cool neighborhood!. Difficult to find a doll neighborhood in Paris! However the Marais stands out as the trendy spot with more locals then tourists. A great place to stroll around, dine and go out at night!This place is also a great for anyone who consider renting a vacation rental at low price while being able to walk to any landmark in Paris. Paris is a walkable city for anyone who is minimally in a good shape. It is the way to go since literally evry little street has something to offer to the eye! Make sure to carry a map however since streets have no logic in Paris.Enjoy!

Loved this arrondissement. Just beautiful, from cafe's to architecture you must spend a few hours strolling these sidewalks, Shop owners are friendly and welcoming. Always greet hello and be sure to say thank you / goodbye-this is the Parisian way. PS-if you like Falafel,,,you must get some here!!

Wild and still civil. If you are in for a bit of fun and excentricity this is the place to go. Grand it is too with all it's the big old houses (Hotels) and royal neighboring new posh areas with funny bars and avant-garde shops. Do not miss it.

Interesting. It is a Jewish Heritage location, but didn't seem very crowded when we went in August. I was suprised at the lack of things to do and see based on other on-line reviews. maybe I missed it? Still a nice area to walk around.
Great atmosphere squeezed in a little area. Small streets that are packed with little shops and brasseries. It can be a bit crowded from time to time, but worth going when in Paris.
Interesting neighbourhood. We enjoyed ambling around the streets. Nice little boulangerie and lots of working class folks.
Take time to walk the back lanes. If you enjoy walking as we do, set half a day apart and combine it with a visit to Notre Dame and nearby Shakespeare and Co. literary bookstore.

A sunday morning stroll. Really enjoyed the Marais, started with the Sunday market in Richard Lenoir and then wandered around for 4 hours. Had dinner at Mirabelles, recommended in Lonely Planet, excellent.
A little Bohemian for our tastes. Very crowded, busy and noisy area. Probably great if you want the night scene but if you need your rest (AKAover 30) probably not the best area.

Great area to walk around. Must visit the Place de Vosges here in the Marais- where the aristocratic French lived. This square is built around 9 brick houses in 4 sides. It is very symmetrical in appearance and arranged very orderly. Very quiet area to take a small break and just people watch. Lots of small shops to window shop around this area-- good to just wander around and sample the surroundings. You can't really get too lost in this area.

A really nice block. Le Marais is one of the oldest block of Paris. It is also one of the most trendy place with a lot of lovely food and clothes shops. This block is also famous because it is the old jewish district, you can visit the synagogue and the jewish museum. One of my advice is to taste the falafel, typic of this neighborhood !!
Place des Vosges. One of the most beautiful places in Paris. Visit the home of Victor Hugo. Walk around in the small streets and discover lots of designer stuff

Great mixture of Jewish tradional food and fashion. This neigborhood offers a great mixture of fashion, jewish taditional food and gay ambience. There are great Ice cream parleors, restaurants, fashion and book stores. Crowded in a good way with a great atmosphere.
Great shopping. Fantastic architecture and wonderful individual shops and some good traditional restaurants.First time I have encountered a gay/Jewish mix for an area.
Dont miss it!. Stayed here when we where in Paris and very much like the area, not to be missed!
Parisian architecture, fashion & beautiful cafe's.. Great gem in paris. Enjoyed the trendy shops, beautiful architecture and selection of cafe's. It's exactly what I imagined Paris to be like.
The Marais...my favorite area in Paris. Enjoyed walking in this area. Many cafes and boutiques. Fashionable young area.
The history...the Architecture!. All I can say is wow. One of the most beautiful areas in Paris. Walk around and soak it in.
Crowded and tourity. Too many chain shops and stores here. Don't see why so many love the Marais. It's not for me.
Fun area. A fun area to people watch and grab a drink in. It gets lively, especially at night.
Lovely neighborhood. Loved the diversity of the picturesque neighborhood. I stayed there for three days and walked miles.

Worth exploring. Le Marais, on the eastern side of the city centre, is well worth exploring. It's on a much smaller, more intimate scale than the grand boulevards and vast civic spaces, and crammed with interesting shops selling everything from Harley-Davidsons to telescopes. There is also a good selection of places to eat and drink.
An interesting and lively part of the city. Worth a visit! Nice restaurants and bars with reasonable prices. Also very interesting and international crowd.

French architecture at its best. The Place des Vosges is the gem of this district for sure. The lines are so clean, the balance of the whole square is perfect. This square should be kept under a glass bowl for eternity ! Through the small gate at one corner pass into the gardens of Palais de Sully to complete the experience and don't miss the 'Taupology' ! Do some smart shopping in the Village Saint Paul- several interconnected back yards with delightful artisan shops.
Quite nice!. This is a very nice area next to Les Halles. On my next visit I will definitely be visiting Marais again as I attend a show at Cafe de la Gare.
Great shopping, great restaurants. love everything about this area and it is very convenient to transportation.
liked the area. we really liked Le Marias in the 3e and 4e arrondissement. a great place to walk around and see the rich history of Paris
Full pof charm. Charming, alternative and very trendy neighborhood on the weekends, especially on Sunday. Wonderful thrift stores, thrift store special attention to the Vintage Bar

The only place in the world where being Gay in a non-issue. The only place in the world I've ever been to where being Gay is simply a non-issue. My hair is curly, your's is straight... issues between us because of this? Non! And neither is being another human in Paris. Extraodinary
A lovely area to wander throegh. The area is really interesting, with lots of funky art shops and galleries, nice bars and restaurants and good shops

Great area to wander around and shop. The Marais is a wonderful place to wander around in. There are a lot of smaller boutique shops that offer unique items. We bought several pieces for gifts at the Satellite and found a bookstore with Italian books, which my husband was looking for. The Place des Vosges is a nice place to sit and decompress. It's surrounded by plenty of restaurants and art galleries.

L'As Du Fallafel. Still the best fallafel in Paris, and possibly the best lunch option for a visiting vegetarian. It's a green fronted shop on the Rue des Rosiers and you may have to queue down the street. A young man comes and takes your order and your payment while you are waiting in the queue, then your food is ready by the time you reach the window. Delicious!

Great!. This was probably out favorite part of Paris. It's a coming area, and has plenty of boutiques, but also some museums, including one on the history of Paris. It used to be the old Jewish Quarter and still has a few Jewish stores.

Great area!. Excellent food, drink, and proximity to sight-seeing destinations. Relatively quiet neighbourhood at night, though there are still plenty of busy pubs. Use the bikes kiosks! They're a great way to see a lot in a short amount of time.

If you love jewellery.......... Great shopping area in general. I particularly love jewellery and there are a number of interesting little jewellery boutiques scattered throughout this area. One I particulary love is called UBU.
Probably very nice !. We went to explore the lovely old specialist shops around the medieval alleys and lanes. nobody told us they are ALL closed on a Monday but they are probably very nice.
Fabulous, this is the true Paris. Loved it, the people were lovely, the shops fantastic, this is the real Paris
Beautiful area. We had lunch at a lovely cafe. We enjoyed every moment of it.

Lively & buzzing. we stayed here & loved it, great restaurants, reasonably priced, great shopping, great Art & the liveliest atmosphere at night. We even went to a chocolate market! Also found the best breakfast ever for 8 euros. Place des Vosges was beautiful.
Mariage Freres. We went to find the shop of Mariage Freres to stock up on canles, incense and tea, we then found so much in this area that is individual and exciting.
NICE AREA. very sweet area and very good for shopping.....shame we went on a sunday : (
Lots of history. there is so much history in this area hiring a tour guide might be a good idea. Its also a good place to eat, many restaurants to choose from and the prices are good.

Love it!. This is my favorite area of Paris. I love Le Marais. Easy access to other parts of the city (across the Seine from the Latin Quarter, quick metro to Montmartre) and a short walk to many attractions too (the Louvre, Tuileries Garden, Il de la Cite). There are several pedestrian streets full of restaruants, shops, etc (Rue Lombards). We rent our apartments in Le Marais.

Fun area where the Jewish quarter meets the Gay Village and contemporary artists.. I like the cafes and little shops here. One of few places where shops are open on Sunday. I dislike the crowds on Sundays.
The best please to tour by walking.. If you like good Parisian streets this is the place to tour. Go in the small streets, the galieries and the resturants.

Perfect way to end our Parisien Adventure!. Le Marais is bustling with people on a Saturday. It is quaint and full of shops, restaurants and beautifully dressed people. We were staying in Chatelet so we were able to wander through Le Marais and end up in the Hotel De Ville area where we ended our Paris trip sitting in the modern fountain near the Pompidou Centre. It was such a nice contrast between old and new. The brightly coloured sculptures in the fountain versus the ancient church that served as its backdrop. We also were treated to a Michael Jackson impersonator. So grooving to the tunes in this lively and eclectic area of Paris was the prfect way to end our trip.
It is the place to be on Sunday afternoon.. Mobs on Sunday. Great atmosphere. Too many stores for temptation!

guided tour. we had a guide show us around this neighborhood on our first full day in Paris. It was a good introduction to the change in cultures. Many small restaurants and it borders the well known areas of the Seine, Notre Dame, and the left bank. It is a great walking area, plan at least half a day.
The perfect neighborhood to stroll on a sunny day. I love the fact that it is not touristy and full of people. It is quaint, calm and for me this is the real Paris :)

Victim of own success?. When I visited - or rather discovered - Le Marrais about 20 years ago it was still very much a local and unknown area. The advent of a local gay bar annex hotel brought a revival and seemed to have elevated the neighbourhood to a hip, design and fashionable part of Paris.When visiting on a Sunday in November 2011 we found the area to be packed, streets blocked to allow pedestrians to roam freely, and shops open to cater for a refined and wealthy audience.Le Marias is still a very lively, fun, original part to visit and has a lot of original stores even though the multinational chains stores start popping up, often indicating that the offering gets commoditised and commercialised to the max.Probably this is also best indicated by the fact that the original gay bar has dissapeared and turned into a perfume store. Is this good? Is this bad? I am not sure about the answer. What is does imply is that time goes by and the only constant is change...
excellent area. Realy enjoyed exploring the Marais. Should be a highlight on everyone's Parisian agenda.

A Great Area of Paris. The restaurant scene alone makes this worthwhile. The history and architecture are just additions to a unique place. Find a Bistro and grab a table outside and watch the world go by while enjoying great food. A wonderful place for a walk before or after dinner, very safe a enjoyable.
Great shopping & dining. Lots of independent, original shops, bars & restaurants to keep you occupied, but as it is Paris it will cost you!
Best boutique window shopping. Wonderful clothing boutiques, blocks and blocks. The men's clothing just as cool as the women's. Loved cruising up and down the mostly pedestrian dominated streets.
My favourite part of Paris. I love the village feel of Le Marais. There's always something to discover on the small streets that weave through this quaint neighborhood!
Artisan Paris. Nice area with lots of small shops. Bring a big wallet though.

Worth a wander. Colourful area, with bars, boutiques, delis, little public parks, galleries and fantastic craft and art shops. For a tasty lunch on a budget, look no further than the numerous falafel joints.
Shopping and night. Good shopping during daytime (Rue de ville Temple) and cozy and a good feeling in the night.

Interesting Old Paris. We walked extensively around Le Marais and enjoyed what seemed more the working heart of Paris with a little of eveything. Museums,cafes.shopping and everyday life going on around the tourists

The secret side of Paris. Forget the large tourist attractions like the Eiffel tower, take some time to walk the streets of Le Marais and discover hidden palaces and gardens in the cosy streets full of typical restaurants and novelty shops

a must see. Don't visit Paris and fail to see this area - gorgeous little area with small side streets littered with cafes, bars and patisseries. Has a real charm about it that beats anything the UK has to offer.

Wonderful Mixed Neighbourhood. Walk around and enjoy the neighbourhood, from the Jewish end to the GLBT side and there are wonderful shopping (including BHV) in the middle. Beautiful galleries and much more.
Best place in Paris.. Just walk thru Marais, watch people, eat at best bistro...
shops open on sunday. Ideal neighbourhood to visit on sunday. Lot's of nice restaurants and great shops. Great atmosphere, but can be very crowded!
J'taime le Marais!. Spend several afternoons walking around, eating, shopping, and just looking at everything. Then go back each evening and try a few restaurants and bars. Love, love, love.

Wonderful area for families and couples. I spent an afternoon wandering around the Marais. Here is a great variety of eateries, bars and shopping to see without the incredible tourist bustle of the main areas. Grab an ice cream at one of the gelaterias and take a walk down some of the back streets. A definite change of pace from the busier commercial areas along the Seine and Champes Elysees.
Fun neighborhood to walk around.. We liked the feel of this neighborhood. All of the Jewish shops and deli's, especially L'As - the felafel's were the best outside of Israel!

Wonderful shopping and dining opportunities. The Marais neighborhood of Paris is wonderful combination of shops (clothes, accessories, specialty items) and restaurants. You can easily spend a half day or more in this neighborhood. There are tempting patisseries and charcuteries mixed in with the cafes. There are plenty of kosher choices here, too.
An overlooked area of Paris. Great to wander the streets in this area and to relax in the Place de Vosges.
Map. place where you can get lost if you don't know the places to go
Paris at its best.. After visiting Centre Pompidou the best thing you can do is to take a walk in Marais. Find a good restaurant and enjoy life.

Charmed!. This was a part of Paris I had never visited before. Thanks to Kevi and Discover Walks I was charmed by the old pre-Haussman architecture, the secret little parks, trendy shopping streets and the beautiful Place de Vosges. Can't wait to some back and spend more time here!

True Paris. If you are staying in a hotel near the main attractions, expand your walks to Marais, especially in the evening the sidewalks are crowded with clubs, cafes and markets. We found the "kosher" street of Jewish delis and right down from that was the "best falafel in Paris" according the man out front. This is a fun, neighborhood, but be careful - don't take a big purse and keep that wallet close by.
Nice place for an afternoon stroll. Go there, nice and fun shops in a small streets full of character

Favorite area of Paris - heart of the city. A mix of people, shops, restaurants and nightlife in historic district. Le Marais is where the heart of Paris' gay neighborhood is located, as is the historic Jewish section. Great energy, fun people watching, don't miss this neighborhood.
Historic. Lots of characterful buildings and unique shops, well placed for central areas. We found a lot of the pavements were spoiled by dog fouling.

Don't Miss Le Marais. Loved exploring and walking around Le Marais. Took a terrific guided tour by Paris Walks of this district which has a fascinating history. Lots of great boutiques, galleries and restaurants.
Crowded and busy. Lots of people like this part of Paris. It is trendy and has many fashion boutiques. I prefer other, less crowded, fashionable parts of Paris to relax in.

Discover Walks. We did a walk in the Marais with Discover Walks. Very informative & interesting walk in the Marais area which is a very old part of Paris with aristocratic town houses, museums & galleries, a large Jewish population as well as trendy boutiques & shops.
The art of being a flaneur. Wander around, eat and you will find the Paris you've dreamed of. The best food, an amazing atmosphere, gorgeous little shops. It's the Paris of the movies.
If you like sth different... It is a great place to stay, but you have to bear in mind that is gay friendly...
Great atmosphere and buzz in the Marais.. Wonderful food markets on the weekend, great shops and a wide variety of cafes and bars. We love walking around the streets in this area.

Look-out for the excellent street-artists!. The areas was wonderful & was of historical interest too. But what really made me love this place was the street-artists! They were amazing! But be careful of the so-called artists who will try to make your portraits (which don't look like you) or a caricature! They are frauds! Also be aware of pick-pocketters.
Cute little shops, cafes, restaurants and small-gem museums. The neighborhood has been gentrified over the years and seems like mostly visited by locals which I like.
Soho. This gem is old Paris. It's the Jewish Quarter. Small streets, chic boutiques, bars, thrift shops, sidewalk cages. If you love the village in New York , then this is the best place Ever!
really parisian area. really parisian area with small roads, good bistro;s, low prices, galleries
Interesting neighborhood. a great area for walking and shopping, a lot of Parisians think so too and it gives one a taste of normal life in that city
Trendy. Do not miss the Place des Vosges, it is a beautiful plaza, full of art galleries and nice boutiques. The streets around are all interesting and full of life.
Exciting Area. We were surprised by what we discovered here from great falafel to the most interesting tea shop ever.

May well be the best Right Bank district. Ask any "Left Bank" Parisian, he whill look down upon any "Right Bank" district, which would lack charm to his eyes. The Marais could well be the exception however: very nice architecture, little traffic, great and varied food, lots of art galleries...This is where the Jewish district stands, around "Rue des rosiers". Plan accordingly for shopping, and do not miss Finkelsztajn for deli (their cheesecake in particular is fabulous).

The heart of Paris. Many good things have been written about le Marais , which led me to decide that this would be my base for my visit to Paris in July . It was a good decision and I would like to thank all those reviewers who led me to this wonderful place. Le Marais has many sights , sounds and smells to recommend it. From the grand Hotels ( mansions of an earlier era when French kings and artistocrats lived here), each with a history of its own, to the perfectly symmetrical Place des Vosges, interesting churches, great museums ( Picasso-- closed till spring 2013 --, Carnavalet, Cognacq-Jay, Museum of Jewish history, Parisian boutiques , cafes , restaurants and an infectious Parisian ambience, I left Le Marais with a heavy heart . It will , most likely , be my base for future visits to Paris.

Safe, quaint and clean.. We took a taxi which was not cheap helped us get us to the Hotel in the Marais quickly. Everything you will nee is with ten minutes from any starting point. If you enjoy diversity, safety and a sense of fun stay or visit this village withing a city. Reminded me of a cleaner and by far safer than Soho of London or the Village in Manhattan ( without slighting either!) I got the sense that people actually live and work there. Cafes, churches, museums, department stores and interesting architecure and lively bars everywhere. The Marais is not a mjor tourist destination for me. It is a cosy neighbourhood, which i was happy to return to after doing the major must see things in Paris.

Beautiful Section of Paris. we walked thru the Marais section of Paris, seeing the sights, smelling the food!!! - amazing deli - Schwartz deli --- typical NY fare... corned beef, pastrami, matzah ball soup... all of course with a french flair!! it was packed!! We also went to one of the several competing Falfel places --- it was an experience!! busy, bustling, and fun! getting your Falfel - we chose to eat outside and walk and enjoy the people.. quite fun. from there we headed to Picasso's home/ museam -- we did not know that it was CLOSED for another year.... but the Walk turned up some great gems, gardens, and a beautiful park .....enjoy!

Lively neighborhood with plenty to do. We stayed in Le Marais and found it to be the ideal base for our trip. One of us had been to Paris many times in the past and often wound up dining or shopping in the area, so recommended it for this visit. It's both central and the center of the action. There are many cafes, bars and stores to explore, as well as Centre Pompidou and many cinemas. It's also full of colorful, stylist Parisians, making it perfect for people watching.

an area not to be missed. this arrondissement had such a wonderful mix of history, charm, culture, and beauty. we walked around to view the numerous old grand residences(hotels) and then spent time browsing in the many trendy little boutiques. there were plenty of good cafes and patisseries and the kids loved it. definitely a great place to go with teenagers

A moveable feast.... If you are lucky enough to have lived in Paris as a young man, then wherever you go for the rest of your life, it stays with you, for Paris is a moveable feast. That is a quote from Ernest Hemingway in which I relate to… as it captures everything about my experience in Paris… for it was a moveable feast for all the senses. As a young person, it has remained a part of me, no matter where I am! After my time serving with the Peace Corps, I required a much needed holiday... I needed to retreat to a place that has always intrigued and inspired me. A place where I could write, play my violin, wear a scarf... and be myself. That place was Paris. In Paris...I could live life... not live at as a spectator looking-in... but as an actor looking out.  There are 20 neighborhoods of Paris. Each one with their own fabulous restaurants, souvenir shops, "Marlboro Red stenched" night clubs and pockets of quiet beauty... but for the sake of time, I can only share one neighborhood with you...Le Marais.  I chose to speak about Le Marais as it was the neighborhood where I spent the most time. I rented a wonderful, modern, fully-furnished loft there in a historic building built in the 19th century.  I would describe Le Marais to you all as an oasis of calm during the day… and an oasis to the night lovers. It is good for life seekers... bar hoppers... pastry lovers and foodies.  Speaking of food... Le Marais offered me a diverse selection of restaurants and cafes, from traditional French bistro fare to ethnic cuisine, all within walking distance from my apartment… I remember eating at at this restaurant called, "Le Petit Dakar." The people who worked there were so pleasant and I ate the best "yassa." Yassa is a famous Senegalese dish that has become popular throughout Western Africa. It comes with chicken that has been marinated for a long time in lemon juice served with couscous, onions, chile pepper, peanut oil, and seasoning. It is also eaten with your hands and it is cooked in a large pot over a flame. I also spent much time eating and drinking at Café Hugo. This Cafe is the "preferred" café on the Place des Vosges. Place des Vosges is the oldest and some say the most beautiful square in Paris. Its history and construction date all the way back to 1612. Café Hugo is a great place for meeting people or just sitting and sipping a Merlot and breathing second-hand some while watching the world go by. It’s a drinks only place... But for dessert…I loved “Le Petit Marché”… their chocolate mousse was a revelation...and their crème brulee was divine… for it was super decadent, dense, creamy, thick and made from goats milk. Two of the chief attractions in Le Marais are the Musée Picasso and the Musée Carnavalet.  The house where Musée Picasso is located was built between in the 1600s and it is considered to be one of the finest historic houses in the Marais. The museum has paintings, drawings, sculptures, prints, photographs, manuscripts, newspaper clippings and photographs. It was nice; however, I am more of an impressionist art admirer. Picasso doesn’t do much for me. I like Edgar Degas.  Now the Musée Carnavalet was spectacular. It had has thousands of paintings, drawings, engravings, photographs, sculptures, pieces of furniture, ceramics, decorations, reliefs, signs, and coins. To me, it is the second best museum...(of course) after the Louvre. I suppose my two most favorite items there was this long narrow canoe made from a single tree trunk that dated back long before Julius Caesar and all the paintings of the famous actors in the drama of the French Revolution. In the courtyard of this museum, there was this huge sculpture of Louis XIV, the Sun King to greet visitors. I can go on and on about Paris… when I wasn’t drinking or flirting or eating or at the museums or at the nightclubs, I did find time to write, play my violin, wear a scarf... and be myself. It was a moveable feast for all the senses. As a young person, it has remained a part of me, no matter where I am. Like Gertrude Stein Said… America may be my country… but Paris is my hometown.

Our favorite arrondissement in Paris. We loved this area and would probably stay here next time over St. Germaine and the Latin Quarter.Do try a meal at La Tartine - one of our best in Paris. Filled with locals and few to no tourists.Do visit the famous square where Victor Hugo lived. Discover the many streets. Try falafel here. Visit Pompidou Center for some strange and interesting art. Ugly building, but great views from the top!

Loved it!. Great area for shopping, people watching, eating, photography, history, art and wandering. This area has it all, from the bustling streets to the quiet alleyways. There's something to see around every corner. Great ethnic foods in this historically Jewish section of days passed and now food of all nations can be found here. Plaques throughout the area tell of the events here in the 1940's. This is an area to be enjoyed both day and night. Daytime activity of shoppers and merchants gives way to evenings of music and schmoozing over a glass of wine in one of the many sidewalk cafes. Spend some time here, anytime of day or night.

Shops and food. I really liked this area even though I only spent about 2 hours here. I walked through the pedestrians streets and shopped for reasonably priced clothes. It is also packed with food sellers from produce to bakeries and sweet shops.

Full of character. Le Marais is an old area in the heart of Paris. It is bustling with tourist but for a good reason, The streets are full of boutiques and classic restaurant. The buildings are old and beautiful and the whole district is full of real, old style Parisian atmosphere. Many gay cafes are located in this area.

An oasis in the middle of Paris. in both senses, an oasis of calm and an oasis to the night lovers, the good life seekers and the bars and pastisseries lovers, you can do all that you imagine in Le Marais, from see monumental areas as place vosges, an impressive square with old buildings and an huge garde in the middle, from having good night or day in one of the open mind bars that fill the quartier more liberal of all France. The buildings are old, the streets are calm, many alternative shops and boutiques very expensive some other less, lots of food and drink bars, and a short distance walking to the city center and main atrractions makes le marais in the most chic and trendy area now in the french capital.

Lovely. It is the perfect place to start a holiday. I love the smart shops and the restaurants, I love walking around at day and night. This little village in the hearth of Paris is one of my favourites places.

ditto. we spent a week on rue rambuteau and were very pleased.this is a great neighborhood - rent an apartment from one of the many on line services, get stuff for breakfast and snacks from one of the many grocery stores, download bus and metro maps from the RATP website (use the "get interactive service" feature) and spend time doing some tourist stuff and then sipping cafes outdoors watching the world go by.doesn't get any better than this!

falafels. If you visit Paris you have to go here to get some Falafels from the Jewish Quarter. Even if it is the only thing you do in this area. Even if you don't like Falafels. They are really really really good!!! There's loads of stands that sell them - just look for the one with the biggest line!

finally , real paris. take metro - line 1 and go there- stations hotel de ville or the next- saint paul- -you have everything in these area- the real old paris- shopping, markets , good ,cheap places to eat- you can finally see and hear french people, and not only tourists - is an amazing place . believe me

My favourate quarter in Paris. During my one-week-trip to Paris this quarter was the most interesting and beautiful spot in this city for me. You can experience a big influence of the jewish culture in this quarter. Probably you want to try some typical jewish food in one of the restaurants or at one of the takeaway shops. I liked its architecture and its small alleys. There are some pristine shops but also a lot of hip and modern shops. In addition there were not so many tourists like in other parts of Paris.

Charming, perfect location.. We stayed in the Marais for a week in a great 1 bedroom apartment over New Year 2006/07. We found it to be a charming neighborhod with lots of small boutiques, restaurants and great walking access to lots of areas of interest. You can walk to Notre Dame, The Left Bank, Pompidou, Hotel de Ville and the Louvre, just make sure you get a good Paris map to deal with the chaotic street lay out!

Paris in a nutshell. The Marais district sums up all that Paris is; a mixture of the modern & old world , both living comfortably together.Superb architecture,easy to get around on foot, very, very clean( Irish Tourist authority take note! ), and safe. Not necessarily expensive!Paris in general lives up to the hype in every respect. What i would give to live there.
